reviewText: This book surprised me from the beginning.  It was written differently compared to the previous two in the series, but that is not enough of a reason to dislike the final book unless you are a fan of continuity.  In retrospect, I can understand why the author chose to end the series this way, albeit it is slightly unexpected.

I know a lot of people were dissatisfied with the way the books ended, but I believe the author stayed true to all the characters personalities. Was it sad yes, but I still enjoyed the read and would recommend it to anyone.

I read Divergent in two days and Insurgent in one day. I pre-ordered this book and was over the moon when it arrived.  That feeling was to be short-lived.  The book is a departure from everything I loved about the first two in the series.  I actually felt at times that it was not written by the same author.This books is not captivating at all.  It took me five days to read because I kept putting it down because I simply DID. NOT. CARE. I didn't care what happened next, I didn't care who said what, or who did what, or what the big secret beyond the city was.*** SPOILER ***I felt ALL of these things long before Tris died.  I'm not a reader who will criticize an author simply because I didn't like how the story ended.  TRUE - I didn't like how it ended, but I didn't like how it started either.  There was SO MUCH drama and excitement at the end of the 2nd book and I thought that same sense would be immediately picked up in the 3rd, however Roth takes you on a 70 page rabbit trail that will have you tearing your hair out. These first pages were so repetitive and un-necessary, I'm certain they never would have made it past an editor if the first book hadn't already been turned into a movie.  The success of this franchise clearly affected good editing, as it often does in super-successful franchises (True Blood for instance).If I could only use one word to describe this book, it would be LACKLUSTER. All of my friends who have already read this one agree - HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT.  Do yourself a favor and get it on Kindle or borrow it - it's not worth $20 at the bookstore.
summary: Not on par with other two books - very disappointing

reviewText: A lot of people are upset about this book, and I understand, but it's just a book! I feel like many of the one star reviewers would go all Annie Wilkes and hold Veronica Roth hostage while forcing her to rewrite the finale of the series.I loved Divergent, but I don't think Insurgent or Allegiant came close to having as good of writing or imagination as the first. And I agree that there were unnecessary and unbelievable plot lines, as well as plot lines that went nowhere. Example: I thought the people in the Fringe would be more important, and I'm still confused about the point of Edith Prior.But in the end, I think that Mockingjay was much darker and sadder. Even though I walked away from The Hunger Games feeling empty and depressed, I still love the series. With Allegiant, I walked away feeling glad it was over and I most likely won't reread any of the trilogy.
summary: Worth reading just to get a conclusion...

reviewText: This is an amazing trilogy, the characters are so well developed and likable, I have referred this to many friends
I loved that Roth wrote this book from both Tris' perspective and Tobias' perspective.Also, as painful as it is to read, this was the perfect ending to this series.

I may one of the few but I really enjoyed this book.  No, it wasn't my favorite in the trilogy but I still really enjoyed it, enough to fly through it and give it a 5 star rating.  I felt the way Roth wrapped up the story stayed true to the theme through out the book. Yes there was more suffering, yes there was more death, yes there was more violence but that's how the first two books were.I enjoyed the varying view points (alternating chapters) of Tris and Tobias in this book.  No the first two weren't that way but this is a different kind of book.  Tris had made herself known in the first two books.  This last book is about the final chapter of Chicago and all the characters in the book, not only Tris.Lots of people didn't like the ending, I think it fit the feel of the books and the characters.  I think Roth did a great job answering lots of questions and tying up loose ends.  I hate books that leave me with unanswered questions at the end.  This book didn't do that.  I am not an author so I don't think I can critique Roth on her ending.  It's her story and she wrote it the way she felt the story should go.
summary: Great way to wrap up the story.

reviewText: Perhaps the most cynical book I have ever read. (Actually I skimmed it a lot as it was so awful.)It was obviously written to be a third in a series for the movies. Divergent was bought for film in manuscript and Insurgent and Allegiant were written on the go-go afterwards. TO MAKE MONEY by being sold as a movie series. Divergent could end where it does. The movie Divergent can stand on its own.When elementary school children write stories they pull rabbits out of a hat as they need them in their stories. This is what Roth does. All of a sudden she's got a vaccine for the simulation serum or injection. And this goes on and on and on.There is a lot of Edward/Bella fanfic out there, most of it very poor and that's where this one belongs. Roth cannot imagine a future world as she has no literary background despite going to Northwestern and taking Creative Writing there. So there goes another well thought of university biting the dust along with Harvard and Yale. (After all if Dubya can get a degree from them, what are they worth?)Roth is a young woman who is over educated, way over educated, for her intellectual ability. To think that this is what a college graduate from a major university writes like, well, what do the graduates write like from other colleges? This is another Summit/Summit cash cow like Twilight and Hunger Games. They have someone decent cast and direct the first one, then they bring in new screenwriters and hack directors - read not artists - and continue on. They promote by trotting the stars all over the world like trick ponies to sell the first one and drum up the slow burn. It is cynical, contemptuous, and a "rape" of the readers and viewers after the first film. Neil Burger made a very good film with a very good screenplay. Lots of editing to clean up the book. Insurgent and Allegiant won't come close with different people. The books  are a travesty of what it means to be a writer. Only Roberto Bolano helps now. He says that the trash is important to allow the excellent to be seen.
summary: Veronica Roth has only Contempt for Her Readers.

reviewText: As you know she is good at twisting stuff. I didn't want this to  end until the last page because she made me feel it was actually completed. I could read these again.
I loved Allegient! One of the best books I ever read. There is always a twist keeping you on your toes!

Allegiant is the final installment of the Divergent trilogy. It is the ending to a story filled with action, romance and extreme situations. I don’t believe that Veronica Roth did as well of a job with this book as she has done with her previous books. She rushed the story at times and at other times she made the story go slow. However, it is still filled with twist and turns throughout the book. The ending will shock everyone who has read the series. Also, throughout the story, Roth changes between Tris and Tobias’ point of views to give you a different perspective each chapter.The faction-based society that Tris Prior once lived in is now gone- broken by violence and power struggles and marked with hurt and betrayal. “It's strange how time can make a place shrink, make its strangeness ordinary” (Roth 387). When Tris is offered to explore the world outside of the limits, she is ready to go. However, Tris’ new reality is even more shocking than the one she left behind. Tris discovers new truths throughout the story. And once again, Tris battles to comprehend the difficulties of human nature while facing unbearable choices about bravery, allegiance, sacrifice, and love. Allegiant brings the Divergent series to a close while revealing secrets of the dystopian world.Out of the three books, Allegiant was not my favorite. Although Allegiant wasn’t my favorite I still enjoyed the story and all the action that happened in the book. I think Roth didn’t craft this story as well as she did the first two. The ending was completely shocking but understandable. Overall, I enjoyed Allegiant and the rest of the series.

The first two books were very good, but this one......not so much.  It was a waste of time and money.  She would  have been better off ending the story at the end of book two, rather than drag it on through a bad plot, loss of character personalitys as well as a horrible ending.

I am an already in love with the divergent trilogy and this leads up very well and i have so many feeling for this book (in s good way). But if u do read this book., make sure you read divergent and insurgent!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

In my humble opinion, Ms. Roth needs to think about what she may have caused and perhaps take responsibility and provide care for the overwhelming amount of seemingly deeply depressed readers in her fan base who appear, from their comments, to have been utterly devastated by her written word. As such, I suggest she should consider setting up a Trust Fund to pay for Mental Health Therapy for her seriously distressed readers. Regardless of whether she helps offset costs, I hope any reader who feels depression, deep sadness, and/or anxiety will consider going to see their Doctor to discuss these feelings. I hope these comments help!
summary: Ms. Roth should consider a Trust Fund to pay for Therapy!

reviewText: This book took a while to get into because of the shifting POVs between chapters. Then I did, and it was okay. I felt like the backstory of the Bureau was never explained enough for my liking.I also generally don't like it when two characters seem destined to end up together. Like in other teen-oriented dystopian novel series. But Tris dying was a total and complete letdown for me. I would rather them ended up together. Shifting the focus to Tobias after Tris's death told me that this series was about him the whole time, that Tris didn't matter so much. That was disappointing to me because I felt like Tris was a fantastically strong and flawed character that young women could look up to.
summary: Meh. Letdown in the final installment. SPOILERS!

reviewText: I think this book has a lot of action. I wish there was more books in the series and tris had not died.

After the end of Insurgent, I was pretty much on the seat of my pants wanting to know what would happen next and find out what was on the other side of the fence! It was something I’d been curious about since I read Divergent and they first started discussing it in passing. Well, my curiosity was finally satisfied, and I’m happy to say it was not at all what I was expecting.I also wasn’t expecting some of the twists & turns in Tris & Four’s relationship, but after Divergent it was clear that they’d always have their disagreements. I loved that because it makes their relationship seem more real. Relationships are not always easy, it’s not always flowers & picnics. People fight. Yes, the world as they know it is fracturing before they’re very eyes, and that is bound to put both of them on edge and make them more prone to fighting and disagreements. Major life tragedies can be very hard on couples. Imagine your country swallowed by civil war and finding out your whole world was a lie. That will put a strain on even the strongest bonds, I’m sure.While I loved seeing the continual evolvement of Tris & Four’s relationship, I didn’t love the supporting characters as much in this one. I found the supporting characters to be very well done in Divergent and outstanding in Insurgent, but there is just so much going on in the plot, the less awesome supporting cast is very easy to overlook.Speaking of the plot, the hardest thing in the world for me to read was that ending. I don’t even know the last time a book devastated me that much. Was it Laini Taylor’s Daughter of Smoke and Bone? Maybe. I think it might have been Melanie Rawn’s Skybowl. I was just so emotionally drained when I finished reading this one, it’s almost hard to read. You’ve been warned. Read with a box of tissues!

I have waited a long time for Allegiant to be released on October 22nd of this year. I read both Divergent and Insurgent in this series in January of 2013 and was, as is usual for me, frustrated that the third and final book in the series wasn't due to be released for some time. A reader's hell, right?While I did pick this book up soon after its release, I didn't pick it up on the first day. I waited about a week. I lurk on a few message boards now and again, and during the week that I waited to get my hot little hands on Allegiant I happened to come across some posts regarding the book from other readers who showed even less patience than I. I read those posts even though they clearly stated they contained spoilers.Now, I'm not going to post any spoilers here, but I will tell you that the majority of readers on that message board were quite disappointed with Allegiant. They didn't like where Veronica Roth took the story. People were killed that the readers felt should not have been. They felt Veronica Roth had completely changed the character of Four/Tobias. And generally, they were just dissatisfied.For me, Divergent was a five star book. I loved every minute of it. Insurgent, not so much. I felt it should have been able to stand alone and that it just didn't stand up to the standard set by Divergent. I still liked it, but I didn't love it like I loved Divergent.Allegiant falls somewhere in between Divergent and Insurgent for me. I really liked it. And actually, the more I think about it - I do love it. Maybe just a little less than Divergent.Anticipation is a funny thing. On the one hand, I couldn't wait to get Allegiant and begin reading it. I read 61% of it the first night. But then I stopped reading it. I read the remainder in drips and drabs over a two week period. "Abie, why on earth would you do that?" you might ask.Because I am perverse. Because I had waited so long for this book and knew it was the last in the trilogy. Because I didn't want to get to the end.But now I have gotten to the end, and I must say I disagree wholeheartedly with the people on that message board. I didn't find Allegiant disappointing at all. In fact, I think Veronica Roth got it right. Life is hard. Even harder in a post-apocalyptic world like the one in this series. Tris and Four go through a lot in this book and tragedy can take a toll. People die - even people you don't want to die. There are very few happy endings in reality, and I think Veronica did an excellent job of making this book realistic.Sometimes the story is what the story is. Readers often want happy endings, but happy endings aren't always realistic, and I love this book all the more - just the way it is.

Hmmmm....where to start.  I LOVED the first and second books.  I think the biggest reason I loved them was because of how strong and tough the characters of Tris and Four were.  SPOILER ALERT so don't read the rest if you haven't read the book.  I was devastated that the author killed off Tris.  I get that she was trying to turn her into a hero but she already was a hero.  It's really devastating to be so vested in the characters and storyline for so long and then have it just end that way.  I did think it was bittersweet with her ashes and how Tobias spread them but just way too depressing.  I thought Four/Tobias' character was weak in this book compared to the first two books.  Just my opinion but I'm disappointed in the final book.
summary: Disappointing finale to an otherwise great series

reviewText: Short Review:  Not great, but not nearly as bad Amazon Reviews would lead you to believe.  Overwhelmingly the negative reviews are complaining about the ending.  I am not going to blow the ending, but I thought it was fine.  It was not a happy ending, but it is a dystopian book, they are not supposed to have happy endings.  I do have a problem with a lack of coherence with the setting.  The size of the factions, the level of technology the actual geography (you can see O'Hare from the Hancock building on a clear day) are all problematic to the story telling.  But fiction books frequently have problems being fully coherent.  Similarly the writing as a bit flat.  But there are very good books that are intentionally written flat (The Handmaid's Tale by Margaret Atwood is a good dystopian example.)But when you mix all of the problems together it really shows.  It just was not as good as it should have been.  I wanted to love it.  But I just could not. But it was not nearly as bad as all of the 1 star reviews would lead you to believe.
summary: Not great, but not nearly as bad as the 1 star reviews suggest

reviewText: It was good but not as good as the first two... I felt she could have taken so many other directions and made it amazing. Instead it was a little bit of a let down. The major issue at the end that everyone hates doesn't bother me. But it seems like there are still questions left... but I don't care enough to want to find out. Again could have been still much better
I loved the first book, Divergent and was excited to dive into the second and final books.  However, I was left a little disappointed.
summary: The third book, not the best in the series

reviewText: I have read every book in this trilogy and they are all great.  The are must reads, plus they are making movies as well.

I have not read a book that shocked me in a really long time, this one did. I love it when I read a book and it makes me emotional, I had the tears flowing. There's not an age limit on this book. Yeah it's young adult but don't let that stop you from reading the series if you are over the "young adult" age. A new world and characters worth falling in love  with. I have to add that not all books are supposed to leave you feeling all fuzzy inside. Some books show little pieces of real life. There will always be that one time when not every character makes it to the end of the book.
summary: A book that stays with you.

reviewText: I don't know why everyone is so upset about the ending. I won't spoil it for you, but it does involve a large box of Kleenex. Anyway, as with the others in this series, it is very well written. This book was particularly slow in parts, but maybe it was just me. Either way, this is a fantastic series and I could sit here and grumble about the ending, but I won't. Do yourself a favor and read the series, you won't be sorry.
summary: It had to come to an end...

reviewText: Let me start of by saying I'm 38 years old and I still enjoyed this book. I read the Divergent after my 13 yr old told me about it, and loved it. I then read the Insurgent and went right into this book after reading that one. I love this series, but also found this one a bit of a heart break for me. I will try to write this review without spoiling any important plot points.First thing you will notice when reading this book is that it's from both Tris's/Tobias's perspectives. It took a little getting used to since the other books weren’t written in this manner. The story starts off exactly were the second left off. As the story moves along and they leave the compound the story hits a huge anticlimactic twist that was a bit disappointing at first, but I liked just fine as the story continued. Throughout this story it was nice to see how strong Tris became, especially compared to the second book. The ending of this story/series was just upsetting. I was truly upset and I shed a tear or 2 near the end. To me this is a testament the good writing and engrossing story of the series; because it was able evoke great sadness and also investment.Okay so still not giving away any plot twist but prepare yourself that many of your favorite characters from the first two books are not going to make it to the end of this book. Sadly a couple of my favorites did not. Their losses sometimes seemed to be for a good purpose, but others met a curious end. Some of my most hated characters made it through, but no one in this story makes it to the end unchanged or unaffected by the events of this story. I won't say anymore so I don't spoil the story for you.Finally I give this story 4 stars as I think that the story was good, but the end left some holes that should have been wrapped up. Also while fairytale endings are not always needed I liked the ending of the Hunger Games and something similar or even somewhat happy would have been nice here. At the end of the day it’s a good read but doesn't live up to the lofty expectations left by the first two books. Give it a read and find out for yourself what the book has to offer.
summary: Good read but Hated the ending

reviewText: Im glad I finished the trilogy. I couldn't put any of these books down. but I was a little disappointed in the way she ended the story.  I wished she would have ended it differently.

When I first discovered Divergent in summer 2013, I absolutely devoured it in under 24 hours. Thanks to Kindle magic, I grabbed Insurgent minutes later, likewise consuming it in two marathon reading sessions. I was hooked, and pre-ordered Allegiant on the spot. Several months later on release day, I downloaded Allegiant not long past midnight. It put me to sleep. Every time I'd start to read it, I just couldn't get into it.  I was baffled that an author whose work I couldn't put down I had become so meh about.And then it occurred to me--I was continually going back and forth to the chapter beginning to see who's POV I was reading again. Tris and Tobais are essentially characterized the same, and moreover, Tobias in Allegiant is nothing whatsoever like Four. The characters are just...flat.Add to that staid prose and a dull plot that employs Insane Troll Logic. It leaves you with a book where you can't really empathize with the cardboard characters, and a plot that leaves you saying, "Yeah, whatever."  I can forgive crappy plots when I am engaged emotionally with the characters. Sadly, I was not.I've seen a lot of other reviewers complain about the ending. I feel that was actually the strongest writing of the book. The middle just felt like a lot of filler to get to that end point. I suspect even Roth was bored for most of the book. It was when she let go of the convention of Chapter 1 Tris, Chapter 2 Tobias, Chapter 3 Tris...and just let the narrative flow from a single viewpoint for a while, that the prose was more compelling. It begs the question, is this a story that Roth WANTED to tell, or was it a novel Roth's publisher PUSHED her to tell because Trilogy=Box Office Capital? God forbid somebody in Hollywood tries to turn Allegiant into Parts 1 and 2 because there's barely enough compelling content there for a single story.
The book was very hard to start with, I couldn't really get into book three.  But it was a bittersweet to finish.

I know some people need happy endings. I don't I loved this book It has everything: intelligent plot, captivating characters, a perfect dystopian future yet hopeful for society in general even if the main character gets something unexpected.

A lot of people already wrote much details about the book, including spoilers so I am not going to go into details. However, I thought the book was well written and I enjoyed reading the trilogy ending, even if it did make me cry. I also enjoyed reading the story from both Tris' and Tobias' point of view. I feel like people are giving this book bad reviews just because they didn't like the ending.

Was one of the many who got sucked into the series with no idea that Veronica Roth is a moron. This book, the final installment in the Divergent series, will leave you wondering why you even bothered to waste your time on them at all. Ms Roth admits on her blog that she didn't even consider her fans when she wrote the final book, that she was only thinking of the story, which by the way wasn't good. This book is really not well written and has no real resolution. Also, on her blog, Ms Roth says that she understands we're upset but she couldn't please us all. Well.. erm.. if you want to sell a book, you better please the majority.
summary: Hopefully you didn't waste your time on the first two, but if you did, I highly suggest you make up your own ending.

reviewText: I signed on to Amazon the first day this book was released and I could not believe all the horrible reviews.  I did my best to understand why, but soon found out I could not read too much into any review, because of the dozens of unannounced spoilers half the reviewers threw out there.  I therefore figured the best thing would be to read all three at once and see how bad this book was.  In my opinion, this book was an excellent follow up to the first two, continuing the story line in a consistent but not obvious direction through the entire series.So I enjoyed it... It's only fiction... I've read Game of Thrones and it's A LOT darker than this one.  Wheel of Time... darker....  This story - A happy ending really, a story of a true hero....That's all I'll say.  Won't want to spoil it like lots of you whiny folks out there almost did it to me... PEACE
summary: I read the first 2 books again and I think this was an excellent way to end series

reviewText: All I can say is I'm SO glad I borrowed this book because I would have been beyond upset if I would have actually paid money to read it. I already feel like my time was wasted which is bad enough. The book read like a rough draft, at best. The story line was so confusing. It felt like one loooooong headache to read this book.First gripe: The back and forth narration by Tris and Tobias made no sense and totally confused me because they sounded the EXACT same. I had read a couple of the short stories from Four's perspective that have recently been released and really liked hearing Four's side of the story. With this, I felt like I got nothing out of the narrations. It was obviously done so the book could continue thru the whole story since crazy Ms. Roth killed off her narrator. But with both narrators doing the same thing all the time, I was completely confused.Second gripe: Descriptions of where characters were and what they were experiencing were totally glossed over. They travel to (or through?) The Fringe, and it was really tricky to understand the geography of, it's size, and even it's purpose, how it's governed and why it exists rather than just slummy parts of a city. No explanations and multiple visits there did nothing to enlighten me other than give a little background to where her mother came from.And that's another gripe: There was so much build up about Tris understanding her mother more, learning of her background and why she did what she did, and it was really for nothing. It never lead to a point or even provided a basis for Tris' reasoning. It was just an interesting activity for Tris to be engaged in. Had it been the thing that made the difference with David, or turned the tide because of what she learned, that would have meant something. This is one example of a storyline that just hung out in the air and then died because it went no where.I have more gripes but I've already spent enough of my valuable time on this book, not going to spend any more on this book or on the author's future books. She short-changed a ton of readers who got a bait-and-switch when they bought this book, she should not be rewarded with future book sales.
summary: Wish I could give this 0 stars

reviewText: Well, that was a surprise. So I give credit for the choice, I just have a couple of problems with it that involve consistency vs shock value but the reality is that I really didn't want that to happen because it makes me sad! And I get how subjective and whiny that is but man, I feel like I kind if wasted my investment in these books now. But I still have to give credit to Roth for making me invested in the first place even though I'm now mad at her. It's very frustrating. I might need a hug.
summary: Gutsy choice. good luck with the movie!

reviewText: I bought two copies so each of my teenage daughters could read at their own pace.  They would soak up the chapters and meet in the living room at certain intervals so they could discuss how much they loved it.  It must be a winner!
Slow at times but regardless an awesome and heartbreaking ending to an amazing trilogy! Definitely recommend to anyone who likes the Hunger Games!

Don't even read the first one-it's a trick!  I think the books contain sloppy, badly-planned writing.  I looked past it through the first two books because I became involved in the plot and liked the characters, but the last book is completely different and the ending made me realize that I wasted my time with all of them.
Too sad, I really love this book but it's too sad. I am literally crying right now and probably for days. Why?!

I wish this book made more sense, but it is sadly lacking in any.  The reasons for the "experiment" are weak at best.  It briefly explains some level genetic tampering that leads to a civil war, but does not explain about the rest of the world.  I find it hard to believe the survivors of the civil war aren't aware of even Canada when this is set in Chicago.  There is no record of wars prior to the genetic war?  I don't get this fringe thing.  Seems like people are living in huts but there are houses around?  The rest of this world is so well developed that this just seems a bit of a let down.  Also, I find it just hard to believe a person who commits an act of sabotage would be given the level of freedom that is granted in this book.  The characters just walk around unmonitored?  Seriously, they monitor a whole society but not a high security building?  Just seems unlikely.  I think it could have ended a bit happier too, but even if it did I wouldn't have given it any higher than 3 stars.  Most of the book is unbelievable at best.

Okay, I wish the ending had been different, but I don't feel let down. For example, I loved most of The Hunger Games, but partway through the 3rd book it just degenerated like the author ran out of time, and I felt ripped off by the ending, even though none of the mains died.Now as for Allegiant, it's sad, but I feel moved, not just let-down. Yes, all the series' pseudo-science is akin to magic. Yes, The Hunger Games was more epic.But this was a far better romance. Tobias and Tris do get proper character resolution (some of which was quite moving). I don't think it had to end that way, and I wish it hadn't been written that way, but it doesn't ruin the trilogy.I was not concerned by some of the things in negative reviews here. For example, that Roth starts switching POV between Tobias and Tris. Why shouldn't we see from his POV? It made it more interesting. Then again I think I like Tobias and his subplot better than Tris. I didn't notice the writing quality declining.Roth seems to be better at individual characters' perspectives than worldbuilding a premise for the society but this part didn't seem too convoluted.

I found the POV too hard to follow in this book. They were written in the same voice, so I found myself flipping back to remember who I was supposed to be listening to. The end...where to begin? I've never closed a book and thought, "no, that isn't how it ended." If a Gladiator type ending was wanted, it just wasn't written with enough poignancy or feeling. But I also think someone has to go through these type of things (i.e. complicated sacrifice and loss) to be able to effectively communicate them. It would be interesting to see how Ms. Roth would write the end as she gets older (and has children - understanding the true goal of a parents sacrifices for their children a bit more). But that's not really something she can control right now. It just isn't something I liked, agreed with or felt satisfied in reading. Sorry.
Action packed with a lot of interesting & heartbreaking moments. I really enjoyed the trilogy! I admit I cried at the end.

I LOVED the first book and even liked the second; they were great stories with good character development. But the third fell really flat. SPOILER...It felt a little forced and the characters just kind of....died, for no real apparent reason, unlike the first books. They just died and were forgotten. Four struggles with thinking he's broken, but you don't feel it. He quickly joins a rebellion, screws up, and Tris has a speedy struggle but, as expected, still loves him. Weak - yawn. Then Four goes back to Chicago to erase one of his parent's memories, but when he arrives he can't do it and instead gives his mom an ultimatum and she...just says yes. AND then his mom and dad meet for a truce and they all just so easily agree??? It's that easy!? Peace was so easily achieved with a simple and quick heart to heart? Lame! And yes, it sucked that Tris died and Four (and the rest of the readers) couldn't have his happen ending, but in the end, even if she lived, I would have still rated it a 2/3-star for all the other reasons. very disappointing. pretty dull. I had to read it just to finish out the trilogy, but felt pretty let down.
summary: The first book was great, the second ok, this one sadly sucked

reviewText: By far the worst book I have ever read. Poorly written and a horrible ending. I do not read for any other reason than to be entertained. This book was neither entertainer nor well written. If I want realism, I'll look in the mirror. reviewText: Just when you think you've endured as many pages of suffering and hurting as is possible to squeeze between the covers of a book, it gets worse.Allegiant is the long-awaited final book in the Divergent trilogy, a young adult series by author Veronica Roth. Without having to write the dreaded words "spoiler alert," let's just say that Roth spent a great deal of time torturing many of the characters that readers already suffered alongside in the first two books.Interestingly, part of the problem with this final installment was the amount of time it took to come to readers' bookshelves, a by-product of the spoiling nature of digital- and self-publishing. Where readers are growing more and more accustomed to the rapid release dates afforded by ebooks, having to wait for a traditionally published sequel--especially one whose title wasn't even released by the publisher until this fall, as if titles are now top secret--was not exactly agonizing, but more like irritating. In the time I've waited since first falling in love with Tris and Four and rooting for the factions and factionless alike, I've found twenty other authors that I like better, and just as many story lines and compelling characters to keep me entertained.Okay, fine...spoiler alert: I feel ripped off by the publishing industry over this book. I became a fan and a believer, only to spend two years of my life waiting for THIS ending to the series. Read at your own risk.
summary: I waited two years for THIS?

reviewText: Whenever a series that has been well-received reaches its concluding chapter, expectations run very high. The Divergent Trilogy, a series that started off readable and declined through the second two books, simultaneously disappoints and satisfies me with Allegiant. Some threads conclude well, but the author makes some very stupid choices in her conclusion.In the third book it is revealed (SPOILERS) that Chicago is actually an experiment run by the government. The reason is that years ago the government messed with people's genes to try to make them better and so they are trying to cure the problem of damaged genes. I don't pretend to be an expert on genetics, but it's pretty clear that Veronica Roth did little research on how all this works. I rolled with it, though, but the genetic damage concept brings up some other problems too.To me, something felt a little bit off through Allegiant. Tris and Tobias are away from the action in Chicago and instead spend their days moping around at the research base. This series has come so far from its initial plot from Divergent, and I'm not sure how much I like the bigger story. The series was stronger when it was focused on the revolution in the factions, not this more complex scientific plot. Genetic damage is treated as something that creates a rift in the social classes, which is a cool storyline, but the author does not know how to effectively use it. Trips to a poorer society outside the research base are wasted potential, and when the author attempts to go for a plot with gray characters, things end up black and white by the end.A major issue with Allegiant comes from a storytelling perspective since the author decided to include both Tris and Tobias are narrators this time around. Unfortunately, both characters narrate identically and I frequently had to look back to the beginning of the chapter to see who was narrating. This was a poor decision, and I personally would have limited Tobias' perspective to the last few chapters when (again, MAJOR SPOILERS) Tris dies.So what did I like in Allegiant? Some secondary characters, such as Christina and Peter, are given good endings to their stories. Uriah's death was the most affecting of the series, and the final few chapters are easily the strongest parts of the book. Whereas Caleb annoyed the crap out of me in Insurgent, the exchanges between Tris and Caleb at the end are surprisingly well-done. While I'm not sure Tris HAD to die for the story, I didn't anger me like it did for others.Overall, some parts of Allegiant were stronger than others. It suffers from the same blunt storytelling the first two books in the series did and some potentially interesting ideas being particularly shallow. I didn't hate it, but don't expect anything fantastic.
summary: The Concluding Book in the Divergent Trilogy is a Mixed Bag

reviewText: Part 1: My Short History with Divergent:I guess you can call me a fan of the Divergent series though I’m not quite as enthusiastic about it. Each book has been engrossing enough to keep my attention through to the end so I guess that’s something. I only tried the series out as it was recommended as a good replacement for The Hunger Games. Its definitely no Hunger Games, not even close, but Veronica Roth managed to carve out something great while capitalizing on the success of The Hunger Games. Despite having read the first two, I really had little intention of buying Allegiant until it released as a cheaper, paperback copy. That is, of course, until the large amount of negative reviews started flooding into Amazon. As a result of these Amazon Warrior Whiners’ actions, I accidentally had Allegiant’s ending spoiled for me by some reviewer who blurted out his dislikes without a spoiler warning. Wanting to know more about the ending and why people were so pissed off, I went and bought the ebook version of Allegiant. Here is my review.These following paragraphs will have no spoilers so feel free to read on if you want. I will put a spoiler warning when necessary.Part 2: My Review of Allegiant:I find the story to be just about as appealing as Divergent and Insurgent’s stories, or the little I remember of them anyway. I sold both copies soon after reading them. Having said that, it shares some misgivings with them as well. My big issue with this series seems to be the excessive, with emphasis on EXCESSIVE, use of love scenes between Four and Tris. Yeah, yeah I know they’re supposed to be dating and all, but really? Do we really need to read about them kissing every other page? Really? Maybe its cause I’m a guy and girls like this kind of stuff, I don’t know, but I find myself speed-reading through any passage that overdoes that crap.While first reading Divergent, I remember thinking that the idea of Factions and how each person in each faction was completely and totally committed to their way of life (being honest, being ‘dauntless’, being smart) was kind of stupid, unrealistic and totally against human nature, but Allegiant’s explanation for this was very, very cool.I’m no writing-virtuoso, but I can’t help thinking that some arguments between Tris and other passages in Allegiant  were ‘phoned in’ and sloppily written. Take for instance this; nearing the final conflict, it is revealed that someone very close to Tris volunteered to take part in something extremely dangerous, and despite just being made aware of this fact, 5 minutes later she’s undressing and making sweet YA love with someone. That particular section seemed very rushed. These areas are few and far between. And as you have no doubt heard about already, Roth chose to write this book from two perspectives, Four’s and Tris’. It mostly works out great but I occasionally found myself unable to remember whose perspective I was reading from. This actually happened more than I would’ve liked, but story context usually resolves it so it isn’t really that big of an issue for me.As for the much talked about, infamous ending of the final book of Veronica Roth’s Divergent series goes, I loved it. The way that particular moment played out could have definitely been better written as it felt like too cliche a way to die, but everything that took place afterward was great.Part 3: SPOILER WARNING: The following paragraphs will contain major story spoilers:In case you completely skipped the above warning, these paragraphs WILL contain spoilers:Well, that important character to die was.... Tris. Like I said, I thought the way David killed her was just so extremely cheesy. Even though he has her at gun-point, she runs to input the code, is shot but enters the code, is shot again and then with the last of her strength, she is able to press the green button. Then we’re treated to a nice vision she has of her mother who takes her up to heaven and blah blah blah. It was just ultra lame. That’s about the only thing I disliked about the ending. As I already said, the rest was awesome and emotional. It was almost as if Roth was trying to make the reader let go of someone precious to them by killing off Tris. After all, we spent two entire books and a large part of Allegiant reading from Tris’ perspective, and so we got to know her very personally, and to just have all of that snuffed out has got to suck and I guess some people just couldn’t handle it. Still though, this is one of the biggest fandom melt-downs I’ve ever seen.As for the complaints of Evelyn’s ‘sudden’ change at the end after Tobias’ ultimatum. I didn’t feel it was sudden at all and there were hints throughout the book that Evelyn cared more for Tobias than leading the Factionless. I thought her turn from Factionless leader to regular person was well-done.I honestly don’t understand why the ending has evoked such a giant negative response from fans. Its not like there was going to be a 4th book so killing off the main character doesn’t really hurt the overall series.
summary: Great book and great ending. Don't listen to all the whiners...

*** SPOILER ALERT***Allegiant, last book of the Divergent series, finishes the story of Tris and her friends as they try to save the experiment that is Chicago.Set in a post-apocalyptic version of the United States, Chicago has become an "experiment" city where the growth and perfecting of supposedly pure genes is falling apart due to inner turmoil and warring factions.I read a review before purchasing the book that expressed such disappointment and anger at the way the book ended. I stopped reading there as the rest of the review promised information I should read in the book and not in a review... I think that reviewer was disappointed because our heroine gives herself to save the people she loves. There is no happily ever after.Watching Catching Fire this weekend, and being an avid Hunger Games (books) fan, we saw the trailer for the Divergent. My husband commented that it looks like a Hunger Games knock-off, and in a way it is.Tris and Katniss share many of the same qualities, both books are placed after a war that ends the world as we know it, and both girls are heroines in their own rights. The similarities end there,Roth has created a different and wholly refreshing cast of characters who are truly developed and dimensional people. Unlike the Hunger Games, where the enemies are almost always enemies, Tris interacts with several people who are both good and bad. Roth does quite a lot to make this one of the main themes of the book; that we are, all of us, made up of both good and bad, and it's only the choices we make every day that make us evil or not.The prose of the Divergent series are also a tad more... prose-y than the Hunger Games. There are several paragraphs that are so beautifully written and express such emotion, particularly the parts that deal directly with Tris and her mother.I finished Allegiant last night, I cried when Tris gave herself for the greater good of her people. For me it was one of the most moving parts of the series and, though unexpected, not surprising as I learned to know Tris in the 1500+ pages of the three books together.That Tris is, like all 16 year old girls, and like all women, in need of her mother or missing her mother, was a theme in the book that resonated with me. That her mother comes to her in the end, and, well, here's what the book says:"Am I done yet?" I say, and I'm not sure if I actually say it or if I just think and she hears it."Yes," she says, her eyes bright with tears. "My dear child, you've done so well".I suppose you can find any theme in any book if you look hard enough, but there is also a Jesus theme to this book. Tris painted as the savior of the world, a girl who is special, who doesn't quite fit anywhere, and who ultimately sacrifices herself.Anyway, I'd recommend the books to fans of the Hunger Games precisely because this is NOT the Hunger Games, but is written in a similar style and has a similar storyline. It's really not better or worse than the Hunger Games, just different than. I like both series equally and would recommend both.

Hey Everyone, who's looking for an alternate ending?? Well check out Stephanie Ziel's alternate ending @ Addicted Readers: [...]Its was AMAZING!!! I wish Veronica Roth would of written an ending like that!!***UPDATED******REVIEW****ALLEGIANT, Oh, ALLEGIANT, how you failed me in so many ways!I went over every feeling, every thought, every emotion I had, be it good or bad. And after all that analyzing in my OWN opinion, I still came back with NOT being satisfied one bit with this Conclusion to my favorite series, or should I say "Used To Be My Favorite Series"?FIRST LET ME TALK ABOUT MY FEELINGS ON THE ENDING:WARNING A BUNCH OF SPOILERS:***READ AT YOUR OWN RISK***|||||||VI had this book spoiled for me before I started reading ALLEGIANT, so I went into it already knowing what was going to happen to Tris in the ending. I found out about it 2 days before I started reading, and I was an emotional wreck! My husband thought I was insane! But I was stunned, I really could not believe Tris was going to die. I had no idea, not even a little thought that it would happen to Tris. So when I did find out, I was shocked! I was in denial for the first couple hours until finally I couldn't take it anymore and I broke down and read some of the reviews! Then, I was FORCED to see the truth, Tris would in fact die!! UGH, I still get teary eyed when I think about it! I never would of thought Veronica would do that to Tris, and not just to Tris, but to her LOYAL FANS! Tris had so many near death experiences, especially in INSURGENT, when she battled with death, and wanting to die, but finally she had an eye opener and realized she did not want to die, and that she was more then a self sacficer. So that led me to believe Tris had all the near death experiences that she was going to have, boy was I wrong!!!I stand 100% behind MY Opinion, that this WAS THE WRONG WAY TO END THE DIVERGENT SERIES!!!AGAIN, MY OPINION!!!Veronica said that she had this ending planed from the very beginning of this series, and that it was the ONLY ending that she felt would do this series any justice! WHAT, NO, WRONG VERONICA! She said she felt having these characters end with a happy ending, holding hands, walking off into the sunset was fake and unbelievable. BUT wait, I came across an alternate ending to ALLEGIANT written by a Fan Fiction author Stephanie Ziel (POST HERE), and let me tell you, IT WAS AMAZING!!! And, NO, they did not have this sugarcoated happy ending like Veronica didn't want! They had a hard ending, that brought tears to my eyes, but still TRIS SURRIVED!!! And IN MY OPINION it was the BEST ENDING FOR THIS SERIES!!! If Veronica would of wrote this ending I think A LOT more people would of been more satisfied, including me!!Now, all that said, I was still very upset that Tris died. I thought it was the wrong move for Veronica to make. (I am NOT the only one who thought this, as of the date of this review, Amazon's has a 2.8 Rating, Not good, not good at all). BUT I wasn't just upset that Tris died, I didn't like the WAY Tris died! I thought Tris sacrificing herself and taking her brothers place in the Weapons Lab, was the worst way for Tris to go! I mean I get it, this book is about selflessness and forgiving, and all that blah, blah, blah, BUT if Veronica Roth was going to kill off the main protagonist she should of at least had her go out with a bang, in which she DEFINITELY did not!THESE ARE THE MANY OTHER REASONS I DID NOT LIKE ALLEGIANT:Okay, the ending was not my only problem with ALLEGIANT. My first issue was the alternate POV's. I HATED IT!! It irritated me to no end! UGH, it drove me insane!! I could not tell Tobias and Tris apart to save my life. Only way I was able to tell them apart was when I went back to the beginning chapter and read the heading of who's POV it was. If not for the heading with the name of who's chapter it was, I would of been lost and waiting until whoever POV it was, said the other persons name. But their voice was so similar, that at times I just wanted to put the book down and scream, yes it was that bad for me!!Another issue I had was Tobias! He was a totally different character from the first 2 books. I mean a different guy all together! ONE of the MANY reasons I LOVED Four was that he always had this sexy mysterious way about him, that just kept me wanting to know him more. And when I read he's POV in the Short Stories, I was in awe! I loved the tough, strong-willed, determined, guarded Four. And being in his mind was really such a treat! He had all these character traits that I loved so much in the Short Stories. So I was expecting to have the same in ALLEGIANT, but of course with more emotion because in the short stories he wasn't with Tris or in love. So I was curious to see how Four would react to being in love and having someone else to worry about besides himself. BUT WOW, what I got was A BIG FAT DISAPPOINTMENT!!!At times Four acted nave, like he was new too their world and all the plotting, scheming, betrayals, and death around him. It caused him many problems that he couldn't get out of! UGH, and he was WAY to trusting with the first pretty girl that feed him a load of crap! Since when did Tobias become so trusting with complete strangers that he was willing to go against everything he believed in? Not the Tobias I have grown to love and care deeply for!Another thing that changed in ALLEGIANT with the character traits, was that Tris became the strong, sure of herself girl, and Four was the weak, trusting and unsure of who and where he belonged guy. And that was not the Four I've come to love! Nope, this new and NOT improved Four in ALLEGIANT --SPOILER-- was so trusting, that it even cost Uriah his life!! I'm not saying it was directly Four's fault, because it wasn't. But if he would of trusted Tris and her judgment, and not trusted Nita, and went along with her insane plan, then the whole mission would of had to wait, then Uriah wouldn't of been standing where he was when it all happened! So again, if Four would of went with his heart instead of his quick impulse, then certain things wouldn't of happened. Which honestly, I felt some thing's happened with really no reasoning behind it. Like Uriah, what was the whole purpose of killing him off??? Really I would love to know, because I can't figure it out. Again, he was another one of my favorite characters that got killed off, FOR WHAT???? Four was just so annoying, and most of the time I couldn't' wait to get back to Tris's POV. But even Tris had her annoying chapters too! I felt the total opposite about all of this in the first 2 books! I LOVED pretty much everything about DIVERGENT & INSURGENT! But ALLLEGIANT just fell flat for me in SO MANY WAYS, so more reasons then what I'm putting in this review!!! If I listed all the reasons why I hated ALLEGIANT, then we would be here all day, because their is SO many! Seriously!Then the plot was so annoying, the whole what was outside of the fence was stupid, and definitely not what I was expecting! (I say that NOT in a good way) The GD's and GP's, was the worst idea Veronica has ever came up with! I was expecting something so unique and original from Veronica, because that's all she's ever given me! I kept waiting for the big BANG to happen when they went behind the boundaries of their city. I was hoping for a drawn out scary reason for them being horded off and locked away like dogs! But the whole Gene thing was just laughable! When I first found out the reasoning behind everything, I was just staring at the book, saying "What Did I Just Read? This Can Not Be It? Their HAS TO BE MORE"? I kept waiting for it all to be a big hoax's, but it wasn't, and I was let down for the hundredth time with this book! I just couldn't take it anymore. Then by the time I got to the ending, I just didn't have it in me to be mad, or upset, or cry anymore! I've had enough letdowns to last me a bookish lifetime just in this one book! And its SO HEARTBREAKING to feel this way about my favorite series!!!I honestly can not think of one thing that I liked about this book! As of the beginning of this review I was planning on giving this book 2 stars, but now that I voiced some, NOT even ALL of my issues on paper, I realized that their really wasn't anything I enjoyed in this last book! So I feel obligated to give this book 1 star! And oh, how that makes me feel terrible! I really, really, really, wanted to love this book! I did, I really did, but I just can't for all the reasons stated above, and more not stated! I can't stress enough how much I LOVED the first 2 books, DIVERGENT & INSURGENT, and I had such high hopes for ALLEGIANT, maybe too high, because I was let down HARD!! I just can't love this book, or even like it, and I can't give it more then a 1 star rating! And I've never given a 1 star rating, NEVER! At least until this book! SO it is really hard for me to give it this 1 star, but it really does deserve it, in MY OPINION!ON A FINAL NOTE:So, I will walk away from this series heartbroken, torn,lost, and unsure if I should ever put as much hope, faith and trust in another author the way I put forth in Veronica Roth! Will I read more of her books? I really don't know! She is such a skilled writer, that just took a big dive down in ALLEGIANT, but that does NOT make her any less of an author in my opinion. So I would hope Veronica would make ALLEGIANT a learning experience and learn from the many mistakes she made in this last book, and not make them again. So as of right now, who knows, depends on if I will ever feel inclined to pick up a book with Veronica Roth's name on the cover!So there you have it, what I hated the most about ALLEGIANT! What are you thoughts on ALLEGIANT?? Did you love it, hate it, didn't really care either way?? But for all of you who feel that ending was the last straw with ALLEGIANT, then please take a moment and check out this alternate ending I have on my blog, as it has definitely made me feel so much better and more complete to walk away from this series with brighter thoughts!

reviewText: I did not like Allegiant.  The writing wasn't good -- was Veronica's editor taking a nap? Do they already think she is so accomplished at this point that they don't need to read her work?  I don't know what the problem was, but the writing is really amateurish and sub-par... if this had been the first book, there would be , no accolades, no hysteria... no movie.The jumping back and forth between the viewpoints of Tris and Four is contrived.  I think Veronica got the idea to do it based on fan response to the way that she re-wrote some of the chapters from Four's viewpoint... but writing is all about decisions... the writers decisions... perhaps she is too young to realize that whimsical notions don't become classics.  I kept having to look back to see who was talking... the difference in viewpoint was not dramatic and served to be confusing rather than fresh, entertaining or insightful.I think there is a natural point in the book where she might have chosen to show Four's view of things -- and that could have been a better choice.Good writers take us on journeys that are not always happy, don't always end the way the want, etc.  This journey sometimes inspires hope, answers all our questions, and then sometimes it just doesn't... but in that case, a good writer has given you enough to consider that the story stays with you... you find yourself working out what happened... thinking over what the author was trying to say.  The journey "sticks with you" long after you finish reading.  The issue here is that there is no point of view; there is no message.  We may have been expecting that, but at the end of the day, the divergent series was a journey to nowhere... and that is why we are disappointed.I hope Veronica is surrounded by people that tell her the truth about this story.  I hope that she learns something about her writing, and I hope that her next novel is fantastic... I also hope that the movie producers take some liberties with the story line so that we don't have to sit through this (as written) on the big screen...

The final book in a trilogy is always going to be the most scrutinized, especially when it is the finale to a series that has been as beloved as Divergent.  As this is one of my very favorite stories, and some of my most beloved characters, I was anticipating this book more than any other this year.  I felt fully invested in what was going to happen and told myself that no matter what, I was going to trust Veronica Roth's vision.When I was thinking the other day about series endings, I actually found it hard to come up with ones that I felt were really and truly bad.  Why?  Because they're not my books and I think an author can end them however they see fit.  Roth was always up front in interviews that she's known how the series was going to end from day one and she laid the groundwork for that calculated ending right from the first page.  So, now that I'm seeing some quite vicious reviews of Allegiant, I would encourage readers to 1) absolutely not post spoilers in reviews so the ending isn't ruined for others and 2) to remember that the only person who knows the fate of this world is the author.  If you're not happy with it, that's why God invented fanfiction.My biggest question going into Allegiant was this -  what's on the other side of the fence?  Roth gives us the full, detailed explanation fairly early on.  It was similar to what I was thinking/hoping, albeit more complicated and planned out.  It was a good combination of psychological and scientific and felt in line with the rest of the world we'd been given.  The reader learns some interesting information about the history of the US and also about Tris' mother, Natalie.  What Tris and crew learn about what's beyond the walls of the city ultimately sets the final conflict into motion.  Roth, as she has over the entire series, brings up some very difficult questions and themes.  I found myself pondering things like how society divides itself, nature vs. nurture, how we manipulate each other for both good and bad, why we make sacrifices, trust in others and in ourselves, science and taking knowledge too far, etc etc etc.  Even though Allegiant is a very long book, I felt like Roth covered a lot of ground in a small space.  Everything - plot lines, characters, symbols - felt purposeful.  I'm finding it hard to believe there are readers who think Roth didn't know what she was doing because, despite some small missteps, the choices she made as a writer were quite calculated.In terms of things I wasn't pleased with, they were minor.  The world-building has been a complaint with readers and while it's never bothered me before, I did feel like there's a bit of an info dump in the first half when Roth explains what's been going on outside the walls.  Not sure how else she could have done it though, so there's that.  Also, the chapters alternate POV's between Tris and Tobias.  I think this was absolutely necessary to get the full picture of what was happening.  But, especially at the beginning, the voices did not feel as distinct as they might have.The best part in my experience with this series has been the relationship between Tris and Tobias, as well as their individual journeys.  In Insurgent, Tris was the neurotic mess and Tobias called her out on it.  In Allegiant, Tobias is the basket case, which was so fascinating for me to read.  I'm such a psychology person and seeing how Tobias' worldview changed as new information was added completely reeled me in.  I think that Allegiant, like Insurgent, is also a grief book, but in a different way.  Tris was dealing with the death of her parents, and now Tobias, and everyone else, is dealing with the loss of an idea, a lifestyle.  And sometimes the consequences of that are even greater.  I loved seeing Tobias come to terms with the changes in his life, trying to reconcile his feelings about his parents, and the choices he made because of those things.  I've always felt that the romance was realistic - actual people have arguments and work through then, shocking! - and appreciated that although the setting was extraordinary, the conversations and feelings and hiccups along the way for Tris and Tobias were not.And then there's the ending.  If I think about the actions of the characters throughout the series, who they are as people, what they value and what they've overcome, the choices Roth made in how to conclude this novel are not surprising at all.  I understand that lots of readers are feeling entitled and upset about those choices, but not me.  I am but one reviewer, but it all makes total sense in my mind and I applaud Veronica Roth for being brave and doing what she knew was right.  After all, she's the author.4.5/5 for Allegiant, a huge 5/5 for the whole series.A gigantic thank you to Veronica Roth for giving me what has been one of the best reading experiences.  I love these characters, will always love them, and I am so grateful.

I'm not even sure where to start. I love reading. I love it. I look hard for books that I really enjoy and when I find a series I enjoy, I can reread them again and again, still enjoying them as much or more each time. I read the Harry Potter series ~10 times. I read the Ender series ~3 times. I read Hunger Games series ~4 times. I understand the necessity sometimes in killing off important characters, whether to make the story more real, more believable, or to portray some kind of moral lesson, or whatever. I get that. I'm used to reading books that have parts that make me cry.This book is different.First of all, I LOVED Divergent. The story was so awesome, I want to read more and more of that world. Then Insurgent, such a tough book! So much action, I was on the edge of my seat and tense for basically the ENTIRE book. A book has never been so gripping for me, and I've read a lot. I was thoroughly impressed.Then came Allegiant...I was disappointed in the story at first. When they go outside of the city and figure out the truth of everything. I felt let down, like it was too ordinary or forced. Like, "This is it? This is the big secret?" Then the fact that she switched chapters between Tris and Tobias. She made them so similar that I had to keep checking the chapter title to see who I was reading about. And that was disappointing. Before this book, I liked Tobias a lot more. He was unique. Showing his thoughts just made him practically identical to Tris, but also showed his incredibly stupid judgment, which I felt didn't add anything good to the book. It just made me disappointed in a character I had revered before.But I liked the world she had created, and I loved the characters anyway from reading the first two books, and I felt that she would end the series strong, as the entire story so far had been, minus the "outside world" letdown had been so strong and unique.*****SPOILERS******But then, she just made the ending stupid. I've honestly never cried so long and hard for a book, nor have I been so disappointed, depressed, and betrayed. You don't kill the heroine. I've read her reasons why she did it in interviews. Because of the theme of selflessness and self-discovery and how Tris finally "knows who she is." and you know what? I think that she could have accomplished the same lesson if she had let Tris live. Tris did sacrifice herself for her brother out of love. She did go through the death serum. She nearly died. But she didn't have to actually die. The sacrifice element was already there. She already created the scenario. Tris made her choice. That was the important part. And I thought it was stupid. Just when she finally valued her life, and realized the right reasons for being selfless, she was just going to die? After all of that self discovery and all that she had been through? All she had done and learned and seen? Just die?I've NEVER felt this way about a book series before. Good job, Veronica Roth, you made the series memorable and you certainly stuck out. I'll never read this series or anything by her again. Because I know that after I get committed to a story and their characters, there will be a blow like that one, and it's really not worth it for me. I know some people think it's cool that she had the courage to write that and she doesn't care about her readers, just her story...whatever. I didn't take away anything good from that ending. I don't think it was a good ending for Tris either. She was a strong character, dying was an out in the story, wasn't it? That's why Peter wanted to take the memory serum, why Tris had wanted to die so much in earlier books, why Caleb volunteered for the task. Tris didn't go for it as an out, but that's all it became, just some painful stupid ending that ruined the entire series.

The reason that I love dystopian novels is the idea that amazing, unbelievable, out-of-this world events can occur.  This is why I fell in love with the Divergent series.  It’s set in a world that I can comprehend, but in a time far away.  It has characters that are complex, but relatable.  It was truly a wonderful experience to follow Tris through her world.  To literally lose track of time.  The best part of any trilogy is the fact that, as a reader, you can continue to experience the world that the characters live in even after the first part of their story ends.  I hate when a story ends and you have to say goodbye to the characters.  This is why I was so excited that shortly after I discovered the first book in the series (and promptly devoured it…as well as the second) I learned of the third.  Now, I waited to purchase Allegiant until I knew I would have time to devote to it.  I knew if it was anything like the first two, I would be reading nonstop to the end.  I spent two days of stolen moments with Tris, Tobias and all the new developments of the world outside the fence.  There were periods of heart-pounding (and I do mean that literally, chapters 48&49) excitement, but also too much time spent on tertiary, one dimensional characters.  I think I can agree with other reviewers when they say that the back and forth narration was a bit confusing.  In the first two novels Tris and Tobias had such distinct voices, this one fell short.  I had a hard time distinguishing them and neither character grew past what I had already experienced.  In fact, in my opinion, Tobias took a huge step back and Tris finally succeeded in becoming a martyr.I read recently that Veronica Roth felt that the death of Tris was a natural progression of the character; she had escaped death so many times before, she could not do it again.  I have to respectfully disagree.  The reason dystopian stories are so wonderful is that the impossible is possible! After the chapter where Tris gets shot, I continued on in disbelief, comforted by the fact that she would be alright, she would find Tobias again, and they would survive the tyranny they worked so hard to overcome.  Imagine my utter disappointment when she actually dies…I was devastated.  She escaped the Death Serum, something no other character, apparently, could do…and then dies because she is shot…lame. Perhaps my expectations were too high or misplaced.  I can say for sure that I was truly disappointed at the end of what could have been a great story.

reviewText: There is a lot of good in this book. There is also a decent amount of bad.The good: The development of the characters continues here. We see Tobias (Four) start to fall apart a bit under the pressure. He's not dealing well with the world they find outside the wall, or the continued conflict inside it. I know a lot of people don't like this breakdown his character has, how much of a change it is from the other books, but I still feel like it's a definite realistic portrayal of someone being put under that kind of stress. Not many people do well with such things.The world outside the wall is interesting, if a bit cliche in places. The overall plot about why the cities exist is also interesting, though it requires a great deal of suspension of disbelief. Still, none of this bothered me. It's dystopian fiction. Suspension of disbelief comes with the territory.The ending...I commend the author for being so ballsy and making it stick. That's all I'm going to say on that. Love her or hate her or it, it was one heck of an ending and true to the characters. I'm not going to talk about the ending because it really can't be done without spoilers, but I felt it gave us further insight into a lot of the main characters and was very well done.The bad: The switching points of view. Ugh. What on earth made her decide to add this to the final book? I often found myself having to check whose viewpoint I was in, at various points of the book because it was hard to keep straight at times. I really didn't like that. At times things dragged, and it felt like various aspects of the outside were shown just to go 'hey look how bad the bad guys are'. Plans made by the characters felt overly complicated and contrived at times, as well.Overall a worthy end to a very good series. Would have been a solid four stars without the viewpoint switching. As it stands, probably a 3.5 stars for me.
summary: Allegiant - Be Brave and suspend disbelief a lot

I could spend years writing down my thoughts and feelings (so many feelings!) about Allegiant but I'll just give my main thoughts.No major spoilersI'd seen a lot of reviews from people saying how this is such a bad book and how they hated the ending and you shouldn't even read Allegiant and just make up your own ending. But I don't feel like any of those things are true. I feel like those are all things from people who didn't get what they wanted and are just bitter.There's not denying that Veronica Roth is a wonderful writer. One of the best. She's created something that millions of people have opened their hearts and book selves to. And that's something special. The choices and decisions she made when writing Allegaint are really brave and while Allegaint didn't leave me happy and singing songs about love, I feel like Allegiant has made it's mark on me and I won't be forgetting it any time soon (or ever).Allegiant gets right to the point, right away, from page one. And it doesn't slow down until the end.I really liked the pace.Of course the characters are great. If your reading this review, I'm going to go out on a limb and say you've already read the other two books in the series.Roth makes a lot of big moves before page 100. Moves I haven't seen from a writer since J.K Rowling. Roth and Rowling are almost two of the same.I feel like Roth really has created a world that is believable and realistic. In the real world, not all the good guys are going to make it. No matter how much you love someone, they can still die.I like how Roth really explored what happened in the past that created the world that up this series. We get to learn a lot more about what led up to the Fractions and what happened to the US.The one thing I didn't like was the scientific reason behind why people are Divergent. I think what really appealed to a lot of people about this series is how anyone can be Divergent. How anyone can be brave, smart, honest, and selfless. But the reasoning that being Divergent is just in your DNA, it kinda messes up the whole concept of the series, in my opinion.Overall, I feel like this is a really good ending to this series. I still feel a little shell shocked from the whole book (I read the whole thing in 24 hours. And it has 526 pages). One of the things that proves that a work of fiction is great (to me) is when, at some point, it makes me cry.If it can bring that out of me, it means it made an impact one me. And Allegiant made an impact on me, more then once.All I can say is, you might not like the ending of this series or you might like it. I don't know and I can't say for sure how everyone is going to feel. But if you start reading with an open mind like I did, you'll make it though this roller coaster.

Nearly everyone I’ve talked with who have read the Divergent series has complained about how awful Allegiant is.  They say that Divergent was amazing, but Insurgent and Allegiant spiraled into a meaningless mess of chaos.  (Okay, maybe not in so many words, but you get the idea.)Well, I’m going to break that mold.I liked the book.Simple as that.  I didn’t LOVE it, but I didn’t HATE it.  It was definitely a slower read than the first two, but that’s all right.  Sometimes, a slow read is better – the reader has more time to absorb the author’s intended feeling and message for the book.  In fact, in some very minute ways, I liked Allegiant better than Divergent.  For instance, maybe I was just desensitized to it by now in the series, but it seemed to have less touching/kissing in it overall.  Perhaps the protagonist just wasn’t as terrified by the aspect of a relationship, so she wasn’t hypersensitive to the touching; therefore it was written in a more natural way for readers.  Maybe; that’s just a theory.One thing that I did really appreciate about Allegiant was the setting.  Finally, Roth was breaking out of the “the city” setting and showing us more of the world.  While reading Divergent and Insurgent, I consistently had a nagging feeling of claustrophobia.  It was just so unnatural for the setting to be focused in one city, and for that city to be the only place ever talked about.  I don’t mind reading books that are set in only one city, but at least the author mentions that it is part of a country; there are other cities nearby, other countries in the world, etc.  In Divergent and Insurgent, it was just “the city.”  This bothered me, so I was very relieved when I read Allegiant, and finally it broke out of the city, expanded its setting, and answered all my questions.  I also realized that Roth had intended to give the feeling of claustrophobia to readers in the first two books – which she definitely accomplished.  As a writer myself, I can’t help but smile at how she manipulated my reading experience.  Well done, Ms. Roth.I’ve also heard people mentioning that they hated the ending, and they cried for days after finishing the book.Not me.I felt like the ending was satisfactory.  No, it was not a happily-ever-after, but it was realistic.  Realism is missing from so many stories nowadays; the ending to Allegiant was actually refreshing, in a way.  They had gone through so much – flirted with death so often – that someone had to die.  It wouldn’t be realistic if no one had.  I also believe that Roth chose the right character to die – if it had been anyone else, the impact wouldn’t have been there, and I believe the effect left by the death was good – healthy, even.  In life, people die.  People suffer.  People move on, slowly but surely.  It was sad, yet real.  I appreciate that.All in all, the Divergent Series was good.  I have a few bones to pick with each book – a few things I don’t care for in each – but overall, I like the story and the characters.  It’s not necessarily a favorite series; I like Hunger Games and other series more, but it was all right.

One would think that by the final book in a trilogy, there is not much left that could surprise a reader. But Allegiant manages to do just that. Veronica Roth is a risk-taker, throwing twists, and surprises, and heartbreaks throughout this final installment of a wonderful YA dystopian trilogy.Readers are rewarded with answers - what lies beyond the walls of crumbling Chicago, what does it mean to be Divergent like Tris? - and readers and characters alike are challenged as author Roth ups the emotional ante.Those who have read the first two books will need no convincing to dive into Allegiant which wraps up Tris and Four's story in a satisfying, if not neat-and-tidy, way.

I won't bore you with all the reasons I think the book wasn't up to Roth's other two.  Other reviewers have more than covered it. Couldn't Tris have been shot and paralyzed and that scene with the ziplining? Tris could lose something and they could gain something at the same time? Like love?And while I"m on a roll...it would have been WAY more realistic for FOUR's mother to meet with the Father, shoot him, and then down the memory serum...how poetic would that have been?  Eliminate the problem and then forget your guilt?  That's flawed and human.  Oh and in a perfect world...the person who would have pulled Tris out of harm's way so she didn't DIE and died himself would have been Peter.  Talk about a redemption story.Ok I'll stop.  Point is...we can say it's realistic that Tris died..but...it's also realistic for damaged, flawed people to live and learn something in the process...and Tris should have lived...
