reviewText: Here is the perfect recipe to ruin a trilogy, an upcoming movie and possibly you entire carrer:1. Write Divegent: make your readers fall in love with your characters, add mistery to the romance, make a skinny girl tough and strong.2. Write Insurgent: Make the girl a little depressed and edgy, make her reckless and unstable, add some fights to the romance. Make your readers want to slap the protagonist in the face for so many bad choices. Fix it all at the end thanks to the guy and its never-ending forgiveness.3. Write Allegiant: Lose the interest in your own story, stop caring if you are developing a good book, just worry about senseless "impact" no matter what, lose you mind and be willing to lose your readers. Then close your eyes and type meaningless sentences without stopping to see what you've done.SPOILERS AHEAD!!Veronica Roth impressed me at first. Such a young author! she created the first two books that are far from being perfect but I got to care and felt fond to the characters. I love the misterious Tobias, never knowing what he really thought and always seeing him be the strongest, most reliable one. After Insurgent I thought we were done with the bad decisions and that the non-developing relationship of Tris and Tobias would finally go somewhere. After their last lines in Insurgent, when the trust was back, I thought that we were now going to see serious development in characters and in the romance... Alligent was extremely desappointing at this and every other single level, and did not bring the so-needed closure and sense to this repetitive story (how many times have they go through revolution and secret agendas?).So many things went wrong! 1)The two POV's were absolutely confusing, there was not difference between Tris' and Tobias' language or way of thinking. I got lost so many times in which one was narrating. Instead of either preserving the Mistery about Tobias or actually discovering a brilliant mind, we only saw Tobias as an extension of Tris's mind. 2)Divergence, actually ment nothing! for two books we got to believe that being Divergent ment that you were special, and that you had some power or skill that made you unique. Now it just means nothing,it didn't even made a difference when Tobias was no longer in that category. 3)Peter was unnecessarily pushed into the book for nor reason. his character never brought anything to the story, just dead weight. 4) Tobias turns into a 12 year old, yelling at everyone and making all the bad decision as possible. At least in Insurgent he had a good motive. But in Alligent he is driven only by his pride and desperation. Not the Four we all know and love.But by far, the worst thing of all is the senseless, unnecessary and very predictable dead of Tris. By the time I realized that this book had 2 POV's it was obvious that Tris would not survive. Ms. Roth, how could you kill your main character when half of your book was and is still in need of conclusion? Tris got to die only to add shock value to the book but it was done in a bad way. It made the full trilogy meaningless and absurd. Real impact would have been that Caleb was the actual unselfish one and at the end decided to do the right thing (Remember Prim Everdeen??). Tris should have survived so all the loses and gains were worth it. Let her live through it and make a real statement of reallity and mending each other, so we had the chance to actually see the story conclude with an actual character and romance development. (Just as Moking Jay did at the very end). And after Tris got killed in the most unoriginal  way (gunshots?? Really?? after surviving death serum?) we are left to see Tobias struggle and suffer and never recovering from his lost. This was heartbreaking and painfull. We don't want to see our beloved characters suffer for no reason and with no sight of hope.And as if this was not enough, Tobias, our brave, strong, misterious, reliable Four, became a politician??!! You have to be kidding me!! the thing he and Tris hated the most? the same as Marcus? this was absolutely ridiculous!Ms. Roth, you tried to make the story real, but instead you made so many unrealistic turns (unrealistic to the characters)and so many absurd outcomes that I have lost my entire faith in this trilogy and in any future book written by you for that matter. We already have enough tragedy in the real world, no need to bring that to our faces in a book. And certanly not in this way! You could have done a great final book, a remarcable one. One that we would never forget, but instead decided to go exactly the other way and now me and other readers will spend our energy in trying to forget this tragic, horrible and insensate ending. I wish I had some memory serum.I just hope I can have a refund. I will buy a notebook and a pencil and write my own ending. At least that will keep me from hating the entire series for ever.
summary: If you love Divergent and Insurgent, Don't read this tragic final book!!!

reviewText: After waiting almost breathless for several months for this to release, I devoured Allegiant in a few hours...and it left me hollow.No, I wasn't expecting a Happy Ever After. But, after spending two book building up great characters and developing interesting plot lines this book just watered them down, tied them up in a neat bow, and offered up an easy ending. I cried, yes. Not because of the what happened at the end, but because the story didn't deliver on its promises and I'm left unfulfilled.Where is the kick-ass, confident, risk taking from solid gut instinct, Tris that I grew to love?Another reviewer nailed it: this is just another version of Divergent--only not as interesting. Do yourself a favour and don't read this book. Make up your own ending, it's bound to be better. :/
summary: Watered down Divergent plot line. Make your own ending up--it'll be better.

reviewText: I won't go into any details or spoilers. I get not making every story end all happy-mushy-goo-goo. The end of the trilogy told us about changes, growth, and love. And that life happens....bad things happen along with the good, but life continues. The beginning of the story was pretty slow though. Very little happened for like half the book. When it finally picked up, it was pretty good; but I kept getting confused whether I was reading through Tris or Tobias. (Any time I had to close the book and come back to it) It was tough to get used to that, after the first 2 books being all from Tris' s point of view. All in all, a really good trilogy. I'm going to go off the deep end and actually say, I loved the entire series and even the last book. Veronica Roth tied up all the ends and gave me something that I wanted to know, but....The ending felt like it was forced to quickly. That everyone had to make super quick decisions. Tobias was pushed to figure out what parent. Tris was pushed to save her brother or a corrupt city. Caleb had to chose to let Tris go. Evelyn had to decide whether to lose her memory or make peace. Marcus had to decide on peace. All of that felt forced somehow and I couldn't put my finger on it. Everything else made since. Why they chose to go back to the city, why Tris died, why Tobias didn't fall apart, etc.This book was a great book. It did leave me feeling depressed and like part of me will never be the same again, because I was hoping for spectacular ending, where Tobias and Tris end up married with kids. But, not all authors are gonna give you that, and that's what makes me love Veronica Roth. She didn't give me what was expected. She gave me the unexpected! Just like Tobias and Tris did. I wanted Caleb to die, but she chose to not be selfish. She chose her life over her brother's because she forgave him. That was the ultimate sacrifice! Caleb dying would have been easy because she would forget all the anger and hatred she felt about him, which wouldn't have solved anything. By dying, to me, she told him, "I love you. Live and be brave because you have given me more than I need. We are all messed up people and even you handing me over to death was not the worst thing you could have done. I chose to let you die.See? I messed up to." She finally knew what forgiveness was, and that made her Tris.Tobias was the one I wanted a little more grief out of, but Tobias is hard and strong. He doesn't show grief in the way I envisioned. He went and done what he had to do, only to be told the love of his life was dead. He doesn't break down or go crazy. He stood still and remembered all the things he could about her. And even when he goes to see her, he still doesn't lose it. True Tobias fashion. You see a broke man, but not on the outside. It did open him up a little bit more. And what really got me, was when he went zip lining. He conquered a fear for her. Not entirely, but he did it for her. He became free. He sacrificed himself to show he wasn't selfish.All in all, I have never laughed, cried, gotten angry and more with any other series. This one captured from the beginning to the end. I just wish the characters didn't feel as forced to make decisions so quickly. The books taught me to love with your whole heart and make your own choices. It taught me to be brave, selfless, honest, smart and kind, because there is no way I can be just one. Becoming who you are is what I learned and took away from it, along with the rest I said. Veronica Roth, I applaud you for taking deep leaps and doing something extraordinary with this book. You have done an amazing job and you have earned every bit of praise for this series :)Be brave, everyone♥

Allegiant was a very good end to the Divergent trilogy. The only reason I did not give it five stars is that it was a bit different from the two previous books. Lots of new characters and situations. So I made sure to buy this book the day of it's release, to make sure that I would not be affected by other reviewers. The reviews were already flaming, which should have been a red flag.There are many, many reasons why this gets only one star. The first as to be the POV switching. I know many have already stated it, but often I had to check who the POV was to understand what was happenig. Tris and Four read as the EXACT SAME PERSON. Who let this happen? The editors, Roth , the publishing execs? Seriously it read like some self published junk not a professionally distributed novel.This leads into the second problem: The desolation of Four.There have been times when a characters actions make me go "why did they do that?" this for the first time actually made me think we were being tricked and Four was under a simulation/drug hallucination. Until the bombing that injure Uriah occurs. Then I truly thought Four was going to have his memory wiped or be left by Tris. Because that amount of idiocy convinced me he had been brain damaged in fsome previous scene we didnt read. No again, no to everything, a guy who supposedly only has four fears and can lead/teach others now has crippling inadequacy issues, is shamefully cowardly in owning up to his mistakes, and is obsessed with his parents. Complete character meltdown.Which tacks onto the character meltdown of Tris. Previously a slightly violent, but selfless girl who is pretty sharp is turned into a psychological genius able to discern other character's flaws and abilities almost omnipotently. Still action oriented,but now so much so that she almost reads like a brainwashed operative. Where did all the conscious and humanity of Tris go? Apparently the same place Four's bravery and intelligence went.To be honest this book was very hard to finish because I flipped between irritation and downright boredom so much.I am trying to write this sans spoilers which is hard because the plot holes and inconsistencies are a huge part of the one star rating. Also these are the problems NOT counting the ending. It gets a one star review because by the time I got to the ending I just didnt care about the characters anymore. In fact the ending to Tris' story was fine by me, the character was already gone by the 65% anyways.Which leads me to the ending. The first time I read it I actually thought it was a joke. Really, I foolishly thought there was going to be a super epilogue and we would find out it was all part of Four's fearscape or something. Wrong,wrong, wrong Allegiant goes out with something an author, who is obviously still very immature, considers "shocking". Think Shonda Rhimes shocking but with almost no emotion, and absolutely no purpose. Instead I daresay the "shocking" part makes another huge plothole, and makes the main character entirely useless to the plot of the story.Finally what really bothers me about this last book is that any sort of value, or meaning that could be taught by reading this trilogy is completely thrown out the widow.  Clearly this was just a money making effort by Roth though how she thinks anyone will read another series by her is beyond me.Save your money, and dont waste your time.

What does it mean to be selfless? That was one of the main themes of the entire 'Divergent' trilogy. But in the shocking ending to the series, Veronica Roth personally shows what it is to be Dauntless, as well, choosing an ending that some less mature readers may not enjoy. She didn't choose the agreeable 'Amity' ending of hearts and flowers and a future of baking cookies that some readers may have wanted for their favorite characters.Roth was brave. She chose a thought-provoking ending. She loved her characters enough to be true to what drives them.I've had a small problem with the earlier books, even though I loved them. People, in general, are not one-dimensional. In 'Divergent' and 'Insurgent,' other than divergent people, you didn't see many people showing traits outside of their chosen faction. What on Earth is wrong with these people?In 'Allegiant,' I appreciated the reasons for what led these people to become so one-dimensional in the first place. Things finally made sense. I often wondered where Ms. Roth was going with all of this. This book is tightly written and better edited than the previous works. And don't get me wrong, those books were great. This was just better, and more purposeful. There didn't seem to be a wasted word in the entire book.I think those who were shocked today to read the ending will later find themselves thinking and re-thinking this series. It may not have had the perfect happy ending. To my knowledge, Roth wasn't writing a Harlequin romance. What she delivered was a well-crafted and thoughtful series on what it means to be human, selfless, brave, kind, intellectually curious and truth-seeking.
