reviewText: I feel like I have to start this review with a quick note...I know that a lot of people disliked this book, but I think it's mainly because they're upset at the ending. That's fine that you didn't like the ending because it's now how you thought, but please don't bash Ms. Roth, who is an amazing author. She has complete creative license to do whatever she wants. She can kill off whomever she wants, and write the story how she sees fit. And if this ending was how she imagined this series ending, then it's good enough for me. Was I upset at the ending, yes. Any rational person would be. I cried and cried, and then cried some more. I literally couldn't believe what just happened. But I also expected it in some ways (which I'll get to later in this review). So overall, I don't care if you complain about the ending, but just stop bashing Ms. Roth because there's a HUGE difference, at least to me, between bashing a book and bashing an author.Anyway, I personally thought this book was fantastic. There were a couple of things that I really didn't like, which is why if I could, I would give this 4.5 stars. However, overall, I greatly enjoyed it, and am very sad that this series is over. Let's start with the dual POV first. I loved being able to read from Tobias's perspective (but seriously, who wouldn't). I honestly wanted to read more from his POV then Tris's. Ms. Roth did a very good job at showing us the real Tobias, who is completely separate from Four. He's not as strong as he would have the world believe. Tobias is suffering and unsure. This glimpse into his true character made the book so much more enjoyable for me, and his character much more realistic. War changes people, and I for one am grateful for the inside look. Tris is struggling just as much in some ways. However, she is stronger, and ready to take on whatever may come her way. She thinks things through, but at times acts rashly. Her character was also very realistic to me, and while I didn't like her POV as much as the previous two novels (which I think was largely because of Tobias's being in this story as well), it was still a great look into her mind.This leads me to one of the things that I didn't like. I thought the dual POV was very poorly done. At first, I could easily tell the difference between Tris and Tobias's POV's. However, as the story progressed, it got harder and harder to tell who was actually talking. I found myself going back to the beginning to double check who was supposed to be talking because the voices sounded similar. Usually, you could tell who was who just by the setting that character was in, but when Tris and Tobias are in the same setting, it just got downright confusing. Dual POV is hard to pull off, but I was expecting a bit more from Ms. Roth on this front because I do think she is a great author that has an amazing talent.Next up is the setting and plot. I will agree that this was one of the weaker aspects of this book, however it wasn't that weak. Granted, I didn't enjoy this book as much as the other two, but this is also a completely different book revolving around completely different terms. Chicago is changing after Jeanine's death and Evelyn's rise to power, and this isn't necessarily a good thing. This is a very fast-paced book, but there were times where it was lagging. These parts easily could have been cut out, and the story wouldn't have suffered in the slightest. At the same time, I flew through this book. I wanted to keep reading to find out what was going to happen next. The circumstances are different in this book, and I think Ms. Roth did an excellent job at pulling everything together. All our questions are answered except one (at least in my mind). We find why this all happened (and why there were factions), we find out about Edith Prior and Tris's mom, we find out what it actually means to be Divergent. Basically, we find out the truth. I know that some people really disliked this portion of the book, but honestly, I feel that what Ms. Roth did made a lot of sense.  I think another reason I liked where Ms. Roth took this book is because it speaks to the science person in me. Being a Biology major in college, this whole thing just clicked with me in a way. I don't feel that in anyway was this a cop-out. While it could have been a little bit better researched in some aspects, it still was a interesting and creative direction to take the story.Now onto the ending. First let me talk about this "sex" scene. I interpreted it as they did have sex. I'm not putting this under spoiler because you can go into any review already and find this out. However, it was confusing as heck by what she meant. I guess it's really up to the reader to interpret what they want, but this part of the book could have been done a whole lot better. This also goes for the romance in the book. I know that Ms. Roth put it in to appease readers (especially because of what happens at the end), but I thought a lot of times the romance was out of place, and just didn't fit very well. In my opinion, there was actually too much. The climax of this book blows you away. There's no way to lessen the blow or anything. You will cry and sob and think it's unfair. Should you not read this book solely because of this reason, no. You need to read the book. But just know that the ending will literally shred your heart to little itty bitty pieces, and you'll need at least a 2-3 day recovery period. This being said, I actually completely expected something like this to happen. Never once in this series has it been sunshine and rainbows, and to expect the ending of this book to change anything is silly. This book is about a war, and in war there are many many casualties. Sometimes people who you don't want to die, end up dying, while the people that you can't stand live long and happy lives. But again, this is exactly what happens in war.Ultimately, I thought this book was great, and even though it wasn't as good as the previous two, I still thought it was an amazing end to this series. The title could have been better (I mean I even was coming up with other titles for this book while reading), but don't let other reviews hinder you from enjoying this novel. My best advice is go into this book with an open mind. Don't expect everything to work out perfectly and remember the world that this series takes place in. Our world isn't perfect, so you can' expect the ending to work out perfectly. I can't wait to see what else Ms. Roth writes because I know that she is a great author that has a tremendous talent.
summary: Not As Good As Other Books in Series, But Still a Worthy Contender

reviewText: WTH was that I been waiting anxiously for this book just to have the worst ending possible. I'm so disappointed that I been waiting just to see one an amazing series ruined. I had fate on Veronica Roth to end this in a satisfactory way but I guess is her story to tell not mine. To the fans be ready to cry your eyes out. To the author you are an excellent writer but next time gives us a warning.
summary: I have never been so disappointed

reviewText: I wanted to LOVE this book. I so enjoyed the first 2 and the relationships of the characters are the best part not the where or what. I can see why your knee jerk reaction is to give this book 1 star.  She ruined the characters ending for crying out loud! BUT this is a well written story, a smooth continuation from the last two books. Did it loose some of the excitement and the page turning need to know more.....yes. For that give it 3 stars at worst.  I gave it 4 stars because it is a good book even if you wanted to throw it against the wall. It lost the 5th star because there isn't an incentive to ever reread this book.  I reread books all the time and it is a huge thing for me to admit I won't reread this one.  To lose a main character like this was pointless, the point could have been made differently.  So yes read this book but brace yourself.
Wow! I don't even have the words too express how I feel about this book. I strongly recommend reading this series.

The best ending to a series that has ever been written. There is so much turmoil in this book. All I can say is be prepared to be shocked and to cry a good bit. The society we thought we new becomes so much more.
Disappointing after the first two better books. You'll want to read it to understand how the story ends but don't expect the dynamism nor creativity of the first two.
I feel like the whole point of the ending was to supply shock and emotion, which definitely happened. I didn't like it at all and was very disappointed.

I fell in love with this series when I read Divergent in less than 24 hours, and read Insurgent just as quickly. I bought the short stories and read them in a heartbeat too. I was so excited waiting for Allegiant that I could hardly read any other books in the meantime, and let me say, what a disappointment.Allegiant is monotonous, not nearly as well written as Divergent, and because of the flaws in the writing, makes a poor ending. When the means justify the end, you understand, sympathize, but you know it is unnecessary, then you wonder what the author is trying to get at. Is it a shock value? Some deaths were absolutely unnecessary and just leave a sour taste in the readers's mouth. Not so nice Veronica, so after you had us fall in love with your characters.The POV style could have been good if I could distinguish who was who. I often had to go back to the beginning of the chapter to see who was "talking" because Tris and Four had the same voice pretty much. That was disappointing, they're supposed to be quite opposite personalities in some cases.I was so excited to watch the movie, couldn't wait. Now I'm not even sure I can enjoy it if I watch it...

If you've read the first two books and loved them, be satisfied with that.  Don't pick this one up.The book started out okay, but I was immediately thrown off by the change in viewpoint.  In this book each chapter switches between the two main characters.  I've read books written like this before and they were great.  Unfortunately, with Allegiant, I often had to flip back a few pages to remember which character is telling the story.  It was hard to follow.  By the time I was a few chapters into the book, it started to drag.  I read each of the first two books in 2 days.  When I got into the third book, I kept setting it down.  It just didn't hold my attention.The worst part was the end.  I won't spoil the ending for you by telling more.  I'm sure the right internet search would tell you.  I'll just say it was a horrible ending.
summary: Is this really the same author as Divergent?

reviewText: I like the story / plot line of the Divergent series, but the relationship between Tris and Tobias was not developed well and had too many back and forth issues.  I wanted to finish the series to know what happened so I continued to read the book.  It got better half way through.  But really how many times can you inject someone with a mind altering drug without it permanently affecting their health?

I loved the first book, it was amazing.  The second book was excellent too but the third book left little in the view of hope.  I had planned on reading the whole series again but after the third book I was so disappointed I couldn't bring myself to re-live that.  I am an avid reader and don't always need a happy ending at the end of my books but I at least need to feel that there was a purpose behind some of the choices in the story.  Overall I gave it 3 stars because of the first and second book being great reads.

I loved the first two books. I waited on pins and needles for the third. By halfway through the third I was ready to give up. It just wasn't good. I had to keep going back to the chapter heading to see who was talking. Roth should never have done two points of view.  I know why she did but because she did it I knew from the beginning what would happen to Tris. I think she should have stuck with an epilogue written by four. As it was, it was irritating. I convinced to others to start the series who loved the first two books. Neither one of them made it more than halfway through the third.

I loved to first two books! I couldn't put them down! The last book, not so much. It seemed like Roth could not keep the series going. I did not like the way Allegiant kept switching between Tris and Tobias (Four). It seemed very broken and rushed. It was hard to keep track of who was talking. I think it could have been better had Roth just kept with all the characters, more story vs single thoughts. I was even ok with the ending, it was typical Tris. I am curious to see how the movie will turn out and if there will be 3 made.
summary: What a way to end the series...

reviewText: Spoilers. I just ignored my family and the need to eat or sleep to finish this series and I honestly want that time back. Why do authors feel the need to make a grand gesture in death? I just wanted a happy ending. I get it she sacrificed herself blah blah blah but it still pisses me off.
summary: Too upset to write a proper review

reviewText: Terribly boring book. I mean boring. I started reading this series because my 16 year old daughter really liked it and wanted me to read it. I actually really liked the first two books and found them entertaining. Allegiant though falls so far away from the standard set forth in the first two books that it's embarrassing. The worst part is this took her more than two years to write. What was she doing? I found myself reading this and inserting my own missed moments of action or excitement: that would of been a great time for fight scene; that would of been good plot twist; that would of been exciting if that happened.... Instead your left with the constantly mundane emotional and relationship concerns of Tristan and Four. Pages and pages of crap. Like many of the people here who gave it bad reviews - I'm not doing it because of the "sad" ending it didn't bother me and I could see why it was done. What bothered me more was that I really didn't care at that point- I literally just wanted the book to end so I could read something good.My daughter who, as mentioned, is a huge fan of the books is so bored that she's stuck on page 280 and she can't push herself to read more than a few pages at a time before she loses interest.I got to wonder what the producers of the Divergent movie are thinking. They jumped on this series hoping it would be a huge success like the Hunger Games and then she's ends the promising series with this time waster. If the movies takes off it will be very interesting to see what they do with this third book. It could be interesting because they would have the opportunity to actually make the movie 100 times better than the book which really never happens.

There is already a great review on this book,http://www.amazon.com/review/RX9IWT6KYAJHR/ref=cm_cr_pr_viewpnt#RX9IWT6KYAJHR,  so I won't delve into all the nuances of why this book was a disappointment. However, I got this book because the previous two were captivating and intriguing and this book broke away from every aspect that made the other two worthwhile reads. I was saddened to see that Roth clearly had no end game plan when writing this.
This book took me weeks to get through. I even put it aside and read two books while reading this. First two were much better.

This is actually more like a 2.5 rating.  I enjoyed the first two books, and to be fair, did not read the third until several months later, so I think I had forgotten too much.  Recommend reading them back to back. Rated the first book four stars I believe.

I agree that the characters seemed to change in this book. I would have preferred stronger, distinct voices for Tris and Tobias. Tris became arrogant and whiny. Four became insecure and wishy washy. They didn't act like themselves. I didn't care about the new characters introduced and I was upset when several characters died. I did not think what was outside the fence lived up to the hype in the other books. Veronica Roth has talent because I really care about the characters from the first two books. My children were asking me why I was crying for about an hour while I read the end of the book. The end was disturbing and sad.

Let me start off by saying is that this book was up there for one of my favorite book series. Right next to Harry Potter and the Hunger Games. I would tell my friends that it could quite possibly be my favorite because i absolutely loved the first 2 books but it depended on the ending, because lets face it, the ending is what makes or breaks the series.With that being said, i felt a roller coaster of emotions. I had been anxiously waiting for the final book to come out for months and was a little let down. the story didnt have as much action and fighting as the first two books did and it got really repetitive and extended in some parts. it had things that could have been left out and some things felt forced in.The ending is obviously the part that everyone is going to talk about. i was heartbroken that Roth had killed Tris. I had grown attached to the character and thought that she was going to get her happy ever after. Yes, i understand that its the type of book where stuff like this happens, but after reading some other reviews, i have to agree where it may not be the fact that Tris died but the manner. She was all up for Caleb sacrificing his life but then at the last second she doesn't because she knows he doesn't want to. it really gave me a sour taste with the story because i had thought she had gotten over the stupid sacrifice thing for Tobias. I felt like she didn't consider even for a split second about him until it was too late. And i agree with some other reviewers, if you are going to kill off your main character, then you should do it in a manner that honors them and leads peace and resolution. Tris's death pretty much only honored Caleb's cowardicy and there was no resolution. and what's worse, her killer, David and the other guards, doesn't even get punished for it.I guess I had hoped/expected Tobias and Tris to survive and get their happy ending because they had been through so much in the first two books. as i was reading it, i knew something big was going to happen because it had been calm up until then but what i thought was Tobias's memory was going to get wiped/reset and he wouldn't remember her. The more i think about it the more i wish that that was the ending. b/c it still would have had that surprise tragedy but at the same time it has hope for the future that they could end up together again.Overall, i can't say i hated the book. because i didnt. i'm not going to boycott the series just because i did agree with the story. being an English major in college it kind of made me more open-minded and accepting. I know that i will reread the series again in the future, but i'll probably stop reading it in the last scene that Tobias and Tris are together and they say they love each other (at least for a little while). I'm not going to boycott the movies because i think the movies are going to be fun to watch and i have a funny feeling that they are probably going to change the ending to Allegiant's movie (especially after seeing the fan backlash)
summary: Not the book i was expecting...(SPOILERS)

reviewText: The first two books were great. This one really disappointed me though. I wish I hadn't started reading this series.
I invested hours into reading these books and for it to end this way makes me furious I understand why she wrote it that way but I believe the readers deserved a better ending

***spoiler alert****This book like the other books Veronica has written captures you from the beginning and you won't want to put it down however this book left me disappointed. It leads up to this big climax only to leave the readers disappointed and in shock. I'm not upset with who dies its just how they die. I figured Tris was going to die at the end just the way the book leads up to it but I feel she died in a way that's so cliche and disappointing. Also I'm disappointed how Uriah dies. You think in this futuristic world they would have a remedy for a coma and yet for the entire end of the book he's dead in a coma. Despite those two disappointments it was an easy read and entertaining to find out what's on the other side of the fence. Guess I just had high hopes for this book since the other two were so good.

Amazing! I hated ending this book and the emotional ending takes you on such a roller coaster of feelings. There was a time or two where I once again feared a possible YA "love triangle" crap, but that was quickly resolved. The whole world is open, nothing is what anyone ever thought it would be. Who really is the bad guy? Are they all bad guys? How can the world really be fixed and what will happen to everyone after so many revolutions, rebellions and changes in everything they thought they knew. Amazing end to a wonderful series. I applaud you, Veronica Roth. Thank you so much for such a refreshing YA dystopian trilogy. I absolutely love it, even if I cried a time or two in this one! I know people were not happy with the writing style, but I feel it went with the trilogy. At the beginning of the first book, Tris was a kid, and at the ending of this one, she was an adult. The changes in the characters, because of all that they went through, is immense and shown in the way this book is written. I am a huge reader, and this is one of hundreds of thousands of books I have read. I loved this book. I was not thrilled with the ending, it was upsetting, but I really liked her tone, the set-up and finality of it all.

This book was amazing. Yes I was upset at the end. However that doesn't mean I declared the whole book a disaster. It was well written and very exciting. This book was an excellent conclusion to the series. Whoever says it is a horrible book don't listen. You need to go in with an open mind. Remember the author is only human. You can't expect everything of her. She did a really great job with this series.

Allegiant is the 3rd and final book in the Divergent series. It picks up at the end of book 2 with the release of the Edith Prior video and the knowledge that there may indeed be a civilization outside the fence. After the release of the video Evelyn and the fractionless take over and forbid anyone from leaving, this causes a divide in the people. The fractionless who follow Evelyn and the Allegiant who are in search of the truth and what is really outside the fence. A small group including Tris and Four set out to discover the outside world.After making it outside the group discovers a whole new world filled with terrible secrets and destruction of its own. After discovering everything they have ever known was a lie and now faces a different kind of destruction they must make difficult choices and show true bravery to save their families and their world.This book did not go in the direction I expected and I would just like to give a big thank you to Veronica Roth for that. What an amazing finish to an amazing series. In keeping true to the values and morals she created in her characters this was a truly amazing end. I can see how people would be upset about this final book because it does stray from the typical conclusion that we are used to from this kind of book. However, that is what makes it such an amazing read. As always Veronica Roth draws you into the world she created with her fantastic characters and descriptive writing. Once again you get drawn into the relationship between Tris and Four and how they are able to navigate their relationship when the world around them is falling apart. We are finally told what it really means to be divergent and how that makes them different from everyone else and why the fractions played such an important part in their society.This was a fantastic book and I definitely recommend reading it. Especially those who have read the others and were put off by the negative comments. You do not want to miss out on the conclusion to this story. This is one of my favorite series and even though it made me ugly cry to finish this series I am beyond amazed by this story. I am definitely a fan of Veronica Roth  and look forward to reading more about Four in the Divergent Story short she is releasing.First I would just like to say I am a bit disappointed in all the reviews posted giving spoilers and not saying they are giving spoilers. Not everyone wants to know what happens before they read the book. Also saddened by the folks posting reviews or negative comments about the book and have not read it. Reading the epilogue and finding out it didn't end the way you wanted and posting about without reading the story it is wrong, and you are missing out on one amazing story
summary: An amazing end to an amazing story

reviewText: I understand what I read. But it is way to shocking to remember myself that this is about life, what real life is.Veronica Roth I am MOURNING right now.I like the reflections that this ending brought to me, and I believe to everyone that reads it.Not every couple gets to be together in real life and we still have to face life after the death of a beloved one.Everyone of us will die someday.Still, I would like to read a diferent ending in a while, because I would like to read in Veronica's Roth words how it would be if they ended together, what would have happened to Caleb? How would Tobias face Zeke after Uriah's death, how would he dealt with Evelyn and Marcus. Would Tris and Tobias been married? Would they have survived the "quiet times" together, as Tris says? Or would they have broken up, after the most harsh days have ended.I know... as we face death in our life, the denial starts whith us wondering when the person will come arouund again, that the door will sudenly open and the beloved one will come back from work, or from the gym, church or watever else he/she was usually at that same hour.And as I said I am MOURNING and I am in denial.
Building me up to disappoint me. A romance killed and  the ending destroyed. Not a story I would recommend if you want the hero to get the girl. Very sad

I finished this book two days ago and I'm still just stunned and immensely disappointed about the ending. I LOVED book one, book two, and even 95% of this book, but I just can't get over the ending. (SPOILER!!!) I am aware that it's a testament to the kind of person Tris was, but it doesn't make my disappointment lessen.

I just finished reading Allegiant and I may be going slightly against the grain here, but the only redeeming quality about the book was the ending. If the author did not kill off Tris or Tobias, then the whole book would have been a meandering pointless mess. At least she bothered to get around to the purpose of the series toward the end....sort of. I think...I'm still not sure what the 'central thesis' was. Maybe - if you die for someone, it's the ultimate way to show you love them. Or - We can all ascend from bad times if we have our pals with us. Or - war (huh) what is it good for?It was bad. I felt like Allegiant belonged to a completely different series. The first book, and arguably the second in the series were about the characters. Allegiant was about...well, I'm still working on that. After about ten chapters the whole thing got so messy and convoluted that the characters got lost. The author spends this insane amount of time writing about gene purity and scientific hokum and who hates who and why, and who's vision is lost and why. There's the Bureau and the citizens and the GP and the GD and fringes and the Allegient, and the Factions and the Factionless and the people who just want to have their memories erased, and the people who are sad that people have died, and the people who have died - and that's just scratching the surface. Too many directions. Way to many. The whole story of Tris and Tobias was lost. The entire sub plot involving Nita and Uriah and the failed  'plan' could have been taken out of the book altogether and it still would have 'arrived' in the same place. The characters couldn't shine through the mire of sub plot and I stopped caring about them.It was an unsatisfactory ending to a series that started on a high note and then....nose dive.

Let me start off by saying I am very disappointed in this book. I am a huge fan of this series but this one just wasn't as strong as the first two.It started off descent, had some bad and good moments then you have the heartbreaking ending. After reading the ending it has damaged the whole series for me, I was looking forward to re-reading it but I don't know if I can (especially now that I know how it ends) And I have been looking forward to the movie, I keep watching the same preview over and over again and I just don't know if I will even be able to watch it now.I don't know why Veronica made the ending the way she did (I cried, and I mean cried A LOT! and I had to keep telling myself, its just a book-its not real). I'm sure I'm not the only fan that is disappointed and a bit pissed.I feel like a piece of me was stolen after a certain part happened in the end, which is an odd way to describe it, but I don't know how else to. When you are a book lover and really get into the book(s) you are reading they somehow become apart of you and I feel like a piece of me was taken after this ending.So I will end by saying that I honestly wish I didn't even start the series, What is the point in the series if it gets the ending Roth gave it????????

*Spoiler Alert*I was disappointed by the ending.  The whole book didn't have the same flair as the others.  It was enough to keep me reading though.  In the later chapters I was getting excited about Tris and Four, finally coming together as a couple and the thought of them being able to settle in after the revolution.  But then Tris dies!!!  And along with the other people who reviewed the book, I also agree that it isn't necessarily about having to have a happy ending, but at least make her death worth while.  It very briefly states what happens after all, and isn't the outcome a lot of people wanted.  No one even recognized her as a hero besides her small group of friends.  She wanted to do something great, for the greater good, but her fatal attempt falls short.  I felt empty from the moment she died until the end of the book.  It did not redeem itself after that.

The story felt a little lacking in what should have been payoff to the series.  I am speaking as someone who loved Divergent, liked Insurgent, but hated what happened with Allegiant.  It tries to introduce new things in the last part of the series, doesn't give satisfactory payoff to the Tris/Four relationship after all the buildup in book one and conflict of book two, and spend more time exploring relationships with characters whose presence is no longer felt then with characters right next to the hero and heroine the whole time.
summary: Unsatisfying conclusion to what could have been a great trilogy

reviewText: I wonder wrote this book? Couldn't be the same Author. I felt so disengaged throughout the book, too many useless people coming and going, stupid plots, unresolved  issues yetDespite that I kept reading so I can finally find that  happy ending. Thanks Veronica Roth for robbing that from us! Horrible

NON Spoiler sectionI, for some reason, spent a few minutes comparing the 1-Star percentages this book has received against the first two of this series and other young adult books. Besides the last Twilight book, several of the other series' final books range from 2% to 5%. Not bad, means the author did a great job in closing the book up.  The Twilight final was 18% (ouch).  This damn book, 24% of all the reviews are 1-Star reviews.  Compare this to under 2% for the first two books of this series and I can comfortably say Summit Entertainment has a big problem on their hands. The 24% doesn't cover the 2-Stars either. Sorry to say, this last book sucks. Movie goers will likely hate it.I rarely write reviews as I don't get caught up in them too much. However, this book had some major flaws.  One being the "dual narrative".  I have to agree with many of the other frustrated readers of this third book.  Both Tris' and Tobias' chapters which are intended to be of their own perspectives sound the same! I am not just talking about the sentence structure and all that.  They actually could be swapped as Four sounds like a frustrated girl most of the time.Additionally, this book is driving me crazy and I'm a dude.  I've been trying to figure out why I'm so upset with a dumb book.  I finally figure it out with the help of some other reviews. The ending simply does not make sense.  It seems Roth simply wanted to twist your emotions around and leave you thinking this was such a powerful book!  Sort of cheating I believe.Spoiler alert!Leave if you haven't read it yet!!!For those of you who have read the book and are looking for others' thoughts...I'd have to say the deaths (several of them in this book) were hasty and carried little of the magnitude of the first two books. Then... her death. To show us just how awesome she was by defying the death serum, only to be shot in the back moments later.  What a waste.  I really felt like the series was a waste of my time.  We know the characters are so damaged, there was no real chance they'd "live happily ever after", however at least let them work on it. This would have been believable. The ending just leaves a bad taste in my mouth. Unlike the end of the Hunger Games trilogy which also had enormous losses, there was closure.  No closure here. The epilogue did little if nothing for me.
summary: I just don't buy into the ending...

reviewText: The first 12 chapters were well done but the book falls apart after that. I appreciated being spared the typical happy ending, but this book didn't add much to the overarching plotlines. In the end the whole series falls flat. Also, Tris and Tobias alternate as first-person but their voices are indistinguishable- annoying.

This last instalment of the Divergent series was a complete snore.  I loved the first two books so much so that I was unable to put them down. I was so entrenched in the story that I sneaked off while at work to read several chapters. Allegiant on the other hand lost my interest after chapter 5 where it started to become very predictable.  I hope the movie does a better job with the storyline series finale.

Where do I begin, it was horrible. Don't waste your time or money. I gave it 2 stars instead of 1 because Roth definitely wrapped it up in the end. Although I hated the ending, the beginning and middle put me to sleep. I can't believe that they would publish that book, even my teenage son thinks it was "blah". Total waste of a few hours of my life I can never get back. I really liked the Born Trilogy by Tara Brown, she even gives an alternate ending option.

I really wanted to love this book.  I had looked forward to its release.  I was sadly disappointed.  In this book, Tris and Tobias seem to just be going through the motions.  Character development and voice in this book are MIA.  Tobias and Tris might as well have been the same person, because they had the same monotone delivery in short simple sentences.  Halfway through, I was begging for imagery, emotion, and at least complex sentence structures.My biggest problem with this story is that our familiar and beloved characters were almost impossible to recognize, as they had been completely different in the previous books.Finally, I don't want to be "preached to" when I am reading a work of fiction.  I get the moral and social dilemmas at hand, but I don't want to be constantly hit over the head with it.  There was entirely too much telling and not enough showing in the book.  Overall, I disliked it.

It felt like a never ending LONG tedious reading!I really don't understand the writter. She could have given us so much more! But instead she gave us this tedious-lack of action & emotion story with a disappointing ending. NOTHING like the first book.I just feel sad for such a poor ending to these characters I used to love!Four was another person in this book. Not the strong character we thought would lead an important revolution in Divergent. Of course he had some issues but with Tris he could overcome anything, right? Wrong! He was just a pity shadow of 1st book Four.Wow! So many things to say about this poor plot (none of them good). I'm just going to keep it simple & with no spoilers. In one word: BAD!

Maybe I'm just easy to please, but I really don't understand the bad reviews! I loved this!I've loved this series since I first tore through Divergent, and I really felt the last book in this trilogy did not disappoint.I love the turn this book took and the explanation as to what is outside the fence. I had my own theories too, but I like how the changes forced some of the characters to evolve. Four is no longer the bad-ass he was in the first two novels... but that is ok! It's more realistic to me. All of the crap everyone has gone through... I think some of the twists that made people mad are some of the things that made the story more believable, to me. In a dystopian novel, the ones I love the most are those that seem somehow realistic and like something that could actually happen. All of the GD/GP things... hello, things like trying to create the perfect race HAS HAPPENED IN REAL LIFE! The events in this book were not that much of a stretch for me.End rant.In  Allegiant, the characters you've come to love are all there, yet things have changed so drastically the things that used to  be so important to them, like factions, aren't anymore. I think the twist was so relevant yet surprising, and I love some of the deeper meanings that came about. "...But now I'm wondering if I need it anymore, if we ever really need these words, "Dauntless," "Erudite," "Divergent," "Allegiant," or if we can just be friends or lovers or siblings, defined instead by the choices we make and the love and loyalty that binds us."Come on. That's good stuff.I'm struggling writing this review because this book was so multi-layered. I don't want to give too much away and spoil it for anyone.I'll end with this- I love reading trilogies, and some trilogies leave a lot to be desired by the time the last book in the series comes around. This is not one of those books. The story does not fizzle away, it is not a stereotypical fairy tale ending, yet all of the loose ends are tied up. I'll concede, I would like to have known more about certain things, like how the conflict ends, more about the Bureau, and more about the aftermath. But I think that's just my being greedy. For me, this is truly one of those books and series that I didn't want to end, and I'll end up coming back to read this again and again.Well done! I can't wait to see the movies.
summary: I don't understand the bad reviews!

reviewText: I CANT BELIEVE IT'S OVER!!!! Veronica Roth wrote an amazing and spellbinding tale. This one brought tears to my eyes. Everything that her characters go through...they feel like people that I know and have come to love. I'm so sad that the series is over...but this roller coaster ride that the Divergent series took me on was completely worth it.
Book went against the first two. Plot was bad and had the worst ending ever. It was such a disappointment especially after reading divergent and insurgent.

Such a disappointing end to the otherwise excellent trilogy. I wish I hadn't read this book. I would have been better off using my imagination to decide how it all ended. I won't be buying the Four series now as a result of this book. I'm done giving money for something so ridiculous.
summary: Use your imagination to create your own ending after the second book!

reviewText: Ugh. What an awful book; it was like a major down hill slope from divergent to this. Divergent was interesting and worth reading. Insurgent was OK, not great not awful, but Allgiant? WHY? I read the mixed reviews on the book and decided to read it anyway hoping it wouldnt be so bad. WRONG! This book is a snooze fest, about half way through it I just gave up. The characters have no depth, and there is just a ton of blah blah blah blah. zzzzzzzzzz... oops i fell asleep just thinking about it! Do yourself a favor and just do not read this book. It will completely let you down.

It was boring, repetitive and without giving any spoilers, the characters who died in this last installment were arbitrary and felt like they only occurred to draw some shock factor from the reader. It's not that I was necessarily looking for a happy ending, but this was just a waste of staying up late to finish.  It also felt a little preachy in places, like the author was trying really hard to teach life lessons  or "words to live by" to the reader.

Struggling with 2 Stars (It was okay) or 3 Stars (Like It). I think I will go with 2, because I have a feeling the more I think about it...it will be 2 Stars.I LOVED the first book and the second book. This book I felt like the author got lost. There was so many things she tried to add when they "went outside of the fence" that not a whole lot really was developed. The split story-line also didn't really do what was going on inside the fence a whole lot of justice either. I continued to read, hoping I would still enjoy the conclusion to this series, that I have recommended to several people. Only to be disappointed, like I really want to throw my Kindle across the room (still resisting the urge). Even as I continued to read, I kept thinking this has to be wrong, the author will redeem herself, only it DID NOT HAPPEN! The final wrap up chapters drove me crazy as well. I felt like she tried to cram every little thing in there, like when you watch a movie and during the end credits they give you little snippets of where everyone is at.If you loved the first two books I actually recommend you DO NOT READ THIS BOOK! Hope for some fan-fiction or something or just come up with a solution on your own.I'm just so disappointed right now. I can think of so many ways the story-line in this book could have been developed.
summary: I think I need a Fan-fiction Alternative Final Book. I do NOT recommend, if you love this series.

reviewText: I absolutely loved Divergent and Insurgent. Tris and Tobias were exceptionally developed characters and completely relatable. Their city, lives and the situations they lived are not easily understood by someone living in our day and age, but the detail that Veronica Roth have made everything understandable.Allegiant is no different. Tris and Tobias are still fighting for the right to live how they choose, but the enemy is different. They still grab my heart with the absolute purity of their love. This time around the enemy and allies are harder to define, but they find their way through together.Did this story end as I would have wished? No.Was the writing, story and the characters still just as interesting and engaging? Absolutely.The story comes from the author and their creative process. We can all disagree on whether we liked it or not, but that does not take away from the emotions the words create.  I cried hard when I finished this book and I haven't cried at the end of a book since Harry Potter. I'm sad it's over even though I wish it ended differently. I'll miss these characters and the world they lived in and are trying to build again. My kudos and thanks to Ms. Roth on an exceptional trilogy!

I'd been looking forward to this book for months and started reading it as soon as it showed up on my kindle. I started getting worried as I saw reviews coming on, but I didn't read them because I didn't want to have the ending spoiled accidentally. No, the book doesn't end with all smiles, but Roth left me happy regardless. She made my emotions go all over the board from scared, anxious, happy, sad, etc. But the epilogue left me feeling happy, even though someone I was emotionally attached to didn't make it to the last page. There is a lot more dialogue than the other books, but I think it's important for Tris and Tobias to explain their thoughts more thoroughly, especially with the ending. If you're looking for a happily ever after, read a fairytale.
summary: Not everything is rainbows and sunshine, get over it!

reviewText: I've watched some interviews with Veronica Roth & her explanation of killing off Tris.  All I can say is "Really?"  This is the first book series that i haveI finished & totally am still waiting for an ending or just closure.  You will not get any of that with Allegiant. So so disappointed. What a waste of my time :-(

I have read the many reviews of this final novel in the series and could not agree more with the majority of them. I loved the first two books, but this one just pissed me off. It was as if the author was writing about a completely different set of people. Tris and Four were not nearly as stupid and trusting in the first two books.  I absolutely hated how everything unfolded and how it ended as well. I can not begin to understand what she was trying to accomplish, but I do know that having Tris go through all of that crap just to die anyway is not justifiable.  It made the whole story pointless to me.
I was very disappointed in the conclusion of this trilogy. I waited so long for the third book, and now I wish I never read it.

Boring. The characters make it hard for you to emphasize with them. Writing style seems to have gone downhill. The narrative was impossible to follow. How did the two main characters have the same "voice"? It was confusing at the very least.Too much was attempted to squeeze in one book. Did it HAVE to be a trilogy? Is that all YA books can aspire to? I never understand why authors insist on cutting their books off at the knees when then can clearly do so much with beloved characters. Not everyone has the attention span of a cocker spaniel.Most people were very attached to these characters and to have their story cut off just because there were supposed to only be three books seems tragic and pointless. There seemed to be so much more story to be told. This book just leaves you confused and bereft.The other books shine in comparison. They were well polished and left you wanting more. I won't be reading this book again, however the previous two will go into my "All Time Favorites" list for future re-reading.This book will gather dust until the end of time. I don't part well with books or I would just let it go. Also what if some poor soul were to get hold of it and have their hopes and dreams for the series dashed as well? It's my social responsibility to hide this book in a dark forgotten corner somewhere.
summary: Very meh with a side of disbelief

reviewText: Where is the grand finale we have all been waiting for? Was Ms Roth in a hurry to publish this? It feels like Allegiant was written by a different person, one that did not read neither the first two books nor the short stories about Tobias.You, as a loyal reader, become attached to the characters, hate them, love them, whatever and then you find out that your favorites die and the evil ones continue with their filthy, miserable lives. And not only that, those who die, die for nothing, just because the author was not able to come up with a better idea. All we got from Uriah's death is a whinning Tobias, a Tobias that would have never become the legendary Four. And Tris' death, well, I guess it happened because Ms Roth wanted to be edgy.We dreamed about the downfall of Peter, Caleb, Marcus and Evelyn, just like Jeanine's. But no, they get to keep on living their evil lives.BTW, this book also has ruined the upcoming movies.I said this on twitter and the fangirls thought it was a good thing  but no. My heart of broken because of this book. Veronica Roth is laughing at us.Please, give me some of that memory serum so I can forget about the whole Divergent thing.

I've had my nose in books long enough to know that not every one ends the way the reader imagines it should. That being said, I found this one horrible. I was on edge waiting for this to be released. It wasn't worth it. The way the author shifted between chapters and viewpoints, made me crazy. Sometimes, I'd forget if I was reading a Tris chapter or a Tobias chapter. Isn't that what the accompanying books are for, anyway? This could've been written much better with an alternative ending.

I absolutely loved the first two books. Read each of them more than once. And I, like many loyal Divergent fans, eagerly anticipated the release of Allegiant.NOT REALLY SPOILERS ... BUT ...Before even beginning the book, I was hesitant to jump it. After all, it's the last book in the series ... which meant that my journey with these characters (who I'd become highly invested in) was coming to an end. It was a reality that made me sad, and it was why it took me about two days after the book's release to finally delve into it. Why did I finally take the plunge and start reading, you ask? Well, I realized that once I finished this book, I could go back to the beginning and read again, taking new, fresh interest in all of the obstacles and hurdles the characters in the first two books endured -- with a new understanding of how it would all be tied together in the end.Well? I feel robbed. For the first time that I can remember, I finished a book series and didn't care what could possibly happen next. My emotional connection to the characters was destroyed and I wished I'd never read the third book. I'm sure it wasn't Roth's intention, and I'm sure she had her reasons for wrapping things up the way she did; I just can't see them. I feel like my investment in all three books was wasted. Pretty sure I don't even want to see the movies now ...
summary: Feel robbed ... and not just because of the ending.

reviewText: I have followed with eagerness all of these books and cannot express sufficiently my disappointment in this finale. As another reader said, DON'T read this finale - make up your own ending. Someone else said they would not read another series by this author - I wholeheartedly agree. One of the many reasons we read is to escape, to see triumph over adversity. That was NOT achieved here

had promise, but the last 100 or so pages killed it for me. this had to be the WORST ending to a trilogy that I can remember! it felt like all the time I spent reading the previous 2 books and now this were a complete waste...I agree with those that say skip this and come up with your own ending, because this is nothing but a colossal disappointment. I read a few books a week and can't remember the last time I asked for a refund, if ever, but yeah, I want my money back.
summary: And People were upset with the Hunger Games ending?!

reviewText: I cannot believe, first off, how people are completely spoiling this book in the reviews.. With that said, I could hardly put this book down once it arrived on my Kindle. I am not going to completely spoil what's already been spoiled, but if you're hoping for a nice ending all wrapped up in a pretty bow, this one isn't going to do that for you.I did not like the switching between points of view. It almost seemed as if the author didn't have enough material for a full length novel and that was the only way she could come up with to make it work and keep the publisher happy.(And as much as I've been looking forward to the first movie coming out next year, I am not sure I even want to see it now.)

I chose 2 stars because it was boring for the most part and had a HORRIBLY disappointing ending! I loved the first two books and have been waiting for this book for well over a year! I agree with most of the other reviews that this book was the last one I will be reading from this author. She took a great story with tremendous potential going into the third and final book and killed it.... literally.Anyone who has read this series in it's entirety won't be going to see the movies. A) it's a huge waste of time and B) a huge waste of money.Disgusted with this book. SMH

This series was up with Twilight for me until this third book. What a disappointment! VR has guaranteed I will never read her again. It was very hard to follow who you were following with alternating chapters. The love story fell flat and killing Tris off was arrogant and stupid decision. It didn't make sense and ruined the whole series for me. Dumb,dumb,dumb! I probably won't go to the movie now and if I would have read a review, I would not have read the book even though I pre ordered

This book is incredibly disappointing. Divergent was a pretty good read, even if there was a lot of suspension of disbelief employed. Insurgent was even more far-fetched and left me very confused and not entirely sure that I wanted to finish the series, but I was slightly curious about how this all might be resolved.I just finished Allegiant this morning and am disheartened and very disappointed by this book. My first complaint comes in the form of the dual narrative. I would often forget who was narrating at any given point and get confused by why they were saying what they were saying. I didn't get it straight until the book was almost finished. I think that there were more clever ways to solve this problem.Also, the solution as to why the people are in the city in the first place is ridiculous. It doesn't line up with real science at all. In fact, why wouldn't they just gas the fringe population with memory serum to make them forget why they're so upset? The technology used is very unbelievable. You could get away with this kind of writing, perhaps, in a middle book, but not in the finale.* Spoiler Alert*Does anyone else have a problem with the fact that a 16 year-old-minor, who is supposed to be the heroine and is perhaps a role-model to other young girls reading the book, has sex with an 18 year old boy? I say boy, because he is not a man and if he was a man he would have respected her body and probably would have held to his Abnegation upbringing a bit more in this area, since it governed his most basic thought and action patterns throughout the books. Do we really need to be encouraging more young girls to be having sex out of wedlock? I think that Tris and Tobias' romance would have been just fine without the escalating sexual encounters. I didn't add to the story and if anything it led to further discrediting, because I'm pretty sure that Tris would have cared about what her parents thought about her actions, since she kept trying to right by them.*Spoiler*The "solution" to the problem of using memory serum on the bureau was beyond belief. Aside from the obvious fact that they didn't even try to think of any more reasonable solutions, there was the fact that these people don't exist in a bubble. The Bureau workers most likely don't live in the complex and probably have families and records kept that would contradict everything they were being re-educated on. Just ludicrous.Also, how on earth were they able to negotiate a truce so easily? If the factionless are so great in number, have most of the weapons and are loathe to be out of a place of power, why wouldn't have they just gotten a new leader and kept the power?Too many unbelievable things in this book to list them all here. There are some great reviews that go very in-depth about them. I just wanted to get it out into the open the things that disappointed me the most.
summary: An incredibly disappointing end to an already loosely believable storyline.

reviewText: Allegiant, which concludes the Divergent trilogy, has taught me several things:do NOT pre-order a book in a series ever again;always read the ending first - that way you don't get emotionally invested in characters who will be killed off;refuse to ride the emotional roller coaster - read books by authors you can trust with your feelings;if you want to read a REALLY GOOD tragedy there's always "Romeo and Juliet";and don't keep falling for the hype.I'm just sorry it's taken me so long to learn.

I loved thr first two books and couldn't put them down (both times I read them).  Sadly this one took me longer to get though and was definitely flawed.  I hated the ending as most people did.  In addition switching between tris and tobias was okay but he should have had a differnt voice.  This book was more explanations than action.  I would never read this one again.  I also don't see this as a movie if they try to make the entire series into one.
summary: disappointing end to what should have been a great series!

reviewText: After all the reviews raving about this series, I bought them all... and now I wish I hadn't. Seriously, I read to escape reality and this was just too "real" to enjoy at all. Spoiler: She dies. Yep, she dies. Not going to ever read another by this author. I don't like death of the main characters...

I think everyone is giving far too few stars for this book simply based on the ending.  i won't spoil it like everyone else on here seems to be doing :P in case you didn't read it in the first two days.I thought it was very similar to the first two books, which I gave four stars.  The reason for the lower star on this book was mostly for the POV changing each chapter.  If you listen to it on audible, it was actually much better because the girl and boy voice switch as the Tris/Tobias POV switch.  But when I finished it on my kindle, I constantly had to go back and say "who am I right now?" cause 2 pages into the chapter I forgot which POV I was in.  Very confusing. Even just left justifying and bolding the name instead of blending it into the chapter # would have been better.Though I'm not sure that would have helped  because the tones and the descriptions (like commenting on other people and their actions) were so similar, you really couldn't tell which head you were in.I liked the idea of getting Tobias' POV, I just wish it had been done better...The book was slow to start with but it kept me entertained the rest of the way. The pace was pretty good, the different "cities" and the plot there was fine but there was enough for a fourth book if Ms. Roth would have been given the time to do it.Although I felt like Tris became a better person, I felt like Tobias became weaker and weaker as the books went on, which was sad for me. I adored the strong Four leader he was.The ending wasn't great but it wasn't as terrible as others seem to think.  It was realistic and one of the better written sections. I like amazon reviewer [ loladirga ]'s idea for an ending better though.  If you want the spoilers, go read her great review and imagine that ending instead. :)
summary: As a whole, not rating just the ending

reviewText: I want to separate my enjoyment of the story from the actual quality. I will say in the end I was glad I hadn't felt really connected to the characters. Reading it I thought the writing was fine. I am normally a devourer when I read, not putting a book down until I'm done. I was able to put this book down. I'm not sure what that says about the book. My students who read it were not pleased and are very sorry for the investment of time spent reading and waiting. I believe one comment from one student was "I waited a year for this?" There were a few other comments but we are all trying to keep the talk to a minimum until everyone who is currently reading can get through it.
summary: Hard to give stars to a story you don't enjoy

reviewText: I think the final book is sad. I can't argue with the conclusion, it is appropriate, but I don't have to like it.
This books was not as fast of a read as the others but that may have been because knowing it was the last book I read slower. I was more sad that the series was over than for the ending itself!!
I was sad for Tris but it was described beautifully.  I was engrossed in the last 20% of the book.

I think it's important when you start a book series you should see it through. Was the VR's best work in my opinion .....absolutely not. Are the characters still wonderful and capture your heart absolutely!  Did she take a risk with her choice to end the book the way she did absolutely. I didn't need a happy ever after ending but there was so much wordiness that I don't feel Allegiant grabbed you like the other two books did.  Tris and  Tobia's romance doesn't have the same heat as the other books.  The back and forth between Tris and Tobias was unnecessary because you never gained any deeper perspectives. Maybe she took this writing approach because she was going to surprise us  with the ending.I advise you read it to see the series through. There are moments, not many, where you see her spark from the previous novels return but I have to agree it 's very luke warm.
summary: You have to see it through guys!!!!!!

reviewText: I liked this book better than the second one but not as much as the first one. I liked that the author alternated between Tris and Four narrating chapters. It was a strong ending but I just didn't care as much about the characters or plot.

I loved Allegiant. I have stayed with this series since it started and I will always remember it. I loved and hated this ending so much. The fact that Roth has Tris die is brave to do as an author and I salute her for it, but at the same time my endless love and hope for Tris and a happy ending with Tobias was killed. Brutally. I loved Tris so much she reminded me of myself and the way i want to be. I know thatt clearly this story isn't real, but in the heart of a true reader it is and today my heart was broken. I will miss Tris and props to Roth on one of the most beautiful and heartfelt endings in a book. The beauty she captured within Tobias after the death of Tris was done to complete perfection. Thanks for these books. I recommend them to everyone.
summary: WHAT A MESSED UP WAY TO END THE BOOK. EVIL.

reviewText: I can not begin to express my disappointment in this book. The author could have gone in so many directions. So she wanted to kill off Tris, fine. But seriously, Tobias just goes back to Chicago to live out the rest of his days. NO one gets further than 100 miles to explore the world which they just discovered is immense? No one seeks to figure out who the government is? No one leaves. Everyone just stays in Chicago. Pathetic. NO one explores the oceans or goes over seas. Ridiculous. Where are your characters! Why are they not exploring. Why are they not trying to unite the world as a whole again?I have been a huge supporter of this series until this last book. Also the way the book was written was enough to drive me mad. Every chapter changing the narrator. Tobia's appeal is that he seems dark, strong. It was alluring. In this conclusion, he comes across a lot weaker than I felt he would be. So they destroyed that character for me.Then, lets briefly touch on the fact that this is a YA book. For pre-teen and teenage kids. You do not have to die to show you are brave. Seriously? The character did not have to die to show she was brave. Why such a depressing end for such a young audience. It was just ridiculous. Then the author goes on and on at the end trying to convince you why Tris had to die to show how brave she was and then Tobia's big tribute is zip lining. WOW. Just WOW.F-The publishers should be ashamed of themselves. It is obvious this author was not ready to truly develop this story properly or well, this is where the author's young age shows through.
Crazy story. It had to end that way. It was believable. Poor Tris poor Tobias... gonna watch the movie now.
summary: It had to end this way

reviewText: The audiobook for Allegiant was terrible.  The narration by Emma Galvin and Aaron Stanford (reading as Tris and Four, respectively) was as flat as Veronica Roth's prose; the narration actually improved once I bumped up the speed to 1.25x.  Like Mockingjay, the 3rd book in the Divergent series appears to have been rushed and the ending is absolute trash.  If you want your faith in YA Dystopian fiction restored, read The 5th Wave by Yancey.  You'll feel a lot better, especially after wasting your time reading this book.
summary: A Flat and Monotone Audiobook -- Just like Roth's Prose

reviewText: SpoilersI didn't not like it because Tris dies.  I didn't like it because what the hec was the point then!? I hated how Tobias was so different.  Just over all left wanting
A disappointing end to a great first book. Plot was undeveloped and confusing. Would no longer recommend this series to others.

I want to make this clear...the reason for the low rating is NOT because of the tragic ending, It's because the whole book seemed out of place compared to the first 2 books. Tobias was out of character for most of the book. The love story was flat. The uniqueness of Tris and the other divergent characters was lost in this book entirely (I can't believe the author made it so Tobias was not divergent). All divergence meant was that they were Genetically Pure. So all the build up in the previous 2 books led to one big disappointment.
summary: The reason for the low rating is NOT because of the tragic ending...

reviewText: No fairytale ending but thoroughly enjoyed reading the whole series. I had a lot of late nights because I couldn't put it down.
The third and last installment of the Divergent trilogy has you clawing at your hair. You hope Tris and Four make it through everything but there are always road blocks. Wish it had a better ending.

So much hype for another cookie cutter YA novel.  Unfortunately the movies will probably be better than the books as they will have phenomenal special effects and the author just seems to lack a descriptive imagination.

I am dying. I am dead. I am crying. I am dead. I feel like punching something. I feel like I am empty. I am deAd. This book killed me. It made me die. People will wonder what made me so sad. I will tell them a stupid guy named David who shot my best friend.

The ending was weak and lackluster.  I found myself skipping whole sections to get to the end, I was so hopeful for a cool end to the saga... but it was pretty bad.  With the new movie coming out for the first one... I can't imagine them making all three movies with this book so lackluster.

I know the ending was not what we expected. And after reading it I admit I was mad at the author for killing the main character. but if you looked at it this was a good ending its tided all the lose ends. the ending was just not the way we expected it so please look at with not with the dyeing of the main character but the plot of the charters it deserves a 5 star. look at with an open mind and if it made since to you should have cried because I know I did. the main charater died the way she was raised.
must read! only wish there were more story to this and four!!! there's never enough it seems. Sad for it to be the last book...
How could it end like this? I'm so mad and upset. I will never read from this author again. She better think about using a pen name. I'm so disappointed with the ending.

I loved this series! A well written book can make your emotions change rapidly. I went from loving Tobias to thinking he was a cowardly cry baby and then back to loving him. The author made you hate Peter and then by the end of the book, you started to like him and even feel bad for him. I really enjoyed how well these books were written although I wish the ending had been a bit different but only because this one made me cry. This set is a must read!

I couldn't wait for this book to be released, but when I started reading it I knew it was going to be a disappointment.  I hate to read the book in spurts because I just couldn't get into it.  I tried over and over again to read it.  It took me almost 3 months to read  when the first two books I blew through in 3 days.  I hoped it was going to get better or at least that the end would make all the torture of the rest of the book worth it.  It didn't.  When I finally did finish the book all I thought was I should have stopped back in November when I first tried reading it.  This book ruined the whole series for me!  I got my husband into the series and he couldn't read this book either too boring.  I ended up just telling him what happened and he's glad he didn't bother reading it either.  I will admit that I'm not so much a happy ending kind of person, but I will admit when a sad ending is really good.  The ending in Allegiant was sad, but a very far cry from good.
summary: Loved the first two.  Hate the last book!

reviewText: It really picked up the final third ... And I want to know why the author choose the ending.  I didn't like that choice.  But still as good as the other two books.

reviewText: This book is awe-inspiring amazingly written and so action-filled! Another rollercoaster of emotions! You'll love this book and say "Where's Your Next BIG book Veronica Roth?"

I know a lot of reader's may have been disappointed in the ending of this series, but I for one, was not.  As a writer, I recognize that it took guts for Roth to make the choices she did and they were, indeed, the right choices.  Roth has taken these children, who were never really allowed to be children, and evolved them into these powerful beings.  They suffer loss, pain, love, betrayal and more loss to the point that as with the characters in the book, she's taken us on this emotional journey of true self awareness that is nothing short of stunning.  Allegiant, isn't a sentimental farewell, it is a force of nature, annihilating the will of the readers desire for an ending with a neat pretty little bow.  Allegiant, is real and best of all, complete,  That's all any reader should want at the end of such an emotionally commanding series.  To those who have yet to read this last book I say, Be brave.Oh, and get a box of tissue.

Compared to the previous two books, this one has less action and therefore, gives more time for characters, relationships, philosophical/moral debates, which was fine.  Without spoilers, I was disappointed in the overall injustice of the ending, considering the entire series was about justice.  There's a delicate balance in the amount of injustice I believe a reader should endure (out of our control since we didn't write the book), but Mrs. Roth tipped the scales in my opinion.  For instance, if you're going to allow for the elimination of a character, then the natural outcome would be that justice would be served for the reason the character was eliminated.  The ending was unbalanced in my opinion.  I could have accepted "X" as long as "Y" happened to bring closure to the story.

I was very excited to read the last installment of the "Divergent" trilogy, "Allegiant." I pre-ordered it on my Kindle, and could not wait to read it once it was available! My excitement soon turned to disappointment as I continued to read. How could this author take a story so promising and turn it to utter crap?!***May Contain Spoilers***I really disliked the shared POV Ms. Roth used between Tris and Tobias. There were often times I had to look back at the beginning of the chapter to see who's POV it was being told from. The personalities of Tris and Tobias were totally watered down to the point I couldn't tell which one was narrating a given chapter. Every other chapter is alternated between being told by Tris and Tobias. A good writer does not need to tell you who's POV the story is being told from, at times I felt like I was reading a bad fanfiction.The plot was substandard. I liked how the other two books addressed the dissidence between the factions, and how Tris was breaking that mold, by not taking on the personality of one faction vs. another. Wasn't the original purpose of "Divergent", to show there were others that didn't fit into the "cookie cutter mold" of a particular faction, and that they were more or so "free thinking?" "Insurgent" ended on the note that there would be an impending revolution to the current faction system, and I was looking forward to seeing what Tris's part in this would be."Allegiant" focused more on the scientific experiments being performed outside the city. The story was badly put together and at times felt rushed, as if the author couldn't wait to finish and just be done with the series. The people in the city were merely "puppets" whose strings were being pulled by those at the bureau. At times, I compared this book to the movie "The Truman Show."I didn't feel the relationship between Tobias and Tris really grew, or even got the chance. I was so tired of reading about Purity Wars, GD's & GP's, Serums, conspiracies, etc.. I was terribly disappointed how Ms. Roth chose around the 90% mark of the book to kill off a major character. I felt like she killed this character for shock reason only, as there was no purpose to the death. The ending was bad, and really gave no closure. I felt empty.I don't have a problem with killing off characters or even major characters for that fact, but her method was pointless. Also, I disliked how the twisted characters of this book all of a sudden just gave up, and were like "okay we'll do it your way, you win." WEAK!Were these really the same characters from the previous books?? After reading this I do not want to see the movie, knowing how it all turns out, which is EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTING.Ms. Roth was extremely lazy, unorganized, and lacked in giving this story a feeling of depth or character and closure.
summary: Disappointing End to a Promising Trilogy
