I loved the first two books in this series. They were tight, gripping and engrossing. Regrettably, Allegiant is better left on the shelf. My advice is to read the first two, and then decide for yourself what happens after that. I can almost guarantee you'll be more satisfied with your version than with Allegiant's. So many readers have wished they had done that, including me! Below I give the reasons why, as vaguely as possible to try to avoid spoilers.The book is not as well-written as the first two. It is much slower since most of the book is just informational or relational conversations, and the characterizations are sloppy. There is too much overt moralizing (though some of the points made are great). There are many things alluded to in all three books which are never capitalized or expanded on, which could have been utilized to tell a better story, but instead the main plot line is a rehash of Insurgent. And some devices were distracting... whenever I saw the initials "GP" and "GD" I had to think about what they stood for, and I often had to go back and check whether it was Tris or Tobias narrating each chapter. It was a much less gripping read. Worse than all of that, though, is that it is rife with plot holes and character inconsistencies. And worst of all is the ending.There are so many plot holes in the book, both in the science and in the characters, that they bleed together and it's basically just one giant hole. I saw some of these holes while reading it, and others presented themselves afterward. (I bet that among all the reviews on the site all the plot holes have been covered... wonder if someone's made a list?)The first and most glaring plot hole to me, which shows up near the beginning of the book, is this one: No scientist would ever do something (or be allowed to do something, under a normally functioning government) to a large group of people without first extensively testing it. Legitimate scientists under legitimate governments (both of which were apparently the case) ALWAYS do this. Always. And this completely unrealistic action is supposedly the premise of the ENTIRE SERIES. This should have clued me in to what I was in for in the rest of the book.The second glaring one was the reasoning behind the factions. Based on the stated goals of creating the faction systems, "faction before blood" and encouraging people's natural tendencies were the absolutely worst things they could have done, and the exact opposite of what was needed to attain their goals.Another head-scratcher is that all of it takes place in a bubble which does not extend past the Chicago area. There are involved parties elsewhere, but they very oddly do not respond to anything that happens in the book, when by all accounts they should. And the condition of the world outside the U.S. is never described at all. Peter studies a map of the world, but nothing is ever said about what goes on in it, or the possibility of leaving the dystopia they've been in for hundreds of years because of things that occurred ONLY in the U.S. Even though transportation (and a map) is available to just go somewhere else and get help and a better life!As for character holes... where to begin? There were so many characters that I couldn't remember who they all were. Tris and Tobias are almost the opposite of who they were in the other two books. Tobias is dense, annoying and wimpy, and Tris is arrogant and actually becomes a complete hypocrite. The plan she quickly concocts to fix a bad situation is awful, comprised of a suicide mission by someone other than herself (for once) as well as harming a group of innocent people "for the greater good," a concept which was criticized throughout the series, including by Tris herself in Allegiant! Everyone immediately goes along with this as the only available option, though I thought of about 5 other viable and morally sound plans in about 5 minutes--and they had 2 days.As for the ending... the positive reviews of this book tend to express the depth of feeling the ending gave them, its power and its poignancy, and defended it on those grounds. I felt those same emotions and the same power and poignancy immediately after finishing the book. So I could have completely agreed with those reviewers about that and left it there... except for the fact that that particular ending only occurred because of the above-mentioned plot and character holes (which is, besides the ending itself, the main criticism given by the negative reviewers). Everything that happens in the end is based on those holes, and is extremely contrived. So after I stopped being caught up in the emotion, my brain kicked in and didn't let me stay accepting of the way it ended. And as a bit more time passed, I found myself thinking of several other reasons to dislike the conclusion, regardless of its potential power, poignancy, etc etc. I realized that the things that moved me could still have been present with a different ending... and in fact with a better story overall. The ending was completely avoidable, contradictory and over the top, and weakened the story. It's apparently something the author wanted to do all along, so she basically molded the story to achieve a certain ending, and the molding was not well done or believable.So I have to conclude, like so many other reviewers, that the author (who didn't have a reason for Chicago being the way it was when she wrote Divergent) got to a point where she was so successful, and so pressured for the finale, that she got arrogant and careless and was allowed to get away with it and publish a sub-par book. It's really too bad. I will try to put Allegiant out of my head as much as possible, and imagine what else might have happened after the end of Insurgent. And I will hope that there is a really good writer out there who will write a fan fiction alternative to Allegiant!P.S. I saw the Divergent movie tonight. Some reviewers had said that this book would ruin the movie and the series for them. I found that was not the case. The movie was wonderful and I'm so glad I watched it; it took away some of the bad taste I'd had from this book. I wonder how the filmmakers will handle all the problems with Allegiant! Maybe it will get completely rewritten... like, say, the Hobbit (which didn't need rewriting, but that's another review for another time!)

I'll just say: The planes would have already been in the air and the aerosol would have been preloaded hours beforehand.There was never any consideration of place or surroundings when the characters were plotting, time passed at incredibly unreal speeds (ten sentences with Nita lasted ten minutes?) and there were so many filler characters that I lost track of who was who. I'm so sad, so pissed off that I spent so much time loving this series until the very end. I don't ever want to read this book again and feel so hurt and betrayed by an author.I'm sure she's writing more and I'm interested to see her next stories. It is difficult to know where to start. I was really looking forward to this book, and it was an enormous bummer.There were so many " how the heck did we get here" moments. The story lurches from one event to the next. I Kept feeling like I had missed some huge important part of the story. Tobias/Four seemed to have some sort of major personality meltdown. He was an entirely different character. I expected that there would be some maturation of Tobias and Tris in this third book, but they seemed to have regressed instead. Their relationships to the new characters had no forethought, no logic.The alternating point of view between Tris and Tobias was confusing. They had the same voice. I kept having to stop and try to remember who was talking. After a while I gave up trying.As for the ending... Yes, it was unexpected, and heartbreaking,. Beyond that, it did not make any sense to the plot of the entire series. The way Tobias' emotional reaction was handled through all those sort little chapters was...well... stupid (I really tried to find a different word.) Those were not chapters. Did Veronica Roth have a chapter quota to meet?I can picture this story being rewritten into two separate volumes with the missing plot and character development fleshed out properly. I would not read them though unless the ending was changed to fit the plot progression from the previous books, and to show maturation of the characters.

Wow. When I started this last addition to the Divergent series I wasn't sure what to think. Too many books between the last one made me a little fuzzy about what was going on in this world and I had heard about the upset with some readers over the ending. I have to say I loved it, thought it was the best book in the entire series and was a beautiful, albeit sad, ending. This is a dystopian novel, there are going to be deaths and even though society often works out for the better at the end of these books it often comes with a very high cost. This book is no different. I think Allegiant is pretty realistic, for a made up harsh reality set in the future, I mean...I think the characters stayed true to their character and did what needed to be done and reacted to the events unfolding in an honest way.Tris's sacrifice was a noble one and it didn't surprise me at all. Once I knew someone was going into the weapons room and face the death serum I knew it would be her and that she would be able to handle it. It is tragic that it was bullets in the end did her in. My hear breaks for Tobias and his loss, he spends his whole life looking for love, of any kind, finds it and then loses it. I am happy that he is able to find love and acceptance with his mother though and hope his able to someday move on from Tris in this new world they fought for.I did enjoy learning in this book what exactly happen to the world we live in to turn it into the one in the book. Sometimes in dystopian novels you get this destroyed world/society but no back story as to how it ended up that way. This is something I wish more authors of these types of stories would share.The end was sad. I finished the last 50-60 pages in tears last night in bed. My heart broke for the loss of beloved friends and especially for those who must live on. After finishing, though, I did have a sense of peace over it all and felt it was a good end for this series. Thank you Ms. Roth for sharing it with us. It truly was a beautiful and tragic journey.

I know everyone and their dog will be harping on the ending... not to beat a dead horse, but I'm right there with them.I didn't hate the ending because it wasn't a pat, fairytale-happy ending.  I hated it because there was alot of tension and build-up in the main character's relationship that pretty much amounted to, er, NOTHING.  The ending did not seem realistic.  It was annoying that there was a huge amount of build up only to be left flat.  This is just my feeling.2 stars because it was the third book in a series that started off fabulously.  I would not have finished this book except that I reread the first two and needed resolution.  I think that is a sign of good writing... in the first two books.I agree with other readers: the mechanism of having two POVs was forced.  It was one way to handle the plot twist at the end but not the only way.  The author did not have a good handle on two distinct voices for Tris and Tobias.  As a result, it was often only the name heading up the chapter that allowed me to know who the hell was talking.My thirteen year old daughter who reads far more difficult literature, became bored within a couple chapters and abandoned the book entirely.  This is nearly unheard of for her, but kudos to her for not sticking around to watch a literary 'bad accident' to unfold.Me, I just had to put the series to bed.  It was a quick, easy read.  That fact made it feel even more cheap- like the author was cashing in on her success with "Divergent".  Such a shame!  This series had so much potential.  I was hoping 'Insurgent' was just a little weak because it was getting the plot back to where we could see some of the awesomeness of 'Divergent' again.Sad.

As anyone can see from the other reviews, people are upset. Most are mad with the ending, and I understand that. But what really frustrated me with the novel was the fact that it does not fit with the other two. The first and second parts are fantastic and are hard to put down! Allegiant, however, lacks the magic for a couple of reasons.First, there are two different point of views. Usually when an author does this, it allows the reader even greater insight to BOTH characters, but in this case, it only was used in order to continue the book when one of them dies. It does get confusing as to who is talking in each chapter and the characters do not grow. We learn little about each that we didn't know before.Secondly, the plot was slow. They immediately enter the potential plot in the beginning (no spoilers, I promise), but then that's it. Nothing truly happens that is significant. Life goes on, and it feels like "blah, blah, blah". Everything that happens is not significant. In addition, I feel like the character's reactions are not that realistic. If I was in their position and found out what they did, I'd be freaking out. They just are like, "oh, ok." Who does that? You would never expect that from these characters, especially after the events of the first two.Finally, the end. This is the reason most people are mad. I've read a bunch of novels with a similar ending, and I don't really have a problem with it. People should react the way they are, because, if they don't, then the character didn't make an impact. I just wish it wasn't so anticlimactic and predictable. You know it's coming.I gave it 3 stars because I feel like there is potential, and I do recommend reading it just because you have to know what happens. But, I just can't give it more- there are too many issues. Sorry, Roth. I really did think it could have been carried out much better.

WARNING----->SPOILERS AHEAD!**************NOTE: Before I get into anything in regards to this book I am stating right now and as clear as day that there will be spoilers in this review. If I could get around it I would but it is basically impossible based on this being a last book in a series and what actually went down in the book. If you do not want to be spoiled I suggest that you stop reading right now, pick up the book, and then come back and see what I have to say.First things first, Allegiant was by far the best series ending I have ever read. Now with saying this I have to tell you my sentiment is in the minority. People are furious with how this book ended. They feel cheated and they feel used and there is a huge controversy brewing over this. But for me Allegiant was the perfect ending for a series about choices and it really couldn't have gone any better. It broke my heart, gave me such book anxiety that I was dreaming about the characters(a good Theo James dream never hurt anyone!) and affected me in a way a series never has before. Veronica Roth made a gutsy choice much like the choices in the series and I applaud her for that decision.Allegiant is the final chapter in the story of Tris, Four and company and dystopian Chicago. After the cliffhanger ending that was Insurgent and the death and carnage that was Divergent Allegiant is the story of what is outside the city walls. About what is true and what has been falsified. About how the city came to be what it is today. About the choices we all make. About life and death. Armed with the knowledge that there is life outside the city walls Tris and Four and a few other familiar faces journey away from the tumultuous world where Evelyn(Four's mother) is a tyrannical leader to an unknown place that is as strange as it is familiar. Integrating themselves into this new society which has no factions but a Bureau and a clear division between what is known as GPs(genetically pure) and GDs(genetically damaged). As lies begin to be uncovered and sides are drawn Tris and Four have to make some hard choices that could affect themselves, their loved ones and their relationship forever.Okay so I'm the first to admit that Allegiant is very heavy with the world building which is completely understandable in this case. Us, as readers, needed a clear picture of just exactly was taking place outside the fence. And even though it is heavy with world building I think Roth did it pretty flawlessly by never using 50 words when 10 could suffice(a pet peeve of mine) and making sure we felt like part of the world, could see all sides of the argument, had a choice on what to believe ourselves. And although it was a lot of information I think it aided in the story as we got to see just what this characters were up against. Simply put, discrimination was happening between the GPs and the GDs and Roth made sure the readers saw that so we understood the choices that Tris and Four had whether we agreed with them or not.Another part of Allegiant that was different but worked was the use of dual points of views. From the first two books we only got to see Tris perspective, her thoughts on things, her reasoning behind why she was behaving the way she was. Making another tough decision Roth decided to tell Allegiant using Four's voice as well and I have to say I was a little worried about this when I heard the announcement that this would be the set up for Allegiant. But in true Roth fashion she made a believer out of me. From the first time a chapter was from Four's POV I knew exactly why she had decided to go that route and I embraced it. I was no longer left to wonder what was going on in the sexy, former Dauntless instructors head. I no longer had to wonder if he really had any flaws or doubts or self-esteem issues. It was nice to finally see Four as a broken boy that felt uncertain of his past and of his future and of himself. Up until this point it was hinted at that he didn't want to be like his father and that was a fear of his, but Allegiant brought it to the surface and showed just how much damage was done emotionally to him by both of his parents.Allegiant also showed the growth of Tris. In Divergent she was a naive girl just trying to fit in and do what she thought was right. In Insurgent she was a girl that had demons she couldn't escape and in trying to do so became self-destructive and had no thoughts for the others that loved her. But in Allegiant Tris was his powerhouse girl that made tough calls and no longer was a adrenaline junkie. She grew up and was ready to do what was right and to make the choices she had to. Was this damning to her relationship to Four at times, it was, but I also understood where it was coming from. The ups and downs in their relationship, although uncomfortable for me to read, were natural as they made choices the other didn't agree with, but I never once didn't feel the love or the connection or their emotional bond. Someone in the book said it best, they were really good for each other.<MAJOR SPOILER ALERT>But really, all of my thoughts on the above is nothing compared to what happened in the final 10% of the book that rocked a fan base across the world. A decision that was so gutsy that it left infuriated people in its wake. Roth did the one thing that very few authors are will to do. She killed off one of her main characters...she killed off Tris. And you know what, she made the right decision. I'm not going to sugarcoat it, I cried, straight up ugly cry, sobbing for the last 30 minutes of reading this book. My heart was 100% shattered and it ached when I was finished. But I still think one of the most gusty calls was the right call because everything aside it fit right in with everything that we knew about Tris and the Divergent series from the beginning. This series from the get go was about choices. The Choosing Ceremony, picking faction over blood, choosing sides, choosing violence over piece, choosing the city over life outside the fence, choosing to live or die, choosing to leave. Everything was about choices and when it came down to it the biggest choice had to be made by Tris and she did it in a way she never thought fit her. She did it after being told time and time again that she would never have this characteristic. She did it out of pure selflessness and that is why Roth made the right call. Tris was one of the most selfless people in the book and by giving her life, her safety up to save the lives of all of the people that had helped her and touched her and loved her, she did the most selfless thing a person could do. She choose them.So yes, I know that my opinion is on an island of its own. I know that Allegiant is unfairly being racked through the coals and I also know that if people took a minute to think about it and to think of all the pieces that feel into place through the series and the guts it took for Roth to do this to one of her babies, I think you will start to see the magic that is Allegiant. I think you will start to see why this book is my pick for best series ender. You'll see why I wasn't disappointed even though it devastated me.  Veronica Roth did something amazing with Allegiant and I will forever be grateful to her for bringing this story and these people into my life. And for having the guts to do it the way she did. Bravo Ms. Roth, bravo!

Like many I waited long months for the much anticipated sequel to Insurgent.Like many, I was left disappointed.In Divergent, Veronica Roth created a gritty dystopian world that did a beautiful job of tying the trials of personal morality into a society that epitomizes the argument of Nature vs. Nurture.  These arguments are continued in Insurgent where we discover this dystopian society is nothing but an artifice.In the finale of a Dystopian trilogy, my major expectation is that where a big Sociological question is asked, an answer will be given and supported by arguments presented through the storyline.  MOCKINGJAY's big failure was not even bothering to answer the question.  Allegiant gave an answer, but only TOLD the argument, all attempts to SHOW us the answer were muted and overshadowed by the use of one of the poorest plot devices ever invented - the memory serum. Instead of a valiant fight against their treatment, their NURTURE, the "heroes" ended up just showing their NATURE by using their resistance to serums to use the memory serum to cheat the system.  It was so full of mixed messages that it imploded on itself.Divergent also included a strong vein of YA Romance, with a hero and heroine that drove the story and whom we all loved.  I won't go as far as to say you should NEVER kill the heroine in a YA Romance, but if you do, it needs to be a transcendent moment, a supreme sacrifice, the emotional crucible of the entire story.  The readers need to feel both saddened and fulfilled by the loss.  Tris's death was none of these things.  Getting shot while using the aforementioned poor plot device (memory serum) was not an emotional moment, unless getting pissed at the author counts (which it doesn't).Like HUNGER GAMES, DIVERGENT showed so much promise.  Like MOCKINGJAY, ALLEGIANT failed to deliver.  I will at least give Veronica Roth credit in that she didn't give up, she at least gave it a try.
summary: Better than Mockingjay, but only just

I had seen some reviews prior to reading the book but avoided spoilers.  I expected that the fanatics were very angry because they didn't like the ending, and I admit my own prejudices regarding the “novella” releases feeling that the author had sort of lost her way when the movie deal happened.  So the beginning of the book was a struggle because I was looking for the issues and decline.First, there is no quick recap of where we were in the story.  I’m sorry, it had been 4 months since I read book 2 (the novellas don’t count because they were not related to the plot at the end of book 2).  I've read many books between and since I’m not a Divergent fanatic, I would have appreciated a short refresher.  Next biggest issue was the changing point of view between Tris and Tobias.  The chapter’s listed whose point of view we were reading but isn't that an indication of the problem with this format?  Even with this notation, I’d sometimes page back to check because it was hard to know whose voice I was reading.Spoiler alert starts here…I assume that the author used the changing point of views because of the ending but maybe writing in the third person would have been a better solution.  The first two books were written from Tris’ point of view and some novellas were from Tobias’ point of view, but the combination was confusing in the third book.  I didn't like that Tobias was weak throughout this book.  He wasn't the reluctant leader we were used to, but more a lost soul.  I don’t know if it was a device because he was out of his element and environment or not.  I didn't like that his mother became a crying brooding mess when she had been so brutally strong, and that she gave in without a blink of an eye.  And like other reviewers, it would have been nice to better understand exactly why Tris was immune to all the serums and more about her being gene purified.The short chapters made the pace of the book move along quickly for me.  And I suddenly realized that I was getting into the story for the first time in all the books and didn't want to put the book down.  I had forgotten about the bad reviews and my opinion of the novellas.  The very very very short chapters for Tobias at the end helped express his emotional crisis poignantly.  The fanatics may not have liked it but I thought Tobias’ reactions were very emotional and the final zip line trip well written.  There was some preachiness at the end that I could have done without but it wasn't over the top.If you’re a fanatic, you won’t be happy to lose a loved character and feel that there was no retribution.  I debated between 3 and 4 stars and decided to go with 4 because I liked this book better than the first two.  I like happy endings in fiction, but I know they can’t always turn out that way.  This series doesn't end with a ribbon, but it was satisfactorily written to me.Format: Borrowed eBook

Of course, if a reader has enjoyed the first two, they should certainly read the final installment, but be warned for the same disappointment I felt.This does not mean I did not enjoy the book at all. I found the tender moments between Tris and Four addictive and I was happy with Tris' ever-growing strength as a leader and warrior, HOWEVER, I found myself bored by the lack of action and some of the supporting characters. It almost felt like even more description could have been included to develop the characters and plot more (but that would probably elicit complaints about length or need for another book).I was also frustrated with Four through a majority of the novel. I know he was going through an identity crisis, but he seemed to lose the strength and resolve that made him so damn sexy in the first two.SPOILER ALERT: I was also very upset with the ending. Now, this may be biased because I want the couples of my favorite fictions to end up happily ever after (I know that is not how the real world works), and that was not the case. I get the theme that Roth was aiming for, about war never being kind and sacrifices and all that depressing realistic nonsense, but COME ON! I couldn't believe it was happening when I read it. I live in the real world, I get enough depressing realistic nonsense that I want to escape from when reading my favorite novels. But, that's just me. I really did enjoy the epilogue and how Four's character grew and learned from the experience, but still...now if there was a spin-off where a spunky blonde teacher (aka me) hooks up with Four, then I might be satisfied.Okay, tirade over. I love Roth's writing and I commend her on staying true to her intentions and doling out the tough love to her readers, but I will probably prefer to think of Insurgent as the ending to this trilogy (and pray that they change the Allegiant movie, or I am going to be a sobbing mess!)Angela Youngers, author and book loverPainting Wallsconnect with Angela on Twitter: @AngelaYoungers

reviewText: Divergent was fantastic, Insurgent wasn't too bad, but Allegiant was just too far from anything I could relate to.  I was completely lost on the concept, like it didn't quite gel with the other two books.  The ending left me feeling a bit ripped off to tell you the truth.

Trying to avoid any spoilers in this review, so forgive me if it is too vague.I loved this Divergent series and was so excited about the movie coming out... until I read this book.  Unlike the first two books, which I read in a day or two because I couldn't put them down, it took me weeks to get through this book, because it was BORING.  Absolutely nothing happens for chapters and chapters; the characters just wander around learning the back story.As for the back story, it makes absolutely no sense.  The plot is nonsensical and everyone acts completely out of character.  I won't say more about the actual plot to avoid posting spoilers, but many reviewers have already written very thoughtful criticisms of the specific plot points, which I completely agree with.The writing is also sub-par.  The use of dual voices is a tricky thing to do well, and this book fails.  Both voices sound the same.  Just like all the other reviewers, I had to page back to the heading of each chapter to remind myself whose viewpoint I was reading.  If you are interested in a dystopian book that does dual viewpoints well, check out Legend by Marie Lu.As for the "experiments" premise of the book, if you are interested in that kind of story, check out the Maze Runner series by James Dashner.  The reason that series succeeds while this one fails, is that Dashner is comfortable leaving many details unexplained.  This book tries to explain every last question, down to the very genetics, and the explanations make no sense.Finally, obviously one can't write a review of this book without addressing the ending.  I was very disappointed in the ending -- not because of what happened, but because just like the rest of the plot, it made no sense, and therefore lacked any emotional impact whatsoever.  The only emotion I felt was annoyance that the author was so clearly trying to manipulate me.Really not sure what happened with this book; perhaps it was rushed to press to finish the series before the movies come out.  As for the movies, I will not be going to see them.  If you're already invested in this series, having read the first two books, then I guess you have to slog through this one to get closure.  But if you can possibly stand having the series end on the cliffhanger at the end of Insurgent, I'd honestly suggest just pretending Allegiant doesn't exist at all.

***DOES CONTAIN SPOILERS*****DOES CONTAIN SPOILERS***DOES CONTAIN SPOILERS*DOES CONTAIN SPOILERSThis was a spectacular ending to a spectacular series.  However, first of all, let me get my one complaint out of the way.  I hate the shifting viewpoints in this book.  The book shifts from chapter to chapter from Tobias to Tris.  Normally, I have NO PROBLEM with shifting viewpoints whatsoever, however, in this particular series, the first two books were told COMPLETELY from Tris' point of view.  Changing that around in the third and final book was very irritating because I wasn't used to it.  I'd start reading a chapter and get three or four pages into the chapter and then there would be a line similar to this:  "I can't believe I'm looking at the man who tried to kill my girlfriend."And I would be completely turned around.  I'd think, "Wait... Someone tried to kill Tris' <I>girl</I>friend?  Tris <I>had</I> a girlfriend?  That makes no sense."  And then, of course, I'd realize, "Oh yes.  This is another Tobias chapter."  I feel like, if the author was going to be flip-flopping viewpoints, she should have found a way to do so throughout the entire series or not at all.However, despite that irritating inconvenience, I loved the book.  It wasn't a shocking revelation like I think the author was going for, but it didn't matter.  It was still wonderfully put together and is a wonderful comment on the state of governmental affairs and absolute power.Also, there are not very many books -- especially YA novels -- that have anything other than a typical, Hollywood happy-ending these days.  That is why the ending to this novel -- this series -- was so poignant and perfect.  Tris' final sacrifice to save the world -- as well as her brother who betrayed her -- was the perfect ending to this series.  There is not a single way this book could have ended that would have been better.

*Review from [...]*WARNING: THIS POST CONTAINS SPOILERS. LIKE BIG TIME SPOILERS. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED.****Another series has come and gone, but very few have gone out in such a bang as Allegiant did. Veronica Roth took a risk and did something we rarely see in YA fiction: she killed off her main, point of view, character, and I bow down to her for it. I have a lot to say about that, but let me start with this: The book couldn't have ended differently. No matter how upset you are or how much you hate Veronica Roth now, this is the ending she thought would best suit the story, and she's one hundred percent vindicated for it. You can (and should because it's quite beautiful) read her response here.Don't get me wrong, I cried like a baby. So much so that I had to make myself a cup of tea and watch the entirety of Dirty Dancing at 3 a.m. in order to stop feeling so upset. But I love that Tris died, and I love how it ended, so if you want to hate me for that, go for it.Here's what I liked: First off, I really liked the entire genetic experiment plot line. It was completely unexpected and I thought it was a realistic concept for what was outside the city. There was also a lot of room for all that drama to go down so that was a nice touch, and I appreciate her adding some interesting new characters to the story. I loved that Tobias forgave his mother. I never hated Evelyn, I disliked the lengths she was willing to go to to "save" the city, but I never hated her. She was doing what she thought was best. But I'm glad that she and Tobias were able to put it in the past and patch up their relationship, it was what Tobias needed. With his father being the awful human that he was, and Tris dying, it wouldn't have been fair to leave Tobias all on his own.What I didn't like: I love that it was in dual point of view, but I feel like there wasn't a lot of difference in tone between Tobias and Tris. Now, it wasn't horrible and I could still tell whose POV we were in, but it would have been nice to see a difference in the way they thought (though maybe that makes them even more perfect together?). That's the short list of what I didn't like, and we can now move on to my spiel on Tris's death.This is important. Rule number one. If you never take away anything from any of these posts but this, that would be okay. Never, never, never threaten an author because you didn't like the way a book ended. Threats aren't okay, guys, and from what I've heard, Veronica got a lot of them. Like I said before, she wrote what would best serve the book and she planned this from the very beginning of the series. You're all entitled to your own opinions, and emotional responses are the best, but just don't threaten writers because you didn't like their decisions. Not cool.Now here's why I think Tris's death was possibly one of the greatest things to happen in YA history, and maybe what caused this book to head to the top of my favorite series list: It was the ultimate sacrifice. Like the lovely Shailene Woodley said in an interview, Tris is constantly battling between being fearless and being selfless, being Dauntless or Abnegation. In the end, she didn't have to choose between the two, they were both a part of who she was. By sacrificing her life for her city and the people she loved, she was fearless and selfless, a true member of both factions. Tris gives a beautiful speech before she dies that really shows why this had to happen. On page 473, she says, "She [her mother] taught me all about real sacrifice. That is should be done from love, not misplaced disgust for another person's genetics. That is should be done from necessity, not without exhausting all other options. That is should be done for people who need your strength because they don't have enough of their own." This is a completely different girl from the start of the series, this is a woman who has been through hell and back and has made the decision to do what's best for other people. And she's not terrified, she accepts it. Hello, character development. Also as a side note, Tobias's reaction is heartbreaking and very real. He's angry and he's numb and he carries it with him forever. That part was, to me, harder to read than the actual death scene itself. Four for you Veronica Roth, you go Veronica Roth. (Other side note, if you really want to have a good cry, read the death scene and listen to "Oblivion" by Bastille... and then prepare for the waterworks)Those are my thoughts, and you can agree or disagree as much as you want. I just think it was a poetic ending and I wouldn't want to change a thing. I could talk about this book for days, and I would like to apologize to the people who are still having to listen to me talk about it. So, thank you, Veronica. Thank you for taking the risk and having the guts to write your story the way it wanted to be written. Thank you for letting us all be a part of Tris's life and adventures, the good and the bad. Thank you.

You know those reviews that say "If I could give it zero stars I would"? Yeah, this is gonna be one of them.So, we finally get all the answers we wanted - and nothing else. For me, a good story should leave the read with questions. Not about the plot or the characters, but about the overall meaning and theme. For example, JK Rowling never does answer if Snape is a good person. She tells us he's a brave person, which yes he is, but not if he's morally correct or not. That's left up to the readers, and we've continued to discuss (read: argue endlessly) that topic.This book doesn't do that. Tris and Tobias were so preachy I wanted to throw this book across the room. Every chapter is filled with some sort of "wisdom" about the humanity. The thing is, all the preachy quips are obviously just the author's own opinions about the world. None of it fits the characters and it really pulled me out of the story.For example:"And now that you're out? How does the world seem to you?""Mostly the same, people are just divided by different things, fighting different wars."This would have been wise, if the author had bothered for it to be in character, for it to fit the present situation, and if it was brought up later for the sake of something like consistency.But we didn't just get answers about 'what it means to be human' oh no we also got answers about 'what it means to be divergent'. Let me tell you something, if it was possible to murder books, I would have murdered this one on the basis of poor research and world building alone.This paragraph is where things get a little spoilery, not by much, just a little warning. At one point we're told about "murder genes" and how they're the cause for human aggression. Not long after that we're told that if you take away someone's low intelligience you take away their compassion as well. Yes, you read that right, apparently in order for someone to be nice they have to be dumb as well. And this is the part that made me have to turn off my kindle and just pace for about half an hour, whispering things under my breath that if my mother had heard me she would have sent me to a psychiatrist. Because this is such crap. Compassion, or treating people with understanding and kindness, comes from empathy. Empathy comes from you being able to relate to someone, to see things from their point of view. Do you think that if someone wasn't smart they would be able to do that?When the research is actually truthful, it's highschool-level. At some point we learn about the difference between memories of personal experience and memories of how to do things. The difference between remembering what the weather was like when we learned to ride a bike and how to ride a book. We learn that those two types of memories are stored in difference types of the brain. This is passed as very science-y and advanced and all I could think about was "I literally learned this in highschool psychology class"I'm getting worked up again, so we're just going to move onto the characters, or lack thereof. When I read Divergent, I saw that the characters could use more dimensionality, but there were two more books so I figured that they would develop into more complex people later on. Not at all.As you probably know by now, this book is in both Tris and Tobias point of view. Every time the POV switched to Tobias I had a hard time remembering he wasn't Tris. The author obviously didn't know how to write this character beyond "badass boyfriend". For most of the book all we get out of Tobias is that he pities himself because of something revealed about his genetics. There is a giant ton of fake man-pain going on in this book. I was rolling my eyes so much I thought they were going to fall out. When he finally gets a grip on himself, he becomes so bland I almost wanted to the brooding man-child back. Almost.Then we have Tris who has somehow changed into a full on not-gonna-take-any-shit-from-nobody-cause-i'm-tough badass woman. I didn't believe any of it for a second. The author's idea of what makes a 'strong' character seems more to be of what makes a 'cool' character. Tris is trying too hard to prove to the reader that she's strong and I got sick of it real fast. And there's really nothing to her beyond that. She's strong. That's it. Apparently she's smart too, but none of the scenes where she's supposed to be showing off her 'intelligence' convinced me because all of it was freaking obvious.Then we have the side characters. They all had exactly one personality trait and that was it, just like the first book. Nothing about them has changed. Characters like Cara, Christina and Uriah are just the smart one, the best friend, and the funny one. Characters like Peter and Evelyn make character changes that are so forced and fast I had whiplash. One paragraph they’re one thing, and then the next they’re another.Remember how at the first book the conflict was about the factions all against each other? And then at the second book it was the factionless against the factions? We sort of get an answer to that conflict, but it happens off screen. Yes, that's right, what this entire trilogy has been building up to be was quickly tied up in a bow when we weren't looking.We find out more about Tris' mom, and once again I didn't care. We find more about the world outside the city, and I don't care. Tris at point thinks her parents would be ashamed of her, and I don't care. Quite a few people die, and I don't care. What I'm trying to say here is that character complexity and development needs to be the most important thing for a writer. If you don't give me a reason to like these characters beyond "This one is cool, this one has a tortured past, this one is sassy, this one is funny" I'm not going to like them. And I'm definitely not going to care about what or who they do.TLDR: This book is full of the author's preachy opinions forced on us as 'wisdom', absolutely no character development, some of the worst worldbuilding I've ever seen, research that was done so poorly I had to stop reading to calm myself done, and an ending that is forced and overly-melodramatic. Don't read it. It will ruin the entire trilogy for you. I'm sure there's at least one fanfiction AU online, go read that, I'm sure it's written much better.

reviewText: A page turner for sure-- and a must read.  Roth knows how to tells a great story and you can't help but want more!

Oh, Ms. Roth!  Why?!  WHYYYYYYYYY!!????!!!Seriously.I loved Divergent.  And I liked Insurgent (though slightly less, as it suffered from that part-two-of-a-trilogy-kinda-pointless syndrome).  Despite that, I was excitedly looking forward to Allegiant.  I was ready to savor the relationship between Tris & Tobias, ready to get to the bottom of this mystery.I have to admit, I was was not a big fan of the dual-perspectives.  I've read a couple of the e-books from Tobias's perspective (Free Four and The Transfer) and they were just okay.  Most of Allegiant feels flat, missing the voice that drew us in with Divergent.  TRIS was that draw, that voice, the character that we saw evolving and growing (though admittedly making some stupid choices in book 2).  TRIS'S PERCEPTIONS OF TOBIAS were the draw -- feeling the attraction from her POV.  And I cannot believe that Roth went the ending route that she did.  It was just heartbreaking.  HEARTBREAKING.  I cried like a baby ... and it wasn't the such-a-good-book!-everyone-enjoys-a-good-cry type of cry.Oh no.  It was a big nasty cry.  And every time I thought of the ending, for hours after finishing the novel, my face would crumple and I'd be sniffling all over again.  Such a disappointment.I usually enjoy reading and rereading my favorite novels/series.  But I don't know that I can go back and reread Divergent & Insurgent now.  I kind of feel like it's been ruined for me.  Darn it, where's my tissues.  Stupid book.ETA:  Okay, now that I've stopped weeping every time I think of the book, I am raising my rating by one star.  I am still disappointed in the ending ... I wanted MORE from this book.  More explanation of the world they are in, more good moments between Tris & Tobias, more closure for some of the other events/characters.  The last third of the book feels a bit rushed; I wish we could've drawn it out, fleshed things out a bit more, given Tris some better final moments.

Are they stuck in the City? Can they not leave? What’s out there? reviewText: I loved Divergent, the first book; I liked Insurgent, the second book; I did not like Allegiant, the third book, and I'll tell you why.  This series, like so many series, starts off with an exciting BANG!  You open the first page and hit the ground running; you're caught up in the book's newness, caught up in its fresh concept.  Divergent was like that for me.  I was very interested in the "faction" aspect of the book and how those factions mimic people in our own society.  Tris was a believable character; Four was believable, and I liked the way their relationship developed.  Insurgent still had some of the "magic," I suppose, but it started to lose some of that original fascination for me -- then came the last book, Allegiant.  Everything seemed to decline in this one: the characters, the setting, the relationships between people, the plot...and Roth ended the book in a way that I would have never thought she would.  That ending alone sealed the fate of this book for me!  It was like watching a very long movie & at the end you have to say: REALLY?  That's IT?  THAT'S the end?  Roth may want to re-write this one!
If you havent read this book what are you waiting for? It is a nail bitter to the end. I couldnt put it down

SPOILER ALERT: Yet another Hunger Games, the series starts off with a big bang and gets our hopes up and then crashes and burns in the end. I feel let down like many other readers. The writer gets us invested and then kills the heroine after everything they have been through, come on...

I have just finished Allegiant after having read all three books in the span of exactly three days.  I loved the first two books... truly I could not put them down.  I fell in love with the characters, the plot, the conflict, the world and definitely the love story between Tris and Tobias.The third book had a LOT of high expectations riding on it... there was a lot of stuff that needed to be resolved and while I admit a lot of it was resolved, the way in which said resolution was delivered was one of the most disappointing, depressing and tragic endings I have ever had the misfortune of reading.  I stay awake at night thinking about this when I should be sleeping, and so I write this review in hopes that getting this down in writing will give me enough peace of mind that I can move on from this travesty of a series and never have to look back.  It is nearly impossible to write this review without giving direct spoilers, but I will try my best.First of all, the BIG REVEAL that they are hinting at and leading up to with what is beyond the walls of their little world was very underwhelming and in my opinion, pretty unoriginal.  Sadly, the idea that this book might be some dystopian version of M. Night Shaymalan's "The Village" did cross my mind as I was part way through book 2 when then started hinting and something beyond the walls... but I thought to myself "no way would she write something that lame"  well yes... she did... epic. fail.Secondly, there are a LOT of holes in the story, incredibly huge gaping ones that make no sense what so ever.  The justifications for everything that has been done to these people, from day one make no sense.  If they wanted to keep everyone under control and in the town, why would they ever choose to arm the governing faction with information that would cause people to want to leave?  Why would that message even be delivered in such as a way as to encourage such a thing?  It made no sense.  It feels like the author wrote the books without having any idea of how she was going to resolve the giant mess of conflict that she created.Thirdly, the ending... I am at a complete and total loss of words for that.  The first two issues I could certainly have forgiven or overlooked, but I cannot in my mind find any reason why the author would choose to do what she did IN A YA NOVEL.  If there was some reason behind it, some kind of important lesson to be learned or some benefit, even some insurmountable obstacle to be overcome... but there was not.  I could not think of a single reason why the author had to end it the way she did, on such a depressing note after you spend SO MUCH effort to build up such a strong relationship with a character you grow to love and has grown so much in the course of your adventure with these books.  I feel cheated, disappointed and depressed.If I had to go back and say whether or not I feel like the time I've spent over the last three days was worth this kind of disappointment I felt at the conclusion of this seires? I would probably say no... it was not.If you are like me and get very emotionally attached to characters in books, and do not like sad endings, then I recommend you steer clear of this series, it will only disappoint you.

I really loved the first 2 books in this series, and I loved the movie, but I have been struggling to get through this last book. There are too many characters by this book that I have forgotten, and the story is just plain boring. I know I like a book if I can read for hours without falling asleep..this book has taken over 2 months to read because every time I start reading, I'm asleep within a page or two. I hate giving a bad review...but I have to give this one a thumbs down :(

This book broke my heart. I don't want to give away any spoilers since it is still such a new release, but it was upsetting enough that I wouldn't even recommend the first two books of her series anymore.Firstly, I felt like the big twist on what Chicago and the factions were was just a slap in the face and lacked creativity. She also threw in a bunch of new characters Stephanie Meyer-style which was irritating.Secondly, the entire book became a thinly veiled allegory on equal rights, which fine, I support equal rights 100%, but why did this suddenly become about that.Thirdly, in a young adult fiction novel, the heroine should be able to have her happy ending - even if it is bittersweet ala' Suzanne Collins' Mockingjay or J.K. Rowling's Deathly Hallows - there was still an uplifting, hopeful end. Yes, you cried and grieved, but they both made the losses feel OK in the end. I feel like Roth just disregarded her fans and their love of the many characters and threw a Hail Mary to try and be shocking.She did shock me, made me angry, deeply disappointed me and I will probably never read anything she writes again.
summary: Disappointing end to what could've been a great trilogy

reviewText: Ah! I was so pissed off with this. I've been reading this trilogy from the very start and I was so excited for the final conclusion and for a HEA.**SPOILER ALERT**But for crying out loud killing the main character is not going to go down well with fans! I mean I get that real life doesn't end happily every single time but god, it's a book, and I read to get away from the nastiness of real life.I'm not going to say I didn't enjoy reading this, because I did. I liked knowing the background to the factions, and how it all started. I liked getting a ending to the series. But I did not like reading that Tris had died. I seriously was in shock and kept thinking "On the next page she'll be alive." But when Tobias saw her dead body I knew it was over and my disappointment was immense.Overall, the book was technically good. It was captivating, had good grammar, an interesting plot line etc. But because I was so looking forward to their happily ever after, I just can't rate it higher than this.

I really enjoyed the first two books of this series but, unfortunately, I don't think the conclusion of the series lives up to its predecessors. I have to look to the Harry Potter series for a comparison. What Rowling did so brilliantly is to gradually expand the size of the characters' world and the weight of their problems, which mirrors the typical process of children becoming young adults. Allegiant takes a very big and sudden plot twist- that the inhabitants of the city were actually placed there by an outside party for unknown reasons- and attempts to resolve the characters' reaction to that knowledge and how it effects their relationships in a VERY short amount of time. I felt like Roth presented a complex and intriguing issue and then just hurried through the end of the story without adequately exploring it. This series could EASILY have had a fourth book and probably would have benefited from it. It felt very much as though Roth was worried that her readers would lose patience with her if she slowed her pace at all, even if it meant a better story. I say you're not doing your readers any service to assume they can't handle a thoroughly told story. I mean, if a kid is bothering to read in this day and age, you have to give them some credit for having a decent attention span!SPOILER ALERT: I didn't totally understand why Roth killed off Tris, but I'll go with it. What I REALLY don't buy is that the crazy stunt these kids pull at the end to save Chicago could solve the problem. After all, the genetic division is ONE part of the government. It's very naive to think that just because they blow a few things up and kill a few people that government would automatically say "Oh, you're right, we should totally nix all these wacko experiments we're doing. Thanks, kids!". I say again: this series needed another book (or a longer third installation) and more thoughtful treatment of the story.
summary: Final Book of the Trilogy Moves Fast and Falls Short

reviewText: wish someone had told me not to read this. there are lots more reviews on amazon.com that are worth reading...very poor character development. you never have any idea who is speaking except for the chapter title. the ending has no resolution or point... there is no plot to the book.... even three quarters of the way through I didn't know what the point of the book was, they were not working towards anything and then a bunch of twist ending things happened that had no point to them. also, they had no real romance to their relationship and like that was blamed on the tense situations they keep getting themselves into and then they can't decide to sleep together or not... Four's personality seemed to be much more random here than in the other books, like he became a child again. its really clear she had never written in two POV before and it was poorly developed... way too many new characters was added and this book didn't need to be 526 pages. what a waste of time.I am NOT reading any more trilogies or dystopian fiction for a long time. the disappointment with this series runs deep and there just isn't enough purpose to the things thrown into the book to care.

**This review contains spoilers**I was very nervous when picking up Veronica Roth's final installment of the Divergent series because I had heard rumors that the series ending was horrible. This worried me because I found Roth's voice and her unique style to be refreshing in the first two installments and would have hated to see it ruined by a bad ending choice.While I understand while some readers were disappointed with the way the series ended, I have to say I was not one of them. I have always been under the belief that Tris' character's only purpose was to highlight who I believed to be the best written character in the book (aka Tobias). I have always felt that Tris as a character lacked the well-roundedness of Tobias's character. While usually I would cite this as a criticism of the author, in this case it worked. It worked because the character of Tris did exactly what it was supposed to do, highlight Tobias and bring out the multi-dimensional traits of his character.I too loved the romance between Tris and Tobias. I loved it's innocence and I loved its simplicity. However what made their romance so great was not the actual romance as much as the context for which it began and grew. Roth did not write an exceptional love story, she wrote a basic love story and she placed it in the middle of a dystopian world in which it flourished and proved wrong all of the other contextual occurings that were happening simultaneously.Tris' death should not be looked at as a bad ending to the story. While I was in fact saddened by her death I was more sad for Tobias' reaction to it then the fact that she would cease to fill the pages of the book anymore. In many ways I found her death to be her defining moment where she stepped out and became a real character for the first time. I personally loved Roth's ending. I felt like Tobias' story was always the actual story and watching him survive until the last page and learn and grow and mourn was beautiful. It was like Roth never gave up on Tobias, she refused to erase his memory and she refused to let him cease being the person that Tris' character highlighted so well. I applaud her for this and I think that true fans of the book will as well.
summary: Props to Roth for keeping it real....

reviewText: *** REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS ***Before I begin, I think it's important that I kind of let you know where I stand with the Divergent series up to this point. I LOVED Divergent so much. It pulled me out of a massive reading rut and made me fall in love with YA again. Then I read Insurgent and was not wowed. Honestly, I think I should have given the book more like 2.5 or 3 stars (I gave it 4.. no idea why, especially after re-reading my review).I was excited about Allegiant because of the big bang ending that was in Insurgent, but honestly my hopes weren't that high. I wasn't convinced that Allegiant was going to wow me, and I was right.***I don't like how Tris and Tobias pushed aside their problems by making outTris and Tobias's relationship still isn't perfect in Allegiant. They have things they need to talk about and discuss. But ANY time this situation comes up, they bury it by making out. It's literally like:"We need to ta--"Suddenly I felt his mouth on mine. [Cue make out scene.]Paraphrasing, but that's the gist of it. SO.MANY.TIMES. It's almost like they thought they had to make up for their fighting/distance in Insurgent, but this was not the right way to do it! You can't just hope your problems will go away by cutting them off with a kiss. It doesn't work like that.***I kind of wish Tris and Tobias just didn't have a relationship at allI grew to hate Tris and Tobias's relationship. Adding onto the previous point, I just felt like their relationship was so half ass. Except when they were making out, they didn't act like a couple. They didn't treat each other like equals. There were still plenty of times when they didn't clue each other in on their thoughts/plans. They just didn't feel TOGETHER.Maybe this is extremely stereotypical of me, but there were so many moments when I felt that Tris and Tobias should have reacted in a certain way as a couple (like comforted the other person, or sought comfort from them), but they reacted so indifferently instead."I could stay and try to comfort him, but I need answers about my mother, and I'm not going to wait any longer."Except when their lips were glued together, I just didn't look at them and think, "You guys are dating. You love each other." Instead I saw.. colleagues? Maybe friends?I felt like labeling what they had as a relationship just brought the story down. I honestly would have preferred if their relationship was just cut from the book because it kept disappointing me."But no more lies. Not ever""Okay."I feel stiff and squeezed, like my body was just forced into something too small for it.Because being completely open and honest with Tobias makes her feel restricted and contained? *eye roll****Tobias and Tris had the same voice.In Allegiant, the chapters switch between Tris and Tobias's points of view, but I couldn't tell them apart. I often had to double check the chapter heading because I couldn't tell whose point of view I was reading from.I think if you're going to have alternating points of view, you have to have two very distinct voices. Tris and Tobias didn't sound or feel particularly different.***I didn't love any of the characters.Overall, the character development and relationships were poor. I already talked about Tris and Tobias, but I couldn't connect to ANY of the characters really. I just felt so little for them.Tobias on his own was weak. I remember loving him in Divergent because he was such a hardened badass. In Allegiant he's constantly doubting himself, wallowing in grief, blaming himself for everything... it got to be a bit pathetic and I just wanted to yell at him and tell him to quit with the self pity.I loved Christina in Divergent, but I was indifferent towards her in Allegiant.There were a bunch of other characters but they all felt so fleeting. They dodged in and out of the book and I never got a sense of who they were and never formed any attachments to them.***I hated how we were given two separate societies and two separate rebellions.It made it hard for me to figure out where I should concentrate. On the one hand we had the rebellion within the Chicago city. The factionless rebelled and are trying to take over and convert the whole city into a factionless society.Then on the other hand, we have the whole of the United States. With this society we have a whole other rebellion. Once this one started up, I felt like I was being pulled in two different directions. I didn't know if the rebellion in Chicago was still important, and I didn't know what to even focus on! I hated how we were introduced into one conflict, and then suddenly jerked into a different one.***The time period was weird.In Allegiant we get the sense that the story takes place at least hundreds of years in the future. We know that the experiments have been running for at least ~7 generations (about 210 years). But I don't think that when they started was 2013 either. It was probably at least 2050 when they started (if not later), then that means Allegiant takes place around 2260.The exact timing isn't important, but what is important is that the Divergent series takes place hundreds of years in the future. And yet... I thought there was so little advancement. All the tech seemed like 2013 tech. It's like advancement was stunted, but the years kept rolling by. They still use guns, normal trucks, airplane travel seems the same, etc. With all the wars and uprisings, I would have expected really advanced weaponry.Sure they had the serums and the fear landscapes, but that's about it...***I didn't like how the serums felt more like magic than science.In particular, I'm talking about the death serum. Surely this serum is like a chemical weapon, right? Like I imagine it being comparable to nerve gas. Everyone who comes into contact with it dies. And yet... Tris can magically survive it through mind power It's literally like she just willed herself not to die. I can understand overcoming fears and simulations, kind of like lucid dreaming. But I can't imagine the death serum being anything but a biological killer.. like nerve gas. And yet Tris can overcome it with just the power of her mind? O_O This makes zero sense to me.***I did not like the ending.Maybe some people will like it for being `powerful' or `gutsy' or `emotional'. I just didn't like it.[I'll be honest, I tend to hate any ending where the main character dies. It's just not how I like to read stories. And in Allegiant, Tris dies. Whenever this happens in books, I get left with a sense of "What's the point?" I spend three books reading from a character's point of view, watching them grow and change, connecting with them (hopefully), just to have them offed. Even if the conflict was resolved (in this case it was), I can't help but feeling like it was pointless or wasted time.But although I didn't like the ending, it wasn't because I loved Tris and couldn't bear to see her die. Emotionally, I didn't actually feel anything when she died. I wasn't upset or teary. I was only angry because of that whole `pointless' feeling. I think that just goes to show how detached I've become since Divergent.Additionally, I thought the ending with Tobias and his mother was so... lame... and easy. Tobias gave his mother an ultimatum. He said: stop trying to rule the city and form a treaty with the Allegiant, or lose me as your son. And she just pulled him into her arms and tearfully said, "I choose you!" Why couldn't he have said that to her an entire book ago?Also I felt nothing when Uriah died. Honestly I kind of forgot who he was going into Allegiant and he was so absent through the entire story that I just didn't care at all when he went into a coma, and I again didn't care at all when they pulled the plug on him.***Allegiant was about what I expected.After Insurgent, I think Allegiant was exactly what I expected it to be. I don't feel like Tris and Tobias's relationship ever "healed", and for the rest I was just mildly indifferent. Throw in a few other problems, and it's about what I expected it to be.I still look back on Divergent fondly, but I think overall I just don't like where the series went. I hated how it destroyed Tris and Tobias's relationship, I didn't love where the plot went, and I hated the ending Roth chose.
summary: Jumbled, aggravating, and finally killed with a bad ending

reviewText: Oh my goodness, this book. I'd read mixed reviews before going into Allegiant (although I somehow managed to avoid spoilers even though I was still active on websites where this book was discussed... thanks for being awesome, internet people!), so I was a little afraid this book might let me down. But it didn't. It definitely didn't.The beginning was a little slow for me, and other parts seemed really rushed, but I think part of that was from having to create an entirely new part of this world. Everything Tris and Tobias know is questioned, and everything has to be rebuilt from the ground up. I think there was a lot more telling in this book instead of things being inferred, but I'm not really sure how else it would have been done all in one book. The world-building was a little lacking in this book compared to the other ones, but it didn't bother me as much as it typically would.I did really enjoy that this story was told from two perspectives though. It was a little jarring at first - since the first two are solely from Tris' perspective, Tobias took a little bit to get used to. But then, I don't think this story would have worked any other way. Divergent and Insurgent were definitely Tris' story to tell, but this one belongs to both of them in so many ways. Tobias has issues that he has to deal with, and Tris has her own problems, and it wouldn't have made any sense for Tris to really be able to explain Tobias' problems and thoughts and actions. It was a risky choice, but I think it's one that definitely enhanced this last book.As I was reading this book, I felt like it had a Maze Runner feel to it. I don't want to spoil anything for either series, but I think people who have read The Maze Runner will understand. One of those "society isn't always what you think it is, we're doing this for your own good" kind of things.The pacing in this book was definitely very fast-paced, but I think the rest of the series is too so it wasn't off-putting. The whole series is a gigantic roller coaster ride, and this book was true to that. Especially with all of the feels. Oh, the feels. So many emotions on opposite ends of the spectrum that I should have been prepared for but wasn't really. So thanks for that, Veronica. You win.I don't want to say too much about the ending, because it's one I think everyone should experience on their own (if you haven't had it spoiled yet, keep avoiding those spoilers!), but I will say that I thought it was excellently done. It was risky, and I know quite a few people were outraged by it and hated the book because of it. I, however, think it remained true to the characters. After reading it, I don't think this series could have ended any other way.If you've read Divergent and Insurgent, you will definitely want to read Allegiant! It has its flaws, but I think it wraps up the series well. I mean, even the epilogue is true to all of the characters. Usually I hate the epilogues, but I enjoyed this one. Any fans of The Hunger Games or The Maze Runner series would most likely enjoy this series, as well as any fans of YA dystopias. 4/5 for this final book in an amazing trilogy!
summary: Not what I was expecting, but still a good conclusion

reviewText: *3.5*In the aftermath of revealing the video from Edith Prior, the fighting continues as Evelyn controls the factionless and destroys the institution of the factions. Many people still believe  in and want the factions and create the group called the Allegiant. In the quest to discover what is outside the fence of the city, a group including Tris and Tobias (four) sneak out of the city and discover the truth. They discover that they are part of an experiment to create genetically pure people (divergent). Tris discovers that her mother was a part of the government and was placed into the experiment to work from the inside. The government has been keeping a lot from those within the experiment and the experiment is on the verge of being disbanded. Tris and her friends must figure out a way to save the people from the city and get rid of the harmful label of "genetically damaged" that has limited peoples advancements and ways of life. Tris takes the ultimate sacrifice to save her friends and family.I had mixed feelings about this book. I feel like Roth should have stopped after the 1st book. I am not a fan of the multi narrative in this book. The other two are from the perspective of Tris and I understand in a way why she chose to write it this way, but I did not like it. The beginning of the book was very confusing and there was a lot going on that caused me to have to re-read it. I did like the way in which Roth finally began to answer some questions and give background to how the city, experiments and world came to be. The addition of all the gene information takes the book in a very different direction and seemed very confusing and proved to be kind of boring. It took me until the last 100 pages to really get into the book. Tris and Four have changed a lot and I don't think I like who they have become. Four has become soft and so obsessed with Tris, I liked him much better as the strong dauntless that he once was. And Tris has become so self involved and cocky. This book was a let down for me. I thought the end was surprisingly well done and I am very picky about endings, but the beginning of the book dragged on and was a waste of paper.
summary: A Disappointing Ending To A Great Trilogy
