Spoilers*SPOILERS* *SPOILERS*You've been warned....Meh. This book was okay. I didn't hate it, I didn't love it. It didn't really make me feel anything beyond some boredom and a little annoyance. And therein lies the problem I guess. I SHOULD have felt something after three books. Mostly I just felt like I was being whined or preached at. And my issues with it, unlike many others, do not hinge on Tris's ultimate demise.I do not recognize these characters. Tris and Tobias seem to have become entirely different people through this trilogy. I guess that could be attributed to trauma and personal growth. Okay, fine. But I don't like this Tris and Tobias. And they don't seem to have grown, if anything they regressed. First of all, I couldn't tell them apart. At all. Every time I was in a Tobais chapter I thought I was reading Tris until he referred to her or Nita or some other character that would have been Tobias-centric instead of Tris-centric. Tobias started as this strong, brave, SMART, mysterious tough guy type. I can understand revealing some of his issues and helping us see him as vulnerable and human. But I feel this book went beyond that and made him seem extremely whiny and needy. He also came off as kind of an idiot. From the very beginning before Tris was even around he purposely took a lesser job than he could have in Dauntless so that he would have access to the technology and codes he would need so he could eventually get out because he knew there was something worth finding outside the fence. He knew something was up with this world they were in. He didn't accept it, or anything, at face value. But now in Allegiant he is willing to go along with some half plotted hair-brained scheme foisted on him by someone he barely knows? After all he's seen? He just kept doing really stupid things that I found irritating and didn't fit with his character. Tris on the other hand became this world wise know it all who was somehow always doing the right thing and always knew what the truth was. She had never questioned anything about her world until the end of Divergent, but now all of a sudden she knows everything about everything and is some kind of human lie detector? I felt like in this book and the last she WAS making judgements based on her feelings (fear, revenge, resentment, jealousy) but she just kept getting lucky in that she happened to be right despite being skewed by her emotions. She started to get on my nerves in Insurgent because of the gun/WIll thing. I get that it's traumatic but when you're in the middle of a battle/war, you can't just give up. Sometimes you gotta do what you gotta do and I really wanted her step up. She did a little bit in Allegiant. At least she could hold a gun again and stopped whining SO much about Will. I think there was honestly just much too much introspection in Insurgent and Allegiant for me. It slowed the pacing of the books down, made them longer than necessary and bored me. I also couldn't identify with Tris and Tobias' desperate need to please and be accepted by parents who were no longer part of their lives and hadn't been for some time. Of course your parents have an impact on your life and you always love them but at some point don't you move on to living your own life and having more important things to dwell on than what your parents did or didn't do years ago? Neither of them seemed to have trouble cutting all ties to join a different faction and presumably never see their parents again, so why now were they both so consumed with them? Especially when Abnegation families tend to not know each other well or be that close to each other. It was a huge driving force in both their lives respectively and I just couldn't understand why.I do not tend to picky about world building in novels. Make up whatever world you want. But you have to convince me. It has to FEEL plausible. I don't need to know every little detail, you don't have to prove it's actually possible. But I need to buy it, and I didn't buy this one. I was looking forward to finding out what was outside the fence. And we really never did. I mean I know there's the compound and the cities and the experiments and fringe. But....what else? And how does that all fit together? There's NOTHING in the western United States at all anymore? How do people in the cities live? Are there schools? Regular jobs? Hover cars? What about the rest of the WORLD? What happened out there while the US was apparently destroying itself over genetic manipulation? Did that happen everywhere? Why did no one step in? Or come help or invade once we had devastated our own population? What is the US government like now? Is there still a president? A king? A mutant octopus overlord? What? I wanted a much bigger, more cohesive picture than we got. I feel like all we got outside the fence was the compound which they never left, except Tris one time. I kept wondering why no one went outside? AT ALL. Wouldn't you want some fresh air? Who could stay inside a compound indefinitely? I'd go crazy. The constant our leaders are lying, the world isn't what we've been told, we must find out the truth and then REBEL cycle got really repetitive and old too.The genetic modification was an interesting idea, but I don't think it supported the plot like it needed to, and that's where it all fell apart for me. For one, I can't figure out why everyone would buy into such an idea in the first place. What do your genes really have to do with your behavior? But okay, people believe stupid things sometimes, so let's say they do. I don't understand the point or benefit of the city experiments when the entire country is populated by GP and GD people. What were they trying to accomplish there? If you want more GPs just encourage the free GPs to reproduce among themselves. Which would be likely anyway since they hate the GDs. Sterilize or kill off the GDs if you're a terrible power hungry elitist organization bent on their destruction. If they were trying to produce GPs or "Divergent" people in the experiments then why did they not remove those that were produced for their own safety instead of leaving them in the experiment to be killed for being Divergent? Why perpetuate the belief that being Divergent was a bad thing when it was actually supposedly the desired outcome of the experiment? And how do a bunch of GD people just randomly all of a sudden start producing GPs? Or how would offspring of the first GD people even have been effected to begin with. Something that is modified on my body is not necessarily going to be passed to my offspring. All the GPs are better, GDs are better back and forth made me feel like I could have just read The Sneetches by Dr. Suess and saved myself some time.I thought SEVEN generations was way way too long for these experiments to have been going on. Seven generations and no one tried to get out? No one questioned this tiny little world they were living in? I know there was one factionless uprising and memory erasure, but why was there never a rebellion? I can't imagine staying in one tiny city my entire life and never trying to find out or wondering what was outside. Also if they had been in there for seven generations then how come no one had any grandparents or great grandparents or really any extended family to speak of at all? And how many people were put in the experiments to begin with? After seven generations of people all stuck in one city wouldn't you start to have some inbreeding going on? I mean there just wouldn't be that many people to chose from.The resolution was unsatisfying for me. Tris exposed the truth to the entire city, which is exactly what David did not want to happen. So I couldn't figure out why he would so immediately and completely trust her. Unless he was maybe setting her up from the beginning. I still don't understand why he was where he was at the end or how he knew to be there or that she would be there when she didn't even know she'd be there. I thought Tris' "sacrifice" was completely needless and selfish. She was leaving behind a lot of people who would be damaged and mourn her for the rest of their lives. She didn't need to do that. Not only could she have sent Caleb who, let's face it, was a sociopath who no one liked and who contributed basically nothing good to society. She also based her decision off of beliefs taught to her by a faction that she knew was just a fabrication to cover a government experiment. That doesn't make sense and I don't think it would have pleased her parents who sacrificed their lives so she could LIVE, not die. Of course they sacrificed for her, they're her parents who were middle aged and had lived good lives. They wanted that for their children too. But all that could have been avoided altogether since apparently the only thing needed to stop the uprising in Chicago was for Tobias to go and give his mother an ultimatum. The only reason they were going to drop the memory serum was because they wanted to stop the uprising and create peace so they could keep their experiment going. Which Tobias did without serum simply by awakening some latent mothering instinct in the woman who for most of his life really didn't care about him at all. I do not understand why Evelyn and Marcus would fold and give up their life's work in one moment like that, but it was certainly convenient. Except for for Tris who was erasing the compound's memories anyway. Explain to me why the mostly innocent people in the compound deserved to have their memories erased more than the people in Chicago? The majority of people in the compound were just as innocent and ignorant as the people in the experiment. I did not like the whole memory erasure thing. It didn't feel like justice, or resolution so much as revenge. I think simply assassinating David, in that case, would have made a lot more sense. Erasing the compound's memory did nothing to solve the larger nationwide issue anyway. And what happened to the other experiment cities? Chicago got it's happy ending but what about everyone else?If this book had been more action packed and moved at a faster pace, I don't think I would have had so many questions. I would have been swept along with it much like I was in Divergent and the plot holes might not have bothered me as much once I caught them because I would have enjoyed the experience anyway. Insurgent and Allegiant slowed WAY down from the pace that was set in Divergent. I think both books could have been shorter, with maybe not quite so much repetitive introspection, which gave me time to ponder the other aspects of the plot. Ultimately, I'm disappointed in this book. I would not have finished it if it hadn't been the ending to this series. I think this series had way too much hype and it will end up suffering for that. When I read Divergent way back when it wasn't popular I thought it was a slightly above average, entertaining YA dystopia. Not necessarily the next blockbuster. I think once the media got ahold of it it got blown WAY out of proportion and I'm not sure ANY ending would have stood up to the expectations that were inadvertently set for it. It is a shame that so many people have been so disappointed by Allegiant.[...]

I read the first two books only months before this one, and can't believe Allegiant was written by the same author. This book was so slow, so dull, so drab, that I found myself skimming pages just to keep from falling asleep. The whole plot reveal about the damaged DNA and other genetic nonsense was just...well, nonsense. The choice to have alternating chapters between Tris and Four, after structuring the first two books differently, felt like a cheap ploy (was it a copy of author Marie Lu's successful format, or just a way to ensure that Four could narrate the final chapters?). The act of killing off a main character felt pointless and contrived; it wasn't necessary, and the death scene was written in such a rushed and fumbling way that it didn't have nearly the impact that it should have.So all in all, this book was a train wreck. I can't help thinking that Roth wrote the first two books with no idea what would happen in the third, then she scrambled for an ending to her trilogy and came up with this sad offering.

It is no secret that I love "Divergent"- by the end of the semester of my YA class I am sure that the majority of my classmates (not to mention prof) wanted to pull some Tris-like moves on me for CONSTANTLY pushing it on them. That being said, a lot of that love was unfortunately lost on "Insurgent", with me feeling that it lost too much of the magic from the previous book- with Tris and Four's relationship constantly balancing precariously over the chasm, Tris refusing to give in any way, shape, or form, and so forth. As such, on the one hand I was beyond excited to read this book (thinking that "Insurgent" merely suffered from second book syndrome and that Veronica would redeem herself), but on the other, I was nervous beyond belief (based upon the previous two books it stood to reason that there would be a lot of conflict, violence, and loss in this)- at times, giving myself a stomach ache when thinking about actually reading it.My biggest worries about this book surrounded its ending because I heard vague whispers that THINGS WENT DOWN- as such, I was convinced before even starting it that I would hate it. However, surprisingly, I did not hate the ending, it wasn't near as hard to accept as I had thought that it would be (Plus, I give mad props to Veronica for doing what she did- it's something that I have literally never seen another author do before, them always chickening out at the last minute. She's going to get a lot of hate for it, but when you really think about it, it totally fits with the overall scheme of things). Furthermore, the last twenty or so pages of this book were absolutely gorgeous- I don't often cry while reading a book, but there was definitely some tearing up going on as I read them. Based on the ending alone, I would give the book 5 stars.Furthermore, I did like the fact that from book to book you can see massive character growth- growth seen in Tris and Four especially (something that really became clear to me as I (re)read all three books in the course of two days). Also, the vulnerability exhibited by all of the characters made them extremely relatable and helped me to understand why they did what they did- even those characters that I swore that I would hate until the end of my days, for instance, Peter and Caleb. Last, I did like the duo POV in this book (I always love me some male POV), however, I can't help but wish that Tris and Four's voices were a bit more ferreted out, it was, at times, difficult to determine whose head you actually were in, since they sounded so similar.That being said, what I did hate about the book, and what did drag down the star rating, was how often Veronica put us through the ringer- with petty, jealous high school drama, further conflict after conflict between Tris and Four (I mean, didn't we get enough of this in "Insurgent"- we get it, relationships are hard and need work, trust isn't a given, and so forth), and an inundated storyline (you thought that the faction system in the first two books was confusing? It's NOTHING compared to all of the layers of politics and whatnot going on in this book- kitchen sink, anyone?). Furthermore, I was not a fan of the pace of the book, the setting of much of it, and I absolutely loathed the new character additions (with the exception of one). Combined, around the 350 page mark, I was about to give up on the book because I was just so angry with everything going on.All in all, for me personally it's a toss-up between three and four stars. Overall, I'm glad that I pushed through and didn't give up on the book. While there is admittedly a part of me does wish that this book did end a different way, as I mentioned, I do think that it is what was truly needed and I appreciate Veronica for having the balls to do so. It's clear that she is the most Dauntless person around. Furthermore, I really and truly do hope that Veronica does continue to write after this, not becoming one of those authors like Stephenie Meyer or Suzanne Collins who seemingly drops off the face of the planet after their massive success.

This is the kind of series that sticks with you in your day dreaming time. At times it was a good deal darker than I expected. But it has some heavy duty underlying philosophy ie - human nature ( can you ever change yours?), freedom of spirit, does anyone really have free will and choice, the fundamental value of trust between people, distrust of science/government, throw in a veiled description of belief that a part of our society has inferior genetics ( as it was thought not all that long ago about African-americans), the necessity of sacrifice to prove our love, what does teaching someone how to kill change that person when they actually do kill. Factions seem to show how extremes can be destructive Seems like a lot while striving to be entertaining. Reflecting back I thought it was then, from my point of view, light on the positive aspect of love and very heavy on "I love you the most because I will die for you" . I also thought the story stayed away from religion/spirituality. So...if this is enough to drive you away from reading these books then I've done you a disservice. There is a story here that's captivating and far from standard drivel. You will have times when you just can't put the book down. I am immensely grateful that the series is complete and I didn't have to wait 1-2 yrs to finish the final book. Buy it, read it, keep it around...you may find something to return to as we all "grow up".

I was shocked to say the least but I rated this book as a 4 based on the fact the author kept true to her characters and followed through with the story line till the end. Sure things didn't end in the way everyone was assuming and hoping for but overall the author stayed true to the characters ethics and the themes weaves and repeated throughout the trilogy which as the reader I could take comfort in, despite perhaps wanting a different ending. I mean if Roth had gone and changed it for the benefit of the readers I probably would have scoffed at the story and said "cheesy" but she went for a realistic story that though filled with sadness leaves readers with a huge emotional impression that will last, which from a literary perspective is better then cheesed endings any day. Overall I have to say it was a good book after thinking about it and not just dwelling on certain parts, plus I must give major props to Roth for an interesting last couple of chapters. I mean when the book could have been done Roth took readers through the end and helped readers finish the story emotionally along with the characters, which I believed helped me get through the completion of the trilogy. If she had just ended the story with out those last few chapter at the end I think the book would have really sucked, instead I believe it was Roth's way of wrapping up the series as well as giving light as to how the books can help readers in the real world too.

reviewText: Although I was not happy with the ending, I am ok with the way it ends. I don't need a happy ending to enjoy a book, or a series. What I do need though is smooth writing with transitions when moving from one character to another. This book was so horribly written that when Roth changed from the perspective of Tris to Four, I was more often than not, unable to tell the difference. I found myself flipping back to the beginning of the chapter to see who was speaking. If I had bought the Kindle version I would have pulled my hear out scrolling back and forth! The voice of the characters all sound alike. Even Christina, who has been, up to this point, one of my favorites, has slid into the background. I feel like I have invested too much time into a book series that is just not worth it once I reached the end. I have no issues with death in a story, but I feel like if someone dies in a book, there should be a reason for the death, or at least make it worth while. That just doesn't happen in Allegiant, and there are several deaths where I question the validity. Had this book published before school began a couple of months ago I would not have began reading Divergent aloud to my class. I feel like they are only going to be disappointed in the next two books. Two of my students read this book after finishing Insurgent, and both of them came back disappointed. I just tell them I understand, since I too was disappointed. In the course of this school year I have already read at over 50 books, and I can say that this one definitely falls at the bottom.

reviewText: I highly recommend THE DIVERGENT SERIES to any readers who enjoy dystopian novels! READ THIS BOOK NOW if you have read DIVERGENT and INSURGENT.  Do NOT look at SPOILERS.  Make your own judgments about this book and the series as a whole.----------------------------Tobias did believe in Tris's judgment at the end of Insurgent and played Jeanine's file for all the citizens to see.  It was a video message from the past stating that the inhabitants were placed there as an experiment and that once the population had a large percentage of people with divergent abilities that would be the time for Amity to allow people to leave their borders, to go to help whomever may be on the outside.It's difficult to say much about this book without revealing what you should read and discover on your own.  There are very minor spoilers here.Evelyn is still ruling the armed factionless and the community as a whole as a dictator.  A secret group of citizens who hold allegiance to the old faction system form with the intent of overthrowing Evelyn.  Tris, Four, Uriah, Christina, Caleb & Peter venture past Amity and make their way to a compound where the government agency responsible for establishing and monitoring the genetic experiments in former Chicago is.  The group have a lot to learn about the compound, their history in the experiment, and the world.  The agency welcomes the group and introduces them to their beliefs and ways.  Tris and Tobias had mended their relationship by the end of Insurgent, but find that with the new territory of the compound comes brand new issues that test them and their relationship.  When they learn the compound scientists intend to meddle with the people in the Chicago experiment in a major way, they must decide if they should take action and if so, what it should be.I enjoyed having the story told in alternating POV's of Tris and Tobias.  In this way we learn what each of them are feeling, withholding, and why.  I think the addition of Tobias' POV adds range to the book.  There were major twists at the end of the book that result in many readers being outraged.  Frankly, I didn't find the biggest twist shocking.  In fact beliefs and decisions throughout the trilogy lead clearly to the twist, in retrospect.  I really believe that Allegiant's big twist and the ending are beautiful, once the surprise wears off.  I loved Allegiant and will be re-reading the whole Divergent series in the future.My favorite quote from the book is from Tris regarding Tobias:"Just as I have insisted on his worth, he has always insisted on my strength, insisted that my capacity is greater than I believe.  And I know, without being told, that's what love does when it's right- it makes you more than you were, more than you thought you could be."
summary: I LOVED ALLEGIANT INCLUDING SURPRISE TWISTS AND RECOMMEND YOU READ IT AND SEE WHAT YOU THINK.

reviewText: I actually like the first two books of this series better than the 'other' series that it is often compared to. But I found the ending unsatisfying.

In Allegiant, the third book in a promising and much anticipated trilogy, Veronica Roth delivers a novel that wouldn't have ordinarily made it out of the slush pile of any reputable publisher. Her prose barely rises above the complexity of "See spot run", and her endless repetition of the same weary adjectives makes me fervently hope someone buys her a thesaurus for Christmas. I am similarly underwhelmed by her ham-handed use of point of view. The previous two books were written solely from the point of view of Tris while this book's point of view alternates between Tris and Tobias. Roth's plain Jane, junior high style prose never achieves a difference in voice between her own narration, Tris, or Tobias. This is especially disappointing because Tobias is such a complex, mysterious character and should have delivered riveting chapters. The finale is the most monotone book I have ever had the misfortune of reading, and if you're perceptive, you realize early on why she has to write from the perspective of two characters. Many people are howling about the ending, and while I maintain it was not the ending I hoped for, my opinion is that Roth is too poor and weak of a writer to achieve the shocking, hard-hitting ending she desired. Never mind all the intricate plots, subplots, and endless revolutions. She couldn't achieve resolution. You could argue that not all dystopian futures will be  or have to be resolved and that her book is actually realistic, but given the scores of weaknesses throughout the book, I'm going to guess that Roth couldn't tie up her loose ends.I'm not sure what happened to the most anticipated young adult novel of the year, but my primary theory is that having released three novels in three years and a slew of forthcoming Divergent-related short stories, Roth was really just looking to cash in big while she could. This trilogy could have been great, and I am sorry a better author didn't come up with it.

Allegiant continues where Insurgent leaves off. Evelyn, Tobias mother and leader of the factionless is now in charge. Tris has been imprisoned awaiting a hearing. Evelyn insists that all factions must be destroyed and everyone should be free. However, not everyone is happy about the abolition of factions and a group of people have come together to topple Evelyn's hold on the city.Tris and Tobias, along with their friends, manage to escape the city and go beyond it's borders. They meet the people who have been conducting the experiments on cities like theirs. They learn that the Divergent are considered genetically pure while the rest are considered genetically damaged. Tobias learns he may not be what he had always considered himself to be and the knowledge threatens to tear his relationship with Tris apart.Veronica Roth writes a very exciting sequel in Allegiant. The story is, for me, more exciting than its predecessors. I could not put it down until I finished it. And the ending is something that I never saw coming.
summary: A Great Way to End the Series

Like many others have noted, it was so hard to tell which character was speaking that I had to double check the chapter title. That's just plain bad writing there. I can forgive a lot in a YA book, but this was ridiculous.
summary: Glad I got it from the library

reviewText: I really enjoyed reading. The ending was bittersweet. I recommend this series. There was never a dull moment and really liked it.

First of all, I commend the author for sticking to the story that she intended to tell from the beginning. I do not believe for one second that the "thing" that happens, that has so many people upset, was for the sake of adding drama. And I'm saddened for the author to be getting so much heat for writing HER story the way she wanted to tell it.As for my review, well I do not want to give anything away at all so I'll be brief.I loved the twists and turns. I loved the dual POV's - which I believe were very necessary in this one and really helped in knowing who Tobias really is. I was enthralled from the very first page until the very end.In my opinion, which is just that, an opinion, so I hope I do not offend anyone which is not my intention, this book lived up to the hype and was a great ending to a great series.I'm very much looking forward to whatever else Ms. Roth will be releasing in the future.

Definitely a good series. But as with Hunger Games hard to imagine these societies. Writers have interesting imaginations. Better read for teens because they aren't killing children that concept was hard yet I did get hooked wanting to know how it ends.
I hate sad endings. I would have liked the series to continue. It could have if the author had not killed off my favorite person.
Another outstanding book finished. If you haven't read this and the other two then please do. Loved them all. Yeah!

Allegiant is the 3rd and final book for Veronica Roth's Divergent series.  I loved the first two books of this series.  They were great; wonderful exciting stories, and some awesome characters, especially Tris and Tobias.  I could not wait for this final book, and to see how Roth was going to end it all.  I discussed this with a few friends, who read this series based on my recommendation.Allegiant to me was a major disappointment.  It just wasn't the same, with the book being very slow early on, as well as the constant redundancy.  I also did not like the POV's that Roth decided to add into this book, which made it so different then the first.  It was almost like a different writer.What drew me to this series were the young protagonists we met, as well as the exciting action throughout.  All of this was missing for the most part.  As much as I loved Tobias, the main character for this series, the one who we followed through it all, was Tris.  She was a fantastic character, strong, smart, tough, and would make a fearless leader. In fact, in this book, I thought Tobias was no where near as strong as Tris.  The best part of the book, despite its climatic ending, was the epilogue.  Roth wrote this well....a nice tribute.SPOILERS ......SPOILERS.....SPOILERS(Do not go past this point if you have not read this book, unless you want to spoiled)I have been a big fan of this series, and loved VR's writing.  But after reading Allegiant, and this is solely my opinion....I was sadly disappointed, as I did not feel this was the same author who wowed us in the first two books.We became invested into these characters.  We loved Tris and Tobias.  We get it...it's a war. People have to die.  It's reality.  But this is fiction; we read and imagine with you the excitement of the battles, the love, the friendships.......the ending game.I totally understand that sacrifices have to be made in a story like this.  VR did make them all throughout.  But to take a main character, and sacrifice that character is not what we invested in.  I wasn't totally thrilled with the ending of the Hunger Games, but Katniss would eventually rebuild her life with someone who loved her.  She made her sacrifices, and paid the price, but she survived.Was it necessary to kill Tris off, especially when she survived the serum? What was the point of risking her life (to save a brother who betrayed her), suffering, surviving, and then killing her needlessly, other then to shock us all?  She deserved more, as in real life how many people would offer their lives?Again, this is my opinion. Divergent was great, more then great.  Insurgent was very good, though a tad less then the first book.  Allegiant had so much promise and to me was a major disappointment. and paled in comparison to the first two books.
summary: A disappointing way to end it all

reviewText: Been a while since I finished this series, but I eagerly await the movies.  Good story and good characters.  Worthwhile read.

This book disappointed me in many ways. I found the first half lacking in the action of the other two books. It took a lot of set up to explain the reasons for what they found outside the city. Once this was done the action level picked up, but the motivations for those actions seemed confused and a bit of a stretch at times. The previous books were narrated exclusively by Tris. Allegiant switches back and forth between Tris and Tobias, which became hard to follow. However, the biggest let down was that the trilogy made an implied promise of something great that in the end was so far in the opposite direction I felt cheated. If you have read the first two books you have to read this one, but be prepared for a monumental disappointment.

If this had been the first book in the series, I definitely would not have read the whole series. It was not a terrible book but it was far from mesmerizing. Having two narrators did not work at all. They sounded exactly the same and I had to keep going back to the beginning of the chapter to see who the narrator was. The action was very repetitive. I did not find the ending as disappointing as some of the other reviewers but, for the most part, there was little suspense in the book. Four became less interesting as the book wore on. I believe that there are one or two good movies that will come from the series, but certainly not three... or "four!"

Spoilers ahead,Many people are giving this book bad reviews for the ending. If you have read the book or have seen other reviews you would have learned of Tris' s death. In my opinion it was well written and followed the story line. Sad, yes, but bad writing? No. What people Don't understand is this was a DIS-utopian society. The tragic ending was implied. Her death did come as a shock to me as I had expected Tobias to be the victim, but the twist added something special. It was well written as said above and I was shaking my head at the end wondering why I had not expected it. Her death made this book different from the terribly written series, the hunger games (Not the first, but definitely the last two). In this book you are not screaming for satisfaction. In the hunger games it  was as if katniss was just dealing with the life she was left with. In this book you feel Tobias' s pain, but you also see him moving on.I gave this book three stars because the writing ( up to the climax) was average. Tobias was a weak character and nothing like four In the first books. At times I couldn't see the difference between his pov and the pov of Tris. Also I felt as though the setting of the outside world was made by a child. Little detail was given as to why the genetics of people were changed. Also the US government is mentioned, but never explained. Crime is everywhere to the point there is no safe place to live, yet there is a government. This altered the story from a dis-utopia to a post apocalyptic world.In conclusion while I thought the ending left me settled and was a good wrap up to this story the explanation of the world along with the weak writing made this an overall average read.

Should have stopped at 2. No reason to see the movie now. I think the author must have just gotten board. and decided to do something else, anything would have been better. I like the faction system and you could have had anything outside the city but just normal America very disappointing. Anyways enough with my thoughts on this it's just a sad end to a promising opening.
summary: Sad end to a promising beginning.

reviewText: Though gripping enough to hold me reading until 2am, I still can't give it 5 stars.  Likely the result of the authors writing style, rather than a reflection of what is a wonderful story.  It was odd and slightly off-putting to shift from one scene to another, sometimes in the same paragraph.  Great story, not for my 11yr old, but maybe in a couple more years.
i loved the whole book till i got to the last few chapters. its full of excitement and tears. with a surprise ending you will either hate or love

reviewText: I didn't like this one as much as the previous two.I don't know why, it just wasn't that good of a read.There was about a year between reading this and book 2because I didn't want to pay $20+ for the hardback.I couldn't remember the story that well, detail-wise,so I went to wikipedia and read the summaries there,which reminded me what was what, more or less.But I would encourage those who read the first twoto finish off the story.

I struggled with getting through this one. I mostly kept with it to finish out the series. In my opinion, Veronica Roth wrote two perfectly good books and then was probably told by her publisher or agent it had to be stretched into 3 books. Quantity isn't always quality.
Loved all the books in this series!!!!
At first I was really bored but as I got sucked into the book I loved it and the end not a lot of things can make me cry but it made me weep so much.
This is another nonstop action installment to end the trilogy, alternating between Tris' and Four's points of view.  It ends the story with a shocker I did not foresee.  Well done but grim.
This was a very satisfying ending to the series. The end was a little sad, but it was perfect and beautiful and exactly what this story needed to pull all the threads of plot and emotion together.
summary: I'd heard some spoilers before I read...I loved it anyway

reviewText: The final installment of the divergent trilogy brings clarity to the story, tying up loose ends and showing how life goes on after tragedy while allowing it to be a catalyst for change.  Definitely not happily ever after but true to the characters.

I've been processing the book for a couple of days now. I found the ending to be powerful and true to Tris. All of the strong reactions attest to the fact that Veronica Roth is a good storyteller and created rich characters. I'm amazed at the venom from other reviewers. It sounds like Ms. Roth ended it the way she planned all along. And, it was her story to tell--I admire her storytelling abilities and wish I had an iota of her writing talent. Just because you don't like how it ends, it shouldn't ruin the fact that the series overall has all the elements of a solid, well told story--full of interesting ideas, action, wonderfully crafted characters, romance, questions of right and wrong, and great character development. Tobias' journey and introspection on whether he was damaged or not was heartfelt and it was great to see how he matured since of course most of the characters are just teenagers. I really liked how Ms. Roth explored the concepts of being 'damaged' and humanity overall. I did feel like a lot was thrown at the reader in this book--it felt like another book could have been added to flesh out all the big reveals.I'm sad to see it end but loved going along on the journey with Tris and all the other initiates!
summary: full of interesting ideas, action, wonderfully crafted characters, romance, right vs wrong

reviewText: I couldn't wait to read the last book of this series, unfortunately I did not care for it!! It was just OK for me. I did not like the turn the story took. It was confusing. Too much information and not enough story. I got lost: the end of the factions, the Bureau, the genic explanations that did not make any sense to me. It was hard to keep up to who was good or bad.  I felt I was reading a totally different book. I also did not care for the dual narrative, again confusing. I found myself going back few times to see who the character was, they both sounded the same. I'm Ok with no happy endings but the death of Trish left me empty. SHe sacrificed herself for her brother but I felt there was no point to it. Loved the first book but the series just got worse and worse. Sorry...

This book has been getting an awful lot of negative reviews. I will admit, for me it was not as great as Divergent or Insurgent, but I still really liked it.I thought it lacked the same on the edge of your seat action and suspense of the previous two books. Also, the romance between Tobias and Tris was frustrating and heart breaking, they just did not connect in the same way, there was something missing, but at the same time, that is the ebb and flow of relationship.I would have loved a happy ending, I am a sap for happy endings and really don't like to read a book that doesn't have that ending where you smile and sigh and feel like it is all wrapped up with a nice little bow on top. If you are hard core in this belief, unwavering in your need for the nice ending, please do not read this book.I never dreamed the series would finish in this way, it literally left me sobbing into my pillow, with a feeling of emptiness and resignation. It almost seemed like the fighting and the sacrifices, the loss and the pain were for naught. However, that is not the case. There is a new start. Pieces are picked up, life goes on. There is no such thing as a utopian society. No such thing as perfection. The fight was fought and a victory won, even with great sacrifice.So Veronica Roth, good job. Good job with a realistic ending, one that teaches that there is life after heartache, through heartache. That we must go on and make the best of any situation. While I may be heartbroken over this ending, I think it was definitely worth the journey, and such good lessons, real life lessons, can be taught if eyes and minds are open to the truths found in this fiction.

This review has spoilers!!!While Allegiant wasn't nearly as amazing as Divergent and Insurgent, it still is a great conclusion to the trilogy. It's sad and heart wrenching, and though I was skeptical to read it at first because I knew this book was receiving such terrible reviews, it was definitely worth my time. Everyone was so upset about the main character dying. I can think of hundreds of great stories of a main character dying. Not to mention that Tris has had a death wish since book 1, all along the way Tris has always been willing to sacrifice herself for others. How did we not see her death coming? And besides, I believe Veronica Roth gave Tris a very honorable death.My only complaint is that I wish Tris had a more grandiose death with many knowing the sacrifice she made to change the society and not just the few people that knew. I also would have preferred her death to not happen immediately after she survived the death serum. I wanted more time to sit with that a moment, that she survived something that no one else has ever survived. It shows how incredibly remarkable Tris Prior is... was.I know alot of people are also upset because of Evelyn's choice at the end, that there is simply no way she would have made that decision. We don't really get to see Evelyn much in this book, but its clear she is distraught over Tobias leaving and we see her on more than one occasion upset. I think her moving away from the factions and choosing Tobias makes sense, even if it kind of felt like it came from no where. We don't see much of her, so how do we really know what internal struggles she's having in this book or whether she's being sincere in choosing Tobias?And Tobias... my heart aches for him. But I feel Veronica Roth gave us just enough time to grieve Tris dying and also enough time see Tobias begin to heal. It gives us hope!I think alot of people need to look pass the fact that the main character died. The author herself has stated that this book ended exactly how she envisioned it ending before she even started writing the first book. Look at the deeper picture in the story. Veronica Roth delivers some very powerful and beautiful messages in her story.Be brave."Damaged" is just a term and doesn't define who you are.The choices you make defines who you are and one choice can make all the difference.Don't let someone sacrifice themselves for you if it's not out of love. If you need to sacrifice yourself do it for the right reasons. Do it out of love. Do it to make a difference. Do it to because it's going to change the world.You don't have to belong to a faction, or to a city, or to a government. But belonging to a family, belonging to friends, that makes all the difference. You belong to them, and they belong to you. They are your home.Life damages everyone, but its mendable, and together we can mend each other.

I will try not to give away anything about the book in this review (at least major things).First, I LOVED Divergent. I didn't think I would, I thought the entire premise of the novel was dumb. Veronica Roth did an excellent job selling that premise to her readers and the book was a good story start to finish. I couldn't put it down. A group of girls in my 8th grade class chose Divergent for their dystopian literature unit and they all loved it and read the entire series. Some of these were girls who did not love to read. So that is something.Insurgent was hard for me to get into, but by the end, I really liked that book as well. I was mostly mad at Tris for being such a moron, but then, that was okay. She's a teenage girl who was recently orphaned and her entire world has been turned upside down for many reasons. I get that, and by the end things got better. But one of the problems with Allegiant can be explained here. Tris was being an idiot, but I already loved her from Divergent that she got a pass.Allegiant- well, this book has some serious shortcomings. I do not like that she changed the point of view on this book. We (readers) got to know Tris from the beginning, we knew her inner workings- her flaws and strengths well enough that her point of view only continued to help us love her more as she continued to tell her side of the story. Adding Tobias in as a narrator at the very end of the series- and only for half of the book was an odd shift that by itself changed the tone of the story. Additionally, Roth jumps right in with Tobias's narrative and character. We don't get to know his perspective as deeply as we get to know Tris. He goes from this amazing solid support for Tris to this completely sullen brat. And because we didn't get to know him other than what we knew from Tris's lovestruck view of him, I didn't have as much love for him as I did for Tris when she was being the same way. Changing the format didn't help readers buy into all the other direction changes and plot twists that were thrown at them in this novel.This novel went into so many different directions that it lost its focus, which also lost my interest. I really think my three star rating comes from the fact that I loved Divergent and really liked Insurgent.Aside from the narration problems that intterrupt the flow of the novel, there is the problem of the plot. Everything we thought to be true about Tris's Chicago is stripped down and thrown away. She spent two novels spinning it one way and then completely turns it around in the third book and that happens just about immediately.I don't want to give anything away, but there is no set rule book about killing off major players in a series. All the memes about George RR Martin, JK Rowling, Suzanne Collins, Joss Whedon and Steven Moffatt are just jokes. Roth didn't need to take that "advice" to heart. It made an already difficult book to love irredeemable. Additionally, it is possible to write a book with a message without slamming them in the head with the book every time the reader turns the page. Give them your evidence and let the reader make their own conclusion. If not- your book will sound preachy and condescending, which this book certainly borders on that line.What I did love: This book has some great observations, and great quotable sections of the book. (It is currently on loan to a student or I would love to share some.) I think this book had great potential but it got lost in the changed formatting and plot.
summary: It could have been so much better if not for some minor problems

reviewText: When I see a young person post a review that starts with "I feel dead inside" it makes me furious at this author. She violated the trust of her readers. I am an adult and I was devastated. I almost feel like this was an "aha - gotcha" on the part of the author. I loved Divergent and had recommended it to others, including a book club....I had purchased it for my niece...the list goes on. After finishing this book the first thing I did was text my sister and tell her not to let her tender-hearted adolescent daughter read it. Divergent was such a great book. Tris, like Katniss of Hunger Games, is someone that showed women that we can be smart and strong...and that good things happen to good people(?!) This book? I won't get into the multitude of challenges (both Tris and Tobias having exactly the same voice, the redundancies, story lines that started but went nowhere, etc.), all of which could be overlooked for a great story.  But killing off the main character? I bet the folks in the movie industry aren't very happy right about now. Going to see a movie when you know the main character is going to be killed off? Ummm, not gonna happen. And I'm guessing the movie reviewers will be sharing the ending with potential movie-goers who have not read the books which isn't going to help the box office. I'm thinking the movie is a one-and-done like Beautiful Creatures rather than what they're hoping will be a repeat of four high-grossing Twilights. And as far as I'm concerened I won't be reading anything else by this author. I don't trust her. Bottom line, this was a cruel thing to do. As one young person posted in a review "Life sucks enough as it is." Shame on this author.
summary: The author should look at the heart-wrenching reviews and be ashamed.

reviewText: I loved Divergent...  Liked Insurgent... and really wished I hadn't read Allegiant.  I have NEVER read a book before where I wished I could unread it.  Roth created a great story and then made the whole thing pointless in the end.  All I can say is "what was the point in this whole series?"  Everyone has to read it for themselves and form their own opinion though.  Happy reading..
Great book for teens.  Would definitely recommend for my granddaughters to read over the summer.  Good series for all ages.

Great conclusion to this series!  I saw a lot of comments before I read it complaining that it didn't end they way many would have liked... that made me aware the ending may be unexpected... and boy was it!  This series has never claimed to be a "feel good" series.  The whole series is a very creative, interesting and high-energy story.  It didn't end the way I wished, but it did end in a way that honored the story and the characters.
summary: Great Conclusion to the Divergent series

reviewText: I loved the first book in the Divergent series. This final book in the trilogy moves fast and changes almost too much with not enough detail for the planning to develop strong enough for my liking.I am still glad I read the book. I would chosen a bit of a different ending, but I suppose this ending made it less predictable.I still would recommend this book to anyone who read the other two books first. I would have given it a three and a half star rating if my Kindle would have allowed it.
summary: Good read, but some of the character thought process was not  Well developed

reviewText: Never have i read a series of books that started out so well, and ended so horribly. This last book was boring, and annoying. I had to force myself to get through it, just for it to end so destructively. I feel like it wasn't creative at all, nor did i find meaning in the entire storyline. I'm disappointed i wasted my time & had my hopes up for the movies. Who wants to watch a movie where the hero is killed? :(

I almost didn't read the final book in the Divergent series, after reading some of the reviews, but I'm really glad I did.  The story did not disappoint. After a slow start, the action picked up and the plot thickened with lots of unexpected surprises. The ending hurt a little, but it left me with a good feeling. Can't wait for the movie!

I really enjoyed the first 2 books of this series.  However, pretty much along the lines of Book 3 in The Hunger Games/Mockingjay--this 3rd book in the Divergent Series fell apart and ended with a DUD!
summary: I really enjoyed the first 2 books of this series

reviewText: I would recommend 10 stars for this amazing series. It has everything you want in an addictive read. Drama, action, suspense, humor, romance and a storyline that explores the dangers of attempting to place the complexity of human nature into neat little pigeon holes. The adolescent angst of trying to fit in or break out is richly explored through the trials of Tris and Four as they try to discover themselves in a splintered dystopian city.
Extremely sad but extremely fitting, many give it low ratings for being sad but it is extremely fitting and ends in a way that is true to all the characters
Well. On so many levels was that inconsiderate, poorly thought out, and disrespectful. I truly don't see how this is series is getting movies made out of it.

Although I think the plot and concept for the final book was decent, I felt there was just too much rambling without the same feel as the first two books, where every part was very deliberate in each of them. Also did not like the new format that switched between Tris and Four narrating, took first half of book before either had a discernable voice that didn't make me keep forgetting who was narrating at the moment.
Requires you suspend disbelief and shift scenes a bit too often to flow smoothly. I had hoped for a more satisfying end.

I reread the first two books in the series(Divergent & Insurgent) over the past weekend. They were just as great reads second time around! I couldn't wait for Allegient to come out.All three books take you through the struggles that young people have while trying to figure out who they are in this broken world. My favorite characters were Tris & Tobias. I think Veronica Ross captured the essence of young love and the roller coaster of emotions that fly high. Somehow, this young couple figured out that there is no magical "happy ever after". Everything in life is a choice whether it's to forgive or to love. Wise beyond their years they manage to always choose each other. That's what makes it so difficult to say goodbye to these characters.It's definitely not the way we want our young couples relationships to go but I saw it coming early on.Tris was so strong, brave, and beautiful! While the series mentions more than once that she's not very attractive when it comes to looks & figure but it's her qualities of standing for what's right, her desire to help the oppressed, her loyalty to her friends, and her willingness to do what it takes to restore the broken world that makes her a true beauty!The thing I missed most in this book were the factions. I had hoped that with all the characters missing the world they believed in, that they would help to rebuild but to have a representative from each faction in government rule. Also, there shouldn't be any factionless. If a person fails initiation of their choice then they should be allowed to return home & try a different faction the next day of choosing.Overall the book was well written but a tear jerker. Not the ending I would have preferred but a good read all the same!
summary: Well written, thought provoking, and heart wrenching!

reviewText: Allegiant was a disappointment from the beginning. The main character became a meek crying mess. Her only joyous moments are making out with the other main character. What happened to the strong young women from the first book?The ending makes me think I wasted my time and money on this series. I will not see the movie or recommend it.

The main characters of Tris and Tobias really grew and developed in this third book of the series.  Tobias who seemed so unintimidated in Divergent, revealed an uncertain side in Allegiant.  He lacked self confidence.  Tris on the other hand, held a lot of self confidence, but was warring between what the right thing to do was.  As with most of us, the wrong thing is very tempting to our flesh; this was what she had to overcome.Exploring the Bureau and learning of the division of people, those that were genetically pure and those who were "Damaged", was just a repeat of their city, Chicago, using a different label.  Still there was injustice from those in power and those who weren't.  And thus, another war was brought about to wipe the slate clean and begin anew and afresh.  And... as in any war there are casualties.I enjoyed the strong relationships of the characters throughout the book.  The characters seemed stronger once again in Allegiant.  I, like any other romantic at heart, had to love Tris and Tobias' love story.  Allegiant may not have ended as I would have liked, but it was in keeping with the realities of war.  This one made me cry and the series certainly allows the mind to wonder, what if....?The Divergent Series was thought provoking, adventurous, exhilarating, touching and very satisfying.  I hope my grandkids will read this series.  And further I hope that reading the series will somehow change us in our categorization of our fellow man.
summary: Thoughtful with a beautiful love story

reviewText: Before I decided to read this last book of the Divergent Series I read several negative reviews. I worried that it would not be what I wanted for a conclusion to the lives I have come to care about. It was unexpected, but it worked. I don't believe in spoiler alert reviews so I will only say, be prepared for some loss, sadness and joy. It will not give you fairy tale ending but it is dystopian lit so you shouldn't expect it. There are some nice kernels of insight into the various characters and a satisfying end to all their sagas. You can't get this far in the series and not find out what happens......
I always believe you can learn SOMETHING from any book. This series has so very much to teach about so many things of life that it could be a supplement to the Bible.

I loved the first two books- couldn't put them down.  I struggled to finish this one, the plot was weak the whole way through and the end was so horrible and ridiculous it made me mad that I had spent time reading any of them.  Just read the first two and stop.
summary: Ruined the whole series for me

reviewText: The first two books were stay awake and read page turners this one was not.  Not that I love the ending but would have been fine with it if the rest of the book was exciting like the other two.  I can't remember a point where I couldn't put it down but kept waiting for it.
summary: wasn't the ending that gave it 1 star

reviewText: You lived in a world divided into four sections & you had to decide which section to live in. This trilogy presents that dilemma & the consequences associated with the choices that are made.

I wish I had stopped with book 2 as the 3rd book was a big disappointment all around. It seemed the writer was grabbing at straws to complete this series and in my book it failed. I read these books to see what my teenage grandkids are reading and it all seems so depressing!

Worst end to a trilogy -- EVER.  Divergent was pretty good; Insurgent was OK; Allegiant was terrible. Not just the ending (I guess everyone knows that Tris dies), but because the story made absolutely no sense. I read a ton of fantasy books. I know you have to suspend belief to immerse yourself in the 'world' the author creates.  But the storyline still has make some sense.  There are lengthy reviews already written in detail about this book, so I won't go through it all again.  Really really don't understand the hype around this series.  I thought it was one of the worst of the bunch out there.  The Legend series is much much better -- well written and interesting.
summary: Would give this less than 1 star if I could.

reviewText: This third book of the Divergent Series is very, very good. I didn't really like the ending but I can also see why the author ended it the way she did.....still doesn't make me like it! The series as a whole is very good and a great read. I'm looking forward to reading the life story of Four.

This is a well thought out world with nicely rounded characters.  It raises serious questions about government, humanity, and science without being preachy.  It has action, adventure, and just a hint of romance.  This series should have excellent readership with young adults, as well as those interested in these post-apocalyptic worlds.
Not her best.  I found it inconsistent with the earlier two books and the end was quite disappointing and unnecessary.

Divergent I gave 5 stars, Insurgent I gave 5 stars, and this one gets 1. I'm so disappointed in the ending. It left me feeling completely empty. I have been singing this trilogy's praises and now, I feel like I can't. I am just so upset with how the book left me. So disappointed.
This entire saga is a epic battle of human nature, but also the most moving and amazing reminder of the human spirit.

Wow...I need time to process, but I will tell you I was a blubbering fool for the last 50 pages of this book.So, I let myself process and I'm still keeping my 5 stars. Despite some of the faults I found with the book, overall I really felt it was truly a great conclusion to this series.Blurb from Goodreads:One choice will define you.What if your whole world was a lie?What if a single revelation—like a single choice—changed everything?What if love and loyalty made you do things you never expected?The faction-based society that Tris Prior once believed in is shattered—fractured by violence and power struggles and scarred by loss and betrayal. So when offered a chance to explore the world past the limits she’s known, Tris is ready. Perhaps beyond the fence, she and Tobias will find a simple new life together, free from complicated lies, tangled loyalties, and painful memories.But Tris’s new reality is even more alarming than the one she left behind. Old discoveries are quickly rendered meaningless. Explosive new truths change the hearts of those she loves. And once again, Tris must battle to comprehend the complexities of human nature—and of herself—while facing impossible choices about courage, allegiance, sacrifice, and love.In the hopes of keeping this review spoiler free, I am pretty sure it's going to be shorter than most of what I write.If you want a book that is going to totally tug at your heart strings and make your feelings fly all over the place, then I'm pretty sure this book will hit the mark.The character development in this one is fantastic. My favorite part was actually getting inside Tobias's (Four's ) head. For the longest time we saw Four through Tris's eyes, and as we all know that can't really show us what a character is truly about. Having Four reveal to us what he's thinking, feeling, wanting, was just incredible and really gave a whole new flavor to this series.As for Tris, she kind of annoyed me in this book. As usual she's a bit selfish, always thinking that she's thinking of others but never actually doing it. It was a bit frustrating, but I think all in all she was coming from a good place and really wanted to the best for everyone she loved.The plot, well it's certainly a twist I was not expecting. I have read a few dystopian's recently that took this turn of events, but not in such a way that kept me totally enthralled. The explanation for the factions, how they were formed and why, it totally turned me around and had me walking backward! I was not expecting it. And the pacing was perfect. I was never bored, I always wanted more and I really didn't want to put the book down.There is so much controversy over how Roth decided to end this series. And, while it broke my heart to read the things she wrote, I give her so much credit for going there and doing what she needed she felt to do to bring this saga to a close. It's artistic license and it's amazing. Will people hate her for it, sure. Will people understand her for it, some will some won't. But it really doesn't matter in the long run what others think because it's what was necessary in her eyes and that's what really matters. The chance she takes is amazing and I totally get down on bended knee and praise her for it!Here is my thought to those who are upset: It's a DYSTOPIAN world, things cannot be perfect, having a happily ever after is UNREALISTIC and if you feel like that's what you want, perhaps reading a different sub-genre would be more your style. Roth truly hurt me with this book, but it was necessary. Recently I have been let down by the ends of the trilogies I have been reading. They have not met my expectations at all. But this book, well, this one shot me right back to wanting to read trilogies again.Bravo Ms. Roth. I can't wait to see what you come up with next!
summary: A fantastic ending to this series!

reviewText: It is the worst book and very sad do not read. If you want to cry then go ahead and read but I hated it.

Divergent and Insurgent were amazing. Hard to put down, I neglected my house duties just to read that book. Browsing the grocery store, my thoughts were to get home and devour the rest of those books as quickly as possible. If it were available as a drug, I probably would have Divergent and Insurgent IV'd straight to my veins. Dramatic? Yes.Sadly as my shaking hands opening Allegiant and started to read it, I really felt as though I was coming down after a great adrenaline rush. This is the direction she chose to end the series?! Really? There are numerous reasons but the following pertain most to my opinions...1. STAY TRUE TO YOUR CHARACTERS! In Insurgent Tobias (Four) foot stomps his Dad in the middle of the cafeteria to prove he's not a coward or a 'pansycake'. In Allegiant we find Tobias crying in the corner sucking his thumb. With the technology available in the books, couldn't he get an injection to help with his manic depression? Why would he go from one extreme to the other? Caleb went from being extremely smart in Erudite to a window licker with breakfast sauce on his shirt. VR, please, please get to know your characters and play true to their personalities. While reading, I kept thinking 'WTF'? The characters wouldn't go down like that.2. TRAGEDY WORKS, ONLY IF WRITTEN CORRECTLY. There were times when I was reading and could tell that VR's thoughts were 'Welp, time for someone to die! Bang, bang'. And that was it. Someone would hit the floor or ground and it was supposed to be 'tragic'. Followed by this weird sense of a relative to emerge from the dead and be struck by grief. I'm sorry, not boo hoo sad, it was 'WTF'? Once again.3. TAKE A DIFFERENT DIRECTION. This book could have gone in soooo many different directions. She could have created more of the thrilling, suspenseful and great love plot that was evident in the first two books. Instead VR took a weird, all together nonsensical direction that didn't work. I love The Giver and Pleasantville, infact, dystopic and utopic society stories are by far my favorite. However, the direction that VR took made no sense to me. These people were living LITERALLY right down the street from a gov't facility that was keeping tabs on them and had no clue?4. NO LOOSE ENDS WERE TIED UP. Seriously. None. See above. So many characters were developed in the first two books and then as an aside were just quickly disposed of. Keep going with the characters from the first two books, no new characters were really needed. She created this wonderful foundation to build this book on and really just said 'Meh'. Know your audience and what they want...I'm sure she couldn't give a crap, VR's probably wiping her butt with all the cash she made off of this book.By and large, I was angry, hurt and just plain dumbfounded that this was how the series ended. I felt as though VR stayed up late all night and wrote some drivel that wasn't even half coherent. It makes me sad too, that the publisher allowed the book to be put on stands this way. I'm sad that these characters weren't given the true justice they deserved to be developed and really saw through to the end.
summary: Ugh, Reall? This is the direction VR chose to end the series!?

I finished this book the day after it was released. I had been anxiously awaiting its arrival; annoying everyone in my family by counting the days. Its taken me a week to formulate and digest my thoughts enough to be able to write this review.Let me start by saying I LOVED Divergent! I thought the characters were well developed. For a middle book in a trilogy, Insurgent was better than most.I did not like Allegiant.My dislike is not based at on the twist ending. I enjoy stories that surprise me. An ending that is not your typical happy ending or even an ending that I disagree with makes me think and analyze and question. My dislike is solely based on the writing.The choice to write from alternate points of view is tricky and Roth did not do it well. The voice of each character did not shine through. I very often found myself having to re-check the beginning of  each chapter to see whose POV it was. There was no distinguishing voice between Tris and Tobias.I also felt the writing was boring. The short sentences that flowed so well and were so engaging in the previous two books, fell short in this one. There was not flow to the story and it seemed very repetitive and dull. The word choice was basic and boring.The story itself was repetitive, uprise-share the truth-overthrow, and the plot twist at the beginning involving the United Comonwealth was very contrived. I found myself muttering, "Are you kidding me?!?" many times.I am disappointed  that such an anticipated novel was such a spectacular disaster. My disappointment had me asking many questions. Were the first two books flukes? Did the popularity of the first two go to her head? Was she too focused on the making of the movie? Did she want to distance herself from the wildly popular series? Did Roth actually write this book???Whatever the answers, I know that I cannot recommend this book to anyone. With that being said, when I am advising on what great books to read, I will still recommend Divergent and Insurgent. I will tell readers that making up what happens next is all the fun of reading.As of now, I am referring to Allegiant as The Book That Must Not Be Named.

reviewText: What would you do if the one you anticipated so much failed you?What if it did not turn out the way you want it to?Those are just two of the many questions I wanna ask now to each and everyone who have read this very epic ending of the best selling series Divergent by Veronica Roth.Before I ever got to read this book, I know for sure that it won't end the way that I want it to. I know that it will be a very wrecking ending. Though it did not make me sob, I think that it was still so sad. And just one thing, I think I get it why it happened like that.Veronica made sure that the book would get all the right things it should have; she did not listen to the fans who want every little fantasy they want to happen; she made it really her own story and no one could tell her what to do, which I believe each author should learn from, BUT, there's a big BUT here, people anticipated, waited and begged for it for a year and they ended up tearing and breaking, on bended-knees of why , why, why it turned out that way.AAAAAARGGGH... I can't put into proper words how I really felt when reading the book.There were times that the feeling was intense and there were times that the feeling was just not it! I was disappointed actually. I expected a lot and maybe that also made other people get mad. We expected a LOT from it.But what made me love it is that it was a big twist. Although it was not more of "Allegiant", it was more of the world outside, where EVERYTHING IS ALL EXPLAINED HOW EVERYTHING TURNED OUT FROM THE FIRST BOOK TO THE SECOND BOOK.( I am trying to lift up souls here so that you should read this ending but when you read lots of reviews around the web, it would be hard for you to do it. )OH GOSH, Tris is just so stupid. I believe she is so stupid but NO, I believe it was for the betterment of the people in the city. Caleb was more of a douche, but I still feel sad for him. He haven't gotten to say sorry to Tris and be forgiven!THE BEST CHARACTER I REALLY LIKE IN THIS BOOK IS PETER! You know what? I actually felt a Sutter Keely in him where Miles Teller played him in the movie adaptation of the book Spectacular Now. I can feel him in my mind. It was just so touching that one would sacrifice his memories to become a better person. oh god.to end this review....THIS BOOK DID NOT CONCLUDE EVERYTHING. IT JUST ENDED WHAT WAS SUPPOSE TO END.  I WOULD STILL WANT YOU TO READ THIS BOOK BECAUSE IT MIGHT BE A DIFFERENT READ FOR YOU! :)MAYBE THIS BOOK DID NOT AMAZED ME LIKE THE WAY DIVERGENT DID, BUT IT WOULD BE A DIFFERENT VIEW FOR YOU. :)I WOULD GIVE THIS BOOK A  2/5 ... This is sad but I guess it was still a good book inspite of the tragic ending.Making this review makes me so sad because it would be the last time to review this series and it wasn't the best one. I wish Veronica can redeem herself next time. I hope she won't stop writing just because of all the hates.
summary: THIS BOOK DID NOT CONCLUDE EVERYTHING; IT JUST ENDED WHAT WAS SUPPOSE TO END..

reviewText: I really enjoyed the chapters being narrated by Tris and Tobias. The big step they made toward keeping their relationship intact was their promise not to lie to each other anymore. Tobias really comes across as a character in love with Tris and she makes him feel more secure and a better person, even though they argue and agree to disagree as well. Tris is still more obstinate and very sure of herself- her way of thinking and reactions are so much different than Tobias'.I loved how they showed much more affection for each other and kiss in front of their friends and they are definitely ribbed about it (but they don't care). There are many upheavals with the factions (more history about before the factions), continued drama with Tobias' parents, and Tris' brother, Caleb. I liked the Old Chicago and New Chicago and the aspects of the truth serum and the ambiguity they feel about using them. I never expected the surprise end, but you will have to read the book. I love Roth as a writer and these 3 books were some of my favorite dystopian novels.

Now the only saving grace here is to do what other authors have done and write (and sell) an alternate ending.  People are upset.  Fix it.I hear another author has come out and said Roth doesn't owe us anything.  Well, that's true, although she may possibly owe me my money back for the Kindle version of this piece of garbage.  But the reverse is also true:  I don't owe her anything, and I will not be trusting her again with my money, my time, and, most especially, my imagination.

reviewText: SPOILER FREE!First, let me say that this was a lot easier to read than ‘Insurgent.’ When reading a series, I usually do not go back and re-read the other novels (‘Harry Potter’ is an exception) because I just don’t have time with my grading load, but I HAD to re-read parts of ‘Divergent’ in order to read ‘Insurgent,’ which I did not like. This is not the case with the final installment.I was able to pick up the novel and read and remember everything from the previous book with no issue.Readers are thrust back into Tris’ Chicago, one full of corruption, one on the brink of total chaos. There is a fight for power as those who prefer a Faction life seem lost in the cracks to those who do not. But this is the least of Tris’ worries.Tris and Tobias reunite and decide it is time for outside intervention. It is time to see what is on the other side of the fence. The consequences are great, and the world discovered sends both Tris and Tobias into a tailspin. The question is, can they survive it—and can they find true meaning within their own lives?Roth really had me with this novel. I read the entire story in one day. I could not put it down. I had to see where she was taking me, and where she was going to leave our beloved Tris and Tobias.If you are a fan of the series, you cannot miss this conclusion to the tale. I do not care what you have read/heard/seen, etc. You have to read and experience it for yourself.With that said, I do have a few issues with the novel. There were several holes in the storytelling that were never answered. But I do have a theory: those holes were just a distraction to where Roth was leading us. While I have those questions, I feel as if I have enough of the story to fill in those holes myself. I just don’t always like to do it.I was so torn about this novel when I finished it. I could not reach out to my fellow readers if they had not yet read it—but I could reach out to the hubby. So, I asked him to read it so we could discuss the ending. He read it. Then he said, “You had me read that book and now we aren’t going to discuss it?!” That man.While I read a story of love and friendship, he re-read ‘Insurgent.’ He felt as if Roth just re-wrote the second novel in a different setting. This is what I want to ask you all: did you feel the same way? I did, and I didn’t at the same time. If that makes sense.But, he and I agreed on the ending—and without spoiling it here, let me just say that we both believe it was not the ending for this novel. I have spoken to several of my students and fellow teachers who have read the novel, and they side with us on this as well.But, I do not regret reading the series. At all. I really enjoy Tris and Tobias as separate characters, but I really enjoy when they are on the page together. Roth has a nice pacing to her storytelling, and while she is not a master at world building, she doesn’t need to. In this series, she shows how easily the world can be torn apart, a world that many of us already live in—in a metaphorical sense.If you are a fan of ‘The Hunger Games’ series but you have yet to pick up the ‘Divergent’ series, this is the perfect time to do it. All three novels are out, you don’t have to wait, you can read all three in a row. Then, come back and tell me what you think. I would love to know.

reviewText: It was ok but not nearly as good as the others. I was disappointed. It started out slow and I was not expecting it to end that way. I loved the first three books and really was looking forward to this one. It also got very confusing and did not flow together.
