The story didn't have my favorite ending, but sometimes books don't always end how you want them to.  All in all I loved the series.

SPOILER ALERTThis book falls way short of the series. Divergent was compelling and fast paced and I loved the momentum. Insurgent, in my opinion, was not as good as the first. I felt like I was stuck with 500 pages of being in Tris' emotional, and nervous, breakdown. It was not as fast paced as the first. Unfortunately, the this book does little to mitigate the second book slump of Insurgent. In fact, Roth never should have written this.First there is the differing POVs.  We constantly switch between Tris' and Tobias' viewpoint. I hate books with differing POV. I won't read them. I only read Allegient because I wanted to know how the series would end. Unfortunately, I had to keep going back to the chapter beginning to find out whose head I was in.  Also, the sudden change to differing viewpoints disrupts the continuity of the first two books, which were told from Tris' POV.Also, Tris just doesn't seem to be as strong of a character in this book. I miss her strength and defiance from the first. She also has the annoying habit of always being right. She tells Tobias to stay away from Nita because Nita is using. Of course, Tobias doesn't listen to Tris and decides to trust someone he doesn't know, which made little sense, and then apologizes to Tris later saying that he should have listened to her.  And then there is the fact that Tobias is a weak willed pansy. In Divergent h had a strength that help Tris and fueled her own admirable qualities. But by book three I felt he was nothing but a mopey whiner.None of the characters really followed the traits Roth set them up with in the first two books.  And the resolution made no sense.  Evelyn is a mass murdering little B***.  As she plans to destroy the factions and seize control of Chicago, Tobias decides to have a talk with her. After pages of boring conversation Evelyn decides not to kill people and to become a good person.  The same with Marcus.  In the first two books, Marcus is a prick.  He wants to take over the world, or at least the city of Chicago. However, Johanna talks him out of it with pages of boring conversation.  She says, you shouldn't. It wouldn't be right."  And Marcus basically goes, "Okay."  And that's the end of that. Seriously?  Such actions don't follow the character's personalities and made for a lackluster ending.Then there is Tris' death. I am normally okay with the main character dying as long as it is done right. Their death has to make sense and Tris' didn't, nor was it necessary.  Since Evelyn and Marcus decided not to kill people, why did Tris have to die? She goes into the weapons lab, ingest the death serum, which doesn't kill her because she is somehow immune to it, but that's okay because a bullet finished the job.  The only reason Tris went into the weapons lab was to save Caleb, and to stop the U.S. government from using the death serum to kill innocent people, even though she had no proof that such a thing would ever happen.Rothalso finally explains why Chicago is split into factions and which lies outside, but none of it made much sense. Apparently, the U.S. government decide to mess with genetics to make people a certain way, but it didn't go right. So they wanted to get genetically pure people, by setting up an experiment in Chicago.  And for a few generations, Chicago lives in their own little world while everything they do is filmed by secret cameras and watched by people on the outside.  So, yeah, when the mass murder in Divergent happens, apparently people outside the city were watching it and eating popcorn.  The majority of the book was spent with people talking about genetically inferior people and genetically pure people. It dragged.  In fact, I started skipping pages. I also felt that the explanation of the Tris' world was not well thought out and just thrown in there.Then there is Caleb.  He betrays Tris in book two and remains the coward in this one. He should hve either died with Tris, or at least been with her when she died. Instead, she sacrifices herself for him, something she would do, and he runs away without even trying to stop her.I also had a problem with Peter and Marcus taking the memory serum. They get to forget everything they had done and live a better life elsewhere.  Where's the justice?And lastly, the writing quality.  Roth's writing skills are by no means stellar. I'm not trying to insult her, it's just her writing reminds me too much of the papers I wrote while in high school. A lot of pople write with the same level of skill she does.  Proper writing is not taught in school.  That being said, I was able to ignore the writing style in Divergent because the book moved, and I found myself wrapped up in Tris' world. But in Insurgent, the book moved more slowly and I could not ignore the writing style. The same for Allegiant. This book is not fast paced. the middle is boring. It felt like she only stuck in an action scene so she could kill off a character. Because of this, I could not ignore the average writing style and I stopped caring about the characters.  What made me love the characters in Divergent did not exist in Allegiant.This book was just a huge disappointment. I was hoping for a better ending, especially one that made sense. I felt like she threw the ending together while at the same time trying to see how many pages she could write.  Another case of a story that had promise, but the author screwed it up in the end.
summary: Another case of "I'm a bestselling author so all of my books rock" syndrome.

reviewText: I LOVE this series. Love, love, love!!!! It hurts, but I can't argue with it. My ability to accept this ending (with only a few tears shed) backs up my claim that I would have accepted a tragic ending from Requiem over the "non-ending" that we got.I really enjoyed the alternating POVs - and Four is one of my favorite book boyfriends ever! He's just *sigh* perfect. I though the character development continued to be a strong suit in this book (as it was in the first two), although there were too many minor characters introduced for that to be true across the board. In fact, if I have one complaint, it's that there were just too many characters and not enough time to understand or develop feelings for them all.The writing, as with the first two books, was just phenomenal for me! Here are just a few of the quotes that made me stop and type status updates:"I'm not sure when, or if, anything will ever get better, not sure if these wounds are the kind that can heal."~Tris"I wonder if this is how it is with all evil men, that to someone they look just like good men, talk like good men, are just as likable as good men."~Tris"I know that change is difficult, and comes slowly, and that it is the work of many days strung together in a long line until the origin of them is forgotten. He is afraid that he will not be able to put in that work, that he will squander those days, and that they will leave him worse off than he is now. And I understand that feeling - I understand being afraid of yourself."~Four"There are so many ways to be brave in this world. Sometimes bravery involves laying down your life for something bigger than yourself, or for someone else. reviewText: Ok. Just to start off, I am a HUGE Veronica Roth fan. My friend and I have tried relentlessly to get our other friends to read Divergent. Reading this book, I REALLY wish that I didn't even START reading the series, but, boredom in Taos when your family is on a ski trip miles away from your friends who have "other plans" can't be helped.So, I have been amazingly excited for this book.The plot (at the beginning)was the same sort of thing as the other books in the series. The "perfect" faction system is being disrupted by something/one, and it needs to be fixed. In the first book, it was Jeanine Matthews who was the criminal. In the second, it was the huge number of Dauntless traitors and the Erudite. In this one, well, I'm not saying anything.I was fascinated with the idea of telling some of the story from Tobias's point of view at the beginning, but when I got to the end of the book, I can see why it was necessary. Another thing that I was intrigued by was Tris's mother's backstory. I thought that it was well- written, and it had some things in it that I didn't even expect. I mean, yeah, just before it was revealed, I saw it coming, but it answered questions that I don't think that ANYONE would think of asking.The main attraction for me, as a 14 year-old girl, was the love story. My best friend in the entire universe (a.k.a the girl who introduced me to this series) would just call me crazy. She really doesn't like love stories. Anyway, the love story was really good in this book, but it does get a little bit mature at one point. There wasn't much detail put in it (thank goodness), but, I definitely would not recommend that children 11 and younger should read that scene. There was also a LOT more kissing in this book than in the others (*giggling because I am NOT telling my best friend about that, and I'm going to be evil and make her find out on her own*), which I was glad about, considering the end of the book.And now, for the last (and definitely most least that you can get) point I'm going to make. *clears throat and drinks some water* All right, here goes: WHY THE HECK DID YOU DO THAT, VERONICA ROTH??????!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! OHMYGOD, WHY DID I WAIT FOR SUCH A LONG TIME JUST TO HAVE A HUGE FREAKING DISAPPOINTMENT?????!!!!!!!!! I GET THAT YOU DIDN'T WANT TO HAVE YOUR BOOK END LIKE EVERY OTHER YA ROMANCE OUT THERE, BUT STILL, WHY COULDN'T YOU END IT WITH A BREAKUP???? DID YOU HAVE TO MAKE ONE OF THE MAIN CHARACTERS DIE??? DID YOU HAVE TO??? BECAUSE I DON'T SEE THE FREAKING POINT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Meltdown complete.The ONLY reason that I gave this book a 2 star rating was because the love story was interesting.

reviewText: I loved this series up to the end, but I feel like Ms. Roth gave up just to end the series.  I still like this book, but it's clear from this installment, that there can be no continuation.

Allegiant is the final book of the Divergent Trilogy by Veronica Roth. In this final action-filled installment, Tris and Tobias leave everything they have known and travel outside the fence. Their old faction-based society has been destroyed by violence brought on by the surprising discovery at the end of Insurgent. Outside the boundary they discover a reality that is more disturbing than what they left behind. Their whole life until now has been a lie and no one can be trusted. Can Tris face incredible choices about love and loss when everything she knows has been stripped away?In Allegiant, Roth investigates the profound themes of courage, allegiance, and sacrifice. Tris and Tobias must have courage to jump into the unknown and fight for what they believe in. They need to risk everything they know to discover what lies beyond the fence. They must have allegiance to their cause. They must show love with every sacrifice. As Tris states, “Sacrifice is the ultimate way to show someone that they love you” (448).The noble elements do not quite outweigh the sad incidents. The duel perspective in Allegiant gives insight into Tobias’s character and makes the story more interesting. Tobias fights and wins feelings of self-doubt created by the real world leaders. The dramatic climax illustrates everything Tris and Tobias have worked for up until this point. Although the major conflict is resolved, the ending of Allegiant is a sad reminder that not all stories have happy endings.Although I liked the majority of the book, Roth did not skillfully wrap up the ending to the trilogy in a satisfactory way. The illusion of a perfect ending with all the conflict resolved was a false hope that ended in discontent. Overall, I was very dissatisfied with the end of this trilogy.

Mrs. Roth missed the opportunity to establish herself as a writer who her readers would be eagerly looking for her next novel. They won’t. The disappointment was irreparable.

Though I did rush through the middle because it slowed down got too weighty in the middle, it picked right back up.There were lots of surprises, and things I both expected, dreaded and couldn't wait for.I loved getting into Four's head and getting his perspective. It was an added bonus in this and gave us some valuable insight.Tris is as strong as ever, even though she has her flaws, that makes her even more relatable, and easy to like and pull for. She has the recklessness, but also the courage and sacrifice that defines her.There is non-stop action in this one, tying up loose ends and resolving all of the plots.OMG. The ending. I am one of the people who are torn. I hate it and saw it coming, but at the same time I love it and think it is fitting. It depends on what moment you ask me.Bottom Line: Fitting and bittersweet trilogy conclusion.

SPOILER ALERTOne could argue that Ms. Roth was under the influence while writing the last book of the series - the influence of her success with the first book and political correctness.  The token gay relationship is finally thrown in for no apparent reason except public pressure.  But there is more, much more, going on here:The only loving, caring relationship in the series is Beatrice' mother and father, both slaughtered to define the fact this is an historical relationship - none of the current characters has a normal loving relationship.The genetically pure vs genetically damaged schism is a mirror to what is really going on - we are never quite convinced that the genetically damaged are not, in fact, genetically damaged.  After going to some length to explain how meddling with genetics produced a large number of sociopaths and misfits, primarily male, we are then expected to jump to the conclusion that, in fact, nothing was really the matter with anybody in the end - it's all just a misunderstanding.To continue on the males: every male central to the plot is sociopathic, cruel, violent and manipulative: Marcus (mark us) is irredeemably evil and even our hero Tobias is "broken" inside - whether as a result of genes or memes we cannot tell but he constantly fights the same violent impulses as his father.  Beatrice cannot be allowed to live after making a choice inconsistent with the matriarchal theme of the series: Tobias.  Caleb is a coward, Eric is cruel, the only solution for Peter and David is a brain wipe.A series of matriarchs beginning with the mothers of each hero and including Jeanine, Johanna, Tori and the stern old single mother of Uriah and Zeke (who are Compliant males: smiley, happy, non-confrontational) dominate the story with the message that a non-violent matriarchy is the solution to all our problems, not tampering with genetics.  Men who do not comply are to be controlled through whatever coercive means are available, authoritarianism is preferred, not overt violence - thus Jeanine, Tori and ultimately Beatrice are killed off for resorting to violence and Johanna is left in a position of influence with Tobias, head shaved like a monk, shuffling around as her apprentice and acolyte.It is a deft representation of current ultrafeminist theory - not feminism where men and women are equal, but a matriarchal point of view where women are superior and men to be controlled through coercion and manipulation - or culled, if necessar. The destruction of the modern family through abortion, adultery, divorce and propaganda keeps violent men from passing on their genes or at least their ideas and traditions, so that we can all live in an Amity compound where mother knows best.  If we can't keep these men from breeding, at least we can take their kids away from them to stop them passing on their ideas, traditions and weaknesses.Veronica Roth has created a remarkable vehicle for spreading this ideology - sort of a Berenstein Bears for the YA market - it is difficult to tell whether it is deliberate or whether she is simply a product of several generations of programming.

T_T This book killed me. I am dead. I am crushed. I am pulverized. I... honestly don't know what to say.Allegiant is the explosive conclusion to The Divergent Trilogy by Veronica Roth. I loved it. And in the end I hated what the author did to me. I want to scream "NOOOOO!!! You can't do this!"When it arrived the day it was released, I was beyond excited. I immediately began reading it. Knowing it was the final book, I chose to take my time. I didn't rush it. The beginning started out pretty slow and gradual, as this book takes place a week or so after the events of book two.But about 10 chapters in, it was going at a steady pace and I was getting answers. A third of the way in, my mind was blown. I had a hard time contemplating everything I was learning about the world of Divergent.Allegiant is told from both the perspectives of Tris and Four (also shipped as Fourtris). I was glad for the chance to get inside Four's head. But I also got irritated with him from time to time.Eventually he and Tris define their relationship and take it to the next level.The ending though... *choke* I am so... crushed...Violence - Mild. Violence is not gratuitous.Sexy stuff - Lots of kissing and sex is implied.Language - A few uses of the s-word, "d*mn", "h*ll", and cr*p".Scary Scenes - Mild.All in all, this conclusion was in fact explosive. In more ways than one, as it both imploded my heart, and blew me away.What did you think of the finale?5 of 5 stars!

**SPOILER ALERT!!!!!!!**So I definitely have mixed feelings about this third book. I think that it was interesting to find out all the information about the genetic damage situation and That everything was a government ploy (mostly because this is supposed to be a dystopian novel) and it also felt more relatable to me because i live in the US. I also enjoyed the point of view switching; and yes it could have used a bit more tonal/ personality difference. But mostly, I think people are failing to see that this is the end to a trilogy.Not only did Ms. Roth give the characters some depth, she allowed us to see that society can begin again even through tragedy. That people can forgive, move forward, and lend strength to others when they don't have any left within themselves. I was devastated when Tris died (I mean snot running down my face on the bus) but it forced Tobias to change and develop into the man we all knew he could be.So kudos to Ms. Roth for giving a bittersweet but fitting ending to this story.
The end will destroy you. I am emotionally broken. WHAT EVER YOU DO READ THIS BOOK!!!!!!!!! ~Brianna the book lover (I'm so sorry Tobias)

Why? So much happened in this book series and to have this ending absolutely killed me. This is an amazing book but so unbelievably sad. Anyone can read this book but no one could not cry in the end.Very good but so sad.Perfection.

**SPOILER WARNING**I have never been more disappointed in a book. First, I could not tell the difference between the viewpoints of Tris and Tobias. I continually had to flip back to the beginning of the chapter to remember from who's point of view I was reading. The majority characters completely changed and acted in ways they never would have based on the previous books. For example, Tris, the heroine, decides that to stop the horrible act of the Bureau erasing everyone's memories, she will simply erase all of theirs? Makes sense. Evelyn gives up all power and desire to lead because Tobias asks nicely and Marcus willingly surrenders leading because Johanna asks? I don't think so. And even if that specific Bureau has their memories erased, the rest of the Bureaus in the country do not! So, it is not going to fix anything anyway. As a result, Tris dies for nothing. Honestly, I like when books do not have a happy ending ("The Fault in Our Stars") because it is realistic, but there needs to be a point! And what happened to Tobias? I didn't even recognize him in this book. The strong, smart, observant leader crumbles into someone unrecognizable. Finally, worst of all, the information we discovered in this book made everything that previously happened pointless. Tris' mother died to release a video that meant nothing? Great. The Bureau and Abnegation had memory serum the whole time, but no one used it on Jeanine when she was killing masses of people? Sure. Divergent means nothing? Awesome. This book not only makes me wish I did not read it, but makes me wish I didn't even start this series in the first place.
summary: EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTED. WISH I WOULDN'T HAVE EVEN STARTED THE SERIES.

reviewText: This book was a fantastic end to the Divergent series. In it Tobias, Tris and a small bunch of people from a group that calls themselves the Allegiant venture outside the boundaries of the city they call home and  end up discovering the people who have been running the "Chicago Experiment" in their city. They learn the truth behind the experiment and the world outside their little home. It is amazing to watch their struggle with right and wrong in this new world. The ending came as quite a shock to me and I am sure it will be well loved by divergent fans for years to come.

This is a great story, but the YA themes are strong. As an adult reading it, I didn't feel as compelled by the story or plot as I have with other good YA fiction. It's no Hunger Games, but it's close. I found the conclusion to the series a bit surprising, but satisfying.
summary: Good read, but not much depth

reviewText: This book was a let down after the amazing first two in the series.  It didn't seem to have a clear purpose and there was too much dialogue and not enough action.  The ending left me feeling depressed not excited or hopeful.  Now I'm having mixed feelings about the movie, which I was so excited about, because I will know that it will inevitably end in doom.

I am deeply torn about how I feel towards this final chapter in the divergent triology. I don't want to say much more for fear of giving anything away to potential readers. I realize that not all stories have the happiest of endings because reality/life doesn't always have a happy ending, but the reason I enjoy reading young adult fiction is to escape the harsh realities of life not for my imagination to be subjected to it. So if you want a happy ending don't read this book.Also, the whole "genetically damaged" concept got a bit confusing at times, but I was able to figure out the basic principle enough to understand what was going on at the end.Still love the main characters, especially Tris & Tobias.

I have no idea whether to even begin with this review. I want to write a lot but I will never have enough time to write what all I think went wrong with this book. I'm finding it hard to think of any other series ending I have been so disappointed in.This final book felt rushed. It actually seemed like someone who didn't know the characters wrote this book. The duel POVs did not work. I think by giving us Tobias's perspective, she actually took away his voice. This Tobias didn't seem anything like the one in the previous books.The whole underlying meaning of the series of being Divergent (I mean, come on, it's the title of your first book Roth), just vanishes. It's kinda like oh, being divergent is genetic so you aren't anything special and what you have done isn't special.I usually never agree with killing off a main character but I don't mind when it adds something and provides meaning. This death was just wrong in so many ways. First off, it was too rushed and almost like an after thought. I feel like it was added for shock value but honestly wasn't shocking at all. It was just annoying. This book made me dislike Tris at times before her death but I really disliked her after. She took away Caleb's redemption. It made sense for him to sacrifice himself for the greater good. Having her take that away from him just proved that Tris had not grown as a character. She did choose to sacrifice herself regardless if what she told Caleb to tell Tobias. If Tobias was really "her family now" and "she wanted to choose to live," then she would have let Caleb do it. Oh, but Tris is always right. Sorry for the rant but I just am really annoyed by her now.Overall, I think the author had a great idea and wrote 2 great books. Allegiant just felt like it didn't have enough thought into the writing or the plot decisions. This is the first time that I wish I hadn't read a series at all. I think she should have waited to release this book until after the first movie came out because now I'm not sure if I even want to watch the movies.

I think it would be impossible for me to review this book without spoilers, so fair warning, THERE ARE SPOILERS AHEAD!!!//////Okay, I have read quite a few reviews on this book now, so I'd like to add my two cents. I have been a fan of the Divergent series from the beginning. Any time someone asks for a book recommendation, it is always up there at the top of my list. But after reading Allegiant, I don't know if I can continue recommending it.I feel like the author was rushed into finishing this book. Because she has a much larger fan base than she did with the first and second books, I'm sure there was more pressure on her to finish it. I was happy with the book until about a third of the way through it. Once Tris started learning the "secrets" from beyond the fence, the story just lost me. Too many serums, too many simulations, too many conspiracies. I liked the idea of their community (and others) being a sociological experiment. But I don't understand why the genetic cause/pure vs damaged/etc. had to come into it. Why couldn't it simply have been that our society was so far gone that these communities had been set up to salvage and hopefully improve what was left of humankind??I also felt that there were far too many new characters introduced this time around without enough character development. I didn't feel any sort of attachment to anyone that wasn't already from Divergent/Insurgent. They all just seemed flat to me.Now, I have read a lot of criticism of both the double pov and Four's character in general. After reading Roth's short stories from Tobias' perspective, I actually appreciated seeing things from his side. However, I do agree that the two voices were very similar. I sometimes got 3 or 4 pages in before I realized the narrator had changed. As for Four being "whiny" or "wimpy" in Allegiant--I agree that he appeared to have lost some of his spark. But come on, cut the guy a break. Not everyone can be a super dauntless all the time...Now finally, the ending. Why, why, why? I have read Veronica Roth's explanation on her blog, but I still feel it was unnecessary to kill Tris.  I know her journey was about learning to be both brave and selfless. That, as opposed to in Insurgent, she really did value her life and have the desire to live. But I think it's crap that she died! Why not allow Caleb the opportunity at the end to finally redeem himself and take the bullet for her after she had overcome the death serum? Couldn't that have served the purpose of her learning to be selfless while giving him the chance to show he still loved her?I adore Veronica Roth and loved the series, but I really, really feel she got this one wrong. So in my head, I have changed the ending to the way I think it should be. And Tobias and Tris work together to restore balance in their city. The ending didn't have to be a "happily ever after"--just a "we don't screw up the whole story by killing off the main character, ruining the love story, and forever ruining this book!"

Original review here: [...]Since 2011, youth across the country have been fascinated and enthralled with Veronica Roth's bestselling series, Divergent. In a world full of YA fiction ranging from questionable to downright preachy, Roth brings new elements to the table: a lovely balance of realism and enveloping storytelling one can't help but fall in love with.The story begins with Tris and Four making discoveries about their city that no one ever even had an inkling about. The two warring sides clash immediately, and the ensuing danger leaves Tris and Four with critical decisions to make. Decisions about the massive revelations and the impending war inside the city's fence threaten to throw off their entire existence, but then dire circumstances force them to go outside the fence in search of what lies beyond.Veronica Roth moves her plot along nicely. So nicely, in fact, that I personally mourn the loss of skill and talent in today's YA market-or the market in general. Roth carries about herself a presence of knowledge: knowledge of her world, her characters, her own identity and skill level. Each tier of certainty shines through until I forgot I was reading a work of fiction. The world and plot build up organically, like a mental pop-up book. This being the end of a trilogy, part of me was incredibly hesitant to get to the end. The vast majority of series suffer from Bad Ending Syndrome (BES), where, for reasons unknown, the author throws anything they can together to pull all the loose threads into a cord that quickly frays and reveals the haste-waste. Roth came around with the origins of her world without missing a beat, and by the end of the book, I felt whole and complete, like I had missed nothing and everything had fallen together. That being said, parts in the middle did lag a bit; plot-wise or not, it could have been tightened up to make things progress more quickly.From the very first book, the biggest facet in Roth's distinct style is her use of real characters. Today's market--no matter the style, genre, age group, or whatever--suffers from an overabundance of perfect people, surface conflicts, and unbelievable situations. For instance: a beautiful, kind, talented girl who doesn't think herself beautiful, kind, or talented falls in love with a mysterious, handsome, secretly-kind boy who tells her otherwise, and they proceed to solve problems come the turn of a page and live happily ever after. Roth destroys this archetype. Her characters are so real, you could expect to walk into any store and see them there. They are flawed, average-looking, talented in unique ways, and always searching for something to make them whole. Within the series, Roth touches on what that Thing is: God.Veronica Roth has never hidden the fact that she's a Christian from any of her fans. What makes her so relatable and believable is that she's a Christian who lives as Christ did: hanging with the outcasts, never preaching directly in someone's face because she thinks they need to hear it or they're going to Hell, always letting people discover for themselves how God is speaking to them through her work. This infusion of reality and faith hits the spirit hard, and this is exactly what Christians need to start doing. We need to set a standard that's far from rose-colored stained glass and be real with not only ourselves and everyone around us, but with God Himself. Roth has begun a precedent I respect highly and strive to follow myself. She has my utmost admiration.Allegiant has zero blasphemy when it comes to cursing; only scattered cusses dot the pages, and characters never use the "f-word". The only sensuality to worry about is Tris kissing Four. One character drinks alcohol due to grief over lost friends, but nothing is promoted or glorified. The only thing prevalent in Allegiant is violence; Roth never glorifies or shows explicit pictures of the violence enacted. Guns, knives, fists, and bombs are used as weapons.Though the Divergent series has closed out, I find myself incredibly satisfied by Roth's method. Tris' world will forever live in my heart, and I can only say a thank-you to Veronica Roth for letting the story tell itself instead of dictating what was to happen. The end is already written. Writers simply have to listen to find out what that ending is--no matter the heart-wrenching costs.

I'm sorry, but this review is going to contain spoilers - the key elements of this book bothered me, so beware if you choose to read on!This book starts off by splitting the perspective between Tris and Tobias - this threw me off at first, but after reading the end I see why Roth did it. However, it didn't add anything to the story. I still don't think Tris and Tobias had any special spark that made me attached to them as characters. I was constantly confused as to whose chapter I was reading because being inside Tobias' head didn't feel any different. I also still felt that everyone outside of T&T; were interchangeable and easily expendable. I didn't feel that any of them really bonded and every time someone died I felt nothing - none of these characters really seemed to matter.Roth also revealed the explanation for the factions and the cities, but there were so many other layers and revolts that it just feel felt convoluted. Tris and Tobias were ready to jump into any revolt and seemed to just take everything they were told for face value. It was like after everything they went through, they didn't learn anything!My last issue was how Tris acted in the end. I just don't buy that she was so self sacrificing. I felt that she became less believable as the books went on - she didn't feel as mature as her actions made her seem. Overall, I'm glad I read the series, but I wasn't overly impressed by it. Part of it might be my age - while I love YA fiction, I expected this series to be a bit more mature.

The masses of information being dumped on the reader were endless and hard to sort out. I found that Tobias and Tris had suddenly turned into lovesick teens with the shuffle of "i'm mad at you! We're breaking up! I love you!! Don't leave me!" seeping into every chapter. YAWN. I kept waiting for some big revelation, something to make sense and bring it all together, something EXCITING to happen...but it never did.  I had a sneaking suspicion that Tris wouldn't make it out alive so I was ready for that. My reaction to her death was mild and slightly sniffly but nothing in comparison to my reaction to another book and the main character's SISTER dying. That had me sobbing my eyes out. It's unfortunate that these two series are going to be frequently compared...but there it is. Competing dystopian society books with strong, aggressive yet fragile and searching female leads dealing with entirely too much responsibility at a very young age. I wish this book had been better. I really do. The first two books were MUCH better efforts. This just felt very forced and a "tie up the loose ends as fast as possible" kind of ending. Oh well. I'm glad I read the books before the movies start pouring out.

reviewText: I felt that Veronica shined a huge spotlight on how much truth and growth Tris and those who interacted with her experienced and achieved at the end of Allegiant and I applaud her for it. Although devastatingly heartbreaking, I felt the book couldn't have ended in any other way. It was poetic, and beautiful. I ached for Four more than I was sad for Tris because she wasn't just noble and brave, she was honorable and extraordinary; she ensured a new life-path for all those she loved and even those she didn't love.She also had such an impact through her actions, thoughts, and words towards those around her that they didn't need to be Divergent to show they were capable of being what they thought they could not be as demonstrated by Four choosing not to take his Mother's memories away as well as Caleb's ability to even feel guilt for what he had done, then love towards his sister. That is her true legacy--her ability to affect those around her by her example and show them they were capable of making choices based on reasons other than genes, or faction standards.Thanks for writing your heart, Ms. Roth, and for weaving together such an awe inspiring story. I enjoyed every bit, even the hard bits because they were real, and morally inspiring.

I've been waiting years to read Allegiant. I've been excited for it, and then dreading it. It finally arrived today, and I started and finished it right away. I'm unsure how to feel. I will try my best to describe it, though. But it will be hard, because I have a lot of feelings and not too many of them are positive. Sorry.I know that I will not be able to write my review without talking about the parts that bothered me the most. So there will be spoilers. But not at first. First, non spoilers. And then I will give a warning and talk mostly about some of the spoilery things :)I don't know how to start. The writing in Allegiant is still very amazing, liked it better than the first two books. The characters are pretty amazing, though I probably only loved Tobias in this book. Tris just could not stop pissing me off. I wish it wasn't that way, but it was and I'm not going to lie about it. I'm giving Allegiant a three star, but right now even that feels like too much when I think of the things that happened.I'm not going to talk too much about the book before I start talking about all the spoilers. Because there isn't much I want to say that doesn't spoil everything. But I am going to say that I did enjoy the book at times, it did some time have things that I enjoyed. I am happy that I read it, because the ending was actually the one thing that I approved of in this book. In a way, which I will explain soon. Some things were interesting to read about. I wasn't bored. But I wasn't very interested in it either. Which sucked.I have seen that people are attacking Veronica as a person after reading Allegiant. I will not do that. Because I adore her and I do think she's pretty amazing. Especially since I got to meet her last summer :) But anyway. I think she did a good job with this book, though I mostly just liked the ending. But I am still very interested in seeing what she writes next, and I'm not going to hate her for not writing this book like I wanted her to do. I do, of course, feel a little bit resentment. But not too much. I hope.Now begins the SPOILERS. Do not read unless you want to know or have finished Allegiant :)I adored Tobias in this book. He just gets better for each book. But seriously. Is anyone ever going to care for him? To love him, and to think of him first? It's starting to bother me a lot that no one does. It isn't fair and to me it felt very overlooked. Tobias deserved more. He deserved more love and more faith. Which he did not get. And that breaks my heart the most. But even so, I adored reading about him and he will always be one of my favorite characters from every book. He is just perfect. So broken.Then there is Tris. My god, I could not stand her in this book. And I'm sorry for saying it, but not really. I did not like her in this book. I did not approve of her choices. She does not talk enough with Tobias. She does not seem to trust him. She does not comfort him at all. And she has done so many mistakes. When he does one, I didn't even think it was that big of a deal, she's breaking up with him. Talk about unfair. I felt like she was being childish. After how much she hurt him, and he survived that. So she should too.There is just so many things in this book that I disliked. We get to know why there are factions, why they live alone. And to be honest, I wasn't impressed with it. It was interesting, but not exciting for me. Things just felt a bit flat for me. The characters weren't very interesting anymore either, and that made me very sad. I did like Christina, though not too much of her either. More of Cara, and I'm even starting to like her more than Tris. She would even be better for Tobias. Sigh. I just did not love this book.One of the worst things about this for me was that Marcus was not punished for all the wrong things he did. I wanted him to die a horrible death. He didn't even get shot or tortured or anything. It wasn't fair and yeah. Not happy about it. I even started liking Peter, and I'm not pleased about his ending either. Didn't truly think he was that much of a coward. I liked Uriah better in this book, but then he had to die. Which truly sucked, because he was one of the better characters. All the good ones die, I suppose.But then. The thing I hated the most happened at about page 300. Tobias does something kind of stupid, like I said above, and Tris is so heartbroken and angry about it and blah blah blah. It was nothing compared to her killing Will. To her giving up her life at several occasions. Yet she acts like Tobias did an unforgiving thing. He did not deserve that kind of treatment at all and it broke my heart. Made me hate Tris a bit. She wasn't being fair. It gets sorted, but not in the way I felt it needed to be.I just couldn't get over the way she treated him. And I'm sorry, but oh. I'm pissed off about it. Which is why I did not mind the ending too much; because Tobias deserved much better than her. Fine, she sacrificed her life for Caleb. But seriously? Why did she do that? Caleb wanted to do it. He didn't have the best boyfriend and the best friends. So why did she go and die, when she said she did not want to leave Tobias? Who does that? I may be able to understand it, but not now. To me it was selfish.But in a way I'm happy she died. It made my heart break for Tobias, because he deserves more than anybody to be happy. It's even making me cry right now, because my heart breaks for him. But I'm happy it was her that died and not Tobias. That would have just been.. unforgiveable. But I'm still not agreeing with it, because to me it was a silly reason. Which you should all get if you have read the book. But anyway. Tobias was the bright point in this book. His point of view was the very best of it all.Oh, and that is the biggest spoiler. Kind of. Because why else would Veronica add Tobias point of view to these books? Oh, because Tris dies and then someone else need to tell the end of the story. I should have gotten that ages ago, when it was announced. Sigh. But anyway. I am glad I read Allegiant, I just know I will not forgive the way Tobias was treated. He deserved so much more and I will stand by that. Anyway. I just had to share my spoilery thoughts. Thank you. Read it? Give me your thoughts :)

This is so hard to rate. I found the first 75% to be kinda dull and arduous. I would have given it 3 stars. But the last 25% connected with the magic and charm that was in the first book. And the last 10% shredded my heart and brought tears to my eyes.What can I say about this book, the 3rd book in the Divergent series, without giving anything away? This book, and in turn the whole series, is one giant question about nature versus nurture. And are certain genes inferior to other genes. What makes a perfect person? Everyone has a different answer to these questions. And these answers have shaped whole societies in this series. Shaped how we think of others. Shaped how we think of ourselves. But is that really all there is to us?This book is also about the discovery of lies. Layers upon layers of lies. It made me wonder if anyone really knew the whole truth anymore. Everyone thinks they know what's for the best. And who really suffers? The answer is everyone.But somehow a better society emerges. And this happens at great cost. I imagine the lower ratings for this book have to do with choices that are made in the end. I have more respect for an author who has the balls to shake things up.
