A brief list of the parts of Allegiant that I did not enjoy:1. The beginning.2. The middle.3. The end.A brief list of the parts of Allegiant that I did enjoy:...Okay, never mind that second list. I honestly can't think of a single thing I liked about this book.Believe me, no one was more disappointed by this than I was. It's been a while since I readDivergentandInsurgent, but I remember feeling so energized by both of them (especially by the ending of Insurgent). And yeah, sure, the world didn't really make a lot of sense from the get-go, but I really didn't care, because the books were SO. MUCH. FUN. Allegiant? It is not fun. It is the exact opposite of fun.**SPOILERS** (because I think they are unavoidable in a negative review of this book)There was just so much about Allegiant that didn't work for me. Let's start with the dual narration between Tris and Tobias. While I actually prefer novels with multiple points-of-view (since it allows for a wider scope), I can't even fully articulate how poorly the strategy was executed in this book. In order for dual narration to be effective, the characters must each have their own inner voice. That was completely absent in Tris and Tobias; they sounded exactly the same. They sounded so similar, in fact, that if I stopped reading at a break in the middle of a chapter, I completely forgot who was narrating when I started reading again (even if it was only five minutes later). Sometimes I'd forget WHILE I was reading! Adding to the confusion is the fact that Tobias and Tris are together for about 90% of the book, so their perspectives really aren't that different. It seems like the only reason Veronica Roth gave us both points of view in Allegiant is because of what happens at the end. And that just isn't reason enough to use that strategy. I would have forgiven her if she did it well, but she definitely didn't.And speaking of Tobias's point of view...it added NOTHING to my understanding of his character. In fact, it actually made me DISLIKE his character quite a bit. Where was the brave Dauntless with only four fears that I knew from the previous books? The man who was scarred, unflinching, but soft somewhere within? What happened to him? Because he certainly doesn't appear in these pages. All Tobias does in Allegiant is whine, make illogical, out-of-character decisions, and whine some more. Dude, okay, we get it. You have daddy and mommy issues (and rightfully so, of course). You're not divergent like you thought you were. The Four that I THOUGHT I knew would have sucked it up and done something about it. But the Four in THIS book wallows endlessly in a pit of self-pity. And when he finally DOES do something, it is so very clearly the wrong thing.The entire book just felt completely pointless. It began with the realization that Edith Prior's message was completely bogus, which made the ending of Insurgent meaningless (and, by the way, the fact that Edith Prior's message was pointless -- and therefore, the reasoning for the message in the first place -- is almost completely glossed over, which irritated me to no end). It ended with Tris's completely pointless death. And between those two events, well, not much really happens. The setting of this book, although outside of Chicago, is very narrow. We don't get much of a view of the world beyond O'Hare, aside from a brief glimpse of the Fringe. And the Fringe, by the way? Really not all that interesting. It COULD HAVE been, if it was utilized more and better. So much about this book COULD HAVE been better. Like, for instance, the plot.The plot was...practically nonexistent. This book is actually BORING for large parts, because nothing really happens. And the plot holes are GIGANTIC. Like the whole explanation for the factions, which makes no sense if you know even the tiniest bit about genetics. And the reasoning behind Tris's death. We need to talk about that.It's not Tris's death itself that bothered me. Not to sound morbid, but I actually think the death of a protagonist or other beloved character can work very well. It can be meaningful, beautiful, heartbreaking, and offer a new perspective. That is, if it's done well -- and if the character's death has some greater meaning.As I mentioned before, Tris's death seemed completely pointless to me. While the death seemed "in character" according to what readers know about Tris (that she is selfless and constantly makes dumb decisions in an effort to sacrifice herself for her loved ones), it wasn't at all necessary. The reasons behind her death were completely nonsensical, because the whole "plan" that the group came up with to save Chicago was totally ridiculous. You couldn't think of anything better than wiping the memories of the people in the compound, even though the wider world will still have the same ideas about GDs and GPs? Really? I'm giving you the side-eye, Veronica. How about...giving everyone in Chicago the antidote to the memory serum? Or giving David the truth serum and forcing him to give them the password so it wouldn't be necessary to break in? The whole premise was built on such faulty logic and, frankly, felt to me like an insult to the readers' intelligence.Bottom line: Veronica Roth wanted to kill Tris. She came up with this ridiculous idea for how it would happen, ignored all logic and all other possible lines of thinking, and made that happen. And not only did she kill her -- she gave her a passive death. If Tris had gone down fighting (since she spent the whole book up to that point reminding us how much she wanted to live -- foreshadowing 101!), her pointless death could have maaaybe been redeemed for me a bit. Instead, Tris just completely gave up and suddenly became willing to die. Tris was an awesome character -- a bit holier-than-thou (especially in this book) and rash, sure, but still a strong, thoughtful, well-developed character. To have her die like that just didn't do her justice. Not one bit.And I still can't wrap my mind around the stupidity of the conclusion to the factions vs. factionless storyline (most of which occurs outside of this book's pages, again rendering many of the events in Insurgent meaningless). The idea that a whole city -- or, I'm sorry, "experiment" -- was saved by a mother's love for her son was just laughable to me -- because NOTHING that Evelyn had done up to that point would indicate that she would choose Tobias over her aspirations. More nonsense. The random secondary character deaths, relayed for the most part with no emotion whatsoever? Nonsense. The reliance on the serums as a major plot device? Nonsense. The blatant disregard for how our DNA actually works? Nonsense.And in the end? More pointlessness, because as we see from the Epilogue, nothing has really changed, aside from the fact that Tris and a bunch of other people are dead. So what did we learn? What was the whole point of the trilogy? That people mend each other? Oh. Okay. I AM GIVING YOU THE SIDE-EYE AGAIN, VERONICA.Bottom line: This book reads like the first draft of a novel that was poorly thought-out. I get the sense that the story just kind of got away from Roth and she didn't really know what to do with it. Like she wrote this fun book about a factioned society, and then later realized she'd need to explain the reasoning behind that societal structure -- and she had no idea how to do that. Allegiant needed to be revised a few more times to make it make even a little bit of sense. On top of that, the prose was over-wrought, and the entire book just took itself way too seriously.I wasn't even going to review this because I thought I'd be too rambly (which is obviously what happened), but I finished this book a week ago and I still can't stop thinking about how awful it was. I wish I could take that stupid memory serum and forget I ever read it.
summary: Allegiant fails on all levels. I'm sorry, but it does.

reviewText: I was concerned at first when I purchased all the books. The reviews for the third volume were way less complimentary. Having read all the books, I can see why some people may not have liked book 3. If you're completely entranced by book 1 and you want to just have life be exactly what you thought it was when you first entered Divergent, feel free to stay there. Be deluded that everything is what you think it is. But Life is never like that. It's never just one layer deep--whether we're talking about the internal or the external world. Life is more complicated than you thought. So if you like being challenged to see a much bigger picture--one that wobbles and shakes, and is most likely going to betray you--then dig into book 3. It's more tragic and yet more "real life" than you might have expected. And it was worth all the investment I'd made into reading the Divergent Series. Besides, humanity isn't much different now from any "then" you choose (in history or future). And humanity will keep making the same mistakes. But it's still worth living.
summary: Shakes your core, but real life will do that when you understand bigger pictures

reviewText: A big disappointment from an author who wowed us with her first two in this series. I am a middle school teacher and I did not like it. It read slowly, had point of view issues, and a terrible ending. I will no longer even recommend the first book because of how she ended the series.

While I understand some people's disappointment with the ending of the novel (and the series), I actually think it was fitting. The rest of the novel was on par with the first two books in my opinion. The only thing I didn't think was plausible is the explanation for why the city of Chicago exists in its "current" form. I you enjoyed the other two books, I'd ignore the naysayers and give this a try.
So sad but amazing I cried through half and could not put it downBe sure to have tissues!!!  Seriously.
I really liked the originality of the series.  I loved reading the entire series, but the ending was a bit sad.

I was discouraged when I first started reading this book because of all the harsh comments. Yet, I was really enjoying it! I thought this book was well written and kept me reading. Quite frankly it was everything I had hoped and more. This book was a very good farewell to the series, though I am sad to see it go. I strongly encourage Divergent fans to read this last novel. I will remain a strong Veronica Roth fan. I know I will be attending The Divergent movie and I hope others will too.

The dual narrator device was not well done, and the ending was terrible.  In fact, most of this third book was terrible.  I really liked Divergent, and mostly liked Insurgent, so I was intrigued enough to buy Allegiant to see what the big pay-off would be - and it turned out to be someone thumbing their nose at the reader.  Don't like that when it happens in real life, and it will definitely never happen again - if Ms. Roth writes another book or series, I'll have to take a pass.
summary: I'd give it less than 1 star if I could

reviewText: I found this trilogy a cut above the usual formulaic, popular series that dystopian readers are offered nowadays.  The beauty of this set of novels is the freshness of the characters with all their rough and tender, I.e. human, edges exposed and the enfolding of the idea of sacrifice from a place of love that moves through its pages to the final resolution.  This is a story of hope and the pursuit of dignity in a world without much kindness, and its protagonists are flawed people who are forced to make difficult choices. It is a love story and a coming of age tale. I absolutely loved it, and applaud the author for her vision. I highly recommend this wonderful series.

Allegiant, the last installment of a diverse, thought provoking trilogy. Fast paced yet like any good ride, it takes the corners allowing you to catch your breath and encourages you to anticipate the next hill. If you haven't already, you'll fall in love with the complexity of the characters. Pick a faction. Who would you choose? Be brave ...

This has to be one of the most boring books I have ever read. The first two books in the series weren't lighting the world on fire as far as plot, or sense, but this book makes the first two look like well thought out tomes of glory.I had to skip 3/4 of the book. The middle was so much drudgery. I can't even express the overwhelming desire I had to put it down. I have never been one to read the last few chapters of a book just to get through it, but I had to do that with this story.Then I got to the ending and was glad I skipped most of the book. This book is truly a waste of time. Seriously. Even if you enjoyed the first two and were willing to suspend disbelief enough to admit that you found them entertaining, this book was not worth picking up. Just finish the plot line in your head using your imagination. I guarantee you will have a much better ending than what Roth presented here.I read the books because I saw the previews for the upcoming movie and it looked like something I would be interested in. Well, I hope Hollywood changes the ending drastically or the movies will be stinkers too. I don't think I want to watch them if they stay true to the books.I can't believe I just wasted hours of my life on this series. What a dud.

How can a science fiction story be so real?  Behind all the futuristic storyline is  real life.  Love, loss, betrayal, forgivenesses and redemption.  I didn't expect to like this series, and had been warned I wouldn't like this last book...but I do.  Great story!

Young adult novels are quickly becoming one of my favorite genres. This series has an interesting story line and is a quick read. I was concerned that the author let the plot get away from her by the third book after seeing lots of less than stellar comments on Amazon; however, while there were a few holes, she wrapped it up nicely and stayed true to her characters. The dual voice wasn't an issue for me. Nor were the plot holes. This series is meant to be a fast and entertaining read. It accomplishes both.
summary: I almost didn't read it based on the reviews here. Glad I ignored them.

reviewText: SPOILER ALERT-----Yes, it's heartbreaking. I did not expect or want this ending. But Patrick Rothfuss has said that the best books break your heart. I wasn't sure what to think when I read that (and it makes me nervous to read the third book of his trilogy!), but this book sheds some light on it for me. Veronica Roth made us care so much for her main characters that we mourned when one of them died and another had his heart (figuratively) ripped apart. She touched our hearts. She showed us that sometimes the most valuable things require the most heartbreaking sacrifices, and that these sacrifices are actually worth it.Veronica Roth explains the ending in her 10/28/13 blog post. It's very worth reading. She makes it clear that her loyalty is to the story, and to her themes, not to her readers' happiness, because there is no way for her to please ALL her readers. Does this mean she doesn't care about her readers? Of course not! Read the appreciation page in the book; read her blog. She is so thankful for her readers.She does not, however, owe us the ending we wanted! I prefer a writer who stays true to the story, rather than only trying to please readers. We end up with stories that show us the author's heart, instead of stories that are written to please readers' fantasies and pad the author's wallet.Did I want a happier ending? Oh, absolutely. But do I wish Roth had given it to me? No. I don't wish she had laid her vision down on the altar of my happiness. That would have been truly tragic.
summary: Veronica Roth was loyal to her story and her themes

reviewText: So, if you're at this point you've probably read through Insurgent. And I mean, what an ending, right? I knew something was up, but that was farther than what I expected. And it was exciting! I couldn't wait for Allegiant to come out, I was checking every day to make sure I had the release date right because I was dying to find out how the city handled their issue. And I probably should've left it there, because Allegiant did a 180 and thoroughly destroyed my anticipation. When you finally learn what the true issue is, it's a stretch. Why the author felt the need to try to take her novel to the next level (when it was heading in a perfectly exciting direction) is beyond me. But okay, I understand wanting to be original and trying to make a dystopian novel that's a little "different." I learned to accept the new plot twist and tried to become passionate about it... buy holy moly. I've never been so tired of the word 'damage' in my life. And I'm sure you will, too. Still, that's not enough to warrant a two-star review, because those things are relatively minor. I've read a lot of disappointing reviews giving the book 1 star because of the depressing nature of the ending. After having read the book, I don't really understand what they mean. It's inspiring and there's plenty of closure. Unless accidentally stepping on an ant makes you cry for a week, you'll learn to be fine with the outcome. I promise. The thing that pushed me beyond my limit was the amount of gushy lovey-dovey crud between two of the characters (surely, if you're looking at reviews of Allegiant you know who I mean, but just in case I won't spoil it for those of you who haven't caught up your reading). Is it really necessary to kiss every time you see each other? And not just that, the characters are teenagers. It felt incredibly uncomfortable and disgusting, frankly, to read some of the things going on between them. I know for some people, that's an element that is desired in a book, but it's not that way for me. It felt like Fifty Shades all over again, but it was so uninteresting and unnecessary. The endless bickering gets old quick, and the steamy makeup sessions get old even quicker. At some points in the book I forget that our protagonist is a teenager, but geez, sometimes her companion really throws a fit like one and it's hard to forget they're so young. I know the book is for young adults, but surely even they're annoyed by the senseless lashing out and emotional instability of some of the characters. It doesn't even make sense when they decide to lose their marbles.I could've handled the plot twist. I could've handled the lack of sentence development and even the nature of the ending. I just can't handle this trilogy, which has been so much about society, to suddenly fall apart in the last book. The characters unravel, and only Tris retains some semblance of normalcy by the end of it. Everyone else sort of falls apart and the story focuses predominantly on a love affair that's, to me, pretty insignificant relative to the other plots in the book. There's not really a good resolution to all the mental abuse I put myself through to finish the trilogy, and for that I'm giving Allegiant a two-star review. I hope that for some of you, these things don't bother you. And I hope that when you finish Allegiant, you don't feel as void of any satisfaction (good or bad, remember that I actually enjoyed the 'depressing' ending) and you find the resolution to be sufficient. It just didn't happen for me.
You could almost call this a cross between Hunger Games and Twilight, but that wouldn't do it justice. Although the ending was sad, and I had to stop reading several times, it is a satisfying ending.
This ends the saga.  Self-sacrifice is the choice again for our protagonist. The final social order is defined for this series. One is satisfied to call the series done with this book.
summary: This ends the saga for the trilogy.

reviewText: Read the three books in quick succession. I found the format change a little disconcerting and had to be mindful of who was speaking as Tris and Four swapped chapters. Still an intriguing story as it led to a conclusion.
summary: I guess I knew it had to end

reviewText: I'm not sure what about this book that I didn't like as well as the first two but this book was easy to put down and walk away from. The first two book were so riveting that I didn't want to stop reading. I don't like the way the book changed the first person back and forth between Tobias and Tris. It was confusing when I stopped in the middle of a chapter. I understand why it was written this way, but it was still distracting. The end unexpected and sad but fitting.
summary: Good but not as good as the first two books.

reviewText: OK-- I'm not in the young adult demographic that this series was written for, and I did enjoy the first the first two books of the series?  But-- this book just got tedious to finish.  Too much emphasis on everyone's feelings, back and forth endlessly.  After three books I expected a bigger climax, but it just wasn't there except for the one event that would be a plot spoiler to reveal.
summary: Kind of fizzled out for me

reviewText: Allegiant is the first book I've ever cried over. I am devastated that Tris died and also very sad for Tobias too. I so thought that they would make a new life after that final fight but no she dies but it was a good death. I have no idea what I'm going to do now since I finished this series! But I know that this series will live with me forever. So those who read this, be brave reading this book.

I agree with the other low rating reviews. Overall the book was kind of a "snoozer" with too much scientific blah, blah, blah and not enough action to keep my attention. The ending was horrible. Someone dies for someone else and it just feels awkward and unrealistic. I'd say more but I don't want to spoil it.If you have to read it, I strongly suggest borrowing it from a friend.
summary: Nowhere near as good as book one.

reviewText: I did enjoy this book.  For me I felt it was a little slower paced then the first 2 which is why I only gave it 4 stars.  But It was definitely good and I did enjoy the ending.

I can understand why a lot of you were upset at first at the end and so was I, but you have to look at the big picture. It was a great ending to series and didn't deserve all the criticism it got. Veronica, you broke our hearts many times but you gave us amazing books and characters to love. Thank you.
They are a well thought out, well written, well finished trilogy.I enjoyed every minute reading them and couldn't seem to put them down. I hope the movies will do them justice.

I can't say too much except that after devouring the first two books, this one took significantly longer to get through, and now that I've finished, I need a vacation from reading. The ending was horrible to me, and I really don't feel like an adequate solution was found for the problem the author presented us with. I wouldn't have purchased this series on my own, and only did so because 1. It was highly recommended, 2.the movie looks good and I have to read the book before I ever see the movie, and 3. Divergent was on sale for $4. So anyway, as a whole, the series was okay, but this last book on its, major let down...
I have gotten hooked so quick with this series. It's nice to have a great book to get into when you have a lot going on in "real life." Be warned: you will get absorbed quickly!!

Tobias point of view and Tris point of view had the same voice, I couldn't even tell them apart. Author got lazy with this last book and basically re-wrote insurgent and added a different ending that didn't mean anything.
This book surely will shake up some people and maybe it's best if you finish the last chapters in privacy so no one can bother you. I just simply couldn't stop readying!

I'm not gonna lie, the last 60 or so pages (basically everything from the thing that made the internet explode on) were what saved the book for me.POTENTIAL SPOILER[ While I didn't cry at the thing that made the internet explode, I found the portrayal of grief that followed really compelling. It rang true for me, and truly, one of the worst feelings was the Tobias chapter immediately after when you knew...and he didn't.]END SPOILERThat being said, any time I open a book (open being figurative, as I read this on my kindle), and there are alternating narrators, I'm inclined to bail. Dueling narration rarely works. In fact, I find it often kills a book for me. It works so much better (if it works at all) in a book with two authors because they're able to keep the individual character voices really distinct. It's so much harder for a single author to pull off the same thing, and pulling it off is a mark of real skill.Veronica Roth did not pull it off.Tris and Tobias sounded nearly the same to me throughout the book, as they have not in the previous two novels. Their perspectives were different, and I while I will own that it was interesting to hear some of Four's perspective on the same events, I would just as soon had Tris up until the thing that made the internet explode and someone else as a coda.It's worth noting, also, that the fact that this is the only book of the trilogy to utilize the two narrator format threw up red flags for me from the very beginning. An author doesn't pull a switch like that without a reason, and the only logical reason I could come up with was the thing that made the internet explode and thus, was not surprised when it happened.It is also worth noting that 75% of this book reads like an infodump. All the backstory you felt lacking in the first two? Hey, guess what! We found it.What kind of infodumps? The science-y type, of course. The whole eugenics-style reasoning for literally every solitary thing that has been a plot point in this series was such a cop out to me. If you've been stringing readers along for 1500 pages and want it all to boil down to "our genes made us do it," please send up a flag so I can opt out early--or do it with more grace and ingenuity than this.When I say that the last 60 pages of the book saved it for me, it's because I mean the book needed saving. I'm okay with having spent the time reading it, but I really don't see myself repeating the experiment.
summary: The long...slow...stop to the Divergent trilogy

reviewText: I have a number of issues with the plot logic, the solution to the problem didn't really seem like a solution to the whole problem it felt, like a more localized solution.  I became connected with the characters in Divergent, and Insurgent, they seemed to have lost something in Allegiant.  There is a lot of loss in this book, and I felt it wasn't much of a gain for all of the loss.  Not trying to spoil it for others so I wont go into detail.  It was not a horrible book it just wasn't as good or full-filling as the first two.
summary: Not my favorite in the series

reviewText: I was really enjoying this series until I read the ending. I really felt let down after being built up. Oh, well. Probably won't read any more of these works.

The series follows a successful path of books intended to appeal to young readers.  The series contains three books and now a few other side stories that intend to expand the story following the popular young characters. The storyline is less compelling than the Hunger Game series, but still filled with the premise that the adult government decision makers have once again brought the human race to near extinction.This is the third book of the basic series that begins with the heroine, Beatrice, choosing to become a member of the aggressive faction.  The series skips around such facts as how the basic needs of a population are met, while the younger generation goes on to battle prejudice and corruption.
summary: A dystopian world ruled by young adults

reviewText: I'm not done with this book yet but this third book in the set is just as well written as the other two!

What can I say about this book? I've waited years, YEARS, for this book to come out and for what? To be disappointed with the entire thing. It was boring for the most part just to make the book longer. I found myself starting to scan just because it dragged so much, especially towards the middle. I wish I had never read this and stuck with the first two books and just imagined what would have happened.

I absolutely LOVED the first two books of the series and I waited for this one to come out. Throughout the book if was bored and had to make myself keep reading. It was slow developing and (spoiler alert) I'd prefer a good love story ending to an ending designed to reflect morals and the life purpose of the characters. It was a disappointing finish to a great series.
The trilogy is complete. I'm sad that its over. I love this series. So bittersweet and heartbreaking. I'm very excited for the movie.
summary: A bittersweet ending to the trilogy.

reviewText: Allegiant is a disappointing ending to a series that has been awesome up until this book. I didn't really like anything about the final book. It took what could have been an interesting situation and did nothing with it.  I could have forgiven that if the ending had at least been good. I wanted to like it but can't. I won't say I hate it because the first two books were great.
When you finish a series like this one the feeling is now what? Roth developed wonderful characters in which you feel connected, joyous, angry and heartbroken.

This book was horrible. I own Divergent as a book on my Kindle Fire and I brought Insurgent from a store. I checked out Allegiant from the library because my friend raved about it at school (11th grade) and I hate it.  My real problem is the book doesn't even focuses on the problem at hand just Tris and Four's relationship. And the ending sucked...a lot. :(
summary: I couldn't even make myself read it

reviewText: I just finished the book and it is worse than book 2 (Insurgent). Sure, Veronica Roth gave a thorough explanation about what really happened in the past for the factions to rise.  But it felt very draggy. And a plot device that had me eye rolling was suddenly thrown into the way in an attempt to keep this book interesting and longer.  Where I expected to be mindblown with terrific revelations, I felt I was cheated because Allegiant didn't rise from those tropes of trilogies that lost their firepower during the conclusion phase. Le sigh. I was literally asking myself, "Where was the series that I love? Where was the book that made me lose sleep for over a year? Am I reading the correct book? Maybe I bought a fanfiction or something...?"I was just glad that with Allegiant, Veronica  gave a thorough explanation about the factions, Chicago and most importantly, Divergence. It is also worth mentioning that the romance here developed in a way that is realistic and swoon worthy but ain't cheesy. And yes,there's also a slight development with Tris and Four's characterization.  However, some of the characters (especially the secondary ones) were neglected and only existed as props.Perhaps, I will also have to credit Veronica's world building. It surely is very believable and downright outstanding considering that she incorporated other cities into the whole story.And I am not so sure whether the ending will work for you or not. As for me, I didn't love or hate it. All I'm sure is that it was necessary to keep things more conceivable given the circumstances of the situation. I would really like to say about it more but I will risk ruining your reading experience.All in all, I enjoyed this one but it didn't hold the same magic as Divergent (book 1). Being the last installment, I actually expected more. I had wanted it to be more explosive than its predecessor.  But alas, life isn't always that easy.  But don't let this review stop you from reading Allegiant. Maybe, I am just the black sheep amongst the throng of fans that waited desperately for its release.
reviewerName: Chardonnay @ Thoughts and Pens Book Blog "~Ch...
summary: Be warned! The way Roth ended this book will either be a hit or a miss for you...read it at your own risk!

reviewText: Between this and the Catching Fire series you wonder about the wisdom of most adults. Are we really blind to things as they really are?  Well written and a fast paced book.

After reading the second book, Insurgent, I was a bit disappointed with where this series was heading, and unfortunately Allegiant did not turn this around for me.  The further explorations of this dystopian world was very interesting, but I really didn't feel it was believable - especially the attitude that analyzing human nature by genes is a valid way to assess the potential of a human being.  It's not nature over nurture since both are important in contributing to a person's personality.  I am disappointed by how unscientific these scientists in the book are.  Especially since they are supposed to be so advanced and have made such breakthroughs.Tris and Tobias were also disappointing to me in this, because they again act in ways that are really frustrating.  I continued to lose sympathy for them in their predicaments, especially with Tobias in a certain plot development.  It didn't help that I felt like there were a few too many passages where Tris and Tobias described how the other looks or smells.  It's kind of annoying and there are lots of bigger issues here. With the writing, I also had an issue with how many similes were used - it felt unnecessary and ridiculous and almost like padding out a story that really could have gotten to the point sooner.No spoilers for the ending, but it is a very difficult one to come to terms with, and yet because I felt so disconnected to the characters, there wasn't really a huge impact for me.  It's a surprise, but I didn't feel emotional over it.  Unfortunately with all my disappointments over the characters and the plot, and the uneven pace of the story, I really couldn't connect to this last book in the Divergent trilogy.  But I am glad that I finished the trilogy and got a resolution.

I liked the way in the first two books how it was told from one persons point of view.  In this third book that changed and I didn't like it.  I kept on reading because I wanted to find out what was beyond the fence.
summary: Not as good as the first two books

reviewText: I really enjoyed the first two books in this trilogy. Roth was doing telling a fantastic YA story in a difficult sub-genre (Dystopian SF) but in the end, the final book doesn't live up to expectations.SPOILERS to follow:******For me, it is not about the ending. It is everything that leads up to ending which made it impossible for me to actually finish the book. I had to just skim ahead and read the ending because the middle of the book was so tedious. The duel POV, in first person PRESENT tense, wasn't done well and I think that is what killed the book for me. I will admit that I am pretty sensitive to POV shifts along with tense shifts. I find them jarring, particularly in first person. Every chapter I felt like I had to reset and start all over again. It made reading this book a challenge. The voices for both characters were weak, and even the Tris chapters do not at all read like the Tris of the first two books. It just did hold together for me, and it really pains me to say that.Perhaps in a few months I will re-read the book, being aware of its faults (I mean, all books have faults) and maybe I won't have the same reactions. I hated Game of Thrones the first time I read it. The second time, I loved it. So sometimes it's just a matter of mood or what I'm looking for at any given time. But for now, this was not it.I really hate to give the book a negative review. I think Roth is a talented writer. I am looking forward to any future projects she has. I will buy them and almost certainly will enjoy them. But the double POV and all of the world building "twists" just didn't work for me.But lots of people seem to love the book. So sometimes it is just a matter of what works and doesn't work for the individual.2 stars from me, but 4 stars for the first two books, and 3.5 stars for the series overall!
summary: Split POV and world-building didn't work for me

reviewText: Overall it is a good story, there are portions that get slow because of juvenile "drama" about relationships.  Sometimes it is frustrating enough to make me verbally tell the character to "grow up" and "move on". reviewText: I'm avoiding major spoilers in this review, and in doing that please forgive some vague notions and references, but understand I hate it when people spoil books for others, so I will try very hard not to do that to you :)I read Divergent four times and Insurgent twice, because I loved them. I was blown away by those two books. But at the end of Insurgent I was very nervous about where things were going to go next. It felt like the beginning of something new. And in a sense, it was. In reading Allegiant, it felt like something, or rather several things, were just off. Here are some of my issues with Allegiant:1. Reading Allegiant felt like I was reading the beginning of a completely different series. I don't mind that it was different, except that the differences lost the flow and integrity the first two books had for me. Even though I could see the connection Roth was trying to make, the storyline still felt disconnected from its predecessors.2. The pacing dragged for me, which was so unlike the way the first two books were. My nerves were also very high considering people trying to spoil everything for me, so I had to avoid a lot of internet stuff. If it weren't for that spurning, it would have been very easy to set this book aside, because it was slow. I was actually very tempted to set it aside and read something else, but my investment in this trilogy and those spoilery people out there helped me maintain my focus. The first time I read Divergent, I read it in a day, then immediately re-read it. Allegiant took me longer and I wasn't compelled to flip through the pages as quickly.3. Too much info-dumping. There were several info-dump sites, and it just really took away from the pacing and story. This is another reason why this book felt like the start to a series rather than the end of one. Part of me expected Roth to add a fourth book because there was so much added info.4. There were plot holes in the end, and I think if this book had been more thought through, it could have been extended to a fourth book, the storyline reworked to flow better and convey Roth's message and intention better. Also, I found it odd that this scientific society that develops these highly complicated serums, that they couldn't create serums or other advancements for other medical issues.5. The character development was off, or lacking. If anything, I think most of the characters regressed. The squabbles between the main characters were quite annoying and even redundant. While the other characters just seemed to fade into the wallpaper, offering bits and pieces here and there, but not nearly the forces they were previously. The other characters felt wasted and didn't offer very much, except for the intermittent heartbreak or a splash or jealousy for effect. And honestly, I just didn't love Tris and Tobias as much in this one the way I did before, though I probably liked Tobias slightly more because he wasn't as full of himself as Tris was. Her character development made her out to be so great and so wonderful and always right and it just didn't work for me. At least Tobias could be humble, and I did appreciate that.6. The dual POVs slowed everything down. This factored into my previously stated pacing issues. There also wasn't a clearly distinguishable voice between Tris and Tobias. Several times I had to go back to the heading of a chapter and find out who was narrating. More often than not I had mixed up the character in my head and thought the opposite person had been speaking.7. The action plateaued for most of the book. There were a few good, intense scenes, but they were resolved quickly. Even the climactic scenes in the end weren't really all that climactic. There was a lot of thinking and self-reflection and philosophizing.8. The message just didn't work for me and wasn't as poignant as I think Roth intended. And while I can appreciate the attempt, the message of this last book, even the message(s) didn't feel complete.9. I also can handle an ending that's not all rainbows and kittens, but the ending still has to make sense to me. This one, while I can see Roth's reasoning, still didn't feel necessary. Or make complete sense. I have multiple issues with it. But the ending was not the deal-breaker for me. I don't mind a twist to an ending, and welcome authors who want to go against convention. And this one could have worked if it had not been for things that had already happened in the book.10. Plus, this book on a whole, was just way too depressing. Kinda made me want to pull an Al and jump in the chasm. I don't know if it was for shock value or because Roth is just a negative "life sucks" kind of person or because this is her perspective on the future and that everything needs to be tragic, but on the whole Allegiant was just depressing. Not that we didn't have our tragedies in Divergent or Insurgent. These are not happy-go-lucky books. But Allegiant just took it a step further, a step too far.Do I have anything positive to say? Well, there were a few lovely moments between Tris and Tobias, some meaningful thought and intentions to the story. I think for some people, this book will work really well for them. I've seen high ratings on this book from others, and I'm glad that this book lived up to their expectations and they gleaned enjoyment from its reading.Personally, I just feel let down, and once again, it's not because of the way it ended, but the overall book itself. I know many people are disappointed with the ending, and if I'm being honest, I am too. But overall, even if it had ended differently, this book still would not have been at the same caliber level as the first two books. I tried very hard throughout the entire book to give Roth the benefit of the doubt and not put preconceived notions and expectations into this book. I know the first two books were a lot to live up to, but I don't think I've been let down by a book like this in a while. So am I glad I read it? Still not sure. Would I recommend it to others? Good question. I think that would depend on if you are a series-finisher and how dedicated you were to the first two books. Will I re-read it? No. I even told my husband to read the first two, and then let his imagination run for the third.
summary: Had multiple issues, not just the ending.

reviewText: I'm not sure why I finished this series, given that the first two books showed early signs of having no direction.  Maybe it's that I'm a fellow Illinoisian and wanted to believe that a hometown author could deliver a great finish to a series that takes place in Chicago.  Or possibly it's that I couldn't believe such a mess of a trilogy could have received a movie deal and surely was going to get better by the end of this book.  Unfortunately I was wrong, and if you've read the first two books, you're in for a big surprise when you find out how much worse it gets in the final installment.The most striking feature of the first two books is the apparent lack of a central conflict in both the books and the series as a whole.  After just about any novel, you can always sum up the central conflict in a few sentences, whether you're talking about a classic work of fiction or a mass-market mystery.  What exactly is the "big problem" that Tris and Four are fighting against in Divergent and Insurgent?  Think of any other series of books and the answer is immediately obvious.  Lord of the Rings=Sauron and the ring.  Hunger Games=President Snow.  Harry Potter=Voldemort. So, what's the problem or conflict in the Divergent series?  It eventually becomes clear late in Allegiant, but when you introduce the "big problem" of a trilogy only halfway into the last book, it's hard to establish enough buildup to make for a satisfying ending.  Instead, the story moves lethargically from one micro-conflict to another, with each minor problem being solved almost immediately, much in the same way that a second-grade author might solve a conflict in a submission for a Young Authors contest.  Between these micro-conflicts, you'll be subjected to ruthless stalling and expectations to care for secondary characters that have no bearing to the central story.The end is a pathetic distraction, designed to make you forget about the lack of substance in this book, as well as the other two.  Instead of devising a central conflict that escalated up until the final pages, Ms. Roth plops around from one minor problem to the next, with the "final battle" feeling no more significant than any of the other endeavors that the cast of characters battle.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS MASSIVE SPOILERS FROM THE START. TURN BACK NOW YE WHO WISH TO REMAIN UNSPOILED.I wasn't sure I was going to write a review of Allegiant, especially because a lot of other people have already touched on my primary problems (POV shifts being weak, writing so spare and minimalistic as to be completely incomprehensible at times) but I did want to talk a little more about Tris's death.Tris is a Christ figure. Throughout each book, even the bulk of Allegiant, we're shown over and over that she is her world's messiah. She is immune to the serums, she's shockingly "genetically pure" (which has it's own slew of problems that I don't think a white, upper-middle class woman should ever have written about, least of all someone as young as Roth), she's powerfully Divergent, etc etc etc. These things aren't necessarily a problem. The messianic figure has been a trope for hundreds of years, even pre-Christ. The Christ story is the one Western culture associates most strongly with the messianic figure, however, and because of that we expect a messiah story to go a certain way. Namely, we expect the messiah to come back from the dead.There are plenty of stories that deconstruct tropes - and the deconstruction of tropes is incredibly popular in media right now. Allegiant isn't a deconstruction. None of the Divergent books were a deconstruction of the messiah. None of them implied, in any way, that the human race doesn't need someone to lead it to salvation - which is exactly what Tris is doing throughout two and a half books. When she dies in Allegiant, the messiah trope isn't deconstructed. It's destroyed. And because tropes are a way to understand and parse media and stories, the reader is left utterly baffled and confused. This, in my opinion, is the primary failure of Allegiant. The destruction of a trope that Roth spent no time deconstructing is the problem, and it's the reason people are railing so hard against this story.

reviewText: This review is SPOILER FREE. I promise!Let's just jump right in, shall we? You have all heard about the ending and everyone's reactions to it at this point, right? Okay, I hated the ending. It was terribly sad and in all honesty, I don't quite understand why it was done. Maybe because it was unique compared to other dystopias? I'm not sure but I didn't like it! I cried for hours and am now in a terrible book hangover.I didn't give this book 2.5-3 stars because of the ending, though. I just want to clear that up right now. Yes, I don't agree with it but it still had me bawling and I appreciate Roth's ability to affect me that way. The real reason I gave it 2.5-3 stars is just the overall concept and execution of the book. For one, and I'm sad to admit this, but aside from the ending, ALLEGIANT was kind of boring. What should have been an extremely climactic book with our lot of characters venturing over the fence, wasn't. They just sort of went. I didn't feel the intensity and suspense like I felt in the other two books.Another thing I didn't particularly like was the explanation for why Chicago was the way it was. That, too, wasn't a huge, world crushing revelation like I thought it was going to be. It was also really confusing to follow along. I was sitting there trying to figure out what all it meant and why it even really mattered in the first place.My biggest thing with this book is the switching point of views. I know everyone loved Tobias and wanted to hear his side of things, I get that. However, his and Tris' voice and personality were just too alike in this book. If I didn't pay close attention when I started a new chapter, I automatically thought I was reading Tris' POV like the other two books. Only upon seeing Tris mentioned did I realize, whoops, this is Tobias' chapter. They just didn't have big enough differences in thought processes to make the switching POV work in my opinion. If there was more of a contrast then I think I would have enjoyed the refreshing change of scenery so to speak.I love the Divergent series and unfortunately, ALLEGIANT fell flat for me executionally. I do think fans of the first two books need to read this. You should find out how it ends. It'll probably devastate you, even if it doesn't make a whole lot of sense!
summary: A bit disappointing compared to the other two books. Sad ending.

reviewText: Do you sometimes get that feeling when you read a book? That feeling that the author doesn’t want to be writing the book that you’re reading? That feeling that the book could have ended chapters ago, yet the author keeps filling it with fluff? That feeling that the author betrayed the story for money and that their love for their story pretty much died?Well, I kind of got that feeling while I was reading this.I know that it seems that I’m being kind of brash and rude with my opening, but hear me out… I’m a fan of Veronica Roth and will support her next publication so I am not writing this review out of spite or because I’m trying to be a hater.With that said, I’m trying to write without spoilers so, hopefully, my review makes sense…First off, ALLEGIANT differs from the first two books because she utilizes dual narrative. Normally, I’m not opposed to it at all because, when executed properly, dual narrative can bring fresh insights into the story and the characters. So, when I first read that Veronica Roth was going to write in a dual narrative, I was ecstatic because I thought that she had the necessary talent into providing an unique voice to Four (I never read the novellas/short stories, so this is/was the first time I would be reading from his perspective). You can only imagine my surprise and disappointment when Four’s voice was Tris’ voice.It wasn’t “similiar” to hers… it was her. Basically, Four’s chapters was Tris speaking while looking through Tobias’ eyes. And, that disappointed me because it was kind of like she knew that fans were going to buy the books irregardless of how she wrote the voices, so she kind of half-assed it…Moving on!The plot! I didn’t hate the plot as much as some of the other people who read the book. I mean, it certainly wasn’t a twist I was expecting but, just because I wasn’t expecting it, doesn’t mean that it wasn’t *that* bad. So, I’m not really going to rant about the history behind how the factions came to be because there are other people who rant about it enough for everyone~BUT, I do care about HOW THEY GOT OUTSIDE THE FENCE!!!! THAT WAS SUCH A MAJOR DISAPPOINTMENT! IT WAS THE MOTHER OF ALL DISAPPOINTMENT FOR ME!(This is kind of a mini-spoiler… NOT THAT IT MATTERS SINCE THIS TAKES UP LIKE THREE PARAGRAPHS IN THE ACTUAL BOOK!.. Not literally, but you get my gist…)Throughout the entire series, it was always “nobody wants to go outside the fence” and “the world outside is bad” and etc. so when they finally decided to go outside, I thought that that journey alone was going to take up a good portion of the story. After all, I was sure that there were many security protocols to prevent people from leaving and, once outside, I was sure that they were going to face many perils and etc before they finally reach the answer.Nope.That was a blink-and-you’ll-miss-it scene. Like, no joke, it was like let’s hop on a train and “wow, we’re outside” and *poof* some people comes out and says “come into our building where we’ll feed you and take care of you and explain what we’ve been doing outside”……Yeah…Okay, it wasn’t literally like that and someone did die, but still!! Where was the danger? The excitement? The feels that should have been over the death!? (Notice how I’m trying not to leave too big of a spoiler~)Ugh… okay, that is pretty much all I can write for this review. I can write more, but I would rather not want to. Basically, it all sums down to this:Read the first two books of the series and let’s pretend that this third book never happened…Originally posted at [...]

I have been waiting for MONTHS for this book to come out. Then it came..... IT IS AWFUL! All she does is reuse the same plot setup about 3 times in the same book! Then, she kills TRIS! Dead. Gone. I cannot possibly list all of the faults in this book but my advice to you is that if you loved the first 2 books, stop there! Just leave it alone and accept it. I don't know how the book even got published. Very upset.

These are good books.  Divergent got me into the groove and I thought Insurgent was the better of the two, so I was a little disappointed with Allegiant.  All in all, these were all a good read but not as good as the Hunger Games trilogy.
I loved Divergent. This was a satisfying sequel but the first person narrative becomes tedious. Great story and it like the first of the trilogy leaves the reader thirsting for more.

The end definitely picked up and I was invested by the time I got 3/4 of the way through it.If you read the first two, you'll have to read this one but don't expect the same type of page-turner!
Spoiler alertOmg you killed her off!!! Poor four hasn't he been through enough? And bloody peter lived!!!! Why why
Good read. Loved every bit even though there are some very sad parts. Can't wait to read the next one in this series!
I think this is a great book. Surpris ending never saw that coming!!! I love the back and forge point of views.
I literally have not enough words to explain how deeply broken and sad this book leaves me. But at the same time, I think there wasn't any chance for it to be different or better, thanks Veronica.

The author completely checked out on the third and final book!  So much so that you get angry at yourself for investing time in the first two books. It is confusing to read and completely flat and unsatisfying at the end. This is tween literature not a great work, come on Veronica give us a decent ending we could enjoy and take away feeling a little good about!

I'm disappointed in so may ways, there are too many to mention.  I skipped pages because I wanted to get to the end, just so I could say I finished.  Don't bother reading this book.  Buy a lottery ticket instead you could get lucky I wasn't when I got this book
It took a bit to get back into the story but the it all came racing back. Great ending for a terrific series. Can't wait to see the movie!!

I just loved it. I really don't know how else to say it but it was wonderful. I think my favorite of the 3 books because it goes between Tris and Four's perspectives. I get a little bored with complete first person or even third person stories. thank you Veronica Roth for such a wonderful and rather profound series.
really enjoyed this last installment , was surprised by their ultimate fates but it was a good switch to same old ending , looking forward to seeing the movie and enjoying more books by this author

I'm a huge Divergent fan, even giving the book as gifts.  And I was satisfied with Insurgent as well.  Pre-ordered Allegiant and had the release date on my calendar to be sure I'd have time to read it asap.  OMG, what a disappointment.  Allegiant is actually boring!  For most of the book, nothing really happens.  There is not much of a plot line to advance and the characters seem stuck & uninteresting.  Whereas Divergent was full of life, Allegiant felt dead.  I didn't stay up all night to finish it and generally did not care about what little was going on.  It became something I could read a little and then fall asleep.  It's such a shame that this talented author put out this piece of junk.  I'd much rather have waited several more years for a 3rd installment so that she could have taken the time to more fully develop the story and get better editing.
summary: Can't believe this is by the same Veronica Roth who gave us Divergent

reviewText: This series is by no means a literary masterpiece but it was interesting enough. I feel the characters and story lack real depth, but there was still enough there to keep me turning the page. I think it will be easy to adapt this into a movie without losing anything.
Good exploration of self worth, identity, science and government... Also of teenage passion and influence. Would have preferred it without the sex parts to make it appropriate for younger readers.

What a letdown! The first book was good, the second book was so-so, but this was just plain bad.Although this was targeted to the YA market, please give this age group a little credit. The "good genes" / "bad genes" premise is way too simplistic. Whether GP or GD, no one has the same genes. Tris was GP, but she had abilities that the rest of the GP did not, and yet the genetic researchers running the Chicago program never investigated this?Switching viewpoints between characters is not necessarily one of my favorite ways to read a story, but it works in some books. It did not work in this book. Without the chapter headings indicating whose viewpoint you were reading, you could not differentiate between the characters.The ending, as many have said, was just plain bad. It did not make sense. It was anti-climatic and it didn't provide explanations consistent with many of the characters' actions. It also alienated many readers - how would the Harry Potter movies have fared if JK Rowling had killed Harry Potter in the last book?
summary: Disappointing -bad writing, bad plot, bad science

reviewText: Since the climactic ending of the book was revealed to me, I almost didn’t even bother to read it.  If part of the book is revealed in someone’s review (especially if there is a spoiler alert), it is my own fault for reading it but when it is revealed in a quote usually there to advertise the book, it is giving way too much away.  However, since I knew the end I was able to anticipate it and therefore see it from a different perspective.  Although it wasn’t my ideal ending sometimes the ending should'nt be perfect.But aside from the ending, the story line just wasn't the same quality as the first two books of the series.  There were too many holes in the story or details left unexplained.I did like the narrative coming from both Tris and Tobias.  And I loved the continued development of their relationship.I just expected so much more.
I enjoyed the twist and exploration of the developing storyline! I also enjoyed how it changed from character view each chapter!

I did not want to believe the reviewers. I picked up Divergent by chance one day at Wal-Mart of all places and have been in love with it since. I enjoyed Insurgent too. And if you are reading these reviews and saying to yourself 'surely the dual povs can't be as bad as what everyone is saying - I mean how hard is it to tell two characters apart?' Think again: it is that bad. And if it were the only bad thing, I could get over it. Unfortunately....Why even name this book Allegiant? There was hardly anything about the Allegiant in it! It would have been a great book if it had been about the power struggle between Allegiant/Factionless and Evelyn/Johanna/Marcus. That would have worked! Those three characters have been built up. They are solid. We know who they are. Everyone who is saying David is weak in comparison are right. In fact, this should have been what this third book was about. And the damaged genes storyline should not have even been introduced until the late parts of this story. It would have worked as two books. This feels rushed, which probably meant it IS rushed.Also and lastly - this is the big one. The spoiler you may want to turn back now on before you see it. Tris's death was pointless. It's not just that it was disappointing or sad. It was pointless! There was no reason to do that when they already had a willing sacrifice. It made so much more sense to let Caleb go through with it because a)he actually had some serious things to atone for, thus giving it meaning b)seeing how Triss dealt with that would have been much more interesting.I have no idea how this got the editor's approval. Any editor's approval. And the plots holes.It just....I hate saying this. I don't think I've felt this let down since I read the 'Matched' trilogy and that was downright awful. It's too bad I just didn't get his from a library. Then at least I could have sent it back.
The characters develop even further than in Insurgent. It kept my attention but has taken me longer to finish. Very readable.

I felt it was a Hugh rip off. All the hate, fighting, death you just keep reading because you are sure it will all come together and make sense.  Instead we get this stupid confusing end with one of the main players killed. All the time, money and emotional effort wasted. I was ok with the "outside the fence explanation, but it just got so stupid, like she was just trying to get to the part where the girl dies and it ends, just finish it. No more money or time on this author and the movie is out unless I hear it ends different.  I felt betrayed!  I was loyal to the author with money, time and all the interest and she bailed. Wished I had never started the books.
summary: To bad, though I had found a good author to read and trust with my money, time and interest

reviewText: I was  very skeptical about  reading this book. Every review has said it was so depressing. To be honest, the real life ending to this great series was refreshing. Sure, I teared up, by  I have experienced loss, and could completely relate to the living on aspect in the end. Not a fairy-tale ending, but a great ending none the less.
summary: Although sad, a good end to a great series.

reviewText: Ohhhhh my.One of the things I liked about the previous two books in the series is that the action flowed along at a brisk pace to keep the reader wondering what would happen next. This particular installment is awfully wordy. I found myself thinking "Just get to the point already" more times than I could count.The alternating point of view between Tris and Tobias was a good idea in principle, but not so much in execution. Both of their voices sounded exactly the same. When I was a kid and reading the Babysitter's Club series, once of the things I appreciated even then was that each character had her own voice. There was virtually no difference between Tobias' and Tris' chapters.This, then, leads me to confess that I still do not feel any attachment to any of the characters. I felt like there was not much growth going on except in the area of Tris' and Tobias' relationship. If you're into teen romance and awkward angsty teen relationships, maybe that will appeal to you. It didn't do much for me. Caleb, truly, showed the most growth out of any of them, but is never given the opportunity to truly redeem himself.I feel like there is far more worth discussing about this novel, but I am unable to do so without revealing some pretty massive spoilers.Is it worth the read? Sure, if you just want to know how it all plays out, and don't mind awkward teen romances and a disappointing ending.
I'm upset, the whole reason I wanted the violence to end was so they could all be happy and live normal lives....Well ugh.
Not what I expected, but sometimes we have to understand authors have a mind on their own. They filled  their own expectations not ours.

I really wanted to read this book so badly… and I got badly disappointed by it. The plot pretty much follows Tris and friends to their new life outside the fence but the pace of the story turns really slow unlike the previous two books.Some mysteries are revealed and you learn why their world is the way it is. However, there was so much to explode that the author missed by just killing Tris in a stupid way to save her stupid brother. I actually thought that there would be more books but apparently it was just 3 and that’s it. So much didn’t make sense to me because the final was as good as written in a rush just to get done with it.Overall, 2 stars is a lot… not worth it. Bad ending for a trilogy that could’ve been so much more.
summary: Spoiler alert: Bad ending for a trilogy that could’ve been so much more.

reviewText: I cannot believe that I waited over a year for this book. It was boring, it was nothing like the first two. And I am left feeling angry, let down, and as though I just wasted my time and energy. I wish I hadn't read any of the books. WORST BOOK EVER. Ms. Roth, what were you thinking?

I loved reading the first two books!  I had high hopes for the last one, but Allegiant has the WORST ending of any book I've ever read.  There are times where there is a point in killing some characters, but Roth was way too trigger happy.  It was sad and terrible when Dumbledore died in Harry Potter but it made the books better.  There is a death in this book that totally ruined this series for me.

I blew through the first two books in this series in two days back in June.  On the third day, I pre-ordered the third book, anxiously waiting for my questions to be answered, like everyone else who had been with Tris and Four throughout the whole ordeal.I got the book (in hard copy, not on Kindle only because the other two I had were in hard copy too and I have a thing about owning a series all in one format or another).  I sat down and read it in one day (big surprise).****SPOILER ALERT*****First, it was as I had predicted to my husband.  There was a government lab/experiment similar to the Village (a horrible movie by M. Night Shamalamadingdong - don't waste your life watching it).  There was more to the factions than we originally knew.  There were horrible injustices being done to innocent people in the name of pure genetic makeups.I suppose that I should not be surprised that it came down to genetic engineering, something that people are always wondering about.  To that end, seeing how it still gives people a sense of superiority over each other, another way to divide society, it was disappointing to know that, at least in this future, we will not reach a place where we finally acknowledge each other as equals (you know, like they do in Star Trek).Now, the ending couldn't have happened any other way.  If there had been a HAE then it would have been too mushy and too predictable.  Did I want there to be a HAE for both of them?  Yes.  They both had a very sad existence, hard lives, hard initiations, had people close to them die.  Didn't they deserve to be a little happy?  Didn't they deserve just a few days to really enjoy being with each other?  They never got that opportunity.  But in the end, it was the only way.  She was the only way.  The upsetting thing though, through it all, is that I got the sense that the government did not stop doing what they were doing.  They may have disbanded the Chicago experiment, but I don't think that stopped everything altogether.  In a way, it felt like she died in vain and that really upset me I think.  Knowing that she could have been happy.  She could have helped people more.Does her death make me hate the book?  No.  Does it make me question if I would have read the whole series and allowed my nerdy self to get attached to the characters as much as i did.  Yes.  I hate crying over a book!  And I cried, cried like a baby.

Veronica Roth saves her best for last. Allegiant was everything I was hoping it would be after a long wait in between the second and third book in the Divergent trilogy. Roth wraps up the trilogy nicely. This is a book that makes you think and reflect on the world we live in and reflect on yourself. If you haven't started reading the Divergent trilogy, start today!
summary: Last book in trilogy is the best!

reviewText: Contains spoilers**The beginning of this book bored me nearly to tears. I had to continue because it's a trilogy, and you have to see it through at this point. If it were the first book, I wouldn't have completed it to the end.After I read about 80%, I felt Tris was acting without thinking things through. She chose a side by her emotions, wanting to fight those that were responsible for her parents death, and not by considering whether it was the right side. A person shouldn't fight, or start a revolution out of revenge.I'm not bummed Tris died. It's a story, and I accept death, even imaginary characters. What I'm bummed about is that there was a 'meeting' between Evelyn and Marcus and there's suddenly peace in Chicago. Two armies at odds won't easily put down their weapons, especially those trained as dauntless.The ending after Tris died felt rushed. Hurry up and show the world is better because of Tris' death. I guess it was written that way because this was Tris' story, and thus dead, the story should end, but Veronica had to continue to give her death meaning.I was a Four fan, but I am not any more. Uriah died because of his actions. Period. There was no way to blame Nita. She couldn't have done what she did without his actions.
Just like the first book, this one kept me so entertained. I couldn't put the book down. I am pretty sure I finished it in one day! I absolutely loved it!

I read this with as much zeal as each of the other two books. I'm happy with how this series ended and I don't think there would've been any truer way to conclude the book, given the thread of learning about sacrifice that permeates all three books and the conclusion that Tris reaches about what it means to give the ultimate gift to the people you love. She did what she had to do for those she cared about most and everyone is able to go on because of it. I think this has been a fantastic conclusion to an amazing series. Thank you, Ms. Roth!
We follow Tris and Four through the last part of the series, learning more about their parents' past and the history of their society.

Dear Ms. Roth,I no longer trust you. I get it, life doesn't always turn out ok, but are serious right now? I have spent months reading and rereading your works. Hell my husband who hasnt read a book in at least 12 years read your books, and liked it! I wouldn't say the book was badly written, but it was repetitive in the fact that besides Tris and Tobias, everyone else was a bad guy. Then you gained our trust and stabbed us all in the back when we weren't looking. For shame. I know this was the reaction you were looking for, but it overshadows the message of we are not what our genetics or "factions" expect us to be, but what we choose to do or be. You lost that message with some bullets and  a ghost. Sad to say I am dissapointed.

To quote one of my friends, asdfghjkl. The end takes awhile, and the climax is a little unclear. Still a great book!

Allegiant: An Awful ConclusionAllegiant. The concluding member of the Divergent trilogy. The trilogy is the supposed competition to the Hunger Games series. If only this was remotely true. The first two books of the Divergent series are half decent, butut, the finale, Allegiant, is awful. It is so poorly written and so unimaginably far-fetched that it ruined the entire series.First of all, the entire book felt forced. Insurgent ended with a great cliff hanger, and I couldn't wait to see what happened. Then, after reading the first few chapters of monotone information, I came to the conclusion that this book was forced. It seemed that there was an exponential amount of poor writing. The forced element of this book is clearly evident when Veronica Roth "throws" in this quote: “You're not very nice," I say, grinning. "You're one to talk." "Hey, I could be nice if I tried." "Hmm." He taps his chin. "Say something nice, then." "You're very good-looking." He smiles, his teeth a flash in this dark. "I like this 'nice' thing.” (Roth 121). Also, the entire series leads up to knowing what's on the other side of Chicago's fence, only to get turned down by the ridiculous genetic engineering experiment which absolutely RUINED this entire trilogy for me.Overall, I see this as one of my very least favorite books. The poor writing, coupled with the forceful element of the book, annihilated any previous feelings for this trilogy. It's such a shame to see a decent trilogy ruined by the finale.

** spoiler alert ** While I loved the first two books, in this series, Allegiant was much harder to get through.This is pretty much how I feel about it, particularly the ending: [...]The reasoning for the factions, dystopian future, etc. seemed somewhat plausible, but the way it was handled by authority figures was ridiculous. Then again, in my experience it seems that the more authority a person has, the less likely they are to make reasonable, logical, unselfish choices. The science behind the genetic issues was also...less than scientific. You can't "fix" genetic damage in the way she was describing. The faction system would ameliorate the psychological expression of those mutated genes, but it wouldn't fix anything. The whole concept seemed poorly researched.The societal problems with "genetically damaged" people being treated as less than full humans/citizens was entirely plausible, however - it seems like society always wants a scapegoat population to blame all their problems on or otherwise bear the brunt of prejudice.I hated the shifting perspectives - it didn't add to the storyline or character development, but merely served as a distraction. The voice used for Tris vs. Tobias and way they told the story didn't change, so I often forgot whose perspective I was reading and got confused.The ending was anticlimactic in a way, and I was frustrated at how everyone seemed okay with such a hypocritical resolution. They couldn't just send former city residents back in? Maybe give city residents a choice in "starting over" with fresh memories?But I could even accept those choices as perhaps the most likely choices of teenagers trying to "save the world." But then...FAIL. Tris survives the death serum, which is pretty kick-ass, only to be killed by a gunshot wound while releasing the memory serum. Just...WTF!!! Her death serves no purpose, other than to burden Four with teenage wangsty grief and overshadow the resolution of the conflict - because throughout this book he morphs from a mature, strong individual to a pansy-ass teenager who doesn't think through his actions.
summary: The first 2 in the series were great, but Allegiant was a letdown

reviewText: I don't even know where to start. The ending to this series is so ridiculously unrealistic. So many things do not make sense, there are major holes in the plot and even the characters were unlikeable. I understand that this is a YA book, but I honestly can't get behind how these teenagers can outsmart the adults unless they are in cohorts with Scooby Do.I was bugged by the unnecessary "kissing" scenes that I do not want my daughter reading. Why can't these YA authors put in light kissing without putting hands in people's clothing and insinuate heavy petting! Major bug when it comes to these YA books that I have to tell my daughter she can't read. Still debating if ill let her read this one. (Btw-she is all but 12)I loved the first 2 books in this series and can't say how disappointed I am by this one. Bah!!

What the heck happened with this third book???? As it stands right now, I am 64% of the way through this book and I cannot finish it. I have to say, I'm really disappointed. I had so much hope for this book, waited months and months for it to come out, and it just did not deliver. And I usually want to give books good ratings, but this time I just can't. The series itself had so much promise, but it doesn't live up to that promise. I can't put my finger on exactly why. The writing itself does not hold the reader's attention.At one point, I came on and read other people's reviews because I just couldn't get through the book, wondering if others were having the same issue. From what I can see, this isn't just my issue. Many are experiencing the same.Some people don't like how it ends and they have beef with what the writer did regarding that - but I can't even get there. I can't even get into the book enough to even care what Roth did with the ending. The writing is what's disappointing to me....not necessarily the choices the author made in the story itself or characters. The actual writing just fell apart.Big bummer. I was really looking forward to this....I really wanted to love this book. I wanted to come on here and leave 5 stars.What the heck happened with this book? I'm still scratching my head, wondering.

I found myself reading in bed by flash light so that my husband could sleep for hours.  I even woke up and read it in the middle of the night to read!
