I would highly recommend this book series to any one who liked the Twilight Series.  They are fun and engaging and next to impossible to put down.

After two action-packed and thought-provoking novels in the series (Divergent and Insurgent), the finale was a disappointment.The main characters lacked purpose and drive...just finding out what happened instead of making things happen.  By moving the story outside of the city, the story lacked continuity and moved away from the rest of the series.I was sorry to see such a fun story end with a whimper instead of a bang.

This is the third, and final, novel in the Divergent Trilogy. All in all, I really enjoyed the trilogy and am looking forward to the movie early next year.This was probably my least favorite book of the three. The main reason for this is due to the change in POV. The first two books are all told by Tris. In Allegiant, Roth chose to alternate between Tris and Four/Tobias. It could have worked, however, it was poorly executed. From the beginning, I had to pay close attention to the name at the start of each chapter (which is where the point of view shifts). Again and again, I found myself confused. The narrative voice was always the same and it was virtually impossible to tell if it was a Tris chapter or a Four chapter. I would find myself searching for little clues or jumping back the chapter start to check. As you might imagine, this was very annoying.Along with the new part-time narration by Four, we get a peak inside his head. Well, intentional or not, Four comes off whiny, weak, and a bit of a mess. How we see him through his own voice is quite a bit different from how we’ve seen him in the past through Tris.There are also some revelations in this one that made me less than happy. The plot moves some of our main characters out of the city and into the outside world. This was all fins, but then it gets into some science-y stuff that just didn’t make sense, and goes off on a tangent. There is little in Allegiant about the factions or the city, and that was disappointed.Now, having said all that, I did like it!  I will definitely be keeping my eye out for more novels by Veronica Roth.
summary: I didn't love it... or hate it.

reviewText: I was afraid to read this final book in the series after reading some of the other not so favorable reviews about it, but I'm glad I did. After thoroughly enjoying the first two books in the series I had to know how it ended and that's exactly what the book provided, an end to a story about loss and love. I now understand the disappointment that other reviewers expressed because the story isn't wrapped up with a nice pretty bow on top and at first I felt the same way. However, now I accept the ending for what it is. I did find this last book a little rushed and not as engrossing as the first two, but nonetheless the writing still drew me in and tugged at my emotions.
summary: Worth reading to finish the series

reviewText: What a disappointment.  After reading and thoroughly enjoying the previous two books, this book was a huge let down.  The writing was substandard and the plot just didn't get it.  It was like this book was written by someone else.  I'm very disappointed. I did not like the way the book went back and forth between and characters and the clarity of character was not evident in the writing.  Very poorly done.
This last book took me by complete surprise...which is a good thing. It made you really think about what's going on in the world now. I loved this series!!
Really enjoyed the first book.  Tolerated the second.  This book was terrible.  The author seemed to want to get it over and done with. Plot line was stupid.

I watch much Joss Whedon and even when the idea of Buffy ending with Season 5 it still made sense.  He built up to that sacrifice over several seasons even.  He also killed of many well loved characters on many of his different projects.  I still watch his stuff knowing that can happen.  (poor Fred)  I was horrified and sad when Dumbledore died, but I still wanted to finish the Harry Potter series even knowing that she could even kill off Harry Potter.  Everything was so well done and so well written and just made sense to me.{Contains Spoilers}That being said.  This book felt a little rushed.  As I was reading it, I was thinking that all the new information was setting up more books.  I have to agree the science behind the genetics was not explained.  Tris as "special" was not explained.  Then I got to the "end" of the Tris part and thought.  I don't understand why?  It was not a character development.  Why spend the time building up a "relationship" between two characters if this was the end all along?  The only reason to build a relationship up seems to be just to sell the book the teenage romantic set.  To build that kind of following then take the book into such a dark place as to just kill off Tris with no further explanation. Nothing felt complete to me.  It actually felt as if the author was just making sure that there was no pressure to write anymore books.  As many have expressed, I have no desire to go see Divergent now and no want to read this author anytime soon.  I am glad for VR to be able to tell her story as she wanted, but I don't think I am going to drink the good review Kool-Aide that is telling me that this book does represent hope.  It does not IMO.  Even Christ rose from the grave.  VR opened Pandora's box and forgot to make sure that Hope was placed in the bottom.Maybe it is my lack of literary knowledge prohibits me from being able to understand the B+ and 4 star rating from critics.  I don't feel the characters were well developed.  I don't feel like I understand what is truly the greater sin. I understand what the message was but that was because it was spelled out better then the whole GP and GN issue.  Not matter what out genetic make up is we are essentially human and all capable of evil and good.At this point I don't even think I am ready to hear VR's explanation that she seems will come.  I will read it eventually, but it doesn't make up for poor and quick storytelling.I do wonder how the Studio that bought the rights to the story are feeling right now.  I don't think they knew what was going to happen or they would have ask to not release the book until after the movie or moved the movie up to a summer release.

reviewText: I loved the series, but I did not see the end coming as it did. I am utterly speechless and yet, I have so much to say. This book and this series blew my mind. I am kicking myself for waiting so long to read it. It is powerful. It grabs you and doesn't let go, even after its over.I had seen that Allegiant didn't receive the high ratings the other two books did, but did not want to read a single review or know why. I am glad that I stayed away from the negativity and spoilers so that I could see Allegiant for what it was. I had a feeling that the ending was going to be sad and so I formulated a few theories in order to prepare myself. And yes, I cried and cried. I sat on my bed reading in the dark with tears streaming down my face and my heart breaking. And that emotion evoked from a story is one of the reasons that this book got a 5 star rating from me. I wish I could rate it higher.I love the characters in this series because they are so much more than that. They are all so front and center, no matter how small their role is. You grow so attached to them that even the smallest amount of pain they feel causes you pain as well.I have to say that Tris is easily one of my favorite female leads. She is real and one of those characters that you find yourself wanting to be more like. Yes, I realize that she is a sixteen year old girl, but she is so much more than that, too. She is brave and selfless. She is strong and doesn't fall victim to the normal girly crap. There were times that I kind of wanted her to be more "normal", but I am so glad that she wasn't. She is kick-ass and I love that. Her character is refreshing.Tobias is beautiful. He is strong, yet so broken, and his struggle to become more makes him great. Yes, he is stubborn and makes some stupid choices, but those choices are what make him better. And his love for Tris and his friends is powerful. There is nothing he wouldn't do to protect them. His journey throughout this series is amazing.I won't talk about the story details because I don't like spoilers. What I will say is that I think it took a lot of guts for Veronica Roth to end this series this way, and I think it was a fitting ending. Was it the ideal ending that everyone wanted? Obviously not. But it was great. This book is suspenseful and emotional. Once you start reading, you won't stop until its over. And then you will want it to keep going.Veronica Roth created a world and characters that are hard to walk away from. The thing that makes me most sad is that it is over and I have no more to read. This series is easily one of my favorites and one that I will re-read over and over. I hope that Veronica keeps writing wonderful stories like this one so that I can keep reading them. I hope that you choose to read this series, and I hope that you choose to see the story as a whole and don't judge it because it isn't they way you would have written it.

When I was about half way through this one I found out why everyone was mad about the book.  And I really do understand why.  But I must say that finishing this series really makes you think about how you move on after tragedy.  How do you pick up the pieces after so much loss and start fresh. I guess the truth is you don't.  You just learn to live with the hole and as the days go by that hole shrinks until its so small you just don't think about it anymore.  But it never really goes away.  I really did enjoy this book and I give the author credit that even main characters were expendable.  The book was really like REAL!  Everyone could die or survive and no one was safe from that fate.  To many books with any kind of romance always end in the Happily Ever After all tied up in a neat little bow.  And it is sad but refreshing that this one wasn't like that.  It ends on a good note where people are moving on and rebuilding their lives.  But also still dealing with the loss of loved ones and the situations that brought them to this outcome.This has got to be one of the best series I have read!!

reviewText: I'll be honest, this is an incredibly difficult review for me to write. This book has left me heartbroken and disappointed for so many reasons.Yes, the choices the characters make are consistent with who they are (mostly) and I "get" how the story comes full circle with Roth's faith woven into the fabric of it all. But the WAY it ends felt like it was done purely for shock value and just seems pointless.

reviewText: We needed an ending, but this book was a bit hard to accept based on the premise of a sub-society test. However, I did enjoy the trilogy and thinking about an extreme single virtue without other virtues to balance.

I agree with a lot of the comments here, but those who say the ending wasn't the right one don't understand it.If Caleb had gone in, it would have revoked his character as a traitor because in the end, he was selfless. But he did not. He let Tris go in for him, proving that was a coward, through and through, and once again, let Tris walk to her death. It explains that some people will be that way. And there isn't anything you can do about it.Did this change Tris's decision? No, because she is NOT a coward. Tris gave her life in the ultimate act of both bravery and selflessness. She gave it for her brother that she despised because it's what her parents would have wanted. Proving, finally, that she is as equally Dauntless as she is Abnegation.Tris, by saving someone who betrayed her, completed her character arc. As sad as I was to see her die, and even more sad for Tobias, it was the only way to prove that she was both brave and selfless, down to her core. That she is a thorough representation of ALL the factions, really. And that everyone has all the qualities of the factions in them somewhere. It's what traits you choose to follow.

SPOILER-ISH ALERT**** Veronica Roth's style changes in this book. In the beginning, you can tell it is forced, but as the story progresses, she becomes more familiar and the style becomes more natural. She truly masters character development in this final novel. In the end, you will understand why the style had to change. You must read this, but I warn you - you will have a SEVERE book hangover once you're done. It took me weeks to begin a new series!

reviewText: SPOILERSI am indifferent about Tris' death, which is a sad statement after 3 books.  I hated the two person POV.  As other commenters mentioned, there was no real distinction between the voices.  I'd get a couple pages into a new chapter and discover I was thinking of the wrong character.  I kept thinking that Tobias thinks/talks like a girl.  I get why she did it. She decided to kill Tris (stupid name as an aside) and then thought she'd need another POV to carry on the story.  Not so. It would've been just as easy to switch narrators after the death.  I also didn't like the setting of the outside world as a bombed out version of the US.  It would've been more effective as just a nondescript place. All the references to Chicago O'Hare fell flat.  It was also super sketchy on the details.  If it was so easy to waltz in and out of the city, why not do it more often?  Also, did anyone else notice the repetition in the descriptions?  Everyone's lip curls, Tris always pulls on Tobias's shirt or belt loops, etc.

reviewText: Allegiant didn't seem to have the same spark as the first two books of the series. The pacing was quite slow--and the additional characters weren't well differentiated. What bothered me the most, though, was the alternating chapters between Four and Tris. It's not that I dislike the format; I often think it's very effective. But in this instance, the voice of the two was nearly identical. I literally kept forgetting which character was telling the story (and would have to go back to the chapter heading at time!), and with alternating narrations, the voices should feel very distinct. In this case, the voice that came out was Veronica Roth's, not the characters.  Unlike other reviewers, I was okay about the ending. It actually seemed quite fitting and in character, despite how disturbing many people found it.

I, like so many others, prefer a happy ending.  This ending was rather hopeless.  I liked the going back and forth between Tris' and Four's perspectives, but, like many others, often had to look back to see who was talking.  I thought the book was good overall, but life itself is so depressing, that when I invest that much time in a book, I want to come away feeling happy and hopeful.

There are a lot of trilogies where the first volume is just great as it introduces a new world with all its complexities and cultures. Divergent was one of those books. It seems to be much harder for authors to come up with equally good second and third volumes, because the fun of learning about a new and different world is over and the book has to rely more on plot and character to carry the load. This book gave a satisfying end to the trilogy but just wasn't in the same category as the first book of the series. I thought the explanation for how the culture in Chicago got to be the way it was, and what the outside world was like, was way too superficial and not nearly as imaginative as the original setting. Still, if you read the first two books, you will want to read this one.

I don't think that fans should  not read this book, because not having an ending would drive me way more insane than an ending I don't like, but I wouldn't set your expectations too high for this one.

This review contains hints at SPOILERS, but not direct spoilers–I can only advise that you read at your own risk . . .If I seem to not make as much sense as I normally do, know that I have just within the past ten minutes set this book down, and I’m still going through a little shock/trauma/grief over it. I feel this book, this ending so deep within me that I don’t know if I’ll be able to properly separate myself from it to type clearly, so please bear with me.Now, let me start off my own thoughts by telling you that I know it has raised some rather harsh reviews from readers, and I understand why in only one aspect–that the ending is not what anyone wanted. But I think that was part of the point that was being made. Life isn’t fair, and people have to die. When I read a book and ultimately suffer the loss of a character–a person within the story that I am close to, a person I identify with and spend the entire series growing alongside, a friend–that has a tendency to invoke a complete and utter devastation to my psyche. So yeah, the series didn’t end how I wanted it to because I would NEVER actually want to lose that friend. But you know what? It made sense. It really did, which is why I can accept it–as slowly and painstakingly as my heart feels like it’s been ripped out and boiled in acid, I can accept it.There were times when reading through the story I was getting so frustrated–at Tris, at Tobias, at EVERYONE–I was sighing and groaning and nearly pulling my hair out, pausing to cover my eyes like I couldn’t believe what was happening. But there were those times when I was so happy for Tris & Tobias, so excited for the next piece of the plot to come and then BAM! The next moment I’d be reeling from death and action. So much feels in this one book that left me analyzing myself, and how I would feel and how I would react, and who/what is right or wrong? What would I do? A true roller coaster of emotion that I will return to read again and again. And that’s part of what I like to judge a book on–the ability the story has to make that connection with me on more than just a reader-story level. When there’s no disconnect, when there’s a bond that ties me personally to the lives within the book and I genuinely feel attached to the characters, I know the story is worth it–to me, at least.I really do realize that there are a lot of people who are upset with this book out there, and I’m not just here to pledge my blind allegiance (see what I did there?) to this series because of the books that came before–I truly love this story and was so wrapped up in it that I felt akin to what the characters themselves were feeling. I know that in my personal experience, every book I have ever read that has tied me irrevocably to its story forever has been one that has lost integral characters in the ultimate struggle, in the end. It keeps me feeling human, because it’s rare that everything you want will work out perfectly, tied up like a pretty package with a little red bow on it.Sorry if this review seemed a bit preachy–remember when I warned you at the start about my working to process what happened? It may all still be . . . processing. But I firmly and without any regret–having used about fifteen Kleenex to wipe up all my tears–give Allegiant one of the most deserving 5/5 stars I’ve yet to commit ;)

Where Divergent was one of the most original and risky YA dystopian novels I'd read in a while, its sequel, Insurgent, was less so in all the areas that made the first one so great. This third and final installment continues the series' unfortunate decline. Allegiant isn't bad, it's just lacking that punch I know Veronica Roth is capable of.Allegiant picks up right where Insurgent leaves off though it seems like nothing much happens until after page 100. From there things do get more interesting. Tris and Tobias trade off POV perspectives at the start of most chapters. This particular literary device feels overdone, but I'm told it's common in YA romance novels. I do understand needing to get inside Tobias' head to drive this narrative along.Overall, the book isn't boring as Big Things do happen, but I wasn't as invested this time around.

I've waited four months to write this review.  I was so angry when I finished reading Allegiant that if I had written my review then I would of broken my #1 cardinal rule of reviewing: no author bashing (yes I was that angry).  Now I don't feel quite like that. I'm still angry about what happened in Allegiant - very angry - in fact when talking to my friends about it I almost always refer to it as "Effing Allegiant".  However, I am no longer angry at Veronica Roth!  It was her story to tell how she saw fit and how the characters told her to.  I'm not here to judge her, but I kinda hate the whole last book of this series and wish I skipped it.  On a plus side, it did make me feel, I felt a LOT and the emotions I felt (both positive and negative) were STRONG.  I was really close to not bothering with the movies now that I know how it all ends... then I saw the trailers and remember why I loved Divergent and Insurgent - Theo James doesn't hurt either!  I never thought I'd say this but I really hope Hollywood changes the ending.So why didn't I like it?  Well it was kind of like The Truman Show meets Logan 's Run.  It was just plain odd.  I didn't feel like the story fit with the rest of the series, which I actually think is what Veronica Roth was going for because, wow - the reality is just off the wall in this book.  I  eventually accepted the circumstances surrounding what was "outside the fence" and even almost starting not hating what was going on... then the ending happened, and that is when I got really angry.  You will have to read it for yourself to see what got me so upset.

I think many people would agree that Allegiant has been the most anticipated YA release of 2013. The third and final installment of Veronica Roth's Divergent series picks up right where Insurgent left off: Tris Prior learns that her world of factions is just a small ecosystem in a much larger world, created to help defend the outside world with Divergent. With Evelyn Johnson abolishing factions and running the city like a tyrant, Tris and Tobias head outside the city limits to discover the world beyond.I  have incredibly mixed feelings about Allegiant, but at the end of the day I enjoyed it, especially because of the ending which I will not spoil for you. Unfortunately the book started with a bad taste in my mouth because of all these Four novellas Roth is releasing to lead up to the Divergent movie release. I enjoyed Free Four to get me through the wait between books, but a whole series of Four novellas just to pump the movie? I think the series does better without them and all I see them as is a ploy for more money. It's money, I get it. But overall I think it chips away at the credibility of the Divergent trilogy and franchise. I find it's insulting to loyal readers, especially considering it would have made more sense to appease us in between the actual books. I think I would have been more receptive if it was one book from Four's perspective instead of four cheap teasers. I read The Transfer right before I read Allegiant, and, even though it was a sound novella, it left a bad taste in my mouth because of all the reasons above. I didn't trust Roth as an author anymore because now I feel she's just in it for the money. Not the best way to begin a new book!Overall this novel seemed very aimless to me. I never felt like there was a distinct arc that I could follow and consequently found it difficult to gauge how far along with the book I had read. I suppose I could give Roth the benefit of the doubt that she wants the reader to feel as aimless as Tris, but given my previous rant, I was too disheartened to believe this. If not for the great ending, I would have been extremely disappointed in the book overall.Another difficult part of this book to reconcile is the extreme change in scenery, which reminded me of Suzanne Collins' Mockingjay. The change of primary setting from the first two books took me out of my comfort zone as a reader. I never realize how a constant setting plays such an integral role in a series until it's taken away and the new setting takes some adjustment. This isn't a criticism of the writing because I understand it was necessary, but it might have played into why I felt this book was so aimless.At the end of the day, though, Roth is still an incredible writer and she can't go wrong with the cast of characters she has created. The themes of identity and being capable of creating ones own future are strong in this book and there are a lot of important lessons Tris and Tobias learn together. I could go on about various parts of this book, but I don't want to imply any spoilers. Despite my complaints, I still enjoyed every ounce of Tris' adventure, especially her evolving ideas of right and wrong. She remains one of my favorite female protagonists and a reason why I'll always recommend this series to other readers.Bottom Line: My feelings are so mixed, but overall I recommend this book and series, especially if you've already invested the time in the first two books in the series. 3.5/5 stars, but I'm rounding up for the ending.

reviewText: The 3rd, and sadly final, installment in the Divergent Trilogy was an emotional rollercoaster for me. I didn't want to begin reading right away because I knew it would be the end, so I savored books 1 and 2 again, then began nice and slow - even taking breaks between chapters, and re-reading sections as I went.Allegiant is told from 2 points of view: Tris and Tobias. I love Four, but I am so used to reading Tris that I wanted to stick with her. With Tobias, we get less insight into his feelings and emotions. He tells us but it doesn't seem to come from 'him' - leaving me with the feeling that Roth never fully got into his mind. If I could give half stars, I would have knocked off 1/2 star because of this.Once I adapted to that switching narrative, I was better able to keep track of who was talking. It was interesting to see how he was quite in awe of Tris though, and how complex he really is.Life is messy, hard, and emotional. A utopia gone wrong, war, is naturally messier, with much more trauma. Roth didn't spare us. She went there, and about half way through the book, I realized she was going to. I didn't know how, but I knew I wasn't going to be happy with whatever ending was coming. I am fine with her decision, it's possibly more realistic than so many of the other routes she could have gone. The ending isn't the point, either; it's the journey of a story that matters most. If it were all about the ending, let's just skip the book and go there, right?But still... I am torn between applauding the courage of the writing and hating it. It's rare that I love the end of a trilogy though. If I have invested that much time, I want more, and sometimes authors take drastic measures to bring it to a close, so I am not often going to be happy with it.Despite some of the downfalls, Veronica Roth still wrote a success that has given me a book hangover, it got under my skin so I wanted more, I wanted to read it when I was working, or when I should have been sleeping. I loved Tris and Four (and Tobias, because really, he was 2 different people, a mask and himself) - I loved them like they were real, and that's some good writing that can do that - they'll stick with me for a while longer.Roth was brave and honest. She told a story that was more probable, no matter how sad I am about it, she uncovered it and she risked it.

I actually loved this book and loved this ending. The big incident that readers got so upset about actually made me love the book, the series, and the author all the more. I thought it was a perfect and fitting end for each of the characters and the plot. The only thing I didn't quite understand or agree with, was how Peter came to his decision, but it wasn't a big enough deal to bother me one way or the other.Despite all this, Roth’s writing style is still not my favorite and it was not a perfect book by any means (but what books are?). I’d say my biggest issue was that there wasn't a strong difference in the voices of the two narrators. Part of that is because both Tris and Tobias are fairly dry, humorless characters. Their actions are dynamic, but neither are very colorful people. They’re matter-of-fact and that tends to make them sound similar, enough so that I couldn't always tell whose head I was in, and that’s not good. Personally, I don’t care for books that swap narrators, and I didn't really see the point (since the first two books were in Tris’s POV only), but it made more sense as the book went along and didn't bother me by the end.So, with all that, I gave it 4/5 stars. I almost gave it 5/5 to spite all the reviewers that gave it a 1 to be nasty, but I’m not that kind of girl. I loved the “Big Bad Thing” that Roth did, but I never fully connected with the characters or the writing style, so that keeps this review a 4. That being said, given the fact that Roth is willing to take such huge risks, I would definitely read her work again.

This review contains major spoilers. Please don't continue if you haven't finished the series.Before I read Allegiant, I saw the negative outpouring here and figured readers were upset because the romance did not resolve how they wanted. I was completely wrong.People are upset because they feel cheated--and very rightfully so. When you write a book series in the first person voice, you are entering into a default agreement with your readers. Veronica Roth broke this agreement, plain and simple. The first-person narrator always survives the story. To have any other result is ridiculously illogical and a cheap trick to boot. This is very basic, beginning creative writing stuff. If a student writer tried to pull something like this in a creative writing course, they'd be laughed out of the room.To make matters worse, Roth maintains that she planned the end all along. Okay, then why on earth wasn't the whole series in third-person voice, or at least in dual perspective as we had in Book Three with Tris and Four speaking? It's clear that Roth had certain philosophical goals here, but she could have met these goals easily without resorting to such a ridiculous solution.At the end of the day, some "rules" for writing exist because to break them means disaster, and that's pretty much what we have here. The story itself had other issues, but none are as significant as the point of view problem. It's a sad end for what had promised to be a stellar series.

WOW! People are really, REALLY upset with this ending. I agree, my heart ached at the end. I'm actually still pretty upset about it. However, considering the hostile world the characters lived in, am I surprised? No.Although I agree that Tris' and Tobias' voices were too similar (I did have to keep checking to remind myself who was talking), I thought the author provided a wealth of lessons in this installment. Aside from the obvious focus on discrimination and prejudice, she addressed bravery, courage, and ultimately, sacrifice. Was it a "storybook" ending? No, of course not. But, that's one of the things I liked about it. I disagree that it was senseless, I thought it served a very important purpose. The problem with a tragic ending in a trilogy, especially a really engaging trilogy with good characters, is that you become very attached to those characters. It actually feels like a personal loss. However, I think after time, and some objectivity, many fans will come to appreciate Allegiant.

I want to start by saying that I loved the first two books in this series. As I was reading them I felt like I really cared about the characters, connected to them emotionally and struggled to put the books down. So I went into this book with high expectations. Unfortunately it did not live up to my expectations. Normally I really like books that switch up the point of view to multiple characters chapter by chapter, but I didn't enjoy that in this story. I felt like Tris and Tobias were written so similarly in this book that sometimes I forgot which character I was even inside the head of in some chapters. I was so excited about going outside of the city and learning about how and why the factions were set up, but when it all played out it just seemed like a depressing acknowledgement that in the future people are going to continue to be prejudiced and class-ist and repeat the same mistakes we have made over and over in the past.In the first two books I felt a connection and cared deeply for all of the characters that were introduced. For some I had strong positive feelings (Tris, Tobias, Christina etc) and others I strongly disliked (Peter, Tobias's parents ect), regardless I they moved me to want to discuss them and the books and talk about it and think about it even when I wasn't reading. In this third book I cared very little about any of the new characters that were introduced.SpoilersThe end of the story was such a disappointment. I am not one of the reviewers who is angry that Tris died... if it was necessary for the story for her to ultimately die then I am on board for that... However in this story I don't feel that it was written in a way that made that necessary. I see her sacrificing herself for her brother, showing her forgiveness and not just throwing her life away like she may have earlier in the series, but it still felt like a waste. It was so anticlimactic and there are no repercussions for those involved, they just have their memories erased absolving them of the crime. On the other hand with Tobias it seems like everything just turns around for no reason with his mother. The whole trouble could have been avoided by just having a conversation between them and she would give it all up like that?  That is so cheap and easy and makes all the deaths appear to have happened in vain and been totally avoidable. That feels like a slap in the face when you deeply cared for those characters.Good things- I continue to love the references to Chicago and the Midwest where I am from, so cool to have a character from Peoria when I live 10 minutes away. I really liked how the different landmarks in Chicago were part of the story throughout the series.Roth can we just have you rewrite this one? Clearly you can do an amazing job, just look at the first two books. So I say... try again.
summary: Dear Veronica Roth, please try again

Love, friendship, tragedy, struggles, sacrifices and finding forgiveness....this trilogy has it all. Definitely a series I will be reading again.

None of the books in this trilogy take more than a day to read.  The problem is, they're so lightweight and senseless that it's hard to remember the nondescript characters and convoluted yet nonsensical plots between books.  I read these books because my granddaughter loves them.  This third novel purports to explain the reasons for the factions and battles in the Divergent and Insurgent.  It doesn't make sense and it doesn't hold together.  When I read the first two novels, it struck me as odd that no one in the fenced-in dystopian Chicago had any curiosity whatsoever about the world outside the fence.  Where did they get gasoline?  Where was their electricity generated?  Where did they get coffee?  Or fresh vegetables in winter?  It seemed to me that they were a pretty dull bunch, Erudition notwithstanding.  No wonder they didn't question their ridiculous faction system.  It never occurred to them that they weren't the only people in the world?  That their city couldn't possibly be self-sufficient? I guess if they were actually smart or curious, they might be forced to ask questions that would point out the thinness of the plot premises.Now, there are a bunch of faction kids from Chicago have gone outside the gate, all the way to the government Genetic Welfare "compound" at O'Hare Airport.  They travel by truck--they don't have to fend for themselves for even ten minutes, although of course people are trying to kill them.  This compound, which still flies planes, is a few minutes outside of the fenced-in city where they lived, yet they've never seen an airplane and don't know about air travel--although it appears that the planes fly close enough to Chicago to drop vaporized serum over the city. I guess it never occurred to them to wonder about that silver cylinder with wings cruising in the sky.  Why should they?  They don't wonder about anything else either.Needless to say, there's some romantic strife between Tris and Tobias.  And an epic battle, where the faction kids outwit everyone and never wonder at their good luck:  they need to go down a restricted hallway to the most secret weapon storage?  No problem.  No guards will challenge them.  Need to learn how to make and detonate bombs? No problem, and it only takes a couple of minutes!  Although they're newbies to the facility, they have no problems finding trusted allies immediately.  They can sneak out and back in with impunity.  Need weapons?  Easy peasy.As has been mentioned in other posts--this story is told in the voices of both Tris and Tobias.  The problem is, there's no difference between their voices.  Not one iota.  The device is a little more confusing than it needs to be.The purported explanation of the factions in Chicago is silly and convoluted.  The threat to the future of the people of Chicago is contrived.  Tris's and Tobias's roles in these matters are just plain ludicrous.This is truly one of the most dreadful book series I've ever encountered.

reviewText: I enjoyed this book, and this series. I'm not sure it will enjoy the same popularity that The Twilight Saga or The Hunger Games has, but there are some important themes in this series. Likenesses, differences; strengths, weaknesses; purity, damage; haves and have nots.....If we don't become more tolerant and collaborative as a society, then we stand to fall and disintegrate as a society, perhaps deservedly so.  This series gives us a considerable amount to think about.  I recommend it.

reviewText: Love this trilogy.  I was very happy with the prompt delivery and great condition this book was in.  I am very happy with this purchase.

Before I read Divergent I suspected that Roth was riding the dystopian wave and had very low expectations of the book. I was pleasantly surprised by it and looked forward to the next two books. Insurgent was disappointing, but I chalked that up to the "sophomore curse" and expected Allegiant to be far better. It's not--in fact, it's a very poor effort.The problem with the book is not the ending. I can get on board with the choice Roth makes--in the abstract. For that to work, however, the rest of the book has to be totally on point. Instead, it's a mess, with way too many new characters, too much exposition, and too much internalizing by the characters. There were times when I just wished the characters would DO something, anything. When they did, it was usually violence that had little point to it except to kill off characters Roth failed to make me care about.Unfortunately, because of the controversy about the ending, some famous authors are defending Roth as "brave." What she did is not "brave" within the context of an intensely mediocre book. Now looking back on it, it's clear to me the potential of the first book was never realized, making the entire series a misfire.I LIKE books--especially books about war--to NOT pull punches and to have the guts to make readers suffer. But for me, the suffering wasn't from the ending--it was from trying to slog through a dull and ultimately pointless book.

reviewText: The book is worth reading for anyone who started the series.  It differs from the initial storyline in my opinion.  I knew the third book would have problems when we learned that the world was artificial.  That left  only two real options a forced experiment or a voluntary experiment.  Both of which are overdone.  What I did not expect was that the beginning would be flat, or  the lack of differentiation in the split point of view-at least in the first half  of the book.  Four as we know him did show up, but only in the last half of the story.  The tragic ending added nothing to the story.  This book seemed to be the author's attempt to write a more important story than the one she started with.  Unfortunately, she missed the fact that the factions and loss of choice was already a very important comment on social norms and problems.  Still, if you started the series I recommend you read it.  I wish Ms Roth future success.  I hope she reads the comments and takes whatever is useful from them.

I loved Divergent.  I liked Insurgent a lot.  I liked Allegiant, just not as much.  It packed an emotional wallop on more than one occasion.  Even over a week after reading it I am still sad. The heart of this story was still there.I was expecting a bit more than we got about the world outside Chicago or maybe about the aftermath of everyone knowing the truth...or maybe just everyone knowing the truth.  I think the ending was always coming but it still broke my heart.What I didn't like about this book was the voice of Four.  I kept having to go back and see who I was reading as there wasn't much difference between Tris and Four.  And I didn't like his voice.  I know he's damaged but his voice made him seem weak. And Four is anything but weak!To me the most important part of this story was about being brave. You have to believe in something and take action no matter how scared you are.  Tris continued to do that until the end.  She will go down as one of my favorite book heroines and I can't wait for my daughter to be old enough to read this series.

Allegiant-the final book in the Divergent Series was the least compelling of the three. One major difference between this book and the other two is that the story's voice now expands to Tobias, as well as Tris. Each chapter's voice alternates between the two. For some reason, this didn't work as well for me. Tobias is my favorite character in the series, but getting inside his head didn't grab me. The stakes are very high in this part of the story. The characters do feel the emotions of their situation, but it did not seem genuine.  The story moves unevenly. At times, moving too quickly to resolution, at other times, seeming to drag. I read this series with my 11 year old. He lost interest in this book and didn't finish it. I had to see it through, but even the ending sort of disappointed for me. This book was not the worst thing I've ever read, but it didn't match the first two books.

This book was just awful... I really don't know where to begin. Let's just say I felt like Bradley Cooper in Silverlinings Playbook.. I wanted to scream "WTF" and throw the darned book out the window!Let's start with the beginning... good start, I guess. But about 15% into the book the plot started to get so convoluted. The explanation of Divergence is just stupid. Also, Roth decided to write this book in both Tobias's (Four) and Tris's POV, when the first two books were only in Tris's POV. The first two books Four was strong and stable and I really liked him. But in this last book, Roth made him out to be an emotional man child... seriously. I was getting so annoyed with him and actually both Tris and Four's voice seemed so similar I couldn't even tell whose chapter I was reading. Not good.As the plot thickens...(or kinda thickens.. it was so 1 dimensional) there are all these new ideas introduced (GP - genetically pure people; and GD- genetically damaged people) that you start to lose the whole Divergence plot entirely. This was so poor explained and irrationally introduced that I almost gave up on the book about 60% through. But alas, unfortunately, I decided to finish it. And what a terrible ending... without giving it away, I feel like Roth ended the series just to shock us. Honestly, I was just left shocked with how terrible it was. The ending absolutely did nothing for the story but make it even worse. After this ending, I have no interest in seeing the movie.I feel so disappointed because the first two books were AWESOME!! I truly believed it would be a strong contender to the Hunger Games Series... but no way, absolutely, now way.

reviewText: A fitting conclusion to the series. Of course it wasn't the ending everyone hoped for, but it was more realistic. Plus, it fit with the characters and their personalities. It was refreshing to see an author go for the ending that fits, rather than the one that's popular.There were some slow parts in the book, and some parts that felt like filler, but most of it was just as well written and engaging as the first two.  When it was first released, I was surprised to see so many low reviews.  Tons of people were rating it 1 and 2 stars, so I knew something big and bad was going to happen.  I purposely didn't read any reviews because I didn't want to spoil anything.  I had a pretty good guess as to what the Big Bad would be, and I was right.I love the characters in this series.  Tris is such a great protagonist.  She isn't perfect, but she is the type of girl you can cheer for and feel good about.  Tobias obviously fits into that category as well.  I took my brother to go see the movie and he loved that Tobias was a "man's man".  I have to admit, I liked that too.  :)My only big complaint about the book was not the Big Bad that shook most people up, but rather had to do with the setting.  Honestly, I didn't really think about anything beyond the city as I read the first two books.  I liked the city and the issues going on there.  I almost never like it when characters are taken out of their original setting and plunked into a different one.  I wanted the third book to resolve the problems within the city without involving the outside world.My favorite part of the book had to be at the very end when Tobias goes zip lining.  I was so proud of him and I loved even him more than I had throughout the whole series.Content: Violence and some profanity, kissing partially dressed.

Its with a heavy heart that I post this. And the ending was epic---epically bad.  The tension and even the likability of the main couple was lost.  I was no longer rooting for them and felt that it was dragging in chapters towards the end.  While I don't require every book I read to have a HEA,  I did feel that Tris' death was not necessary and did not serve the overall storyline.I don't feel that this was the worst book I have ever read, but its certainly the worst ending to a promising and beautiful crafted series. reviewText: Oh my.... wow, what to say that hasn't been said.  I got this book the day it released, but didn't read it until this week because I saw the horrible reviews. It made you think.Cons -I missed the 'ahhhh moments' between Tris and Tobias - they just weren't there.The relationship between Tris & Tobias didn't grow, If it had, I think the death would have given me a good cry, but I didn't feel anything when the death happened.I found myself skipping through because there wasn't anything holding my attention.  this is especially true for the last 1/4 of the book.Pros -I finally got to know what was on the other side of the fence.I like the idea behind how everything got split up in the first place.I liked Tris finding out more about her mom's lifeI liked that she came to terms with CalebOverall POV - I couldn't leave the series without reading this book. reviewText: First off,  full disclosure here,  I am not a professional or even amateur book reviewer.What I want to do with this review is tell you how I felt about the purchase of this product.When I bought this book,  I knew the following:1. The target audience of the book is teenage level readers.  This would include adults looking for some very casual reading.2. I enjoyed reading the other 2 books (solid 4 stars, if not a bit better).3.  Lots of folks love the book,  lots of people hate the book,  far fewer  take a more neutral stance.Having that in mind, I still wanted to finish reading the series, so I spent the $7  for the Kindle download and began reading.My thoughts...1.  Allegiant  is NOT a literary masterpiece (nor was it meant to be.  Newer Author,  targeting teens).2.  The story line gets a little 'weird' at times,  there were a couple of times I had to overlook 'flaws' (an opinion, of course) and keep on reading.3.  The first two books were more enjoyable to me (Divergent being the one I enjoyed the most)4.  I have no problem what-so-ever with the ending.  A  personal statement, not a literary critique.5.  At no point while reading this book did I get bored and want to quit reading based on the writing.  A few parts were "just okay" though.6.  Allegiant is very differently written than the other two books.7.  Finally,  I liked reading the series.  Not nearly as much as Hunger Games or Harry Potter  (other teenage target series), but not terrible either.Why 4 Stars?1 star = 'I hate it'  - Not True.2 stars = 'I don't like it'  - Not True either,  I did enjoy it.3.stars = 'Just Okay'  There are lots of just okay moments in the book.  Might fit.4 stars = 'I liked it'  There are lots of moments in the book I do like. Might fit.5 stars = 'I love it'  - Not really true either.So, in the end,  I would really like to give a satisfaction rating for Allegiant of 3.5 stars.  However, I have to choose though between 3 or 4 stars.  In the end, I 'liked' the book (and certainly the series) and the $7  spent was a good value for the entertainment.
It was a good book but I feel like the story was rushed a little bit...plus I was not a fan of the ending.

It read as if a completely different, less talented writer had penned it. The rigid first-person writing style was an unwelcome departure from the previous books—it was a real effort to finish this book.
Better than expected closing of the series. A little dark for younger readers but then so was Lord of the Flies...

I have three things to say about the Divergent Series.1) It's a lot of fun for 2 and 3/4 books.2) The last 1/4 of the last book stunk and ruined the entire series.3) The love story is cheesy and gives the 11 to 14 year olds reading the series a skewed and inappropriate idea of what first love is like.I always say that a book or a book series (which is really just one long book broken into parts) is only as good as its ending. What you are left with when you close the cover on the end means more than all the stuff that came before.  As fun as the story of Tris, Tobias, and friends was, it means nothing when the ending makes me wish I hadn't read it at all.You know what the kicker is? I even knew it was coming. I never, NEVER read spoilers. But this ONE time I did. I always wait to start a series until the last book has been written--I hate cliffhangers and waiting years for them to be resolved.  I knew Divergent had a ton of fans and I was just waiting for the final book to come out, but when it did and the reviews were horrible I decided to investigate. I didn't want to read something I was going to hate! When I realized what had even the most passionate fans ready to rumble, I decided I wouldn't even start. But then Amazon went and had them as a Kindle Daily Deal and I couldn't resist. I wish I had. So there's that.My other gripe is a bit harder for me to put into words. I read books both for me and for my kids. I want them to love getting lost in a story as much as I do.  I know first hand how powerful words can be, especially how words in books can shape perspective, understanding, and expectations of things that someone has never experienced for themselves.  If you have never been to Alaska read "The Snow Child" and you'll feel like you grew up there.  Want to know what it's like living in small-town Mississippi? Read a John Grisham novel.  Want to know how it felt to experience the 9/11 terrorist attacks in Manhattan? Read "Peace in Amber" and you'll think you were there.  Its been 17 years, but I still to this day think I know what's it's like to be an 11-year-old girl because I read "Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret" when I was 10.  I still remember how I felt when I read a book nearly 20 years ago, and has shaped me! So, do I want my 12-year-old daughter to learn what first love is like by reading about Tris (who is 16, has never even held a boy's hand, yet can navigate romance with the skill of a seasoned adult) and Tobias (who is 18, never had a girlfriend, and has super human control over his hormones)? No! No! No!  Their relationship is not real.  I'm sad for these young children who read about Tris climbing in bed with Tobias wearing only a T-shirt and underwear, wrapping her legs around him under the covers, making out with passion and feeling, rubbing hands on hips and up and down bare backs, and then chastly falling asleep together, Tobias protecting Tris from her bad dreams. So romantic! So ideal! So not real! Someone who has experienced love can filter the fantasy from the reality. But children who have Tris and Tobias to thank for their first experience with love are going to be disappointed when their expectations fail to meet with their reality. So, as much as my daughters and sons may want to read the Divergent Series, I'm going to insist they wait.In fact, I'm going to be suggesting the skip the Divergent Series all together.
summary: A fun series sunk by a stupid ending and too mature for the young kids reading it...

The characters were flat, underdeveloped and I didn't really feel anything about any of them. The premise of GDs and GPs felt like a lecture on human nature. Too much time was spent on that explanation (which sounds odd because there really weren't many actual details) and not enough time on character interaction and development. Except for a few characters we didn't get to know any of the people living in the compound or the fringe.  This book felt rushed to print and I wish I had stopped after the first two-which I thoroughly enjoyed and didn't want to put down. I had to force myself to finish reading it and found myself skimming the final chapters in boredom. To be fair I went back and forced myself to read them completely but still felt the same-bored. Very disappointing ending to what started out as a great series. I need to add to my original review. Its not all about Tris dying or not dying as so many people are complaining about. That  has nothing to do with my review. Its about the overall construction of the third book. Compared to the first two it is flat and two dimensional.The plot, the pacing, the repetitive narrative. It left me feeling bored, cheated, disappointed. I will follow an author's idea anywhere as long as the ride is a quality work of writing. reviewText: After reading Insurgent I wasn’t expecting to be wowed by Allegiant, and unfortunately my expectations were right.Roth is excellent at writing action and suspense. The scenes with the Allegiant getting ambushed while trying to leave the city, Tris, George and Amar being attacked while visiting “the fringe” and  Tris and Caleb trying to breach the weapons lab were good, not as good as some of the action sequences in Divergent and Insurgent, but good enough to keep this reader engaged.However, outside of the very few “action” scenes, the conclusion of this series was uninspiring.Tris – Totally preachy, self-centered and self-righteous. Her 'I am always right. I always know what to do. I can’t forgive him, Caleb, for joining Erudite and leaving me,' attitude made her character even more unlikeable than she was in Insurgent. Though her POV talked about her pain and sometimes confusion over all that had happened, I never believed it. The words were on the page, but there was no feeling behind them. I didn't see or feel Tris' pain. She had no reaction to the truth about Divergent, which was a word she’d strongly embraced and used to define herself. She had no reaction Edith Prior's message except one that served the plot eta., her near obsession with going outside the city without very little thought about why they should do that and what they may encounter outside of their own world. She had no reaction to Caleb's impending execution until it served the plot. Her choices didn't feel organic. Instead they felt like a list of things the author needed to check off for her to do before she finally made the ultimate choice of self-sacrifice. As a result, Tris didn’t come off as real, and therefore became unrelateable. When she died I was somewhat surprised the author went there, though the last morning she spent with Tobias and  Roth choosing to do this last book in two POVs should’ve been a sign that one of the two narrators were going to die. I didn’t feel anything when Tris died. Her death seemed preachy with her continuous thoughts about how sacrificing herself for those she loved was what true sacrifice was.  It was disappointing because this was a character I really enjoyed in Divergent.Tobias – He was by far my favorite character in the series, but in Allegiant he became a shell of his former self. His voice was not any different from Tris’. It was the same tone, the same word use, the same everything. Furthermore, he turned into a completely different character.  I always got the impression that he never put much stock in being defined as Divergent, yet when he learns that he isn’t and is thus “genetically damaged,” he becomes insecure, reckless and even more brooding. I found no interest in his mending relationship with his mother, because there was no effort put into that relationship except when it served the plot.  I thought it would’ve made more sense to explore resolving his issues with Marcus, his father, since this man had been a presence in Tobias/Four psyche since the first book. Yet Marcus was just kept around as a minor plot device before disappearing completely, without explanation, when the writer had no more use for him. Despite the poorly written POV of Tobias I still cared about this character. I was pleased that he lived (and that he may end up with Christina), but similar to Tris’ POV I didn’t feel like his final words were organic. It felt as if he was speaking to the reader, telling the reader the true meaning of bravery and survival. It took me out of the story and made me feel as if the author, not Tobias was speaking at this point.Tris/Tobias –  I couldn’t  have cared less about their relationship, which is sad considering it was much of the center of Divergent. There was chemistry there, a hotness that jumped off the page in the first book, when these two interacted and there was respect, much of which was lost in Insurgent. In Allegiant, everything that made this couple interesting was completely gone. Though Roth, I’m sure, intended for their relationship to come off as two young individuals going through the difficulties of being in love and in a relationship, it came off as two individuals who were just doing the only thing they knew to do, the only thing that remained familiar in their ever changing world which was to be together. I didn’t feel the love, respect or potential that this relationship represented in the first book. When they said they loved each other I didn’t believe it. When they said the other was their life, I didn’t believe it. The words were there, but the warmth was missing from their interactions, which made their relationship tedious. When they were on the verge of breaking up and when Tris died, I just didn’t care about her brief moment of pain over never seeing Tobias again or how he’d be devastated over her death.  Like many of the characters in this book, Tobia and Tris’ relationship was a shell of its former self. It was no longer viable and should’ve ended long before Tris’ death.The experiment (genetically damaged vs. genetically pure) – Was one of the most convoluted and contrived things I’ve ever read. Granted, I could understand Roth’s desired commentary on prejudice, bravery and humans desire to play God and fix what isn’t broke. However, the execution just didn’t make sense. The science was completely unbelievable, and the characters reactions, or lack thereof, to the lies that was their lives and who they were didn’t ring true. Lastly, the resolution being Chicago becoming this Utopia where the genetically damaged and genetically pure could live in peace and harmony was completely implausible. If the culture of the United States was that the government/genetically pure believed that the genetically damaged were menaces who were not worthy of rights and respect, would they really standby and let Chicago turn into this Utopia for all?I think the original concept of Divergent was interesting and likely could’ve been managed had the concept been kept simple. However, with Roth adding in government experiments and conspiracies, civil wars, societies within societies, it just got too big. It was impossible to keep a coherent story with so much going on. Perhaps this story should’ve been spread out into several books so the characters and the world they lived in could be properly fleshed out. Unfortunately that is not what happened, and as a result what started out as a promising series ended up being a severe disappointment.
summary: An Uninspiring Close to the Divergent Series

reviewText: Well I would never want to hurt the feelings of this author but I absolutely hated this book.  Not just the ending like some of the other reviews but really the entire book.  I don't know why she did the perspective of both Tris & Four, if the 2 books before did this then I would understand but why start now. I even felt that she only wrote some of the book. I see and feel her writing in some of the chapters and then I felt like it was a completely different person's thoughts in other chapters. Huge disappointment for me.

So. This book gives you time to realize what it means. People. <SPOILERS> You may be disappointed "noo Tris didn't even live no happily ever after" or "noo Tobias ISN'T as macho as I thought!" For possible scenario #1: She's (Tris) a strong character. It was, admittingy, a bit of a let-down for the ending. But, it was actually crafted pretty well. Tris dies with a happy feeling. But with the epilogue? Not the same. Tobias is practically fine. It has been Two Years, according to the chapter/epilogue. If someone you loved died and it's two years after ONLY?! I mean, wouldn't you be practically damaged without repair???Possible scenario #2:It shows that Tobias is like cuddly teddy, if you give him time. He's sweeter on the inside. Meanwhile, everyone hates that Tobias is a sweetheart to his gf. It's lke saying, "Aww, damnit! Tobias actually DOES care for Tris! Damn!"--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Anyhow, Allegian is a good book, despite the negativitys. I think if you'll give it a chance, you'll like it.

I feel like many others do about this ending book of the series.  I didn't like it at all.  The first two books were great, deserving of 5 stars, but this was a huge disappointment.I didn't like the switching of narrative from Four to Tris!  It was very difficult to get into the characters switch and I found myself confused several times and had to re-read many pages.  I have never seen this type of narrative switch and if I find that it is in any book, I will definitely pass on the book.  It has no redeeming value.The narrative was boring most of the time, with a weak story line that didn't fit the first two books.  The answer to what was outside the borders of the first two books was, in itself, a disappointing twist.  I started to say that it wasn't believable, but that is an oxymoron in fantasy fiction. It just didn't seem to suit the story line.The way it ended was extremely disappointing ! ! ! !  To come that far being a champion of Tris to see it ended in that manner made me want to stop reading immediately.  I kept on, thinking that Roth would come up with some twist that would negate this egregious turn of the plot.  That left EVERYTHING in seeming limbo with absolutely no good feelings about how the book ends.A very big disappointment overall.
summary: Totally disappointing ending to the trilogy.
