I skimmed through chunks of this book because it was so boring, and finished it only because I read the other two books. Blah. Read it if you can't stand to leave the series unfinished. Otherwise, skip it.

I loved Divergent. I loved Insurgent. Maybe it's just me (and it seems to be) but I love Allegiant even more.I get it wasn't the perfect, tied in a bow, happy ever after most people wanted, but this ending was SO fitting for the characters. I sobbed, I grieved, I hugged the book. My heart still aches for them, but it is what it is. The writing was as beautiful as ever, and I love Four just as much now as I did the moment Tris stepped off the net in Divergent.

I can not believe that you chose that for the ending. There was no reason for killing her off. And not letting them do what they had to do and letting them live happily. Unbelievable. Worst ending to a story I've ever read. Waste of my time and money reading these books. Never again will I read a book by you.

I bought all three books in the series..Allegiant is the third in the series..The concept of genetic manipulation is a good primis and the hero being a young teenage girl (Hunger Games) but I could not ingage with Four and Tris..I finished all three books but I could have stopped half way through the second book...Sorry I know a lot of people love this series.....

This is a hard review for me to write because I loved the first two books so much. Did I enjoy this book? Kinda. Was I shocked and left with unsettled feelings? YES! As with the previous books in the series the emotional investment is pretty intense. Maybe that’s why this one has the most impact on me, but not necessary in a good way. Perhaps I was too emotionally caught up in the lives of the characters and the twist in this, the last look into their lives, was more than a little disquieting.ALLEGIANT begins where INSURGENT ended. There is a continuation that would have been fluid if not for the jarring use of two first person voices. This doesn’t normally bother me and I actually enjoy it in quite a few books I’ve read. Not the case here. Found it difficult to remember whose take on the story I was reading in several different points throughout the novel. Despite the confusion of which one was doing the talking, once again Tris and Tobais consume my total attention, as do all the characters in the story. There is a richness in each personality that isn't always seen in other books. I found myself invested in what was going to happen to them and what they were going to become embroiled in. The realism comes across, even if the story is unimaginable. But sometimes realism isn’t always a good thing. The buildup as to what is going to be found beyond the fence was so well done. The reality of what they find I wasn’t so happy with. Parts of it worked but larger parts were disappointing.  As in the first two books, there are no punches held. Perhaps that is what makes all the stories so consuming. Knowing that nothing and no one is sacred brings an intensity and tension that’s tangible. If you have already read the first two books in the series you are going to have to read ALLEGIANT. I’m happy I read this but find myself left with mixed feelings as to the ending, heck, to the whole book. Maybe this is the only way for the story to end in Ms. Roth’s mind. She definitely left me with my feelings in turmoil and maybe that is what she intended.RECOMMEND to anyone 15 and older. Contains acts of extreme violence.
summary: DISAPPOINTED, BUT HAD TO READ IT

reviewText: Allegiant has received countless negative reviews and I can think of one chapter that may have caused them, but say what you want about Roth's decisions, this book ended the trilogy in a away I never (and I mean never) saw coming. Allegiant had it all: romance, humor, and of course, action, or revolutions, I suppose would be more appropriate. It did get a bit slow at times, but I believe those times were needed in order to soak everything that is revealed in, and a lot is revealed. I almost found myself just as overwhelmed as our main characters.Roth does a great job of crafting a conclusion that answers all our questions and providing closure for the things left unresolved in the other books. I see that many people are unsatisfied with the way things turned out, but honestly don't see why everyone is so bent out of shape. Allegiant has twists and turns no one will see coming, and I definitely enjoyed the ride. I will miss all of these characters though...

I really enjoyed the series.  I have to say, I wish the end would have been different. I don't want to spoil the ending for those who might want to read the series with my review. I would read it again.

The Story-Even though Tris revealed the secret at the end of book 2, Allegiant finds her in prison for treason. Due to her resistance to truth serum, she is able to lie and get herself and her friends of the hook. But, life in the city is almost as worse as before. The factionless have taken control, and have demolished all the factions. Now that they are out of the shadows, the factionless are ruling the people by force and declaring the video Tris released as a lie.Tris, Tobias, and a few close friends decide the only place left for them is outside the city walls. However, when they leave they find the world waiting for them has as many problems as the city they just left. Years of genetic manipulation has left the human population at odds with one another. "Purity Wars" were fought and millions died. Now, the genetically pure lead things, with the genetically damaged seen as second class citizens.As Tris and Tobias learn about the world they've escaped into, they see the injustice running rampant and join forces to help the GD (genetically damaged). Things get hairy when they learn of the Bureau's plot to wipe out all the memories of everyone left in the factionless city and reprogram them to be different people.My Thoughts-A great ending to an action-packed trilogy. Wow, this book really tied together all the loose ends, both emotionally and physically. The story switches back and forth between Tris and Tobias' POV's. We see Tris as she learns that her genetic defects have healed, and Tobias as he is declared genetically damaged. Both struggle to relate to the new world and find their places in it. I have to admit that I often got confused about whose POV I was in. Tris and Tobias are so alike that it would catch me by surprise to find myself thinking I was in one of their heads, when in fact I was in the other.Though not as action packed as the previous two books, this one is full of emotional drama. I didn't miss the action as I learned about the world that was outside the city. The idea of genetic manipulation is feasible for our day and age, and reading about the results and the deluded secrets of the people left in charge was hard, because I could see it happening in real life.The ending is a big shocker. I wasn't ready for it, and when it happened I was in disbelief. However, Roth does a great job continuing the story so that we feel the aftermath on our characters and as you read on, the shock eases. Wow, this series has some great lessons.

This was the conclusion to a great trilogy story involving a group of friends working through some difficult times in their lives.  It kept my attention all the way through but shocked me with the unexpected conclusion.  It was wonderful seeing how these young people helped each other with each difficult problem as they came up.  I noticed how our government could parallel their government if we're not careful.  I was thinking that we need to be involved in how our government is functioning and prevent a complete takeover maintaining a government created by the people, for the people, that will not parish from this earth.
Never imagined the conclusion. Well done. Now I need to read four's story .  The whole premise of this series reminds me of the old science fiction books that I loved to read.

Once again Veronica Roth delivers an extraordinary story. Is it perfect? Probably not. Did it have the perfect ending? Maybe not. But life is not always perfect, we just have to be aware of moments that make us laugh, gives us hope, and allow us to love one another. Tris is and will always be a true heroine, because in the face of chaos, death, and despairs she chooses love. And most importantly, she chooses to be brave.

I really enjoyed the first book of this series, the second one less and felt this book was totally unnecessary. These days I'm so over the big war/battle scene. Why do we have to write books like that people get murdered. Why do we have to create these heroes that are so illogical and egotistical?  I would recommend the first book to another person but tell them to skip the other two.
Did not meet expations!  After reading the first two books was really looking forward to the final installment in the triligy but was dissapointed.  Lots of dialog with limited action.
summary: Not as good as the first two books

reviewText: Well, I've just got to ask...Doesn't anyone know how to write a good third book in a trilogy... I mean, geez! It was slow and boring the whole way through. None of it really added up and then the ending... WT!! Why should we care?! Let's hope they fix it in the movie... Like the a Hunger Games (3rd book a stinker also...) Very disappointed.

Enjoyed the series, and it generally made sense through plot and character development. Nice light reading, especially if you are a teenage girl. I'm not. Doesn't rise to the level of an Asimov or Iain Banks, but it is worth reading for the entertainment value.
summary: Good work, but not great sci-fi

reviewText: Allegiant picks up exactly where Divergent left off and doesn't miss a beat in story continuity or pacing. The new twists will engage and excite.
summary: Continues the great series with fidelity.

reviewText: This book started out much slower than the first two in the series.  I therefore mistakenly predicted the book to end all happy, nice and cozy. It didn't end as expected and it left you with a tangle of feelings.  Even though this is a young adult series and I am not, the things these young characters had to face and go through kept me hooked. They faced evil, danger, love and hard choices much like every adult faces day-to-day in real life. Sometimes books come into your life at just the right times and this series did just that for me.
summary: A roller coaster of emotions all wrapped-up into the third and final book of the Divergent series.

reviewText: It takes a bit for the last book in this trilogy to get going and for a while I thought “how is this going to wrap up neatly before it ends?”  Despite waiting a while to get going when it does it’s really good.  It offers a deep look into the life outside of the city and how this world came to be (although I can see a book on the purity wars coming down the line), which is why it takes a while to get going, and paints a disturbing look at this brutal world.  The book gets a bit preachy/hokey at the end, but all in all it was a good way to close out the story.  Being able to see the story from both Trice and Tobias’ point of view also added another unique twist to this installment.
summary: A great ending to the trilogy

reviewText: I liked this 3rd and last in the Divergent Series.  It brought the story all together in a very fascinating way.  Veronica Roth has a wonderful imagination and I loved the whole concept of the series. I  think this is good reading for teenagers as well as adults.

Allegiant is an amazing action packed adventure that takes you through the life of Tris Prior. It shows the betrayals and losses she's faced, and the blood that is shed. All to get out of the city and find out the truth. This book also shares the love between Tris and Tobias, but will that end? and will they die? Divergent will be the next BIG thing.

I found the end of this series a tad disappointing. That being said I would have read it even knowing this.  Once you have committed to a 3 book saga, you know you have to see it through.I don't want to give anything away because there is nothing I hate more than the unconsiderate reviewer who thinks a review is "telling what happens".  A review should be about if I liked it or not, not be Cliff notes for the story.It's as if the saga just falls flat.  I'm not sure if V. Roth ran out of time with her publisher in having to get Alegiant done or if she just ran out of ideas but it just seems like Alegiant is like Insurgent's twin or as if someone copied the concept for Insurgent and wrote fan fiction.  After Insurgent,  I expected it to go in a different direction, be unlike any of the first two books and instead I felt like I was reading a book I've already read, with some surroundings changed.Don't get me wrong, the book wasn't complete trash.  It had it's moments.  I just felt like there was SO much she could have done with the story considering how Insurgent ended.  The story was wide open and it was as if she stuck with what worked before rather than creating something new.It did manage to engage me.  As the end of the story came I had tears flowing so V. Roth had me immersed by the end of the book.  And that's saying something since I read "The Fault in our Stars" and remained dry eyed.  So, where a book about teens with cancer didn't make me cry, Alegiant had a hold of me and held on like hell.If you've read Divergent/Insurgent.....might as well see it through.  I mean hey, you've come this far, right?!
I loved every bit of the series.. I was saddened when Tris died but she died for a reason. I'm glad she'll be able to see her parents. Long live Tris.

I read the first book and understood the hype.  The second one was still intriguing.  This last one, however, lacked the thrill of the first two.  In Allegiant, Roth switches perspectives between Tris and Four/Tobias; not a change I found agreeable.  I wish Roth would have remained consistent, like she did in the first two books.On top of this, the plot (without spoiling it) did not hold my attention.  With the other books, I looked forward to reading.  With this one, I could take or leave my reading time.

Dear God this is the best book I have ever read in the history of time, and trust me I have read many books. This book I would recommend 11 and up if mature. But read the first two in the collection, Divergent, and Insurgent. Be sure to take your time, because this is a book you just can't put down

I chose this rating because I enjoyed all of the other books in the series. I am not a huge fan of the ending but I expected some of that type of sad depressing stuff. Overall there was enough action to keep you excited and a good bit of character development even for the end of the series. I enjoyed this book and the whole divergent series. Hopefully everyone agrees with me. (Also hoping the movie is as good as the book!!!!)
A real page turner.  It must be about another Chicago, though, since this one has a Madison Street, not. Madison Avenue.

Ok I give the book 4.5 stars because it is very well written but I couldn't give it 5 because I just totally hated the ending in every way possible ... (Slight spoiler alert) I know you aren't supposed to expect a "happy" ending all the time but after 3 books, to just end it this way leaves such a bummed heart of a feeling ... I do hope Hollywood sees fit to adjust the ending to something much less devastating and sad... That being said, I can't fault the author for the written word because she did great in that aspect so thumbs up for that and thumbs down for its harsh ending ... :/

We get both Tris & Tobias' POVs in this book. Initially, I did not like Tobias' POV, though I have read Free Four which tells his side of the story for one scene in Divergent and didn't have a problem with it.  But here, it didn't feel genuine, though I think this may be because his thoughts and feelings were different than what I expected.  It did become easier for me to read his POV as the book went along, though.As for the story, it was interesting where Roth took this.  I know it was her intention all along, but there were parts that were different than what we had been previously told and it felt a little to me like she was trying to correct mistakes from the previous books, so that did irk me a little, but I loved the direction she ultimately took.  I guess it didn't hit me reading the first two books just how limited their little world is.  They know NOTHING beyond the borders of their home.  They didn't even have a name for their city.  What really struck me was how they never really thought to question the borders of where they're from and if they hadn't stumbled upon Edith Prior's message, they probably never would have.This book was fast paced, exciting, sad, revelatory, and ultimately hopeful.  There's been a lot of talk about how people didn't like the way it ended, and I'll leave it to you to determine your own feelings on the matter, but I understood why Roth did what she did and ended the story how she did because, to me, it was genuine.  It was completely in character and believable.  I found myself being hopeful for their future and wishing we could revisit them in a few years to see how far they'd come.  So, Bravo!
summary: a surprising and shocking end to the series

reviewText: I can't no matter how much I want to. I wanted to throw this book at the wall and rip all th  pages out I was sobbing when I finished it. Then I went into denial that the book was bad and ended the way it did (Yes folks pretty much everyone dies Tris included) and read the book 19 times willing it to have a different ending and it never did. I just now realized that while I didn't want Tris to die and I wanted Tobias to finally be free and be able to leg go and him and Tris would be happy forever. I realized what a delusion that was. They loved each other yes and they should be together  yes but the point of the book wasn't Tris and Tobias being happy together. No it was about forgiveness, loyalty, and love. This book isn't  romance it is a futuristic set dystopian society. So while I am disappointed in the way the city was just a experiment, that Uriah dies, that Tris doesn't at least get to die with Tobias next to her an  tell him she loved him one more time, and Tobias couldn't get his last kiss, and that Marcus, Peter, and Caleb don't really redeem themselves - This is still the  best book I have ever read because it made me feel all three books changed me and maybe I don't like the way it ended but we don't always get what we want and this book couldn't have ended any other  way.
summary: I wish I could give this one star but....

reviewText: This was really hard for me to read. I always end up falling in love with the world that I am reading about. So I was on an emotional roller coaster for this whole book. I did cry at the end. Even remembering now makes me want to reread it and try not to cry again.

The first book was good, the second lousy, I only read this because my grandson is reading all and I wanted to be up with him. I can't believe the author took a perfectly good heroine, turned her into a wuss and conniving liar then into a needless martyr. Pointless.

The series as a whole was very good reading and edge of seat story... Especially the feelings between four and tris. And where it leads them in that time period. Fighting the good and bad. And the difference of people just trying to stay alive in that climate and life in the future of man kind.... It may have not been real... but one has to wonder....doesn't one....

It would have been very easy to cop out, but this book gives a realistic, tough and fitting end to the series. Not everyone will be happy with it, but the story is true to the characters, and the actions they take here aren't idealized - they are the hard choices that need to be made, and the choices made ring true, especially both the ones Tobias and Tris make. Kudos to the author for not taking the easy way out.

(Spoiler alert) As an educator and sponsor of a YA book club I really enjoyed the first two books in the series. Not only was this one disappointing, it was depressing and it seemed rushed. My students were so excited for this title to come out and l haven't talked to one who like the ending. Now maybe there is a new trend in the Joss Whedon or George Martin school of writing that encourages the killing off of main characters, but it did not seem authentic for this book. It actually felt very anti-feminist to have this strong heroine survive so much to be killed in the end, reminding me of the many other plots where the female can't handle or has to "give up" her power for the sake of the community. I have a prediction that this series ending will doom the planned movie franchise.
summary: Disappointing end to a series with a promising start.

reviewText: I was very, very disappointed in this, the third installment of the Divergent trilogy.  A story that began with such promise ended with tedium and melodrama worthy of the world's worst soap opera.As soon as I saw that this book, in contrast to the first two installments, had dual narrators (Tris and Four) it became obvious that Tris' days were numbered.  Why else but to have a means to continue the story after the death of Tris would Roth suddenly give Four a first-person voice?It's inconsistent and distracting that Four has now become a first person narrator.  Roth should have just maintained consistency and ended the story with Tris' death instead of dragging the story on via Four's morose acceptance of her death and the changes in his world.That said, what Roth really should have done is trashed this boring conclusion and started anew.I would NOT recommend this trilogy to anyone now.  Too bad.

If you are the type of person who likes a happy ending, like I am, you're not going to love this book. Also, it was not quite as interesting or action-packed as the first two; however, still a decent read.
summary: Not as good as the first two- spoiler alert

reviewText: I know there are mixed feelings about this novel.  I have mixed feelings about it.  The novel in itself is a great read, and the issue is mainly the ending.  But, let's start from the beginning.I was happy to know some answers as to what were going on.  We get plenty of answers, and it was a unique twist to dystopian fiction that I was happy about.What I didn't like, Tobias' point of view.  I felt he was whiney and way too damaged to love more than I already loved him. (This is not a pun on the word.)I also didn't like the ending, but of course, if it's how the author felt about writing it, it's her decision to make.  I won't criticize her for it.  I know it must've been a tough decision to make and honestly, if you think about it, we saw that coming.  She had been foreshadowing it through the first two books and even through the last.  It was a natural way to end it for the author, and I get it.  I'm not happy with it, but I get it.So, all in all, it was an entertaining read, not as good as the first two books, but I quite enjoyed it.

SPOILER*****************************************************************  I asked my ten year old son why he thought an author would kill the main character at the end of a series and he said, "to be fascinating," that pretty much sums it up. In an attempt to be different to be dramatic the author has "gone outside the box" and ruined a beloved book for thousands of readers. Another author defended her decision stating that a writer "owes" their fans nothing. A writer can write whatever they want whether we like it or not. This of course is true, HOWEVER, if you want people to read your book and not feel jerked around then you do owe them something. A writer needs to take care with others emotions, to take them on a ride yes, but to purposely jerk them around in order to be fascinating or dramatic is quite another thing. It's a lot harder to be original and fascinating than it is to kill someone off.  We as fans also "owe" nothing to the writer and she has seen that in people vowing to never again go on her roller coaster to only be thrown off in the end. As a writer if you truly do not care about your readers then why publish? Write your book that owes nothing to nobody and put it on a shelf to be viewed only by you in your leisure time. This writer is very young and her choices reveal that. I think she is finding her fans can be dramatic and fascinating as well.
summary: A young author trying to be dramatic

reviewText: I was so looking foreword to this book as I loved loved the first 2 & thought they were remarkable however the last book is by far one of the greatest disappointments iv ever encountered I almost felt that it was written by some one else. I feel some of the characters lost their entire personalities & went from being strong to weak willed wimpy characters. At times I was so disconnected from the story I was quite bored then just irritated that I wasted money on this. Killing of the lead character was one of the least bothersome things about this conclusion there were to many others to even mention. I feel like the author ran out of ideas on what to do with some characters strong characters with strong personalities. My suggestion would be read the first 2 but don't bother with the final in my opinion there is no satisfying conclusion to this story you might as well make up one of your own it'll be more satisfying.I Am Truly Sooooooooo disappointed

Had to wait a while before I wrote my review because the ending made me angry but overall it was a good conclusion and not your cookie cutter trilogy ending and doesn't mislead you into hoping for more
summary: Great wrap up for the trilogy

reviewText: For about seven hours after I finished this book I cried inside and then I realized that that was how it was supposed to end...

I had read the first 2 books, and then again when I knew this third was on its way.  I have seen people complaining that they didn't like the ending, but for me, the last quarter of the book is what made the difference between a great read, and a great masterpiece.The story simply had to take us where it did.  So, if you are into summer romance novels, this isn't for you.  If you want to read a MAGNIFICENT trilogy, read Divergent, Insegent AND READ ALLEGIANT.My guess is that these irst books came out fairly close to when The Hunger Games were published, and this trio got pushed to the side due to advertising hype. (not that I didn't/don't love the Hunger trilogy)Again, this book is not for those looking for happily ever after.  Happily ever after books hardly ever make the list of Great American Novels.  This book, along with the 2 preceding, SHOULD be considered among the Greats.Brava, Ms Roth.  You wrote the book the way it had to be written, and didn't cave on the ending.  Brava!
summary: WOW!  I expected a good story, and I got a great piece of literature.

reviewText: After some thought, I've decided to change my review. This ending kind of completley emotionally destroyed me, but I would still reccomend reading it. The message of bravery and sacrifice is one worth dying for, even though I don't like it. I'm giving it four stars due to editing mistakes, but I'll continue to read VR in the future, but I'll keep my eyes open so I don't get to dissapointed when she murders all my favorite characters. Lol.

The three books in this series  was hard to put down once you get started.  It took me a week  or two to read all three  but l really did enjoy them.  They were  similar to the hunger game books .I do a lot of books in series and I will recommend these to my friends. Good luck . I hope to read more of your work later later.

WHAT THE HECK VERONICA ROTH!!!! JK Rowling needs to call our dear friend VR and tell her how to write final installment.First off....Tobias was my book crush...I no longer have a crush on the Tobias that was in Alligant. Don't make this mysterious, strong hunk of a man sound like a weenier. Keep the Tobias we all new and loved going, don't make him so weak on the inside. He became uninteresting and he started to sound like Tris. Now I KNOW my boyfriend and I do not have the same thought process or ways of speaking, you'd know who was thinking what immediately. If she had not written who was speaking at the beginning of the chapters I would have no idea. There were no distinctions and I'm pretty sure that there were several distinction between tobias and tris in the first two novels.Second...THERE WAS NO NEED TO KILL OFF TRIS!!! Especially by DAVID!!!! he wasn't even a good villain!! He wasn't worthy to kill of the hero! Tris escaped everything that happened in "Chicago" AND a death serum but David is the one that manages to kill her off?? It was SO unnecessary!! Nice try at shock value VR but I no longer respect you as an author.Third...How confusing was all the GD and GP crap? I sat through half the book confused. It sounded thrown together and so not thought out. VR has shown that she is an amazing writer that can create interesting story lines but this book was hardly interesting.Fouth...So they can shut down an entire city with memory serum and death serum and have serums to create complete hallucinations but they haven't created something to CURE a COMA! Really Uriah died from a coma? In the least heroic way possible!!Fifth...The overall book seemed random, not thought out and who kills off main characters for no reason. If you have a movie deal where people are going to connect with Tris through the big screen and the novel why would you crush their hopes? We see enough death everyday in the real world that we don't need to see it from our heroes in our imagination. Viewers and readers are going to HATE the third movie. DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY!!! Borrow this book from someone or download it, but don't spend your hard earned cash on this book!
Such a great ending to this trilogy!  I absolutely could not put this book down!  It took me through wonderful adventures with Tris and Tobias with all the friends!  So GOOD!!!!!

I will not go as far as to say this is the worst book I've ever read. I will however say that it did not deliver a good ending to a great story. Beware there are spoilers!The first two books were great, I devoured them and couldn't put them down. Though the writing was easy to follow, I could also not identify when Tris and Tobias were narrating the story, I had to go back to see who it was! Now, I love the parallel narrator but I don't think it was executed properly.I hate the fact that Tris died, I saw no point to it whatsoever!! I get the sacrifice, but to be killed by bullets after surviving the serum, that's just ridiculous and pointless. She could have (and should have) fired before he did. She had done it before, she was skilled and smart, though her plan doesn't suggest it, but the rest of well executed story before this book does.I also hate how Tobias changes from this perfect strong man into a girl, literally he lost his entire identity and becomes annoying to read! I loved him strong and smart, but then it didn't make sense!!! He got lost somewhere for no reason, just like the characters were dropping dead for no good reaso... I also think he should have gone through his fear landscape one last time, as a close. He overcame all his fears! (Zip lining at the end counts!) It would have been fantastic for him to live through as a sign of acceptance and moving on.I thought at first the story was going to make sense, and for a whole it did, although it fell flat at some point. It was obvious that it was a social experiment, why ever they thought it would work is beyond me. As for why it happened in the first place: that premise is the most stupid thing I've ever read! Genetic modification doesn't work like that! "Damaged" genes will only get worse after mixing them with other damaged genes, not better. Also what is this about genetically pure people being perfect?!? I mean what?!? Did they just randomly choose to forget world history before their time of convenience or where their memories erased?? (This would actually make more sense!) I mean come on! Tris is anything but perfect and that's what was great about her.. All characters are flawed!In the end, her death was pointless. I hate that they brander her a rebel kid and that her death has no meaning and how it was all for nothing... I want to say I cried, but I was outraged at how her death came and the pointlessness of it, I was pissed, and by the end, it just felt empty... Btw: before I read or decided to read the series I already knew she died, but I wanted to see how, and was sorely disappointed. I don't mind that she died, just how and why...The final chapters that take you through Tobias's mourning, and the scattering of her ashes also felt forced, somehow. this entire flash back is just ridiculous cause it doesn't make sense! Like a situation like that would ever happen just because one of the compounds was brain washed, yeah right!I was frustrated and left feeling empty as soon as I finishes. I wish the author swould re-write this into another coherent story ending.. Tris can still die, Tobias can too, but for the right reasons and with purpose and meaning...
summary: empty end to a fantastic story

reviewText: Allegiant was a good book, and resolved the problem that the blast book left off with, however Veronica Roth made a major mistake by killing the main character of the series. The storyline is good, but once again Veronica Roth kills off way too many people. There are hardly any of the central characters left in the book by the end of the trilogy. The  central problem was resolves, but it was unnecessary to kill the main character. It was also nice to read from Tobias' point of view, however it did get confusing at times. I enjoyed reading about the group of Allegiant that ventured outside the fence. If she had not killed the main character, I probably would have given this book a four or possibly a five.

reviewText: This book was a disappointment to me compared to the first two. I didn't like how it jumped back and forth between who was telling the story. I kept getting confused. I seriously loved Loved LOVED the first two books. They were so good I could not put them down. After Insurgent's cliff hanger I really wanted to know WHAT COMES NEXT???? Man was I disappointed.I looked at the rating of this book before I read it and compared to the other two the ratings for Allegiant were not so good. I ignored what people said about it being awful. I should have listened.I honestly believe anyone who gave this book more than 2 stars did so out of respect for the first two books. Allegiant is where Roth's storyline and good writing came to die. This book frustrates me so much that I almost wish I would never have started reading the series. (honestly the only read I did was because my husband who never reads, read Divergent in one day and could not stop talking about how good it was. and with the wonderful technology of kindles I decided to read along with him and surpassed him..... I wish I wouldn't have because it would have saved me a lot of time and disappointment).The first part that truly frustrated me about this book was that she wrote it in BOTH Tris' perspective and Tobias' perspective I think if that was something she was going to do it should have been like that from the start. She also never changed writing styles at all and I kept getting confused on who's head I was in and would have to continuously re-read chapters. I have read plenty of books with dual (or more) perspectives and never had this much trouble keep person to person straight.******SPOILER ALERT***************SPOILER ALERT*********Then when it comes to the actual events of the book.Most of the situations that Tris was presented with were redundant. It appears the only change was you were able to read Tobias' point of view during this time also. I mean how many times can Tris and Tobias argue about trust..... apparently too many.How many times can Tris tell Tobias that a person is lying to him and he shouldn't believe them, and then he still goes against what she says....... again apparently too many. This difference this time was that Tobais' ally caused Uriah's death, which causes Tobias a lot of guilt.Tris is an annoying know it all and if people don't agree with her she gives them the cold shoulder. And then as if to prove her point she is ALWAYS right. No one can be right that often.The part that I loathed the most is that Roth killed Tris off in one of her acts of selflessness when Tris decided to go on the suicide mission that Caleb was supposed to go on in retribution for his betrayal. I understand that Roth may have wanted to make this books "realistic" but why start with killing off the main character? This was just plain stupid. This is supposed to be  Young Adult fiction, in my experience that usually means a happy ending for the main character....... NOT KILL HER OFF!And lets be honest I do read books and expect happy endings. Who in their right minds allows the "evil" characters live and not the main character?Peter gets to start over after having his memory reset.Marcus just disappears.Caleb get to live.David has no negative consequences for his actions other than having his memory reset.And then the war between the Factionless and the Allegiant just fizzles out with an agreement that Marcus no longer be a leader. How anticlimactic.The only way I will ever encourage anyone to read this series (not just book because lets be honest if you start a series you want to see how it ends) is if Roth decided to create an alternate ending where Tris lives. Otherwise as things are now I will advise against it.  This was truly a waste of my time.
Allediant is a great book but has the worst ending ever in the history of books. It is so annoying and it made me cry. :-(

reviewText: ALLEGIANT turned out to be my favorite out of all three books. I was hooked from page one, and the pace of the story in this final book was fast and action packed. DIVERGENT was a good trilogy in my opinion, but for me it definitely peaked in ALLEGIANT. (I won't write much more, because if I even mention characters I'll spoil the previous books for you.)What really made me love this book was the ending. Ah, despite the heartbreak I loved it so, so much.

I will have to say, this was fairly entertaining, but not as riveting as the first. I feel in general that the series went down hill from the first. Don't get me wrong--I was entertained. But there were some issues, too.On a positive note? We find out what's going on, big picture. I like that. Except it opens doors to bigger pictures, like what is going on internationally? In our world, everything is becoming so internationalized, I can't believe this USA is so isolated as to not effect the rest of the world.The character development in this one was not as good. What made Divergent so good was Tris and her uniquely human character. She was imperfect and that made her a great character. But this one was all roses and butterflies--cheesy love scenes and easy make ups. I suppose she may have grown as a character, but part of who she was included being impulsive, unforgiving, survivalist. I like the idea of switching perspectives, but I agree with every other review that comments the two POVs were completely indistinguishable. Often I would get confused and have to go back and check which POV I was reading because I was thinking it was a different one (I am a fast reader and skimped the title pages of the chapters a bit, I suppose). But if I have to check, then how can I tell if the characters are different. It felt more like a third person narrative from two POVs, written in first person.SPOILER--As for her dying, I guess I'm conflicted. Part of me thinks that was kind of necessary to make it not a perfect ending. Part of me thinks it's kind of crappy. I like the idea posed by one reader to have had the memory serum work on her, but that doesn't mesh with her resistance to other serums. Still, would have blended the bitter with the sweet (a little "The Vow," if you will).Overall, worth reading as part of the series. But if you stop at Divergent, that's not a bad move either.

reviewText: Tris and Four, by the end of the first two books, had already overcome so much, so I wasn't surprised there was more for them to face. For people to expect that level of writing is silly.This is the perfect book to curl up with at the end of a long day. I can't wait to see what other stories Veronica Roth comes up with. reviewText: I need to preface this review by saying I am always nervous starting the final book in a series I’ve loved, and Allegiant, by Veronica Roth, was no exception. I’ve loved this series from the first chapter of Divergent, book one. Just when I thought nothing could top Divergent, out came Insurgent, which was even better than book one. So I had high expectations for Allegiant, the third and final installment from Veronica Roth, even though I was really nervous too.I was excited when I first learned that Allegiant would be written from two points of view, those of Tris and Four. A chance to get into Four’s head! Who wouldn’t love that? But the transition to an alternating point of view for the third book was awkward for me. I didn’t find the voices of Tris and Four distinct enough. A few times I forgot whose head I was in and I had to flip back to the chapter heading to confirm. This was a problem for me throughout the book. The chapters were all generally short and didn’t give me enough time to get comfortable in any character’s head before popping into an alternating view point.Despite this problem, Allegiant had nonstop action and gut wrenching emotion. Let me repeat that. Gut. Wrenching. Emotion. The kind of emotion that tears your heart out, steps on it a few times then runs it over with a truck. As I got closer to the ending, I found myself reading slower, trying to savor the final words of this series, willing it not to end because I knew how much I’d miss this world. But the world that Veronica Roth gave us in book one is not the world we are left with in book three and in some ways that made saying goodbye easier, because the characters also had to say goodbye to the world that captivated me throughout this series.Even though I felt some of the plot lines were a bit contrived and forced, Allegiant did what the final book in a series is supposed to do; give us closure. All of the characters traveled full story arcs and completed their journeys. I’m sad to say goodbye to Tris, Four, and all their friends, but the book’s ending gave me the closure I needed.

reviewText: Like the majority of reviewers here, I was very excited to read Allegiant--what was beyond the fence?--and was subsequently very disappointed. (I won't bother to summarize the plot, as so many reviews have already done that.)First of all, it's incredibly hard to keep the two perspectives--those of Tris and Tobias--separate. They sound exactly the same, and I often had to flip back to see who was talking. That being said, they hardly resemble the characters they were in the first two books. Tris is no longer spunky and impulsive, and Tobias is no longer brave and hardened--they're just bland.Second, the author spent way too much time exploring the genetically damaged/genetically pure plotline she introduced. Besides the improbability of that plotline, it totally discredits and undermines the impact of the first two books. What were Tris and Tobias and their city even fighting for or against, if it all came down to an experiment? And how is it that no one bothered to go beyond the fence before? I would have liked to know a lot more about the political dynamics beyond the Bureau, and the war and situation in the Fringe. It felt like the Fringe was just plopped in as convenient, to move the plot along, when really it was the most interesting part of the book.In Divergent and Insurgent, the author created an interesting world that I found entertaining, even if I didn't always find the characters very well-rounded (it was no Hunger Games, which in my opinion is far superior). In Allegiant, things just went off the rails to the extent that I wouldn't recommend the trilogy to anyone. I wouldn't want them to waste all that time in what is ultimately a disappointing experience.
summary: Disappointing Ending to What Was a Promising Trilogy

reviewText: This was definitely at 3.5/5 stars (DARN YOU AMAZON FOR NOT ALLOWING HALF STARS!)I adore this trilogy. The first two books were beautifully set up. But this third book, it was just different. I will try really hard not to give spoilers in this review but that might be hard. If there are spoilers coming they shall be labeled.Let's start with things I enjoyed about this book, because there truly were quite a few. I LOVED the fact that the relationship in this book deals with the idea that relationships aren't easy. People lie, get jealous, make stupid decisions and a whole lot of other things. While the issues weren't handled in a terribly realistic manner, the fact that they were addressed at all was impressive. Also, I really enjoyed the fact that the build up that occurred in the first two books was addressed and I guess "resolved" in this last book. While I am definitely not a fan of the way it was resolved I applaud Veronica Roth for taking a chance and ending a book in what might not be the popular option. She took a risk and stuck to her guns and I can respect that.So one of the issues I had with this book was the introduction of the dual perspectives. In the first two books the story was told solely from Tris' perspective. But Allegiant was told from the perspectives of both Four and Tris. The transition between the two was hard to discern but I got used to it eventually. It was just a bit startling at the beginning of the book.The biggest problems I had with this book was the end. While I can see the reasoning behind her choice in ending the trilogy the way she did, I still wish it would have ended differently. I just...I was expecting something so totally and completely different. While this ending is better than the open-ended ending that I thought was coming I'm still not okay with it. I don't know if I am the only one who feels this way but ya. As I said above I applaud Veronica Roth for sticking to her guns and making a choice that she felt was right for the trilogy. While it might not have been a popular choice, she did it anyways. That in itself if brilliantly wonderful. I respect that. It just might take me a while to come to terms with what happened.Be brave.

reviewText: Veronica Roth is a phenomenal writer. Despite anything and everything said on the contrary, especially in regards to 'Allegiant', you just can't deny it. Or, at least, I couldn't while finishing the Divergent series, and still can't, hours later.Allegiant, the final installment of the 'Divergent' series, begins with the characters we know and love, coming to terms with the video they've just seen. Aparently the whole faction system, their whole city is part of a big experiement controlled by people outside of Amity fences, to breed a large enough Divergent population. When you put into contrast, the first and final books, the plotline has changed drastically. It's just like admiring one particular section of a painting, and then slowly backing up to see the whole picture. Roth does this in such a subtle way, that you wouldn't notice the drastic change until you really looked into both books. Her ability to do so is truly commendable.Another thing I noticed about the plot of Allegiant was 1) how smoothly the story ran, and 2) how, in every chapter, was something significant. The first is pretty self-explanatory, no parts of the book felt unnecessarily prolonged nor was any part too fast-paced. The second, however, could use some further explaining. What I meant was, that out of the fifty-six chapters that make up this book, none of them felt like fillers. A filler is a chapter that does absolutely nothing for the plot, character development and so on, and they're found in almost every book nowadays. But I didn't think Allegiant had any of those. Every chapter made sense, and felt necessary."The world beyong ours is full of roads and dark buildings and collapsing power lines."- TrisOne thing that the first book, Divergent, sort of lacked, was impressive world building. I don't think I have to stress how important it is for a YA dystopian to have good world building. We, the readers, have to know the world doesn't exist, but believe that it could exist. In Divergent, only the Dauntless compound was thoroughly explored. In Allegiant, everything from the city's history, to the Bureau outside of the city, was built so well.After Tris, Four and the gang leave the city, and are taken to the Bureau by Amar, descriptions go through the roof. Not in such a way that you're overwhelmed with description after description, but rather, that you don't have to try so hard to imagine the world you're reading about, it comes naturally. That's something I really enjoyed about this book, because ultimately, your reading experience is made so much more fun."I'm sick of doing bad things and liking it and then wondering what's wrong with me. I want it to be over. I want to start again."- PeterOh my God, the character development in this book is unbelievable! Like.. holy crap!Tris is now my favourite heroine, of all time, and that's saying a whole lot! Who thought the fragile little protagonist of Divergent would ever turn out to be such a strong and mature, leader in what, a year? And Roth's bringing this transformation to life, I thought, was just so impressive. For me, one of the key moments when I just knew Tris' had really grown up, was later on in the book, with her forgiving Four. After the fight they had, and Four's participating in Nita's plan, I thought they were done for good. I was impressed when Tris actually understood that they stay together because they make each other better people and whatnot.Also, it wasn't just Tris' character who's development was more than impressive. I felt like most characters across the board were well developed, from Christina, to Cara, to Peter, to Caleb, and most of all, Tobias. Any character who, in my opinion, needed to be fleshed out, was fleshed out and it was done effortlessly. Nearing the end of the story, after all the tragedies, the most significant of all took place; Tobias. I have no uncertainty in my saying that Four has changed so much, there's little resemblence between his character in Divergent and the finale, Allegiant. In the beginning of the book I didn't actually like how much he had changed, because he seemed too vulnerable, but it worked out perfectly at the end."'Oh, are we at the insult part of the breakup?' she says. 'Because I got in a lot of practice after what happened with Will. I have several choice things to say about her nose'"- CaraMan, did Roth's writing improve after writing 'Insurgent'! Seriously, I went through Allegiant, thinking to myself, that the writing techniques and styles were so much better this time around!My review of Insurgent made it obvious that I was disappointed with the ending. With Allegiant, despite all the controversial opinions, I still think it ended perfectly. I don't want to spoil anything, because part of my enjoyment was due to the sheer surprise, but yeah, I thought Roth made the right decision. Sure, she could have ended it another way, but it wouldn't have been as memorable. If I say anything else, I will end up letting something slip, so I'll just leave it at that.I think some people may be mis-reviewing this book, based more on how they didn't appreciate the surprise at the end. Me, on the other hand, thoroughly enjoyed it, in all it's heart-wrenching glory.
I loved it.  I think it was a little slow moving at some parts but overall very good.  The epilogue left me wanting to know more about the characters

It's too bad when a series starts off this strong to only falter. The second book was weak, this one was lame and disappointing. I wanted so much more for Four and Trice. Maybe the author was rushed? I thought with divergent songs insurgent this book would be amazing. it wasn't. I easily got bored off the book and wanted to give it up. the twist at the end w was good, but it was happening too fast. :P

This is the final book in the Divergent Series which I have loved and this book was really good too.What is outside of the fence? How will their worlds change when they find out the answer? In Allegiant we finally find out the answers to these questions and find out things were definitely not as they thought.The twists and turns are outstanding but also believable and work well into the rest of the series.I really am unsure what else to say as I don't want to giveaway anything. Some of the twists and turns left me so angry but yet also seemed so right and so believable; so in the end it felt like the right ending.The end and some big aspects of the story seemed wrapped up too quickly, or just ignored all together; but I did like the overall message of the story.This book does switch back and forth between Tobias and Tris, by chapter, at times their voices were quite similar and it was hard to remember who's chapter it was.Overall though I loved the series; though the truth about what is outside the fence definitely changes everything.Veronica did a great job wrapping up this series.

This book is a must read!! But make sure that you have read Divergent and Insurgent first!! One you finish this book you life will be changed forever! Once u finish you might want to watch and interview with Veronica Roth on MTV. It will help u understand what your feeling. Please read this book!!!

reviewText: I found the Divergent Series just a few months ago and could not believe what I'd been missing out on. I was eagerly awaiting the release of the third and final installment. I was looking forward to finally getting some answers and gaining some insight into the issues that plagued the main characters in the series. I was expecting angst and destruction, I was expecting an uphill battle that would ultimately lead to some sort of resolution. I was NOT expecting heartbreak of this kind. I understand that for good to triumph sometimes sacrifices must be made and I understand that those sacrifices sometimes may include death. However, I felt as though Tris made plenty of sacrifices throughout the series without having to literally die herself. I also understand that death happens, but in Allegiant I could not find a legitimate reason for Tris' death - other than perhaps 'shock value.'I will stick to the first two books - which I loved - and return this one and pretend it did not happen.What a sad end to what could have been an amazing series.
Wasn't the conclusion I was expecting, but I got thru the whole book in two days and really enjoyed it.

The shift of point of view between the 2 protagonists wasn't what bothered me in this final novel in the Divergent series. Rather it was the contradictory and obtuse philosophies that the characters purportedly supported.  The plot went well beyond the reader's obligation to suspend reality.  This novel just was not worth it.

This book got very confusing. I wasn't sure of some of the sequence. It didn't make a lot of sense and I hated that bad decisions were made that lead to a poor ending.  It seemed the writer got tired of the series and just ended it poorly. If you read  the other two, however, you ar committed to finish the series.

Insurgent left us with a broken Tris and with a curiosity of what lay beyond the fence. The whole base of the faction society is in question and Tris is one of the few who is willing to get to the bottom of things, no matter the cost.Honestly, I mentally prepared myself for Allegiant weeks before I read it. Everyone in the Divergent fandom pretty much heard that the ending was basically going to blow you out of the water. Then, to add to it all, there was the hype of Four also narrating. It's pretty easy to say that expectations were very high.Tris and Four each took turns narrating for us, and after reading The Transfer, I was really excited. Four's voice was completely different from Tris's in the latter. However, in Allegiant the first or second POV changes were fine, Four's voice was just as I remembered. But after the third or fourth time, their voices just started blending together. So that was a bit of a let down.The plot was.... not expected but not unexpected either. For me, some of the magic was kind of lost when Tris and Four go beyond the fence and learn the truth. At that point, it was just the work and world building from the previous two books that kept Allegiant from feeling just like every other dystopian out there. Don't get me wrong, it was different but also a bit similar. Then there's the fact that Four is a freakin' hypocrite. He and Tris promise (again) to be honest, and he goes off in the night, learns something important, and doesn't tell her when he should. Four was... frustrating.As for Tris, I loved her. She really grew. I do feel that her recovery from all of the emotional trauma suffered in Insurgent was a bit rushed. But Tris returned as a strong and more honest character in Allegiant. And I would say, finished her journey and fulfilled purpose.The ending was the most traumatic thing I have ever read. I was trying not to cry for the last sixty or so pages. I know some people were angry but that wasn't my reaction at all. I'll admit that I wish things hadn't ended the way they did. It definitely wasn't the ending I wanted. But Miss Roth handled it all very well if you ask me. Now that its been a few weeks since I finished, I see the symbolism behind this traumatic event. It brought this character full circle. Literally.All in all, it was a great book but it wasn't the ending I wanted. All things considered, Miss Roth tied everything up pretty nicely. I commend her for daring to write the ending she wanted and saw instead of the ending readers would have dictated.
summary: Look for the symbolism in the ending. I commend Miss Roth.

This one was hot off the press when I snapped it up, eager to read the rest of Tris Prior's story begun in Veronica Roth's first two books, Divergent and Insurgent.  Wow!Roth finished what she started and finished it well.  Taking up Tris' tale and adding in a new perspective from Tobias, she continued to supply plenty of perfectly paced action, soul-searching dilemmas, and her hallmark plot twists.  Though like life the story doesn't always go where the reader would like it to go, the plot line stays unforgivingly true to the characters and their next logical steps.  Kudos to Roth for not shying away from some tough moments.Once again, I'm impressed by the author's clean prose, which gets some pretty hefty themes across in simple, beautiful language.  The story has absolutely no wasted moments, and yet it feels complete at the end.  The characters are painted in realistic strokes, never heavy-handed, but utterly real.  Although the setting is alien to us, Roth manages to give the gist without time-wasting explanations.I will be recommending this book and its two precedents enthusiastically to all, especially young adults.  Fantastic!

reviewText: Not at all what I expected after reading the first two books, but after I was able to put myself back together and really look at this book, I see one amazing author. She wrote this book in a way that the story needed to be written, and not in a way the readers wanted...with a tidy little bow with rainbows at the end. Their lives were brutal in a lot of ways, and that's not something they can be switched off, nor did they know any other way. We loved the characters of these books for their strength and resolve in doing the right thing for everyone...no matter what. We knew there would be heartbreak in this book, since there's heartbreak in every war, but maybe weren't prepared for this one. But there is no question I'd read this book again and again, and change nothing....although maybe more Kleenex available.

I was really looking forward to this book, I pre-ordered it all the way back in May, but it was really not on par with the other two.  Like other reviewers have said, the dual POV was poorly done.  I couldn't tell which character was speaking and about halfway through I decided I didn't care anymore.  The revelation about what the divergent actually are was kind of a let down.  The factions being a form of behavior modification was not explained well and didn't make sense to me.  It was a weak explanation of how the world of factions that existed in the first two books could come to be.  And most of all I don't think killing Tris was necessary or a good idea.  I think the situation in reverse would have been better.  The plan being for Tris to go in and set off the memory serum becuase she had a chance of survival and then at the last minute Caleb stepping in and sacrificing himself.  We already knew Tris would sacrifice herself for others, she did it several times in the previous books.  It also might have shown that the GDs weren't so damaged after all.The book was bad enough and the ending shocking enough that I actually wondered if the author did it on purpose.  A lot of people are saying that they won't go watch the movie now, and I'm wondering if that was the point.

As I write this review, I'm still in shock. Not because Allegiant was horrible, but quite the opposite--it was good, it was realistic, it was unexpected, and oh my goodness, it was emotional. I'm still reeling from the ending. Just my saying that might have some of you guessing at what the ending could be, but you'll probably still be surprised (well, unless you already read a spoiler somewhere, of course). I was entirely shocked--I'm not sure I've ever encountered a YA novel that ended quite like Allegiant did. Does it sound arrogant to say I'm proud of Veronica Roth for writing it the way she did? I hope not, because I truly mean it as a compliment. So many authors either avoid reality or plunge too far into it, turning it so tasteless that it's like trying to swallow bitter ash. But Allegiant walks a fine line of bringing those moments that make us giddy and happy, and then reminding us of the seriousness of being a real person in real life.Dang, I loved this book.I wasn't sure at first. Insurgent was good, but not as amazing as Divergent, and of course Allegiant started off in yet another different way, so I had no idea how it would go. Whereas Divergent was almost insta-love, Allegiant was more like falling in love with a best friend who just sort of crept up on you...unexpectedly in some ways, but yet, not so unexpected.I suppose I should actually mention the plot, beyond all these vague hints. I don't want to give too much away, and I think the summary covers the plot just fine, so what I'll do is I'll talk about the questions that are addressed in this book. If you want to know absolutely nothing about the plot and what is answered, stop reading here!So...for the rest of you. Yes, Tris and Tobias finally learn what's outside of their city. They learn where they are, what's been going on in the outside world, and how their faction system originally got set up. We also see what happens to the city they're from, so it's not like the city's totally been left behind. Tris and Tobias have to again make decisions about their values and morals, and they are wonderfully true to character. And I don't mean they keep making the same decisions no matter what, I mean that they change, grow, and make decisions based on both old values and new realizations. Just like any person does. We also get a little bit of an epilogue, which is nice. I'm glad the book didn't just end--I hate when stories do that. Especially considering this ending...yes, it is extremely sad. It will probably have you in tears. You may hate Veronica Roth for a while. But...the fact that the book makes you care so much about the end? I think that's the mark of a good writer.If someone's looking for critiques, the best I can give you is that Tobias has changed from who he was in Divergent, and some fans may not like that, who knows. He's a little less mysterious since the POV switches between him and Tris, and some people might not love seeing more of his tortured soul. Also, some of the science/ scientific ideals seem a little unbelievable to me, but I suppose you have to sort of take that in stride when you're reading a dystopian.But all that aside, it was the writing style, message, and characters that mattered more to me, and I loved all those. So a definite five stars for Allegiant, and I can't wait to see what Veronica Roth comes up with next!
summary: Refreshingly different ending to a popular YA trilogy

reviewText: There are no actually stated spoilers in this review, yet they can be inferred.I devoured the first two books in this series when they were released by Harper Collins 18 months ago. They are both wordy and overlong, but I loved them anyway. They were amateur, but that's okay. I enjoy plenty of "amateur" books. You know the ones, the ones where the author is untried, hasn't quite found her groove, isn't quite sure how to get her point across.One of the things I loved the most was that the typical formula in YA dystopian books was that the heroine is depressed in the third book and it's painful to get through. Why is that good? Because Insurgent was that book for the Divergent Trilogy. Tris was a wreck in that story. She made foolish decisions, put herself in danger, teased death at every turn. It was depression, hopelessness, recklessness. It was painful, but I was hopeful because if we saw that behaviour in book 2, then book 3 was something to be excited about. There would be growth.Then I was even more excited when I saw that this story was categorized as Teen Romance. So, not only would we see Tris' emotional growth, but there would be relationship growth for Tris and Tobias. After all, romances have "rules". They may be unwritten, but they are understood. And people who read romances are ticked if those rules aren't followed.I read the first 12 chapters of Allegiant before I pottered off to bed. I was enjoying it. Getting inside Four's head was a lovely surprise and it seemed that he and Tris were going to figure things out. Before I had a chance to come back to the book I started hearing about negative reviews for the book. One or two and I don't think much of them. But that number was rapidly rising as my morning continued forward. While at the grocery store I stopped before the wall of hardcovers and couldn't stop myself from nabbing one off the shelf. I thumbed to the epilogue, skimmed enough to tell me what was going on, put the book back on the shelf, and then my emotions warred  between anger and hurt.Miss Roth broke one of the cardinal rules of romances. And she broke my trust. I don't care about realism. Life is emotional and sucks as it is. A story can be written where it's realistic in some areas, yet still allows us to hope in others. Quite frankly, life isn't worth it without there being hope. Can hope be argued in this story? Sure. Was the final scene poignant? Yes. I GET it. But that doesn't make it enjoyable. When I read a single book that drags my emotions through the mud, I want a payoff at the end. Something to make it all "worth it". Well, that goes triple when I'm dragged through a trilogy. As a reader, you're waiting for that moment. That payoff. Those words that leap off the page as if the author is saying, "See? You just had to trust me. I made you sad and hurt and ache before, but it's all worth it! See? See!"Yeah. This book? Not worth it and makes me feel as if I wasted my time rereading Divergent and Insurgent this last week. Wasted my time being excited for MONTHS for Allegiant to come out. Wasted my breath when I told my family and friends about this series. And I never want to feel as if I wasted my time on a book. Do I always like the final installment in a series? No. I can name several where I wasn't thrilled with how a series ended, but Allegiant trumps them all.If you want realism, look out the window and at the world around you. I returned my Kindle copy before getting past chapter 12 and I sure as heck don't want my daughters to read this. I'm deleting the other two books. I will not be watching the film when it's released in the spring. And I will not buy or read another book by this author.
summary: If you loved the first two in this series... leave it there and imagine your own ending.

reviewText: I preordered Allegiant so I would have it on my kindle the morning of October 22. Before I started it that day, I read so many bad reviews for it. I was anxious to see how the book really is. Let me tell you: don't believe the bad reviews. Allegiant was amazing; by far the best book in the trilogy. Allegiant was perfect.

reviewText: My book arrived quickly and I enjoyed reading it. This book is different from the two before it. It was still interesting however, as it was full of twists and turns.

I liked the first book. I thought, after reading the first book, the series would be about how the factions, while a good idea at first, was not the long term solution. That the divergents were proof that people can't be crammed into a group based off one characteristic that defines your entire life. The 2nd book was predictable. I knew Evelyn was going to end up just like Jeanine from the beginning. What annoyed me the most was Evelyn and the factionless. She wanted to destroy the factions and make everyone equal but she didn't. In the end there was the factionaless and the ex-factions. Instead of 5 groups there were 2. About halfway through I guessed that it was just a government experiment and was disappointed to find out I was right in book 3. It was all to correct gene damage? Pretty much the experiments were to let people breed until there was no longer damage. Wouldn't that have happened without holing people up in a city? I wasn't upset Tris died but how she died. When Nita approached Tobias about how the Bureau finds the GDs to be expendable, I thought not again. Finding out that it was all just another simulation would have been less disappointing than the redundancy of overthrowing another group again. I could have handled the experiment part better if it wasn't just a repeat of Jeanine or if Tris and the rest decided to get revenge and burn the place down. I wont give the book less than a neutral rating because of my personal opinion

Right into the second chapter, I was extremely confused. Once I got to chapter four, I was slightly upset and even more confused than before. This last book, this supposed culmination of a trilogy, was basically a different book altogether. I honestly felt like Divergent and Insurgent were the true beginning and end to a story, and Allegiant was fan fiction the author couldn't help but throw in.We get a completely different plot that ends up overshadowing the main plot of the first two books, our Mary Sue character apparently becomes a bit too perfect for the author to handle, and a character who is clearly emotionally unstable and extremely codependent on the main character suddenly becomes the main character himself.I adore Toby. He is like that hurt puppy you want to cuddle all day long. But we just spent two books cheering on the extremely perfect Tris. I don't mean perfect as in she can do no wrong, but I do mean that in the end she always fights for the greater good and we are all fans of the greater good. And now you're giving us the boy who spends all three books still in fear of his father, and honestly never getting over the abuse he felt growing up. He latches on to this inherently strong individual who offers him love and support in a way that no one else could. He is honestly weak, as shown throughout the the book and at the end. He doesn't give us any true character development. I'm supposed to just be okay with this because he is obviously the authors favorite character considering she gives him a voice here and some side stories? Or is she just bowing to the masses of little girl Toby-lovers and giving them what they want, which no author should ever do because it's not the fans' story to write? This is why fan fiction exists, so that creative folks don't have to worry about their work being manipulated by the audience.Ranting aside, the switch between characters was often confusing due to a lack in distinct character voices for both main characters, the ending was just random in a way that did not at all flow with the rest of the books, and everyone who is a fan could do without reading Allegiant altogether. It's just not worth it. I won't say I hate it because I do appreciate that we were given some kind of closure and while the random!plot was thrown in, it was an interesting theory to postulate.
I enjoyed the story until the end. It's ashamed she let Peter and Marcus live, but killed Tris. Not good!

I bought the 3-book set after reading Divergent from the library and being 466th in line for Insurgent. I liked Insurgent pretty well although I didn't understand a lot of Tris' actions, but the 3rd book just totally lost me. It started off okay with going out of the city to see what was out there but it fell apart quickly. After getting to the compound, it's like they didn't do much of anything. Inconsistent with these Dauntless adventure-seekers. And Four aligning with Nita because he's all upset about being GD was out of character. I found the dual POV confusing sometimes but didn't mind it as much as some others did, though I agree it was hard to tell them apart a lot and I don't think Four would have acted or spoken as he did. He's too much a leader for that. So many inconsistencies ... the compound was so close but it wasn't seen from the top of the Ferris Wheel or the 99th floor of the zip line building? Lights would have been seen for sure. Natalie was able to keep her communications with the compound secret? Eurudite getting the simulation serum from the compound when a war would cause just the reaction the Bureau DIDN`T want from their government overseers? Not finding another way to keep the Bureau from resetting memories in Chicago?  The whole story line was just too contrived for me, and I HATED the ending. On one hand, it is very in keeping with Tris' character, if you look just at the situation, but the situation itself is so contrived. And I like happy endings and think these characters deserved a happy ending after going through so much. I had planned to re-read the books but don't know now if I will. Really think the book was not well done ad suggest readers skip it and read just the first book or the first and second book.

reviewText: I really enjoyed this series right up until the ending. I hated the ending. so, interesting story, great characters, lousy ending. I probably won't buy any more of her books
Tris and Tobias must overdome new challenges and face new trials in this excellent, though  bittersweet, conclusion to the series.

Sometimes a book has such a good story that the writing itself can be mediocre and it doesn't really matter. Other times, the writing is so amazing that the story can be lacking and it's still a great read. Unfortunately, this book is neither of these. The writing is awkward and reads like a CliffNote's version of a book. The plot is unbelievable, even within the context of the book, and the characters are lackluster. I was halfway through a chapter written from Tobias's point of view before I even realized it was Tobias speaking, not Tris. I would still recommend the first two books, as they fell into the "okay writing / great story and characters" category. This book, however, I would only recommend as a model of what not to do in the third book of a trilogy.
I found  the last book harder to read.  A little too wordy maybe, too much detail, something but I plugged  through and the ending moved me. Definitely unexpected.  Great series.

This book gets 4 stars (I would give it 4 1/2) instead of 5, because the ending was just too pat and neat.  You have news that could destroy a city, you have outsiders would want to destroy the city, and then you have Tris and Four and Tris's annoying brother who are trying to save the city, along with a few other friends. The first part of the book was ok - the middle dragged a little bit compared to the rest of the series, and then the end... *shakes head*Don't get me wrong... I love this series.  I waited until I had all three books to read them.  I just feel that the ending of Allegiant was a let down. It was sad for the right reasons, but the resolution to the main problems that Tris and Four battled since the end of Divergent was just "fixed" too easily.I loved the world IN the book Divergent, and I would love to read more about that... perhaps that author will release more books, such as a prequel where we get to see Tris's parents as teens making their choice, or even further back when the city was first "created" as it is.

reviewText: What a bummer ending. Slow and boring. There was no creative element to the writing. Just bland dialog and basic descriptions.

In a way those words may be a bit to strong, but I've been crying , for about an hour. Veronica did a wonderful job finishing this series, it had a real ending, not some stupid clique happy ending. I'm not saying it was sad, it was just real.  When you become dedicated to a fandom (eternal,obsessive love for something, usually book series) you feel like they're real people not just characters made up.
