****SPOILERS CONTAINED IN THIS REVIEW****WOW - not sure this is a good time to review this having literally only just finished reading it. I now have to try and review this without giving away too many spoilers re the ending.I decided not to read Insurgent after I'd finished Divergent (I did start this series late so both books were already out when I started) as I wanted to be able to read the second and third books straight after each other - and I am so glad that I did.Allegiant starts pretty much straight after Insurgent finishes and find that Tris is still branded a traitor and being kept apart from everyone along with Christina. Eventually a small group of rebels begins to form in response to the factionless regime implemented by Evelyn. Some of these then decide to leave the city and see what lies outside the city boundaries - including Tris, Four, Uriah, Cara & Caleb (saving him from being executed). There they finally find out the history of the world and what led them to be in Chicago to begin with.Although at first it seems like the 'Bureau' are the good guys it soon emerges that they aren't any better than Jeannine Matthews or the factionless. Of course things eventually come to a head where big decisions have to be made which will affect not only their own lives but the lives of everyone.The ending of the book took me completely by surprise and seems to fly in the face of convention with series of this genre. This was an extremely brave choice made by Veronica Roth and, I would hazard a guess, not an easy one to make. Knowing that there would be a lot fans of the series who would, for want of a better word, be outraged by her decision. I'm not one them. I thought the ending was fitting with the character of Tris and the culmination of the journey that she had been on from the start of the series. It was completely in character for her to do what she did - I could see her decision coming after a conversation she had with Caleb. Finally she was able to do the right thing for the right reason which showed incredible growth on her part.I also loved the switch in point of views from Tris to Four giving the story a whole new dimension and from this we were able to see his growth as a person too. In fact, in this book we kind of see a switch in the characters with Four acting out like Tris did in Insurgent.This was an amazing finish to a great series and I cannot wait to see how the film version compares. I know there are a lot of people who won't the like ending and say that this spoiled the series for them. For me personally, I do not feel that way and think that Veronica hit a home run with this one.

This is the third and final book in the trilogy. You need to have read the first 2 books to understand what is going on in this one.This book was, to be honest, the hardest book of the trilogy for me to read. There's several reasons why.1 - This book is told from dual POV's, jumping between Tris and Tobias. It took me quite a while to get my head round this as I had to constantly remind myself which character I was reading about. It was, at times, very confusing.2 - Once the characters leave their home and venture outside the fence we are bombarded with a lot of information about what's actually going on. There's a lot we find out which I had to really concentrate on in order to follow.3 - The ending. I went into this knowing that the ending was something which a lot of readers didn't like. So I was anticipating it all the way through. Usually I read a book without checking reviews as I want to go into it with a fresh mind and perspective. But because this is such a well known series I couldn't avoid reviews. It did kind of spoil it for me a bit.The lives of Tris, Tobias, and their friends have yet again been turned upside down by a revelation at the end of book 2. This leads them to decide on a course of action which will take them away from the lives they know, and into the unknown.Along the way there are characters whose lives are lost, some more emotionally charged than others. But all necessary to the story in some way.Tris and Tobias soon discover that their whole lives have been a lie. What everyone was led to believe isn't true, and what they discover shocks them to the core. They have to get their heads round a whole new scenario, while also trying to deal with their growing feelings for each other.Once I got my head round the 'true' story, I really enjoyed the way the author moved on. In trying to get some semblance of normality back, Tris and Tobias have to yet again work with their friends to bring about a change which, they believe, will better their lives.This book is a rollercoaster of emotions for the characters, their friends and families, as they explore their true destinies.I totally understand why a lot of readers didn't like the ending. I get it! But as I already said, everything was necessary to the story. The author obviously had an ending in mind, and in order to get to that conclusion she had to make some tough decisions regarding characters we have grown to love while reading the trilogy. Unfortunately that conclusion has to involve some bloodshed in order to get there.All in all a great ending to an amazing series, and I'm sad to see it end. But I look forward to the movie which is coming in March 2014.
The ending is so sad, but then, life is sad. Even in the sadness there is hope, and that is a good thing.

If I could give this book zero stars I would.  Not because I'm mad at the author for being 'bold and edgy' with her decision (though, really, Veronica, bold and edgy this was not).  But because she broke one of the cardinal rules of fiction writing, and did it for a very stupid reason.  What happened to Tris was completely meaningless, and then to watch Tobias struggle with the fallout left me in tears.  I rarely cry over anything anymore, but I cried at the end of this, and NOT in a good way.  Both me and my little sister waited MONTHS for this book, and though we weren't expecting happy rainbows and puppies, we did want a reason to keep rooting for Tris through all of her struggles.  Even Mockingjay had resolution!Roth's quick-grab at a 'tragic romance' ending felt heartless and empty, and if I was being brutally honest, a complete waste of my time.  It ruined the entire book for me, and I was really enjoying it (and ready to give a five star review) right up until that point.  I still love Divergent and Insurgent, and will keep them locked away for rereading until a moment when I'm less likely to want to beat my head against a wall every time I see the bookstore display.  But...needless to say, I'll never read another book by Roth, and I'm taking this one back to Barnes & Noble for a refund.  I'm okay with reading books where the above referenced event is  a completely integral part of the plot, but this just made me feel like my emotions had been jerked around for two books, and I was awaiting the awesome climax it seemed was coming, only to watch a truly dynamic romantic lead suffer at hands which cared little for anything resembling the pact made between author and reader.For shame, Veronica, for shame.  You won't be wasting my time again.

I normally try and avoid spoilers in a book, but I couldn't after reading so many terrible reviews and after hearing how much everyone was angry at Veronica Roth. This review contains spoilers, but I will try not to give away anything more than most of the other reviewers do though I can't promise anything. For those who want my opinion without spoilers all I can say is only read this if you like a story that mirrors the pointlessness of some things in eyeball life, makes you think about hard choices, and holds a lot of meaning for interactions with people in our life.I hated Tris's death as much as I hated it when will died in the first book and when Fred and Lupin and Tonks died in Harry Potter, but it was also a beautiful death. I was so afraid after reading the review that it would be meaningless and there wouldn't be time to mourn, but it had so much depth to it. What made Tris such an amazing character was her how selfless she was. If she hadn't done what she did her brother would have died anyway and nothing would have changed. Her sacrifice did make all the difference, and in the army that would be the type of sacrifice that would win a Medal of Honor. It was beautiful. And so last minute because all. The Plans they made fell through, and that happens.All the interactions were life lessons about interacting with people and comping with the reality of death. People die young. Fiction stories are meant to entertain, but a lot of times they are also meant to teach a lesson. I felt that the author's way of dealing with Tris's death was beautiful. I was crying, and I have a feeling that Roth had to be crying when she wrote it. Only the pain of killing of a character you love could have been written so well in her work.I feel that character death is a very strong device and the more the reader likes the character the stronger the catharsis is. Most author's avoid killing the main chapter, but I applaud Roth for being strong enough to kill off Tris.In regards to the comments about the science, this is a dystopian sci-fi. The science doesn't have to make any sense, and often times scientists will mislabel what a gene is responsible before figuring out later that it does something else. And as to the truth serums, sci-fi is my response. You really can't bash the science in science fiction. Nobody bashes the science behind Anne McCaffrey's books because stories like that are about the people in them, not the hard science behind them.My one and only issue with this book was I had a lot of trouble telling the difference between Tobias and Tris's voices in the story and often became confused as to which character was narrating.

This book had more problems than the ending.CONS- First, the alternating point of views were confusing. Tris and Four's voices weren't differentiated enough. On more than one occasion, I mixed them up and had to re-read.- I spent the first two books becoming truly invested in the city and the factions. I found them to be unique and fascinating. The majority of this book is spent outside of that world, which sucked some of the magic out of the book for me.- Then, we leave behind the principle problems from the first two books as well:  the factions versus the factionless and the killing/hunting of the divergent. Instead, we travel to "the real world" and get involved in totally new problems and introduce brand new characters. The old characters are biting it an alarming rate.- They ruined Four. I don't know if it was reading his point of view versus seeing him through Tris's view, but he was no longer brave and strong. He was broken and misguided.- THE ENDING!!! I don't want to spoil anything, so I will simply say the ending is needlessly depressing. In some books, they end on a note like this and it feels right. This isn't one of those times. It seems like the author just wanted to avoid a clichéd happy (well relatively) ending to be edgy. This a YA lit. It wasn't realistic in the first two books, why start now? Also, the last few chapters drag in epilogue-like quality and sadness.PROS- The relationship between Tris and Tobias feels real. They don't always agree. It isn't always magical. But they love each other, and they forgive each other their shortcomings. I believe the book says something along the lines that they choose each other every day. That's beautiful.- The idea of all the serums was interesting. Especially the memory one. A creative and thought provoking alternative to physically killing someone. Is it really merciful? All you are dies, but your body lives on and you become someone else.

reviewText: Now that I think about, I have been greedily devouring every book I see with a post-apocalyptic dystopian theme. Does that mean that I want to see our high-tech nature-poisoning civilization crumble?  Or I just want to be assured that if the worst happens we'll still have capable and honorable heroes to look up to? Tris and Tobias are all that, although it's tiring to read how Tris beats herself up over every righteous decision. In Allegiant we discover the other side of the Faction-driven world. who decided it should be like that, whose family tree roots sucked up the minerals left when the old civilization rotted and got plowed under.  One lesson between the lines is how quickly the trials and errors of the old world (meaning us) will be forgotten when our descendants are reborn in the light of a new day.  Whose self-abnegation, whose bravery, whose genius, whose truth and compassion will bloom and intertwine to make a world less vulnerable to human foibles? And whose commitment to narrow-minded principles will transform them into monsters? And who will make the ultimate sacrifice to bring the monster down? The vision of Veronica Roth is powerful, and her characters play out a compelling parable. This is the lesson: aim heart and mind at the highest goal, and don't get bogged down in the muck.  There is nothing to fear after you stare down your fear and call it false.

UPDATE:I was about halfway through the book when I wrote this initial review. I was already unhappy with it but I forced myself to continue and finish Allegiant. Without a doubt this is the most ill conceived and poorly written book that I have ever read. And I read a LOT of books.I don't ordinarily feel compelled to write reviews unless I think a book is exceptionally good or horribly bad. I was a latecomer to Divergent and absolutely LOVED the first two volumes, but I was waiting to finish the series so I could heap praise on the author and give all three books the most glowing review that I was capable of writing. So much for THAT plan.I think that Ms Roth lost interest in the story but she was under the gun to meet a deadline.  If she missed that deadline her little kingdom would begin to crumble. Praise for the first two books came so abundantly and easily that I imagine she thought she could just breeze through this third one and be done. After all, she had the MOVIE and all it's glorious MONEY to focus on. At the last minute she realized that her writing was SO bad that the fans were going to notice. She had to do something for shock value so maybe we'd forget the horrible writing - thus the ridiculous ending.Wild horses couldn't drag me to the movie - that is IF it still gets made. What a horrible disappointment this book was!  In fact I thought it was SO BAD that I had Amazon remove it from my Kindle and give me my money back. I'm sorry now that I ever started reading the trilogy. It'll be a while before I start another series - no matter who the author is.--------------------------Initial Review:I read and loved the other books and spent what seemed like forever happily anticipating the publication of this one.  I haven't finished it yet because I just can't get into it. It doesn't even seem to be written by the same author. I suppose she's using both Tris' and Four's voices to compare and contrast their thoughts and feelings - but in doing so (in my opinion) she has lost BOTH voices.  I can't tell them apart until whichever one is currently speaking mentions something that identifies who it is.  I know their names are at the beginning of each chapter but that's so forgettable when they sound identical.Plus, the plot seems to be recycling and going nowhere fast. I've never before given up in the middle of a book but I've already been SO disappointed - and judging by some of the other reviews I can't see it getting better - that this may be the one book that I give up on.

The most major difficulty I have with this story is the degree of strawman that the author has employed when characterizing scientific inquiry. She does make some allowances to have good-guy scientists, but this whole story has a set-up that reeks of the implication "because science therefore naziism" which is a false equivalence that I don't well abide. Further, trying to establish the outside world was an extremely weak reveal that took fully 30% of the book. It's almost like she didn't know what she was going to do when she reached the outside world. Going through the "genetically pure," "genetically damaged" nonsense for that length of time was hard for me to swallow because I knew she was setting it up from the start to make it easily pushed over rather than actually realistic.I decided to add one additional point here that I suffered with for three books. It would be less of a sticky point with me if the author had not proven so anti-scientific and anti-intellectual. As an author, there is some free license in word choice used to name fictional things and it is a classic technique to take the name of a real thing to convey purpose to a fictional thing that does something similar. The author does this with her ubiquitous use of the word "serum." The great problem here is that the author clearly never bothered to learn what serum is. Her usage of the term clearly means "drug" and I know it is inspired from "serum" applied as medicine used against disease. Unfortunately, serum is not a drug: serum is technically the watery part of blood. When you take blood and centrifuge it, the blood cells will aggregate on the bottom of the centrifugation vessel leaving only a clear fluid, the serum. Serum is the stuff that comes out when you burst a blister. Serum can in some cases be used as a treatment for a disease: if an animal or a person has raised an immunity to some antigen, a toxin, a protein poison or sometimes a virus, they have antibodies in their blood that can recognize this antigen. If you collect the serum containing these antibodies, you can administer it to a victim of the disease and sometimes cure them or save their lives. A particularly effective application is against snake bites. If you treat an animal like a goat with low levels of snake bite toxin, they build up a resistance to it by raising antibodies against it in their blood. When a person is bitten by a snake, you administer serum to them collected from the goat... the goat's serum antibodies then operate with the snake bite victim's own immune system to clear the snake toxin from that person's body, lessening the effect of the bite. Hopefully, anybody reading this will stop to wonder why a death spray would ever come out of a serum obtained from a living creature. Does the author simply have an aversion to the word "poison" or is she incapable of using words for what they mean? I volunteer the latter, done in attempted poetry, at the clear expense of science.

Divergent is one of my favorite series, and I was so excited to see how it would end! I was a little worried I wasn't going to love Allegiant as much as Divergent and Insurgent, though, because a lot of people seemed to be disappointed with the way Veronica Roth ended the series. I loved it, though, and Divergent continues to be one of my favorite series!Instead of having only Tris's narration like in Divergent and Insurgent, Allegiant has dual POVs from Tris's and Four's perspectives. Even though I love Four, I wasn't to keen on that decision at first - partly because I'm always iffy about changing something like that within a series, and partly because to me, the two voices just sounded a little bit too similar. After a while, though, I got used to the dual narrative and started to enjoy getting Four's perspective on things, and I saw how this set-up makes sense with the structure of the story.My favorite part of Allegiant was definitely the development of the characters - many of the characters we got to know in the first two books undergo a learning process and experience a lot of character growth in the last book of the series. The relationships develop in interesting and at least partly surprising ways, too; I especially enjoyed following the relationship between Tris and Caleb because I thought the brother/sister relationship didn't get enough spotlight in the first two books. Both Tris's and Four's development is interesting in relation to the factions and their values as well as the plot of Allegiant: there's no right or wrong, not even one bad guy, really, just lots of different and conflicting ideologies.What fell short, though, in comparison to the character development, is the worldbuilding. I was really excited to see what had happened to the rest of the world, but sadly, we don't get that much information. I feel like there was just too much stuff that the characters don't find out about until this book, making Allegiant crammed with information and conflicts that I had a hard time distinguishing and focusing on. We don't get to see one issue be explored in any depth, and I'm still not entirely sure what the rest of the world looks like, because we are always only told and not shown about what the world has come to. To me, it might have been better to break with the trilogy format and split this up into two books so that we could explore this world's issues better, even though of course I know a lot of other factors play into decisions like thatI know a lot of people were upset about the ending, but I for one loved it. I can see why people are upset - and of course I was upset too; I was bawling for the last 50 pages. It's really unconventional, but I think this ending works really well with the development of the plot and the characters.I can see where others' complaints about Allegiant are coming from because I'll admit that the ending is upsetting and the worldbuilding isn't as strong in this book as in the previous two. I still really enjoyed it, though, because the great character growth and emotions the story evoked in me made up for it. Allegiant is a solid conclusion to a thought-provoking, unique, and inspiring series!

Her "in your face" marketing with all these novelettes is sure to make her rich, yet I believe her writing suffers because of all of it. And while it's great to love your characters, I can't help but wonder if Tris' death was due to Roth falling in love with Four.Think about it. Divergent started out being about Tris and her life adjusting to her new faction, learning about being Divergent and what that means, yet somewhere along the way, Four became the main character. It was Four's parents that were at the center of all the chaos in Chicago, while Tris' parents were both killed in the first book. Four quickly became the focus of these books after Divergent and I think that is where Roth failed.Yet, I still gave this book three stars... and "OK" rating. <b>4/5 HEARTS review from [...]</b><b><u>BEWARE: Spoilery Review!</u></b>On the morning that Allegiant came out, I had a copy of it on-hold at my local Barnes and Noble, but when I woke up at 5 a.m., I just couldn't wait any longer for it, so I set off on a trek that led me to three stores (Meijer, Walmart, and Target) before I finally found it at Target, hours before B&N; would have even opened it. I was 75% of the way through the book by the time I would've been checking out at B&N.;Allegiant made my mind melt. Literally, it just broke me. The ending was so unexpected and I couldn't start or finish any other books for weeks because I was just so hungover. I am now suffering from what I like to call Allegiant-related PTSD which makes me extremely nervous about the final book in any trilogy.But ... now that it's been months since I finished the book, I can honestly say that it was a fulfilling book and one that took a lot of bold choices. The ending was extremely fitting for Tris and her character.It broke me in all kinds of way, it emotionally crippled me, and it is still one of those fictional deaths that I think of every day and my heart just sinks. She's a character I miss. Knowing that her fictional soul isn't still out there in the fictional world hurts my heart.But the book was beautifully written, extremely captivating, well-paced, and left an impression in my mind and footprints in my heart. The ending was brave, just like Tris was, just like Veronica Roth is and encourage her readers to be. I have made my peace with that ending.I gave it a four hearts rating, due only to the fact that I felt like the epilogue was extremely rushed and that there's still just a bit of me that wishes Tris didn't have to die to achieve the ending. But I devoured the book and I would still recommend the entire Divergent experience to other readers.
summary: A bold and brave ending; would still recommend the whole Divergent experience to any reader ...

Tris and Four were shocked to see the damning video left by one of Tris' ancestors. Now the city of Chicago is in chaos since Four's mother seized power. The Factionless are in charge and the former Factions are forcibly disbanded. The city is on the verge of another war. Tris is approached by the members of the secret group known as The Allegiant. The Allegiant want to maintain the factions while sending the Divergent outside as dictated by the city's founders. So now Tris, Four and few others will journey beyond the city confines to see what is on the other side. Will they find chaos and ruin or something far more troubling?What I Liked:*This one of the hardest reviews for me to write. I went into this book with great trepidation after months of avoiding it. So many people told me that didn't like this final installment, and I was wary as I know full well how it feels to disappointed by the final installment of a beloved series. Needless to say, my fears were unwarranted as I was completely blown away and stunned by the finale. Sure I can see why readers might be unhappy, but for me it was a realistic, heart wrenching, but believable ending to an amazing series. I loved it, and I can honestly say that this is a series that will remain on my favorite shelf. It is hard to put into words my feelings without spoilers, so I will keep this spoiler free.*The world building continues to be outstanding. I did have some quibbles after Insurgent, but Ms. Roth got back on track in this final book as she presented some stunning revelations regarding the factions and the world outside the city confines. I loved the surprise! Well done, Ms. Roth. Her ideas are terrific, and I liked how she brought the whole nature vs. nurture issue to a whole other level. I won't get into the details here, but let's just say she brings up a debate regarding pure genes vs. damaged genes and shows what happens when society tries to pin evil behavior on bad genes. Can one so easily separate behavior from genetics? I think not, and I loved seeing how Ms. Roth wove this debate into her story.*Tris and Four continue to grow and mature and change in unexpected ways. For the first time in the series, the reader gets Four's view point. It was interesting to peek beneath his tough guy facade and see the real Tobias underneath. He is frightened and insecure and still trying to break free of the abused child he once was. He flounders quite a bit in this final book before finding his footing, and it was hard to see the fierce Four reduced to a man struggling with his identity and his past. Tris, on the other hand, continues to grow and mature in new, positive directions. While she may be a Dauntless, she hasn't forgotten her Abnegation lifestyle, and her past leads her to make some tough choices that lead to a heart wrenching choice. I liked seeing her selfless side, especially at the end regarding Caleb. She shows maturity beyond her years, and I was most pleased with her growth.*The romance..... I struggled again with the romance in this book. I wanted to return to the breathless giddiness that I felt in Divergent. Tris and Four's blooming relationship in the first book remains the highlight of the series for me. Since that first book, the romance has gone through the all too familiar stumbling blocks. I hated seeing the dramatic downturn in this book, but in the end, I was pleased with the final outcome. It ends up strong again, but nothing like the swoon worthy romance I fell in love with. Even though I had issues with the romance, it is true to life. We all want to stay in those giddy highs we experience when falling in love and ignore the realities of building a relationship. So even though I missed the giddiness, I appreciated that Ms. Roth walked us through the growing pains.*The ending..... I won't go into spoilers here, but I personally thought the series ended realistically and satisfactory. Yes, there are several painful sacrifices and plenty of heartbreak on the way to the end. Fans cried out because they didn't get their perfect happily ever after, but you know what? That is life, we don't always get rainbows and sunshine. Ms. Roth delivers an ending that made sense as it stayed true to the characters. I don't think it could have gone any other way. Tris could never live with the guilt of asking someone else to sacrifice. I appreciated that Ms. Roth made some tough choices, and in the end, she gives us an ending with hope. I was even pleased with the Epilogue, I thought it wrapped up the book nicely. I couldn't have asked for more.*I listened to the audiobook version of this book and I was pleased with both the narrators for Tris and Four. I had no issues with the audio and would definitely recommend the audiobook, though this is a book that I feel I need to go back and read to fully absorb the information.And The Not So Much:*I wish that I had a better grip on the whole Factionless population. Early on in the series, it was indicated that they were nothing more than homeless refugees, but in reality there was so much more to the story. As much time as Ms. Roth spent on developing the Factions, she should have devoted the same amount of time to the Factionless as they ended up playing and important role in the book.*Once Tris, Four and the others venture outside the city, I was excited to learn all the secrets, but then I quickly grew bored as they were once again drawn into more of the same conflicts. It was a bit boring to have the story reduced to more of the same as it takes on genetically pure vs. genetically damaged instead of the Factions.*There is a heavy focus on Four's father, Marcus, throughout the series. He once again plays an important role in this book. I was dissatisfied that nothing is resolved with him. I wanted Four to stand up and confront him, and at the very least see him become accountable for his actions, but nothing really happens to him. I was expecting something more from this storyline after all the buildup.*I was hoping for a bit more redemption as far as Caleb was concerned. I was happy that things took a more positive turn with him, but I still wanted more.Allegiant delivers a stunning finale to an exciting, entertaining and highly original series. I felt the ending was realistic and I was left satisfied. This final chapter doesn't quite deliver the happily ever after that readers hope for, but it stays true to the characters and the story. I loved the intelligent ideas presented, and I will be pondering on this one for weeks to come. If you have yet to check out this smart series, do so. I loved it and I can say I will definitely be revisiting it.I borrowed a copy of this book. All opinions are my own and I was not compensated for this review.Rainy Day Ramblings.

reviewText: This is not going to be a typical review. I don't think I can do that without spoiling the book way too much. I have bookish friends to do that with! Still, like many other readers I devoured the book on release day. I've seen a variety of different reactions and thought I'd add mine. I won't be giving away plot points but I will certainly be talking about how it made me feel. If you don't want to know anything at all you should probably stop reading right now. Also, don't go to any blog posts about the book. Actually, you should probably just get off the internet because it is littered with major spoilers!!! :)So, day two post finishing Allegiant... and I'm still all wrapped up about it. First and foremost, I think it's amazing. Veronica Roth can sure tell a story. I admire her and the choices she made in writing the story as she did. And I think it's just... right. I can't think of any other word to use.That doesn't mean I wasn't sitting slack-jawed at parts or that my heart didn't break at others. Sure, there are things I wish didn't have to happen. But I don't wish it because they are "wrong" or ruin the story or because I think Veronica Roth "owed" me or anything like that. I wish it because they are hard and sad and I wish they weren't so true to what would likely happen. I wish everyone, everywhere got a happily ever after. I wish a broken world could easily be healed. I wish many, many, things. But as John Green writes in The Fault in our Stars, "The world is not a wish-granting factory." So, yes, things happened that shocked and upset me. But they certainly didn't ruin the book. Rather, I think they make the series stronger. And, while I may not re-read the third book over and over again, I am glad I ordered it in all it's forms.Allegiant was an emotional end to a much loved series. No matter what happened there were going to be tears. While I was not prepared for the volume of them, I do not regret or resent a single thing. Well done Ms. Roth, well done.

reviewText: I almost never give books one star ratings, but today I will. Everything about this book struck me as just so extraordinarily wrong that I couldn’t justify giving it any higher than what I did. (My rating wasn't even that affected by the ending. Though I thought the ending was crappy, it wasn't because of what transpired so much as how it was executed.)The characters? Completely flat. I hated them. I didn’t feel for a single person at any time.Tris and Four’s relationship? They are a HORRIFIC couple. While I agree more people need to put work into their relationship instead of giving up, they are such a catastrophe of a couple I was hoping they’d have the sense to leave each other.The writing was flat and wooden. Not just in the boring sense either. It was straight up irritating at times. Also, there was no distinction between Tobias's voice and Tris's. I'd constantly have to flip to the front of the chapters to see who was speaking.The plot was utterly ridiculous. Roth set up a world with factions, Choosing Day, power balances, etc., only to completely abandon it and instead make it out to be a sham. The justification for this is that the U.S. government, (which is still a thing in this book; a bit incongruous, huh?) created the propaganda of certain people being “genetically damaged”, so cities such as Tris’s were designed to rectify this. (Which doesn’t make sense, because if the government KNOWS it’s not really true and it only hurts them, why go through all this in the first place?)Overall, this book was a shoddy final installation to an otherwise entertaining trilogy. From the writing to the character dynamics to the plot, nothing about Allegiant struck me the right way, earning it a 1 out of 5.

The Short Version:Plot: 18/20Characters: 18/20Writing: 20/20Originality: 20/20Entertainment: 10/10Recommendation: 10/10Total: 96/100Review:I have been putting off this review because I know I am going to have a hard time writing it.  I loved the Divergent books.  I read all three of them within a couple of days... it really is a good thing I was done with my semester at school, or else nothing would have gotten done!  However, out of the three, this was my least favorite - and not because of the reasons that most hate the book.I don't hate the book.  I just think that there was so much that was just different about it, that it didn't make is as good as the other two.Let me put it out there before I even start: I LOVED the ending of this book.  I know most people hate it, but I did not.  I thought it was how the ended needed to be.  If it would have been a different ending, I don't think I would have liked the book as much as I did.Now, let's delve into the few issues I did have with this book.  First, the plot.  I liked where the plot went in this book.  It was very interesting.  However, what I didn't like was that suddenly we are switching chapters between Tris and Four's point of views.  While I see why it was necessary because of how the book went, I still didn't like it.  I was almost glad I was warned of that before I started reading the book or else I would have gotten really confused at the beginning.The second thing that really annoyed me about this book was Tris and Four's relationship.  I felt like after two books they should have been more trusting and just solid in their relationship, but yet again in this book there is more trust issues and problems, and I found it frustrating.  I know others didn't, but that is one thing that really annoyed me while reading.However, other than those two knit picky things, I really enjoyed this book.  Be prepared and have Kleenex on hand while reading (learned this one the hard way), but it really is how I think the ending of the series should have been.  If you started the series, read this one! I know a lot of people that have heard things about it and so they have just decided to not read it.  I totally disagree.  This book puts a whole different spin on the world Roth set up in Divergent, and I was fascinated with it.Overall: Great ending to a great series.  If you read the other two books, read this one, even if you have been advised against it!
summary: Great ending to a great series

reviewText: LISTEN, once I bought Divergent, I was thrilled. As a fan a Suzanne Collins, Divergent was recommended to me. So I read it in 4 days... and it was pure perfection. I started Insurgent, and soon realized that Roth is probably the BEST author! She keeps you guessing!Spoilers Below!SPOILERS.When I read what happened to Tris, I cried. Not your average tearing up and then wiping ypur eyes either. I sat there unable to think, to move, to act.To be honest, what happened to Tris was spoiled for me, courtesy of Instagram.When Tris headed to the Weapons Lab, i figured that thats how she would die ~ from death serum. BUT I WASNT FREAKING EXPECTING HER TO BE SHOT BY SOMEONE WHO LOVED *HER* MOTHER! But this is why I love Veronica. She probably thinks of something, but writes the opposite.I also dont understand how some people didnt enjoy the different POVs of Tris and Tobias. I honestly loved that! It was unbelievably sad when Tobias was thinking Tris was looking up at the sky just as he was, but really she was taking her mother's hand, ready to let go.OH THE TEARS.But I do recommended reading these books because, even though you will no longer have a social life, YOU'LL HAVE AN UNHEALTHY OBSESSION WITH IT :)

I was practically giddy when I picked this up. I was a fan of Veronica's before Divergent was widespread. Now, I'm just disappointed. I feel totally betrayed. While she died a hero, she deserved to live in peace as one too.I've never been so disappointed in an author in my life. reviewText: I was really looking forward to this conclusion and was somewhat disappointed or bored, I can't decide which.Positives: mildly interesting sci-fi elements, no major grammar issues.  Yay.Negatives: The character's individual voices were completely lost.  It was all bone no marrow! They just didn't exist.  There was simply one voice for two characters and it didn't reflect either of them.  Maybe there was too much pressure to end the series?

Many reviewers have already commented on the MANY weaknesses of this final installment. I will thetefore attempt to sum up my critique briefly and without spoilers.1) I loved the first 2 books, this one under delivers, and feels like it shouldn't even be part of the series. The author just abandons major story lines and has them occur off page, then throws new plot lines at us that we don't care about and in which we have not invested 2 books.2) I will willingly suspend my disbelief to fall into a new world/mythology. However, the "answers" provided in this conclusion volume were lazy and stupid. Just because you made up the world doesn't mean you can throw whatever completely implausible reasoning at your readers and have us accept it as part of the universe. For example, you could tell me that a nuclear war made the planet uninhabitable, so we had to go to space. You don't get to say, we're in space, therefore everything you know of human nature has completely changed because... ummmm... because... I say so.3) The writing was poor. I have slightly lower standards for YA writing, but we've seen great examples of the form in recent years. Even the first two books were great stories. This is not that. The author's decision to use dual first person narratives was inorganic and poorly differentiated. I couldn't tell when Tris was talking or when it was Tobias because they have the exact same voice.4) The characters behaved in uncharacteristic ways so that the author could manufacture situations that otherwise made no sense. Again, inorganic and lazy.Basically, I wish I'd never begun reading the series because the final installment is so disappointing, I feel like I wasted my time in the first two books (which I enjoyed) because now I know the last part of the story is silly and poorly done. There are other additional reasons, but I didn't want to use spoilers. However the 1 star reviews that contain spoilers do a great job of articulating those other reasons. Someone should have caught this and forced a second and possibly many more drafts. Incredibly disappointing.
Still enjoyed the characters - I was still interested to read their reactions and plans, and i would still have an emotional reaction to events. Recommended!

If you have only read the first novel, Divergent, I would encourage you to stop reading the series now before the 2nd and 3rd books ruin it for you.Intentionally vague, non character specific spoilers ahead:I am however, incredibly disappointed and saddened by the author's ruthless treatment of characters who you learn about and becoming attached to during the series. She could have done without some of the death. There is so much death in this series, some of it senseless, that it becomes cliche and worn out.I don't think the author cares about delivering what fans want. reviewText: Divergent was refreshing. I enjoyed the unique premise, the lack of a love triangle, and a female lead character that was neither a pushover nor brilliant at everything. After the slightly less satisfying Insurgent (which I expected of a middle book), I was excited to read Allegiant and bring the series to a close.Unfortunately, it is a dissatisfying ending (and not only because of the actual ending!) Part of what made Divergent so engrossing was its characters, but the personalities were sorely lacking in this book. At times it felt like they weren't even the same characters anymore, and I don't mean that in a growth kind of way. Four, in particular, is disappointing in this book. Though he has a sensitive side and questions it himself, no one could doubt that Four belonged in Dauntless during Divergent. Here, he has been replaced by a rash, self-doubting, moping boy I wanted to shake by the shoulders for most of the book. Tris seems more self-righteous teenager than justified insurgent, and most other characters are just filler.The action and intrigue weren't at the same level of Divergent or Insurgent, and answers to mysteries fall flat. I was left with an "Oh, that's it?" feeling instead of the, "Wow! I didn't see that coming!" reaction I wanted.Switching narrators throughout the book also completely changed the tone from the first two books and made the novel feel like it was rushed (even though it's almost too long). It also made it confusing to follow the story. As other reviewers have noted, Tris and Tobias have incredibly similar voices. I frequently had to go back and check whose chapter I was reading.Though I can still see myself rereading Divergent and Insurgent, I'll leave this one sitting on my bookshelf.
summary: Did this book really belong to the same series?

reviewText: The first half of the book is completely boring, but if you can manage past that, you can find the brilliance of the first two books and won't be able to stop reading!

First of all, I was putting off finishing the trilogy because of all the horrible reviews this book has received.  Having read it last night, I am glad that I finally decided to stop paying attention to the reviews and judge for myself.  I will say that the first two titles in the series are, in general, better books, but Allegiant was certainly not terrible, nor a disappointment.  I'm not going to go into plot details here, because I really think people should judge this one for themselves.  The alternating points of view from Tris and Four was a bit confusing at times because there was not enough differentiation between the tone of the two characters to always be able to tell who was speaking, but that certainly did not make the book unreadable.  To say that I enjoyed the book would be a little dishonest, as there is little enjoyable material in this part of the story, but I am glad that I read it,  and I think fans of the series will benefit from finishing it.  After all, fans of a series cannot expect all the conflict in the story to be happily resolved and neatly wrapped up at the end.  Life doesn't work that way, which is precisely what makes this story more "real" and more plausible to me than a fairy-tale ending where all the characters lived happily ever after,
summary: Give Allegiant a chance.  I'm glad I did.

reviewText: I think this book doesn't have great reviews because people acted too quickly. When I first finished it, I was shocked and very angry with the ending. But then I took some time to think about it, and realized that what Veronica Roth did was kind of perfect, in a way.So maybe the book doesn't have a happy ending. But that isn't what dystopian books are about. In dystopian books, just like real life, bad things happen and people die, and it doesn't matter who they are or how much you love them. The point is that people get up afterwords, and they keep fighting to fix things. Allegiant shows that better than any book I've ever read.Allegiant isn't a perfect book, and it doesn't end the way we want it to. But it's beautifully realistic, and that is something that's hard to find in a book. I do think that fans of Divergent should read this. It's painful, but it stays true to the world of Divergent and the personalities of the characters. And the message to be brave and carry on is there until the end. As painful as it is, I think Veronica Roth made the right choice.

This is an amazing book! Veronica Roth it's such a great author. I would recommend the whole Divergent series to anyone who likes science fiction. A great book, even made me tear up a little... but it was great!

*Spoiler Alert*I was really looking forward to this book and thought I would get done rather quickly. Nope. It was a slow progression into disaster. I am giving it 3 stars because it had a clear climax, ending and closed up a majority of the questions so the reader is not left hanging and wondering what happened to whoever, or whatever. Am I pissed, hell yeah I a pissed. What author in their right mind kills off that many main characters? I mean really! REALLY! ( I will say that Game of Thrones does an excellent job of killing of main characters meaningfully) This is not Game of Thrones. You need these people in these books. I was so excited and this fell completely short. Still well written, but there was too much jumping back and forth...Tris, Tobias, Tris, Tobias.....I was pulling my hair out trying to remember whose mind I was in and had to re-read some parts to confirm.Furthermore, I am all for inclusion in everything, including writing, but is it me or does it seem like the author tried too hard to put a gay couple in the mix. I feel like it came out of the blue and did nothing to help the story line at all. I almost feel like it was created because there is a movie coming out, and it would make a great scene for the 3rd movie ( Although this book would need a lot of work to make it a script, unlike the other 2 books) It was torture to get through this and I am glad it is over. Generally, I like to leave a series with a collective sigh, and feeling whole on the sense of the way it ended but this was not it. Hmm let me see 2 1/2 years seems like a great place to give people updates about folks, lets write about that.I truly did love the characters in this series. They were well thought out and had layers. I also enjoyed that family played a big role in the decisions that were made as well. I would like the writer to take the Truth Serum and tell us what was she was really thinking about while writing this last book because the end seemed to rush in, and the beginning seemed slow like she was not sure where to go. 3.5 Stars

But you cannot write two 400 plus page books from one characters perspective then decide to have more than one POV- it totally ruins the bond you've made with books and the flow you have come to recognize.I read the first 2 books in 3 days total and eagerly downloaded the third (this one) the moment I finished book 2- already disappointed with the authors decision to this.

reviewText: Last Week, I went to see the movie Divergent and was fascinated and enjoyed it very much.Because of this, I immediately bought the series rather than wait to see if a movie is made of the remaining two books.  Oh how I wish I has bothered to read the honest reviews first and saved myself some money because under no circumstances is this book worth the $9.99 I paid for the Kindle version.  I am only 30% of the way through Allegiant and already struggling.  I only get to read for about an hour at a time and the constant switching between Tris & Four's narrative is beginning to irritate me because I can never remember who's point of view I was reading when I put the book down and reading on a Kindle, can't just flick back a few pages to check.I am sick of all the kissing between Tris & Four and I am wondering why the author has it in the book at all - maybe this is aimed at the teenage reader because it sure isn't aimed at my age group.I hope this review is read by someone about to purchase the book because from the number of review, a lot of people have purchase it and don't believe they got value for money.Sorry Veronica but the first 30% of the final book in the series is a disappointment and doesn't inspire me to read any more of your books, which is a shame because Divergent was such a good story.,  Maybe you should have stopped after the first book, or at least taken a little more time and given more thought to the rest of the series.

I really wanted to give Roth the benefit of the doubt with this one. But after reading the book twice, it's just not good, and a really disappointing way to end what was otherwise an engaging and fun series.First, the switched perspectives are impossible to tell apart, as others have said. I thought Four would be more reserved, stoic and provide an interesting look into his and Tris's relationship, but it's really just a lot of the same with a different name. The plot twist I would have loved, if it hadn't been done so poorly. I didn't even know anything had really happened until a few chapters later, at which point I had to go back and re-read. There's a way to do shocking and interesting but it needs to be meaningful. Roth's shocking felt like it was there for the sake of shocking people, rather than for the sake of a good story.All in all, this isn't terrible but it's not on par with the series and it's not a good way to end the book. I really expected more.

So the reason so many people have their panties in a bunch is because it made them realize that life doesn't always have a happy ending and sometimes things will hurt.

I'm so glad I did finish it on my own though. I realize that most people had a problem with Tris dying and Four and Tris not getting their happy ending. But I see it differently. They did get their happiness, they acknowledged they were the forever kind of relationship that stood up to every hardship and still held immense love. They saw the things that they brought out in one another and in their last days were truly together. She died not wanting to leave him and while I definitely wanted Caleb to go, not her, I loved knowing that the love between Tris and Four was in tact and whole not fractured like I worried it was going to be.I think each reader will feel their own about this ending but I cried for the love they had and the love he had even after she was gone. That was beautiful to me. We don't always get the ending we want from a book but I don't think this book' sending deserves all the negative reviews it's getting.I gave it four out of five because of course I wanted them together in the end but ultimately I still loved the book.

reviewText: WARNING: There are slight SPOILERSThis book made me absolutely hate the fact that i get really emotionally involved in what i read.  After the climax i had to convince myself that this book was worth reading. I felt a little empty like how you feel at the end of Mockingjay, both before the epilogue. After reading the epilogue I still felt a little empty but you got the sense that everything would be okay with your characters.I read this series in 4days i think that's why i was hit so hard but the happenings. I'm not some crazed fan. Most people who gave this book 1star was just upset that the book didn't end the way they wanted it to. It left them sad and empty. The All Quite on the Western Front ending as I call it. I didn't like the ending personally it left u suspended in sadness. I cried for the rest of the book. Evelyn won. That's all i could think about. She said Tris was temporary and she was permanent. Of course you audience will root for this romance.I think authors are so focused on trying to get that wow factor that they abandon what would actually benefit the storyline of what the series is actually leading up to. This one was love. This book can actually teach about love. Losing love, gaining love, trying to hang on to it, feeling betrayed by someone you love. Love. All the way around. I can think of many other possible endings that would not have taken away from the story as much as this ending did.I didn't like the dual voice thing at all. She doesn't capture the essence of how her audience sees her characters. We are let into Tobias' head but it sound like Tris. He sounds like a 16yr old girl and i hated it.

reviewText: I won't bore people with too many of my viewpoints & dribble, I'll try to stick to the facts & avoid make spoilers known.I wasn't fond of the plot in this book.AT ALL. It was the weakest & most RIDICULOUS idea i think I've ever read... I don't know what Roth was thinking, well, obviously, she WASNT. After all of the buildup, all of the journey through Divergent & Insurgent, we get THIS with Allegiant.I'll go out on a limb here & say that the plot driving Allegiant is weak & (I don't think I'm alone here in saying this) stupid. It's almost as if Roth was too busy counting money to care about the content of Allegiant. I thought maybe I was judging harshly so I've waited a few days after reading Allegiant to post a review....And I still think it sucks.....---possible spoilers---To start, we are reunited with Tris & Tobias at the start of a factionless regime headed by Tobias mother, Evelyn. Tris is still hated/feared/admired/respected/whatever....Can I say I HATED Tris? Always have...simply because of how Roth wrote her...Tris comes from a subservient faction to a dominant one, gets a tattoo & SUDDENLY she's the most bad ass thing this side of creation? No one can take her on? Her tail is unkickable??? Sorry, I couldn't suspend my disbelief that far...I found her extremely unlikeable, her cocksure arrogant attitude turned me off completely. Tris only gets worse in Allegiant.And Tobias? Oh where did the strong & daring Tobias of past books go? He wasn't here that's for sure. This time around Tobias acted more like a proper whipped boy than a headstrong, sure headed male. I grew tired of him falling all over himself to follow Tris.Roth wrote Allegiant with different POVs, from Tris & Tobias & it got to the point that I'd have to go back to the start of the chapter to recall WHO was talking in the 1 I was reading. Tris & Tobias were both written the same, with Tobias having exactly the same tone as Tris, the tone/attitude of a 16 year old girl.BIG SPOILER!!!!!Genetic damage? THATS WHAT THIS WAS ABOUT? That was the BEST you could do? For shame....Back to the POV chapters....I understand WHY Roth needed to have corresponding POVs by the end, the ending NEEDED that. (Even though the ending was TERRIBLE) I do think that Roth could've done a much better job differentiating between Tris & Tobias in chapters though....As for the end? I do think it was terrible, but a scene at the end with Tris, the end scene, was nicely written....but other than that, I hated the book. Not enough to sink my teeth into...weak plot, weaker writing....

reviewText: I rated this book with 5 stars because it was a very strong finish to a good series.If you have not read the rest of the series, I strongly recommend that you do.What I found most compelling is that much of this work --more so than the others -- is largely allegorical for what is going on with us and our society now. reviewText: SPOILER ALERT:  But this one sucked.  I'm upset Tris died, she didn't deserve that, and I feel that's a writer's cop-out when they can't figure out what else to do. reviewText: Ladies, get your kleenex out for I promise you that you're going to need it when reading this book. I wont spoil it, but let's just say that things don't turn out as expected, as one makes a sacrifice for their loved ones and another gains a family. Tris, Four and their friends finally venture outside the city limits and learn that everything that they've thought important up to that point has been part of an experiment, and that nothing is real. Everything they once believed is turned upside down, and they once again have to fight to do the right thing, which will have an everlasting effect on their entire world and culture. Packed full of adventure, and drama this book felt more serious than the first two, because it felt like we as the readers were finally getting to the true bottom of the truth, and not all these smokescreens. In this book, the author derails from the previous format and tells the story from both Tris and Fours point of views. Once you get to the end of the book, you'll understand the importance of doing this. I listened to this book in audio format, and it took me a while to get used to the actor who was reading for Four, but got used to it about half way through. Really recommend this book for parents to read with their kids (under 14) as some of the content may be too mature. However it is suitable for tweens and older.SPOILER ALERTSo I've read a lot of the negative comments that people have written about this book, in that they felt betrayed, etc. But come on people, just because Tris dies in the end and does not have her happily ever after does not mean her sacrifice is in vain. If you even think that her brother Caleb could have pulled off a successful mission at the end and taken the bullet, then you are delusional. In reality, Tris was the only one that would have been able to do it. No one else. She did not just do it for Caleb, but did it for everyone. Although I agree that Four got a bit annoying and whiny, and I didn't really understand his motivation for feeling worthless, I could still appreciated that he was struggling dealing with the fact that everything he once believed in was a lie. I think the author did a good job of putting hints throughout the entire series, that there was more going on here than just your normal city left to survive. It was not that big of a leap to imagine that this was an experimental city. I thought this book ended the way it needed to. Not every story has a happy ending, and I never thought that this one would, but nevertheless life goes on, even for the characters.

reviewText: It was the reviews that got me and the huge drama over a key character dying. That spiked my interested like nothing else. Every one was making such a big deal about how horrible it was and so I had to read it.Initially, the only reason I wanted to read the last one was because of the movie hype. Honestly, the second book has so many plot twists and people dying, I really wasn't sure about a third book. What would be talked about?Well Roth did a good job of rounding out the series. Yes, it still felt a little tedious and slow like the second book, but this one wraps everything up. It leaves no questions unanswered, and Insurgent really makes sense now with Allegiant read. Her physiological and gene emphasis definitely makes her series unique in dystopian fiction. What makes it even more amazing is that these are her first books! I am officially jealous.Anyway back to the subject at hand, most importantly the death that had people wailing. Most people will have you believe that it was senseless. It is not. In fact, I must say the best part of the book was the end and the death. The death represents so much--the character's original faction and her adopted one; her journey; forgiveness; victory over fear; and I could go on. Her death is really beautiful and that is why I gave the book a four because the ending was so gut wrenching, but heartwarming. After that moment, events and characters really come full circle. Roth brings you back to the first book and even though that character is gone you can still feel their presence. Sacrifice. Bravery. Love. Hope. That is what this book leaves you with. Then I remembered why I fell in love with the first book so much.

“I fell in love with him. But I don’t just stay with him by default as if there’s no one else available to me. I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other, I choose him over and over again... and he chooses me.”That sweet little piece from Allegiant is probably the only thing I found to my liking when I read this book. I’ve been procrastinating about writing a review for this because I thought maybe I’d change my mind about how I feel. Meh! It only made me more disappointed than I already was.I have been tense throughout reading this. Aside from the constant angry comments and text messages I’ve been receiving from Maria @ Reading is the Ultimate Aphrodisiac (we were buddy reading), there was this gut feeling that all of this was going to end bad.I like Tris here, she’s the brave girl I once saw in Divergent and not the annoying b*tch she has become in Insurgent. I love the moments with Tobias; his sweetness and selflessness, and all the gushy moments with Tris. Too bad I couldn’t find it in me to savour them. He suddenly turns into someone I don’t even recognize. He used to be a consistent character during the previous books and then I see him with so much negativity. This is not the Four I used to know. Is this a plot to make Tris a more endearing character that would make her sacrifice a lot more dramatic and justified? It didn’t work, just so you know.It took me quite a while to absorb everything. At first, I felt so detached from the story. I don’t know if maybe I’m looking at Allegiant with fresh eyes or lost ones. I had issues with almost every decision the characters made. I should mention, by the way, that I really had problems with the amount of characters in this book – it’s a struggle to keep up.In the end, to be honest, I just felt cheated. I read Divergent with such optimism, and when I finished Insurgent, even though I didn’t find it as grand as Divergent, I felt there was something rather deep going on with this trilogy. Allegiant just made me realize that reading Insurgent was a complete waste of time. It felt pointless. And Allegiant itself was shallow and overrated.It was a truly tragic ending. It was sad and heartbreaking. I expected to be pissed but I’m not as angry as I thought I would be. But it did leave me questioning; was it a necessary kind of sacrifice to make? Tris has proven herself enough as a selfless brave heroine, her fate just turned out to be a travesty other than being an embodiment of virtue and morality. Mostly it felt strained.

reviewText: The first part of this review will be spoiler-free, as best as I can make it.I read both Divergent and Insurgent, and while I was not impressed, they weren't bad and I was interested enough to see the series through. I was mostly interested in seeing the whys and hows of the world.Unfortunately, it was very disappointing in execution.The book opens almost immediately after the end of Insurgent. The dual narrative of Tris and Tobias was, simply, not pulled off. The voices of both characters sounded exactly alike--multiple times throughout the book, I would think I was reading from Tris's POV, and then suddenly realize that it was actually Tobias. It made for a very distracting reading experience. And what happened to Tobias himself? He was a strong character in the first two books, but in Allegiant he has suddenly become whiny and easily upset. Tris also seems to be right about almost everything, which was grating.The romance between those two was....awkward? There were several major kissing scenes, and while they never really got fresh, they happened too frequently and I got really tired of constantly reading how Tobias smelled like wind.As for the world reveal, that was where I had my biggest problems with the book. Apparently it is very easy to leave and enter Chicago, despite what we've learned from the previous two books, and the characters come back and forth pretty often. If it was so easy, why did no one try it before? It didn't quite make sense.When the characters leave Chicago, and come to a place called the Bureau, this is where they learn about the world. It all comes in an info-dump. We get paragraphs of how and why Chicago was sectioned off and the factions were created. It wasn't very plausible; the reasoning behind the factions felt sketchy and a little hard to believe. The characters were also well-received at the Bureau, which I thought felt strange. These people just show up, wanting to know more about their world, and they are taken in and treated well and given answers to their questions....I didn't like it. It was too easy. I don't want to spoil anything, but it's hard to clearly describe what went wrong without doing so.The resolution to the war between the factions was very, very anti-climatic, and very, very disappointing. It was far too easy, like Roth wanted to wrap it up quickly. The use of the serums has become a deus ex machina: they seem like easy cop-outs, at least in this book. And the concept of sacrifice and other themes was presented a little too preachily.........which leads me to the ill-received ending. My problem with the ending wasn't with the result itself, but the circumstances leading to and after it. Roth had had this planned from the beginning, and it almost felt like she was forcing the story to fit this plan. The characters get sloppy with their planning--coming up with a suicide mission when they obviously could have done better. There was no true reason for the ending, the way it was written. There was no true purpose. That was what I didn't like about it.In the end, I think Allegiant was the weakest of the three. It definitely felt its 500+ pages, and not in a good way. I didn't actually hate it, but it definitely fell short of what I was hoping it could be.And now, big spoilers will follow so I can explain in clearer detail on the ending and the world reveal.*****************SPOILERS*********If the main character is going to die, there preferably should be a reason, no other options available. With Tris, there were other options that could have been taken. As it happened, she survives death serum, only to be shot. Though she died, it would have made no difference to the story if she had lived. She didn't have to die. There was no reason for her to, the way it was presented. If the death serum had killed her, that would have been better. Or if they absolutely had NO other plan, and something would become of the death. But they could have done better, and nothing ever came from the death. It felt forced, like Roth wanted to make a point about sacrifice. It just didn't work.And the world reveal....I didn't buy the whole genetics scenario. Centuries ago, the government decided that they would remove genes that caused "bad" behavior (like selfishness, lying, etc, all of the things the factions stood against). Well, the removal of those genes turned out to make another bad trait stand out, and so the altered people, the "genetically damaged," and the unaltered people, the "genetically pure," got into a war. To resolve it, the government put all of the "genetically damaged" people into controlled places (like the factions in Chicago) to allow them to eventually "breed out," so to speak, the "damaged" genes and become "pure" again. The genetically "pure" people are the Divergents. I found this setup to be very hard to believe.
No spoilers, but really? Great series that literally ends with a bang. I'll be curious to see how each of the three films ends up.

The final book in the Divergent Trilogy left a lot to be desired... That being said, the book wasn't necessarily bad and I feel that most fans of the series will ultimately be at least satisfied with the trilogy's ending. (In other words, it could have been a lot worse.) There's not much I can say about the story without giving too much away; the action and intrigue that comprised the first two books is still present in Allegiant. Also present is the ensuing romance between Tris and Tobias. Despite having the core elements that made up the first two books, there were a few things that I took issue with in Allegiant...For one, this book is told from the perspectives of both Tris AND Tobias. I was initially very excited about this aspect of the book. However, I just feel that this idea was better in theory. The dual perspective was not executed very well. There was no real distinction between the voices of Tris and Tobias. If you were to open to a random page and read it you would not be able to distinguish who was speaking (except for use of pronouns, names, etc.). I feel that Roth should have spent more time developing a clear voice for Tobias instead of using the same writing style she's used for Tris's voice.I was also a little disappointed about what was "beyond the fence." Don't get me wrong, it was interesting and thought-provoking, but... I just expected more! I feel like the explanation for the secrets behind Tris's world were just very bland (for lack of a better word). The previous two books were just so mind-blowing that I expected the same sort of pizzaz from Allegiant, but it just wasn't there.Despite these errors, Allegiant really is a decent ending to the trilogy. Even though it doesn't necessarily end the way you want it to. However, its flaws keep it from entering the realm of 5-star books like its predecessors, Divergent and Insurgent.

Tris went through the whole 3 books, struggling with her identity and how to balance her selflessness with her bravery. With her experiences she realized that selflessness isn't dieing for no reason which she attempted a couple of times. It's succeeding in an act for someone you love and not caring about how it may result for you. She showed her selflessness by taking her brothers place in his suicide mission. She then also showed her strength and bravery by dieing  for what she believed in and facing it head on! It may not have been the ending you wanted, but ultimately it was  the most honest and genuine ending that Roth could have written. It sums up Beatris' struggles and it showed how she overcame all of her obstacles and attained her goal. To end my statement; The Divergent Series has a beautiful ending and I highly recommend this book to anyone who wants to be moved.

I did find the switching POV very distracting and confusing.  I did have to flip back to figure out who was speaking.  Not good.  But I'm selfish.  Because they sounded so alike in thought...I feel as if she didn't die.  Because her voice was still there to the very end.So I am giving it 5 stars.  It should be read, reviewed and remembered.

reviewText: It was good until the ending. Sadly the author screwed up big time! All this time I had been in awe of the character Triss.
