Allegiant, you were the biggest disappointment of the year for me. Here I was looking for an epic battle between the Allegiant and the Erudite but instead, what I got was a complete and utter mess. It's taken me days to form some coherent thoughts on the book so here goes...WARNING: MAJOR SPOILERS AHEADThe problems I had with AllegiantMY WHOLE LIFE IS A LIENow I don't have any problems with going out of the box, and Allegiant was a true mind numbing experience. Instead of giving us the epic, final battle we were looking for, Veronica Roth chose to defer from the whole thing and explain the true reasoning behind the factions. This is how it went...The Bureau of Genetic Warfare: You were all an experiment, and your whole life and everything you know is a lie.Tris and co.: ...Oh okay then.Wouldn't you think that if this happened to you and your friends, there would be denial, breakdowns, refusals and drama? These guys were just stunned, accepting mullets.WHAT MAKES YOU SO PERFECTThe biggest shock to Tris and Co. appear to be some strange form of prejudice, where the Bureau has manufactured the Chicago experiment to box people away into their neat little pigeon holes so they can modify their behaviour based on their genetically damaged (GD) genes. Yes, these are the factions that we know.The reasoning behind this is to absolve the flawed behaviour of these genetically damaged people after the government has unsuccessfully messed around with people's genes resulting in The Purity War, which I'll talk more about below.I don't know about you, but calling someone genetically damaged does not sit right with me. Everyone has flaws and you learn to live together and love one another. If you thought the prejudice of the factions were bad, imagine the disdain that would come from someone's genetic makeup. I can't ever imagine people giving consent to messing with people's genes on a mass scale...Every faction loses something when it gains a virtue: the Dauntless, brave but cruel; the Erudite, intelligent but vain, the Amity, peaceful but passive; the Candor, honest but inconsiderate; the Abnegation, selfless but stifling.FLAWED REASONINGThe Bureau pretty much manufactured the experiments after The Purity War, where those with damaged genes after extensive genetic manipulation had waged a war on the government and those with pure genes. Their primary goal is to ultimately heal people's genes to become the Divergent, recovering from the ultimate fatal flaws of the GD. If this is the case, why did they not equip the Chicago experiment with this knowledge and filter all of the Divergent out of the city, once identified? Why were the Divergent placed under threat from the faction leaders? It makes no sense.LET'S JUST HIT RESETThose Bureau guys just won't learn. It appears that the uprising in Chicago has happened once before in the outer edges of the factionless places. So they administered the memory serum to make everyone forget it ever happened and start over. While it's happening again, and what's their solution? The memory serum again. Just so they can watch their sick reality TV show all over again.Not to mention Tris's plan to wipe the memories of The Bureau, thereby making everything obsolete and pointless. The experiments, the GD war, the serums, everything. Let's stop them from wiping away the memories of our loved ones by wiping away their memories, that will teach them! Last I heard, two wrongs don't make a right.GOODBYE SEXY BROODY FOUR, HELLO MR WHINYWhen Allegiant was announced, we were excited to get inside the mind of the mysterious Four and find out what goes on in his head. What it turns out to be is a constant whining, insecurity, mommy and daddy issues, and a whole lot of angsty emotion. Four in Divergent/Insurgent, was a hunky, confident, mysterious instructor. Four in Allegiant is an annoying, whingy puddly mess. Not only that, but in Allegiant he seems to make all the wrong decisions and not trust Tris repeatedly, even though she was right. Roth must have had a vendetta against him, making his decisions result in Uriah's death, taking away Tris, making him one of the GD.As the book switched perspectives between Tris and Four, it was difficult to pick out who it was throughout the book. The two just sounded so damn similar and their voice was exactly the same.SIDE CHARACTERS - WHO WERE THEY AGAIN?Christina, Uriah, Caleb, Cara and co. were all in this book but the fact of the matter is - you could have taken them away and come up with exactly the same outcome. The only one that seemed to make any impact was Nita, the new rebel girl who has her own illogical ideas. But the whole flirting with disaster thing with Four? Didn't sit well with me. And Caleb of course, who was a sniveling mess of a man living in the shadow of what he did to Tris in the past. There's a man who for his whole early life, urged Tris to be selfless. There's a man who couldn't be selfless himself, when it came down to it.HERE'S AN IDEA - LET'S COMMUNICATE!At the end of the book, there's 4 different plans that went on to stop the overthrowing of the Chicago experiment, that would result in the death of thousands and dare I say - the genetically pure/Divergent. The Bureau would release a mass memory serum and wipe out the memories of the entire city. One group will go in to inoculate their loved ones from the mass memory wipe. The other group will go in, take the death serum and release the memory serum on The Bureau. And Four decides to go against all of this and administer the memory serum to either Evelyn or Marcus to end this thing once and for all. At any one point, they could have told each other what was going on. But nope, never happened. Which is frustrating, seeing as Four's plan could have saved them all.FINALLY...THE DEATH WAS ONLY FOR SYMBOLISM'S SAKEI'm not so cut that Tris died in the first place, after all that is who Tris is, brave and selfless and always putting her loved ones ahead of herself, even if it was for snivelling Caleb who deserves death himself. Tris, in this novel could do no wrong. She was always right, she was selfless, she was genetically pure, she loved and finally sacrificed herself for the good of everyone. That's great, because we love Tris and her journey over the past 3 books have showed her that she's her own person.But my biggest problem was how the author administered the final blow, and then the way she justified it to everyone in her explanatory blog post. Let's have Tris survive a death serum (how is that even possible), have a false sense of survival and then have someone come in a shoot her! That is just cruel. Tris has survived death so many times and she went in because she knew she had a sliver of a chance in surviving. Roth considered having her survive, but didn't, just because she deserved it and that was what she chose:This was the end she had chosen, and I felt she had earned an ending that was as powerful as she was. - RothSymbolism's sake, the ending could have just been powerful in the wake of Tris surviving, but instead it is causing an Erudite/Factionless outrage.OVERALL THOUGHTSI found Allegiant to be disappointing for a myriad of reasons, it was illogical, rendered a book boyfriend completely useless and ripped away what could have been a satisfying ending to an awesome trilogy into something that completely ruined my affinity for the whole series. Veronica Roth took risks, she's Dauntless and gave us something that we couldn't have imagined and that, I do respect. Unfortunately, the end result turned out to be an incoherent mess filled with illogical sequences and a crappy ending.Now does anyone know where I can get myself some memory serum?I received a review copy from Harper Collins Australia in exchange for an honest review. reviewText: First off, let's just say that I wanted to read this book for two reasons: I THOROUGHLY enjoyed DIVERGENT and INSURGENT, and where INSURGENT leaves off, I HAD to know what happened next. 2nd: I saw all the one star reviews, many of which contain MAJOR spoilers, and I HAD to see why people hated it so much.This trilogy has the action and intrigue you would expect from the best of Matthew Reilly or Jeremy Robinson - and the last 10% of ALLEGIANT had me crying more than even the best Nich Sparks books - and I'm a 31yo tough Southern Man.The ending played out almost exactly the way it had to. I'm not going to give anything away, unlike those "most helpful" reviews, but there really were no surprises in the endgame. The mystery of what had happened outside the fence contained quite a bit of commentary on human nature itself, which as someone with "genetic deficiencies", including Autism Spectrum Condition, it was incredibly interesting to me. I HOPE they can convey all of this in the movie, though I doubt they will be able to.I LOVED this book, but let's face it - 1) don't read the last book in a trilogy without reading books 1 and 2 first and 2) if you've read the first two books in a trilogy, you're going to finish it out, regardless of what all those "most helpful" 1 star reviews say...

I knew this would be an exciting and thrilling conclusion but I ended the book feeling cheated.  Really cheated!!  A lot of people have compared this to the Hunger Games trilogy.  Don't go there, the Hunger Games was well written from beginning to end.  The Divergent series ended with a meh....If you've read the first two, go ahead and read the third one and get it over with.  However, if you're just getting started, stop after Insurgent and move on to another book.Sorry Veronica Roth, perhaps you can rewrite this book?

I was so excited for the ending of this story. The first two books were awesome, and I love Tris and Tobias. What the heck happened with the final book!! Boring...slow...repetitive...uneventful...awful ending. The only thing that kept me going was the love story between Tris and Tobias because I was always wanting more than what the author gave. If this was supposed to be a young readers book, then what's with all the violence. I thought maybe due to the violent content that something more than kissing was going to happen between the two, but I was of course let down.I feel that the author was trying not to rush the last book, which can happen in some series, but this was the wrong way to go about it. It...was...so...slow. Half way through the book, I was skipping paragraphs, and skimming pages for dialogue. Nothing exciting was happening, so I raced to the end only to be greatly disappointed. The message I got from the book is that life is tough, and there's not always going to be a happy ending. But Tris's death didn't even  mean anything. And why wasn't Tobias, or anyone else, smart enough to know that Caleb was never going to give himself in the end. Of course Tris would step in. Because she's selfless all of a sudden. Whatever. She wasn't selfless throughout the whole story, and now she's changing her mind. I feel that if anything she'd be more selfish by now because she found in the second book that she really didn't want to die and she was going to try to live. Now she wants to give her life. And for what. A society's memories?? Maybe this sounds selfish, but it's not like they were going to die. They were going to live but not remember who the hell they were. Who cares! It didn't sound like Tris and Tobias were going back to the city anyways.I kind of want the author to look back on this and rewrite the last book. I finished the book today, and I've waited all day to write this. The disappointment hasn't gone away yet. I just want to forget about the book and move on it bothers me so much. Wow, I'm just that sensitive I guess.I read a lot, like 2-3 books a week, and this was top 3 worst books I've ever read. Sorry, that's mean, but I can't even think of anything good to say about it.

I had been eagerly awaiting the release of Allegiant, counting down the days like a child waits for Christmas. I considered taking off work to read the book all day (thank God, I didn't). I finished it in three days.I honestly have never been more disappointed in a book, ever. The first two were so good! They were interesting, they were inspiring, and they didn't leave you feeling like you've had the stomach flu for a week and your parents are getting a divorce.Not so with Allegiant.From the very beginning, this book was going nowhere. It is boring, lackluster, and the ideas are borrowed. Mazerunner series, anyone? (and I thought I hated the ending of that series - it was better than this one)Four was a strong character in books one and two, a protector. You are introduced to a girl, who in order to become free and able to understand herself she has to break her parent's heart. Then you are stunt as this meek girl, become an amazing woman.  Who spires other to be equally as great.***************warning: SPOILERS************************************Then you come to the last book what a disappointment that was. We find out that their entire lives where lies, manipulations of doctors and politicians to refuse to be wrong. Then the death of TRIS, I was so heartbroken. I won't belabor the points.  Others have covered them quite eloquently.  But, I can't stay silent on what proved to be such a disappointing end to this promising series.The biggest disappointment isn't the plot holes (there are plenty), the ending (which I wouldn't actually have minded if it hadn't felt like it was being done just to manipulate our emotions), or even the ridiulous over the top explanation of the bigger picture and what has really been going on (which really undercut the life and death stakes of the first two books for me).No.  For me, the biggest problem with this book is the way in which it was written.  Gone is the vivid dystopian society that Roth spent so much time establishing .  Tris seems almost unrecognizable and even worse - thanks to Roth's apparently inability to write characters with distinc voices - Four has turned into the male equivalent of Tris.  If I had a dollar for every time I had to look back at the start of the chapter to see who was talking, I would have earned back not only the price of this book but the entire series.  Note to the author (and the editor):  if you cannot actually write in distinct enough voices to tell the two main characters apart, do not structure the book to have chapters from alternating perspectives.  It is annoying, hard to follow, and does not engender good will.

Before I spoil this book for you I will give you a chance to decide before going into details. Allegiant was different from book 1&2. It really goes into genetics more than fighting and stuff like the other books. If you would like to finish this story I recommend reading this book up to chapter 49 and starting chapter 49 online with the alternate ending. you can Google it, a couple of fans have written a more appeasing alternate ending. That is what I would do to finish this trilogy. But if you go passed chapter 49 you are in for a twist. Okay that was your chance now for the SPOILER ALERT. BOOK REVIEW:The divergent trilogy was conflicting to review. DIVERGENT (book1) and INSURGENT (book2) were amazing! I literally read both books multiple times because it was so good. However, Veronica Roth, in the third book broke my heart in a million pieces. The way the stories are written from the very beginning (book1-book3) is very misleading. She deluded the readers into thinking and buying into what seemed like possible "foreshadowing" as to how this story might end and then she does not meet those expectations. THIS IS THE SPOILER. Tris at the end of DIVERGENT learns that Jeanine Matthews has given Four a newly developed simulation serum which makes his surroundings appear threatening to him and he can no longer see Tris as Tris ''his love interest'' but as his enemy. Tris can't get through to him. At this point he cannot hear or see her as anything other than a threat. Tris and Four fight to the point where she draws a gun to him. She decides that nothing is worth killing him for and so she turns the gun around to her own head as she had done in her own fear of landscape when she volunteered to die instead of killing the people she loved. She is ready to die for this. This act pulls Four out of the simulation and he is back to reality.Then in INSURGENT Tris, Four, and others, temporarily reside in Amity, then with the factionless, and eventually end up in Candor. Tris by now had been reckless with her life; Working against Four by conspiring with Marcus (Four's abusive father), shooting herself in a simulation, but most importantly, going to Erudite headquarters willingly giving her life to Jeanine Matthews in order to save the other divergent from dying. She was ready to die.  At the end of the book Tori ends up killing Jeanine Matthews and Four finds out that Tris was working against him but there is a bigger truth that keeps him from being upset with her.In ALLEGIANT they have discovered that there is a world behind the fence.Their is mix group of Amities, Erudite, Candor, Dauntles who call themselves the ALLEGIANT. They decide that they need to explore what is behind the fence. Some go and some stay behind. Tris, Four, Peter, Caleb, Christina, Uriah, Cara, all make it beyond the fence and they find out the truth. The truth is that they were part of an experiment that started generations back and the people running the experiment are interested in the divergent because those who aren't divergent are genetically damaged and they believe that is the cause of so many crimes among human beings. What these group of people intend to do is release a serum that wipe away the memory of all the people left in the experiment who include Four's parents, Uriah's family, Christina's family and all the people that they all grew up knowing. Wiping away their memories would be like they never existed. All they would know is their names and how to read and write but Tris and the rest decide that is not enough. Tris and Four want to stop this but the only way to do that is to go into a lab room that is enclosed with a pass code that only one person knows. That person is the one interested in wiping the memories of the people left in the experiment. So they can't count on his help. There is a death serum that is released into the air If anyone was to break into this room. So ultimately someone has to sacrifice their lives to retrieve the memory serum and prevent them of sending it out and instead Tris wants to give it the the people running the experiment so that both worlds can exist. In Allegiant Tris realizes that she does not want to die. She wants to live and Four foreshadows or hint towards having a life with Tris after all this is done. Tris through out this particular book expresses her desire to live and her love for Four and admits that Four and she have a complex relationship but she will rather weather the storm and choose to be with him everyday of her life just as her parents chose each other every time. Veronica  Roth deluded the readers into buying into those foreshadowing moments for example in Insurgent Tris cries into Four's arms saying that she's lost her entire family to death or betrayal and Four says that he is her family now. There were many more misleading moments like this one where Veronica Roth makes you picture a life after this struggle where Tris and Four find a world that works and they are there for each other always. It is so misleading that when they decide that someone has to sacrifice their life for this cause, Caleb volunteers to do so and Caleb has no lose ends. He betrayed Tris by working with Jeanine Matthews and letting Jeanine almost kill Tris. Caleb's parents are both dead. There is nothing left for him in the story, no friends, no family, no love interest, there would have been no lose ends with him dying. At the last minute Tris takes his place and goes in for serum which by the way did not kill her but upon leaving the room she encounters David, the guy running the experiment and he shoots her to her death. Mind you the story was set up for her to live. It was heart wrenching and a very poor decision to kill her character off. Veronica Roth should have kept the story going toward her self sacrifice motto in Allegiant if she was going to kill Tris anyway. But she didn't. Instead she diverted the plot and Tris' concept of life to where it all made sense for Tris to live along side Four who never felt loved or like he was worth loving until Tris. She tells him that he is and that she loves him. It all fit to end with them both alive. If anything I could've seen a plot twist where Four falls under the memory serum on his way to the others and he loses all knowledge of Tris and what she has done and how he feels for her and Tris has to fight for him to recover his memories of her and make him fall in love with her all over again or something like that. Instead Veronica Roth chose to kill Tris and Four comes back to the news of her death. It was a devastating ending.We as readers become engaged in their lives. We become emotionally invested in these stories. We follow these characters books upon books investing our time and developing a vulnerability towards them and I feel like Veronica Roth in this particular book really let me down. I would recommend reading book 1 and book 2 (Divergent, Insurgent) and ending the story there. Knowing that there is something more to this world than what divergent describes and making up the ending for yourself or reading an alternate ending online (there are a couple written by costumers). Or if not then don't even start the trilogy unless you're ready for a heartbreak.

This book broke my heart into a million pieces. I have never sobbed so hard or for so long while reading a book. I guess that’s because I’ve never read a book that can be so true to life. In real life happy endings don’t always exist and life is not always fair. We see this every day in our lives yet we rarely see this in books. And truthfully, I did love this book. I loved this book all the way until the end. The end is NOT what I wanted and I was so upset that I wanted to rate this book a 1 star. BUT when I thought it through, I still loved Allegiant and I realized that the rating should be based on EVERY part of the book, not just the ending. And again I found myself lost in the action, I fell in love with the dialogue, there were so many characters that I loved and loved to hate and I was enraptured with how the story progressed. I was so lost in this book that I was ignorant to think the ending could be what really happens. Looking back, I can see that Allegiant flows perfectly with how the two previous books progressed and it sticks with the theme Veronica Roth has created and doesn’t deviate from it. That in itself I highly value. Ultimately, I will read whatever Veronica Roth writes in the future BUT I will go into the books being realistic and knowing that I may need a huge box of tissues.This book starts off exactly where Insurgent left off. Tris and Christina are locked in a cell since Evelyn sees them as traitors and she and the factionless are now in charge of Chicago. Everyone, including Tris, is still reeling from Edith Prior’s revelation about what lies outside of the fence and that being Divergent is more important than they ever could have thought. When Tris and Christina are released as traitors they learn that there is a group, called the Allegiant, and they are allied with the original purpose of the city – sending people outside the city to help and living in factions. Upon hearing of this, Tris becomes resonate in her plans that she has to escape the city. She HAS to know what is out there. And again, from here I became completely absorbed in their world. Between the action, the knowledge we gain, how the relationships blossom and wither apart and the way the story progresses, Allegiant is addicting!This time we get to alternate between being in Tris’ and Tobias’ head. I loved being able to listen in to both of their thoughts and see the situations from both of their points of view. I loved being able to see the logical process of why Tris wanted to do certain things and then how Tobias viewed what Tris did and how he reacted to it. It made me feel as though I knew them both inside and out and I felt that much closer to them. I finally understand what makes them tick and why they both do the things they do. Sometimes they can be neurotic but in the end their love for each other is beautiful.I was so happy to see that Tris seems to have more of a grasp on who she is. Her compassion, her strength and her ability to analyze situations amazed me and even though she still struggled I felt as though she was confident with who she was and the choices she makes throughout the book. Tris is back to someone that I would want to stand behind in times of great unrest and danger. Tobias is a little bit different……since we get to see inside Tobias’ brain we finally get to see how much he struggles in this book. It reminds me of how Tris struggled in Insurgent. He is desperately trying not to become who is parents are and he is also struggling with trying to figure out what is really right and wrong. Even though I wanted to yell at him a few times he is still sexy as ever. His love and loyalty for Tris is a force to reckon with and I think that’s what makes me love him the most.I LOVED the huge revelation of what was outside the city. I was so excited to find out that it went along with what I thought from the beginning when Tris sees that the gates on the city’s fence lock from the outside and not the inside. Overall, I love this series. Did I wish it ended differently….uhh yeah! But in the real world and Divergent you don’t always get what you want. And sometimes that can be ok and other times you just have to the make the best of things and think of all of the wonderful moments you got to experience while going through this journey.

Allegiant is the third and final book of the Divergent trilogy written by Veronica Roth. (However, additional novellas will be published throughout 2013 and 2014.) It is a story of explosive truths, plot twists and turns, and an intense ending that every reader has their own thoughts about, ranging from bittersweet to outright hatred. You will have to read it yourself and find your own closure in this intelligent, young adult, dystopian story.“Sometimes, all it takes to save people from a terrible fate is one person willing to do something about it.”My favorite things about this book: Allegiant stayed consistent with the characters’ value systems. The beliefs the factions have instilled in each character shines through their actions in this story. However, the factions themselves take a backburner in this book. “I don’t belong to Abnegation, or Dauntless, or even the Divergent... I belong to the people I love, and they belong to me- they, and the love and loyalty I give them, form my identity far more than any word or group ever could. – Tris” The author did not compromise any of the characters’ integrity, but complimented it with themes of truth, forgiveness, love, sacrifice, and bravery. After being “inside the walls” for the first two books, the reader gets outside the factions and learns what “divergent” is and what it means for the characters. This added some new and interesting content to this final installment, although the telling of the information was at times slow. The epilogue was a nice touch given the shocking ending.My least favorite things about this book: I found it difficult to fully invest myself in a large portion of this book. Initially, I thought it was because I was reading while traveling and my reading settings were not ideal. However, reflecting back I realize that Allegiant was like reading a whole new book outside of the Divergent series. Yes, Tris, Tobias, and all of the remaining characters from Insurgent (book #2) were in it but the story is in a different setting, there are new characters added, and the story features a whole new reality. Oh, and it’s dual narration! After finishing the book, I realized how important the dual narration was at the end but it was slightly confusing throughout the beginning and middle of the book. First, I would forget whose perspective I was reading throughout chapters and I had to flip back a few pages to remind myself. Although each chapter begins with the name of the narrator, it wasn’t always easy to tell who the narrator was based on the content and thoughts. Second, I was confused by being in Tobias’ head because he’s not as strong as he appears on the outside, he’s more damaged that I thought and I wasn’t prepared for that. “I don’t know how it would feel, to hate your own history and to crave love from the people who gave that history to you at the same time. How have I never seen the schism inside his heart? How have I never realized before that for all the strong, kind parts of him, there are also hurting, broken parts?” – Tris (about Tobias)My favorite quotes:“‘A lot of the younger people think you’re downright heroic.’ ‘Oh, good,’ I say, a sour taste in my mouth. ‘Heroism is what I was focused on. Not, you know, trying not to die.’” – Tris“So much space. I wonder what it’s like in the places beyond ours; I wonder how people live there. I look out the window again, taking slow, deep breaths into a body to tense to move. And as I stare out at the land, I think that this, if nothing else, is compelling evidence for my parents’ God, that our world is so massive that it is completely out of our control, that we cannot possibly be as large as we feel. So small as to be negligible. It’s strange, but there’s something in that thought that makes me feel almost…free.” – Tris“I used to think that when people fell in love, they just landed where they landed, and they had no choice in the matter afterward. And maybe that’s true of beginnings, but it’s not true of this, now. I fell in love with him. But I don’t just stay with him by default as if there’s no one else available to me. I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other. I choose him over and over again, and he chooses me.” – Tris“To me, when someone wrongs you, you both share the burden of that wrongdoing-the pain of it weighs on both of you. Forgiveness, then, means choosing to bear the full weight all by yourself. Caleb’s betrayal is something we both carry, and since he did it, all I’ve wanted is for him to take its weight away from me. I am not sure I’m capable of shouldering it all myself-not sure that I am strong enough, or good enough.” – Tris“‘Yeah, sometimes life really sucks,” she says. “But you know what I’m holding on for?’ I raise my eyebrows. She raises hers, too, mimicking me. ‘The moments that don’t suck,’ she says. ‘The trick is to notice them when they come around.’…Since I was young, I have always known this: Life damages us, every one. We can’t escape that damage. But now, I am also learning this: We can be mended. We mend each other.” – Tris
summary: A story of explosive truths, plot twists and turns, and an intense ending that every reader has their own thoughts about.

While I liked Divergent and Insurgent, something seemed missing, preventing me from loving it. Veronica Roth found that missing piece in Allegiant. The story is powerful, intriguing, and emotionally gripping. It is a mature romance between two teens who had to grow up too fast ... two teens who show unfathomable strength. Tris's choice at the end is a beautiful demonstration of her selfless, brave, and intellectual divergence, following on the cusp of an honest conversation with someone she loves.In the conclusion to the series, we learn what lies beyond the experiment known as Chicago: The Bureau of Genetic Welfare. And what a bureau it is! Its location at O'Hare Airport is perfect, and learning about the Purity Wars and the origin of the factions is fascinating."I tick off each quality in my mind -- fear, low intelligence, dishonesty, aggression, selfishness. He IS talking about the factions. And he's right to say that every faction loses something when it gains a virtue: the Dauntless, brave but cruel; the Erudite, intelligent but vain; the Amity, peaceful but passive; the Candor, honest but inconsiderate; the Abnegation, selfless but stifling."I was thrilled to hear Four's perspective in about half of the chapters, though I agree with a Goodreads friend Brooke who stated that Tris's and Four's POVs are not distinct enough. Four's story is heartbreaking."I have never had parents who set good examples, parents whose expectations were worth living up to, but she did. I can see them within her, the courage and the beauty they pressed into her like a handprint."Four shows that he is anything but "genetically damaged". Genes vs environment? The Bureau leans too heavily on genes, forgetting that our experiences also shape us. And Four is so strong that he turns the environmental pressures he experienced into resilience, not weakness.I find the abuses of government to be appalling, and the cautionary tale about those abuses to be timely."It's not hard for me to believe that the Bureau would do bad things, because every government I've ever known has done bad things."In the end, this story is about love, especially the sacrifices we make for those we love."That's what love does, when it's right -- it makes you more than you were, more than you thought you could be."I hear they will likely split Allegiant into two films, and I can't wait to see who they cast as David and Matthew. Wonderful series!

I just finished ALLEGIANT, the third and final sequel in the DIVERGENT series by Veronica Roth.  It would be a disservice to give away anything that happens to the major characters, but I have to say that Roth’s writing is as brave and convention-shattering as her main characters.  She demonstrates that Young Adult fiction does not have to be safe and comfortable for its audience.Out of the series, I still love DIVERGENT the best because of the newness of the world and the uncertainty and challenge facing the main character Tris as she leaves the self-effacing faction of her childhood for the most wild, dangerous, and even reckless faction for her future.  The story follows the conventions of other dystopian series’ like LEGEND and HUNGER GAMES but stands on its own.  The second book in the series INSURGENT explores the world that was set up to its limits and then breaks it wide open.  I didn’t know what to expect from ALLEGIANT.  Story-wise, I was lost on some of the details of this second-new world where genetic testing and purity, damage and reconstruction are behind everything I thought to be true.  But from a character standpoint, Roth took a leap and pushed her characters beyond anything I’ve read so far.  And I realized as I was reading that I didn’t know how she was going to wrap it up.  It stopped following convention.  And that’s when I became afraid.Like many of these dystopian series, the teenage girl at the center of the story makes decisions with as much logic and analysis as she can muster with a default gut-reaction in her back pocket.  They tend to be smarter than average, know their own physical limits, and willing to push themselves past all those limitations when necessary.  In the real world, the fact that these girls’ decisions end up being the right thing to do would be mostly due to luck, but in these series’ these profound consequences are a testament to the girls’ special qualities.  The message is clear: Be smart, young ladies.  Be brave.  Think before you act, don’t let emotions get the best of you.  And if you must take a leap of faith.In the real world, those leaps of faith for a teenager are based on crazy hormonal shifts and raging emotions.  While I agree with the sentiment behind these character traits, I don’t know how well they translate.  Honestly it’s confusing being a girl sometimes.  I grew up with the whole-hearted belief that I could have a thrilling, passionate, demanding career in a difficult field and still have an incredibly rare marriage and perfect children that I would have time to raise and money to support.  I’m not saying this isn’t possible, but as life has surprised me along the way, I have realized that the reality of this belief is not at all like the fantasy in my head.  With the pressures women have to be thin, have flawless skin, be perfect and smart and strong and feminine, there is no room for error as these girls navigate into their womanhood.  I think of Miley Cyrus who in all reality is doing exactly what she should be doing as a young, passionate, creative woman.  She is being vilified for not being a role model and yet rewarded for her crazy behavior with media attention and money.  How will she navigate into adulthood?  Obviously celebrities are a special breed and again the translation to us normal humans is not one-to-one, but still I hope you see my point.The most important aspect of these dystopian young adult series’ is that these strong female characters face dangers and actually lose something in the process.  They face the compromise of life and find a way to keep living.  I can’t really recall a story from my formative pre-teen/teen years that offered such a mature outlook on life and the future.  The ones that come to mind all offer some kind of replacement solution, usually in the form of a man/relationship.  In many ways, it’s heartbreaking to read ALLEGIANT now, as a parent, because I don’t want to think about loss and disappointment for my own children even though I know it’s inevitable.  And worse, I know that loss, disappointment, and failure are all the best teachers to becoming a better person.  They can do the opposite as well, but handing someone something on a silver platter doesn’t seem to have done much good for anyone I know.  Fighting for what you want, failing and having to figure out which battle to fight is key to understanding oneself and others.In adult fiction, I keep my guard up as a reader, knowing that all bets are off, but in YA I tend to think there’s a safety in the genre that things will be realistic but not that real.  ALLEGIANT blew me away because it shattered all the safe promises the other series keep.  What is salvaged from the wreckage of the story is true and beautiful and heartbreaking and the best thing anyone can pass on to the next generation.  I literally sobbed at the end.  I don’t want to leave these characters.  I don’t want to admit that Roth ultimately took my expectations and used them against me and I played right into her gifted hands.As a fellow writer, and one who likes to break conventions, I salute you Veronica Roth.  As a reader, you have broken my heart and mended it with the bittersweet truths of your words.  Thank you.

I was wary going in to this book.  Even though I am not part of the YA community, the degree of backlash was impossible to miss.  I heard the author even received death threats.  While that is crazy, extreme, and never ok, after finishing the book I understand the disappointment. And a little bit of anger.  After all, the first book was really good.  Tris and Four were so compelling.  I grew to care about them: about their fight, their happiness, their evolution.  And all I am left with now, is a hollow feeling and the resounding question, why would any author do this to her fans?I'm not going to spoil the ending. Just in case, like me, you have managed to avoid spoilers up until this point, I am not going to be the one to ruin it for you. I'll let Veronica Roth do that for herself.  I will say that I am not sorry I took the journey with these characters. I just wish this final installment had gone a different way.It's not like the ending was the only issue I had with the book, though.  I was a little let down that Insurgent veered so far from the tone and core of Divergent.  But here, we literally leave everything behind for an entirely new world altogether.  Things get so out of hand in Chicago, our main characters leave and start all over again outside the walls. It's a completely different society, but almost all the problems are the same.  The same disparities, prejudice, rebellion and machinations, only with a slightly different spin to fit the new world.  It felt too heavy handed and convenient that so much happening inside the city mirrored what was happening outside.That wasn't the worst thing, however.  No. Other than the horrible ending, the worst part of this book was the destruction of Tobias.  He is almost unrecognizable from the character we got to know in the first two books.  Yes, he was flawed before, and he had some issues. But here, he is a hot mess. He has lost his quiet surety, his inner strength and compass.  He is basically a whiny idiot for much of the book.  This is made even more obvious because the book is told in alternating POVs between him and Tris.  I thought that I would like that in the beginning, but I didn't... primarily because Roth did not give these characters distinct enough voices.  Even though each chapter was labeled with who was narrating, sometimes I would forget whose POV we were in.  It just didn't work.  Now that the story is over, I understand why Roth did it, but that knowledge really doesn't help.It wasn't all terrible.  Tris has improved since the last book. She's grown some --and I cared about what was happening with her. I cared about her stupid relationship with Tobias.  And I can definitely say nothing about the book was predictable. So there's that.Bottom line, should you read it?  Well, if you read Divergent and you like it, you will no doubt have to read it.  The books in the trilogy are too intertwined not to.  As in the Hunger Games trilogy, book 1 is great. Book 2 is ok, but has a major cliffhanger.  And book 3 makes you want a stiff drink. Take that knowledge and do with it as you will.  I can't imagine how they'll get away with this ending in the theaters.  They'll be throwing popcorn at the screen and demanding their money back.

reviewText: **Warning: I do my best to stay away from spoilers, but since this is the third and final book of a series, I might slip. So beware!**Let me start off by saying that I enjoyed Allegiant much more than Insurgent. But I didn't enjoy it as much as Divergent. I think this is a common trend with trilogies. First book rocks. Second book drags. Third book rocks and drags.Unlike its predecessors, Allegiant went back and forth between two POV's: Tris and Tobias. Overall, I enjoyed this updated format. In fact, I wish Veronica Roth had written the first two books this way. The varying perspectives added a deeper dimension, propelled the story forward faster, and gave the reader a break from Tris (who, lets face it, can be borderline unlikeable at times). My only complaint about this new format: I kept forgetting if I was reading from Tris or Tobias's POV. Because it's written in first person, and because Tris and Tobias are so similar, I'd end up reading entire chapters thinking I was inside the others head. Friends of mine have also complained about this issue. I think a simple solution would've been to add Tris or Tobias's name at the top of each page, or even use the strategy of Marie Lu's Legend with different font colors.**Okay, I'm going to tread into Spoilerville here. I must. Sorry.**The ending. Wow. Just...wow. I'm sure many people will disagree with me, but I liked it. I thought Tris's fate made perfect sense and fit the book's theme of "choice". And, come on, this was never a happy series. Death and despair and WTF-just-happened? moments were always the norm. I'm still trying to figure out if I liked how Tris died. At one minute I think, "Well, it makes sense", but then the next I think, "Really? Gunshot? Really?" I suppose I'm leaning towards the "Well, it makes sense" side. Just like the death serum, Tris made a choice to get shot. Even though she knew it would mean death if she lunged for the button to release the memory serum, she did it anyways to save those she loved. I liked that.I must applaud Veronica Roth for having the guts and boldness to kill off her main protagonist. I'm so used to YA series ending in a shower of glitter and flutter of butterflies. Even Hunger Games had a sorta happy ending, with Katniss and Peeta building a life together. But Allegiant ended horribly realistically, and, in this case, logically...At least Veronica Roth gave the reader a sliver of satisfaction by taking us a couple of years into the future with Four to see how he's dealing with Tris's death and how the world Tris died for is faring.Even so, it was a bittersweet ending to a bittersweet series.For more book reviews, visit jenspenden.wordpress.com.

Also, I usually dont write reviews...or give only one star...unless I just cant continue with a book(only one other book every got 1 star from me) But this was just disappointing and doesnt give me any desire at all to finish it.**Update 12/27/13***May contain Spoilers*This is my first major review of a book. Normally I just rate with stars, but since I really liked the first two and couldnt stand this book I thought it required more of an explanation. I dont have the writing skills or literary insight as some of these reviewers but I will try my best.Ok I couldnt help myself and a friend talked me into it. (I read her copy, Thank goodness because I would have been furious if I paid for it.)I really liked Divergent and Insurgent. But from the very beginning i knew I wouldnt like this book, although I tried to keep an open mind. The whole tone of the book was different. Tris didnt sound like the Tris I came to love in the first two(Tobias wasnt very Tobias either). The POV's were executed very poorly. Usually if you have multiple POVs it adds insight into the character, their world and their situation. Not in this book. Tobias and Tris were generally together throughout the book, and when they werent they would relay the information to each other anyways making the whole thing very repetitive. And again, Tris and Tobias POV's were written exactly the same. You could only tell who was narrating by situation cues.The whole plot was overly complicated and left wholes in the story. The GP's changed their genes because people were bad, but the GD's are bad and the GPs never created war? Doesnt that contradict itself right there. Just totally out there and made barely any sense once so ever. I think she tried to layer the plot but instead it just seemed all over the place and just event after event without having too much to do with eachother. For example theres been this big pending war built up between the Allegiant and the factionless but then wait forget about that were going outside the fence and Tobias is going to join a different rebel cause. Then at the end he just goes back to ask his mom if she will stop the Allegiant/factionless war and just like that its over? (Not the Evelyn we knew either) Just the whole thing didnt seem to sync well with me.Now the ending. Like other people have said, I do not need a happy ending to like a book. Not at all. (As you can see earlier I barely even gave this book a chance before I got to the end) I actually knew about her death before I even started reading Insurgent. I was excited to read the story and see how it got there. Usually when main/favorite characters die there is a reason for it, it propels the story further, it has a purpose that changed the course of everything thats currently set in motion. Not this. Tris's death had no meaning at all, I understand that she would want to take Calebs place because she loves him. But Caleb needed a redemption and that was his one true shot at it and she took it from him in the name of love. So Tris is some sort of superhuman and is somehow the only one ever to survive the death serum. Just in time to get shot, but of course right after she went there to do what she needed to.(What the hell) But the thing that made me most mad about her death was how her mother greeted her. I would not think her mom would just show up and pull her to death (especially after sacrificing herself so her daughter could live). I would think if she did have a vision of her moms spirit (ghost, whatever) that her mom would be urging her to hang on to life not pulling her to death.The only part I remotely liked about this book was Tobias's grieving. It was the only part that felt real and full of emotion to me. (even though he still didnt sound like the Tobias in the first two) But again, Tris's death did not propel his story further either. I believe he would have faced his fears with her too(he already has in the past in the fear landscape)Im not sure what was going through Ms. Roths mind when she wrote this. Seems to me maybe she just wanted to get it over with, IDK but definitely not the trilogy I thought I would love. This book was the most disappointing series finale I have ever read. I will definitely not be reading it again. (I had already read the first two twice but Im done with that now)I wish I had listened to my instinct and not let my friend talk me into this. (somehow she loved it)

reviewText: Allegiant explores what true sacrifice really means.  Sacrifice isn’t giving away other people’s lives for the good of everyone.  True sacrifice can only come from within yourself with the desire to truly help others no matter the cost to you.  I liked how Allegiant explored the idea of a good or evil sacrifice.  I liked the ending, though it did give me a major hangover that I had to discuss with my husband for an hour or two before I could move on.  I think the ending was tragic, gutsy, and really tied all the books together and stuck with the theme of the series. I also really liked Veronica Roth’s explanation of why she ended it the way she did.Even though I liked the book overall, I did have a lot of issues with it that seriously hindered my enjoyment.  My biggest complaint was how slow the middle was.  There should be a PSA in the middle of the book that says, “We would like to interrupt this conflict to bring you All The Answers for at least 100 pages. Thank you.” Yeah. I was bored.  Not a lot actually happens for a huge portion of the middle of the book.  The answers of what was really on the outside of the fence was not really what I expected based on the ending of Insurgent.  And I don’t understand Tris’ anger for the people outside the fence not helping.  First she was mad that they were meddling in their lives and then she’s all mad that they weren’t?? Make up your mind!I think the secondary characters would make really good cardboard cutouts for a movie.  I can just see Luke Skywalker turn around after he wins his medal and see the entire secondary cast of Allegiant.  I could not tell any of them apart.  I could not remember who was who.  I was constantly googling all the secondary people.  If Veronica Roth is going to just assume I know who all these characters are just by their name, then please don’t make them so flat and boring.The romance was okay.  It was a lot of kissing and then getting mad at each other.  But it had it’s moments that I really liked.  I think my favorite was this quote from Tris:I fell in love with him. But I don’t just stay with him by default as if there’s no one else available to me. I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other. I choose him over and over again, and he chooses me.Veronica Roth, Allegiant p. 372Overall, I enjoyed it for the most part but the middle dragged way too much and the secondary characters were completely flat.

reviewText: By the time I got halfway through this book-- which I had anxiously awaited all year-- I was feeling oddly bereft, like I was missing something.  I decided to jump online and read some of the reviews to see if others felt the same.  Needless to say, everyone else has already picked apart in great detail the shortcomings of the third installment: a disappointing ending, dragging storyline, weird, out-of-left-field character development, and an underplayed romance that didn't progress or evolve enough.  For me, though, the thing that I missed from books one and two was the magical, ethereal quality of the characters' lives within the faction system.  Yes, it was hugely flawed, often evil and corrupt... But they were still enchanting.  The amity in their apple orchards, strumming banjos and laughing... The dauntless hanging around the the chasm or boisterously scaling the pit, all covered In tattoos and black... The cool blue and glass erudite, the frank and unflinching black-and-white Candor... The somber, grey Abnegation, calm and compassionate.  It was these colors of fantasy that captured my imagination, and that I sorely missed in Allegiant.  I found myself unable to care about a group of characters who couldn't seem to decide what they stood for, in a setting as dull as dry toast, with a constantly and confusingly  shifting array of "bad guys."  My heart just wasn't in this read...  However, the two stars are given for the fact that Tris and Tobias finally stopped with all the lies and secrets, and that I kind of dug how the city turned out in the end.  Considering that books one and two were an off-the-chart SIX stars, two isn't saying much...

reviewText: I can't even put into words how disappointing this book was for me. Yes, I dislike the ending and found it profoundly lacking, but I'll save that for last.First of all, despite it being YA, I still expect it to be decently written and engaging- and Allegiant suffered on both accounts. The dual viewpoints between Tris and Four sounded like a good concept, and one I was ready to get behind...but in practice it's messy, non-cohesive and somehow despite the constant shifting, very monotonous. The first 2 books gave me the sense that Roth was really finding her voice and improving, so I was ready to forgive the first signs of these problems I saw; except that they continued throughout the entirety of the book. It became hard to recall if you were in Tris' POV or Four's, and the value of their separate perspectives suffered as a result. It got to the point where I really lost interest in the story altogether, only continuing in hopes that it would regain footing and reveal something worthwhile.I resisted the temptation to look into spoilers. So I read no reviews, didn't listen to Roth's explanation of her ending or even talk about the book with anyone further along. So my initial reaction was a very surprised, strongly negative one. I doubted very much that her words on the matter would change my thought, but I was still curious and did listen/read what she had to say. It left me somehow even more disappointed. So Tris was finally grown up, self-aware and ultimately WORTHY enough to sacrifice herself? That's her powerful, 'righteous' ending? I'm not saying it should have been a clear cut case of Tris and Four walking into the sunset, never to have further struggles or fighting to evolve further....but to say neither of them is deserving of the proper ending together; and that Tris finally became who she wanted, and who her parents would have been proud of, only to die is fitting- seems a little wrong to me. It seems to me Roth was just so desperate to be different and NOT have them 'ride into the sunset' that she felt the need to ruin any further development there could have been.So I muddled through the unimpressive writing, terrible POV shifting and struggles all for an ending that ruins everything leading up to it. I'm incredibly disappointed with this book, from start to finish.

reviewText: I am more sad for Veronica Roth than for Tris. This was a fascinating world, with virtually unlimited opportunities for studying human nature. In Divergent, Roth does this very well. In Insurgent, she does it fairly well, but I felt it had a lot of pointless filler material, with not much newness. Allegiant is, absolutely without question in my mind, the most disappointing series finale I've ever read. There was no new material of any value. I did not connect with any of the new characters. The story line, through the first two books, was all about Tris. When the Point of View was split between Tris and Tobias in the third book, alarm bells went off. Frankly, she doesn't ever connect us to Tobias the way she did with Tris. I feel that this book (in addition to a pitifully unsatisfying ending) was rushed, and Ms. Roth does not have the writing chops to write a book this quickly and do it well. It is a lot of mind-numbing nothingness stretched out over too many pages, with very little actual story taking place, and no real mystery whatsoever.SPOILER ALERT:The ending of this book is utterly disappointing, not because Tris dies, but because the story dies. It was her story, and it feels incomplete, but it is oh, so very over. Several relentless chapters AFTER her pointless death reinforce to us just how over it is. Just in case you weren't sad enough, she piles it all on a bit more.No, I' not sad for Tris - all good characters have to end sometime. I'm sad for Veronica Roth, because she had hit on something that could have been genuinely big. At this point, I doubt they will even make the third film. By the time people read the third book, they won't want to watch it in the theater. I know I won't. Too bad, Ms. Roth - and by the way, if you had an editor, he/she should be fired. There was no redeeming quality in this third book, and an editor should have had prevented this calamity from reaching print.

Tris' and Tobias' attraction to each other and their relationship was like a sidebar without the passion and urgency of the other books.  Roth portrayed Tobias as a whiney little kid...where did that come from, for heaven's sake???  The explanations for the "experiments" seemed contrived with lots of loopholes.  The plot seemed rushed, even though it was a very long book."SPOILER ALERT"  DO NOT READ FURTHER IF YOU HAVE NOT READ THE BOOK.How could Roth kill off Tris? She killed off several favorite characters, wasn't that enough.  I am so disappointed.  I enjoy reading good books several times and now I won't with this series, nor will I read anything else written by Veronica Roth.  She deals with betrayals in her books and I feel like she betrayed her readers.
summary: I can't believe that Roth did this to her loyal readers

reviewText: It isn't often that an action – fantasy novel has me me in tears, but this one did.  Don't expect an unrealistically happy ending like in "The Hunger Games," this book was much more real.

There will be spoilers so if you have no finished please do not read unless you do not care for spoilers.  I finished this book around 11pm last night, crying through the last 20 minutes.  I really did like the book up until the ending because well I become devastated when a book does not end the way I want it to in my mind.  I am one of those people who become a part of the characters especially my favorite ones.I think that the way this book was written letting you get inside of Tris and Tobias was fabulous because I like him just as much as I like her and felt this helped to get to know his mind better and how he really feels and why he makes the choices he makes even when you are like WHY ARE YOU DOING THAT???? So to get to the point I had been looking forward to reading this book for a long time, ever since I finished the others for the first time (I have read them multiple times since)and even though I was disappointed in how it ended I have to give to to Veronica this is probably one of the only books/series I have read, and I read a lot, that seems to be like things happen in real life.  Tris and Tobias' relationship was not perfect and they loved each other for all of their flaws and good parts.  The part where Tris makes the comment about thinking once you fall in love she used to think the rest just happened but now she realizes that it is not because there are not other people out there for them but they both continue to choose each other day after day and thats what really makes their love is the best description of love I have ever heard.I think that the way the book ended may have been the way it needed to end for Caleb and Tris to be okay because had he truly done what he was planning to do I dont think she would have been able to forgive herself and that may have altered who she could be when it was all over.  This helped him to know she really forgave him, it just killed me for Tobias because she really didnt want the result that happened in the end but didnt anticipate David being there waiting.  I was super sad for it to end but it was a change to not have a book end in the way everyone would think and instead have a more real life ending because as we all know life is not perfect.  This series will be missed and I do look forward to the movies but it will be hard watching knowing how it ends.  Thanks for a great series.
I was very sad to see this series go, along with it's characters. The story was very differently written from the first two, however, I believe that the message it portrayed was great.

I liked the last in her trilogy, however, I did not like how it would go from one character to another in the chapters.  When reading the first 2 they were all from "Tris' " point of view.  Allegiant went from her to Tobias (Four).  I would have to go back to the chapter heading to figure out whose point of view I was reading about.  I did like this book.  It was sad, but not everything in life ends happily.

My sister recommended this series and I was hooked three pages in to Divergent. I plowed right through it and loved it. Same for Insurgent. I had such high hopes for Allegiant. I jumped in to this book as quickly as a Dauntless jumps on to a train. Oh man was I disappointed. It starts off okay but it ends up being more of the same. I won't put any spoilers in here but suffice to say I just felt empty and disappointed.The first two books were so good but this one felt like the author had run out of ideas and had to throw in the big shocker at the end to try to save it. I have several other people reading this series now an  I almost feel bad about it because Allegiant disappoints.

I wanted to love this book, but I didn't.  It isn't that I disliked it or didn't enjoy it, but it was too easy to put down and walk away from.  It lacked the sticking power of the first two books where it was hard to break away and do something else.  I was able to put this down for days at a time.  Part of me gets that way when I know a series is almost over, I want to prolong what is left of the storyline, but I think at the same time the last installment of any trilogy is hard and where readers start to get the most critical.Tris and Tobias are living in Evelyn's post faction world with a new movement afoot, the Allegiant are forming to rebel against the anti-faction order that has been imposed on Chicago.  Meanwhile, many are wondering about the message about the need for the Divergent citizens to leave the city to help heal the world.The outside world reminded me of The Maze Runner and The Hunger Games.  There are issues of control and issues of who is more worthy of time and attention.  Is the reason for why we act the way we do all because of our genes, or do we have some control over what we do with what we have?I don't want give any spoilers, but I am conflicted over the ending, I can see why Roth chose the route she did, but I would have liked to have seen it all go a different way.  I still look forward to seeing what is done with the movie version of Divergent, but this story let me down a bit and took both Tris and Tobias in different directions than I saw them in the other books.  Tris got much more regimented and set in her ways, passing judgments and holding people up to very high standards and expecting others to go along with her way or to be quiet and Tobias, who was always so strong and sure of himself, succumbed to a lot of self-pity and whining.  Almost as if Roth took the normal stereotypes of male and female characters and flipped them.  Not sure it works all that well either way though.

I really enjoyed the first three-fourths of the book and then one chapter disappointed me. I won't spoil it but let's just say I was hoping I was reading the words wrong. Overall though I did like the series.
Great writing and story. The ending is rough but the characters are great. I love the main character. I'll miss her!

This book was a huge disappointment, and not just for the reasons everyone is saying.  The plot, the writing, the failure of the two narrators, and yes, the ending -- they all made this book horrible.  I am very disappointed and wish I had stopped at the second book.  I hope the movie changes not only the ending but the entire story because this revelation about genetic experiments is just plain stupid.  Epic fail times ten.

SPOILERSI understand, killing off your main character is the new science fiction thing to do. Oblivion and Elysium (movies) are the two most recent stories to do this.But this novel, then end of the trilogy, killing off the main character was just stupid. On so many levels. But mainly I am irritated because since book one Roth has been building up Tris as an individual, but also in her relationship with Four. Why would you spend three ENTIRE books helping these characters to grow together, and overcome so many obstacles that happen in real life with different circumstances? It gives the reader that hope, that maybe no matter how bad things get (and we went through a lot of terrible things with Tris and Four) you can get through them and things will be better.Roth has most of book 3 building up their relationship, and overcoming the same problem that happened in book 2, but with Tris realizing she will always forgive him. And then Roth kills her. It makes all of that writing seem like such a waste. If she hadn't built them up together, making that one of the major plot lines, then I think I would understand why she killed off Tris. If she did it for the greater good. But.....the reasons that were given felt like excuses.I agree with another reviewer, I think all the problems with this book (because killing of the main character is the worst, but definitely no the only one, why suddenly change the writing style from the first two books? I don't want Four's POV, I have her short stories for that.) I think Roth felt pressured writing this. It was like she cracked trying to write this. Maybe she felt limited by having to wrap it up in one book? My advice...then don't! She would have done so much better and honestly would have probably made more money. Finish it the way you want it.I think Trilogies cab fail because of this. Just write the story, if it's three books then call it a trilogy, but if it's not I'm perfectly happy to keep buying the series if it is a good series.I was in love with this series until I finished (almost) this book. It ruined the whole series for me and now I don't think I want to read any more short stories about Four. I loved the ones out, but now Tris is dead. Who cares?I'm sorry, I really wish this was the book we all wanted to read. I think I might try to rewrite it for my own sanity. Closure.

I couldn't bring myself to care enough about the characters to finish off the series. The first book had so much promise. The second one annoyed me to no end, and I just didn't care by the time I got to this. Save yourself $8 and read the synopsis on Wikipedia.
summary: After the first two, I just don't care anymore

reviewText: This was an amazing series. I was absolutely captivated and am so sad it is over. I will be looking out for other titles by this author. It is a must read series.
I loved the divergent series. This was a great ending to an awesome series. I'm so sad to have come to the end of the series. The book has some twist and turns and highly recommend it.

I have been waiting for this book to come out and to say I was excited when it popped up on my kindle last night is not a lie. I have no words. I am so sad and disappointed. Four is one of my book boyfriends and I was so looking forward to getting his POV. That little treat did not help how I feel about what happened in this book. I loved the first two, and will let everyone I know not to read this one because the first two will be ruined as was this series. Why Veronica? I don't get it?
summary: Don't read the this book if you want to keep loving the first two

reviewText: Amazing series. Was disappointed at the ending tho :/ was still a good book, keeps you interested right up till the end.

There are some things about Allegiant that I think will turn off those who read Divergent and Insurgent:1) This is no longer "inside the fence" so the entire plot of this book is nothing like the last two. There's far less running, action, shooting, etc.. and far more discussion and angst from psychological issues. It's scientific and not battle-tastic.2) The ending is polarizing. There are some types of readers who will embrace it and some who will hate it.3) The POV jumps between Tris and Four, but they are almost indistinguishable (no seriously, I had to go back to the start of the chapter to check who it was sometimes). That's frustrating for a reader. It also means that much of the witty banter between our favorite couple has disappeared. They (sadly) spend a lot of time angry at one another.4) The side characters are MIA for most of the novel. Which is sad, because I think Roth did an excellent job creating other characters full of depth and life. The plot was slow to move due to an influx of information, and yet we received next to no information on how the other characters were handling this HUGE change in their world.So here's the bottom line: can you handle it if it doesn't end like a Hollywood perfectly packaged present? Yes, great - keep going.No? Stop now and pretend the third book wasn't written. Seriously.But all that said, I still loved Allegiant. Roth has a distinct writing style that I truly enjoyed, and I never felt that this was a slow moving or uninteresting novel.It did turn my perspective on Tris' world upside down because of the major revelations. I'm shocked that this is where Roth had intended to take the series all this time. The huge world outside of Tris' previous one is such an adjustment, and it almost makes you feel like all the heroic actions of Tris and Four are insignificant on this new grand scale. That's new. I like that they are thrust into a place neither of them can control or be top dog of.I truly loved the end and couldn't have seen a better way for it to go. I hope that in time the fans that are upset by how this book went can return to it and see that it has a lot of great qualities despite some disappointing ones as well.
summary: Some of the magic is lost, but the ending is perfect IMO

reviewText: Allegiant was so much better than Insurgent.  strong female character and a story line that was probable.  Sad that the main character died at the end.  But what do expect???
Excellent book. And an even better series. I can't believe its over or that it ended in the way it did, but I'm so glad is read it. This book has helped me deal with grief in a whole new way
This was a great book!  I enjoyed reading it right up til the end.  Don't care for real life endings!

I enjoyed the first book and marginally suffered through the second book to see if Tobias and Tris would finally get together in a meaningful, substantial way.  And in the third book, it's just more of the same irritating conflict and constant loss.  I can't think of a single happy scene that was actually satisfying.Spoiler Alert...And when she killed off Tris, I was so done with this series.  All that irritating, depressing reading with hopes of a happy ending gone. reviewText: Eh.  Wasn't really drawn in this time.  The characters' deviations from past two novels established traits was disconcerting.  Still, a solid conclusion to the story arc.
A little disappointed in the ending but still a good book. Not her best one of the series but still good
Pleasing finale to the Divergent Trilogy. Easy, reading as were the first two novels. Highly recommend all three. Veronica Roth has hit a home run with this series.

Though I did find Allegiant to be a little rushed I enjoyed it and found it to be a wonderful and unique end to an excellent series. I can't believe the 3 stars and all the crappy reviews simply because the book didn't end as they wanted it to.NO, the ending will not be what you expect or want but the reality of it is that in war, nobody is off limits, sacrifices will be made.  In  the end, hearts may be broken, but life ultimately goes on.

It was difficult to give this book a four star rating. It's not that it's a bad novel, but the series didn't end the way I expected it to. I was finished the book while waiting for my car to be repaired...I had to stop myself from crying in public!

Yup, that pretty much assesses my reaction to the book. Nothing interesting happens for the first two thirds of the story. Half to most of the time I would start reading a chapter and be half way through before I figured out I was reading through the wrong character, start the chapter again, then fall asleep. I finally just skipped to the end after the introduction of a couple of unsavory characters, and read the last part of the last chapter just to see what happened. It was a ho-hum ending.So disappointing because I really liked the first two books!i will not recommend this one to my students.
