reviewText: If you liked Divergent and Insurgent, you will like this book as well.  It is the same style, the same high-action plot lines, and the author does a great job of not making it totally predictable.  I think a lot of people rated this book low because they didn't like author's plot decisions, not because the writing was bad.  I thought about not reading past Divergent because this book was rated so low.  Don't let the stars get you down.  It's as good as the other 2.
summary: Just as Good as the Others

reviewText: Spoilers!What kind of book lets all the bad characters live (without a fight or climax I might add) and all the good ones die?  I get that sometimes good characters die and sometimes it's required that they do, but ALL of them?!  There is no resolution in this book, just misery, depression, and pointlessness.This book DRAGGED on, felt meandering, and had hardly any point at all.  There were all these extra plot lines that got introduced in the last book that were SO out of place.  I was willing to consider the genetic story line but what the heck was with the fringe people?!  They go into this story almost like for a change of scenery. They don't fix anything, help people, and it made no difference to the City of Chicago.I can't believe this got published.  I would have rather waited another year for her to come up with a better story.  It's almost like the author had three weeks write this.  I'm super disappointed, to the point that I won't be buying this for Xmas gifts like I had wanted to.  I'm actually hoping Hollywood fixes this mess because it was THAT BAD that they can't make it worse.

I have to say, this was not my favorite of the series, and not just because of the ending! It took me longer to get into the book than with the others, and it just didn't grab me quite the same way. I don't know if it was the switching of povs (although I did like hearing Tobias's thoughts throughout) or if it was just that this one seemed more confusing to me. Either way, by about halfway through I was sucked in and I couldn't put it down. Except for the last few chapters. They were so intense I did have to put it down a few times. Roth did a great job of making it believable and I'm not ashamed to admit that I cried and cried through the last few chapters. I'm not going to spoil it, but the ending was very different than I had imagined, but probably the most "true-to-life" the ending could have been and I'm not yet sure how I feel about that. It was one of those books that I think I'll need to process for a while before I can fully form an opinion on my feelings. I will also admit that this was a book that definitely gave me "book hangover." I've been waiting for it for so long, and I finished it in a day, and now I don't know what to do with myself.

I love the key and connections Veronica disguises in the book,waiting for you to get to the next chapter to find them out. Sometimes not even knowing they were there. I wish Tris was still alive so her and Tobias could start over and begin a new life together, but her memory will live within him. This book deserves a superior rating because of the magnificent details woven inside. I recommend this novel to anyone who feels as strong and as brave as she was, IS.
Not as attention grabbing as the other two books. Still a good book to finish off the series and tie up loose ends
Fantastic final book to the Divergent series. I went through nearly all emotions while reading this book. Veronica Roth writes another book that I wish went on forever.
summary: A fantastic End to an even better series.

reviewText: I reread Divergent and Insurgent before I read Allegiant. I have been thinking about this book and the many problems that were in it ever since I finished it.  I was excited to see where the story was going to take us after the end of Insurgent and after finishing Allegiant I was confused and disappointed.  The book has so many problems with the storyline and the characters felt like they had actually de-evolved instead of growing.  And don't even get me started on the genetically pure and damaged garbage.  Yes, I know that it is Veronica Roth's story, but when you published something and charge money for it, you owe your readers a good story. I had a problem with the way that the many deaths were handled....I was not emotionally invested in the characters like I had been in the previous books.  It was like a different author wrote Allegiant.  I have never finished a book and felt empty and betrayed like I did after finishing this book.  I didn't even know what to read next.  I was even afraid to read a book that I hadn't read before.  Thankfully, I have the Harry Potter books on my kindle and I was able to immerse myself in that world ( I started Deadly Hallows last night).  I reread my favorite books and I doubt that I will ever reread the Divergent trilogy.....I almost returned Allegiant for a refund.  And I probably will never buy a book by Veronica Roth again.

I so enjoyed Divergent and Insurgent and pre-ordered Allegiant months ago. The writing style was different- less developed/thorough and like so many other reviewers have expressed, that left me less invested in the story and characters. Many plots didn't seem well thought out and I was just disappointed that after all the waiting, this was the end of what had been a really well written series.

Did this book end the way I wanted it to end? Not at all. Not even a little bit. But sometimes things happen the way we don't plan them to...and we end up being the better for it because they change us and they have us looking at the world differently. For that alone, Veronica did a brave and beautiful thing with this last book in her series. A very difficult thing for an author to do and one that's left me astounded and impressed.

I am always disappointed when books end the way I envision them, but we would not have the need to heal hearts and lives if they did.  Read this volume with great expectations and no matter how you want it to end it won't matter to you in the end as you read how the characters handle their personal lives.

i loved the book!! I know some people didnt but thats life in post apocalyptic times. Wonderful series!! I will miss the characters. Thats how you know you just finished a good book, when the characters stay with you for a while.

After two exciting and well written books, Allegiant was predictable and preachy.  Every eight grader has thought of this ending that human were a mere experiment being observed as we existed under a dome.  And then to be preached at as though the reader cannot figure it out on her own - BAH!!!!!  The characters end up flat and ho-hum.  I so enjoyed the first two books but given this ending would not recommend reading any of them.
can't wait till they make the movie about this book I could not stop reading I enjoyed it so much
I liked this book of the trilogy best of all.  Even though the ending is sad, the ending was great.

I am not going to even address the end... It didn't need to happen that way, it could have been different, it wasn't, I have accepted it.Moving on! She adds soooo much plot with not enough time to fully cover it. If there was one more book then this might have worked. Plot would have developed, characters would have developed.She took risks with the ending and it appears it didn't pay off.I know relationships in books have to have rocky spots but I feel like Tobias and tris's lives are rocky enough that they didn't need that useless rocky patch.I would give this book a one star but she did bring in an interesting plot just didn't have time to fully delve in.Blah... I probably won't suggest this series to others any more and it used to be the first thing I would suggest people to read...Disappointed...
summary: Too much plot additions, too many risks

reviewText: I am very surprised that a book from the young adult section could so thoroughly consume me. Well written, wonderful concept and several detailed characters.I was sad to see the series end yet I thoroughly enjoyed the ending as it was not at all what I expected.
I have no idea why this book got such terrible reviews by everybody. Yeah it's different, no it's not more of the same, yes it ends the series. What else do you want? Stop complaining!

this book was a great ending for divergent. I wasn't expecting the ending but that's what made the book creative. I would have made both the main characters die so that one didn't have to live in Great Depression of the life that is now gone. I think that this book was at some points scary and others boring, but it was really a great book. I can't wait to read other books by Veronica Roth.

THERE WILL BE NO SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW.It's been said that the ending is controversial. My daughter and I have been reading these books together. I finished first.  I suggested to her that she not finish and whatever way she thinks it ends to walk away with that thought. I know that's almost impossible to do and so did she. She finished it and she and her friends didn't like it much either, though clearly I had the more visceral reaction. It reminded me of The Dark Tower Series by Stephen King. Another really unexpected and disappointing ending. At least he had the courtesy of pausing and telling the reader "my ending is not your ending "(more or less what I told my daughter) and I didn't heed his warning any more than my daughter did mine.  In the end it's the authors story to tell but I just don't see why she made some if the choices she did. I finished these books not wanting to read anything more by Veronica Roth. All just a matter of taste and as an avid reader I probably have a "type". This was it until Allegiant.
summary: Disappointing way to finish an interesting dystopian series

reviewText: Allegiant followed it's predecessors path quite nicely. I won't get into the spoilers, but I think it wraps up the series quite nicely. If you have read the whole series the ending makes perfect sense. I was proud of Roth for doing what needed to be done there.Yes, there were some holes in the story you could drive a truck through, but I don't mind them so much. I expect some of that from reading YA. We're not talking about Tolkien or Austen here.I was not so thrilled about the constantly shifting POV, but I can tell you from a teacher's perspective, it will make a great mentor text for that.This is not your "Harry Potter lives no matter how stupid he is" series, so why should it have that ending.Go Veronica!
The third book in the trilogy was good but not a s good as the other two. Still a good read.

So happy I was able to complete this series. I waited months for the final book and it was worth it.I had to wait a few months so I had to go back and refresh myself with some of the details but it all came back pretty quickly.  If you haven't read the Divergent series I'd suggest reading them one after another much like you would read 'Hunger Games'.Others have, and will, summarize the story line and they'll do a much better job of that than I ever could. From an average reader's point of view - all of the books in the series were very good and this final book won't disappoint you.
I bought the Divergent trilogy, read them all. At times I thought it was torture to continue reading. I do not recommend them
I loved it! The end was so sad... wish it was a different ending with them together, but it was still the best book in the series! :)  Can't wait for the movies!!! Gonna watch the premier. :D

This was one of the worst books I've ever read.  I simply don't have the energy to sit here and write an essay with pros and cons and observations and such....  So all I will say is this:  The ending; and what I mean by 'ending' is what happened to one of the main characters, did not bother me in the slightest, because the book was so completely and utterly annoying that if it wasn't written this way, I would be wishing that it had been.  The author is SO repetitive and has an extremely limited vocabulary.  (wiping the sweat off my hands, black spots clouding my vision, I'm so tiny and little) among others, are phrases that are used to the point of frustration.  The dual narrative was horrible.  Not because it was a dual narrative per se, but because the author was not good at it.  When you are writing for multiple characters you need to make sure they each have their own voice, their own personality, their own style of speaking and of thinking.  Tobias and Tris' dialogue were indistinguishable from one another.  In fact Tobias sounded SO MUCH like Tris, that he came off as effeminate, minimally, a bit of a pansy.  What self respecting Dauntless male, describes his mothers freakin' hairdo??  While the author did fine with male characters dialogues. (quotes) she did extremely poorly with the narrative, making this strapping male sound like a four foot girl.  The first book had a lot of promise, the second was even ok (though very repetitious descriptions) but by the third one I was so ready for this to be over so I could get on with my life and stop wasting my time.  I doubt that Hollywood will incorporate the writing flaws into the cinema version of this story so I will likely watch it, though I most definitely will not re-read the books, especially the third in this series.
summary: My honest short and sweet review of Allegiant

reviewText: Such a good book great series everyone should read this. Inspiring and he artful adventure love it has it all
I thought it started kind of slow but it got better the twist at the end was very unexpected I thought they would finally live in peace with no more violence or loss
I loved all of the story and I read all the books.  Very interesting story line, one thing I didn't like was the very end when Tris dies.

******WARNING, SPOILERS************I really didn't like the choice to have the story told from two different perspectives (Tris and Tobias), especially in the beginning when they were both doing the same thing anyway. But it definitely gave me an ominous feeling that it might be necessary later.One of my friends told me that she HATED the ending, so then I was thinking that both Tris and Tobias died, or they accidentally erased the whole city's memories, or something else crazy like that. As it turned out, it was just Tris. Of course, for the first 20 pages after she died, I didn't believe she could really be dead.But I didn't hate the ending. I thought it was well wrapped up and justified her death. There was a really good conclusion that seemed realistic and made me care that Tris died without thinking she died for nothing.The rest of the book, though, was just OK. I liked learning about the compound and the backstory for Chicago's current state. The plot itself was pretty good, except for the constant need to stop for Tris and Tobias to fight, or make out, or mope around about the state of their relationship.So this is a hard book to rate. I'll go 4 stars, -1 for the YA-ness of it all, total of 3.
summary: Didn't hate it, didn't love it.

reviewText: Although the ending to Allegiant was sad, it was also beautifully written and full of meaning. I won't say why it was sad, I've probably already given away too much.Like Insurgent, this book picks up right where the last one left off. Also, it's narrated by Tris and Tobias, which is awesome, if you ask me.

While Book 3 in the trilogy was as entertaining as the others in the Trilogy, its only weakness was the romance that further developed between Four/Tobias and Beatrice/Tris.  Rather than enhancing the story it was more of a distraction.  Realizing that these books were written for the teenage group, these parts of the books rang untrue, almost like it belonged in a novel about 1950's teens and not about teens who are separated from parents to be trained to serve the community in their respective factions.  When the factions are in jeopardy and certain individuals including Tris and Tobias are in survival mode their relationship plays more like  Frankie Avalon/Annette Funicello movie from the early 1960's than how actual teens, even today, would respond.  But, the conflicts and action as the characters in the book(s) respond to threats they face from all sides kept me turning the page to find out what happens to our hero and heroine, as well as their companions, next.  It's a wild ride and entertaining from page 1of Book 1 thorough the final page of Book 3.

A poignant story of America's future. The political ideology of today's administration makes this view a somber probability. the character of the protagonist conveys a feeling of hope for the re-emergence of the American way of life.
I just finished Allegiant and I can't stop crying its so sad. Why must life have no happy endings. Why. =::::(

Too many people were focused on the ending, and if you ask me, I hate cookie cutter happily ever after's anyway. Its about time someone took a risk. I really enjoyed getting the dual perspective this time around, I wish there were some spinoff book from Four's perspective of the first two books, because it really completes the story and helps the reader become more impartial instead of rooting for one character the entire time. My only complaint would be that there isn't a few more chapters (or a whole book, hint-hint) to sum up what happens in the city. There's just a barrel-full of aftermath left rotting in the basement, so to speak, and no ones going to touch it.
summary: It was great, so quit your whining

reviewText: I reread the first two books before reading this one. That was helpful, especially seeing so many negative reviews. Apart from the unexpected ending, it seems pretty consistent with the others. That is, choppy writing style, slow character development, plot and plot holes - but also original ideas. I say, well done Veronica Roth for your originality, I for one will look forward to your next lot of books.
I saw this book upon which an upcoming movie is being based and purchased it to see what was going on. It was only a few bucks to buy and read.
summary: Bought this easy read to see what the movie was going to be about.

reviewText: Too bad Ms Roth had to go and "John Wayne" our heroine at the end. A sequel or two would have held my interest. I've been pondering how to write this review after finishing Allegiant several days ago. I was a big fan of the previous two books and like so many other reviewers I counted the days until the release...but I really messed up and read a spoiler I hadn't intended to read, so I read the book knowing the ending. At first I was shocked, HATED the idea of the outcome, but I was able to read the book with a different perspective. I concentrated more on plot and character development, looking more closely to clues as to why Ms. Roth chose this ending. And, people, it is her RIGHT as the author to do so. I wanted to join in and hate it and bash it like so many others but I find I really can't. So much of what made Tris tick was pleasing her parents and family. Family ties was a huge theme throughout the book, even with Tobias, Tori, Christina, Uriah....Time and time again Tris would "hear" her parents' advice in her head. Saving Caleb was the ultimate selfless expression of her love for him, her obligation...I suspect Veronica Roth wanted to be remembered as the author who did NOT present us with a total happy ending..like Stephenie Myers did in Breaking Dawn, like Suzanne Collins did in Mocking Jay, like JK Rowling did with Harry Potter. But I feel like the shock ending only created the much needed drama that the mostly blah story line did not do. I sense she wanted to deliver a message to her YA audience about the hard knocks life presents you. But I also feel we readers could have been led to believe we had lost Tris, only to have her rehab out of sight and reappear....because we need those happy endings in our lives somewhere - what better place than in our dystopian/ fantasy series?So I  and so many others won't have that comfortable feeling a happy ending brings. It was still a good read

Allegiant was one of my anticipated books of 2013, I really didn't know how Veronica Roth could wrap up the series successfully. Allegiant was panned by fans and many fans felt that this book ruined the entire series for them. Then there's me, one of the few "black sheeps" who actually enjoyed this book and felt that it was extremely necessary that it ended this way.Allegiant is nearly impossible to describe because there's just so many subplots going on at the same time. At any given moment, there are at least 5 or 6 different storylines that Roth is telling and it's a bit overwhelming at times. This is definitely the most complicated of all of the books in the series and I guess it makes sense, given the fact that Roth needed to somehow conclude the series in a satisfying way.Finally readers will learn what being "divergent" really means for Tris and Four. Tris and Four's relationship is definitely tested in this one and there is a lot of bickering between the two. I just wanted them to make up and just resolve their differences; it does make sense that they are constantly on edge due to hectic nature of their lives. When there aren't fighting (which wasn't very often), there were some very sweet moments between the two. The romance in this one is pretty light, but we do get to see more of what's going on in Four's head.I completely understand why Veronica Roth decided to write in Tris and Four's point of views, but it wasn't up to par with the high quality writing that was evident in previous books. There were times when Tris and Four sounded way too similar and I had to flip back to the beginning of the chapter to find out whose point of view I was reading. There were other times when I had really enjoy Four's point of view because it was extremely revealing and it was completely unbarred. The reader slowly learns to understand why Four is such an enigmatic force and why he keeps himself so reserved from Tris. I really felt like Four's point of view was extremely vital to understanding who he is and how much he cares for Tris. I do wish that the writing was tighter in some of Four's chapters to make his voice more distinct for the reader.The side characters in Allegiant have been called undeveloped and unimaginative by so many reviewers, but I disagree. All of the secondary characters (both new and familiar faces) place an extremely important part in helping Four and Tris make decisions. The secondary characters help raise the stakes, they help Four and Tris realize that everything isn't going to end perfectly like they had hoped. Each character has their own specific purpose and rightful place in Allegiant, it was truly something special to see my favorite characters from the series interact with new characters.I have to address the way Allegiant ended because it's caused so much controversy  Veronica Roth received death threats after fans had read the ending. IT'S NEVER OKAY TO SEND SOMEONE DEATH THREATS, I thought that was common sense, but apparently not. The ending of Allegiant is so ballsy and was such a risky move on Veronica Roth's part; Roth had the guts to pull off something most authors wouldn't even dream of doing. This is why Roth has sold millions of books because she pushes the limits and is always creating ingenious plotlines. Anyway, I felt that this ending felt inevitable, Roth even said that she always felt like she knew it would end like this. After a bit of pondering, it all made sense to me and I felt like Roth had been leading up to this ending ever since Divergent. In fact, if you read Insurgent, there's tons of foreshadowing that hinted that Allegiant would end like this. Allegiant's ending felt necessary to me and I really feel that this is the ONLY ending that truly would have worked. While I didn't love the ending, I felt that Allegiant's conclusion was extremely effective.Though Allegiant is extremely slow-paced and slugs due to info-dumping, I really enjoyed the final installment in the Divergent trilogy. Allegiant didn't provide readers with the happily ever after that readers were looking for, instead it provided readers with an extremely realistic ending. As much as I would have loved Four and Tris to ride into the sunset on an unicorn, Allegiant had to end in such a manner. Allegiant has solidified my love for Veronica Roth's writing abilities and it ended on a satisfying note, in my mind. I really look forward to reading Roth's future books and I hope that Roth will continue to defy all odds with her incredible books. There's no denying that Veronica Roth is dauntless after reading Allegiant, it takes an extremely brave and daring individual to write an extremely controversial ending without fearing retaliation from fans.

Not the happily ever after that we might want, but that isn't life. The truth is, even if Tris had lived, it wouldn't be happily ever after. Her parents were still dead, her brother had still betrayed her, and her world was gone. The belief that some things are worth dying for was the point of the book. So, was it the best book in the series? No. But was it terrible and not worth reading. Not at all.

reviewText: I almost did the unthinkable for me which was to not read the last book in a series, this book. This is the third time this year I've waited for the final book of a trilogy, and it's the third time I've been let down by the author.  No plot at all, a point of view  by two characters who were indistinguishable, and a confusing explanation about the rise of the factions make this book one that is not only dull, but difficult to pick up and read.  Veronica Roth owed her readers much more than this book delivered.  However, I gave it a four-star rating because I do think she is an incredible writer who just fell far short of an anticipated mark this time.

I began reading Allegiant with a real sense of nervous anticipation.  Even though I had been a big fan of the first two novels in the series, it had been a good while since I had read them.  I didn't have the patience to go back and re-read, so off we went.  It didn't take long for me to get drawn back into the world of Tobias and Tris, factions, and terrible choices.  I had a hard time keeping track of some of the supporting characters, and this was the only thing that made me wish I had taken the time to re-read the first two books.I have no urge to ruin the plot by describing it here.  Many fans have been waiting on pins and needles to see what happens and they won't be disappointed.  There are surprises, twists and turns, and then even more twists and turns.  I was dazzled by the author's plotting skill as she laid out a careful web of deceits and half-truths that are sure to keep readers turning the pages, much as I did, looking for the truths that always seemed to lurking just beneath the surface of what our heroes were being told.This story is told in alternating chapters by both Tris and Tobias.  I will admit that I was not a fan of this method.  The author did not do a very good job of giving them distinctive voices, often leaving me confused as to who was speaking.  I believe this robbed the narrative of some of its energy, leading to a pace that was slow, and an overall tone that was far less suspenseful and dramatic than it should have been.While I admired the author's plotting skill as she introduced so many new elements, I did end up feeling that some were contrived.  She slipped into quite a bit of telling instead of showing, and if I hadn't been so interested in where she was going, I might have ended up feeling frustrated pretty early on.  As it was, I was captivated by the story and the society, and intrigued by the many ethical questions offered up in the book.  The author has a firm grip on the dystopian world she has created and uses it to widely explore questions of equality and free will.I was all set to assign a three star rating to Allegiant until I came to the last eighty pages or so.  The drama and emotion that was somewhat lacking in the book, came at me full force in an ending that was brave and exciting and totally unexpected.  Fans of the series should be well satisfied by this ending.  It's not perfect, however it's a very worthy end for a story that has garnered millions of fans and made us all think about the power of love and a single choice.
summary: A flawed but  worthy end to a powerful story

reviewText: First, I really loved the first two books.  The plot, twists, characters - just, fantastic.Second, I was really looking forward to the third book but was immediately thrown off by the point of view writing.  It felt natural for Tris since the first two books were solely from her point of view but Tobias?  It felt very superficial and unnatural and I wasn't able to relate at all to Tobias as a character this way.Third, there were so many plot holes and I feel as though so much was left unresolved.  I don't have a problem with a book/series that doesn't end with everything tied up with a neat little bow but this?  This was just poorly done.  Why bring characters through two books to just ditch them without any commentary in the third?  The writing was so uneven and the twists weren't fully explained so that by the time I got to the end of the book, I wondered if maybe some chapters had been accidentally deleted.  Or maybe this was written by a different author?As it is, I cannot recommend this as a trilogy.  I would recommend the first book as a stand-alone but wouldn't recommend two or three.

reviewText: I pretty much hated this book. So much of it felt tacked on, like the author had to write SOMETHING to finish it up. But THIS is what she came up with? It bore little relationship to the first 2 books of the trilogy, which I really enjoyed. I was irritated from the beginning, but my irritation really began to blossom with the introduction of Amar. Never mentioned in the prior 2 book, it's just almost casually mentioned: "Oh, he's the one that gave Four his name." WHAT? That's pretty significant, and it's clearly something she tacked on and never even thought of in the first 2 books. Veronica Roth, if you read this, I want to say: Go back and try it again. This was just terrible. And its terrible-ness has nothing to with the death of an important character.

This is probably my favorite book of the series because the format of storytelling changes, not perfectly but it was a well enough attempt. Each chapter flips between Tris and Tobias's (Four) perspective. Also the story takes a twist, like a Joss Whedon movie when it goes outside the city. With this twist the story could have gone on with a few more books perhaps but maybe the author was tired of the characters and story so wrapped it up here. Other things I liked about the last book is that the characters are maturing, however, in the end, the thing that makes half the readers unhappy with this book is the concept of change, ultimate love, and sacrifice. None of which Tris or Tobias has yet to experience but yet go through the motions of living. Maybe if they had a younger brother or sister, or maybe after they have their own kids would this concept be more acceptable. Though I didn't find this as bothersome, I think there was ample opportunity to extend the story, but what I felt a little cheated because the ending wraps up too neatly and cleanly, all of a sudden all is well in the world and only sadness and moving on remains and everyone is depressed and sad, the fight is gone. It happened way too fast without much exposition.Some points I agree with from other readers...There is no difference in between Tris and Tobias between chapters, it's difficult to tell them apart, it is all one voice.The ending wraps up too neatly and cleanly.The bigger world was given to us but it could have been bigger and the story longerOverall, a good book but I can think of a few ideas that would have kept the series going in and outside the factions. The characters could have developed further rather than putting them all in a situation that they accept willingly after fighting so hard for their own concept of individuality. And what happened to the Divergent? Why are they not involved as much in the books when in the bigger picture, it's all about them? Where is the crowds and crowds of Divergent that have been hiding? Anyhow... perhaps there's more to come perhaps not but this saga ends here.
summary: good book in the series but ending is too clean and neat

While I felt it was awkward at first how the POV changed between Tris and Four and I wasn't happy with the outcome (I don't want to spoil it although others already have - I'll let them spoil it for you), I can't imagine how else to end this book. The changing POV is necessary so we can better understand how the main characters process their thoughts and to further tell the story... without that changing POV throughout the book, the ending would be very awkward. Of course, a happy ending is always desirable, but anyone who has read the other two books knows that a happy ending isn't in store for this book. I still walked away with a warm feeling in my heart, but at the same time I am left wondering what happens to the remaining characters. I would love it if Ms. Roth could write an alternate ending to the book that doesn't involve the loss of such a dominant character, one that gives us that happy ending we crave. I loved this series enough and was so saddened when it ended (not b/c of how it ended, but b/c my time with the characters was over) that I ordered the other 5 supplemental books. I can't get enough of Tris and Four and I absolutely cannot wait to see the movie (especially considering who they cast as Four!) To have others see her sacrifice and use it as an example to not make stupid mistakes ever? Or What? I don't even know myself... Wish it was better.

reviewText: I have to preface this by saying that I LOVED the first two books of this series.  I felt like this third book was written hurriedly, with little thought given to character development or depth.  I just didn't feel a real connection to ANY of the new characters outside of the city and many of the characters from inside the city seemed to become more shallow. And the ending (spoiler alert) was horrid.  Not only killing off one of the main characters...but then there just didn't seem to be any good way to wrap it up, so it just rattled on for a couple chapters with Tobias trying to figure out how to live without Tris?!?  I can think of about 30 ways that this could have ended that could have been more meaningful, less wasteful and more worth reading.  I'm not even convinced that Tris had to live...sometimes a main character has to die (because they are just too injured/mentally traumatized to continue)...but there should have been a better way to wrap it up, for Tobias to find out, for him to grieve her death. reviewText: Allegiant is definitely stirring up feelings and strong reactions among Divergent series fans. I tried to avoid reading reviews until I read the book but even just scrolling through my social media feeds, I could see something severe was going to happen.  I had an idea of what it might be, and while I was on the right track, I didn’t quite guess it.  This is going to be a spoiler-free review.I really liked the explanations in the beginning of Allegiant after the group went outside Chicago’s city limits. The truth about the factions in Chicago and the existence of the Divergent made so much sense to me. That part got scientific and I enjoyed that. I liked that this was a smart book. I always wondered why the scenario with the factions was going on only inside Chicago. While reading the first book I wondered whether the rest of the country still existed in this world, or if it was all a wasteland with Chicago being the last with a civilization. So I found the additional world building in Allegiant to be very satisfying.However, the remainder of the book, leading up to the epic ending, was very political and a bit dull with all the strategy and discussions. I get that it was necessary, but it dragged for me. I also had a lot of anxiety since I knew something awful was going to happen, but I didn’t know what or when. I had even more anxiety when I realized what was going to happen, and that it was going to happen soon.The relationship between Tris and Tobias went through some tests in this book but the two of them are so strong together that I believed that they could work through anything.  I did like how Tobias was less than perfect in this book. In the past he always seemed to be the best at everything, to me at least, so I liked to see him being more vulnerable. Though, the ending was more than anyone should have to endure.So, that ending. On one hand it makes perfect sense. I wouldn’t have expected anything less from this character (no spoilers here). But on the other hand… OMG!! Yes, it was an epic way to end the trilogy, but was it truly necessary? The end goal would have been accomplished with or without that something awful, even if the author says it was in the plan all along (you can read about it on her blog, but DO NOT read it if you haven’t read the book yet unless you want the ending spoiled). I do agree that this character’ journey throughout this series was leading up to this decision, and this choice really did define this character. BUT, making that choice was the defining moment in this character’s development. The actual outcome could have been different and wouldn’t have changed the strength of that choice. Yes, that epic ending was powerful and so so painful. And yes, that makes this ending so dramatic. But I don’t agree that it was absolutely necessary. I’m just going to leave it at that.

Yes, questions were answered in regards to the city's factioned existence and the history of the destruction.  But the whole premise wasn't entirely satisfying.  It was another bureaucracy trying to control a population by any means necessary.  And more rebellions against the big bad government, since no one can be satisfied with their station no matter what excuse is provided.Don't even get me started on the ending.  Now I understand why Roth angered so many of her readers.  Changing her narrative device made sense after the conclusion, but it really ruined the flow. reviewText: I really wanted to like these books.  I really did.  But they were really lacking in my opinion.  Veronica Roth goes from building a story from the point of view of "Tris" in the first two books to randomly splitting it between Tris and her boyfriend(?) Four.  It was very confusing and hard to follow with just this alone.  Throughout all 3 books Tris and Four flirt with physical and emotional intimacy but they act like emotional, stupid teenagers (which they are) but they are represented as being "adult" in this society that they live in.  It's frustrating to read the stupid actions and thoughts that they go through with one another.  Then, the ending is a complete letdown.  Not only do Tris and Four never get their life together, (SPOILER ALERT) Tris dies! Seriously?! Something that the story had built up that she didn't need to do.  It felt very unnecessary and very blah (only word that comes to my mind at the moment). If you have any interest in romance, love and the reality of how two teenagers behave around one another when alone, half naked and attracted to each other, then don't read this.  Some of the story was good but ultimately it felt like the author was just trying to create a bunch of martyrs and a meaning that just didn't live up to the goal.

I loved the style of writing but  felt the author could have pushed the characters more to easier distinguish the narrator.  While I don't mind that style of writing, Too often I found myself having to flip back to the beginning of the chapter to determine who was speaking. As the one and only negative I found with this book, I will admit  this is the first book that I have ever highlighted an entire page on my kindle.  The series resonated with me as I associate with both Trish and Four.  I find the change in Four completely believable and even necessary to portray. I loved that it wasn't an easy transition for either character and was out a book's typical norm but rarely does life create easy or expected results especially at first. Day and Night both have beauty but its when they meet that the true beauty of the two shines like nothing else. Four and Tris had beauty in strength, character, etc but it wasn't until the darker or less appealing sides became visible that you could really see it.  Some people are able to acknowledge those negative traits without allowing them to take control and some people sadly never overcome them. (ex. without spoilers-the one that took the memory serum) Some can't face or acknowledge any negativity and therefore stall never moving forward even if they aren't going backwards. They will never know how strong and beautiful they could be if they would push through. Not to say that everyone can do it alone, which I think was addressed in Allegiant. For all the physical and mental strength that Four had, he couldn't accept all of himself and therefore was weak even if nobody saw it. It wasn't until he came full circle to really see this side of him and allow others to see and help that he became truly strong. Some people found the plot holes as a negative but I don't agree. I liked the author's lack of details. It wasn't clear as to how things changed or why people accepted the way things were without question for generations. Yet I think that is one of the major points of the book. Things happen in the world that baffle people every day yet do these same people take action or sit idly by allowing change to gradually happen whether good or bad. In Allegiant the sculpture was a prime example of this. Tris's view of the sculpture was different than that of the scientists but just as valid. I will even take it one step farther by saying just as the water was slowly changing the stone below one drip at a time, future viewers may not realize the stone's original appearance was drastically different. The ones that were present to see the slow change may be so accustomed to it that they don't even realize or acknowledge it happening or remember the original beauty without proof. Hopefully now you can understand my acceptance of the author not filling in all the plot holes in a less abstract way as I  am quite capable of filling them in myself. For me it was more important to learn the above lesson than to know the exact who's, what's, or ifs. Some reviews disliked the science of the book. The were caught up in the impossibilities found throughout which I can see cumbersome to some but for me I was able to believe for the sake of the story. In the end, I found the book  inspiring without preaching, suggestive of self worth but not love of self,  thoughtful teaching of the different dynamics of relationships, and proof that things are not always as they seem. Beyond that I found the best ending isn't always the one we want but what we do with it that makes the difference.

reviewText: First of all, I loved Divergent. It was fast paced and full of action and drama and surprises. Insurgent was also action packed. I loved the conflict and the growth of the characters. Now, my mistake was reading Allegiant, but in my defence, I didn't know what I was getting myself into (just like everybody else).Okay, I had really high expectations for this book, especially since it was the LAST ONE of this series. At first, I liked it and I liked how Roth gave us insight to both Tobias and Tris' point of views. However, when they went through that gate and out of the city, the story took on a different turn for me. At first I didn't like it at all but then it became tolerable after a while. I didn't like how we really had no clear idea of what was going on inside the city with the Allegiant and the Factionless. Just little snapshots on a screen in the monitoring room or wherever it was.I felt like I kind of lost sight of Tobias' character in this book and actually had to substitute his name for Four to remind myself of the tough, tattooed Dauntless trainer that he was.Throughout the entire series I admired Tris for her outstanding bravery, I really did. I thought, "Wow. She is BRAVE."  Saying that, I'm just going to skip to what really pissed me off about this book: Her death.First of all, WHAT THE ****!! Okay, just had to get that out. Roth is obsessed with killing people!! Oh my goodness! I can't even count the deaths in all the books combined! I mean, she killed so many people it literally stressed me out, and that was before she killed off Tris terribly and pointlessly but we're getting to that.I couldn't understand why she killed so many people. Al, Will, Tris' mom and dad, half the Abnegation, Lynn, Marlene, a little boy in the elevator, Eric, TORI (what was that??? And then to bring in her brother afterwards?! That was awful. I was saying "Oh God" along with Tobias when George showed up all excited to see his sister who Roth killed off for really no reason at all) Fernando (I liked him! Ugh) Edward, Uriah (Why. Just why. He bought light to this semi-depressing series!! And died right after Tris too), Jeanine. Just so many characters dead. Dead dead dead. I was literally applauding anyone who was still alive by the last book. Especially Christina.Now, before I get to Tris I want to talk about Will's death. In my opinion, I think it was made into a bigger deal than it should have. I mean, Will wasn't really a strong, memorable character and it didn't seem like he and Christina had THAT strong of a bond, nor him and Tris. I mean, I can understand some mourning but having nightmare's and being afraid to hold a gun and all just took it a little too far in MY eyes.Okay, now to Tris' death. Three words:What. Was. That.Throughout the ENTIRE SERIES Tris escaped death SO MANY TIMES and always managed to come out of a near death situation triumphant. That was one of things about her that kept me on my toes. I wasn't really surprised when she took Caleb's place, and I was so glad when she resisted the death serum by finding that 'fire' and that will to live. I was like, 'Yeah!!! :D'And then, ta da! Here's David in his little wheelchair and gun. I was like.. oookaay. Why are you here?Tris and David exchange some words which really weren't important and then Tris lunges for the box to type in the code and.... gets shot by David! After escaping execution from Jeanine, jumping from a train when she first joined Dauntless, jumping to the net, Eric almost killing her twice, dodging bullets left to right in all three books and escaping guards. Heroic, brave Tris conquers the impossible death serum only to be killed by freaking David and his bullets.WHAT EVEN. I was psychologically distressed and still am. I am mentally exhausted and want to sleep so that I can forget what I just read. I am so disappointed in Roth. She killed SO MANY characters i guess that it only seemed fitting that she killed Tris too, right? Well at least give her a GOOD ENDING.And why does her mom show up? Hallucination or not. Where's her dad? Does her mom have special powers in the after- life? I couldn't believe how the Tris that I admired and looked up to met her end. NO. NOOO!I loved Tobias but now (and I'm sad to say, I really am) he's just whatever. Yeah go to your house and cut your hair and try to forget everything when Christina magically shows up and stops you from taking that memory serum. Way to go Christina.I feel like her character changed from the first book until now. Not evolved, not grew, but simply changed and not in a good way. Like we lost touch with the witty, mouthy Candor turned Dauntless girl. Maybe it was her grief or whatever. And I don't know why Roth didn't just kill Peter since she saw it fitting to kill all the GOOD CHARACTERS like Uriah and Marlene and so on. He had no purpose except for in Divergent, to add some drama. Other than that he could have zip-lined to Mexico for all I cared. Bye Peter!My main frustration with this book was Tris' unjust ending and my frustration with the series was Veronica killing people from left to right. It IS a thrilling series, don't get me wrong, but this book in particular? No. I think the ending even made some of my hair fall out but I'm not sure. It was just. so. stressful. And no one needed Tris and Tobias arguing like that in the last two books. I mean, I know all couples have their disagreements but if you really get down to the root of Four, he didn't strike me as the type to stand there and argue and chastise over and over again.My last thoughts: Marcus was a prick, Evelyn was unstable and gave in too easily to Tobias when it seemed that she was hell-bent on controlling the city, Nita was a pointless character. And the whole GP and GD and the Fringe was just a big mess. But props to Veronica because (excluding this book) she created a pretty thrilling series.

3.5 stars.*Warning: mild spoilers*Allegiant is such a difficult book to rate.  It took me a while to decide on a rating, but in the end I decided on 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4.  If it weren't for the ending, though, this would probably be 3 stars.Okay, so what happened to the amazing writing in Divergent and Insurgent?  Those books were fast-paced, action-packed, and had strong characters.  And I felt like Allegiant was lacking slightly in all those areas.  The pacing was weird, making me occasionally bored with the plot.  There was a fair amount of action, but there was also too much useless, boring dialogue between the characters.  And what happened to the formerly kick-butt Tobias?  While I still liked Tris in Allegiant, Tobias was more wimpy than he was in the previous books.  His POV and Tris's were way too similar.Still, there were definitely moments in Allegiant that I appreciated.  I love the minor characters; they each stand out in their own way.  There are a couple adorable Tris/Tobias scenes.  Mostly, though, I love how Roth writes about relationships.  I love the tension between Tris and her brother, Caleb, and how Tris has to decide the importance of family and how far she'll go to save her family and friends.  I thought their brother/sister bond was written very realistically.  There's quite a few quotes that I loved, too.  Roth writes beautifully about the meaning of bravery and sacrifice.I'm still in shock over the ending.  I disliked it at first, even though it made sense and was very fitting.  But now, I have to say that, as sad as the ending is, I do like it.  I admire Roth for that ending; it took guts to write that.  It's very heartbreaking and actually moved me to tears, but I'm happy with it.  Not every dystopian has to have a happily-ever-after ending, and Roth has proved that.Although Allegiant didn't hold my attention as much as the previous books, I still found it to be a thought-provoking and enjoyable read.  I can't wait to see what Veronica Roth writes next!

I finished this last night and afterwards I felt just dead inside. I absolutely hate when a series ends leaving me feeling unsatisfied and even, in this case, angry. I feel kind of betrayed by the author.I loved Divergent. The book had its faults, but I really fell in love with the whole story, the characters, the romance between Tris and Four, the Factions, etc. I read and re-read Divergent probably 8-10 times. I bought the audio book version as well. I was SO PSYCHED about the movie! I bought Insurgent and devoured it as well. It didn't have quite the same magic for me that Divergent did, but I still loved it. So I was REALLY psyched to read Allegiant.And maybe my hopes were too high.I don't know.That doesn't change the fact that this book utterly and completely disappointed me.SPOILERS AHEADFor real, SPOILERS!READ AT YOUR OWN RISK![**What's outside the fence?**I was really excited, after reading the 'cliffhanger' ending to Insurgent, to find out what was outside the fence. I had my theories, and I was right about some, wrong about others. I was expecting the cameras and Truman Show-esque thing, but I was not expecting all the genetic manipulation crap. As soon as our heroes get outside the fence, there are chapters and chapters of info dumping and, to be honest, it's kind of dull. We learn that Chicago (and some other cities) were created as 'experiments' because of genetic manipulation gone wrong. Supposedly these cities were an attempt at creating more 'genetically pure' people (aka Divergents). This is so far-fetched and bizarre, but I was willing to go along with it.**Tris and Four**I wasn't against the dual perspective, though once I finished the book I realized why she HAD to write it in a dual perspective. However, I don't think it was done well. There were several times where I would get halfway through a chapter and not remember who I was in the head of at the time, mostly because the two narrators had identical voices.Tris has always been an interesting character to me. I really liked that she was tough, but a little vulnerable and naive. I liked her progression through Divergent and Insurgent. She doesn't really progress much here. We've always known Tris is a selfless person who is more than willing to sacrifice herself for the greater good, or for her loved ones. That doesn't change here. More on that later. She does become kind of arrogant and holier-than-thou here, and it really started to bug me. She's 16, but she often acts (and everyone treats) her like a grown-up. She is pretty much always right in Allegiant and she makes sure everyone knows it.Four was awesome in Divergent. He loses all of that awesomeness in Allegiant. He becomes quite whiny and pathetic to the point where I actually wanted Tris to break up with him. She probably should have, considering some of the stupid and completely out of character stuff he does. I really hated seeing him reduced to this quivering mess of a boy who does nothing but wax poetic about his mommy and daddy issues. Four was always strong, and he is the polar opposite of that here.I did enjoy the progression of their relationship though. Some people have complained about the scene where Four accuses Tris of being jealous, but I actually liked it. I like that they, FOR ONCE, acted like TEENAGERS. Unfortunately that was a tiny part of this book, and for the rest of it they act like 30-40 year old worldly adults.**THE END OF THE CONFLICT**So we have Four's mother Evelyn running Chicago like a factionless tyrannical dictatorship. Johanna and Marcus running the Allegiant, trying to reinstate the factions.Evelyn has been portrayed as a nearly heartless person, hell bent on making all the Factioned people clean toilets like the Factionless had to do for so many years. At the height of the conflict, she is willing to allow a "Death Serum" to kill pretty much everyone in Chicago in order to avoid going back to the Factions. This is when Four arrives and says "Hey Mom, I'll be your son again if you stop acting like a monster" and she goes "Okay."She then negotiates with Marcus and Johanna. Marcus wants to take over as evil dictator and Johanna says "Nah, you're not gonna do that" and Marcus just says "Okay."Conflict over.WHAT?WHAT????????????**Mass Murder**Roth has not shied away from killing off characters in the first two books, but I felt like most of that had a purpose. Tris' parents in the first book, Al (due to the guilt over his own actions towards Tris), Jeannine in Insurgent, and more. Deaths in Allegiant come just as rapidly and have even less meaning. Tori dies in a very sudden manner, and then is mostly forgotten about. She was referred to as the leader of the Dauntless, but she is killed and then is nothing more than an afterthought for the rest of the book.Uriah's death is given a lot more page time, but only as a way to make Four feel like total garbage for getting involved in the rebellion and to make Tris "right" once again.The biggest death of all was Tris, and this was the biggest disappointment to me. I will be straight up honest - I LIKE a happy ending. I read YA because I like knowing that things will most likely end up happy overall. I read romance because I know there will always be a happily ever after. HOWEVER, I can deal with a bittersweet ending so long as it feels satisfying and feels like closure.Tris' death was NOT that ending.Caleb's betrayal was a huge part of Insurgent, and that continues on in Allegiant. He has a LOT to atone for in Allegiant and when he volunteers for the suicide mission to help save everyone, he does it because he wants Tris to forgive him. And he doesn't want to live with the guilt of what he did. Instead of letting him, Tris forces him to let her go instead. I understand this. Tris forgave him and doesn't want him to die because he feels guilty. I get it.HOWEVERCaleb doesn't get that opportunity to redeem himself. While I understand that Tris acted the way she had to act, that doesn't mean Caleb can't take a bullet for her. That doesn't mean he can't force a redemption. Instead, Tris dies in a completely unsatisfying scene that left me going "WHAT THE HECK JUST HAPPENED?" Caleb lives and basically still is the coward and traitor.Caleb NEEDED to redeem himself. He needed to take that bullet for Tris and die.Instead, we get this messed up ending where Caleb lives. Peter lives (gets his mind erased BY HIS OWN CHOICE and gets to start over). Marcus lives (just disappears somehow). David (Tris' murderer) lives (also gets his mind erased and even though he's an evil murderer, no one cares because he doesn't remember). Almost all the bad guys live and get to have perfectly happy, normal lives.This is NOT SATISFYING.THIS IS POINTLESS.Sorry, but this book was awful. I wanted to love it. I REALLY wanted to love it. I was willing to deal with all the weird genetically damaged stuff. I was willing to deal with the complete dismantling of Four's character. I was willing to deal with a lot, but Tris' pointless and needless death... NOPE. This death felt like it was here for shock value only. So the author could be "edgy" and "different."Unfortunately, all she did for me is ruin the entire series. I won't be re-reading Divergent or Insurgent anymore. I won't be re-reading Allegiant. And I definitely won't be seeing the movies that I was once so excited for. Knowing how depressingly it ends ruins it all for me

Tris is so absolutely mesmerizing, she captured me from the moment I read the first word of Divergent.  With Tobias by her side, I knew they were capable of anything!This book and entire trilogy was absolutely amazing!  Excellent Veronica Roth! I have no idea why the Divergent series has become such a hit.  I found the first book boring and the last one incredibly flat.  Only the second one, Insurgent, held my interest at all.  I couldn't believe my reaction to these books, since the rest of the country seems to think they're spectacular.  After reading The Hunger Games series, which I couldn't put down and loved like no other fiction I've ever read, I had heard that the Divergent series was supposed to be the next coming of The Hunger Games.  That's why I read it.  But, as I did, I kept waiting for things to happen, like they did in nearly every chapter of THG, but very little did.  Everytime it seemed like it was building to some conflict or danger, everything just petered out.  And the teaser that there was some incredible horror "beyond the fence" never paid off.  Don't even get me started on the ending, which I won't talk about due to spoiler issues.  I just found the entire series much ado about nothing and wish I knew what the appeal is to other readers.

I must admit that I was frustrated and annoyed the entire time I was reading Allegiant.  I thoroughly enjoyed both Divergent and Insurgent.  I found the plots to be exciting and the characters to be well developed and edgy.  In Allegiant, Roth tries to tell the story in first person part of the time. She switches off between Tris and Tobias, one chapter will be Tris---the next Tobias.  This makes the flow of the story very hard to follow at times.  Also, while I believe Roth's intent was to give us an opportunity to get in touch with the feelings of these two character, I believe the first person style has the opposite effect.  The characters, especially Tris, suddenly seem to be whiny little seventh graders instead of strong, self-assured leaders of Dauntless.  The plot was decent, although it was difficult to follow at times because of the switching back and forth between Tris and Tobias.  And the ending----don't even get me started on that!!  Yes, it made logical sense, but Roth did Caleb such a disservice as a character when she chose that ending.  I'm glad to be done with it.  I will not reread it, nor will I see the movie!

reviewText: This, the third book in the trilogy, ties up all the loose ends; the story behind the forming of the factions, why some people were "divergent" and what the purpose behind the factions was.  I read all three books one after the other so for two months these characters were part of my reading life.  As weird as this sounds, I truly cared about these characters, especially Tris and Tobias.  Reading this last installment in the series really left me feeling satisfied that everything that went on before was all for a specific reason.Even though these book are targeted for older teens, I recommend the trilogy for everyone because the writing and character development is superb.  I did not want this book to end and actually am missing these characters.

Being that this is the last book of the series, I won't worry about spoilers. I am unsure of how I feel about this final chapter. It really didn't go in the direction I thought it would. It definitely stopped reminding me of The Hunger Games, except in that I was left not really liking or completely hating the conclusion of this series, just like I did with the conclusion of The Hunger Games.I guess what I liked about the final chapter of this series is that the overall message of the series is that despite our differences, people are people, and there is no success in trying to get them to conform to a linear way of life. Life is constantly evolving and when you try to stop that natural progression, evolution will always find a way. I also liked the fact that with each of the books Tris' growth was in the forefront. There is no doubt she was meant to be the hero of this series. Her lack of self-preservation and unbounded courage is something to aspire to, albeit maybe not so recklessly.Now for what I didn't like. I really didn't like the whole "genetic damage v. genetic pure" debate that is all too prevalent in Allegiant. I know this is a fictional story but I couldn't help feeling angry because no matter how you slice it, it is a discriminatory concept. When I got to this point in the book, I finally understood why so many people were not happy with Allegiant. I also didn't like the almost dictatorship-like political hierarchy "The Bureau" had over everyone's lives. This whole "serum" business and unnecessary elimination of life was annoying aggravating.So I guess the best way to summarize how I felt about Allegiant, on its own, is to say that I hated to like it. But to summarize the series as a whole, I liked that I was left questioning the right & wrongness of it all.

reviewText: There are a lot of detailed reviews out there, and I don't want to be overly repetitive. My biggest gripes are actually not the phenomenal fail of an ending, but more structural issues throughout.First, like many others, I *LOVED* Divergent. And Insurgent was one I devoured but didn't love as much. But Allegiant was a complete and total disappointment.As many have said, it was nearly impossible to tell Tris and Tobias apart. Doesn't help that their names are so close visually, so a cursory glance at the chapter title doesn't suffice--you have to really look, and then keep reminding yourself through each chapter. But I do not remember this being an issue before. So....what happened????The science. I have a college degree in biology. Not a PhD, but I do have a BS and my favorite topic of study was genetics. What it boils down to is this:You cannot regain "genetic purity" by putting a  bunch of "genetically damaged" people in isolation and encourage them to interbreed. Oh, wait--they don't even really encourage it. You see, the factions are so bent on staying pure to themselves, most people stay within their faction and breed among the same population of people with the same genetic damage. It might be different if the law were that you HAD to CHANGE factions and breed with other factions.But really, the best thing would be to let those people breed with the "pure" population and water down the "bad" genes.Or, as others have mentioned, if this society has the tech to extract genes from humans, they have the tech to insert them, too. Also, most scientists these days ALREADY KNOW that genes very rarely work in isolation, so they would have known extracting genes for one thing would affect other things.Anyway, my science background is getting in the way here. So let's talk story.Again, the voice was an issue. Also, the character reactions were inconsistent. Places where there should have been MAJOR conflict, or at least inner conflict, were glossed over, and other places where the characters should have been more logical they got all emotional.Plot: No. Just no. None of it made any sense to me. The serums for everything, the way these people go about it all, the explosions. No, these people have access, and are hacker types and scientist types and they would have been much more sneaky and would have USED THE SERUMS THEY HAD on the guards and David in private and there would have been no death from explosions. Not to mention the timing of everything. The moment Tris or Tobias learned of a plan, it was immediately implemented.The pacing was all wrong, too. Long stretches of theological-disguised-as-sociological discussion broken up with bits of violence and/or kissing. I won't get much into the Christian message of this book, but it doesn't work. I'm a Christian, and I felt preached at through the whole thing, although there were times when I wasn't entirely sure *what* was being preached.Let me finish this off by saying this: I feel awful writing this review. I wanted SO badly to love this book. I respect the author and her talent that is obvious in Divergent. But I had to have my say on this one. I wish I were raving about it.

The Divergent series by Veronica Roth is easily on par with the Hunger Games for me.  I could NOT wait to get my hands on the final installment of the series and pre-ordered it from Amazon. The book continues to fall Tris and Tobias (AKA Four, man of my dreams) on their quest for freedom and truth in the dystopian society they live in.In Allegiant, the factions have been dissolved, but the citizens of Chicago now find themselves slaves to a new tyrant who enforces their "freedom", Tobias' own mother Evelyn. Tobias, Tris, and their friends make their way out of the city to find a surprising new world where they finally learn a truth that will change everything they believe.So what do I love so much about this book? So many things. Seriously.1. Tris and Tobias. There is no love triangle in this series. Praise God. They have a solid relationship that faces challenges other than a third person getting in the way.... Instead they have to deal with lying, trust issues, and forgiveness. A lot of this stems from Tris' previous errors in the relationship. "Remember when I teamed up with your abusive father to basically end the world as we know it?" You know, the usual.  However, Tobias brings his own challenges in this book which makes it clear that they have an equal and truly loving relationship.2. The point of view.  Unlike the first two books which were told solely from Tris' perspective, Allegiant alternates between Tris and Tobias. This switch adds another dimension to the story-telling, and makes the resolution much more poignant.3. Action.  There are some great action scenes that do not drag on or distract from the story line... instead they add to the storytelling and allow us to see the true nature of our heroes.4. SPOILER. BIGGEST SPOILER EVER. DO NOT READ THIS SECTION. DANGER, DANGER WILL ROBINSON!!!!!Are you still reading? Take a breath. Tris dies. YES. I really admire Roth's bravery in killing off the main hero that we have rooted for over the course of three books. Honestly, it seemed like the only fitting ending. Tris finds in herself the courage to face death, even when she has so much to live for, to protect all the people that she loves. Even those that may not deserve it. She is innately good, despite the society that has tried to turn her into something else.  It turns out that she has more Abnegation in her than she maybe even thought. The last several chapters are told only from Tobias' viewpoint, which is especially touching.Overall, Allegiant is a beautiful, fast reading story of friendship, love, and redemption.... with a little dystopian drama thrown in for good measure. If you're into the Hunger Games or other dystopian fiction, I highly recommend this series. And make sure you start reading the first book before the movie comes out!

There were so many other options here. I felt like it was a cheap shot for shock value. And what the deuce happened to the story line??? The entire series was building up to a faction and faction-less war. Instead, the author went with a completely different dystopian story line...genetically damaged and genetically pure? This is the final book in the Divergent trilogy. You can see my review for the first and second book on my blog (KDH Reviews).First, let's talk about the point of view of this book. The first two books are told exclusively from Tris's point of view. This book, however, is told from the POV of both Tris and Four. In general, I like seeing a story from multiple points of view, but not always. This is one of those cases. I didn't like the switch up. I would have preferred sticking to one point of view.Let's discuss the good parts of the book. One, we get answers. We learn about the city and what's happened in the world. These are answers we've been waiting for since the beginning of the trilogy. Second, I enjoyed the ending. Allegiant has an ending that's polarizing. Some people will love it and some people will hate it. After everything that's happened, I liked it. It was fitting.Now, let's get on with the not so good parts. One, this book moved so incredibly slow. Compared to the first two books, Allegiant moves at a snail's pace. It bordered on boring, if I'm completely honest. Two, this book kind of left the entire trilogy feeling mediocre to me.Overall, I don't really know why there's so much hype surrounding this trilogy. Yeah, it's good, but it's *not* that good. I expected more and am left feeling disappointed. I don't blame the books (they are worth reading), but all the hype surrounding them.Be sure to check out all of my reviews on my blog, KDH Reviews.

I always hate to see a favorite series (in this case, trilogy) go while at the same time I love to see how everything is going to end up. Before I managed to finish this book I knew that there was some controversy about it and I know there are plenty of people unsatisfied with what happened. Though I have to say this book ripped my heart out and made me cry more than I'd like to admit, I still can't see the sense in disliking it because of that.I absolutely loved the first book of this series, Divergent, and didn't like Insurgent as much as that. I think that I like this third book more than I liked the second one. It was just so much more interesting to me and I loved not knowing what would happen next. I can't say anything specific without giving away spoilers but be satisfied knowing that there are very cute scenes and scenes filled with action and suspense.That said, I didn't get the same heart-pounding feel I had through most of Divergent until I got to maybe the last third of the book. But I loved the pacing in this, even though some scenes felt very unnecessary. I liked being able to see more of the characters from other books in calmer settings, not just when they're about to get killed. The theme of forgiveness that was strong in the first two books makes its return here in new but equally heartbreaking ways.I did like hearing from both Tris and Four in this book. However, I didn't like how similar their voices were. I'd often find myself reading and thinking that it was one of them, only to find out that the character I thought was speaking was somewhere else in the room. That made me backtrack a few times and tended to be annoying. I just wish that they'd had more unique voices.If you haven't read Allegiant yet, go and pick it up now! This is a quick read, despite its bulk, and I want to hear your thoughts on everything that happens!

Even as an adult, I am a fan of young adult fiction because I really enjoy watching how younger minds are being shaped by what they read. This dystopian trend is actually very useful in exposing young minds to the idea that they are powerful and capable of shaping their own worlds. It allows them to explore philosophy, sociology, and political science in a carefully constructed framework. It should, in it's best forms, empower young people to recognize their ability to bring about great change. The Divergent series opened with fantastic potential. And then it failed spectacularly to carry through.While the first two books showed promise from having created an original and interesting culture, this book brings it all to a very unsatisfying resolution. It also brings to focus some of the problems in the earlier books that were easier to overlook amidst all the action.The first book creates a fabulous, unique and interesting microculture. It's beautifully thought out and opens the door to all types of fabulous exploration of that world and how it came to be.I wish there had been subsequent books about the other factions before we went to the eminent collapse story, but we moved straight into that in book two. It was very action-laden and didn't pay enough service to the amazing world Ms. Roth created. So much missed opportunity, but my attention remained riveted, and I really looked forward to book three and it's promise of explanations. However, while explanations of a sort did present themselves, they were threadbare and surrounded by so much teen angst and superficial emotional wallowing that there was little satisfaction to be had.These characters are all, regardless of age, extremely childish and one-dimensional. Their emotional development doesn't even seem to reach adolescence. There is an obsession with forgiveness on a very elementary-school level, written by someone who seems to have struggled with their own issues of forgiveness via a simplistic morality-based philosophy instead of through the eyes of a mature adult who has developed empathy and wisdom. Everyone is a foot-stomping, fit-throwing child who needs to find sacrifice and proper humility in order to grant forgiveness. Long explanations about nonsensical differences between "confession and admission" compounded with flat and uncomplicated descriptions of the personalities of abusive parents reveal an author who has a long way to go in exorcising the demons of her own childhood. And, of course, all of this detracts from any narration that might exist in the story. Our characters spend the majority of the book mad at each other, mad at their families, mad at authority figures, mad at the past, and just mad in general. They are angry young people who spend more time narcissistically struggling with their own anger than dealing with the very real problems surrounding them. Whenever they do get around to DOING anything, it is often just a bunch of reactive flailing with very little thought to consequence. The fact that anything is ever successful seems to be more of an accident than anything else. And, of course, they come out of each experience angry with everyone else involved. Resolution to this anger is painfully immature. Yes, I realize the protagonists are mostly young, but even the adults involved seem to react to the world as if they were 13. Having even one mature mentor might have helped a lot, but I'm not sure Ms. Roth would be capable of writing such a character.I wish we could have moved away from the sophomoric existential struggles of childhood morality and really explored the deeper philosophical potential of this world. The best young adult fiction gives the reader an opportunity to expand their thinking. This one gives them an excuse to continue being mad at mean parents, mean authority figures, meany-meanersons everywhere. Complete with foot-stomping.What a shame.
