reviewText: This book is definitely the worst of the divergent trilogy, which is surprising because I was extremely critical of the first one.What makes this book so bad? For me, a major part is a shift in how the story is presented. In the first two books it is entirely from Tris' perspective. You would think after reading two books that do not deviate AT ALL throughout, the third book would follow suit. Not the case at all. For whatever reason Roth decides to jump back and forth between Tobias and Tris. This made the story incredibly hard to follow because after a few pages I would forget the chapter switched to Tobias' narrative and wonder why Tris would say, think, or do something totally out of character. I'd flip back to the beginning of the chapter only to realize it switched again, which removes you entirely from the story. Think of it as watching a DVD and you see an actor you recognize but you cannot for the life of you remember his/her name. You decide to stop the movie and check the credits. A few minutes go by and you forget the name, so you check again. Yeah, it gets annoying really quickly!The cliffhanger at the end of the second novel was simply amazing as the possibilities were literally endless. Anything could have been outside of the city walls. Sadly, the truth was much less exciting than many of the possibilities I dreamed up while waiting to read the third book. Roth should have spent more time developing the world outside. Instead, she went the greed route and put out a book before it was fully ready and hoped fans of the earlier two would come flocking to read it. Sadly I fell for it, but I do feel better knowing I borrowed the book from a library and can give it back. Having it in my collection would depress me to no end.

The final book could have been much better.  There was no distinction between Tris and Tobias' point of view.  I had to keep flipping back to remember who was narrating.  They almost became the same person.  Tris' death seemed forced and unnecessary. It took me much longer to finish this book and it has tainted the serious for me.

So this isn't a terrible book. But it could have been better. Here's the thing: the way Roth handles the ending, in my opinion, was just so unnecessary. I don't understand what this new fad is with killing off protagonists in the final book of a trilogy just because the author can. Sometimes I truly think that's why they do it. That's why I knocked off one star.Here's the other annoying thing: I don't think Roth is a bad writer. But this book could have used an editor that actually told her the honest truth about her use of VOICE. I mean, switching between Tris's perspective and Tobias's was a good idea and could have been powerful - if we could EVER tell a difference between who was who! She used the EXACT same voice between both characters - same tone, attitude, everything. I had to constantly look back at the chapter opener and remind myself of who was talking. That's why I knocked off a second star.So...the rest of the book was pretty good. I love the way she handles Tris and Tobias's relationship, actually. But the book could have SHONE. It really could have. And it missed that opportunity by two stars.

reviewText: I'm really deciding between 3 and 4 stars. This was the third (and final) book in the Divergent series by Roth.  It was well written and I still enjoy Roth's writing style, however the story itself was a disappointment.The story switches between Tris's and Tobias's point of view.  Tris is languishing in lockdown after releasing information that Tobias's mother (and leader of the Factionless) didn't want released.  Tobias is walking a fine line; he doesn't really support what his mother is doing but wants to be in the know and wants her to trust him.  Tobias also wants Tris released.  Then both characters learn about a faction called Allegiant which is against what the Factionless are doing.  When Tris and Tobias get involved with the Allegiant they are asked to travel beyond the fence and see what's out there.  Both of them hope that beyond the fence will be a better place where they can start anew.It honestly took me a while to figure out what I thought about this book.  There are certain things that happen at the end that will piss off the reader big time.  So I had to take some time and think the book through in order not to just have the "Oh, my God I hate this book" reaction.  In the end I realized that there were a lot of things...not just the ending...that I was disappointed about.I think a lot of these dystopian trilogies suffer from poor endings.  I mean really, the first book is the big reveal of a cool new world and neat ideas.  The second book is further development of those ideas.  The third book has to resolve stuff, and that's tough when honestly the resolution is usually a bit convoluted and boring.  I mean ultimately you are looking at replacing a corrupt system with a better one...and that's not all that exciting or easy to do in an entertaining way.  I can't think of one dystopian series I have read where the final book in the series is better than the earlier books.I did like that Tris and Tobias actually tried to work through their relationship problems.  However, even this got a bit old...they have the same problems over and over again.  The chemistry between these two seems to have cooled off some in this book.The book is very readable and well written, I am not sure I liked how convoluted the story got.  I was a kind of disappointed when Tris and Tobias get out of the city and find very similar problems to what they faced in the city.  There are multiple factions outside the city and people are not being treated fairly.  The outside was just an echo of the inside of the city (or visa versa).  The addition of more and more different factions just got old...and to be honest boring.  No surprises, nothing all that interesting or groundshaking.  I was having trouble staying awake as I read this book.This is a long book...I feel like a lot of what is in here was unnecessary and just added complication.  The whole thing ends up being a war between Tobias's dad and Tobias's mom...which is kind of dumb and disappointing.  Not to mention the vast number of coincidences that happen in this story to lead the reader to that point.  It just came of as convoluted and contrived.Also, while I understand the ending of the book and why it was possibly the most realistic path forward, I also think it wouldn't have killed Roth to write an ending that was just a little bit more happy.  It would have been nice to give the reader a bit more hope that things in this world were going to go the right way in the end.  As mentioned above this is part of why I am getting sick of dystopia...they never end all that happy.Overall definitely the weakest book of the trilogy.  I still enjoy Roth's writing style but I thought that what Tobias and Tris found Outside was disappointing, boring, and just added complication that didn't need to be there.  I didn't enjoy the addition of yet more groups and factions and the fact that the whole thing ended up being more of a war between Tobias's parents than anything else.  I also didn't like the ending, although I understand how it fit the story well.  I really wasn't a fan of this book, it felt more like a necessary evil I had to read to finish this series than anything else.All that being said, the first two books in this series were absolutely excellent.  So I still recommend the series as a whole; it is really really well done.  Unfortunately this final book was probably my biggest disappointment of 2013.

reviewText: The story line breaks down in this third book. I loved the first two, but this one seems forced, like the author lost her vision for writing it. I actually went back and rewrote the storyline in my mind for the last half of the book. Such a let down after the first two were SOOO good.

Did She hit her head?Did her publisher push her too hard?Did she have a nervous break-down?Had she just stopped caring entirely???This is the type of book that makes you really contemplate the time it takes to read it. Thoughts like, 'I can't believe I'm spending my limited amount of time on earth reading this crap', or; 'I'm never going to get the hours back I've spent reading this offensive garbage,' for example, go through your head quite frequently. These topics interrupting my chain of thought as I struggled through the pages. This book was such a disappointment, not just for the series, but for the entire literarily world. I had to force myself to finish it and even then, it took a couple months. The premise might have been interesting to begin with, but now it’s just non plausible and ridiculous.What the hell happened, Veronica Roth?

I've liked the Divergent series from the beginning, but I've never been wowed by it like so many others have been.  I think it's because the books feel slow to me and I never identified well with Tris.  This series has been entertaining, but I haven't been on pins and needles between books (like I am when I'm in love with a series).  I liked the way the story concluded in Allegiant and I really enjoy Roth's imagery.  Her writing is good and once the books get going they are good reads.  It's just hard for me to go halfway through a book feeling like not a lot is going on.  One thing I admire in a writer is when they take risks with their plots, especially being unafraid to kill off characters.  And that's exactly what happened in Allegiant: people die, people you aren't expecting to, and it was pretty shocking.  All in all, I liked Allegiant and would recommend it--and the series--but it wasn't a favorite of mine.

This series did that.  I dont feel like Four lost some of his appeal in this book.  Some say that he was reduced to a whiny, annoying mess.  And I dont think that Tris got "holier than thou" with being right.  I feel like he always asked her to feel out a situation, then didnt respect her opinion, and justified it (in both cases) that she didnt like the person (and in  1 case of being jealous).  I thought those were very real relationship issues, even if in the extreme. And I do LOVE that Four faced a big fear by zip lining to scatter her ashes.Basically this book was ok.  The series as a whole would have been great had there been more justice.  People got off way to easy in this and the only people that were punished were the people who were fighting for good.  They are the ones who lost people... while the bad people got to live their happily ever after.  (Even Evelyn who was evil and even told Tris that she would be with Four long after she was gone.)I really wanted to see the movies, but at this point I dont know.  It really hurt me so much by just reading about it, that I really dont know if I can handle SEEING it.  I almost want to go back and read the first 2 books and then write my own version of the final book so that I can have it end in a way that doesnt devastate me to the point where I was in a very bad mood for a day or so when I finished it.Very unsatisfying!

reviewText: Where do I begin? I was so very excited about this book coming out! I had read the first two quickly. I couldn't get enough of Tris and Four, then I see the trailer to the movie, and I get even more excited. I usually don't read the reviews to book because I want to go in not knowing what is going to happen. However, I wish that I would have read the reviews before I bought this book. Not only do I feel I need a refund on this book, I highly doubt that because of this book, I will not go see the movie, and wait for it to come out on HBO where I can watch it for free.Veronica, took this series and completely ruined it! She takes the goodness and the pureness of a teenage romance and completely destroys it. And she doesn't do it gently at all. On more than on occasion, they are happy endings, well, in a YA book, I would hope that they would all be happy endings. We read books to escape the reality that we live in. Yes, we do not have this particular type of society, but we do have the heartache and the fights that all couples go through. That doesn't mean we want to read about people (especially the main characters) being killed off!!!The fame and the spot light has gone to Veronica's head. She took a trilogy that was awesome, has a strong heroine, and a strong partner. They have their problems, and they work through them. But, this book needs to be hidden away, and never seen again. I wish that I had the memory serum so I can forget that I read this book.  Don't waste you money or your time on this book. Stop at the second book and call it good!!!
summary: Don't waste you money or your time on this book. Stop at the second book and call it good!!!

reviewText: Enjoyed this as much of the first one.  At first I was confused by the back and forth between the two main characters, which was not done in the first two books.  However, near the end I understood this change.  WOW!

Explanation:Allegiant opens with the discontent people of Chicago hoping to make a stand against the Factionless. The discontent, become the Allegiant, a small group revolting against Evelyn Johnson, the new leader. The Allegiant want to find answers and resolve order to the city of Chicago. Tobias, Tris and their friends are chosen to go where no one else has gone before, outside the city limits into the world beyond. In leaving the city they enter a society they know nothing about.  Here they learn the truth about their home, and must decide what to do with this knowledge. The Allegiant have two choices- to assist the citizens of this strange new world and walk away from the only home they have known or to fight for the people they have left behind.Opinion:Every once in a while a book comes along that is so different, exhilarating and refreshing that it takes your breath away- Allegiant is one of those books! Veronica Roth elevated Allegiant from what could have potentially been a mediocre read to an EPIC novel, by creating a diverse and unpredictable plot. How do you make a book truly EPIC? You leave the reader reeling, with the most unsatisfied taste in their mouth after turning the last page! This feeling makes the reader ponder what could have been, long after the book was completed.When I first began reading this book I did find it a bit ‘ho-hum’. It took me a week to get halfway through and I really wasn’t interested in getting to the end because I thought I knew exactly what was coming- oh how wrong I was! I think my reluctance to read the book too quickly was also because I didn’t like some of the earlier revelations in the book, and I didn’t want to know how anything else could damage these characters.  I preserved though and all I can say is wow, Veronica Roth, WOW!Roth also did not do the one thing that turned Stephanie Meyer’s Twilight Series into a mediocre read. She did not close every loose end up by the conclusion of the book. Now I am a fan of stories being completed properly, and I hate movies that leave you guessing. But Roth created her story without its neatly packed endings, which elevates this book to the beyond impressive level.The dual perspective writing also gave more insight into both Tris and Tobias‘s thoughts and feelings. The previous two books in the Divergent Series are told only from Tris’s point of view. That sufficed for those books, but Allegiant very much needed the two viewpoints in order for the reader to understand the whole story. Tobias’s point of view allowed the reader to see how deeply he cared for Tris and how much his parents have impacted upon his life choices. Tris’s chapters were written in the same strong, determined and selfless voice of the heroine we know and love.Summary:Allegiant could have been just another nice, teen book series where the heroine always gets what they want. Instead Roth has turned it into a best seller. Allegiant was fantastic. The Divergent Series was amazing! The movies are going to be phenomenal! Kudos to Veronica Roth!

I read the first two books in the series very quickly and really enjoyed them. I could hardly put them down in fact.My experience with this third and final installment was quite the reverse. The story did not capture my imagination anything like as much and I found it very easy to put the book down and almost had to force myself to finish it. The plot was both predictable and frankly a bit boring. While the ending was also not the one I would have liked to see it is not the main reason I only gave this book 3-stars. The whole book just felt like a drawn out final chapter to the two books that preceded it. All in all a pretty average ending to what otherwise was a great set of books and if it was not for the fact that I like the series overall a lot I could easily have given Allegiant just 2-stars.

reviewText: I read some of the reviews--no spoiler ones--before reading this book.  I loved Divergent and Insurgent, so no matter what I was reading Allegiant.  Some of the comments had me wondering what I was getting into, but it was so worth reading.  I think having both Tris and Four's viewpoints from chapter to chapter helped finally get his viewpoint--we mostly only had Tris's viewpoint in the first two books.  I think we learned a lot more about their true feelings in this book and their acceptance that although they were both Dauntless, they were still different in how they saw things and wanted to solve them, but they still loved each other.  I think a lot of the negative reviews are because it wasn't all wrapped up at the end in the fairy tale package like most YA trilogies have been.  This was more real.  I admit it made me cry in parts (I won't spoil it with what parts), but I think it was supposed to make you feel what they were feeling.Someone said in one of the reviews that Peter never showed remorse for his actions in the other books then he does in this one--did they not read Insurgent--Peter is the one who saved Tris from death at the hands of Jeanine then when the factionless took over, he stayed near his mother and didn't participate--he was already hating himself then.  He was never meant to be a good guy, but he always knew he should try to be better--he just never could put forth the effort to do good instead of evil.No book is perfect, so I think the criticism of this one has been a bit harsh, but I still liked it.  It did remind me of the Matched trilogy in the memory erasure, but all these YA dystopian novels have similarities.  At least there was no love triangle in this one--Tris and Four loved only each other--I still refuse to call him Tobias.  Now I get to wait to see how they destroy the novels for the movies...hate to see the amazon reviews when they release the movies.

I could not wait to read this book. I know some people were disappointed, but I was not to disappointed. It still had excitement, danger and a few twist. Of course it could have been a lot better. I like to have different perspectives, but it you do it at the end of a series you know something is up. Plus make sure your characters have two distinct voices.

The pros: There is closure to the storyline. It was an easy, quick read. The melodrama from the second book between the statcrossed couple - Tris and Tobias - isn't as over the top.  The issues make more sense between the duo, and they actually communicate more. And the whole Tris / serum situation makes sense given the last book.The cons: The other characters, both the "divergent" and "non divergent" come across as 7 year old children in their ontellectual capacity,  as that's the only way to make Tris the heroine. Given the last book, she should have already known how she would react to the serum. Given that these serums were made for divergent,  security in the ouside world should be for both. Why not just go simple with guns? And when did non-divergent equate to stupid? To make the story work,  everyone but Tris has to be sufficiently compromised intellectually,  otherwise she can't be the heroine. By far,  the first book was best.  I think that was the one thought through the most.  This read as a last ditch effort because I think it was.
summary: if you want closure,  read. If you want quality,  perhaps skip.

reviewText: I'm going to keep this short and sweet because I could really rattle on and on about this book and series all day long. I know there are a number of people really angry about this book and I just have to disagree with them. I loved it and I love this series. I know some of it can seem to drag on about technology and the history behind this city but I felt like I learned the most about their past and present in Allegiant than any other book. We settled a lot different plot lines in these pages plus had quite the number of surprises along the way. If you don't want to be spoiled I would stop reading right now.Tris had to die. I'm sorry but it's the truth. This conflict was never going to end with her being alive and moving on. She became the hero we all thought she was all along by saving everyone but losing her own life. I thought the author took a major risk doing this to main character but it was the risk worth taking in a series that has been unique as this. Tris went out in a blaze of glory while saving the people that she loved and it felt right. This wasn't the happily ever after that we all want for our beloved character but it was the right ending. The only complaint I had with Allegiant was the narration. We spent two other books in Tris' head and didn't need Fours. I would actually rather have seen the entire book played out in her own head and when she dies have Four narrate the rest. That would have been a much better transition for me to hear. It would have played out much like the novellas that have been interwoven into the series along the way rather than introduce this new perspective in the last book. It seemed strange and awkward but I understood why we needed his eyes at the end.  This series has been a really great ambassador for the YA Dystopian genre and I think aided in gaining a lot of fans from young to old for other books like it. I'm sad to see it go but for me this was a great goodbye.
summary: Sorry but that ending was right.

And the series is over.Divergent is a pulse pounding, violent chase through a dystopian society. Insurgent is more emotional, allies and foes and lies and love. In Allegiant, Roth tries to wind everything up into an explosive finale. And she does a pretty decent job of it.Honestly, while Divergent slapped me in the face, pulled my hair, and screamed “Read one more chapter!”, Insurgent felt slower. Although I feel like there was a lot of emotional storytelling in the middle book, all of the backstabbing and lies felt a little to much for me. And Tris got on my nerves. Now in Allegiant, Tris and Four are trying to find a new path together, one filled with honesty and love and truth. And you know, save their world at the same time.Allegiant introduces us to the world outside of their city, and a new cast of characters. I don’t want to give too much away, so all I’ll say is that I loved this idea. The whole thing. It’s creepy enough for it to be real. Roth does a good job at trying to explain the origin of their city, the fractions, and the divergent history. The third book asks a lot of new questions and there’s a lot of truth that are now shown as lies.  I really liked the questions that were posed, how vulnerable Four and Tris are, in their own ways. How two wrongs don’t make a right.Tris and Four each handle these things very differently and it’s great to see how their relationship strains and stretches under the stress. Their problems are based on real issues many couples have- trust, strength, identity. The real issues between Tris and Four make the book believable and real, bringing the reader back to a place of emotion. It’s easy to get lost in the new dystopian world.At the beginning of the book, there is one death in particular that I think is supposed to be shocking. Honestly, I wasn’t moved. I think because Allegiant dives right in, being the third book and all, and it’s been a while since I read book two, the deaths weren’t as emotionally jarring to me at the beginning. I barely remember some of these secondary characters. That said, the death does do one thing really well- it fills the reader with a sense of dread quickly and soon, you’re running and jumping and dodging bullets with Tris and Four. You’re there. With them.I did feel like there was something missing in this final installment, but I can’t place my finger on it. Maybe it’s the introduction of so many new characters, a new setting, new truths that don’t have time to be explored. The ending and actions did feel rushed, out of sequence sometimes, reactions and split decisions that weren’t backed up with enough information for me to honestly believe that this was the only choice the characters had to make. The justifications weren’t always there and I found myself yelling at them to slow down, don’t trust them, get more information.And the ending. I was surprised at first, but then, after thinking about it, no. The ending is the way it should be.While Allegiant isn’t my favorite in the series, it is a solid ending, bringing together closure for the characters and a hopeful path ahead.
summary: An ending falling short, but still a great series.

This whole thing is so full of plot holes, I don't even know where to begin. For one thing, if you have to explain the name of the book in the book, it's not a good name. "Emergent" would have been a better title since they will be leaving the city to see what it's like outside. When they do, they find....it's just the same outside as it is inside.The experiment is made up of organized factions, and disorganized factionless living in squalor. Outside the experiment you have an organized general population, with the "genetically damaged" living in "the Fringe" in complete squalor. So how is the experiment different from real life? They've still left a large population to live in deplorable conditions. What is to be gained or learned?I had to really think out the timeline of this world and it came to this - some people get their genes modified, this turns out bad, so they round up all the genetically damaged people and dump them in concentration camps...I mean "experiments" until they "get better." This is ridiculous. Damaged and Pure are terrible names for these conditions b/c seeing "GD" so many times and people talking about genetic purity is really disturbing, and not in a thought provoking way.Why maintain this experiment for 7 generations? If 20 years makes a generation, that's 140 years. No one comes up with anything better in 140 years? Did technology (except serum-development) take a screeching halt during that time so that no better solution could be found?With all the wide and varied serums, why not just modify memories more often so that people behave? If you're going to talk about purity of genes, why not sterilize the damaged? Then they can live in the general population but not pass on their deformity. Oh right, b/c eugenics is bad and everyone knows it. Better to dump them all in a self-sustaining city until they implode.When you're writing a story, you need to start with the ending so everything can build towards it. I felt like Roth was making it up as she went along and so it didn't come together well at all.
summary: The outside is like the inside...

I debated how many stars to give this but decided that I felt strongly enough to give it just one. It's not because of the ending. I had read about one-third of the way through when I decided to stop and put the book away. Part of it was reading the two alternating perspectives got a little confusing. Tris and Four never really had different voices so I sometimes had to check to see whose point of view I was reading. I decided to finish the book because I LOVED the first two so much. I now wish I hadn't wasted my time. Once it's read, it can never be unread!I wondered as I read Allegiant if an editor ever came to Roth and said, "You know, maybe you should think about going in a different direction." If that had happened, she should've listened. But it's apparent that for reasons I'll never understand, she decided to write this mess. The dialog is stilted, Roth isn't good writing from different perspectives other than Tris', the characters never really developed and it seems like Roth didn't know what to do with some of the supporting characters so she either kills them off or they just sort of faded away and became irrelevant.And what happened to Four between the time she wrote Insurgent and Allegiant??? Did she suddenly start to hate him? I never liked that his daddy and mommy issues weren't resolved during the first two books but they really make a difference in his thinking in Allegiant. Four used to be badass but in Allegiant, he became this whiney, angst filled, insecure boy/man whose parents didn't hug him enough. Sadly, his character devolved over time.I love Tris. I'll always love Tris. I think Roth knows her best so if this is what she wanted to do to her beloved character, then it's her choice. But I think Tris' relationship with Four, despite the fact that she thinks she's in love with him, just seemed too contrived and maybe Roth couldn't write it any other way. The whole plot, the relationships that had been built over the first two books, just collapsed in this one.And frankly, with that ending, Roth pretty much guaranteed that I will never read this series again.

This is not a book worth owning.  Borrow it from a friend; get it from the library.  Though I happily lent out and recommended the first two books in this series,  I can say that if this had been the first book, I would not have continued the series.  This is by FAR the weakest of the book in almost every sense of the word: plot, character development and over all writing.  I think it's the poor writing and inability to maintain the identities of the characters she developed in the first 2 books that I find most irritating.  Poor Four.  He is a totally different man in this book and not one that you like.  And the way Tris's story ends, well, its utterly pointless and robs the reader of the pay off that they should have gotten after stickiing with this series.  If it had been handled another way, I don't think I would have been as upset.  But it just seemed abrupt and added for shock value. I know Roth says the ending was planned that way all along but seriously, I don't buy that.Other reviewers have already mentioned the problems the writer had handling dual view points.  I can only agree.  Roth's readers and editors shouldn't have let the book be published with some of the writing problems that were present.  She is no JKRowling.Finally, I had all sorts of issues with the plot shift once our heroes leave the city.  Contrived and utterly unbelievable.  The entire premise of the GP and GD conflict is so bogus and why in the heck would our guys decide to jump into someone else's fight within a week of meeting them??  Everyone was behaving so out of character.All I can say is that I don't think I will ever read any novels by Roth again given the nose dive her skills have taken.

I purposely didn't read any reviews or anything about this book before I read it, but I did know that it didn't have a happy ending and that a lot of readers weren't pleased with it.Now that I've read some of those reviews, I'll say that I do agree with some of the complaints. There are issues with the "science" and reasoning behind some of the events in this series. But, for me, I was able to just accept that the science in the "Divergent" world is different from what we have here. I understand, though, why some people couldn't do that. I'm not always able to do that when reading either.What made me like this book was that the ending, while sad, felt real. I felt the characters acted as I would have expected them to. I often feel that too often in YA literature, authors wrap up the story with a big bow and a happy smile. This doesn't happen here. There is loss and people don't get what they deserve and that is realistic. I love that Roth wasn't afraid to go there.I've kept this generic in order to avoid spoilers. I think that if you LOVED Divergent, you'll probably really enjoy this. But if you had issues/only just liked Divergent, you might be disappointed by this. While there were some issues with the series, I still really enjoyed it and will read whatever Roth puts out next.

Overall, I enjoyed the book.  I was surprised with the ease in which the book finished.  I've read plenty of other dystopian trilogies, and found the endings,including Mockingjay and Requiem, left me feeling angry and confused.  The endings were rushed, problematic, and unsatisfying.  I will admit that I didn't have a high bar of expectations, but I felt like Allegiant satisfied some of the "loose ends" of the society without leaving gaping plot holes.  I felt I understood how the characters came to the decisions they did, and how the world in which the characters live resolved.SPOILERS!!!I was disappointed, but not completely aghast at the death in the end.  I sort of expected it to be one or the other, though I was shocked and didn't believe it until they actually saw the body.  I wish things could have ended differently, but I think the character's choices definitely made sense to put this person to his/her eventual end!So, anyway, I'm sad, but impressed that Roth had the gumption to end the book somewhat realistically and true to the story and characters.  I wish there had been a different ending, but I think the ending satisfied my desire for resolution. I'll still recommend the series.

reviewText: The last installment of this trilogy felt extremely rushed.  I would have rather waited two more years for this book to come out, had I felt like it would end in a way that fit in better with the first two books.  Everything about this felt like it wasn't completely thought out, and a lot of what happened did not make sense for the characters.For example (SPOILER ALERT):Did anyone really think, for one second, that Tris would let Caleb sacrifice himself? Therefore, why would Tobias think that she would? He knew her well enough to know that that would have NEVER happened.  Yet, he went back into the city without a question and left her in the compound to "save the world".Tobias is also not one to trust very easily, so why would he have so quickly trusted Nita?There was this crazy buildup of Evelyn as this evil leader, and all it took to get her to stop was Tobias making her choose between him and the war.  That was way too easy!Did Uriah's death add anything to the book, other than causing Tobias to have to go back to the city to tell Zeke and his mother? I think that his death definitely made Tobias feel worse about working with Nita, but I think he felt bad enough before finding out about Uriah.  He made a mistake and Tris always had to be right about everything.  I would have liked to see Tobias be right about something, for once.  I really wanted Tris and Tobias to work together equally.  I felt like Veronica was leading up to them finally working together and having an equal trust of each other in their relationship, but then Tris had her plan with the memory serum and no one else's opinion mattered.When Tris died, it was like she wasn't even trying to stay alive.  She just accepted it.  When in Insurgent, on her way to be given the death serum, she realized how much she wanted to live.  I don't think it was necessary to kill Tris.  I honestly don't think it added to the story in any way.  If anything, it makes me not want to recommend this trilogy to people anymore.  Tris was a survivor.  She would have fought a lot harder to live.Overall, I did love this trilogy.  I would have liked it to have ended differently, and I would have liked Veronica Roth to have had a little more time to think through the rushed ending, but I'm still happy I read the book and finished the trilogy.  Maybe she will see all of these reviews and allow the movie to end differently, or she will write an alternate ending :)

reviewText: If I could give this book 10 stars I would.This is a very hard book for me to review.  I want to do it justice, and I hope I can.Veronica Roth's dystopian trilogy continues with ALLEGIANT. In both DIVERGENT and INSURGENT Tris narrates the novel from her point of view. This time around, Tris and Tobias alternate the narration. The reason this becomes necessary is made clear near the end of the book.SPOILER ALERT: THE REST OF THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS.This book was un-put-down-able.  There were times when I wanted to throw the book across the room. (I refrained because I was reading it on my e-reader.) I had to take a break a few times after an intense scene, but I couldn't stay away from the story for long. The plot flow was logical and the characters' reasoning for doing things was explained well.Both Tris and Tobias are guarded individuals, and it shows in their thoughts and speech. There is not a lot of elaboration; they say what needs to be said and give you the information you need to know and not much more. This is consistent with growing up in their Abnegation faction.  Self-sacrifice and not drawing attention to yourself, in speech or in dress, are attributes of the Abnegation. They both chose Dauntless in the choosing ceremony and their actions are in line with this choice. Both Tris and Tobias are constantly on high-alert and actively looking for danger at every turn. They have witnessed and participated in too much death and destruction to be trusting of anyone or anything.I cannot separate the themes in this book from my own Christian perspective, so I will make no attempt to do so. Through the creation of factions, uprisings, brain washing and memory altering, those in charge of the city or the "experiment" are constantly trying to re-mold human nature to fit their ideal. Ms. Roth demonstrates time and again that no amount of behavior modification, serums, or slaughter of the genetically damaged can change or repair human nature. Their feeble  attempts to eradicate "sin" fail every time. Instead of looking outside themselves, to the God who can redeem them, they try to change themselves on the inside. Only those characters who realize the futility of this, and learn to love one another in spite of their faults and forgive each other find true peace.While the ending did hurt, it did not ruin the story for me. Tris is consistent in her selfless nature and her death is not without meaning. She accomplished her goal to stop the Bureau from destroying the "Chicago Experiment" and showed forgiveness to her brother by her agape love. I am reminded of what the old Amity woman in INSURGENT told Tris. "It isn't about you. It is a gift. You cannot earn it or it ceases to be a gift." She believes that she can be forgiven and gladly goes with her mother.Although there is a lot of tragedy, I find the ending hopeful. Tobias ultimately overcomes his fear of the zip line and honors Tris's memory.  Tobias is the more "damaged" of the two, but even he realizes there is reason for hope. We can all be mended.

I'm still trying to understand what happened here... nothing about this book makes sense.To say I'm completely and utterly disappointed in Allegiant is an understatement of the highest caliber. I spent most of the time wanting to throw my Kindle out the window.Yeah... not good. I waited over two years for an epic conclusion to this series and instead I feel I was shortchanged. I went into this book thinking it would be non-stop action and all-around badassery. I didn't get that at all. Instead, I suffered through a ridiculously hole-ridden plot that barely made sense. The question I asked myself for the first 40% of this book was, "Sooooo, what was the point of the first two books then?"In Divergent, I absolutely LOVED both Tris and Four. Insurgent had me pissed off at Tris for the majority of the book. Allegiant made me want to punch Tobias/Four for the first 70% and I completely blame Veronica Roth for that. She almost re-wrote his character and turned him into a douchebag and it didn't work for me. I'm trying to figure out if it was to add angst or drama in an otherwise lacking plot.Oh! The "plot"... I. Don't. Get. It. At all. The end of Insurgent was such a cliffhanger and it seemed like Allegiant would pick up right where it ended and we'd be shown complete and utter turmoil. Sorry, to disappoint you, but that's not going to happen. We get a lot of nothing and lame explanations for WHY the factions are in place... genetics, perfection, blah blah blah.For the first 30% I was scratching my head and repeating, "WTF?" in between bouts of fighting sleep. NOTE: I finished the first two books in this series in less than a day. This one took me THREE DAYS to get through. There were many times I wanted to give up because it felt like the book was either:a) Never going to end.orb) Have absolutely no conclusion whatsoever.And oh how I wish I had DNF'd this one! Or maybe I wish I had come across the ending spoiler because I'd have known I was wasting my time. But I gave Roth the benefit of the doubt and stuck it out. I had no idea she'd piss me off and make me despise the series.Some of the secondary characters add absolutely no value to the story. It feels like they're there "just because".Christina, Uriah, Peter... POINTLESS. Even in the end, they have no major role they played in this contrived disaster. And then there's Evelyn. Once again, Veronica Roth fails. Someone as power hungry and controlling as this woman cannot change who she is in a split second decision. Except in fiction. This all happens at the end, when all the "BIG" things are finally happening. Which, btw, isn't any major battle. It feels like a lesson in church or a moral message that we're supposed to appreciate and find comfort in. BUT IT DOESN'T WORK! I am bummed to think that Roth sold out and went for shock value instead of an ending that made sense. I cannot support such a ridiculous decision or rate this book high because I liked the prior books. reviewText: A lot of people seemed to be a little disappointed with the way this book ended. I had heard about the ending because I had read the reviews before I read it so I knew what was coming. It didn`t bother me. This is not the world of happily ever after, but it is an interesting world. Many people have decried about the ending, but that’s not even half of what makes this book a total and complete fail.Early on, when they announced Allegiant would be written from both Tris and Tobias’s point of views (POVs) I was cautiously excited. I really looked forward to getting to know Tobias better (by seeing things through his mind’s filter). And then I read it…utterly disappointing.Did an editor even look at this manuscript before it went to press? Tris and Tobias think and process the SAME exact way. This is nothing short of poor and amateur writing abilities on display. Doing the two POV’s exposed Roth’s weaknesses as a writer—she could only write one character moderately well. All others were cardboard. No two people think and process the same on earth. A good writer makes it so that the POV ‘voices’ are so different that a reader can open a book to any page, remove name references, and STILL know who’s head we’re in.  Roth failed to do this and this is the ultimate failing of the book.Okay…and for her next book, can someone please help her brainstorm so every plot twist isn’t either solved or thicken by the introduction of a new serum. Seriously. It was like: Ahhh…the world is ending! I know. Oh let’s say there’s ANOTHER serum that gives people longer life and ANOTHER serum that heals wounds and ANOTHER serum that makes mean people smile and ANOTHER serum that tames unicorns and ANOTHER serum that…you get my point.Also, can someone please give the author some romance lessons? I mean…I guess romance in her eyes is “let’s fight and be mad and OH! let’s make out for a chapter, but now I’m mad again, but let’s find some place to make-out.” If that’s considered good romantic tension these days it’s no wonder the divorce rates are rising. But really, again, it just exposed shoddy writing. Roth can’t figure out how to create genuine romantic tension for her characters. Period.And the ending. Yes. We can’t ignore that (unfortunately, because I’d sure like to). Honestly, Roth’s characterization was so weak in this third book (because of the POV failure) that I didn’t even care by the time I got to the last couple chapters. That being said—I’m not entirely opposed to killing off characters (I’ve done so in my own books), but how Roth did it was wrong and ruined the entire series.Allegiant and subsequently its author, Veronica Roth (who, for the rest of this will be known as VRoth) failed readers on so many levels, but more than anything it/she failed a generation of teen readers who are looking for a new brand of hope.See, when an author writes a book they can’t just willy-nilly send it out into the world. They must keep in mind that their words have the power to shape and affect people. An author, especially someone with a huge readership, has a responsibility to their readers. They must offer hope within the pages of their book or it’s a pointless waste of time for the author and more so, the reader.Author William Faulkner said in his acceptance speech for his Nobel Prize, “The writer’s duty is to help man endure by lifting his heart, by reminding him of the courage and honor and hope and pride and compassion and pity and sacrifice which have been the glory of his past.”Does there have to be an “and they lived happily ever after” ending? Absolutely not. Suzanne Collins’s (author of The Hunger Games series) editor put it best when she said that young adult books don’t need a happy ending, but in the end, there must be “a window left open”—a way where we can see that the characters we’ve grown to love can move on from tragedy.There must be hope.Teens today are growing up in a far different world than the one I grew up in (and I’m not that old). I’m of the Harry Potter generation. The books of my youth were stories of teens that could rise up and save the world. My generation was the one told that if we go to college and work hard then we’ll get good jobs and we can accomplish anything. I’m the generation just in front of today’s teens—and the teens of today have watched as the bottom dropped out of my generation’s lives. Where going to college hasn’t landed many of my friends a job, instead it has left them drowning in debt. Where many parents are divorced and a significant amount of people I know have watched their family home seized by forecloser.Teens today have grown up watching this all unravel. For all of the aware part of their lives, our country has been at war. Think about that. They don’t know of an America not at war. Polls show that their vision of success is very different than my teen generation (which is only ten years ago). Today’s teen sees success not as owning a home, graduating college, having a family, or starting a business, instead the number one measure of success in recent polls showed them wanting to be debt free “at some point in life.” That’s it.Contemporary teens aren’t looking for books about teens saving the world. They only ask for the small hope of saving their small corner of it. So popular books for this generation are ones that in the end show that in the midst of a messed up world, you can find your own peace/hope, even if it’s just between you and one other person.Fiction has always been meant to combat the reality of life. VRoth failed us here. She didn’t show us what could be possible. Instead she smacked us in the face with what is. And we don’t need that. Because we’ve all dealt with more than enough loss and hardship and heartbreak. We don’t need books that repeat what we live every single day, we need books that show us that in the midst of a heartbreak world, we can find our own little pod of happiness/joy. That just because the world we live in is going to pot, doesn’t mean we have to lose hope.Whatever her purpose, VRoth showed teens with Allegiant one horrible thing: their life, their struggles, their fight for right…none of it matters in the end. Which leaves teens asking: what’s the point? If nothing I’m working for matters…why try? I know that’s not the message she meant to send, but when an author is careless with their responsibility to readers, this is the kind of thing that can happen.I’ll admit I spent a good amount of time reading Amazon reviews for Allegiant in order to see if I was the only one left disillusioned. I wasn’t. Sadly, I’m in the majority with the one star reviews.Most of the five star reviews I read were people who applauded VRoth on her bravery in “giving a realistic ending.” To this I say: there is a whole genre dedicated to realism. If you want stories that make you feel like someone has stabbed your heart on the last page with no chance for recovery, then feel free to read that genre. But for the ninety-five percent of people that read for enjoyment and escapism, sorry, we want some glimmer of a happy ending. If the Divergent series was meant to belong in the realism genre then it was marketed terribly because right now, all we have are broken promises to readers.Also, even within realism, hope is usually the end game.Take the book The Fault in Our Stars which falls in the realism genre, the teens in the story who fall in love both have terminal cancer. In the end of the book Augustus dies. Why weren’t readers rioting over that? Because a promise wasn’t broken—when they picked up the book they knew they were going to read a story about dying teens so a teen dying at the end of the book was something they were braced for, if not expecting.Even still, The Fault in Our Stars ends with hope. Hazel realizes that although Augustus has died, her love for him doesn’t have to. Death doesn’t have to change the definition of relationships. My grandfather, who is deceased, is still my grandfather because I’m living and can claim him as such. The last line of the book is in present tense whereas the rest of the book was in past tense. Meaning life goes on. This is a hopeful message.VRoth killed her main character which is just hard to do well, especially in young adult fiction. Unless the author brings the character back after death (like Harry Potter), a theme/point is better demonstrated through killing a beloved secondary character like Augustus in The Fault in Our Stars or Piggy in Lord of the Flies (how’s that for old school). Otherwise, just save it for realism or adult fiction. Period.

reviewText: I just finished Allegiant and came to Amazon expecting to find glowing reviews, and am shocked that so many people hate it.  I read Divergent as a school librarian, curious to see what it was all about, and liked it but didn't love it. I thought the writing was a little stilted, the many characters confused me, and the atmosphere was relentlessly bleak. Insurgent didn't change my opinion of the series; still liked, but didn't love.  Somehow Allegiant brought it all together for me, and I loved this book. Ms. Roth's writing has matured and become focused, and I love where the story went and how the world opened up, both literally and atmospherically. Their world is still a small one; baby steps for us, but expanding quickly for those characters, and I was impressed by her restraint in not over-describing the mind-blowing changes they go through.  I can see that other readers may find the writing style to be underwhelming or dull, but as a journalist I appreciate a "just the facts" approach so that I can fill in my own details and create a reading experience for myself.As for the unexpected major character's death, I was shocked and sad, but it worked for me.  This reminds me of the varied reactions of readers to Mockingjay; you either loved it or you hated it.  Sudden senseless death was part of their world.  The idea that she may have been immune to the death serum was more of a stretch for me than that she could possibly skate through all danger with no consequences. The world that Roth created throughout the trilogy should have left no doubt that change could not come without sacrifice.

reviewText: I'm stating it now, spoilers!I often read books to escape my life and live another for awhile. But I can't judge a book because it doesn't give me an easy time with that escape. They are scared to deliver the hard facts of what a war world is like. I feel the same on shows... Authors or writers are scared that if they kill someone that the fandom praises, they will loose out on sales or making it to the top list. But Roth did what had to be done, she ended the book as realistic and forth coming as it was always set to be. To judge her for making a Dauntless decision is not fair. And I've never felt something as much as I felt as Tobias finally sails down the Zip Line, screaming at the top of his lungs. He was everything Tris ever saw in him and ever hope to experience with him in that moment.A lot people have sworn off this book because why? It'll make them feel something? reviewText: I won't bother with plot recaps in this review, but I will share my feelings about this book. I looked forward to it for quite some time, as did many fans of the trilogy. I'd give it three stars for a couple of reasons. I personally think trying to portray the emotion and reaction of people who discover they're all basically lab rats in an experiment is an incredibly challenging subject matter. The disappointing thing for me is how shallow the reactions are from the characters. They seem to nod and absorb the information, or information overload as it were. It's almost a numbness. The airplane ride, the tablets, the computers, the wide, wide world in which they live: it is so nonchalant. There are twists that feel cut off. Sometimes I feel like the book should've been longer, more fleshed out, so we could feel the confusion, the chaos, the shell shock that our characters must have gone through. Instead, they fall right into their roles. It felt rushed. From a generalized standpoint, the plot was believable, but the characters reactions to their surrounding just weren't for me. They grew, the matured, they developed, they forgave, they were human. But, it wasn't the strong finish I had hoped for, and it left me feeling like I wish I'd left off reading after Tris and Four forgave each other. For me the book ended when Tris realized that a mature relationship was one in which you must choose to love every day.***THE REMAINDER OF THIS  REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS, SO DON'T READ ON IF YOU DON'T WANT TO KNOW THE ENDING!***When they return from the outside, they're just accepted. It's okay. Peace, love, and happiness, and Marcus slinks quietly away to find absolute power somewhere else. Really? Some things just get glossed over, and I wanted to see and feel and live the reactions. Maybe my heart for this story died with Tris. Maybe I should reread it. But knowing the end, I can't. From a plot and storyline perspective, if I was just reading a synopsis, I like the story and felt it a believable outcome.One of the better parts for me is the off the cuff change of plans that Four employs at the end. He finally trusts himself. He finally grows into a person who can find the end without means that are destructive. And, just as he grows, he loses the one person he loves the most. As he gains the love of his mother, he loses Tris. Evelyn's ominous foreshadowing (you will never be in the new world with my son) comes to bear. I understand the author's point, but the fact that this story ends without a chance at happiness for some of my favorite characters knocks it right off of my re-read list. Kind of like Game of Thrones. As long as I don't open book 5, Arya lives. So I will never read it (until George RR Martin assures me she lives, which he won't!). While I thought the plot was well conceived and a fitting end, it is heart wrenching that Tris never gets to see the peace she enables. But that's life. Stark realism. But, in life, there are many ways to be happy and find happiness and I (as many readers) would've rather seen David die than Tris. In the end, a simple bullet kills her. Maybe in a world so dedicated to peace there wouldn't be a place for Tris. But, in the end, I feel like Four. I'm moving forward, but there's a hole in my heart where an amazing ending should be.
summary: Gut wrenching, realistic, but not on my re-read list

It was no secret that I would review Allegiant after having read the first two novels in this series. Divergent and Insurgent were both five star reads and I eagerly jumped into Allegiant upon their completion. Allegiant takes a different style and faces different challenges but kept with the same captivating style that keeps you racing for more. All in all, however, this novel is rated as FOUR STAR read.Again, Allegiant picks up right where the last book, Insurgent, left off. Tris is outside of the city heading to a destination unknown. They eventually meet up with the bureau of genetics and that is where things start to heat up. Instantly there is conflict and you find yourself not only in Tris' mind but also Tobias'. At first I was weary of this back and forth perspective because the authors style of writing is the same for both minds and it was occasionally confusing as to who I was reading from. However, by the end of the novel it becomes quite obvious why this method of writing suited the author. I won't tell you why, you'll have to read it yourself and find out ;)There are a few new villains now that Janine has been defeated. Conflict rises in the city and outside as well. Tris is left with monstrous decisions and Tobias tries his hardest as well to keep up and find his own ways of supporting their efforts. I found that within this novel there was too much conflict between Tris and Tobias, my two newest favourite characters within the novel. I found myself frusturated that they just couldn't smile and make up quicker than they do.I won't spoil anything within this novel but I will say that it is an emotional roller coaster as the author has no issues introducing new characters throughout the series only to have them die off eventually. You come to love some of the lost characters and mourn for them through your tears (or at least I did ;)So my two obvious favourite characters are Tris and Tobias, the stories main characters. But other than that, I found that I related a lot to Cara.It's strange to see people you don't know well in the morning, with sleepy eyes and pillow creases in their cheeks; to know that Christina is cheerful in the morning, and Peter wakes up with his hair perfectly flat, but Cara communicates only through a series of grunts, inching her way, limb by limb, toward coffee.The main reason this novel lost a star is due to the fact that: (1) The back and forth between Tris' perspective and Tobias' was hard to follow at times because the writing style never differed, and (2) I didn't like the ending all that much. I could come up with a few different endings that would have satisfied me more. That being said, all in all, it was still an amazing read. Slower than the first two books, but just as interesting.My FactionAt the end of this book was a faction quiz. So like every other Divergent fan out there I took that quiz. I figured I should share my results with the readers of my blog. The quiz is a short seven question multiple choice quiz and at the end of the quiz my results show that I would be a Erudite. That should have been obvious since I am a book nerd ;)You can find the quiz through an online search also :)~The Schwartz Reviews

reviewText: Quite possibly the most drawn out, depressing story I have ever read. I LOVED the first TWO books. The characters and the story of the society was intelligent, creative, and thought provoking. I actually thought about which faction I would choose. It was unique and intreaguing, especially to fans of Hunger Games and other such dystopian novels.This story however took a horrible turn for the WORST. The story between switching narrators was rather annoying because they always switched before something good happened to keep you in suspense... But I liked the other books because they DIDN'T do this. It just annoys me that Veronica Roth would so completely change the writing style in the final book.Also after the eerie feeling this book started to give me about a third of the way through, it never dissipated and culminated to what I would call the worst ending to a young adult trilogy that I have ever read.As an adult female I choose to read young adult fiction to keep my reading light and cheerful, but this depressing and dark ending was horrible. It completely ruined the storyline that had been built from the first two so much that I wish I could UN-READ it and go back to my imagined ending. I would have preferred the annoying lack of ending to this depressing novel.Do yourself a favor Divergent fans, don't read this novel, and only stick to the first two movies! I feel as though my hatred of the third book should not cloud my love of the first two books too much. I just hope I can still enjoy the Divergent movie coming out soon.Thanks a lot Veronica Roth for ruining my favorite book series. I don't care if it was your original "vision" for the storyline, times change, and that was your vision before Divergent was a best seller. reviewText: I loved the first two books, but this one just did not finish the series how I thought it would. The plot had so many wholes it couldn't stand a simple logic though.

When I purchased the book, there were only about 12 reviews, mostly bad, and I skimmed enough to get the idea that something really bad happens and a lot of people are angry about it. I'm a 33 year-old woman and I'm so glad my kids were in bed and my husband was not home when I read the end.  I cried so much I'm almost ashamed of it. But, I think there is something to be said about an author who can create such a story and such characters that the reader becomes that emotionally affected. I've read plenty of books, and I've never been so heart-wrenched by a story before, yet so satisfied with the outcome.I think it was beautiful and - sad as it was - the perfect way to end the story. Many of the other positive reviews are right - I don't particularly want unhappy endings, but mushy perfect "happy" stories make me want to vomit. It's not always meaningful.But, really, it DID have a happy ending. Tris sacrificed herself so that the man and the friends she loved don't have to live in a world where they are seen as damaged. No one else could have given that kind of gift. Plus, she didn't do it just to die for her friends - she honestly thought she could survive, and I think that makes a big difference. There are so many other good things to say about this trilogy - hints that these characters believe in God, suicide isn't a solution out of a tricky situation (which is my biggest complaint about another popular trilogy), and all of the characters come full circle in so many ways.I don't understand why so many are complaining about the writing style or it being boring. It's the same as the other books. This one may have had a little less action, but the characters were in a new situation and had to take time to adjust and figure out what was going on. Makes perfect sense. And, I don't understand why everyone is also being critical of Evelyn's choice. Yeah, it might have been her life's work, but it cost her child. Have you never suddenly realized something you were working on wasn't worth it anymore? She was tired, she was beginning to doubt.  So when she was given a way out, a way to get back what she finally realized was important, she took it. It all makes perfect sense.

After the revelation wore off, there was some slow going in this, my least favorite of the three books. For some reason I got very disconnected with the main characters and didn't really care what happened. It's unfortunate and I hope I'm alone in that thought. In the end, I did like how the story ended.

After Insurgent, the story picks up with Tris in trouble and Evelyn in control of the city.  Soon, Tris, Four and some others choose to leave Chicago and pursue the meaning of the Edith Prior video.  Most of the remaining story takes place inside a special facility a short drive from Chicago, where we find out what the story is about Chicago and the factions, as well as what it really means to be divergent.  Three-quarters of the way into this story, I was very disappointed.  It felt like the author was just going through the motions, and frankly, the story was boring and dull--lots of talking and philosophical introspection, but not much plot movement.  The last quarter of the book salvaged things for me and raised the story from one star to 3.5.  No, like a thousand others, I didn't like the ending, and I didn't think the ending was necessitated in any way by the story arc.  It seemed almost as if the author realized the story about to crash and burn, so she tossed in this ending to slap us in the face.  HOWEVER, the ending was well done and beautifully written, and it was quite evocative.  I thought the writing went from passable and average to excellent and gripping.  BUT, I'm only at 3.5 stars because the ending doesn't really fit the overall trilogy IMO.  So, for those that want a 'they all lived happily ever after' ending, don't read this book.  Stop with Insurgent and think up your own ending.  For those of you, who--like Tris--aren't afraid to jump off the roof into the net below, you should read it and experience the pain.  I just wish the first part of the book was written nearly as well as the ending.  Yo, Tris, you...well, you know what i mean.

reviewText: Allegiant starts off strong with the venture of Tris, Tobias, and a small group of Allegiant. Those who call themselves Allegiant believe in what they learned in the video at the end of Insurgent. They believe in the faction system put in place by the generations before them, and the choice to pick which faction you want to belong to. Tris, Tobias and a small group of others venture outside of the boundary lines to see what waits for them...*** Spoilers , don't read any further if you have not yet read Allegiant. ***I am so glad that they went outside of the boundaries in this book. From the very beginning of Divergent my parter in crime, Krisha, didn't like that they never explained what was outside of Chicago. Come to find out, the only world they have ever known was really just an experiment to cure the world of defective genes. Those who are "Divergent" are Genetically Pure. Allegiant definitely had a different feel to it than the other two books, most of Allegiant took place outside the city. I liked how Tris's mother was involved in all of this , that she came from the "outside" and chose to be apart of the abnegation faction. I love how Tris was able to understand her mother more by reading her journals.And now the moment you all want to talk about.. ughhh I still can't believe it happened.. Tris ... D.I.E.D.....first off , I knew she wouldn't get hurt from the kill serum, and then after all that .. she got shot !??!? When I first read it I thought it was just going to be a flesh wound.. I had NO IDEA that Veronica Roth was going to take it there... so I kept reading and stayed in denial. Even when everyone was sad.. even when Tobias was loosing it and ready to take the memory serum,  there was a baby glimmer that they were going to pull a magic rabbit out of the hat or something and bam, Tris would be alive.... wait for it.. wait for it... NOOOOO. She really died people, I was in total shock !How many YA dystopian books do you know of that kill off the main character ! I haven't read many, Heck, I am still in shock about it now. As much as I really didn't like that Tris died, I will say that it was balls-y, and the pain and sorrow that Tobias went through was heart breaking. It was for sure a stunning, and shocking conclusion to the Divergent trilogy. As much as I wish that it didn't happen personally, I see why it had to happen to make for a solid conclusion to this series. I would love to know what you thought of it!Plot : Good, learned a lot about the society, traveled outside of the boundaries. was a little slow at times but definitely picked up.Characters: definitely loved and learned a lot more about my main characters, especially Caleb, Tris, Tobias and loved learning more about Natalie Prior. You really had to read the Four Novellas to feel attached to others such as Uriah. I wasn't as attached to the other characters as I feel they wanted me to be.Cover: amazing, matches great with the other two book in the seriesYou might like: Hunger Games, Shatter Me,Rating: 5 Stars !
summary: A shocking and tear jerking conclusion to the Divergent Trilogy !

“Allegiant” is the third book in the “Divergent trilogy”. It is a young adult (YA), dystopian society book set in Chicago at some point in the near future.  Overall, I thought this was a disappointing conclusion to the series for a variety of reasons including the narration, the change in the two main characters, the overabundance of romance scenes, the premise behind the central conflict, and the ending.  Below is a spoiler-free recap of these things.The narration switches between Tris and Tobias (Four) constantly throughout the book was confusing and unexpected since the reader understand things from Tris’ point of view.  There is a name heading at the beginning of each chapter to tell you whose point of you view you are following; however, I found myself having to stop to recall whose point of view I was reading since they were both first-person, and to be honest sounded a lot a like.While the narration switches were annoying, the actual characters of Tris and Tobias seemed to be a lot weaker than in the previous books.  I don’t know if that was the author’s choice to show a weaker version of the two, but it seemed to be a bit of a letdown that they were not the same strong, action-oriented characters as before.  You cannot even factor in the passage of time since this book takes place immediately after the previous one – there is no time for sudden growth and change in the characters.I know this book is in the YA category, but I also wonder if it was trying to be a romance as well.  It seemed like there was a much stronger focus on Tris and Tobias relationship, and it was more detailed than the previous books where the author used it to transition between scenes.  In “Allegiant” it seemed to be a central element, and it still seemed a bit dysfunctional at times as the two work out their issues.One of my biggest complaints is with the central conflict.  For two books, we’ve read about the secret information inside Chicago – information so important that that it would lead to killing.  A faction war is brewing and at the end of book two we finally have some more of the truth revealed.  Book three continues with that revelation, but it takes a backseat to a new conflict in the final book that didn’t seem very well thought out and somewhat weak overall.My other big complaint with this book is the ending.  Since this is a spoiler-free review, I won’t provide details about what happens, but I will touch on the illogical motivations and result.  Perhaps I’m thinking too much like Spock or Sheldon Cooper, but it seems like the actions the characters take should include some logic and alternatives especially if those actions are dangerous.  With “Allegiant”, it was more like “This is what we have to do and there is no other alternative.”  It seemed like the ending was more about shock value and discussion than it was about bringing the story to a satisfying conclusion.
Wow. Definitely as attention grabbing and page turning as Divergent and Insurgent.And that ending, there are no words for

What would you do if you discovered everything you thought you knew about yourself, your family, and even your world was a lie? This is what happens to Tris and her friends in this stunning conclusion to the Divergent Trilogy.Allegiant is a story of love and hate, of madness and self sacrifice, of decency and degradation. It's a powerful story about what it means to be human. Following Tris and Tobias as they struggle to discover who they truly are is an emotional rollercoaster ride made all the more intense by what's going on in world around them. Everything is falling apart and it only stands to get worse if they can't find a way to stop it.This is by far the best book in the trilogy, but I warn you, the ending is a punch in the gut. I suspected it was coming but I was so hoping I was wrong that when it actually happened it still managed to take away my breath. But if the moment itself was painful, then the aftermath is even worse.I highly recommend this series to any fan of YA dystopian fantasy. You'll fall in love with the characters and have your heart broken at every turn, but it's well worth it.
summary: Stunning End To A Great Trilogy

reviewText: ** SPOILER ALERT ** (I didn't give exact details, but it can be easily inferred)I feel let down by the poor portrayal of the alternate POV's (I was one of those that had a very hard time keeping up with which "head" I was in) and lack of originality vs. the first two books (it seemed like the same story told from a slightly different perspective), which made the end feel like it was written for "shock value" in order to make up for the ho-hum pace and absence of page-turning action throughout the rest of the book. I'm not saying that was intended, obviously I can only speculate what was in the authors mind. Regardless, that is the way it "felt" to this reader.Not only that, it felt so pointless... there wasn't anything revolutionary or thought-provoking that gave comfort and purpose to the pain you felt reading the end. One of my favorite movies is "Pay It Forward" which ends in the death of the main character, and a child at that. It even ends just when everything seems to be looking up for the little guy. It ripped my heart out, but it replaced that pain with hope, understanding, and "awe" at seeing just exactly how far-reaching the actions of that character were. Just writing about it now gives me chills.Allegiant was nothing at all like that. I don't feel like it would have taken much to show the effect and impact the sacrifice here had on the world, not just one character. I suppose I'm just as disappointed for all the possibilities and promise it had, but didn't take advantage of. I may have missed the author's point, but the author's point is lost without more definition for those who don't have those characters inside their head/heart and need a little more detail to "get them there."Now, those going to the extreme of being just downright hateful are going way overboard for a book.  Death threats - take a deep breath and get a grip!  I'm also not going to be overly hasty and say I'll NEVER read one of her books again - never say never.  But, will it make me think twice about reading her material the next time? Absolutely. Will I go searching and make it a point to keep up with her future publications, salivating for the next one? Obviously not. ESPECIALLY for a newly emerging author. This isn't an author that I've been reading and loved so many of her books and she just had a "flop" in there. I'm not going to completely "write off" Veronica Roth, but I'm not going to be anxious for her either.

reviewText: So many negative reviews... and I dont know why!SPOILER ALERTHow else would anyone expected this to end?  This is not a happily-ever-after trilogy.  All three books lead us to believe that Tris is more selfless than she gave herself credit for, which came in to play in the biggest way at the end.  The book left the city in a rebuilding phase.
