reviewText: It’s books like this that make it hard to write a review spoiler free. Anytime I try to formulate a sentence I just have one thing I want to say… and I can’t.I started the Divergent series straight off the heels of The Hunger Games trilogy. Prior to reading that, I had only read a handful of YA so I was desperate to find something that made me feel like The Hunger Games did. Luckily, it took me no time as my local bookstore had Divergent labeled as “If you liked The Hunger Games try this…”. I dove into Divergent and fell completely in love with it. I had no idea it was the first book in a trilogy when I picked it up, but lucky for me I had waited so long to fall in love with YA that Insurgent was just days away from release. I had no idea that this trilogy would do things to my heart the way it did. I have loved AND hated the same character from one book to another, I have cried and I have screamed and it’s so entirely weird to me that this is how It ends. It’s done… and I don’t know how to sum into words the catastrophic event that my heart just happened to go through in the prior hours.I am going to keep this spoiler free as possible, for Allegiant. Divergent and Insurgent spoilers will be inevitable so if you haven’t read those two yet, I suggest stopping now. I have linked to Goodreads at the end, so list a few additional thoughts in a spoiler tag.Tris, quite possibly, might be one of the strangest written characters for me. I loved her in Divergent, just adored her. I thought she was strong, but emotional, kind but tough… and I just really liked and appreciated her for her qualities. I practically detested her in Insurgent. I hated her whinyness, and her inability to think about anyone but herself and probably the biggest reason was for the way she constantly hurt Four. Well, I loved her all over again in Allegiant. She was almost entirely back to the Tris I fell in love with in Divergent and I have to thank Veronica Roth for giving me back the heroine that originally made me love this series. Surprisingly, Four who I have consistently loved from book to book was the character that I wasn’t to scream at. He seemed so irrational in Allegiant at times and it more than frustrated me. He did come to be the Four I loved again, but… I didn’t much enjoy that I spent a large part of the book being angry with him. Christina, will always be a favorite of mine and I have liked her consistently throughout the series. Uriah and Zeke were two of my favorites from the beginning of the series, and they might be two of the characters I am saddest to leave. I loved their personalities and how they played an equally important part to both Tris and Four.For the first 25% of Allegiant I thought it was very good, fast paced and it held my attention. Then the next 55% of the book was so slow-paced that I honestly expected I would have to put it down for good… well, I reached a certain point at the end where my entire stomach region may have, in fact, been lodged into my throat so for that, Veronica Roth, kudos to you because only excellent writing can do that to a person.I LOVED the dual point of view. The fact that we could view this story from both Tris & Tobias’s eyes was fantastic. I think it wouldn’t have had as big of an impact on me if it wasn’t for that. I especially loved Tobias’s voice. It especially becomes import with the dual point of view towards the end of story and I think Roth made an excellent choice by writing like this.One of my biggest disappointments of Allegiant was the predictibility. I had somewhat of an idea or expectation where the story was going to go after Insurgent. I really loved the ending of the second book, but I had this idea in my mind what was going to happen and I wasn’t entirely wrong. I also wanted MORE. I felt starved of an amazing story when I finished and that is probably my biggest problem with the ending. I mean, Roth took this book where I’m sure no one thought it would go, I sure as hell didn’t at least and I HATED THAT. I think she achieved a shock value and surprise that we may not see again for a very long time but I hated the way she did it. The actual event that takes place is not even the part that bothers me … it’s the way it was done. I don’t think it did the characters, or the series the justice it deserves.I enjoyed the epilogue however, and that did actually cast Allegiant in a better light for me but I’m sad to say that I was expecting a bit more from the ending of one of my favorite series and I didn’t get it.My review is impossible to sum up my feelings, I also don’t think that you should hold my review in much regard when it comes to Allegiant. If you started this series, you should finish it… and keep an open mind. You may love the ending, you may hate it… or you may be a bit put off like me. It’s worth it to see how Tris & Four’s story ends.

If you're gonna have two different perspectives, both in first person, they need to feel like different characters, but they sounded the exact same. Veronica Roth’s Divergent Trilogy quickly filled the gap left in YA dystopic fiction after the release of Mockingjay as many rushed to call it the next Hunger Games. With this week’s release of Allegiant, the Divergent Trilogy’s final installation, the comparisons continue. Allegiant definitely packs an emotional wallop for many invested readers of the trilogy (and for good reason), but after a little time and reflection, I understand and agree with many of the criticisms of Roth’s conclusion.The biggest difference between Allegiant and its two predecessors is the shared narrative. Instead of limiting itself to Tris’ perspective, the novel alternates between her and Tobias/Four. Many find this confusing because their narrative voices are very similar. I didn’t have trouble or think too much of it but then, I had just finished a different YA novel with a similar narrative technique that was executed in a poorer manner (the review of which, I will post next week). The sudden change in approach did strike me as odd and initially unnecessary but by the novel’s end, the larger reasoning for the change was made clear.For the complete review, please visit my blog[...]

reviewText: I am not going to write a full review. I agree with what everyone else is saying.To summarize:1.) Tris and Tobias both have a brusque, extremely similar tone. He doesn't need to be perfect, but the decisions still didn't seem like him. They didn't seem like things that would compel him. Tris seemed cold to me, too controlling. Just like in Insurgent, except perhaps not as suicidal. Evelyn, Marcus, Peter, and Caleb also weren't the same or realistic.4.) Finally the ending. I don't know if Ms. Roth became cocky and decided to kill Tris because she was trying to be literary and not just write for the fans. I sobbed and screamed because I was so angry and upset. This wasn't what I asked for. I asked for answers and an ending that made me feel satisfied. TRIS DYING, THAT DIDN'T DO ANYTHING GOOD. I'VE FELT RESTLESS AND OUT OF SORTS. Like the ending was ill-fitting.Why?I wish I could talk to Veronica. Maybe she could answer my questions.Or maybe she wouldn't no what to say. Maybe she doesn't know.Maybe she had no idea of the damage she's done. I admired her so much. And now I feel lost.

reviewText: I cannot remember when I have been as disappointed with the end of a book or series as I am with Allegiant, nor do I understand why Veronica Roth would write this ending with the Divergent movie due out soon. I could not wait for this book. Almost a full year of wondering what's going to happen can drive an avid reader mad. So once I had ALLEGIANT in my hands, I was ready to see what author Veronica Roth had in store for her final book in the Divergent trilogy.This book is classified as a dystopian. It's a strict world that's built on secrets. There will, of course, be discord and chaos. This is also a war story--people are going to get hurt; other people will lose their lives. So if a reader approaches this type of story and expects sunshine and flowers, the story is already an injustice.Everyone has a right to their opinion, and you can get angry, and you can rage over the things that happen in this book; I've gotten angry over many books. I understand that expectations are high and when they're not met, it can dampen the spirit. But it's shocking to see how many people are docking this down because of the ending. I admit, I was unprepared for the ending. It was very sad and I don't agree with it, but it's not going to be a reason to dock this novel down on a rating.My major complaints involved the pacing and the merging of two points of view. The writing has always been an iffy point, but it was always engaging. I had such a hard time getting into the book. I've never been a fan of dual points of view and it doesn't help that Tris and Four sound the same. Also, for being narrated by two people, the views were so limited. It took forever to learn anything new. And their romance feels so forced. By the time I reached the middle, I was wondering if they were really a couple or just forced together under the circumstances. Those, to me, were the biggest letdowns.I'm still shocked by the low ratings for the ending. Save your tears for the narration and storyline instead.

(3 1/2 stars) I actually finished this 2 weeks ago and have been sitting with it before reviewing, as amongst all the uproar over the ending I needed to process it a little bit to figure out what I really think. And what I've decided is this: I am OK with the ending - it's not my favorite, but it does feel true to the individual characters and the overall storyline and theme of the trilogy. While I appreciate when a series leaves me with emotional satisfaction, this isn't the purpose of all books, and an author owes us nothing. Roth did what she felt she needed to do  - this is her work - and I respect that. It's thought-provoking, and that's powerful in its own right.But I still can't rate Allegiant 5 stars, because the larger problem for me with the book are the holes in the 'big reveal' we get. Divergent and Insurgent created an intriguing world for us, with the faction structure creating a fascinating lens through which to comment on our own contemporary society - this is how the best dystopian fiction functions. The problem with Allegiant is that the 'big reveal' - the story behind how this world was originally created - just has too many holes and leaves too many loose ends. How is this genetic agency able to run so independently? Where is the rest of the government and everyone else? How is it that no one has escaped from these experiments, or has always been caught? How do they have cameras all over the experiment, capturing every moment, and no one in the experiment ever becomes aware of this? Then there is the matter of the memory-wipe and death serums, and that there is one per faction - the serums are just way too convenient and feel contrived.Combine that with Tris's and Four's love affair getting a bit annoying at times, and Allegiant just wasn't as satisfying as the first two books. On its own, it was only a 3 1/2 star for me. But I'd still rate the entire series a 4-star, with many 5-star ideas and scenes, so I do look forward to the movies, and hope they pull from the best.

This review and more can be found on my blog, The Library Canary: [...]I’ve been waiting for this book for so long. We’ve all been waiting for this book for so long. When it arrived at my house on Tuesday, I practically ran to the door and ripped the box out of the delivery guy’s hands. I danced around my living room with it like an idiot. Then I started reading. And I realized that we got to read from Four’s perspective! I don’t know how I didn’t know this, but I didn’t. I was pumped. I love multiple POVs and I’ve wanted to get inside Four’s head for a while. (I haven’t read any of the novellas yet.)Unfortunately, I was disappointed with the shifting POVs. Four’s voice wasn’t very distinct. I found myself forgetting that I was reading from his perspective. Then, when he would say something like “Tris said”, it would jar me. His voice and Tris’s just sounded so similar. They are such different people that it shouldn’t have been like this. I understand why Veronica Roth chose to write from both perspectives. It was necessary to the story, but it could have been done a lot better. In addition, I kind of felt like Four turned into a wimp in this book. And maybe it’s because we were in his head, but I just always saw him as this super strong character and in this book I saw an insecure child. He lost some of his swoon-factor for me.I have been dying to know what’s outside the city for a year now. Then I found out and it was like a slowly deflating balloon. So disappointing. I thought it was kind of lame. Not exciting at all. Just more typical dystopian novel stuff. This book was a lot slower paced than the first two. At times I felt like the plot was dragging. I think if what had been outside the city was….cooler?….the plot would have moved a lot faster. But it didn’t. And I was sad.Tris and Four still hadn’t worked their crap out in this book. I wanted them to be together, truly be together for the majority of this book. And they weren’t. They were still constantly bickering and arguing. I miss their relationship from Divergent. That being said, the times that they were together in this book were magical and had me crying and squealing.“I fell in love with him. But I don’t just stay with him by default as if there’s no one else available to me. I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other. I choose him over and over again, and he chooses me.” –TrisI love Tris so much. She's so smart and so brave and she's come so far throughout this trilogy. She's one of the most kick-ass characters I've ever read about. Every book she has learned something new and this one is no exception. I just wish that Four would listen to her!!!Four on the other hand, seemed to go backwards in this book. He didn't seem like he learned anything and he almost seemed to get careless. I felt like he didn't develop at all in this book. Maybe he just didn’t develop the way I wanted him to. I don’t even know. I’m so confused over my feelings for this book. I was really happy that Four got some closure with his parents though. His relationships with both his mom and his dad were really complicated and he was able to deal with them in this book.If you haven’t read it yet, prepare yourselves. Not everybody makes it out. Veronica Roth was not afraid to kill her characters. And I approved. Sad as it was (I cried so many tears), I admire the fact that she took the risk. This is a dystopian society. The city of Chicago is extremely unsettled. War is brewing between faction supporters and the factionless. Death is part of war and Roth doesn’t let us forget.I’ve been trying to figure out how to rate this book since I started writing this review. I just don’t know. I didn’t hate it. Everybody is in an uproar over the ending. The ending shocked me. I never saw it coming, but I understood it. And I felt like, had I opened my eyes throughout the whole series, I would have seen it coming. So I really didn’t hate the book. But I didn’t really enjoy it either. At least not like I enjoyed the first two books. So how do I rate this?Veronica Roth did tie everything up nicely. I didn’t have any unanswered questions. She closed it up enough that we knew where all the characters were, but also left the world open enough that we’re not sure exactly what was going to happen in the future. It was the perfect combination.“Sometimes it [bravery] is nothing more than gritting your teeth through the pain, and the work of every day, the slow walk toward a better life.” –FourThe writing was beautiful. I will give Veronica Roth that. There are so many sticky notes in my copy. It’s crazy how many lines I marked. There were lots of feels in this book about many different things. I pretty much cried the whole time reading. My heart is broken. My soul is broken. I feel empty. But, I think I’m going to give it a solid 3 stars. Obviously you should read this book. Especially if you’ve already read Divergent and Insurgent. Even if you haven’t, you should read this series. It’s a great series with lots of lessons learned and some awesome kick-ass characters. I guess I just expected more out of this conclusion and I didn’t get it. Happy reading all!

reviewText: Allegiant is a very powerful book. It pushes limits, breaks hearts and always, always makes you think. It is much more complex than most young adult novels in its challenges of what is logical versus what is right. The characters are infinitely human, neither heroes nor villains, at least not fully.Tobias reveals vulnerabilities I never would have guessed he had, and yet, they were completely believable and right for his personality and past. I loved that half of the novel was told from his point of view; the darkness and desperation he fights against were so intense it hurt my heart.Tris' side is less complicated and she doesn't change as much as Four, but her coming to terms with her family, living and dead, strengthened her character in subtle but significant ways. She gains a deeper understanding of things, which in turn gives the reader a deeper understanding of the characters and their motivations.While I loved so many things in this book, the writing didn't really pop as much as the previous novels, at least not for me and not in the beginning. At first it felt like a lot of exposition as a hundred new things had to be explained all at once. This might have been necessary, but it was also kind of awkward. Towards the middle it gained more intensity and the pace picked up, and by the end I was on the edge of my seat. Crying.The end was perfect. Heroic and sad and beautiful and unexpected and so very, very brave. Not just on the characters' parts, but on the author's as well. She took a unique path that, upon the arrival of the last page, made the whole trilogy fall perfectly into place. It was an ending that left me recalling earlier scenes with an 'Oh' of revelation that it was all leading to this.This novel is a worthy addition to any bookshelf.

Ok. Divergent is one of my favorite books. I read it over at least four time and used as topic for many of essays in school. When I read insurgent I was slightly disappointed because it wasn't as great as the first one but it wasn't terrible whereas the final book in the series was.Allegiant was a terrible conclusion to a well written and entertaining series. The story was completely predictable and I remember telling my friend exactly what would happen. It was nog only predictable but all of the concepts in the book were stupid and didn't really make much sense. *spoiler but not really a big one* the whole genetically damaged thing was stupid. I mean if you were going to play with genetics wouldn't you only test it on  a few test subjects rather than almost all of the people. And than again why would anyone do that? The whole thing seemed completely unrealistic.Another thing I didn't like about the book was the duel perspective. I don't mind books that are written in multiple points of views but I do mind when the characters sound exactly alike. And I mind when one of the characters whole personality changed. Tobias spends most of the book whining about everything and being depressed because *spoiler* he's genetically  damaged.Ok I'm done complaining. In general the book wasn't completely terrible there were some parts that I didn't mind. Like the part with tris learning more about her mom but that's about it.

Not the best of the series, but good. I do wish she would have given the switch in perspectives different personalities ans voices; I often felt confused as to whose chapter I was on. The ending is what I was expecting; but it was fitting. It made sense for the story and I applaud Veronica Roth for throwing caution to the wind and writing an ending that stayed  true to her characters and who they are, rather than writing a "candy" Disney ending.

This review contains absolutely NO SPOILERS if you've read Divergent and Insurgent.As some of you already know, Allegiant has generated some seriously STRONG reactions. They war on the five-star and one-star extremes. I don't provide star ratings because I dislike slating books together in a category when they are so completely different and how I felt about them was so completely different.In this case, I will make an exception and clarify that this was a 5-star book. I'll explain it the best I can without spoilers.For those who have already finished Allegiant and still have questions, Veronica Roth wrote this COMPLETELY SPOILERY End of Allegiant Explanation on her blog here: [...]Ok, let's get started. Some series enders feel like a rush-to-finish story where all of the loose ends are haphazardly tied together for a "ta-da" moment at the end. Allegiant is not like that at all.While there are certainly a ton of story lines and relationships that need resolving in this final book, Roth takes her time getting there, weaving and threading the future with the past. Tris, Tobias and their friends risk it all to see what the truth is beyond the fence and what it means for the factions and their lives.And that's something Roth does extraordinarily well - explain the toughest parts of life. Love, loss, heartbreak, joy and faith.Like this: "I fell in love with him. But I don't just stay with him be default as if there's no one else available to me. I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other. I choose him over and over again, and he chooses. me."Allegiant is simply filled with sparkling revelations like that one that make you want to weep with the truth of it.This novel stayed true to the previous books. Some feel like the end doesn't make fit in with the story as a whole, but I couldn't disagree more.Tris and Tobias develop even more in Allegiant and make decisions that fit in with their growth and maturity. In this book, the story became more than just factions and romance and frienships. It was about society and devastation and rebuilding.I loved that Allegiant had a more serious tone and stayed true to its core message: people are more than the sum total of their parts.This was an incredible series and more than getting a cookie-cutter, predictable ending, I got ideas. Ideas about how we live and think and about how people in the world of Divergent coped and loved and progressed. And that to me was more powerful and memorable than everything happening "the way it should."OVERALL:This book will make many of you sad and angry. I saw it as an authentic, harsh, beautiful way to end this amazing series. Allegiant leaves no loose ends and gifts readers with a story they will think about long after the last page is turned.

She is a major pushover letting everyone else make the decisions. Hands down Tris is the better character.

I do like the world of Divergent and how Chicago was done and the factions and such, I just don't think the author knew where she was going with the story.The dual narrators from Tris and Tobias is the main reason for the one star. 2.5 stars rounded up.Be Aware: Whilst I do not exactly give away the ending this review could be said to contain minor spoilers. And possibly major ones if you read between the lines.Blurb : Told from a riveting dual perspective, Allegiant, by #1 New York Times best-selling author Veronica Roth, brings the Divergent series to a powerful conclusion while revealing the secrets of the dystopian world that has captivated millions of readers in Divergent and Insurgent.Yeah. But no. Sigh. Pfft. Oh where to start. Darn it, I try and build up a reputation for being able to find the positive in everything and here I am actually struggling. So again I say Pfft.Ok, having given myself a few minutes there are positives. I won't have to read it again. Oops thats rather an ironic positive. Lets go for a more positive positive. The quality of the writing has not diminished. Ms Roth can still put words together into sentences and make them jump off the page. Great. Thats one of the things that made Divergent and Insurgent so compelling. She's a damn good writer. Characterisation is (was?) top notch and the world is (was?) well imagined...thats why many readers have been holding their breath for the promised "stunning" conclusion of the series. Well job done. It WAS stunning. Although perhaps not in the way one might have hoped...For the early part I kind of enjoyed it...I disliked the dual points of view especially because I worked out fairly quickly why we were going to need such a thing, and despite my hanging on in there in the hope that I was wrong - I was not. Which in and of itself left me uninspired - a writer of the calibre of Ms Roth really should be able to surprise me. After all she has done it once or twice over the course of the first two novels.  Then shortly after Tris and Co hit the "outside" world it started to annoy me..then I started to swear at it.The whole "genetics" thing seemed illogical given what had gone before. It was also a terribly dull explanation considering the lead in and the inspired writing that gave us Dauntless, Erudite et al and how the ending of "Insurgent" hinted at the possibility of something unique and wonderful to come. The new characters were a bit wooden - possibly because, this being the last novel, there was nowhere really for them to go - so yes. Uninspired. Thats me.Now I'm back to this. Sigh. Pfft. Disappointed.Final thoughts.  Some people have called Ms Roth brave for the ending she gave us, others have called her cliched, others still have said she has betrayed her loyal following. Me I sit here. This is her story, her vision, her ending. So in that sense it is what it should be. For me though it felt wrong. I disliked it intensely and I'm not afraid to say so. Ms Roth has not betrayed me, she wrote her ending and its my choice to not like it.  I would agree there is some cliche, and I would also agree it was kind of brave....I also wonder if the movie trilogy (assuming they all get made) will have a different ending. I imagine it will...Happy Reading Folks!**Hardback purchased via Amazon UK **

I was not a fan of this series.  Teen dystopia is over done and gimmicky.  Throughout this series, I excused this fact because the main relationship between Tris and Tobias had some potential.  Mind you, I was never fully convinced of their ages, but given the "world " created for them I excused this as well...(Tobias would be preternatural in his fully ripened manhood if he were even 23-24 let alone 18...but hey I let it slide.)The world created in this series was utterly silly artifice.  Any intelligent teenager would find it  an over-simplified attempt at allegory of teen society.  But hey....everyone needs something to read....I get it.  Also, secondary characters were meaningless, utterly expendable in their lack of vitality or development...ok whatever.However, what was refreshing was the relationship between Tobias and Tris, and particularly the character of Tobias.  In the first two books, Roth had  written a lovely man with Tobias.  Sure he is  rippled with bo-hunky muscles and tats....but he was more than that....he was a fully ripened man.  He was confident and calm without being patronizing.  He was tough and accepting and perceptive.  He respected other people and mostly he respected Tris.  He understood that she needed whatever she needed and did not judge her for this, and (most importantly to parents of teenagers here) he was fine with her needing to lead and be strong in her own way, not because he "let" her, but because he loved her.  He was a true man...as I said before this is way unbelievable for an 18 year old even in a dystopian future....but hey like in Ender's Game, I aged him by 6 years or so in my mind.Then, as if she didn't understand what she had written in the previous two books, Roth decides to emasculate her character in the third book.  It doesnt help that she took the "cowards" way out and created the device of a dual narrative (horribly executed) in order to write this third in the series.  It was a glib disservice to his character to not at least have made the effort to develop his narrative properly.But what really emasculated him was taking away the true manhood of his character.  Why would a fully confident whole adult male suddenly need to "grow up" and mature more?  Sure, given his circumstances, he would be unsure, bewildered and not himself in this chapter of the story.  Sure, given that he was a human being he would still have some fears (four to be exact), but it seems that Roth confuses these things with maturity or lack thereof.A mature man can be hero and a resolved, complete, compassionate and smart one at that, AND he can still be worried, irresolute and make mistakes.  This does not mean he is child, it means he is human.  But Roth seems bent on using these reactions in her character of Tobias,  to make further assumptions that he is just a "teenaged boy after all". "Allegiant" was a disappointment on the same level that any story that ends with,  "And then I woke up..." would be a disappointing. Once the main characters walk outside the city, the author runs out of story.  It's really unfortunate that she kept writing anyway, because "Allegiant" spoils what started out as an interesting, reasonably plotted story.***SPOILERS***It is spoiled, not because the main character dies, but because the author dumps a lot of implausible hoopla in our laps that adds nothing to the series, and creates problems that were not an issue in the previous books.  In fact, Tris dying is the only thing in the book that makes sense.For example, we discover that all you need to do to leave Chicago is get on a train, ride to the border, then take a truck the last few yards past the fence. Which makes you wonder why the factionless have been content to hang about Chicago, cleaning toilets and starving, generation after generation, when all they needed to do was leave.We also discover that the people inside the city have altered, defective genes.  The "divergents" are the only normal people, with normal, unmodified genes. Which leaves the reader wondering, why exactly are normal humans resistant to mind altering drugs?We discover there are lots of normal people outside Chicago who have normal, unmodified genes. These genetically "pure" individuals are capable of producing children.  Yet, they've decided to shove a bunch of people with altered genes into a city for a few generations on the off chance that some of them might produce normal children. In other words, the existence of the city makes no sense at all.When the book was about the misunderstandings that arise between people with different temperaments (a very real, and often relationship destroying problem), the author was doing pretty well. It was good that she pointed out that there are physical and genetic differences between people to explain many personality differences, I think people need to be aware of that fact, it helps encourage tolerance.  I can even see some merit in imagining a group of scientists making a misguided attempt to breed a generation of people with more flexible, multi-temperament minds, then losing control of the experiment. An experiment run amok is good, solid, and traditional sci-fi plotting and it could have been used to bring out many of the themes the author apparently wishes to address in her books.But the author starts floundering when she attempts to convince us that our perceptions of the situation in the first two books were all wrong. Tris is normal, and by golly, so is everyone else. So let's shed a tear for the fallen, set aside our fears, remember that God forgives all, and so should we.  I see where she was trying to go with it all, I even applaud her direction, but she created plot holes all along the path and then filled them full of trash.  It's a terrible shame.

reviewText: Veronica Roth left us with an epic revelation and cliffhanger in INSURGENT, and we can now see the Divergent journey through to completion with ALLEGIANT. If you've not read the first two installments in this worldwide best-selling YA dystopian trilogy, be warned that the following review will glance by plot points better discovered on your own in those two novels. However, I will not throw in spoilers from ALLEGIANT. And, unlike most of my reviews, this one will primarily concentrate on Roth's writing style, because I can't add to this book's blurb without ruining the surprises you've got coming!Catch up with me by reading...Divergent...and...Insurgent (Divergent, Book 2) (Divergent Series)...if you haven't, and come back!Picking up with Tris awaiting trial in lock-up and Four roaming the halls of Erudite/Factionless headquarters, Roth has made changes to or exaggerated parts of her prose which may or may not fit your taste. The most obvious is the switch to two narrators. Delirium, Matched, Partials, Legend, and Letters to Nowhere are YA series with at least one book with a single and one book with multiple narrators. Some series' volumes received more acclaim with reviewers with one narrator; some with duel narration; others saw no measureable difference. The common factors in the rating upswings appear to be easily-distinguished personalities of the protagonists and little variation in what readers expect from their favorite characters.* Did VR employ differing writing styles to separate T's and F's narrations? No.* If there weren't names heading each chapter, could I tell who was speaking? Rarely.Did VR include context clues to keep the narrator's identity in the forefront of my mind at all times? Rarely.Beyond the voice of the narrator, the pacing of the book should feel natural. The timing of each narrators' experiences should be clearly indicated to allow the reader to build a mental timeline. As these experiences occur, short and long sentences should be varied, to keep from bogging the reader down in a rhythm. Conversations which take a stated number of minutes should last longer than a few lines of dialog and be balanced by other characters progressing in whatever their projects were at the time. The last book in a series is often not the correct place for "all" fine details on dystopian technology, history, and genes; authors should present enough answers prior to the omniscient book - at least to satisfy an inquisitive teen growing up in the environment and who'll be asking, "Why?" (And don't tell me that you can modify that out of them).* Did VR have clear timeline delineation? No.* Characterize VR's sentences? Always short/choppy* VR's individual scene structure...? Often feels rushed* Did VR clear up lingering Qs about tech, history, and genes? Yes (in the 3rd book)After each few chapters, I would check to see how much of ALLEGIANT was left. Closer and closer to the end, and I still had no idea how Roth would wrap up the story before I was out of pages. Then, the biggest, most impossible scene in YA history! Roth took a risk, and many readers aren't happy. Then, a double-digit number of additional chapters. I won't tell you the shocker (That is the point of the book?), but I also don't want you going in wholly unprepared. Grab the box of tissues and whatever is your comfort food. If you set the novel on fire afterword's, I won't blame you (Sadly, I have an e-reader.). But Roth's chances paid off in at least one way. We'll all remember Roth, Divergent, and "the" bravery that was truly dauntless.* Did the trilogy end suddenly? Yes and no* About that ending? Tear-jerker alert!* Sexual content? Kissing/touchingNow, readers will be debating which character embodied which faction virtue- Candor the Honest, Amity the Peaceful, Erudite the Intelligent, Abnegation the Selfless, and Dauntless the Brave. Some may argue that these no longer matter, but I believe otherwise. Veronica Roth did her best to teach us to overcome our own human nature. Even the best of us cling most often to one avenue for personal character improvement. No one says, "I should be better at..." and lists a number of self-reflective choices, which will likely benefit the community, just as much as herself. Though the trilogy is complete, let us all continue to strive to be divergent in our behavior, whether or not we liked the trilogy's ending.Perhaps, dear readers, the unpalatable ending is the greatest gift of all. We learn afresh the Divergent values bone-deep at the end and receive a conclusion no other best-selling YA author of my acquaintance dared to offer up until ALLEGIANT. Roth was a first-time author; she was still learning. And yet, she will follow me long after I forget many of the must-haves on my TBR.Have you read...Julie Cross'sLetters to Nowhere (Letters to Nowhere Part 1)Lauren Oliver'sDeliriumMarie Lu'sLegendDan Well'sPartials (The Partials Sequence)Ally Condie'sMatched
summary: Veronica Roth completes the trilogy with dauntless writing experiments, but not all are right for ALLEGIANT (Divergent #3)

NO SPOILERSI am one of the biggest Divergent fans out there... but Allegiant was the worst novel in the trilogy. In fact, it might be one of the worst books I have ever read. Never mind the pointless ending, but the writing itself was atrocious. We started the series in the mind of Tris, and her character was pretty obvious. There was a VERY distinct tone of the first two books in this series, and I think that's what made me fall in love with the books. Roth had a unique and addictive writing style that is completely absent in this novel!!!! It's GONE. Tris and Four behaved in ways they NEVER should have, going along with things they would have never considered in the first two books. I'm all for character development, but not a complete re-write of the characters we fell in love with. Not only did Tris turn into a spineless, whiny little brat, but Four lost so much of his mysterious-bad-boy demeanor that he didn't even seem like the same character.Allegiant read like Roth was bored; like she HAD to finish the series but didn't quite feel like putting all her effort into it.... which is odd because the book IS lengthy, but the quality is AWFUL. I can't begin to tell you how angry and upset I was all day after staying up ALL NIGHT on its release day, but as soon as I started Allegiant I knew I was in for disappointment. I feel betrayed as a fan and not only did I return the book, but I will never, EVER buy another novel by Veronica Roth again. I think she got greedy and forgot about her passion for writing, because it certainly seems like she did.The ending was completely unnecessary and probably one of the most unsatisfying, incomplete conclusions to a series I have ever experienced. Roth did what she did because she could. She did it to prove that she could take a risk. But I think she made the wrong decision and, personally, it made me hate the book even more, which I thought was impossible.If you're a fan, pass on reading this book. Imagine your own ending. In fact, read some clean fan-fiction because I assure you it will probably we better written and more satisfying than this piece of crap.

**SPOILERS**My review is based on what I've read about this book--the plot summary, numerous other reviews with spoilers, and Veronica Roth's blog detailing why she ended the series the way she did.  I LOVED Divergent, slowly made my way through Insurgent, and I'm not sure I'll even be able to read Allegiant knowing about all the plot holes, weak writing, and the overall message. If I do, I will update this review.You may be wondering how I can review a book I haven't read.  My review is simply to express my displeasure with the message Roth sent to young adults in the final book (and through her blog).Throughout the series, Tris was constantly flirting with death in the name of sacrifice and ultimately dies in the same vein, once she apparently fully understands the meaning of sacrifice.  Why not have Tris be a strong heroine who saves the day by finding an alternative? Instead, the author is telling young adults that as long as you love someone, you're strong enough, and it's (arguably) necessary (the three criteria she lays out in her blog), go ahead and die. Forget trying to find another way to solve your problems. I hate to think how young adults might translate this message into their own lives and their own problems.  I don't think self-imposed death (even in the name of sacrifice) should be revered in young adult literature.  There are too many ways for teens to interpret the need for a "sacrifice."  In my opinion, making sacrifice seem like a noble act of courage shows a complete lack of responsibility by Roth to her target readers.
summary: Not a good message for young adults

reviewText: Spoiler warning, don't read this post if you don't want the ending ruined: A series of this nature, based on a cruel and harsh world, is always going to feature lots of death, including the death of central characters. Tris' death was pointless, she survived the death serum only to be shot is just pointless. reviewText: I loved the first novel of this series and was reasonably happy with the second. But the third just doesn't work. ***Spoilers in case there is anybody who doesn't already know the ending***Whether she intended to do so or not, the author raises certain expectations in her readers when she creates a strong romance plot. Likewise when she writes most of a series in the first person heroine's point of view -- i.e., you can't tell your story if you're dead. Switching to a dual POV in the final book is a giveaway that either Tris or Tobias isn't going to survive, but unfortunately the dual perspectives don't ring true, since the two voices are too similar.Killing the heroine/hero of any novel is a huge risk, and it really only works when the readers are expecting a tragic ending. In a series like this one, we expect triumph at the end, not to mention a happy resolution for the primary romance. But when the trilogy can be summed up with "your mom dies, your dad dies, your friends die, then you die" there's not much to celebrate or feel good about. The world sucks and then you die. I read books to escape that unhappy reality!
summary: Taking risks doesn't always pay off.

I have just finished reading Allegiant and I feel that this is going to be a hard review to write. I'm going to try and keep it spoiler-free, but that's difficult, so if you haven't read it yet, you might want to stop reading here.While the story was good overall, there were some things I didn't like. There seemed to be a bit of repetition. I got sick of being told what people's feet sounded like against the floor, for instance. Also, I found it difficult constantly switching between Tris' and Tobias' points of view. It made it hard to follow at times, especially if I had to leave the book to participate in Real Life for a while. I would come back and have trouble working out whose head I was in. I understand why the changes in point of view were necessary, but it was still annoying.I was worried in the first half of the book that Tris' and Tobias' relationship was just going to be more of the same from the other book, with them constantly at odds with each other. Thankfully, that wasn't the case throughout the whole book.Also, with the revelations of what was going on outside the fence, everything felt a bit flat. It was almost like it took away the magic of the Divergent world, even though I was expecting it to go in that kind of direction.And now for the ending. There's no doubt it upset me, but at the same time I had to acknowledge that it was consistent with the characters' personalities. I know sometimes authors can't change character behaviour in their stories because that behaviour can almost seem beyond the author's ability to change. I think that's probably the case here. I must confess that, almost to the last moment, I was hoping for a 'Bobby Ewing' situation, but at the same time, I knew it would be a cop-out. Having said that, I don't think I can bring myself to read any of the Divergent series again.

This is my week of exploring the world of Veronica Roth, captured in the books of the Divergent trilogy.  Unfortunately, after a strong start and middle, Allegiant fell in my esteem.  The reason for this is quite simple - and not at all tied to the "shocking" end that had the blogosphere in an uproar (I remember seeing all of that and, having yet to pick up Divergent, just dismissed it because I didn't want a spoiler to hit me.  I wasn't spoiled, but I wasn't surprised by the ending either.)  That said, there will be a bit of spoilers happening in this review because it's the third book in the series, so don't read on if you haven't read the first two: Divergent and Insurgent.Here's where Allegiant went wrong for me.  The dual narration technique.  All this time, I've been in Tris's head.  Four has had a mystique about him and, while I still don't get the whole romance angle (except from a marketing point of view), I liked the bit of mystery.  Imagine my complete and total disappointment to find that he thinks remarkably similar to Tris.  So much so, in fact, that there were times I had to flip back to see just whose head I was currently in.  Four was nothing like I imagined him to be, and I really didn't like him that much after being there in his head.  Not at all.That said, I think Roth overstepped in Allegiant as well.  Too much in too few pages.  Too many factions vying for control weakens them all, and the story by default.  I was so confused that, by the end, I was happy to actually see something happen - although the dual perspective tipped me off from the start on what the surprise might just be.  I was so disappointed, because really... Divergent was well thought-out and put together but by the time Allegiant began to move it became sloppy and hard to keep track of.  Too many people making stupid decision, too much happening out of character (how often have you seen people step down just like that? *snaps fingers*), it just didn't make sense.  I understand that there needed to be some kind of neat, package ending all tied up with a bow but the series would have been better ending on chaos and left out there in the air, for the reader to speculate.  I hated feeling pigeon-holed into fully believing all of the really far-fetched things that were happening.So, while I thoroughly enjoyed Divergent and Insurgent, Allegiant was a dud for me.  I would recommend the series, still, because the first two books carry it (and I'm hoping the movie ends up better since we are, thankfully, free of what's inside the characters heads).  But watch out for this book, man.  If you loved Four going in, you are really gonna have a hard time with it.

And I spent most the time with my face scrunched up in utter disbelief that I only continued to read it just to finish it off.Half way through it I went to WIKIPEDIA and read the ploy summary, rolled my eyes and forge on.Four is NOT Divergent (What was the point of that???)The city is a scientific experiment to produce good genes ( Really?)and being watched by big brother. (dumb)Four does irrational acts that is sooooooooo not like him.Tris and Four fight....The war within the city comes to quick halt.....I can only blink at this.Tris dies.....I hoped that her selflessness would break through and Caleb would die instead, but not so. What was the point of her dying away????I felt for Four as he mourns her. I did get choked up about that.Bottom line, with the expectation of the first book, I was seriously disappointed.I really envisioned this book going in a completely different way. I saw more of a teenage urban warfare, the overtaking of a government and establishing a new one.... I really had this mix of Buffy the Vampire Slayer//Harry Potter///Red Dawn in mind and it went sooooo off the rail. Why did it go so crazy???? I am a 40 something-year-old mom who loves to read and get involved and fall in love with the characters in a story.  I loved the first two books in this series.  I thought they were amazing.  I couldn't wait for the third book so I didn't even think about reading the reviews prior to reading it. I WISH I HAD. This series had everything going for it and the third book just should not have ever been written. This book did not have the same intensity or excitement as the previous two.  I found myself over half way through it and was asking myself when the action was going to start. How do you make Tobias a wimp in the last book when he has always shown what a strong character he is. How do you end up killing off Tris and letting all the bad guys stay alive. How do you write 2 books that are so intense and exciting that you just can't put them down and then end up with this last book and have it all fall apart. No suspense. No excitement.  Just depression at the end. Perhaps, if you were tired and just did not have the material to complete the series, you could have just waited.  I know that I would have been more than happy to wait for a better book with a better ending. Because of the way this book ended, I wish I had never started the series.  I have no desire to see the movie.  I will not read anything else by this author. Real life is depressing enough without investing time, money and energy into a book series and then have it shoved in your face. Worse yet, is my 13-year-old daughter, who is not an avid reader but is devouring these books, is determined to see this series through to the end. I hope she doesn't feel like I did when I finished it. From now on, I will never start a series until it is complete and then I will wait and read the reviews.

There’s obviously been quite a bit of controversy about the ending, and as I said no spoilers, but I will say that I was surprised and wouldn’t use the word “like” but I respected the ending. I also know that this book took a while to come together and was a bit of a disaster for a while and honestly, I totally got that while reading, but I was also influenced by that going in.But let’s skip back a little. When the story starts Tris is imprisoned by the new government, run by Four’s mother, waiting to figure out if she can go free or not. Eventually she’s obviously freed and even though the factions have been abolished there are still a lot of problems. A group called the Allegiant forms whose aim is to bring back the old faction system and also explore what Edith Prior meant when she said they needed to leave the city and help repopulate society. The Allegiant recruits Tris, even though she’s not sure what she wants, and a group, including Tori, Four, Christina, Uriah, and Peter leave the city to go in search of what else is out there.I actually really liked what they found when they left city boundaries, although I thought it could have been developed a little more, I was left with some questions at the end. But I thought the explanation of how the factions and their world came to be was really interesting and, as disturbing as the whole thing was, I really did believe it could (mostly) be true. Which is what I think makes dystopian books either good or bad–you have to be able to buy into what you’re reading as possibly being able to be true.My biggest issue with the book was the length. It was just so long, but somehow felt like not much happened. Even know when I’m writing this review, I’m trying to recall what happened and pretty much I have Tris released, they leave the city, discover what’s in the world, try to figure out what they want to do next. The story never dragged, but I still think it could have been made considerably shorter and tightened up, as well.Bottom Line: This wasn’t a completely satisfying finish to the story for me. I wish Veronica Roth could have ended it as well as she started it, but I didn’t dislike it and part of me respects that she was able to do what she did. I’m glad I read the series and I am incredibly excited for the first movie next year!
summary: An Ok Ending To a Pretty Good Series

reviewText: I ENJOYED ALL THE BOOKS TO THIS TRILOGY. THE BOOKS KEEP MY ATTENTION AND INTEREST. I ALSO ENJOYED THE CHARACTERS.

Do the publishers get a writers first book and then nag them to finish the trilogy in a certain length of time? There are a number of books that are so promising for a series and then they feel too early born to live decently.

...it's probably because you already read Divergent and Insurgent, so by all means, finish the saga so you can see for yourself if it was worth the time and the money.I'm glad I stuck with this trilogy, even though I was so disappointed with Insurgent, and despite the wave of negative comments Allegiant has caused.The tagline "what if your whole world was a lie"? practically gives away the entire plot: Allegiant keeps uncovering lie after lie after lie.There have been may negative comments about plotholes, the writing and the ending. Let me just say that the reason why I liked Allegiant so much is that despite the plotholes, the sloppy writing at certain points and the whole "haste" of it all (because it's clear Ms. Roth had to meet a deadline), is because it remained true to its essence to the very end. Although the Divergent trilogy has a love story at its core, it is still basically a dystopian novel, and that is what people seem to forget. I was not expecting rainbows and ponies, so I was not as shocked as others by the twist. Actually, when I saw there were 2 narrators I knew something was coming.Anyway, if you already embarked on reading the Divergent trilogy, just know that Allegiant does bring closure to the series, and even though there is a lot to process, the story remains true to its essence and in all honesty, I don't think it could've ended any other way.

I agree with most of the reviewers; this was a book that presented more questions than answers.  One question that I don't remember seeing was how could Tobias be a GD and Divergent when he also was resistant to the serum and had to be injected with the Divergent serum.  Michael, the lab tech said that Tobias showed a talent for resisting the simulations but that was all and it was an anomaly gene that allowed Tobias to appear to be Divergent.  Well, if he could resist simulations and serums and all the other cool stuff that Tris could do...(if it looks and talks like a duck).I didn't get how Peter loved being evil but at the end wanted to erase his memory so he could forget all the evil stuff he did.And why was the "secret" so powerful it would change everything...but didn't change a thing when it was revealed?Finally, I failed to comprehend why dividing people into factions would make them undamaged. The peace at all cost (Amity)faction wouldn't have survived a generation unless they could isolate themselves.  The selfless (Abnigation) faction would have little or no factionless people and all the starving factionless would run to that corner of the city making it impossible to sustain.  The nerds (Erudite)would shut themselves off and never have interbreed to create pure genes.  The tell it like it is (Candor) faction would hate each other by the end of the first year.  And the tattoo daredevils (Dauntless)would try to take over the other 4 factions.  There would be no way these factions could live together in a city and no way to keep one faction from taking over the weaker ones. None would heal, much less produce GP people.

Aaaaah man. I was so excited about this book after reading the first two back to back and again immediately. People are being very harsh because they're unhappy with the way it wrapped. While I'm in the same unhappy boat, I'm not harping on Roth because of the way the story ended. As a writer, I know we have to make difficult choices our readers won't like. My main problem was the way the ending was written. There were a lot of moments in the first two books where I had to reread passages to see if she was insinuating that something had happened (ie... Did they "hook up" that one time and she just didn't write it? There is one of those in Allegiant too, and you never really know.), and with the main part of the ending that everyone is so mad about, I honestly didn't think it had actually happened until it was undeniable. Trying to avoid spoilers here, sorry for the vagueness. I didn't like the way the "issue" was revealed to the other characters either. It was too quick and honestly a little heartless. I needed more from those two scenes as a reader.As for the rest of it, there were lots of questions that went unanswered, including one key fact that I thought was going to save them all... The code to the weapons lab--- "HER." That was a given for me but it never amounted to what I expected it to, when it was so obvious.I don't know if I'll ever reread this book again, I feel so let down emotionally. I love Tris and Four, I don't love the way they end up. But that's not going to keep me from pursuing Roth's other books. She tells an incredible story, describes emotions and depth of human character absolutely beautifully. I still love you, Veronica, I just don't like you right now!!! :(

This was far more confusing than the others in the series. It was hard to remember who was who because the exposition was very limited, and it depended on the reader remembering, which is difficult after several months. Not the best of the bunch, but still on the podium with a bronze.

This was a strong series. The middle book lagged for me in places as I grew frustrated with Tris's increasingly poor choices. Circular thinking stalled the story. Tris felt like a child in crisis from beginning to end and everything became stale as she rode current after current instead of making her own waves. But, in this book- she grew up! And her growth saw everyone around her evolve too. I work with Young Adults in a library and trust me, I almost didn't read this book because of the poor reviews. There is NO hiding the SPOILER and the MANY disappointed fans. I thought Roth was nuts. Who messes with teen fandom after your book has been picked up for a big budget movie makeover? But, after reading Allegiant- I think the answer is someone who is both dauntless and candor. Roth wrote a great series and her final book was solid with an excellently managed two person view. Nothing felt like it was done for shock value because every consequence rang true for all the characters. I think young people will ache for how the series ended, but for those who have suffered loss and chosen or witnessed real courage will find their own truth in Tris's journey. I will read this series again and I will continue recommending it to my readers over 13.
summary: Great Finale for a Strong Series

I would find myself forgetting who was narrating in the middle of a chapter sometimes but I did appreciate getting to hear things from Tobias's point of view.  I feel like Tris and Tobias had a really rough break since everything they ended up involved in was crooked and so to hear that the government outside the fence was also corrupt was a bit of a let down to me.  However, I do see where the author needed conflict to keep the story interesting. I was entertained throughout the whole book. I also really appreciated grammar and editing in this series.  Of the three books, I only noticed one error in grammar (which I believe was in the first book) which is refreshing these days.

reviewText: I waited so long for the ending to this trilogy that when it arrived I read the first half one night. I want to start off by saying that Veronica Roth is a wonderful writer.  I felt every emotion the characters felt. I loved the fact that. Roth allowed them to have feelings and thoughts way beyond their teenage years. Roth forces the reader to understand that, despite their young age, the world is so different and these kids have had to grow up fast. As an adult I appreciate this and can relate to it. I love the love between Tris and Tobias...its perfect first love chemistry and emotion. But its also real enough for readers of any age to relate to.Now my critique ...SPOILERS AHEAD!I think the main plot (besides the love) lost its credibility and edge with the addition of so many sub plot conspiracies.  I get that once the group left the city they had to encounter conflict...but to find another war (gd vs gp)  within a war...just made me lose interest. I didn't care for Nita and did not see the point to her character. And David...I felt like I didn't know enough about him to understand the obsession behind his motives.  If he loved Tris mother so much that should have been the focus of his life mission to destroy Tris..or to save her.Caleb...he would have never accepted to sacrifice his life. I just didn't believe it. Same with Evelyn. She  hadn't been a mother in years, didn't think twice about her son during the war but all of a sudden she'll quit the life of endless power and ambition after ONE conversation?  I don't buy it. Same with Marcus.And of course Tris ' death. I understand why she had to die but the way she died was ridiculous.  After all those life threatening ordeals she went through,  2 random shots by a guy in a wheelchair kill her? And the fact that it was all in vain ...besides her friends, nobody else seemed to care?  And her last words for. Tobias...just the whole thing seem rushed. She deserved better...all her sacrifice,pain and loss should have been rewarded. She deserved a happy ending.  If not happy, than she should have given her life for Tobias or Cristina. That would have made everything come together.Overall, the series is brilliant and I loved ever minute of it. I just do not agree with some of the choices Roth made for her characters....she lost what made each one sk strong or weak..that one trait that described them. And of course, I'll say it again, Tris deserved a better end.

First of all ---- story-related comment: it is so intriguing and dense that I couldn't read between the lines... And I think I'm pretty good doing it.My second point relies on the writer herself -- and careful SPOILER ALERT--- my deep and absolute admiration to Veronica Roth for having the nerve to make such an incredibly hard and interesting decision involving the main characters in the divergent series. I mean, seriously??  Not exactly the soft-spot romantic ending. BRAVO!! Veronica...... BRAVO!!

reviewText: I finally finished the third book of the Divergent series, Allegiant. I didn't plow through the book by any means, but instead read it over the course of about two months.Over those two months, I have to say my final review of the book is mediocre. Allegiant as a stand alone book MAY be okay - but as the third book in conclusion of a series? Not okay.First, the way the book is written is disorienting and confusing. Roth switched back and forth between Tris and Tobias' perspectives. Since I read the book over two months, however, this proved more confusing than interesting. At times I read Tobias thinking that it were Tris - and other times I read Tris thinking it were Tobias. I couldn't enjoy the plot.That brings to the second point - the plot. Like I said - the plot MAY have been a good standalone plot. Allegiant's plot, though, is incredibly different than the first two books. Essentially, furthermore, the nature of the plot semi-disregards the plot of the first two. All of a sudden the plot of Divergent and Insurgent don't matter in Allegiant - they'r just the "things of the past." This was sad to see, because I feel Roth worked very hard to develop that world and conflict.I will not go into plot holes or mistakes I believe Roth made. Through poor character development (I didn't know who was who half the time - nor did I feel the need to care) and unrealistic plot advancements, I have to give the book a 2/5.Was it entertaining? Sure. But don't think too much into it.
summary: Was it entertaining? Sure. But don't think too much into it.

reviewText: I loved the first 2 books in the "Divergent"series. The story kept me engaged and I loved the characters - Tris, Four, Uriah, Christina, and their group of friends - as well as the world that Veronica Roth created.My question for Veronica Roth on "Allegiant" is - WHY?????????** SPOILERS **Why does this third book change so drastically with no relation to the plotlines, premise and characterizations that you built up in "Divergent" and "Insurgent"? Why did you write such an empty, hollow story and in such a way that completely severed the audience's emotional connection to characters that they have loved?I could go on and on, but other readers have already said what I would like to say: "disappointing," "hollow, " left you drained," "ending has no sense of hope," "non-sensical deaths," "empty," "boring," "devoid of emotional ties and connection." I agree with other readers who indicate that they felt betrayed by Roth. I felt that as well and it is such a shame that the two books that I have loved are now completely damaged by this third, non-sensical conclusion to the story. I wish Veronica Roth made different choices to this book. The way the author set up the two narrative voices of Tris and Four (and flipped back and forth between them on EVERY - yes, EVERY - other chapter) just made it impossible for the audience to develop an emotional connection to the characters and the story. Did she really need to shift back and forth so often - too often that jarred the reader at every turn and prevented us from feeling continuity in the story and the character's point of view? In addition, this process made Tobias' thoughts too exposed. Any good fiction writer with a female protagonist understands that the male (romantic) protagonist always has to leave a sense of mystery in the eyes of his love interest. Even Stephenie Meyer understood this on the "Twilight" series. While we knew Jacob's thoughts, Edward's was often a mystery. Knowing Four's every thought and word diminished this sense of mystery. Four's character was also altered from a strong, protective, authoritative figure to a petulant, weak young man. I loved Tobias in books 1 and 2 but he ends up a battered and unrecognizable character in this one. And let me not even start with Tris. What Roth did with Tris was non-sensical in my eyes.I wish she decided to continue where she left off - continued with the characters and portrayals that she built; continued with the premise and plotlines that she created and developed and that the fans loved in the first two books; and fulfilled the destiny that was meant for Tris and Four - working together to rebuild the societies that have fallen apart (whether in Chicago or outside the wall) and mend the broken relationships with friends and family around them. Not like this. I did not expect this. I am upset, confused and angry about what she did with Tris and Four and how she ended this story.My final advice to anyone who is curious about how the story ends. Don't bother. Ignorance is bliss. You are better off just reading books 1 and 2. This book has ruined the series for me. I felt emotionally drained and empty. Angry. Devoid of feeling for the characters or the story by the time it ended. There is nothing in this book that gives audiences a semblance of hope or felt uplifting. Veronica Roth has not learned what Suzanne Collins, JK Rowling, JRR Tolkien, Jane Austen and many other successful and loved authors before her knew - that even with all the trials and tribulations that the hero or heroine go through in their journey, the ending has to lift the audience up and provide a sense of hope for the main lead(s). Harry Potter lost friends and family on his path to become a great wizard and beating Voldemort, but he survived and will rebuild with his best friends Hermione and Ron beside him. Katniss and Peeta may have gone through hell and back in the "Hunger Games" series - but in the end they will heal together. Frodo goes off with Gandalf, Bilbo and the elder elves to the Undying Lands while Sam, Merry and Pippin live on and raise families and Aragorn fulfills his destiny as King of Gondor in "The Lord of the Rings." Elizabeth Bennett marries Mr. Darcy in "Pride & Prejudice." And yet, here, Veronica Roth decides to rip the hearts of the audience apart and  leaves a torn Tobias and uncertain future for the very few left in the story.What a waste of an opportunity to end the story in a way that remains faithful to the spirit of the first two books. No thanks to Veronica Roth for ruining the series. This is going to be the first time where I hope Hollywood makes A LOT of changes when (if) they eventually make the 3rd film. Because at this point, nobody will want to watch this movie when it makes its way to the theaters. I know I won't.
summary: I feel cheated. A pointless and disappointing ending to what could have been....

(No spoilers in first paragraph)I'm surprised at the number of people who have given this book negative ratings.  I happened to glance at a few review titles before I bought the book (through G. Play), so I kind of knew something was going to happen, but I abstained from reading the spoilers.(WARNING: SPOILERS BELOW)...<b>I immensely enjoyed the ending (and the book in general) for a couple of reasons: </b>1.  I like it that (SPOILER) Tris died at the end.  It was obviously sad, but it was real.  I'm sick of books that everything is perfect for the heroine/hero and only minor characters die.  That's not the real world.  Yes, it's a book and it's fun to dream about things being rosy-posy, but that becomes cheesy and fake.  Up until about 2/3 through the book, I was expecting there to be a love triangle between Tobias-Tris-Mathew.  I figured that Tobias would die, and Tris would end up with Mathew, thus avoiding any real choice being made.  It dawned on me that perhaps Tris would die, not one of the guys, and I became more interested.2.  I like it that Tris and Tobias had a real relationship.  It was full of ups and downs, highs and lows; just like in our everyday lives.  It was full of depth and wasn't superficial (like Edward and Bella... ugh).  I like it that she was close to breaking up with Tobias, but chose not to.3.  I liked how many references there were to the world we live in.  All the uprisings reminded me of countries with constant political conflict and the US's relationship to them.  The constant replacement of one dictator for another was accurate.  I also appreciated the lower-class GDs.  The GPs' perception of them was similar to whites and blacks.4.  I like the way the sex scene was handled.  It's very tricky with YA books to have premarital, unprotected sex.  Many books don't even go there (e.g., Delirium, Matched), so it was realistic to have a hero/heroine do this.5.  The general depth of the characters was refreshing.  I liked being attached to more than one character.<b>Things that got a little annoying:</b>1.  There were a few grammatical errors and editing issues that made it awkward. For example, the lack of commas when describing who felt what became confusing.2.  The constant emotional feeling between Tris and Tobias.  I get it that they're deeply in love, but we don't need to constantly read about how every time they kiss it's like puzzle pieces fitting together and they can't keep their hands off each other.<b>Final thoughts:</b>For a young adult book, this is very well-written and engaging.  It's easy to read, but it makes you think and reflect on personal relationships and the world at large.

do not recommend Allegiant.*slams my brand new copy of Allegiant on the floor*Pointless. So utterly pointless.(and I will not contain my grief.)Here I thought Delirium series has a disgruntling ending. Congratulations to Divergent series for having the most illogical, senseless, and f***** up ending to date.*throws knives instead of confetti*When Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince ended, I was choking with tears. When The Reapers Are the Angels ended, I was ten times inconsolable. At least the grief for these two books was warranted. The deaths were not necessary, but it somehow embodied that the loss of life will contribute more on the lives of the people they left behind.That was so not the case for Allegiant. My buckets of tears were from anger, disbelief and outright dubiousness of a death that was obviously contrived just so this sacrifice can be as tangible as it gets for the readers.Well, f*** sacrifice. F*** selflessness.Are these two traits only measurable by death?Heroism only identified when life is offered willingly?I don’t think so!I did not mind that the plot is ridden with holes, or the story is outlandishly veering off from the dystopian theme (and straight to a sci-fi one), or characters did not leave the same hard imprint that the story implied (Who is Edward again? Or Tori? I cannot even remember George Wu!). I no longer cared as much about these elements, so long as Tris and Four get the fruits of their triumphs, whatever they maybe.But I was denied that. Fully, truly denied of that.Without it, I asked myself: “WTF am I reading this for?!!!”It’s been two days since I finished Allegiant, and I think it would take more days for my anger to subside. The madness brought about by its ending is nowhere near dissipating.I remembered I hated that time when GRRM killed a main character after building him so succinctly in A Game of Thrones. I finished three books already in ASoIaF series, and I still question that death. I still question, and yet I understand more now of why it is necessary.Veronica Roth killing one of her characters in Allegiant is a far cry from that. Not even a whimper.The term Allegiant was just a décor. Because when Tris and her friends went outside for the first time, there is a new uprising waiting for them that they can join. But now, it is between genetically pure (GPs) or genetically damaged (GDs). The conflict between the factions and factionless is still spiking, but Roth has to introduce another set of conflict for Tris. Gah, it never ends.So when the war between the factions and factionless reached its peak, the people watching from the outside (Department of Genetic Welfare) decided to act. But it was an abominable plan to Tris. But wait… in order to prevent them, Tris thought to do that same horrific deed (she abhorred) to the originators of the plan. What?! How’s that for a solution?!! The morality that Tris was asking for was so two-faced, even Four called her on that. But Tris told him, “let’s choose the lesser evil.” And Four reluctantly agreed. WTF.Looking back, I realized that Four’s POV being present in Allegiant was a letdown. I did not see the Dauntless legend, the stern and disciplined Dauntless instructor who can whip his initiates into submission. Peter even manhandled him for a while in this finale! Four was insecure, unstable, and still reeling from hurt because he cannot have the love from either of his parents. *sigh* It was sad, really. But I love you, Four. Always have, always will.Tris is stronger, wiser, and better equipped to deal with issues than Four. Her character was still developing, progressing into this heroine worthy from a dystopian world. The stupid twist in her fate was incomprehensible, incorrigible, un-f******-believable in the truest sense of these words.The buildup of the story poorly supported the necessity of death of one of the characters. Not to mention that this character declared in this book, that s/he truly valued her life now, s/he very much wanted to live! So WTF is he/she doing sacrificing his/her life?!?!Where is the f****** sense in that, please tell me.One choice death to define you – puh-lease. Divergent is not as good as The Hunger Games. Allegiant failed where Mockingjay succeeded. Success in a series finale is not always linked to a death, to any death for that matter. So I wish the comparison between these two dystopian series will stop.Forget the Epilogue. Why write one when you already killed…?!!!!!

**If you have not read the first two books – Divergent and Insurgent – you will stumble upon spoilers in this review**Like the second book, Allegiant begins right where the last one left off. Edith Prior’s news of what is outside the city walls has the remaining factions and factionless unsure of what to do. With Tobias’s mother stepping up as leader, the city is doomed to face another tyrannical government. Luckily, the Allegiant is formed. Tris, Tobias, and other friends join and face the world outside the city they grew up in. They never knew how big the world was until they stepped outside. Being outside the city is not what they expect. Government manipulations, damaged genes, experiments, and lots more await these brave young adults.Narration: First person through Tris and TobiasCharacter Development: With Tobias narrating in first person, the reader can understand what is going on in his mind much better compared to the other books. Through this, we see that Tobias has more weaknesses and doubts than we previously thought. His thoughts reveal his reliance on Tris, his anxieties over his parents, and how he handles the consequences of his actions. He is still strong but now the reader can see the little niches that make him human.Throughout the book we see Tris grow as a person. She tackles with her brother’s betrayal, the fear of still holding a gun, learning who to trust, and how to make her relationship work with Tobias. Each character has to face their past and their fears. They are thrown into world outside their comfort zone – a world where there are no factions. A world where divergent is not some weird trait, and those that are considered divergent might not really be a true divergent.Plot Development/Flow: The story moved along well. I kind of wish it was given a year of some sorts in the mix of everything (just to gain a little baring while reading it.) The story is obviously set in the future, but it could really be close to the present.At first I would periodically confuse myself with who was narrating. The other two books where entirely done by Tris, so I would naturally keep reading in that mindset instead of Tobias’s. The more I read into the book, the easier it became. I can understand the purpose of the two views, especially near the end. It would have been impossible to include everything if it was just Tris’s view.Standalone or Part of a Series: Last book in the Divergent Series
