I originally reviewed as a 5 star, but this was largely based upon the other two books in the series, I changed to a 2 star for this book on its own, it was depressing.I believe Ms. Roth must learn some important lessons if she wants to continue to be successful in a long writing career.  First and foremost, she needs to understand that this is the entertainment industry. People want to be entertained, not depressed. It is all about being able to write exactly what you want to convey you message and then sell that product to prospective readers.  Second, she needs to develop a better grasp of her target market and write to that target's expectations, thus building a loyal following of readers.  I think this book has damaged the loyalty built in the first two books.  I've read several comments that at book signings she failed to listen to what her audience has been saying.  And these are people which specifically came to see her.  Lastly, IT IS her prerogative to tell the story the way she wants to.  Although this is true, I will caution that there are ramifications to exercising that freedom, and deviating from the expectations of the target market.  This is exactly the reason why the Dixie Chicks fell from the top of the country music charts.  Their music was top notch, but what they chose to say and do (their entitled rights) outside of their music directly alienated Nashville and most country music fans. Accordingly, as is the audience's prerogative, everyone turned them off.I believe she owes us an explanation (and maybe even a re-write). There is so much more she could have done. She at least had the opportunity to put Tobias and Christina together 2 years later, but chose not to do so.  That would have at least invoked a better appearance of healing.Added to the Review... It was not realistic to me that David had the actual abilities to actually kill Tris (as opposed to just sheer dumb luck).  First, David was a high level administrator, not a dauntless trained "killer"/soldier. He is used to subordinates executing his instructions. No where in the story leads us to believe that David had ever fired a weapon himself (at least not in the book's storyline).  He was wounded and had limited mobility in the wheelchair.  Plus he was fully aware that Tris was a recently and deadly trained soldier (creating an extremely tense situation).  There are countless articles available where trained police officers fire massive number of rounds in a stressful "firefight" conditions without hitting their targets, but we are expected to believe that David can fire and hit twice with deadly accuracy.  Second, if we are to believe Tris is as smart, resourceful and well trained, then her believable course of action once confronted would have been to evade, maneuver and disarm David, maybe getting wounded in the process, but not just making herself a silhouetted inviting target.
summary: There are some lessons to be learned.

reviewText: I am not a young adult--I am 63. My teenage grandson & I are avid readers and we both read this series. I appreciate the social implications of the "factions" & the faction-less. This 3rd book provides a history of how this faction-ed society came about and gives a resolution on how it ultimately is dealt with. The series is dark and rather shallow. It delivers a hopeless old message; knives and guns, weapons, bombs, bigger guns, and manipulation are the only means to reach the goal of securing power over everyone else, so you can then survive to fight more--and more--and more. I've notice quite a few books recently that are delivering the same message, that the only hope for the younger generation is to take up the tools of the older warring generations to deal with human conflict. The Hunger Games series (the books) has a message that challenges the idea that war, class divisions, revenge, or bigger weapons could ever be the answer to bringing about a just society or real peace. The Divergent series lacks that depth.

reviewText: I believe people have some very good reasons for not liking the series ending, but personally, this book was my favorite of all three.  However, I didn't read Allegiant until several months after it was released and, by that point, there had been a big enough media storm about the ending that I had some inkling it wouldn't be quite what I was expecting.  I think if you read this book as it is, and not what "it could have been" or "should have been," you'll find that it's really quite good.Main piece of advice:  LISTEN TO THE AUDIOBOOK-  From what I've seen in most other reviews, people have had trouble telling the difference between the narrations of Tobias and Tris.  I read the story via audiobook with different narrators for each part, so I wasn't even aware this was a problem until I read what other people have been saying.  While their narrations in the book may be similar, their actual personalities (i.e. their desires, their fears, their purpose) were very distinct to me through the audiobook.  I'd recommend giving audiobooks a try it if this is your first time reading the book :)From this point on, my review may contain spoilers (but I'll try to keep it as spoiler-free as possible).  Also, this review is STRICTLY my opinion.  I'm not saying other criticisms are invalid or that my opinion is better than others.  This review is only a reflection of my experience with Allegiant.Loved:- The natural, efficient flow of eventsPersonally, I felt like every event naturally led to the next event.  Everything seemed to contribute to the story and not a word was wasted.  More importantly, I admired how EFFICIENT the flow was.  For example, Roth opened many of her chapters with a conversation.  This method skips over any extra detail of "later that evening, they all met in the kitchen..."  It's a great 'cut-to-the-chase' technique.  While the story was a little slower outside the fence, I never felt bogged down in the details.  Roth moved from scene to scene smoothly, with just the right amount of detail to convey descriptions and emotions.- The writingIn my opinion, the writing was very well done.  Perhaps the audiobook narrators added to this effect or perhaps I've just read quite a few YA books that are not well-written, but I'm choosing to believe that Veronica Roth is a great writer.  I even think she's improved over the series, and I'm interested in seeing where her skills go from here.- The character developmentLike I mentioned earlier, Tris and Tobias felt very distinct to me.  From the beginning of this series, there has always been a struggle with identity for these two characters.  Allegiant was no different in exploring this struggle, particularly with Tobias.-  No "mushy" stuff (for lack of a better word)This isn't really a new thing, but I really appreciate how Roth keeps the romance honest and real.  I feel like Tobias and Tris's relationship go beyond passion and puppy eyes, and it's quite refreshing to me.My Criticisms:- Outside the fenceI loved the cliffhanger that Insurgent left us with, but I was worried how it was going to work out.  What kind of world was going to be outside the fence?  It almost seemed too drastic of a change to add right before the series finale.  In my opinion, the last book is NOT where you want to be throwing in a whole new world.  HOWEVER, I was pleased with what Roth did with the world outside the fence.  It wasn't as drastic as I feared.  Really, the main downside was that being outside the fence meant being outside the action of the rebellion going on within the city.- What about a different choice?Earlier I mentioned that I felt like the events flowed naturally, and, for all intents and purposes, they did.  Each choice had a fitting consequence.  However, that doesn't mean it was the best plan the characters could come up with.  There were some instances where I felt like the characters were overlooking some of their better options.  Even though there may have been some holes in the decision making (and therefore the plot), it doesn't mean that the story didn't wrap up nicely.  Personally, I still enjoyed how everything worked out.Anyways, I'd recommend reading this book, mostly if you want to see how the series end.  Although, definitely try buying it as an audiobook, because it seems like that might be the better choice of mediums.  Overall, I wouldn't judge the book by its ratings.  In my experience, if you keep an open mind, you probably won't be disappointed!
summary: Kept an open mind and wasn't disappointed!

reviewText: Possible spoilers:I was pre-spoiled for the ending by reading here.  I was very upset about the ending after reading the reviews.  The ending (after reading it) didn't bother me as much as I thought it would.  It was sad but beautifully so.  What does bother me is how much this ending ruined the series for me.  I can not enjoy this couple who were set up as soulmates thinking about how they were separated and what was lost.  I find it hard to accept that Tobias left her to deal with the situation that led to her death alone.  He had an obligation to Uriah's family, but honestly, any of his friends could have gone to fetch them, and he could have made his confession later.  I find it hard to believe that Tris' sacrifice was unforseeable from Tobias' perspective.  I have a problem with Tobias' lack of insight throughout this particular book (whether it comes to Tris' intuition being right, Tris being likely to take her brother' s place, his relationship with Evelyn [carried over from Insurgent] or being tricked by Nita).We saw this same ending in Insurgent but with a different outcome, and the sacrifice that Tris made in Insurgent made a lot more sense (preventing the loss of innocent life).  She had a symbolic death and resurrection.  There was a completeness about that "death" that made this sacrifice seem like an epilogue.  It paled in comparison to the one in Insurgent even though her motivation was more selfless vs. reckless this time.Tris and Tobias' morality is all over the place in Allegiant.  They break Caleb out of custody because he's Tris' brother, but Caleb was a co-conspirator in events that led to the deaths of hundreds of people and deserved to stay in custody.  Many reviews have criticized the morality of being ok with erasing memories of the government workers to prevent the erasing of the memories of the factioned/factionless/Allegiant society.Re: Romance.  It feels very unconsummated although their last scene together was somewhat ambiguous.  I thought for sure we would have a real emotional climax moment in this book if not a HEA.My biggest issue with the romance, however, is that the ending made Evelyn right when she said that Tris was only temporary and that she, Evelyn, was permanent.  This is just awful if you love this couple and have been a loyal fan of the series.Re: Genetically damaged (GD) vs. Genetically pure (GP): We spent two books with the factioned society, and it was pretty clear that these were folks segregated based on personality rather than genetics.  They didn't live up to their factions because they were made that way...They struggled to keep their anti-faction tendencies under control, either with sheer will or peace serum.I also felt the GD/GP conflict seemed contrived to keep Tobias in a state of unease and self doubt and reinforce the fact that Tris was unique and he was not.  You have to ignore many things that happened in the first two books to be able to accept this.My biggest issue with the POV shifting (other than having to page back about 8 times on Kindle) is the loss of Tris' narrative voice.  I felt doubly deprived by Tris' death because I lost the enjoyment of her voice for 1/2 of this novel.
summary: Didn't live up to the promise of Divergent and Insurgent

reviewText: A good beach read or summer thing but it just ENDS without resolving anything.  She should have written more rather than descending into the quick buck "stories" she has added.

Veronica Roth is a very young 25 year old author just starting out -- and it shows. The Divergent trilogy was a flawed but promising beginning.  If the critical reception of this third rather dull and sloppy book does not completely blow her confidence, I expect she will grow as a writer and will hopefully learn that structure, planning and careful editing can make all the difference. But getting older and more experienced helps as well!JK Rowling was 32 when she started the Harry Potter series and 42 when she finished Deathly Hallows; she had already married, divorced, was raising her child, and dealing with the death of her mother as she started her seven book saga. Tolkien was 33 when he wrote The Hobbit and started on the Lord of the Rings trilogy; married and well on in his academic career, he, too, had had an eventful life, surviving the trenches of World War 1 but losing all but one of his close friends to conflict.Truth be told very few authors produce much more than half-baked drivel in their 20's.  This series is a step or two above that level.  I certainly will give her next book a chance.I also have secret hopes that the movie will iron out some of the flaws in Divergent (not perfect, even though it was the best of the three).  And as for the dreadful ending to Allegiant, and the confusing, implausible plot...directors and screenwriters can and often do make major changes as they translate books to film. reviewText: I can easily say this is my least favorite in the trilogy. It started out awjward. Not because of the writing. I think Veronica Roth is a very talented writer. At first, I did not understand the sudden POV shift change from just Tris to Tris & Tobias and at first it was confusing. I was so used to it being only Tris that I would start reading a Tobias chapter thinking it was Tris and be like, O.o until I figured it out. I did get used to it though eventually, a few chapters down the road.The storyline was kind of a letdown. I wanted the Divergent to be something more than they were I guess. Not just normal people. But, I know this is dystopian and in these worlds things are more bad than good and that’s just the way it is otherwise it's utopian. Still. If this were a standalone book and not related to the Divergent series at all, I probably would have liked this storyline better if that makes sense.Let’s talk about the characters. I liked most of the new characters, save Nita. I thought she was an idiot and HATED that Four followed her stupid plan and the destruction it caused. I really liked Matthew. Great addition. Tobias/Four, I’m sorry, I fell in love with him in the first two books, but he was a little whiny in this one. There is a fine line between broody and whiny and he crossed it. His relationship with Tris did get a little tiring with all the back and forth fighting.Evelyn threw down arms a little too quickly for me there at the end. “Hey mom, could you go make peace?” “Anything for you son.” Bam! Done. Really? After years of planning a Factionless rebellion, and hate and vengeance growing deep inside her for her husband, she’s just going to roll over that quickly? No. Yes, it goes along with the plot, I understand, but, sigh, for me it didn’t seem very realistic (yes, I know it's fiction, but still it needs to seem authentic).Now let’s discuss the “shocker.” I get it. I do. Stuff happens. The world isn’t perfect. Selflessness. Courage. Sacrifice for those you love. The greater good. Yeah. It didn’t have to be Tris. That really could have been Caleb’s great moment of redemption. Or she could have done all that and survived it. She died of GUNSHOT WOUNDS for God’s sake. Not even from the death serum. Killing main characters is like sacrilege or something, well, unless that’s what your book is all about and your readers know. UGH! Veronica, I feel betrayed!!!Here’s what it comes down to for me: I loved books 1 & 2 in this series. Not a Hunger Games love, but a close second.Pluses:Veronica’s writing is beautiful and flowy (yes it is a word I just made it up) when she needs it to be. Clear and concise when she doesn’t.Her characters are well developed, interesting, and unique. It is easy for me to picture them in my head and I’m in love with Four. Well the Four from books 1 & 2, not so much this book.It is the 3rd book in a series in which the first 2 books won me over. Very good escapism.Minuses:As part of the series, I was disappointed in the plot. If this would have been a standalone and not related to the series, I think I would have enjoyed it much more.The shift of POV from the first 2 books was problematic for me at first, until I got used to it. It took me a bit though.The ending. ROAR! The peacemaking too easy. Tris’ death. No likey.I vacillated between a 3 & 4, but ultimately, I think I can only give this a 3.

I give the final installment of the Divergent series a 2/5 not because of the ending alone (don't worry, I won't ruin it) but because of all the writing leading up to it. In the previous two books, Roth has created an engaging and dynamic world which has recently been upended by a great revelation. Allegiant sadly does not do justice to what should have been a climactic finale. Here is what went wrong:The two viewpoints where essentially the same: We see the story from both Tris and Tobias'  point of view in this novel. The trouble is, Roth does nothing make the characters different; if it weren't for the chapter headings you would not know who was speaking. Their thoughts and manner of thinking are virtually identical, and their personalities get muffled by the writing which comes across as a tad immature. In other works, multiple viewpoints often enhance the story and allow you to see the situation from multiple perspectives and get inside different people's heads. Tris and Tobias may as well be one in the same.The writing was subpar: I feel like an entirely different Veronica Roth wrote this book. The writing became immature and the plot lost its intrigue quite quickly. I felt as though a teenage shadow-writer was behind this book, as it was the sort of writing one might find in a high school english class attempting to write a Twilight-style novel. While the novels have always been told through the eyes of teens, the writing has felt like that of an adult up until this point. I was left frustrated by the sudden deterioration of quality.The ending: No spoilers I promise. But I can think of a million better ways to end this series which would have achieved effectively the same outcome without the reader feeling disheartened and like they just wasted several hours of their life.Do yourself a favor. Stop reading the series after Insurgent and make your own ending. I promise you, you will be much happier if you do.
summary: Disheartening and Lacklustre Finish to What Should Have Been a Great Trilogy (no spoilers)

Well I hated this, the only parts I liked included...well nothing. First of all they wrote the book from Tris and Tobias' point of view which I hated.  This kept inconsistent with the last books and was hard to follow. They made all the masculinity and quirkiness of Tobias disappear and turned him into a girl.  All those funny lines from the last book where he jokes with Peter sarcastically about shooting the bullets out of his nostrils are gone. I couldn't distinguish between Tris and Tobias and had to keep flipping back to remind myself.  Tobias is supposed to be strong and all muscular but he sounded so weak, I got more angsty teenage girl from him.  Next problem was that the book was boring. For the first 300pages I had to force myself to get to the end, because no action was happening and I was bored and angry.  My last problem was all the death.  First there's Tori then all these other dudes then Uriah, then Tris!! WTH? Excuse my abbreviated language but why??? More than half of the people die and Peter goes all memoryless.  Tris survives all these gunshots and serums but then dies from gunshots?? That's not a heroic death at all! That's just being stupid, walking straight into your death. That was weak, not the death we were looking for, even though we didn't want one at all. What really broke my heart though, and made me cry was Tobias. He conquers his fear of heights to spread her ashes, 2 and a half years later for some reason.  Veronica could take a page out if mockingjay literally and give the characters a happy ending. People don't read books for realism they read them for happiness and this was not happiness.  You don't have to end it with perfectness but at least with the main characters surviving.  Obvious money grab for Veronica and I will never read her books again. The girl needs to go and learn how to satisfy an audience, because she obviously can't.  Her excuse for Tris's death was not a good one.  I always knew the Hunger Games was better.

The tragedy here is not just in the ending that the characters faced, but also in what the fans who have waited for this book for so long have had to endure. I loved Divergent - the story, the characters, the world - was captivating. Insurgent fulfilled the "middle book" role - it had its problems, but it was good enough to keep the story moving and keep me engaged anticipating the finale. But this book...this book shows the age of the author (and I'm not just talking about the ending - the book was an overall mess as many others here have noted) and that she truly doesn't understand the audience that she is writing for or that ultimately writing is a business. I can understand naively wanting to create your vision and be true to the story you want write, but at the same time you have to understand the long term impacts of those decisions - and this is one that I can't help but wonder if she will come to regret in the future. When you have the potential to profit off of three movies and a series of short stories in the future, you need to pay attention to your target audience a bit more as you are depending on their loyalty for the success of these ventures...and after this book, I personally won't be back. I cancelled my pre-orders of the short stories and no longer have any desire to see the movies, so while I may have lost the money I spent on buying this book (although I may yet try and return it), I at least won't waste any money on any of the short stories or movies!So sad as this series truly has so much potential.

I fell for the dystopian coming of age story in the first two books. the trilogy forces teens to take on adult responsibilities and decisions that shouldn't be thrust upon young people, but when you give teens the opportunity, they believe in the impossible, knowing they can change their world permanently, not apathetic or callousness like adults would be.the best part of this book was the twist that they were living in a world within a world - an experiment or a zoo and that outside there was another conspiracy worse than the one they had just solved. This book doesn't let you believe in the HEA that the MC had solved the problems and then escaped to build a new life. The ending forces the reader to remember that pain is part of life and that forgetting it all is a coward's way out.overall it was a brilliant wrap up that wasn't simple or easy, challenging the reader to keep growing up, no matter how old you already are.

This was painful and difficult to read. The narrative was confusing, the passion lost (almost mechanical), and the messaging I am still uncertain after having sit on it for a few days. The arc of this series is not something I seem to "get," because what I was "sold" on (the human spirit, courage, and passion) in the beginning, turns out was not the purpose of this series (or maybe I missed it). I realize that maybe it is my fault for not seeing the author's vision for this series, but I can see that I am not alone. I, like many, am sorry I ever read the final installment. Did I have certain expectations? Yes. But it was only to have a satisfying and "full circle" revelation/ending. To see it all come together, but the way it was delivered, I ended on the last page feeling hollow and hopeless. Maybe I am not Abnegation enough to see this is not about me, but about the author's vision. However, with every book I read I take away some lesson, and I have taken aways one from reading this series. It has to do with trust and risk. With every book you open, you take a risk that it may be what you need and you learn to trust that some authors are able to give that to you and others are not. I respect the author's vision, but I do not trust her to deliver what I need as a reader.

There is also a lot of science fiction in this one, more so than the first two books.  This can be tough to enjoy for a non-sci fi audience.  I would have liked to have seen a little more happiness, but I can still appreciate the realness of the book.

It's not like the rest of the book leads to some big moment where you just realize that it HAD to happen in order for the series to end as it should. The way this book is written I can only surmise that this thought is what the author wanted you to take away...because the storyline leads you no where else.Honest to the Heavens....I have NEVER been so excited about a book to then be this let down.  I would get my money back if I could.

Allegiant was more than just "okay" but I could easily put it down. The pace was better than in Insurgent & the characters redeemed themselves (I was getting annoyed with them in book 2). The characters have matured and you can feel the gradual transition towards adulthood. It was nice to have the dual point of view, alternating between Tris and Tobias. As with Insurgent, the first half was very good, the middle fizzled out and the end was powerful.The story telling is choppy. Too often, situations were left without conclusion or resolution before switching to another one. There are too many unfinished conversations. I would have liked more depth in Tris & Tobias' relationship. The romance is very cut and dry, except for the end, which is powerful. Regardless, I enjoyed the ride Veronica Roth took us on. It was entertaining. I won't re-read the books but I will see the movies, based on my appreciation of the story. As for then ending (no spoilers), I found it fitting. I liked the way the ending was written: story & style.This is book 3 in the Divergent trilogy (Divergent, Insurgent & Allegiant). Short novellas are also available as add-ons to the trilogy. The story is set in a futuristic dystopian Chicago. Written in the 1st person, alternating from Tris and Tobias' point of view. This series has been written for a teen audience but can be enjoyed by adult audiences alike. Parental guidance and warnings: Violence, death & weaponry. I read at an average speed and it took me 12 hours to read Allegiant. Tags/genres: Dystopian, teen, politics, revolution, war, romance.

I am all about twists and turns and people dying so I am ok with whatever ending Roth throws at me.What I am most disappointed in is the writing style.  This book reads as if someone totally different wrote it.  I am ok with the story point of view going from one character to the other.  BUT thereare a lot of:  "I say, _____" sentences instead of things like  "I blurted"  "I huffed"  "I said in anger"  "Sadly I said"  Reluctantly I said"  etc.  Where was the feeling?  A lot of short sentences.  I want to hear how Tris feels kissing Four.  Not:  "we kissed.  We pulled apart".  I want:  "I still had butterflies every time our lips meant...."  These emotions which made you fall in love with Tris and Four in the first two books make me fall in love with these characters.  I teared up reading their story in the other book, I wanted to fight for them.  Now I am just reading a blocky, black and white story.TO ROTH:  I am sorry and feel as if I'm betraying you and your works writing this review.  Keep your emotions and feeling in your writing.  This books feels as if someone totally different wrote it so if someone told you to do this, don't do it again!  Go with your gut.  Good luck with your next writing and I will read it and hope it's better than this book.

I found the last book (Allegiant) to be OK, although it suffers from the same flaws that keep the other books from being great.  I'll try to summarize them briefly:1. A general lack of characterization:  Almost all of the characters are interchangeable.  I kept having to remind myself who characters were as I was reading which kept me from getting emotionally connected to the story.  This was extremely problematic in Allegiant because this book is told from the perspective of both Tris and Tobias.  Honestly, I couldn't tell them apart except for the chapter headings.2. Plot is shallow:  These characters make all kinds of secret plans, then discuss them in very public areas and are never overheard.  Then they invite strangers into their conspiracy, and the strangers just go along with their plans rather than turning them in.  The plans themselves are juvenile at best.  I can suspend belief for the sake of  the story, but eventually I just can't get myself to feel the tension when the plot is hanging by a shoe string.I'm not sorry I read the book--I'm glad to know how the story ends, but I'm pretty sure that as soon as I click submit on this review, I'll forget about it.

Update 10/26 -- Well, after sleeping on this one for a day I think I'm going to drop my rating to three stars. I still feel the same way about the ending, although with time, instead of feeling more at peace with it I think that I am more disappointed in it. I really do think that Veronica Roth could have gone in a different direction that could have been just as gritty and harsh, but a direction that could have at least rewarded the readers for sticking with Tris and Tobias for three books. After all, we read to escape reality or to discover something deeper about who we are or about humanity in general. I'm not sure the ending to this series managed to accomplish that. Still, I do recognize the bravery of an author in deciding to go this way. But ... the reason that I need to drop this rating a star is because I spent some time really thinking about the themes and issues that were set up initially in the opening book of this series. These issues were never really addressed. They were dropped as new issues arose in book two. And then in book three we get a whole new set of issues. For continuity sake I feel as if the author dropped the ball in favor of a more soap opera dilemma-of-the-week approach that weakens the overall series. The characters are weaker as less time is spent on them and their individual struggles and more time is spent on the newest danger that Roth throws at them. So, anyway, I don't fall into the camp of die-hard haters out there that are spending their days trolling the amazon reviews and marking all the four and five star reviews as unhelpful while they publicly throw giant fits about the ending. But I also don't fall into the "this is the best book ever" camp either. It is not. I am somewhere in between. I see some value in the issues brought up in this final story, but I think that the execution of the entire series ultimately ended up falling flat after a solid beginning. Here's my initial review:Well, I'll say this ... Veronica Roth is one brave author. I can't really say why without majorly spoiling this book, but (man oh man!) that ending! There are going to be a lot of Divergent fans who are seriously angry about the way this trilogy ends. A lot. I can totally understand where those feelings would come from. I, however, can appreciate the choice that Roth makes in writing the events of this story. I don't necessarily like them, but I can appreciate them. And that is all that I can say without revealing too much. Just be prepared for a good dose of reality ... sometimes happy endings require sacrifice, and sometimes that sacrifice sucks ... big time!This conclusion to the Divergent trilogy is a good one. I did not re-read the first two books before I started this one, but I wish that I had. I think if the events of those books were clearer in my mind I could have appreciated a lot more of the nuanced dilemmas that crept up in this story. The alliances and motivations that guided so many people for the first two books had changed and become confusing in those stories, and so, because I did not have those stories fresh in my mind, I was having a bit of difficulty remembering who I was supposed to be trusting and who I was supposed to be angry with. I eventually remembered everything, but I do wish that I had taken the time to refresh my memory before reading. It would have made the first half of the book more enjoyable for me.Things I liked:The themes presented in this book. We finally get to figure out exactly who is pulling the strings in this new Chicago reality and what motivates the government. It is pretty creepy. In some ways I felt like it was a demented episode of The Truman Show. Creepy. There is the theme of the problem that comes about when those in authority take it upon themselves to manipulate others for "the common good." What is that exactly, and is it ever okay to take away someone's autonomy or freedom to protect it? There is a huge theme involving genetic research. Who are we when we discover that our genes are not "optimal?" Do our genes make us who we are or are we a product of our life experiences? So many fascinating things to thing about, and I love it when a book makes me think about my own world and my role in it.Tris. The tough, altruistic girl of the first book is back for this one. She has some seriously difficult choices to make. Seeing her make them in this book made me want to go back and re-read the first book, just so I could see her evolution from the very beginning. Love her!Tobias. Sigh. I don't know what to say. I adore this character and all of his layered personality. All I can give him is another sigh. I will always remember the way he ends this book in the epilogue. Perfect! Long live Four and all he stands for!Making the difficult choices. I began this review by stating that Veronica Roth is a brave author for the choices she made in writing this book. This doesn't just go for her. Her characters also have to make tough choices throughout this book. Tris. Caleb. Tobias. Peter. Matthew. Evelyn. Cara. Christina. All of them. Sometimes the choices end up well. Sometimes the choices make things even harder. But they make those choices, and I loved the bravery they showed by making them.So, this is a book that may end up thrown across a lot of bedroom walls when the ending arrives. Be prepared for that. But also be prepared for a beautiful story of a people overcoming great odds to find some degree of autonomy and happiness in an incredibly messed up world. I ended up truly enjoying it, and I know that this is a series that I will revisit in the future. Four stars!
summary: Prepare for a lot of books to be thrown out the window with this one

How to start a review about this book? Well let's just say it felt like an awful piece of fan fiction, and I'm a fan fiction junkie, but there's good ffic, and then theres the one that resembles this.First main problem, the book is written from Tris AND Tobias point of view. You don't switch your narrator on the THIRD book from a series, you just don't; it's like a cheap way to desperately please the fans. I don't know why Roth did it, maybe she liked Four so much she wanted to share him more, but this was not the way to do it. Besides, it presented him in such a different way, he was just a shadow of the man he was on the first book.I wanted so much to like this book, despite everything on the internet, I thought they were just haters ( like on The Hunger Games, the third book got a lot of hate, and yet I loved it) but oh my, weren't the haters right.So it turns out they were just an experiment, the real world was happening, and they were just living there like lab rats, I mean can you imagine finding out everything you knew was invented by some people running trials on you? This is why it felt like fan fiction. Most of us book lovers, fall in love with characters more often than not, and it's not so hard to try an imagine how our favorite characters would be like in our everyday lives, you know, our not epic routines, filled with Netflix binge watching and mundane jobs. There's a reason they live in their own world, they are just weird and out of place people if you take their fantasy land away, all of a sudden, Tris was not the special center of the universe anymore, she was literally just a girl who didn't know nothing and risked her life for a bunch of lies. It's a fun literary exercise to imagine your extraordinary character in your ordinary life, but after this, not sure it's good best-seller material.To make it all worse, Tris didn't just loose her world, she lost her "main character status", she was now sharing with her boyfriend, and ultimately she also (view spoiler)The character development I was expecting just didn't happen. Peter made a bunch of snide clever comments, and BIG decisions that were never explained. Caleb just sort of became good again (I now believe he's the one the book owes the most, he went from being perfect to awful to kind of hated to loved without any sort of sensible line or just plain sense)The book felt all over the place, it wanted to deal with genetics, propaganda, deceit, love and it just never came together. I found myself just skipping lines at the end.By the way, Tris was the one I was following, not Tobias. I felt cheated out of the mind of my trusted narrator just to hear from some guy that didn't resemble who I had come to known in two previous books.I give it two stars out of respect for my previously beloved characters; the rest of the book just left me disappointed.

This is a Spoiler free but Detailed Review of Allegiant.I never was a fan of this trilogy but I wanted to finish it to see how it will all end up and it was poorly wrapped up and a slap in the face to people who are fans.In all honesty this was not good at all. It was Boring. It took way too long to get to the point and to be honest except the very end, far too much was EASY for the characters. Up until the end of the book, there was really no challenge. Anything they did they more or less got away with.1. Plot & WritingThis book continues off of the events of Insurgent where Tris has revealed the recording of Edith Prior and the people are now being held against their will by Tobias' Four mother.You would have thought after the events of Book 2 that Book 3 would more or less be adrenaline rushed and non-stop.WRONG....For about the first 20 or so chapters of the book, the book is a bit slow. Yeah there are a few action scenes or intense scenes but for nearly 1/3 of the book it is mainly Tris & Four just sitting around talking.  Talking about their relationship, talking about the plans of what they are going to do, talking about this, talking about that.It was boring to be honest. This is mean to be the final book...you are supposed to go out with a bang and let it be non-stop where the book barely gives you a chance to breathe...Instead, I got bored quite a bit and did the skim reading thing.But then if the first 1/3- 1/2 of the book was slow, then last 1/2 was a bit too rushed. The ending of the book was sort of anti-climatic in a way and I can see why so many people are pissed with the ending. I would be pissed as well if I was a die hard fan. Too much time was spent focused on a less important plot that the biggest shocker of all sort of is just glazed over and I was like...Really? That's how you want to end it.I will say what i enjoyed about this Book compared to the other 3...We get POV from Both Four & Tris. Every other chapter switches between their pov and it really allows you to get into the head of Four(more on this later).2. CharactersThis book switches between Four & Tris and it does so very well but a lot of time it almost feels like they are the same person. Tris even admits her relationship with FOur is more serious as they don't really have a sense of humor.I've honestly never really cared for their relationship....Tris doesn't have much chemistry with Four and up until Book 3 Four has always seemed one-dimensional to me. I enjoyed getting to know about Four in this book but to be honest...his Parental issues were getting on my nerves. Had this been Book 1 or 2, I wouldn't have minded but this is Book 3 and Four spends most of this book just whining and whining and it's like dude...it's time to get over it.Four also does something completely stupid and ignorant that has horrible consequences and I thought Okay...FINALLY, Four/Tris will become interesting but that only lasts for a couple of chapters and then it is back to "Woe is Me" Four.Tris was equally boring. She spends the first half of the book sort of doing nothing really but investigating and reading but nothing memorable. The last half of the book, she starts to come alive but for her to be a protagonist and the lead character she was boring. Four, despite all his whining, was far more interesting because at least he had major development.One thing I hate about Tris is that I miss the Tris we sort of saw in Abnegation in Book 1. It's like as soon as she got to Dauntless she became this hard-ass and lost her Abnegation side most of the time. I didn't care about Tris at all in this book.Secondary characters....Eh, they were not that interesting.Peter is here in this book but what was the Point of Peter except a choice he makes at the end? If Peter is going to make a big decision like he did in the end, then give the boy more screentime. He'd be in a scene but he just wouldn't talk. He was literally just there for the book.Christina was likeable and did very well in her supporting role...especially at the end of the book. I enjoyed Christina and I wish she had a little more to do than her sarcasm and being the good friend role.]Caleb had some great development and I did enjoy Tris in her scenes with him. I actually like the character of Caleb because he shows the desperation and flaws of Human nature all in one character.I Also love cara and her quips and sarcasm. She certainly brought humor to the story in her scenes and I am so glad we got Cara in this book.There are a bunch of other secondary characters who are more or less one-dimensional and are merely there to further the plot along.3. OverallThis was not a satisfying end to the trilogy.  It was too slow in some parts and the ending not only felt rushed it feels like it sorts of cheats fans of the trilogy.I am no fan but if you are going to go for that ending, give it more of an UMPH and don't make it feel like it is tacked on.I also got a major Hunger games rip-off this book...Especially with Mockingjay. Like there is an event in the book that makes me think of mockingjay and i was like really, that's the best you can come up with?While we discovered the root of the factions, it just feels a bit meh. When the characters discover the truth about the factions and the outside world and what may be out there, i wanted more from them but instead we got more talking and more talking.The biggest thing that annoyed me was Tris/Four in this book. Their relationship troubles are always so petty. They fight over the dumbest of things only to make up a chapter or two later. But they have a legit reason to have an issue and Tris is one of those girls I hate. They credit the fact that they are a strong person to the fact that their man made them feel that way.Really? So had she never met four would Tris always be some shy and quiet abnegation girl? I mean she picked Dauntless before she had even met Four so i would think she'd still be strong and brave even without Four.Ugh.I am so glad this series is over....Definitely a 1.5 out of 5 Stars read.

reviewText: Sadly, the final installment of the Divergent series falls dramatically short. Most frustrating was the change to multiple 1st person perspectives; Tris continues to narrate, but Tobias alternates as well. While this may have been necessary for plot convenience, the  "divergence" was from the earlier volumes was awkward and required occasionally flipping back to each chapter start to be reminded of who was narrating. As irritating and inconvenience this back and forth was, the story itself is woefully inadequate.For readers of the first two volumes, it was rather obvious from the outset, that the factional society was artificially constructed and imposed on the inhabitants. For example, there didn't seem to be any logical explanation, nor was one offered as to how a population would ever arrive at the conclusion and voluntarily agree to hand over political power to the only group that claims not to want power at all. Beyond the city, where most of the action takes place, we learn of a vague history of what sounds like attempts at genetic engineering with disastrous results that led to a civil war that the country is still recovering from. Somehow, this city (and others) were created as experiments to reset humanity. The science fiction elements are exceptionally poorly rendered and are either vague, ludicrous or incomprehensible. It's unclear exactly what their goal is as Tris' divergent status appears desirable, but she is treated simply as an ongoing data point, rather than an expected result.With at least multiple generations beyond our current timeframe, the future is rather indistinguishable from today. People fly in airplanes, drive cars, shoot guns, and stare at computer screens.Medical science has only advanced in the development of various "serums" which ironically sounds more like a throwback to turn of the 20th century medicine. The death serum in particular sounds a lot like just a chemical weapon that doesn't need much sophisticated science to create. In essence, the global chemical weapons ban and the Helsinki Accord on human experimentation have been discarded. The whole notion of genetic damage completely misses or ignores basic facts about molecular biology and propels the ridiculous notion of trying to "fix" people which has little scientific justification.Unfortunately, the author attempted to get a bit too fancy and ended up with a science fiction farce along with a weak, disjointed plot and characters that could not grow into their intended roles.

I love this trilogy. I think it had a lot of very deep and important things to say about human nature, about the sociology of how people interact in groups, about courage and identity and different kinds of relationships, and all the vagarities of sin and forgiveness. As for criticisms, the writing was a bit plain for my taste, though I won’t mark it down too much for that, and a lot of the love scenes felt not quite as emotional as they could have- I didn’t feel like I was really INSIDE the character’s heads as much. Also, the POV’s of Tris and Four didn’t have super distinct voices to them, which was disappointing. But there was so much else that I loved about these books that I can definitely forgive the little things.I especially like how Roth portrayed love over the three books: how in the beginning Tris saw Four as this sort of mythical creature, perfectly strong and sexy. Over time, she began to see his weaknesses, the places where his personality steered him wrong. I loved the passage about how they choose each other over and over again, about how love wasn’t just something you fall into and it’s done for good. This is a very mature view of love and I was happy to see it in a YA. I also like the notion that they change together that they stay together because they make each other better and that respect is a huge part of that, in action not just in name only.I also liked the development of Tris’ notions about selflessness throughout the book: how at the beginning it was something that was forced upon her, and it wasn’t something she valued until she was able to choose it freely for herself and to reframe it as an act of courage. I love that her sacrifice at the end was a true sacrifice. By then, I really felt that she didn’t want to die and that it meant a hell of a lot to her that she survive, but she felt she had to do something.The worldbuilding was very ambitious in this book and I appreciate all the hard work that went into this. Personally, though, I could have used a few less “new plans” and changes in dimensional reality. It seemed like a lot of time was taken up in making new plans and plan preparation and it was time I would have rather spent sunken into the characters. I do appreciate how each plan was a new formulation of morality based on the available knowledge, and how difficult and terrible it is to make choices with huge consequences when you have both imperfect choices and imperfect information. Also, because this was all done quickly, I felt like the details of the plans were not as fully formed as they could have been, and quite a few things were glossed over. The characters’ continual free rein to move about the compound at the Bureau strained credulity a bit, as did the fact that there weren’t surveillance devices to catch them scheming, especially after one of their number was convicted (and conveniently released) for doing just that. In a world that thrived on surveillance devices, it was weird how many places there were in this last book that didn’t have them.And now, I have to comment on the ending. First, I think it was brilliant that in a trilogy about courage, she ended it with our two main characters showing 2 very different types of courage: the courage to give your life when you don’t want to, and the courage to go on living when you don’t want to.I don’t know that anyone who is not a writer could possibly understand what it is like to kill a character, especially one whose head you’ve lived in for three books, thousands and thousands of hours. It’s like killing your own child whose life and world you created. It’s like killing yourself. You don’t do it because you are cruel or because you think it’s “grabby.” You do it because it must be done. Because that is the truth of the story. Because in a story about war, not everyone wins.Roth’s writing is very deliberate. She uses symbolism fervently, frequently, so that every scene echoes with her message, and it’s an important one. All of her scenes are very purposeful, even the quiet ones, and I don’t know how anyone could write so brilliantly about war and not lived in the middle of one. Maybe she has, I don’t know. But her conclusions about human nature are morbidly hard to look away from, almost as hard as they are to live with. Because I suspect they are all true.We are the best and the worst there is. We draw lines between people and we fight and condemn and hate, but we always draw together at the same time. Neither impulse can be denied and neither impulse is completely healthy.I think it is a sign of how important this book is that all the top reviews for it on goodreads are these flashy, surface-level negative rants about the reader’s disagreement with the writer’s choices, because it was NOT a feel-good book. These reviews were crammed with capital letters and condemnations and moving pictures and they are just like what popular culture has been accused of being: a distraction from what’s truly important.Roth dared to write a vital, wise, deep book in a popular genre that can be pretty shallow in its readership and a lot of people are slamming her for it. It makes me sick to see her punished for being daring enough to say something true that we didn’t want to hear. So, Ms. Roth, if you ever read this little review, know that I applaud you. You wrung your soul and all your considerable technical skills out for this one and I applaud you for it.

First off, I just want to say that I absolutely loved Divergent and Insurgent. Even though I didn't like Divergent for the first few chapters, I started to like it more and more as I read on and ended up loving it. I've been waiting for the past few months for Allegiant to come out since I finished the first two in July and with the huge cliffhanger in Insurgent, I was hoping that Allegiant was going to be even bigger.I was a little wrong. I thought that it was very slow, kind of boring at times, which I wish I didn't have to admit to that. it was really hard to distinguish whose POV I was reading. I had to keep going back to the beginning of the chapter to see which one it was. As much as I love Tris and Tobias, their actions were somewhat the same at times. For some reason, Cara was always touching her hair. Most of the storyline just seemed unrealistic and hard to believe. It was much more convincing in Divergent and Insurgent, which is why I do feel like this book was kind of a let down.The ending. -----SPOILERS!!!-----I think most people, knowing how Tris truly is, probably expected her to sacrifice herself for her brother, Caleb. She may not have realized it until the very last minute since Caleb was supposed to be the one to go in the Weapons Lab, but she comes from Abnegation where you are to be selfless. She always thought that she was selfish, but as it turns out she never really was. Even Tobias saw it the minute she dropped to the net in Dauntless HQ.What gets me (and that someone else had mentioned in another review) is that Tris lived through the death serum, when no one can survive through it because it seeps into your skin and kills you, but Tris who is Divergent, lived through it, only to have David waiting for her. You'd think as obsessed as he was about GP's and GD's that he'd want to experiment on her to figure out how she survived the death serum, but then we know what he does next.I've read a lot of reviews about how everyone is pretty upset about the ending and I am in a way not too happy ether. - how Tris dies, how sad and depressed Tobias is and oh yes, it is truly depressing. I've cried and cried and can't seem to stop. The main character that we've grown to love has died, has left behind the one person who she loved and he claimed to be her new family in Insurgent after her parents sacrificed themselves for their only daughter, while Caleb betrayed all of them. I could not stop crying the last 30 pages of the book. It is truly heart wrenching. After waiting so long for this book you only want Tris and Tobias to finally have a nice happy ending to live their lives how they've always wanted to, which is very upsetting to find out that it doesn't end that way.I've read people complain that it leaves you with no hope, but I think in a way it does and I'll explain that in just a minute. I feel like I can somewhat relate to Tobias' grief in problems in my own life. After Tris dies, he wants so badly to just take the memory reset serum and to forget everything that has happened, which I and I'm sure other people would like to forget things in our past as well, but Christina convinces him not to because it would be just like Tris never happened. The good out weighs the bad even if the bad is so hard to get through day after day. We know that Tobias is brave, but as he says on page 509 - "There are so many ways to be brave in this world...." --  "Sometimes it is nothing more than gritting your teeth through pain, and the work of every day, the slow walk toward a better life. That is the sort of bravery I must have now."Two and a half years later shows the hope in Tobias. His life has continued even though he's without the one he loved the most. He's reconciled with his mother and hope it all goes well. He has a job and is gun-free to try to live a better and safe life. He faces his fears by going on the zip line (something that Tris loved to do but Tobias was afraid of heights) and does it all for Tris, the one he will always love and never forget, in memory of her by spreading her ashes. He has his friends and Tris' friends by his side and to always have the memories together. "Since I was young, I have always known this: Life damages us, every one. We can't escape that damage. But now, I am also learning this: We can be mended. We mend each other." This is the hope.Lastly, I just want to say that this has been one of the hardest reviews I've ever written on anything. I can't stop crying. I'm giving it a 4 star rating even though the story wasn't as good as the first two books and has a terrible tragic ending that will be very hard to forget anytime soon, I would recommend it, especially if you've read Divergent and Insurgent. I just want to warn you if you do decide to read it. - Be brave.

I devoured the first two novels in this series.  I liked Divergent, found it to be a quick, light read that also contained an interesting and creative premise, and so of course I purchased the second novel.  Insurgent wasn't as good, but I was willing to wait for the third installment to see how Ms. Roth wrapped things up.There were many things left unanswered in the first two books so when I picked up Allegiant I was expecting to have those answers I was hoping for.  They were given to me.  And I was not happy.It seemed as though the author wasn't quite sure of her own story with the first two books, and I had my suspicions that this was the case but I was willing to give her a chance because this story had SO much potential to make a statement in a creative and artistic manner.  I was greeted with pages of characters whining and repeating the same sentiments over and over, a lack of distinction between the voices of Tris and Tobias, unbelievable explanations for what is beyond the world of factions and Divergent individuals and much, much more.First of all, for there to be no real reason for Divergent people is ridiculous.  The first two books placed so much emphasis on these different individuals, building them up to be special just to blow that plot line off entirely was a complete letdown.  I think, had the author perhaps had more time she could have come up with a better reason for there being Divergent individuals in the first place, but she had no idea in mind in Book One, no idea in Book Two, and certainly no idea in Book Three.  It was frustrating.Also, there's the alternating perspectives.  Many have addressed this so I'm just going to say that the two characters were absolutely indistinguishable from one another.  One thing I CAN say is that while Tobias did spend a lot of time whining about being 'damaged', I thought his character development worked fairly well.  Tobias spent his whole life thinking that we was special, that he was a leader.  When he finds out that not only is he not special he is literally considered, by the government, to be 'damaged', I think his reactions though redundant, were accurate.  I wish he could have developed beyond that, maybe finding a middle ground between badass and wimp, but that didn't happen.The explanations given for all the things we were curious about were just lame.  The plot felt contrived and the story felt rushed.  I didn't read this one as quickly as I did the other two, and I didn't even feel like I was in the same series, to be honest.I read somewhere that the author stated that she had no idea when she started the series where she was going with it, and I think that this fact unfortunately caught up with her in 'Allegiant".The author is young and shows a lot of potential for development in her writing so I will be reading more from her in the future because I always give authors a second (or in this case, really, fourth) chance.The ending...I knew what would happen when I was introduced to the dual POV, so it didn't come as a surprise to me and I wasn't sad.  I was angry that the author didn't end the series in a more realistic way.  Tris, being truly selfless, would never have left Tobias to grieve her loss after all that he's been through.  Tris wouldn't have been so selfish as to essentially go on a suicide mission.  I think the Tris we've grown to know would have realized that death is the selfish option, not the least selfish.  She didn't have to die, and I am not saying that because I am upset about her death.  I saw it coming a mile away and while suffering through the narrative I wished for her to die many times.  No, I am saying this because she really did not have to die.  We, the readers, already knew that Tris was willing to be a martyr.  She tried to do so before and was unable to.  We were aware of her savior complex.  She could have shown her complete selflessness in a hundred other ways that I can think of rather than dying for her brother who, by the way, could have been given his redemption.  Ultimately I think the more selfless thing she could have done was to have allowed Caleb his redemption.As I've said I will read more from this author, but right now I think she's just too naive to pull something like this off properly.  I love the potential she shows and she's a wonderful story teller.  I think when she was self-published she did a much better job of telling a story.  I wish she would have just stuck with that, to be honest.  I think she's an intelligent young woman with a lot of talent and I do hope that we all get to explore her true potential someday.  Unfortunately, that is not going to be today.

reviewText: Do NOT discredit this book based on the bad reviews.  People are upset that it's slower paced and they didn't get the ending they wanted.  That does not mean this book deserves the reviews it is given and I am heartbroken at this fandom for bashing it as so.I absolutely 100% loved this book.Let me explain.Yes it's slower paced than the other two books, which I'm ok with.  We were taking time to explore and learn the world outside Chicago.  That was worth it to me alone cause I was fascinated by what was going outside the faction's world.Did I love how it ended?  No.  Would I have wanted a happy ending for our beloved couple?  Of course!  Am I ok with it?  Yes.  I think it's a nice change of pace from all the other dystopian teen novels out there.  It was a shock to see it happen, it was heartbreaking, but it was totally understandable and called for given the character of our hero.And my biggest thing, regardless if you loved or hates how the story ended, that doesn't chance the fact that the ride was so, so worth it.  It wasn't the closing I wanted for the series, but now that I've read it, I can't imagine it going any other way.  It's a very fitting end to an amazing ride.Also, the few love scenes we were given between Tris and Tobias were very worth it to me as well, and if I had one complaint to give, it'd be that we were given more of them.I cannot wait to see what this author writes after this and look forward to reading her next endeavors.

Placing a book on my all-time favorites list doesn’t happen every day, so telling you that the entire Divergent series has a spot on that list says a lot. It was a study in patience to wait for Allegiant to hit the bookstores. When the blurb revealed it was to be told from two points of view, I grew wary. That does not mean the book was a disappointment, but it wasn’t what I expected.I praise the portrayal of life as messy, confusing, ugly and beautiful. The love between Tobias and Tris goes through the normal ebbs and flows that make relationships worthwhile, worth fighting for. I commend Roth for not shying away from showing what can happen when government gains too much control.Veronica Roth does not disappoint. The world she created in the first book and began to dismantle in the second defies description. In Allegiant, she turns everything on its head and shakes the foundation she erected. All the elements that I loved in the first two books, the characters, the writing and the world building are still there, but...While I give Allegiant the highest marks, a part of me feels a bit cheated. From the beginning, it was Tris’s story to tell, but for some reason the final book is also told by Tobias. I can see the advantages of doing so, but it kind of feels like Roth took the easy way out.That being said, it’s an excellent finale to an incredible story and I highly recommend it.

reviewText: *Spoilers* First of all let me just say that I cheated. I read a bunch of reviews on Amazon a couple of days after the book came out and so I was emotionally prepared for the ending.Perhaps because of this mental and emotional preparation, I was okay with Tris’s death. While it might not have been what I wanted to happen, it made sense for her character and for the plot line. And having Tris prove immune to the death serum, but then die immediately after from bullet wounds was a great twist. I can be at peace with how things played out and how Tobias (Four) and Evelyn eventually reconcile. I love how many of the characters remain friends and start their lives over together after the experiment is disbanded. The only disappointment in terms of character development was Peter. The way that Roth had the inner conflict of Peter play out was interesting and unpredictable – it showed that even the most evil of people could perhaps find redemption. But I was not a fan of Peter once he took the memory serum – he was at first a dumb baby, and then sort of disappeared from the story with the shallow explanation that some of his harsher traits had resurfaced. I felt this was a poor wrap-up to an integral and interesting character.I gave the book three stars mainly because of the Tris and Tobias POV switching. Had this been done well, it would have made the book. But it was not done well. Not at all. In fact I kept finding myself in the middle of chapters and not being able to figure out if Tris or Tobias was narrating. The fact is, Roth could not seem to write from a male point of view. Tobias sounded like a girl. And he sounded just like Tris. It was beyond disappointing for such a strong character in the first two books.My final thought is that while I’m fine with Tris’s death, and her sacrifice to save Caleb’s life, I would have wished for Tris and Tobias to have a more united front in this last book. It would have been far more satisfying if they bickered less, lied less, and tried to spend as much time together as possible. Then we readers could feel like they’d had their time and Tris’s death was a tragic, but beautiful end.Instead Tris and Tobias seemed to disconnect from one another at every chance possible. They still couldn’t seem to trust each other. They spent little time actually in one another’s presence and when they did, they were either fighting or making out. This made her death feel more wasteful and much less tragic.Overall, while I did not love the end to this trilogy, I didn’t hate it either. I’m satisfied with how Roth has wrapped things up, even if the society she portrayed has been written before and written much better (“Pines” by Blake Crouch). “Divergent” alone is the reason to read this series – the chemistry between Tris and Tobias hooks you instantly and carries you through till the end of “Allegiant.”

If you weren't madly in love with Divergent or Insurgent, Allegiant probably isn't going to change your mind. If you loved the first two books, one of two things is likely to happen: you're going to feel like this is the perfect, inevitable ending to the trilogy, or you're going to hate it. I'll have a spoiler section in a bit to talk about the ending, but as for the major content of the book, this is what you'll get:1. More of an emphasis on ideas than action for the first 2/3. This doesn't mean nothing happens, but the tension comes from a different place than it does for most of first two books. This will bore some people quite a lot, but if you're like me, and you find questions about what motivates human behavior interesting, and you love to critically analyze where assumptions come from and how they become problematic, you might find this section fascinating, as I did. I love peeking over Roth's shoulder as she examines where humanity's aggression comes from and how we fool ourselves into thinking these answers are obvious.The fact that a YA book bothered to dig deeper into these complex situations without offering easy, parental answers is impressive--much of the recent YA I've come across struggles to deal with anything more than love triangles and supernatural powers. This careful consideration of what constitutes moral behavior digs deeper than the first two books. I liked the first two, but they were a little immature in the complexity of thought compared to this one. I see this as a pro, but as I said, if you don't enjoy this sort of reading, you might get bored.2. Struggles between Tris and Four. I love love love Tris and Four's relationship, and I have since the beginning. I loathe insta-love in books. It's stupid and immature and completely unrealistic, and I'm not a fan of love triangles either. Tris and Four have been better developed than that, and considering the state of things after Insurgent, it wouldn't be consistent or realistic if they didn't have some bumps here. I thought they were explored well for the most part, and Four's issues in this book were occasionally frustrating, but I always felt like his behavior was real and consistent with his character, despite the fact that he sometimes did things I didn't agree with.3. The resolution of the battle for the city and the exploration of the world beyond. This part is intriguing, although in a couple places it meanders a bit. New characters are introduced that, frankly, aren't nearly as interesting as the old ones, but they don't spend a lot of time in the forefront of the plot, so it isn't a big detraction. This part delves into the original development of the city and the factions and you'll learn about the vast conspiracy that set all of that up--and how it influences things for the better and worse now.Finally, the ending. SPOILERS follow, but mostly about theme and tone. I won't discuss specific plot points, but you'll probably be able to infer some content if you keep going.This series takes place in a dark world, and it's only getting darker. Characters are killed (think of how many died in Divergent alone), Tris and Four endure terrible grief and hardship, and the violence in these books is unflinching.That being said, I was kind of expecting this ending. It's true, the ending is not what I would call a happy one, but I do think it's the right one. Roth could have arranged things so that everything worked out perfectly and everyone lived happily ever after, but to be honest, that's the ending that would have made me angry. It doesn't fit the world or the characters, for one thing. There are so many dystopian YA books on the market that end just like that. They play it safe, and as a result, they're predictable and boring. I've read so many of them that they blend together at this point, and it takes a lot for a book, and a character, to have lasting resonance.Tragedy abounds in literature for a reason. Complicated endings keep a story in a reader's mind for a long time as we try to figure out why we had such a strong reaction to the events in the book. It forces us to be engaged, to respond, and to think. The ending to Allegiant is beautiful, meaningful, and perhaps most important, consistent with the themes, characters and world that this series is set in. It isn't an easy ending or a fun one, but it's real, and far more adult than most YA I've read. I won't be forgetting Tris or the journey I've been on or the way this has made me think anew about what it means to be strong. If the ending were different, some of that power would have been lost, and Tris and Four and this story deserve to be remembered.

The writing continues to slightly disappoint, the reliance on magic 'serums' to do anything that might be handy, and the total ease with which people can access world ending type weapons at any time they finish wrestling with their allegiances and come to a bloody decision kills all sense of suspense. Once the teens decide to save the world they will conveniently have access to the tools to do so.Adults continue to appear as flat, dimensionless characters though attempts are made to show that even adults struggle with what is moral. None the less adults remain dim enough to be outwitted again and again by a handful of teens and pretty much only exist to be overthrown. Honestly everyone in these books seems to be the age of our main characters (late teens) or some ubiquitous 'parent age' of around 40 or so, and the adults are all frighteningly innocent in the face of the all wise teens.After two books form one character's viewpoint I found the first person switching highly annoying as I wouldn't always remember which character I was reading (a telling fault by the way when the only way to distinguish between the first person voices is by context clues) and had no sense of the newly introduced first voice from the inside. By then the plot device is explained, but it still interrupted the expected flow and was frustrating, not least because it highlighted how little difference there was between the two voices, rendering the division a one trick pony.I finished the series, I was in the mood for light reading and these fit the bill, but I was always aware that this story never fully achieved what it could have.

I really loved Divergent and Insurgent kept the series going for me. This book started out okay but once they got on the outside it just lost the tone of the series for me. It seems like it focused too much on Tris and Tobias fighting and making up and then rushed through the action, the parts that actual added to the story. Aside from the annoying back and forth between Know-it-all Tris and Stubborn-little-boy Tobias, you had the conflict of the situation in Chicago and then the new GP vs GD conflict. Neither of which really had a satisfying resolution.  I mean Tris died to do the memory wipe but David as still in charge after that and what everyone was just magically living together in perfect GP/GD harmony? I was disappointed that Tris died but I was more disappointed that she didn't die for a good enough reason. If Amar could get Tobias and Christina could get into the city so easily and inoculate certain people against the memory serum why didn't they just do that. And it seems like Nita and Matthew could have figured out long ago to use the memory serum on everyone. Nita had planned to use the death serum, Matthew was against that why wouldn't he have suggested the memory serum as a compromise. And if David was so suspicious of Tris hanging out with GD people why would he make her part of his council? She came into the compound with her GD brother, best friend and boyfriend, she lived in the dorm with the same GD people the entire time and in the end her give away was she was spending too much time with GD people?  And then Tobias is able to end the entire conflict with the factionless by appealing to Evelyn's motherly side. A mother who abandoned him, used him, spent most of her life planning this rebellion and just went okay I will give up? And all the factionless who had been spit on their whole lives just went okay cool you have your son back let just forgive and forget. And the same thing with Marcus he starts to disagree with the compromise Evelyn sets up and the Joanna is just like no and he backs down. She threatens that she will expose him for refusing peaceful terms but why should that matter? I mean why didn't everyone reject him when they found out about his abuse and Tobias.  It doesn't even make sense that Joanna would have accepted him as a leader for the Allegiant in the first place. It felt like it was all forced for the end when Tobias has to "choose between his parents." And then Marcus just disappears. And I didn't really feel clear on the whole experiment. So when there was a large population of Divergent they were supposed to come out and do what exactly? If they are trying to keep them in a controlled area until future generations are genetically repaired why leave so many GD on the outside, just to discriminate against them. The GP supposedly hated them and punished them to harshly while the GP got away with stuff. But when Tobias tried to help the rebels get ahold of the death serum they didn't really do anything to him. I didn't care for both perspectives. After the first two books it really messed with the flow of the series. Now I see the whole point was so Tris could be killed but it didn't feel like a natural progression of the series and aside from mentioning each others names it was easy to forget which person you were reading. Tobias's perspective didn't add to the story it distracted from it.  It felt like you were getting half a story from him and half a story from her, but since they were both doing such different things all the time you were never getting the full story. This whole book felt incomplete and forced. The resolutions weren't satisfying nor did they make sense for the series as a whole. The book was called Allegiant and so was the group that wanted factions back but the book didn't really have anything to with that. I would have called it Tangent because she started out telling the Divergent story but then got caught up in this other thing with genetic testing, and it got convoluted like she lost a clear vision for the story.  The characters felt like pawns, like Roth had forgotten the passion with which she built these strong characters in the first two books. She was just having them do whatever she wanted whether it was fitting to their character or not. If you are going to kill such a strong character like Tris then the death should feel impactful and meaningful, hers did not. Peter could have died long ago, he didn't need to be in this book. Who cares if he gets to start over and try to be a good person? So if you want to know what happens to the Chi town gang check it out at your library or borrow it from someone but don't spend your money. It isn't worth it. I don't even feel like it was worth the time I spent reading it.
summary: If you want to see how the series ends check it out at the library. You might regret spending your money.
