I know everyone is harping on the ending, but that isn't even the problem in this novel.  I don't expect much YA novels to be Hemingway, or Rowling even, but reading Roth's monotonous and continuously stilted, short sentences for the duration of this story made me long for some artistic flare.  A bit of purple prose, even.My main problem is that Roth, for having decided to alternate POVs to both Tris and Tobias, has created no discernible tonal differences between the two.  Neither develop a distinct personality and that leads to a boring read.  If each chapter title did not state whether it was in Tris or Tobias' view, then I would not have been able to tell who was the narrator, aside from situationally figuring it out.  Both viewpoints really do read that similarly.Again, the very minimal diction (not to be confused with the bare style of The Road, an artistic masterpiece in simplicity) also leads to little passion.  For all the kissing that Tobias and Tris do (a lot), there's little romance and tension.  Unfortunately, this style also renders the rest of the novel, including all those action scenes, as repetitive and somewhat boring.Finally, about that ending.  I give a lot of leeway to authors.  They can do whatever they want, even if it devastates me, as long as it serves a purpose.  In this case, I don't see how the ending served the story for the better except for "shock-value," mainly because the end is filled with too many plot holes. Plus, by the time I even reached the end, I was already bored to apathy.And just to be clear, my low-ish rating of this novel was not affected by the ending.  I found the rest of the novel to be far more problematic.

****SPOILERS****I like many of you waited and longed for this book to come out to find out who Edith Prior was and what was the job of the Divergent. Roth did not disappoint me. I never could have predicted the direction she took this series but I feel it was a truthful representation of what happens in war. Am I sad at the end? Yes! Did I cry for Tobias and Tris? Absolutely! And still am! But I don't think this story warrants a bad review.Allegiant was an easy read. I read it in one sitting. And to Roth's credit, I felt I knew Tris's fate before it happened. Little hints were given so that when her moment came I was ready. Still dreaded reading it but I was prepared.I like that Roth continued Tobias's story and allowed us to see him moving in with his life and doing what Tris believed he was born for....to be a leader.Overall I gave it four stars because, come on......I wanted the happily ever after ending......but it was still excellent!
everything about it was poetic. the deeper meaning embedded into this story was amazing. the best stories are the ones that don't end the way you expect them to.

My sister-in-law had mentioned several times that I should read this series since she had and thought I'd really enjoy it.  I already had a huge reading list so I put it off for quite some time.  I finally read all 3 books recently and loved them.  I was completely hooked with Divergent and couldn't wait to read more.  Book 2 was okay but the series really came together with Allegiant.  While it may not have been the happy ending I was hoping for, it fit with the rest of the story.  I'm looking forward to the movies but am definitely glad I read the books first.

This wasn't my favorite series but it is a good one. Obviously the ending was the hardest part to read but I honestly felt it fit the story well. Like Tobias said "a flame that burns that bright can't last forever" It definitely changed my view on some things and I think that is what a great book does. The series overall was a good one. The first book I loved, the second I was fine with and the third was a really good strong ending. Everyone hates what Veronica Roth did but sometimes you have to let characters grow and sometimes the only way to do that is to let other characters GO. Albeit it usually isn't the MAIN character that is let go but i thought it was a smart move. This was the only way to help Tobias get over the demons of his past and give him the strength he was missing.

reviewText: I just finished the trilogy and of course I loved loved loved it!  It's action packed but has a love story! I absolutely rec ok moment this book for girls and boys! Anyone will love it!

I finished this book at 10:30 pm and was so distraught at the ending that I couldn't sleep.  I feel like the characters at the end of the book deserved hope that they could rebuild a new world after discovering all the deceit and lies that they were living in.  But nooooo, the author has to go off on a selfless tangent and kill off THE main character.I did read V Roth's explanation on her blog as to why Tris had to die, but I don't think this whole self sacrificing story line had to go that far. Tris proved herself in her ability to go above and beyond selflessness for the people she loved. So it doesn't make sense why VR couldn't save her. When her mom comes to her and Tris asks if she's done, her mom could have said, "No, there's so much more left to do" .. like .. rebuilding society, having a more normal life, and continuing her relationship with Tobias.Would it have been so difficult for VR to write that the death serum had an preserving affect on Tris because she was Divergent? Yeah, I know that being Divergent isn't some magical property, but if that wasn't the case, couldn't someone (anyone!) reach Tris and save her?I guess I became too emotionally invested in this story. I hope a book won't affect me like that again.
summary: Veronica Roth did a great disservice to her faithful followers of this trilogy.

CONTAINS SPOILERS!I liked the book a lot. It was well paced. Of course, there were redundancies, like who cared if Mathhew had a supervisor or not, and Reggie was an unnecessary character. There are some holes in the story -- who produces all that wonderful food, where? Who makes the weapons for example? and BTW, did they or did they not have sex? But none of this is crucial to the story. What Roth accomplished is she gave us a deeper understanding of all of the characters. Tris is not perfect, she is super smart and very courageous with an enormous level of compassion and ability for forgive, and that's why we love her and that;s why her loss is so terribly painful, but she is still struggling with her feelings toward Caleb and her relationship with Tobias while trying to figure herself out. Tobias was a very strong and very powerful young man in the first book, but i felt that he was becoming more and more flawed since Insurgent, and even more so in this book. But at the same time, all of that is understandable, based on his upbringing and his choices. As Amar said, Tris was making him a better man. Now, how will he cope? Will he be able to find happiness? This is where I cannot even write any more bec. I get so upset. Really, for a YA book, we could've gotten a somewhat happier ending.  But I think the point is that someone like Tris would have to do something huge and everlasting, but at a great expense to herself  -- as Tobias thought, "I suppose a fire that burns that bright is not meant to last." Which is true, unfortunately, and that is why the loss to everyone, the characters in the book and us as very invested readers, is so profound and so tragic and so perfect.
Liked the continued story from previous books. But didn't care for the ending would of liked it to end with hope of another book in future
I loved the first book, but I really didn't like where the author went with the story line. Hated the ending.

*deep breath*  Okay, so what to say.Did I like the book and was it worth reading it?  Yes. Because I believe this book makes you think and ask some pretty tough questions.What is bravery? What is sacrifice? What is a life worth living and what is worth fighting for? Love? Pureness? A better way of life? To uphold 'status quo'?And, the most, What is change worth? What are you willing to give - how brave are you? - to bring about that change?And with this story, the series ends. I think it ends well. On a high note, even if not the happiest note. We've been brought into the world with Divergent. We realized the world and the people were very broken in Insurgent. Allegiant finally fills in the gaps and will hopefully answer the question as to whether all the sacrifices in book 1, 2 and 3 were worth the change they inspired or created.Don't shy away because of other reviews. READ IT FOR YOURSELF and decide for yourself what you get out of the book. I'm glad I read it and found for myself the message it delivered. I didn't allow someone else to tell me what it was.

reviewText: I thought the Divergent Series was okay. The writing wasn't stellar, and the plot wasn't overly original, but it was a quick read if you're just looking for something to pass the time.

In anticipation for Allegiant appearing in my Kindle on Allegiant's release date, I read through Divergent and Insurgent a second time. The first annoyance with the book for me was the current trend of writing in two voices. If an author is going to do that, I shouldn't have to look backwards to remind myself whose voice is speaking. Tobias and Tris didn't have distinctive styles of communicating, so I found it annoying. While reading the book I also had other images of stories or films popping into my thoughts; The Truman movie was one.I also had some character problems. I didn't think the older characters were justly addressed and all the new ones didn't seem fully developed. The treatment by the community of the Divergent members was never clarified to my satisfaction, especially with the "big brother" eyes. I liked the genetic manipulation angle to the story, but I'm not sure how the targeted audience is going to receive it or even begin to understand it. ( I work as a substitute with middle school children daily, and  frequently read what's trending among them.) What crystalized my negative feelings about the book was its ending. It was not necessary, nor was is satisfactory to end it the way it does. (I was fine with the MockingJay ending.)Since reading the book, I have stopped suggesting Insurgent to the thousands of middle school kids I come into contact with. The book needed more time in the editing room.
summary: From Fan to Not a Fan

reviewText: Many spoilers here.  I am saddened and relieved the book is read.  There was some good and some really bad.  Many others have written about this far more eloquently.  But none-the-less here is my list.GOOD1. Tris stayed Tris.  Got to hand it to Roth, she didn't corrupt her character and turn her into a jerk like Thomas in Maze Runner Series.2. Tobias and Tris worked through their issues by accepting good and bad in each other.3. Evelyn said yes, she would give up her fight and choose her son and I cried.4. They win in the end.  For all the characters struggle they emerge better people and fight for a better world.5. Some good points of tension leading up to pivotal events.6. Tris forgives her brother, sacrifices herself for the right reason, survives death serum to be able to complete the mission.BAD1. Couldn't tell which chapter was Tris and which was Tobias.  Had to keep going back.2. Couldn't stand the lack of action or suspense.  Too much he said, she said, how I'm feeling now.3. Minimized the drama of Chicago so much they didn't even care what was happening, when before in Insurgent it was plot twists, action, betrayal.  Now the whole city is blah.4. Half way in I was debating being done with the book because it was so boring.5. Marcus just let it all slip away from him and he didn't get death in the end?  Really?6. Who were the soldiers that the fringe were afraid of would take them?PERHAPS THE WORST1. Factions are just away to get people to behave in a certain way.  And they can be done away with in the end.2. Divergent, the most powerful theme of the first two books, turns out to be just a genetic thing that really doesn't matter until procreation or simulation time.3. Tris dies and gives her life in the ultimate sacrifice.  Too easy?  Could have made her crippled or made life hard for her and Tobias.  But still given a happy ending.

The last book in the Divergent series wraps everything up. Love the characters and the similarities with life. The chemistry between Tris and Tobias is so true to life. They have problems but when you truly love someone you work thru them not give up.

***spoiler alert***I enjoyed this book and this series overall. I think this book rounded everything out nicely and pulled together all of the probable loose ends. Did I like the ending, no. I kept waiting for the story to say, 'just kidding, that didn't happen'. But, in the end, it did and I was sad for a few minutes after finishing the story. I almost cried a little.I thought of this book as a combination of The Hunger Games and the movie The Village. Actually, with that comparison, on some levels, I liked these books better than The Hunger Games because they're more believable and realistic to where we are in our world with genetics. When people talk about genetics they always seem to think of designer babies and parents choosing superfluous things like hair and eye color, but, as in this book, it could be more than that. They've chosen to 'breed out bad genes' to try to eliminate murder, selfishness, fear, and other things. Could we actually go that far, probably not. However, I believe I've heard of talk of a 'murder gene' or 'violence gene' or something like that. This book definitely got me thinking, which I think a good book will do.This book was written from two different perspectives, Tris and Tobias, and the perspective changed almost every chapter (it was weird and confusing that some chapters ended but then still had the same voice/perspective in the next chapter). I've read this style of writing before and enjoyed it. However, in this book, it didn't work out as well and I found myself flipping back to the beginning of the chapter from time to time to figure out who was speaking. This is disappointing since one is a male and one is female character and you would think they'd think/act differently. They didn't have drastically different perspectives, which is kind of the point of this writing style, and it seems it was only done due to the ending of the book. It seems as if the author could have kept with her same first person perspective of Tris throughout and simply deviated near the end when it became necessary.Divergent was by far the best book in this series, as trilogies generally go. However, Allegiant was the worst of them. Yes, it had its plot twists throughout, but so much of the story was explaining the Bureau, introducing new characters, and talking about 'the war' that never really happened. Yes, I think it wrapped up the end of the series as best as it could, but it didn't have that satisfying 'bang' at the end like a good series should. It just kind of ended, with the main character/voice being gone. Sad.

I really enjoyed Divergent and Insurgent, so I was very excited to continue the story with this 3rd book.  I was thrown off and disappointed right away when I noticed that every other chapter (give or take a few) alternated between Tris' point of view and Tobias point of view.  This wouldn't be a big deal, or even a problem except that the writing and voice was exactly the same for both characters.  I found this disappointing b/c I feel like if you're going to take that risk in the 3rd book of series, you better really be able to capture each of your character's unique voices, and in this book, Roth failed at that.  The only way I could tell the difference between who was talking was b/c at the beginning of each chapter, it actually tells you at the top (As an author, if you really think that needs to be done, that should give you a clue that the writing is not strong enough to continue in that way).  SPOILER ALERT-The reason she does this is b/c Tris dies, but not where the story should end, so Tobias has to take us through the rest of the story.  I understand the story reason for this and think it's a very bold move to kill your protagonist, but think the voice could've been stronger so I felt like I was really hearing Tobias, not just another teenager who sounds like Tris.As the story goes on, it lags a lot-there are about 50-60 pages in the middle that don't add anything to story or really need to be there and seem redundant and tedious.  Once the action really gets going, it is good and I like where the plot goes, but it just takes SO long to get there!!I really wanted to like this book, but the end just sorta drops off, like she didn't really know where to go with it.Overall, the first 2 books are FAR better than this one.  This does give you closure on the story, but only leaves you really wanting to turn the pages in a few places, unlike the previous books that I didn't want to put down.

reviewText: I'm not going to go into a long, drawn-out explanation of why I loathe this book; other reviewers have already done a wonderful job of it, and I couldn't have said it better myself. However, I do have a little to say.....***SPOILERS AHEAD***Basically, Roth betrayed us all by not writing in the same caliber she had for the first two books. She wrote both Tris' and Tobias' points of view in the same, nondescript voice, which was a voice that was quite different from both of their personalities we had come to know and love in Divergent & Insurgent. Throughout most of the book, I had to turn back several pages to figure out whose point of view I was muddling through at the time.In addition to this problem, Roth also rendered all of the progress our favorite characters had made thus far completely irrelevant. Oh, you think you're special? Nah, that's not true...you're either exactly the way we've programmed you to be, or you're defective.If that's not bad enough, Roth also kills off a main character without any purpose. Well, that's not strictly true...I suspect she killed Tris so that she (Roth) could be different. She wanted to be the author that "went there." Well, congratulations, Veronica, you did "go there." However, "there" is not a place you should be happy to have gone. If you were going to have Tris die, that's perfectly fine, but you need to give it the full attention and respect such a situation deserves. She should have died from the death serum, just after she released Abnegation's serum, or in some other heroic way that actually accomplished something. I just found it stupid that she made it through the death serum, accomplished her goal, and then got shot. Also, it was incredibly cruel how Tobias, thinking his love was alive and well when she was not, made a comment about moving on and starting his life with Tris. And everything after her death was even more pointless. Tobias stayed in touch with his idiotic mother, was unable to move past his fear of heights and even struggled to honor Tris' memory by doing the zipline, and still hadn't shown much progress in moving on after 2 years of her being gone.Well, I suppose I did get a little long-winded there, but trust me when I tell you that I had MUCH more to say that I chose to hold in. For such an epic fail of a book that completely betrays its readers, I think I kept it pretty conservative.

***Spoilers***Cried. Of course you cry with this book. How can you not?Veronica Roth is crazy with what she does with her characters, but I loved it. reviewText: The second installment of this series was so good that I couldn't wait for the 3rd. Now that I'm done with it, I'm not sure how I feel about it. The ending made sense. It was appropriate for the storyline, truer to what would likely happen outside of the world of make believe, and therefore not what you would normally get at the end of a book. Fortunately, she gave us time to grieve along with the characters so we didn't walk away feeling quite so let down. Still, though I don't know how I wanted everything tied up, I still feel a little unhappy about the direction she took, even if I think it was the brave and right choice for the story.All that said, I felt there was something lacking in the writing this time around. There would be moments that I would be really drawn in, but overall, it wasn't that difficult to put the book down. Somehow, I just didn't feel as connected this time. If I hadn't needed to know how it was all going to turn out, I might have moved on. To her credit though, the series was so good overall that there was no way I wasn't going to see it through.

reviewText: SOME HINTED SPOILERS AHEAD READ AT YOUR OWN RISKFirst and foremost, I want to address anyone mentioning how depressing the ending is. It's a book, Veronica choose this ending and I think symbolic to what she was aiming to do. I can't tell you how many times I've picked up a book, looked at careless individuals become a hero at the end and receive glory and no punishment for their mistakes. This book brought light to my life and a new perspective. The ending was fighting because the character was careless. What the individual had coming was due and please don't sob about no happy ending. It's fiction, it was a utopia. The point I'm trying to get across to anyone who has read the book or is planning to is that Utopia's fail, they don't work nor will they ever. Expect an ending fitting to such an ideology. Simple. Enjoy a wonderful read.

The series is wonderful, i was shocked at the ending and upset for a time but the ending has grown on me and I find that it is very bittersweet. The unique ending is what makes the book so great because that is what makes the series so different from all the other books, I mean most books don't have endings like that, at least the ones I have read.

One of the biggest things I liked about Allegiant was the character development, for Tris especially, I thought, was very well done. You can see how she has changed from Insurgent. The plot itself was clever and I liked the inclusion of 'real life' in it, and the way it served to the reader, as a reminder that the Divergent universe isn't real, it doesn't exist and we are all as small in the world as Tris was to the Bureau. On the other hand, I felt as if Roth tried too hard to make Allegiant 'bigger' than it needed to be; there was meaning already in the series and this direction felt to me too much like a contrived attempt at creating depth in an already deep storyline.The self sacrifice element annoyed me. That's happened, she did that in Insurgent. I would have liked for her to realise that sometimes you need to take a step back and that her life is important too. It was a disappointing plot inclusion.That's not to say that character death itself doesn't work, take the film Children of Men for example (there are lots more but I can't think of them right now).In Allegiant, I found it to be contrived, disappointing and unsatisfactory. When I read who died I hoped that despite this, the plot would come together and there would still be that feeling you get when you finish the last page of a series, like you've been holding your breath, but it didn't. I just felt sad for everyone in the book. This sort of decisions can work and obviously not everything has to have a happy ending but here it would have been appropriate. The idea was solid but the execution lacked the poise and cohesion that was Divergent.I think Veronica Roth tried to make Allegiant bigger than what it should have been. Divergent worked so well because it was contained, it was clean. But Allegiant delved too deeply into issues that would have been better left untouched. I think Roth took a risk, did what she thought was right but I don't think it paid off.

Overall, I wasn't impressed with this book. I had a hard time getting through it, it didn't grab my attention and force me to read as the other books in this series did. The science experiments seemed dull and stilted. The explanations around genetically damaged and genetically pure were utterly absurd. I think the author was trying to get at a chilling, Hitler esque idea around race and purity, but it was ineffective. I work in the field of science and was disappointed in how ridiculously science was portrayed in this novel. But worst of all, how boring it was.The shifting perspectives was a neat idea, but poorly executed. Tris and Four's voices were so similar as to be interchangeable. I like the idea of the author exploring how Four's abuse shaped him, but it ended up feeling very shallow, somehow lacking a believable voice, depth, or something.The main reason I am giving this three stars rather than two, is that I do appreciate that the author took a risk in the end and ended it in a way that she must have known would be unpopular. I've read many YA series, and this is the first one I can think of where the author dared to *SPOILER ALERT* kill off the main character. I like that. Many other YA books explore war and sacrifice and hardship, but it doesn't impact you in the same way when you KNOW the main character is safe.

The GP and GD thing was stupid so was this was some kind of sociological experiment thing. I really liked the first one it went downhill from there. I dont understand why Tris had to die. *There will be spoilers*This book completely ruined the entire series for me.  I enjoyed the first two books and was very excited to see how the author would tie up the series.  I think it has been quite awhile since I have been so completely disappointed by a book ending.  It wasn't even an issue of the fact that the main character dies.  I thought that was in interesting twist that I didn't see coming.  Other than George R. R. Martin, I can't think of too many authors who just kill off main characters like it's no problem, so I was surprised it happened in this story.  What was whole-heartedly disappointing was the attempt to make the plot of this trilogy make sense.  It felt forced to me, like the author realized she was on the last book and had no idea what her great plot twist was supposed to be and was bored of trying to figure out something that would have been worthwhile or interesting.  I found the whole book fairly pathetic.  Anyone reading the first two books would probably be better of just imagining an ending of their own because it would almost certainly be better than the drivel Roth wrote.

So, I put off reading this book for as long as I could. I, like the world and his wife had waited (very impatiently) for the final installment of Tris and Four's story. Then I read the reviews, i heard the shocking spoiler, I couldn't run, I couldn't hide. I couldn't make sense of why an author would callously kill off her own beloved protagonist.`Just like that' I heard. It couldn't be true!! Why, why, why why? So I thought if I didn't read it, it would never happen. Tris and Four would be happy farming their dystopian wasteland with at least 10 dysfunctioning babies.Then I finally put on my big girl panties and decided it was time, time to face my fears without the aid of any serum and just bloody read it. Then I could also go on a Veronica bashing spree and be done with it. I could move on and forget an author had butchered and killed my hopes and dreams.What I wasn't prepared for was what I actually read. Tris, Christina and Cara are spared death for revealing the Edith Prior footage. Tobias (Four) knows he cannot stay with his mother Everlyn, she has gone nuts. Power hungry and ruling worse than it ever was in the factions. Jeanine Matthews is dead.Caleb has been sentenced to death (and rightly so, is what I thought) One chance abduction and Tris is brought into the world of the Allegiant. Led by Tori and Johanna they plan to find a better way, one outside the city and one trying to overcome Everlyn's new regime.So the story is set. Trish will travel outside the city with Tobias, Christina, Cara, Uriah, Tori and Caleb the rest will stay and fight. What they find is more horrific than what is inside. They are plunged in a world of double-dealing, lies, back stabbing and more lies.The compound isn't all it seems and neither is the fringe. The enemy isn't who they believe it to be, and their allies aren't either. The story is slow to start with, building piece by piece but that is part of it brilliance. It is EXPLAINED, maybe a slow poke like me needs the slow blow-by-blow account of how the world got the way it was but I was fascinated by the perceptions of the GP's (Genetically Pure) to GD's (Genetically Damaged) to the people in the Fringe (I was expecting Mad Max to jump out on me)What I loved most was Veronica didn't spare us anything, it was an emotional roller coaster of a story, that while I knew (or I thought I did) what was coming, I knew it was the only story she could tell. Tris didn't die because the author got sick of her, or because she knew she was ending the series. This is bloody war people, good people get hurt. Good people die.If you want the happy ending pick up a Disney, better yet don't pick it up. This is a Dystopian world where it is dog eat dog. Tris died because it was the only thing that in the end would save them. I have to admit though, reading Tobias after her death had me running to the bathroom to sob my heart out. To read the 2 very short chapters of when he first noticed her ripped my soul to shreds.I'm still not over that, but it was beautifully done. In the end Tris saved him, and he began to live for her too. Beautiful, brave and haunting story. I won't forget it in a hurry!!Follow more of my Reviews at Never judge a Book by its Movie [...]

So I waited and as soon as Allegiant was released I started reading Divergent. I loved the first book Divergent, the second Insurgent was okay, but it still kept me interested. The 3rd "Allegiant" was HORRIBLE. So many of the things that happened make no sense and I feel like the author just rushed through without really thinking the book out before completing it.Let me start off by saying I understand that not all characters get their happy ending. I am a HUGE fan of "A Song of Fire and Ice series aka Game of Thrones" and as anyone who reads those/watches that series knows, never get too attached to anyone.  I know and I've come to love a good book where there are heartbreaks and where some of the main characters die. BUT they die for a reason, a reason that makes sense, a reason that has meaning and actually adds to the book. I did not feel this way about Allegiant.I think my major disappointment in the whole book was that none of the characters I came to like/love acted the same as they did in the previous books. Allegiant. Where to begin? It's been nearly six months since this book came out and it still makes me so mad to think about it. My friends now know not to mention Divergent, Allegiant or anything that may set off one of my now infamous rants. And this will be a rant more than a review. Also, spoilers. You've been warned.The story was shoddily put together and introduced a whole new set of ideas that Tris had to navigate. Once outside the fence, we learn that apparently Chicago, and other cities, are experiments to try to breed out "damaged genes" from some genetic war generations ago. So the government has set up camp in O'Hare Airport to monitor the Chicago experiment and they take in those that have left.Tobias learns that he is not, in fact, Divergent at all and it sends him into a downward spiral where he becomes a whiny, useless crybaby. He joins up with some genetically damaged rebellion and helps cause an explosion that ends up killing his friend Uriah. Of course, this makes Tobias feel worse, so every time I'm in  his head, I have to listen to him whine about how much of a screw up he is.Except half the time I don't know if I'm in Tobias's head or Tris's head. Their voices were identical. I would figure it out half way through the chapter when whomever's head I was in would think about the other and then I'm like... oh... yeah. That's right I'm in Tris's head not Tobias's.And all this sets up for the "bad guys" to want to "reset" the Chicago experiment. Chicago has devolved into class warfare, essentially, and to save the experiment, they are going to use a memory wiping serum. Tris can't abide this, because, you know, their friends and families are there! Even though none of those people wanted to leave the fence. And honestly, while I DO understand why Tris and company wouldn't want this to happen, I also can see the government's side. I mean, they are practically killing each other, on the brink of all out war. Why not wipe their memories?And so, we have this conundrum. If we don't want Chicago to be memory wiped, how do we stop it? By turning the serum on the baddies, of course! Because that's ALWAYS a good idea. See how YOU like it, bad guys! Except, they can't remember anything, so they sure learned their lesson!You mean to tell me they couldn't come up with ANY better way to stop them? Really?And then there's the ending. I'll admit, it made me mad, because in YA I expect a happy ending. And Tris's death meant NOTHING. NOTHING! Not a single thing changed that wouldn't have happened had she lived.So Ms. Roth stated in a blog entry later that Tris dying was part of the plan and she finally COULD die because she learned the true meaning of self sacrifice. Well, I'll tell you what. If I gave up MY life so that my kids could live, I would be mad as hell if a few months later, my idiot daughter went and got herself killed for a stupid cause. Being selfless does not necessarily mean giving up your life. Especially if it can be avoided.I rewatched the season finale of Burn Notice recently and Madeline Westen gives up her life to buy Michael time. So he could LIVE. And when Fi tells him his plan is suicide and asks about his "stupid death wish" he tells her that his mother bought him a second chance and he doesn't intend to waste it. That he wants to live, probably more than he's ever wanted to. THAT is what a selfless self-sacrifice inspires. It inspires the one that lives to LIVE and do good. It doesn't inspire them to live only until they can properly sacrifice themselves.Maybe I'm reading too much into this. Maybe comparing Burn Notice to the ending of Allegiant isn't the right comparison. But Maddy's sacrifice and Michael's reaction are what I felt should have happened in Divergent/Allegiant.Besides. Tris is 16. She's WAY too young die, and for such a stupid reason/cause.So there you have it. Allegiant's story was weak, Tris's sacrifice was artificial and Tobias was a whiny crybaby that I hoped would just disappear. You win some, you lose some. But I can tell you this: If I had known this would be the ending of the series, I never would have picked it up to begin with. You can make of that what you wish.

reviewText: 4.5/5 StarsWow!! I had to wait a day or so to write this review because my head was just spinning when I put the book down (not to mention the fact that I was sobbing and needed time to catch my breath!). I think it really helped that I read all three of these books in a row because I really got to see the full arc of the story and the characters that way (without having to try to remember what it was I loved about the first two books). Plus, this way the series had momentum for me that would have been lost otherwise.The negatives:Failure to communicate.Once again, there were periods in this book where Tris and Tobias had problems based mostly on their failure to communicate. Just when I thought that they were going to really work together and face the world as a team, they would disagree over something and then pretty much not talk to each other - it made me crazy! Tris' lack of compassion also got to me sometimes (for instance, she doesn't seem to understand why Tobias might have strong feelings about his father's sentencing and then, when she does realize it's bothering him, still doesn't bother to talk to him about it). Now, to give Roth some credit, there were parts of the story where Roth did have Tris and Tobias hash out their issues (and where they made good relationship choices) - I just wish I hadn't had to suffer through their lack of communication to get to it. (Although, honestly, the relationship might not have been all that unrealistic - lack of communication is a real issue in lots of relationships!)Some people will HATE the ending.I honestly feel sorry for any author who is ending a hugely popular series like this one because it seems that there is no way to truly satisfy everyone - all these people who are waiting for their story to come to an end and might not agree with how the author does it. This is one of those cases where I can tell you right now that many people are going to hate this ending. Roth doesn't let all of our beloved characters live happily ever after in a world where all their problems have been solved - nowhere even close to that. I list this as a negative because I know many people will see this as a big negative. Most people will either love it or hate it. But I'm actually kind of on Roth's side on this one - see my note below.What I LOVED:I didn't hate the ending.Okay, that's not exactly true. In some ways I hated what happened at the end of the book. But I also felt that it made sense based on who Roth made these characters to be and the type of world they lived in. Was it painful, horrifying and gut-wrenching when certain characters we've come to know and love didn't get their happy ending? Definitely. Was it still amazing? I certainly thought so! I will not be forgetting this book any time soon - I can't stop mulling it over in my mind, and that is a sign of a fantastic story in my opinion!So many questions answered.I LOVED that this book answered all of my questions and made sense of a lot of the holes in logic from the first two books. I mean, I really didn't get why the Divergent were supposed to go out into the outside world and how they were expected to save humanity. And why was it that people in the factions had such strong tendencies toward specific behaviors? (It was explained - there was an actual reason based on genetic experimentation that was done!!) I was honestly desperately worried that the answers I would be given in Allegiant would make no sense, so I sighed a huge sigh of relief when so many things were explained in ways that made sense to me! Yay!!Tobias' struggles.I loved that we got to see half (or so) of this book from Tobias' viewpoint!! I was thrilled to see the world through his eyes and to really be able to see and sympathize with his struggles. Whereas, in the first book (and somewhat in the second), we got to see Tris' vulnerabilities and her struggles with who she was - selfless or brave - in Allegiant we got to see that Tobias, with only four fears, could still be haunted by those fears. In this book, it is Tobias who doubts who he truly is - what makes him who he is. Is it his genes, his upbringing, his choices? He struggles to come to terms with all of that and there are no easy answers. I grew to love Tobias even more in his weaknesses and was that much more behind him when he overcame them!The action.The first half of this book didn't have nearly as much action as Divergent andInsurgent, but I found myself so intrigued by learning about Tris and Tobias' world, that I actually didn't mind much. The second half of the book picked up the action quite a bit and there were enough twists and turns to keep me constantly wondering what would happen next.Allegiant gave us an explosive ending to a thrilling series! While it had a few negatives, this is not a series that I will soon forget and I'm not disappointed. I only hope that the upcoming movie does it justice!(I debated back and forth between 4 and 4.5 stars for this book, but when I compare it to other books that I rated 4 stars, I came to the conclusion that, even with its flaws, I enjoyed this book more than most.) 4.5/5 stars.
summary: A fitting farewell to an amazing series!

I was extremely excited for this book to come out since I thoroughly enjoyed Divergent and Insurgent. I anticipated finding out exactly where the author was going with the story.  Wow.  Am I ever shocked, confused, and a little disappointed.First of all, this book is COMPLETELY different from the other 2.  Not only is this book told from different points of view (Tris AND Tobias), but there is a completely different feel to this book in general.  The flow and style are different from the first 2 and it almost feels like you're reading a totally different series.I DID, however, enjoy the character development for the most part.  We see several characters growing up and maturing, while others not so much.  I was a little disappointed with Tobias' character development in this book. It just didn't feel like him. Again, it almost felt as if I was reading a totally different series.Now on to the biggest issue with the book in my opinion:  the ending. reviewText: Young adult fiction or literature?  What's the difference?  Veronica Roth may be struggling with this question as she reads customers' reviews. Whether we are a product of material DNA or are something more and the role of self-sacrifice in an increasingly callous and self-centered society are important questions. NO SPOILERS!Basically, this will be a useless review. But I'll tell the basics:First of all, I adored this book! Oh. my. gosh. I cannot tell you how emotionally destroyed I am. I haven't felt this way before. I mean, I was gobsmacked and hungover by The Hunger Games trilogy, The Fault in Our Stars, Not a Drop to Drink, and This Song Will Save Your Life. They all have wildly different endings. But they all have one thing in common: SOUL DESTROYERS.I was freaking out that I would hate it. After the things I'd heard...(though, luckily, I didn't see any massive spoilers). How could I survive an end to the trilogy I'd loved so far? But I loved it. I so loved it. I had a hunch, and I was right. By 80% through, I knew what would happen. And I was right. Did that wreck the book for me? No. Ha. You're funny. I was too busy screaming.Characters? They were perfect. I mean, they were perfect in their imperfections. What I love most about this series is that the author, Veronica Roth, sets up characters who are strong: not strong as in "I-will-fight-everyone-with-my-teeth" (though they kind of do that as well). But they're strong in that they never act out of character. They are like REAL people. They're well written. Their thoughts make sense in their lines of thinking. Plus, I felt the characters continued to grow and mature and change. Awesome, right?Tris and Tobias? Ohhh, I love them. I loved their relationship (or lack thereof at sometimes). I love that there was no love-triangles. They knew they were for each other. Okay, yes they fought. Yes, they hated each other sometimes. But they knew they'd have to work for their relationship if they wanted to keep it. I love that there was no easy-love. Ah, just another thing to make them freakishly realistic.Plot? Like I said earlier, I did have a feeling about what would happen. I was right. It was the most epic twist in the world. I have no regrets for loving this book. But seriously? I was SO emotionally ruined. I cried. I read the book in one day. ONE DAY.The author is brave to do what she did in her book. But, you know what? The Divergent series belongs to Veronica Roth. She let us see them (thank you so much). I don't care if she had a drastic ending. I don't care if that's not what fans wanted. I care that this is HER series and she obviously did what she wanted. I loved her ending. If you asked me (um, when I was more emotionally stable then right now) how it should end, I think, in all Candor honesty, I would have done what she did. It was right.The ending was right.Now leave me alone to die.

The city formerly known as Chicago has been divided into factions for generations, but it was never more divided than when a group of factionless, led by a tyrant of a woman, forced the factions to disband. In the conclusion to the Divergent series, Allegiant is Veronica Roth's chance to wrap up the stories of Tris and Tobias.With the factions disbanded, the people of the city are struggling to find their rightful place. When Evelyn locks the city down, Tris, Tobias, and a number of others designated the "Allegiant" or rebels against the factionless, decide to escape the city in the hopes of some help from the Vast outside. What they find outside the city, however, is something none of them could have expected. They have known all along the Divergent were special, unique. They also knew the Divergent were being hunted, but they assumed those people were lost forever. When Tobias runs into the Divergent who helped him when he joined Dauntless, he can't believe he is alive. But outside the fence, there are even more secrets to be uncovered.Very quickly they learn Chicago is only one city of many experiments. All were treated differently, and not all had factions, but the most terrifying thing is the organization outside the fence is just as devious and cold as those factions inside the fence. When a war is on the brink of eruption in Chicago, they have plans to "reset" the experiment. Tris, Tobias and the others are stuck on the outside watching their friends and family inside being treated like mice in a maze. But if you know anything about these brave kids, you know they don't just sit idly by and watch tyrants mess with their lives. They are going to do something about it. Even if it means risking their lives.I have a truly strange relationship with this series. I loved, I mean adored the first book. The second book was good, but it just didn't have that magic for me. And again, I liked this book, but it just didn't have that spark of the first book. I will, however, say that for all of you out there who hate the romance or the relationship angles of these dystopian books (can't harm the sacred 10 people who we love so much!), you will be happy to know Roth ended this story in a way that leaves no question where her loyalties lay. She is dedicated to her story, not her characters. She is dedicated to the world, not the relationships in it. While I struggled to truly LOVE this book like I had the first, I totally respected her dedication to the world she built. I am sure it wasn't easy for her to do and she will get a lot of flak for it (much like Robert Kirkman gets for his ruthless treatment of his characters in The Walking Dead).I think the struggle with this story lies in the huge amount of conflicts all intertwined but still independent of one another that are going on. Sometimes they contradicted one another, which made the whole situation a little more confusing. For instance, there was more than one rebel movement in the fence, more than one outside the fence, people pretending to be on one side but really on a different side but actually secretly working for a third side?! Sadly, in an effort to make the story intricate and complex, it got lost in a convoluted mess. That being said, however, it wasn't a bad story. I actually enjoyed it and was content with the ending (although I predict many readers will hate it). I just don't think the rest of this series lived up to the amazing first book, sadly.

reviewText: I just finished "Allegiant".  I have enjoyed the series but I wouldn't say I was a die hard fan or a part of its fandom.  That said, I found this spoiler online by complete accident.  At first, like many readers, I was shocked and a bit horrified.  Then I thought about how Ms. Roth took risks herself to write this ending.  She had to know that she was going to get backlash for this decision.  But it was what she first envisioned when she began writing the trilogy (never guessing how popular it would be) and she stayed true to that vision and I think that is classy.As far as the actual book, I found the storyline to be much more interesting than the second installment but not as good as "Divergent".  As all of the truths and lies were unraveling I got confused a few times and had to go back a few pages and reread to make sure that I understood things.  I was steeled for the ending but it still knocked the breath from me, but if it had to be written it was done masterfully. Also the rest of the book from that point on was done realistically. In every war there are going to be casualties.  There is a very famous adult author who has a series up to 14+ novels and you never have to worry about her characters being in peril because she refuses to kill them.  Its unrealistic that they could survive that much danger that many times.All that said, I agree that this will certainly cause a mess for the movies unless they change the ending drastically.  I am not sure how such an event would play out across movie audiences.

reviewText: For many readers and reviewers thus far, it seems one of Allegiant's mistakes lies in its realism. I'm not bothered by the absolutely brutal realism that Roth gives us in the ending of this book, but I am bothered by the context it's been thrown into... and the places where that realism is abandoned, where the plot loses its sense in an effort to resolve what the author has deemed not worthy of properly solving. With the dual perspectives, we are given dual endings. One half serves as shock value, and what many are referring to as "preachy" as Roth hammers in the themes she has stretched over the trilogy. The other half serves as an oversimplified (to the point of being illogical) solution to one of the problems brought up in the series. It almost felt like the one half was intended to be so shocking that Roth expected readers to not realize that the other bit of what was going on really made no sense at all.In Divergent, readers were given action and character development throughout the book. With Allegiant, things felt slow (though rushed towards the end) and disconnected. Readers are taken out of their comfort zone and into much more boring territory, where what lies outside the fence is revealed to be completely uninteresting. Complications in the plot, which eventually led to the entirety of the book not making much sense, were often petty problems that took up time that could have been better spent. Ultimately this book was a disappointment, and it was not that Roth did not give us our perfect ending - it's that this book did not have the magic of Divergent.

reviewText: I enjoyed the first two books and rate them four stars. There was a lot of action and character building in Tris. I had high expectations for Allegiant. I was very disappointed. First, the switch back and forth from Tris's pov to Tobias. If it had been consistent from the first book to the third it might have been okay. But, I had already decided the kind of person Tobias was based on Tris's perspective and I liked him. He was mysterious and strong, kind, yet no nonsense. The Tobias in Allegiant was nothing like the one I'd created. He was sort of a wimp. There were many times when I had to go back to the beginning of the chapter to remember whose pov I was reading-there just wasn't enough personality in Tobias for me to recognize who was speaking. I understand the author must have felt the need to have the shift because of the events she chose to focus on, but I just don't think it was done well.I also feel that the author must not have much love for her characters as she kills them off so easily. By the time the book ends there's very, very, few of the beginning characters left alive. Yes, I agree war is like that, but this is also fiction, and I guess I'm the type of person who likes the heroes and heroines to survive and see the fruits of there labors(hope that's not a spoiler), especially after I've spent so long worrying there fate.I wanted to give this book only one star. I was so disappointed with the ending. I gave it two, only because there are a few points in the book that she expresses thoughts eloquently, something I really enjoyed about the first two, and I highlighted them. But, other than that, I found this book to be a huge let down after the first two. If you like fair yet happyish, not poignant bordering on downright depressing endings, you probably shouldn't read it. If you don't mind slow beginnings, questionable middles that don't really explain much and feel like a repeat of the second book, and dragging sad endings, or if you just want to know what happens, you might enjoy it more than I did.

Despite the gut wrenching ending, I respect Veronica Roth's choice to end it the way she did. The underlying tone throughout the series pertaining to self sacrifice is unfortunately a fitting end to the series. I may not like what happened, but I get it.

I read several reviews before reading the last book. They were very negative and I almost didn't read it. I am so glad I changed my mind. While the loss of beloved characters was painful, they were truthful and purposeful. Rarely am I satisfied by the ending of a series, but this one was fulfilling.

reviewText: I didn't like this book as much as the first two.  The ending of this one was off for me.

*MY THOUGHTS*Divergent gave me all the feels. I cried, laughed, and got so angry at some parts I was yelling at the book. Insurgent had me on edge and I knew that their city was on the brink of war and I was strangelt so excited for it. So, naturally, I expected Allegiant to be all about the war and how it would change Tris and Four's life.... Did I get what I expected? Well..... No."Who are you? I demand. 'We are the Allegiant,' the voice replies. 'And we are many, and none."11% (Nook Book)I say "no" because there were so many things I had problems with. For instance, the characters. I'll start with Four.... When I met him in Divergent, he was a knife throwing, gun wielding, bad ass. He didn't take any shit because he had taken it most of his life already. But in Allegiant, he definitely hanged my entire attitude about him. He had none of his original qualities and I felt like he was a completely different person. I've seen a lot of bloggers say that Tobias and Tris both sound the same and that's the perfect way to put it. I felt like he was acting more like a female than the sexy bad ass I knew him to be."Death is so quick, so certain. Where we're going now, nothing is certain.."17% (Nook Book)Which brings me to their romance. This was really the only thing tying me to this. I was in love with them when they were together. It was the only time that I felt like Four was back to being strong and Tris was showing her growth. And then at the end, I can't lie, my heart broke for Tobias. I wanted to jump through the book and console him. I felt EVERYTHING that he felt."If they told us what to believe, and we didn't come to it on our own, is it still true?"24% (Nook Book)As for the plot, I was a little let down. In Divergent, it seemed like every chapter had a cliff hanger. And in Insurgent every PAGE had a cliff hanger. In this one, I just didn't feel like anything was hardly happening. In the beginning I was digging it, because put yourself in that situation. If you found out that your life was an experiment and your friends were dying because of other people, how would you handle that news? But then right afterwards it went to nothing. I had become so accustomed to Roth's gritty, in your face, eff your feelings attitude, that I wasn't a huge fan of the fact throwing in my face. Because that's pretty much all that Allegiant did. Which, I don't feel was 100% explained. That was a lot of information to process, and it was info dumped in my lap. I'm sure I would have had more fun with the action on the last few pages spread throughout the entire book than that madness that was the end."Everyone has to blame something for the way the world is."41% (Nook Book)And speaking of the end, I will now attempt to put my thoughts of it into words..... I understand why it happened, but the WAY it happened, I just couldn't deal. *SPOILER* Tris is bad ass and she had just survived the death serum.... And then she dies from gunshots.... -___- *END SPOILER* I felt like it should have been in a blaze of glory. With more then one person shooting or something else to acknowledge the bad ass that she was. Honestly, I'm ok with what happened in the ending, but not the HOW. I was one of the few that was spared from the humongous spoiler, but I kind of wish I was. I would've read it and been spared the heart ache I got from reading it all the way through."It's strange how a word, a phrase, a sentence, can feel like a blow to the head."55% (Nook Book)In short, I didn't hate it, but the only reason I stayed intrigued was my curiosity of what the major event that everyone was talking about was. And unfortunately, when I got to it, I wasn't impressed. I honestly could've done without.

There were so many awesome things about Allegiant and the Divergent Series in general. The plot was excellent, the story was incredible, and the character development was good. Every book within this series, Allegiant included, was a page turner.My reason for giving it 3 stars instead of 4 is that though Allegiant had lots of good elements, there was just SO MUCH. Here's what I mean- at points the inner monologues became incredibly verbose. Thoughts that could have easily been stated in two or three sentences were several paragraphs long. The same thing happened during conversations between characters. So, it was a little wordy at points. And secondly, I felt like I was supposed to like Tris, but I just couldn't. At the end of the book, I admired what she did, but throughout the story her character really annoyed me and because of this I had difficulty sympathizing with her. I'm not sure why she annoyed me so much...maybe it's becauseshe came across as too perfect, all of her decisions and perceptions accurate while everyone else around her fumbled in an effort to keep up with her.In the end, I kept reading because of the plot and story, not because of the characters. And it's not a good plot that makes me in fall in love with a book, it's the characters. That's what was missing (for me) in the Divergent Series- characters who I felt attached to.In any case, Veronica Roth is a good writer and this is a solid story so hats off to her!

reviewText: One of the things I am always wary of is finishing a series as I wonder do I really want to finish it as will I be disappointed with the results or will I be happy with the way it concludes ? What amazes me though with the power of the internet is how people can go about their daily lives and bash authors in the process about their books because something didn't set right with them. Allegiant was one of those books that was bashed , so I made a point of not reading any reviews about it and from the first page, I was hooked and could not put it down. I did find about halfway through the novel - it got a tad slow for my liking but of course I persevered and OMG the last few chapters came and I had tears in my eyes and was like NOOOOOOOOOO - how could Veronica do that to us poor readers :) This was a tissue moment. As a reader, something I am not too keen on is the alternate POVs in chapters - one off/ one on. In Allegiant , Veronica Roth has taken a leaf out of Marie Lu's and Rachel Caine's books and written Allegiant in both Tobias aka Four and Beatrice aka Tris's POVs. In this instance though, I congratulate the author as she has done it perfectly and the story flowed beautifully. You will note thy readers, that in this review I am trying to skate past what the book was about as I do not want to spoil it for you, so I shall leave it with these parting words - if you wish to see how the series concludes, then what are you waiting for - get off your seats and grab a copy of Allegiant as readers it will be worth it as you turn that final page#This was an ARC from Harper Collins.
summary: Bring Tissues with you to conclude Divergent

reviewText: Having thoroughly enjoyed Divergent and Insurgent, I was so looking forward to Allegiant. However, I did not find the novel an enjoyable read. I did not like the chapters alternating between Tobias and Tris, though I guess it was understandable considering the ending. One reason was that I could barely tell the difference in the tone between the two, and I also felt that the first two novel's flowed better because it was Tris alone narrating.  I felt that 'Under the Never Sky' did the perspective shift chapters much more successfully.And compared to the first two novels, I found Allegiant to be anti-climatic and almost completely lacking in suspense. For example, the Death Serum scene was about a single page. The scenes with serums in the first two novels were long and suspenseful. And the scene which so many readers hate so much, regarding the demise of a central character, was rushed and vague. I also felt that too much information was dumped through conversations held in the first half of the book that seemed to have little other purpose.I understand that the first novel is being turned into a movie, for which it is well suited. I cannot see how Allegiant could be turned into a movie unless it was changed significantly, for there is no substance to it. Repetitive talks about being 'genetically damaged,' spending most of the book milling about in the Bureau without achieving anything, and nothing being done with the divergents who emerged.One of the most frustrating aspects of the novel was that the previous book made it look like the divergents would save the world from endless strife, perhaps emerging as leaders of a post apocalyptic, fallen world. Yet when they did come out, nothing special was done with them at all. Not even with Tris who could resist all simulations. It cheapened the first two novels, making me wonder, what was the point of it all?One good point about the novel was stressing that 'genetically damaged' people are still just as whole as 'genetically pure,' and that we cannot justify people's bad behaviour by saying that being 'genetically damaged' was the reason.A good theme running through the book was that although people damage each other, this is not a reason to despair, for people can help to heal each other of those damages as well.The reason for the reconciliation between Caleb and Tris was one of the highlights of the novel, I felt.

reviewText: I will preface this with the thought that the first tow books in Ms. Roth's Divergent series were wonderful. In addition, I know how it feels for something you create to be criticized after you work so hard at it. However, Allegiant didn't impress me in the least right up until the very end.First, I was disappointed by what was "outside the fence." There was plenty of room for creativity, there were so many options for the author to explore, yet what happened was, to say the least, a let down.The lack of interesting solution to this question wasn't the only problem I had with the answer. I feel it skewed the message I took away from Divergent and Insurgent, that "Taking a virtue, intelligence, bravery, selflessness, peacefulness, and honesty in this case, too far could cause problems. A person must keep all qualities in mind while living their life." Allegiant, through what was really beyond Chicago turning out to be what it was, more or less told us that those people weren't taking good things to an unhealthy extreme, they were simply genetically altered. I understand the thought process behind the whole "revolution" was to teach people that they weren't "damaged," but that doesn't mean they weren't genetically altered, it means that they remain a person, regardless of their genes.I feel the new message, though, was a good illustration of how prejudice affects our society and why it should have no place, ever, no matter what it is about. This is one of the reasons the rating is two stars instead of one.The disappointment of the secret was only the beginning. The plot, for lack of a better word, dragged. While the first two books made me want to read them at every available moment, I forced myself to finish this book. At first with the hope that it got better, then with the thought that it would be a waste to have read over half and not finish it. I dislike not finishing books very much. The plot really picked up only at the last 100 or so pages, and there were over 500 pages in the book total. The fact the Bureau was corrupt after all of the other things going on made want to roll my eyes. The idea of "the government controls the information so the government controls the truth" works well in some books, but in my opinion was too much and a tad cliché in Allegiant.Switching gears, I would like to talk a bit about the point of view switching between Tobias and Tris. I understand that is is hard enough to keep one narrator's voice consistent, let alone two, but I found it very difficult to keep track of who was talking. I felt I was working too hard to figure out which person was narrating at the time by looking at the context, and I needed to keep that thought in the back of my mind while I was reading. If the author was having difficulty creating the distinct voices, she could have only used Tris' point of view and remained the same as the other two books.I feel character development was not addressed as well, and was hindered rather then helped by this new technique. All that was truly worked on was the theme of forgiveness, which we saw happen several times over. Otherwise, it was put on hold to allow more focus on the less-than-spectacular plot.Finally, we get to the ending. Contrary to many people's opinions, I was perfectly fine with the ending. It was written well enough that I teared up a bit, which I did not expect after the whole book was so unsatisfying to me. This shows the writing at the end was well done, and is the other reason for the two star rating. It couldn't compensate for the rest of the Allegiant, but I will end on the though that the very end was what I expected the whole book to be, absolutely fabulous. I hope that Ms. Roth continues to write, and will hopefully adore another book by her as much as I adored Divergent and Insurgent.

First off, Allegiant reveals a great maturation in Veronica Roth's writing. She illustrates relationships with more nuance and explores emotional depths only touched upon in Divergent. There are moments in Allegiant that will stay with me long after much of the rest of the trilogy will melt away in my mind. I was particularly intrigued by the passages narrated by Tobias. Full of contradictions, he is perhaps the most complex, flawed, best drawn character in the trilogy.SPOILER: Let's talk about the end. I imagine many readers will feel disappointed or even betrayed by the conclusion of the series. It seems very fashionable these days to emulate George RR Martin's practice of killing off the best characters.  I must confess the final few chapters did not culminate into the most satisfying ending I could imagine. I'm all for stories where the hero goes out like a boss at the end, but that's not quite what happens here.  Tris's death, at the hands of a very under-developed antagonist, feels almost accidental.  In such a fanciful adventure tale, where our heroes have previously escaped near certain death time and time again, the effect is dissonant to the tone of the rest of the story. It's like all of a sudden the rules got changed on us. A great ending offers surprise, but also a weight of cosmic inevitability.  Tris's death felt a little more like one of those long long joke/stories kids tell, only to pull the rug out from the listener with an abrupt ending like, "Then suddenly they got hit by a car and died."  At the same time, the ending did not destroy the book (or franchise) for me either.(To those reviewers whose hearts seem devastated by the unfortunate turn of events in the last few chapters, let me suggest this: Imagine how you would have seen the story concluded, and let that be your ending. Or write Veronica Roth a letter asking her for an alternate ending. Who knows? She just might do it. Remember that Mark Twain's original ending for Huckleberry Finn had Jim captured by slavers. In a literary sense, it's a strong ending, totally consistent with the world and anti-slavery themes of the book. But readers were so disappointed that Twain later wrote an ending where Jim gets freed. But I digress).In conclusion, Veronica Roth has a voice well worth devoting some attention. I look forward to seeing what she decides to write next.

reviewText: I really enjoyed this Trilogy.  I happened to have a couple of days with hours free, so read the trilogy all at once.  The premise that includes a new Society after the world war that destroyed the entire world, is brilliant.  The factions, their designations in the proper way to run the society is all brilliant.  Because I am a pastor, the theological themes jutted out of the story with each faction having its weakness,.  Then when true Evil, the weakness of all us humans, comes to the fore, the entire society is threatened.  By the time we get to Allegiant, with Tris and Four still surviving after multiple attempts to kill them, we find ourselves back in "Chicago" with the lead couple set to confront their parents, who have successfully taken over the society.  It is hard to write this review without spoilers, so I will end it by saying that the ending of this book has been panned broadly.  I actually would have liked a "riding into the sunset" kind of ending, but Veronica Roth chose something else.  It works.  The ending brings this book, and the Trilogy into the genre of dystopian fiction for everyone, not just young adults.

****This review contains spoilers*****Well, I really debated between 2 stars and 3 and settled on 3. It wasn't poorly written or edited. It wasn't confusing, really. It just...fell flat. And I couldn't be more disappointed given how much I loved the first two books.I debated not writing a review but given my glowing take on the others I felt remiss leaving this one blank. As if people wouldn't figure out that, "when you can't say something nice, don't say anything at all" would apply.It wasn't terrible. I didn't even mind *********spoiler alert**************that she killed Tris. It was ok. Believable given that Tris should have died about 50 times prior to the moment when she finally does. But it just didn't do it for me. Instead of leaving me broken and distraught, I just felt relieved. This last book felt like one long attempt to wrap up a global story that was never really meant to be global and the lack of direction seemed kind of obvious.I'd always wondered at the tight focus (Chicaco only) of the initial world. How did these people end up in this dystopia? Was there an apocalypse? What circumstances led them to this point? (In Eden's Root I killed myself researching to cover the "how" and "why" of my apocalypse because if it didn't feel real to me, it wouldn't have felt real to anyone, Or so I thought. But maybe that's just me.)Unlike people who loved "The Road," I actually want to know WHY the world is burning and dying and shaking...I don't just think, "Ok, not gonna focus on that, let's focus on these two people and how they deal with it." As long as the tale is set on Earth, or any other location I know, I want to know what happened. And I said as much in my review of Divergent.But Divergent was just SO GOOD! The tight focus worked well. Roth seemed to build a whole world within that little snow globe that was rich and layered and fascinating.And then in Insurgent, the lens widened to include the other factions and explain *some* aspects of the dystopia. It was enough for me and I loved that part of the story too.And then the lens widened further and the story seemed to disappear - up in smoke - with no center and too many questions.If the U.S. took these genetic purity/cleaning steps, did the rest of the world participate? She never says. And yet, you'd assume if not that the world would have sanctioned our country for violating human rights. If the rest of the world did participate, what does the rest of it look like now? And why did Lake Michigan dry up? Did she explain that and I missed it in plodding through another 500 pages without being so riveted this time?The "wider" lens seemed to only cover a handful of cities and that was it. I just...didn't get it. And then there was Four.Sigh.Somehow, some way, Roth lost her sense of Four. While human vulnerability (as he showed in Divergent) made him sexier than some one-dimensional strongman hero dude, he got a little TOO soft in this book (a progression which began in Insurgent, I'll admit). It was like he dried up and blew away, just so much dandelion fluff. And no, I'm not referring to his reaction to Tris' death (which was equally lame), I mean DURING the story.He couldn't decide what he wanted, he waffled and wishy-washied, and when he and Tris finally got together "all the way", there was no heat left. None. Where was the guy who had only four fears? Where was the guy who climbed the ferris wheel despite his fear? Where? It's like once he became Tobias instead of Four, he slowly deflated - a balloon with a tiny, 1000 page pinprick.And the "funeral?" Well, it was truly depressing, so I guess that's accurate. I actually wrote an alternate ending to comfort myself and a friend...going more for inspiration,  hope, and courage than a continual dirge.I can't recommend this read unfortunately. I'm sure that some loved it. Some probably sobbed and felt totally plugged into the emotions Roth was striving to convey. But it wasn't that way for me.
