It really pains me to write a negative review like the one I'm about to write because I absolutely LOVED Divergent and Insurgent, but it must be done.*spoilers ahead.*I will first say that I am not a person who is very harsh on books in general. I give them the benefit of the doubt even if I've heard bad things. Sadly, all the negative reviews I read were spot on. Secondly, I will say that I do not need the main character to survive the series and I do not always need a happy ending. Yes, I prefer leaving a series feeling fulfilled and happy, but it's not a required formula to make a book worthwhile.I have been putting off reading this book since it came out and I didn't really know why. After Insurgent was finished I was so excited for the third book to come out, and I waited patiently. However, I waited until just a couple days ago to pick up this book. Now I wish I never did. I would gladly use some memory serum to forget all the happenings in this book.-To start off, as many others have stated, the tone of voice from Tris to Tobias really doesn't change. I found myself reading this book feeling completely disconnected from the characters I had grown to love and respect.  They both seemed like shells of their former selves, and not due to any trauma they endured.-There was no character development. If anything I was just left confused who I was even reading about anymore.-I absolutely did not like the plot of this story. It made the concept of Divergence completely pointless. I wanted there to be something unique about the divergent, I wanted them to be special. But no, it all comes down to their genes. It all comes down to something they couldn't control. Oh and what do you know, Tobias isn't even divergent at all according to his genetic code. I just didn't like all the science crap thrown in to this book. I felt like this final book was thrown together hastily and Roth just picked an idea she thought would work because she knew people wanted the third book to come out.-Not only was the plot of this book flawed, but so were the fates of some of the characters(I'll only cover Tris). I knew going into this book that there would be death, I accepted that. I knew before hand that Tris wouldn't make it. I read on anyway because I was expecting her death to mean more than it did, or at least be necessary. However, I think she was killed off just so Roth could try and be different by killing off the main character. And to avoid tying up loose ends that would have arisen had Tris survived. Tris could have let her brother die instead of her. I know there are reasons she took his place, but none of them are good enough for me. Caleb needed to prove himself and Tris took that chance away from him. I just think that if an author is going to kill the main character it should be 100% necessary and make a huge impact. I am a very emotional reader and usually get very invested in characters I love, but I didn't even feel sad when Tris died. In fact, I hardly felt sad at all throughout this book, just numb.-The book didn't make me feel emotional towards the characters. As I have stated, I am an emotional reader, but throughout this book my mood hardly changed. Allegiant didn't spark any real feelings in me besides annoyance. When I finished it I found myself feeling very empty and disappointed.-I was very excited for the movies to come out but this book has basically ruined the whole series for me. I thought the first two books were really leading to something big and exciting(whether it was good or bad) but really those two books were just leading to a massive disappointment. Now I'm not sure if I want to see the movies because I'm bitter about what the ending will be.In conclusion I would not recommend this book. If you want to know what happened read some spoilers and save yourself the time, effort, and money it would take to read this book. I really wanted to like it, but I just can't.
summary: Not excited for the movies anymore...

reviewText: ALLEGIANT brings the Divergent Trilogy to completion with surprising conclusions for each beloved character.  The surprises continue to both delight and sadden the reader. The gambit of raw emotions is both exciting and frightening. The ending will catch you off guard, and will make you love or hate the author. Either way, Veronica Roth has captured my interest with her bravery and dauntlessness!
What a horrible ending to a wonderful series. So disappointed with how the author decided to end this book. Almost wish I never got involved

I understand why many readers are very upset at the ending. They have certain expectations for the genre this trilogy was slated in, and this book disappointed those expectations.However, I am dark and twisted and love endings like this. I knew this was coming about halfway through the book and anticipated it with emotional tremors. I feel the ending and the choices the characters made followed logically from their personalities, back grounds, and growth. I was particularly appreciative that the conflicts the characters faced were rooted in harsh realities, not superficial misunderstandings.I desperately hope the reception for this book doesn't inhibit Roth's career or desire to write. Her ability to address depths of character and truths of life has grown with each book and showcased in Allegiant.
I enjoyed the series but this third book was anticlimatic. As I reader I guess I always expect more. But I did still enjoy the book and series overall.

Terrific series peopled by flawed, amazing, gutsy, thoughtful human beings, doing meaningful work for their culture.  Spoiler alert--unhappy at losing my favorite character but not enough to avoid recommending the series.
I personally wouldn't have ended the series like this - but the whole story - all 3 books, were well paced, intriguing and kept my interest. I can't wait for the movie in March.
summary: An end to a great series

reviewText: The final book is a compelling read often posing reflections of the world we live in today. Life damages us but we help mend each other a journey perhaps of our future.

A sad and somewhat strange ending to the trilogy. I really loved the series and was as frustrated with book three as I was with the final installment of the hunger games but it has stayed with me and there is certainly a sense of completion.

I was worried that it wouldn't be as good as the others after reading other comments, but I loved it!  I am glad to see Tris get her tough girl image back in this book. Tris and Tobias' love is still strong throughout the book. I thought the twist would be a break up with them once they leave the fence and new relationships would form with the new characters they meet, but I am glad I was wrong. Many others commented about the ending being bad or not right, but I believe it was complete and left me feeling like I got great closure to this trilogy. I sooo wish someone would make a movie out of these books.  They would be a huge success!  Thank you Veronica for these three wonderful escapes from reality for all of us busy moms who just want to relax and curl up with a great book. I hope that you will continue to make many more similar to these.

**Warning- spoiler alert**I stayed up until midnight finishing this book and ended up having the worst nights sleep I've had in a long time.  I feel like my best friend has just died.  Which in fact she kind of did.  I have been reading other reviews and there are two that I keep thinking of...one that says something like, "if you devoured the first two books of the trilogy and loved them as I did, stop there! Don't read the third one.  Just make up your own ending."  And the other is, "does the author want to end her career?"  I can honestly say that I feel pretty certain that I won't be following or supporting this author anymore.I think I would've been able to accept the ending better if Tobias had been killed instead.  As Tris is the main character of the book, I came to love and admire her. I identified with her.  What will this book say to all the other girls who also identified with her?  Will they feel like they should sacrifice themselves also?  I hope not!I was barely able to finish the last chapters and epilogue.  Who wants to watch the man you loves trying to move on?  And to imagine who he might end up with?  Who will take Tris spot?  It was heart wrenching.Seriously, what a huge disappointment.  Tris did deserve better and so did we.  I reserved this book months ago, not caring how much I paid.  And now I find myself thinking what a waste of money and I'm so glad I only paid $7.

This is the first review I have ever written. I wanted to try and save people the heartbreak I have just suffered.SPOILER ALERT BELOW!!Ok, first of all how could you just kill off Tris in such a meaningless way?? The whole story line there was FULL of flaws. There were so many things that could have been done to make this book great! But it was like every time Roth stumbled across a path of narrative genius headed in the right direction she jumped ship and went somewhere completely confusing with it!Also, I was very excited to see how Tris and Tobias progressed in this book but there was nothing. Yeah so they figured out they loved each other. We knew that in the second book. In this book we found out that we just keep hurting the people we love but we continue to love them anyways.I didnt like the way Roth changed between points of view. It was confusing most of the time because their voices were EXACTLY the same! I was very disappointed in the the way Tobias left Tris knowing how self sacrificing she is and expected her not to take the place of her brother.The killing off of other beloved characters for stupid reasons (Tori killed and not thought of again, Uriah dying for simply standing in the wrong spot at the wrong time, etc.) Was completely devastating!! You cant let readers get attached to so many characters and then rip them all from us in the end!I loved the first two books but if i were you i wouldnt even waste my time with this book. I am very disappointed and will go on with my own alternate ending to these books because i cannot believe how they turned out. No way will i be going to see these movies when they are released. I feel bad for the actors/actresses who were cast to play what should have been career starting characters but have been robbed of that chance.
Ending to Divergent series.  Kept the heartbeat up!

I'm so sorry to say this, but it is what it is... Just ok... And as it is, it was all right in the begining, horrible in the middle, and it got a lot better towards the end. Thankfully! Honest to God, there was a point there I almost stopped reading. I didn't, and I'm glad, since the end was what I thought it should be (don't worry, no spoilers) But still, I was sorry for the whole thing.Just so we're clear, I LOVED the first two, couldn't wait for the finale. And I could argue that this was the problem: too long had past between the second and the last books, my expectations were way high, I had forgoten Roths writing style, forgoten a little of the plot. I had to re-read a lot of the first two books before starting this one, and also read the first of the Tobias Stories, to get in the mood. But I thought it was worth it then.So I began reading the book, which starts slow and that's ok. It was understandable, since she was building a whole new world. But then all the in-your-face hard-ass wonderful characters that I fell in love with started, in my opinion, going completely out of character - so to speak. They explained - instead of showed with action - every single feeling they have had so far. And they explained it with therapist-like understanding of their psyque, giving a self-important life lesson at every page. Suddenly I wasn't allowed to comprehend anything for myself, everything was chewed down for me. And I swallowed it with a good dose of self-pitty that came from almost every character. I felt stupid through this whole process and that's when, around chapter 20, I almost quit reading the book.But I didn't, and I'm glad, since, shotly after, the action portion of the book began and it got a lot better. Like I said, the ending was how I thought it should have been and at least I wasn't completely frustrated with it. I was actually satisfied at the end.So I guess the point of this review is: don't get your hopes up. I did and it didn't help me much. But it is still worth reading if you have read the first two.
summary: Heartbreakingly, after wonderful two books, the final one was just ok

reviewText: The outcome was unexpected, but realistic with a touch of hope. In a world of pro quid pro, the better side of humanity was evident.

Veronica Roth had an incredible opportunity to wrap up this trilogy in a very creative way. Instead, she introduced a brand new storyline that was so boring it was hard to keep reading. If she wanted to kill off a main character, that's fine- but do it right. JK Rowling killed off her characters with meaning, she didn't rush a death just to be shocking. It's clear Veronica Roth didn't have an actual gameplan when she wrote this book. To be honest, this was the worst third book in the history of trilogies. I almost wish I didn't waste my time.
summary: Boring storyline, horrible way to end a series

reviewText: I can't help wondering what the author was thinking when she wrote this book. Out of all the directions she could've taken it, this whole scenario is less than impressive and seemed inexcusable even for a YA book. I am not even referring to how various characters were killed off for no reason; I am referring to what has got to be the lamest excuse for a dystopian future ever! There is just way too much that didn't add up here..I mean, I could make a list of supporting reasons but let's face it, this book was bad on so many levels in so many ways that it seems cruel to create a giant list of reasons for why it sucked... The worst part is I'm sure the author agonized over how to finish her series but I kept getting the sense that she just committed to the whole gene therapy storyline out of a desire to go somewhere different and unfortunately, she stubbornly ignored the fact that it didn't work and ended up sacrificing her story and characters for it. It really feels desperately cobbled together after too much thought in a last minute attempt to just be done already.  By the time I was nearing the end I was hard pressed to care, but I don't really understand why she felt the need to abruptly kill various characters either (seemed like it came out of nowhere and for no other purpose than to surprise us). Worse than this, the attempt to split the POV between Tris and Tobias only resulted in them becoming the same person so it was kinda like Tobias--who was my favorite character up until now--wasn't even in this book!

Forgive me for being mad after reading this book but I bet you that your reaction will be the same too! After reading the first two book and completely loved it, I expected the finale will be explosive with a great ending! This book left me empty, distraught, and angry! Not a way to finish this Miss Roth!

While the understanding for outcomes in the novel exists, it doesn't allow full closure for the reader who has developed an almost personal relationship with these characters at the point in time they reach this installation. Fast paced and well written, it leaves a sour taste in your mouth that you will inevitably experience yourself if you have already read the other two--as you can't leave the story unfinished.

You start with something good (Divergent) and slowly get worse and worse.  Can anyone say greedy and money-hungry?  Roth is SUCH a coward for ending the book the way she does.  For a character to survive nearly being thrown off a chasm, and execution, and being nearly beaten to death, and a death serum that no one can survive [among other things], to be killed off by being shot!  Are you kidding me?  What a coward.You took a good thing and made it really, really disappointing, anti-climatic, and a horrible experience for so many people who used to be fans.  I don't want to read anything you write ever again.
Loved it until the end. Not what I was expecting and I was hoping for something ... a miracle......... don't want to give anything away but uhgg  needed tissues.....
I have never been so heart broken or let down by the ending of the book. I wish it stopped halfway through and just imagined my own ending!
I liked the first two better. It took a little longer to get through this one but it was still good.

Let me begin by saying that in spite of the things I didn't like about "Allegiant" I enjoyed reading the book.  Just like the previous two, it is hard to put down.  And even though I may not agree with the direction that Roth took it and with all of the plot points, I can understand and appreciate why she chose to take it in that direction.  It is a fitting ending for what she began in "Divergent" even if all readers are not thrilled about it.  It is very hard to talk about "Allegiant" without giving anything away as SO many other reviewers have done (even though this isn't the forum for that), but I will try not to.The story picks up right where "Insurgent" left off, with the dystopian future version of Chicago in chaos because of the video that Tris made sure was shown.  In that video the residents learned that there are people outside of the fence who have placed them in that city for their own protection but that it is time to let out their divergent population.  Yet Evelyn and her factionless army do not want this to happen.  Now that they have overthrown the faction system, they want to install their own system - talk about going from bad to worse.  Yet Tris and a small band of her friends (Christina, Uriah, Cara, and Tobias, among others) sneak outside of the city to discover what is out there for themselves.  What they find is nothing like what they imagined, and it threatens to tear them apart as they try to reconcile new truths with old truths and struggle to determine if these truths are real or just more fiction.Roth made the decision to tell the story through the viewpoints of both Tris and Tobias, alternating between them.  This isn't necessarily a bad idea in theory, and for those who purchased the collection of stories from Tobias's point of view, they had some familiarity with his perspective.  The problem comes in the fact that their identities when they are telling the story are not different enough.  There were times when I had to turn back to the beginning of the chapter to remind myself who was narrating at that point.  Perhaps this is what Roth wanted, or perhaps these characters are so similar, but there needed to be more differentiation between their voices.  Another issue is that there are so many new characters thrown at the reader but hardly any of them are developed enough, especially those who are meant to be the villains in this piece.  Perhaps if Roth had made this a longer book, or split it into four books, these characters could have been given their due.  Which brings me to my last issue with the novel.  There are so many climaxes among the various plots that the ending just feels way too rushed, especially considering the impressive beginning this series had.  It's been over a week since I finished and I think I am still in shock with the direction that Roth took this in.  If she feels that she has been true to her characters, then I can't fault her for that, even if I don't agree.

I was kinda disappointed with this third in the series.  While I loved the first two books, this one was harder to read and understand what was happening.  If you've read the first two books, you will have to read this one also but don't expect too much......

The tears just keep flowing! The bravery and love and selflessness is just amazing in this book-this series! I am absolutely in love with this series and this last book was breathtaking, the love just flows! I will definitely be reading this series over and over again!!! I recommend it to everyone! Tris and Tobias are AMAZING!

This was a very disappointing conclusion to a trilogy I had really enjoyed.  I think the overall feeling the reader is left with is sadness and hopelessness.  I have listened to the author's interviews about her choices for the ending of this story, but I think she really missed the mark.  I think she wants the book to speak to the reader about self-sacrifice and maturity, but instead has crafted a story that represents futility.  If a character as brave and resourceful as Tris can't make it through all life throws at her, what hope is there for the ordinary person?  I also found the recurrent theme of suicide somewhat concerning for a young adult book.  Don't buy this book if you or the  person it is intended for suffers from depression.

I hate to sound like a broken record, but this was not a good ending to this series.  First, if you've read James Dashner (Maze Runner Series), there were a lot of similarities in plot. I actually would have liked this book slightly better if I hadn't already read that series.  Second, there were several holes in the plot.  I won't repeat what others have already written, but I totally agree that the things just didn't add up.  Also, the ending was disappointing, and it seemed like there were several conflicts that just suddenly resolved.  (Did anyone else feel like some characters were killed off just to add needless short term drama?)Having said that, I did think the book was worth reading.  I was engaged enough to finish the book and did feel connected to the characters.  There were several spots in the beginning where I laughed out loud. (Uriah claiming to be much needed eye candy for the expedition)  So, I'm going with three stars.

I read Divergent and Insurgent several times in anticipation of Allegiant.  I cannot express the disappointment I felt after reading Allegiant.  I deal with enough loss and injustice in reality. I do not read fiction books for more of the same. Veronica Roth is a gifted writer.  I found myself personally connected to the characters she created.  Because of this I will not read anything else she writes.  If I could give this book a negative star rating I would.
summary: Can I give a negative star rating?

reviewText: Allegiant is nothing like Veronica Roth's first two books.  It was a lot of chapters that didn't really have much happening.  I kept putting it down with no desire to pick it up again.  Several weeks later I would tell myself it had to get better and keep going a bit longer.  I think she struggled on the story line of this or just didn't have any more adventure left to write about.

I took sometime reading this series, for me it was not a "can not put it down until I finish" experience.I enjoyed the characters and how Ms. Roth described this world. That lasting premise that all are damaged by life yet we can mend ourselves and others by choice to do so is lovely and for me true.

For me, it's just not worth it to read something that's going to leave me sad and depressed. I loved the first two books, but I sort of wish I hadn't invested in those only to be saddened so much with this one. I just don't like to leave a story feeling worse than when I started it, that's just me.

It was very slow reading two-thirds of it.  Yes the plot had to be set up but it was very slow going.  It was very frustrating with Four assuming the worst of Tris, going against anything he had ever seen from her.  I didn't expect the ending.  I did like the epilouge explaining the future.
summary: A let down to the series

reviewText: Oh, Ms. Roth...I so wanted to love this book as I enjoyed the first two books in the series.Alas, I could not.The first two books were filled with action, excitement, daring, battles, struggles.  And this one?  It was filled with angst and regret.Yes, I am disappointed with what happened to Tris towards the end.  Could I see why you did it?  Of course.  As the author, you have the right, power, and choice to do what you want with your characters.  And I could see why you chose to go the route you did.  I don't have a problem with that.The problem I had was that nothing much happened in this book.  All the suspense and tension was missing.  And I did not like the Tobias/Tris changing point of view narration.  As a reader, I could not tell which character was telling the story, as they both sounded so similar.It's almost as if you ran out of steam after book two.  There was a tremendous set-up at the end of book two; perhaps you just....got tired.I wish I could've liked this book.  It took me  month to get through it, and I zipped through the first two.  I felt like I was slogging in mud to finish this, like I was obligated to.I did enjoy learning more about Tris' mother, and what lay outside the city.  But, it felt flat, underdeveloped.

(NOTE: Half of this review is for people who HAVEN'T read Allegiant yet. The other half contains spoilers and my thoughts on them. If you wish to not know what happens, stop reading before the line of asterisks.)To me, Allegiant was exceptionally well-written. It's raw and feeling, and I think that this is the most Veronica Roth has ever put into writing. It conveys every emotion, and yes, some may argue that it's too harsh, but given what Insurgent set the scene for, such realism is to be expected. You can't have something build up and not get a big reaction from it. I personally think Allegiant delivered pretty well.The only bone I had to pick with Allegiant was the two-voicing feature the author put in. From Divergent and Insurgent, I'm used to hearing Tris's thoughts, and Tris's thoughts only. Now suddenly, I know mysterious, secretive, and brooding  Tobias Eaton's thoughts too? I get that he's  a real person and that Roth wants to show his vulnerability, but I think Ms. Roth just isn't used to writing in a male voice. Whenever I'm reading and I happen to skip over a chapter name that details if the story is currently told by Tris or Tobias, I'm confused until I see the word "Tris" or "Tobias" and know who's speaking. They just sound too similar. Their characteristics, actions, aren't as diverse as I would've hoped to see, and that kind of disappointed me.*****************************SPOILERS START HERE*********************************Okay, now I get why there were two voices. Obviously, someone had to close the story after Tris died. And I think that's where Tobias's perspective really shows through.And on Tris's death: Nobody wanted her to die. I get that. But in real life, the hero doesn't always get to live. Sometimes the hero is the one who gives up everything to save everyone. And  if Tris hadn't disabled the device that was going to brainwash her whole city, then her world would've been chaos. But you're thinking, "Tris could've went with the original plan and let Caleb go in. Then everything would've been fine and we could still ship Tris Eaton." But really, would Tris still be the heroine we know and love if she just let her own brother die? With all the unselfish values her courageous mother taught her? The answer is no. We wouldn't love the book if that happened, either. That's why I'm giving Allegiant 5 stars for allowing it's heroine to stand by her values from the beginning... to the end.
summary: Bittersweet, raw, and beautiful. Bravo, Veronica Roth!

reviewText: Call me crazy... I cried my eyes out and found it hard to swallow at times, but I still loved it. It makes perfect sense when you consider the series as a whole. I can't say I'm not still upset, but I understand and appreciate the ending and sometimes that's all you can do.
summary: An Emotional Ride -- Not What I Expected...

reviewText: IT’S SO GOOD I WISH I HADN’T READ IT. And by that, I mean, for a lot of different reasons, that this book made me feel things emotionally and intellectually that were almost too much for me to handle. Imagine Mockingjay, only worse. Yeah. I said worse. It is brilliantly written, imagined, and executed. I am honored to have been a part of these books.It’s hard to write a review for the finale book of a trilogy without giving away lots of spoilers, so I’ll keep my review short.The characterizations only get stronger throughout this book. Their personalities, their weaknesses, their strengths. Everything about these characters gets pushed to the breaking point. These characters are so well written that they become real life people, making good and bad choices, suffering and finding joy in awful situations.Tris and Tobias’ relationship is so sweet throughout the whole book. They have REAL couple fights, not just “who loves each other more” fights. They get mad at each other, they lie to each other, they yell and they cry. But there is also a very deep connection between them that can defeat any obstacle they come across. Of all the young adult books I’ve read in the last few years, Tris and Tobias are the best example of a healthy relationship I’ve ever seen. All my kids will read this book so they can see what they should aim for when they fall in love at 16.It’s like Veronica Roth came up with an idea for them, and then by the end of the series the characters had taken on a life of their own. Instead of the series ending happily, it ends realistically. This book demonstrates the terrible nature of war, the loss that comes with conflict, and the reality of sacrifice. It’s hard to read because of how accurate it is, but the accuracy makes it a more satisfying finish.I loved this book. I love the way it’s written. I love the characters. I love the romance and I love the war. Veronica Roth is an incredibly talented writer, and I’m so excited to see what she’s done next.

I am hoping those of you reading these reviews have not purchased this book.  I raced through the first two books and thought they were really good.  Bizarre, considering the age of the characters, but the story concept was believable.  The books contained no bad language, no sex but plenty of violence.  The first half of the book was very heavy on the science of genetics.  I read books because they take me places and allow me to escape  to someone's world.  I don't want to read books that make me stay up all night feeling bad or really tick me off.  So that being said, WTF.  (SPOILER ALERT)  Why would an author writing for young adults kill off one of the main characters through an act of horrible violence?  I will not recommend these books to anyone.  Nor will I see the movie.

As a fan of "Divergent" who found "Insurgent" satisfying, I was disappointed by "Allegiant" in almost every way. It takes a while for the story to start (Roth seems to wallow at the end of "Insurgent"). Then the plot turns out to be highly implausible and fairly uninteresting. (How is it that the substitute history lesson given isn't immediately modified by "David's superiors"? How can the technologies be that similar given generations of independent development? If you haven't read the book yet, don't worry about not understanding these points; I'm being purposefully unclear so that I don't spoil anything.) The fire between the main characters is largely extinguished and rarely explored (they keep talking about wanting to be alone, but then when they find themselves alone in the dormitory, Roth skips straight to the next chapter and day). Finally, the ending is thoroughly dissatisfying (perhaps from a decision to put artistic integrity above reader enjoyment). The whole book has the feel of being too quickly written by someone who became too immersed in her own story to keep the reader's perspective and desires in mind.
A must read of what life could become. It shows one what could happen to each of us. All three books are a must on your book shelves.

I felt like I waited FOREVER for this book to finally come out!  I loved this series from page one of Divergent to the last page of Insurgent.  Then I had to wait again for Allegiant to come out.  I pre-ordered it months in advance and checked my mail box a hundred times the minute Amazon said it had shipped.  I avoided all reviews because I wanted to go into the last book with pure thoughts and my own ideas of what was about to happen to Tris and Tobias(Four).  After reading Allegiant, I would have to say I am a little disappointed in the writing of the book and even the way it ended but I will NOT give spoilers!! Sigh....Allegiant begins where Insurgent left off, with Tris and her friends locked up for participating in the uprising.  Tobias is Evelyn's right-hand man and also her son.  Evelyn is the new leader and is trying to bring everyone back under her control and rid the city of factions through brute force and any other means necessary.  While Tobias doesn't agree with what his mother is doing, he continues to follow her orders until he can find a way out.  Caleb, Tris's brother is also locked up and is awaiting his trial for helping Janine create and administer the mind warping drugs given to Dauntless to kill Abnegation people."He is a part of me, always will be, and I am a part of him, too. I don't belong to Abnegation, or Dauntless, or even the Divergent. I don't belong to the Bureau or the experiment or the fringe. I belong to the people I love, and they belong to me- they, and the love and loyalty I give them, form my identity far more than any word or group ever could. I love my brother. I love him, and he is quaking with terror at the though of death. I love him and all I can think, all I can hear in my mind, are the words I said to him a few days ago : I would never deliver you to your own execution ""To me, when someone wrongs you, you both share the burden of that wrongdoing - the pain of it weighs on both of you. Forgiveness, then, means choosing to bear the full weight all by yourself. Caleb's betrayal is something we both carry, and since he did it, all I've wanted is for him to take its weight away from me. I am not sure that I'm capable of shouldering it all myself - not sure that I am strong enough, or good enough."Tobias, Tris, Cara, Christina, Uriah, Peter, and a few others decide to leave and head to the fringe to find out what is out there.  What they find is the Bureau.  They find out that the Bureau has been monitoring them for generations and is doing scientific experiments to create the "perfect" human, not only in Chicago but across the country.  While at the Bureau, Tris and her group of misfits find out a lot of background history on their city and the many secrets kept from them and the others.  Tris finds out where her mother came from and that she was not born in the city but was actually placed in Dauntless by the Bureau as a spy."I take a deep breath. I'm not sure where that swell of desperation came from, but know that I've acknowledge it, it's impossible to ignore, like a living thing has awakened from a long sleep inside me. It writhes in my stomach and throat. I need to leave. I need the truth.""Knowledge is power. Power to do evil...or power to do good. Power itself is not evil. So knowledge itself is not evil."Tris and Tobias have a hard time figuring out their own identity and where they belong as the secrets are unveiled.  Rifts and bad decisions begin to pull them apart instead of strengthening their bond.  Will the answers they are seeking bring them back together or will their bond break with more death and destruction than they can handle?"Since I was young, I have always knownthis: Life damages us, every one. Wecan't escape that damage.But now, I am also learning this: Wecan be mended. We mend each other.""I don't belong to Abnegation, or Dauntless, or even the Divergent. I don't belong to the Bureau or the experiment or the fringe. I belong to the people I love, and they belong to me-they, and the love and loyalty I give them, form my identity far more than any word or group ever could.""It reminds me that no embrace will ever feel the same again, because no one will ever be like her again, because she's gone. She's gone, and crying feels so useless, so stupid, but it's all I can do."The disappointment in this book is palpable.  I loved this series and even though Insurgent was a little predictable I still enjoyed it and the development of the characters.  Allegiant fell flat in the growth of the characters.  I think there was too much trying to be told and answered, to adequately tell a great story.
summary: What happened?  Had so much potential!!

reviewText: I hate it when this happens!!! I wrote a very nice and lengthy review over this book, and when I went to save it.....nothing. I lost it all. Ugh!!! :-( Well.....anyway....this is going to be the abbreviated version. It's just been "one of those days".I would probably give this book 3.5 stars. I heard so many people talk about how horribly it ended, but I was ok with the way it ended. Was it sad? yes. Was it a surprise? not really. I knew something big was going to happen. I had thought it was going to be that everyone would lose their memories/be "reset" and have to start everything over again. What I DID have a problem with in this book was all the back and forth between this uprising and that uprising....good grief! I was SO over it. I had trouble keeping track with what they were "going up against". I was fine with the first fourth of the book, but once they left the city and were picked up by Amar and that chick, I was done. It was SO anticlimactic once they got back to the compound and heard that the "big revelation" wasn't really the REAL revelation....and on...and on....blah, blah, blah. There were lots of little things that didn't seem to make since, or work. Like when they left the city on foot....apparently never to return....with only their clothes on their back. No food. No water. Nothing to help them survive indefinitely in a place they knew nothing about. Yah....that makes perfect sense. Or at the end when they set the memory serum off at the compound so that they could kind of "reprogram" all the people so that they didn't believe the whole GD vs GP thing (which I thought was weird and far fetched). That's good for those people, but doesn't the rest of the country/world believe in the GD/GP thing? So really, they didn't solve that problem. Also, throughout the series I kind of had a problem with big, tough, practically fearless Tobias scared of heights. Really?!?! That seems to be as likely as saying he was scared of spiders or something. And it seemed like this fear wasn't always an issue. Sometimes he was deathly afraid of being high up, but other times it didn't seem to be a factor. But again, my biggest problem with this book is the repetitiveness of the uprisings of this group and then that group. It was hard to keep track of, and I wasn't at all invested enough in all the various groups' problems to keep track of it all. :-\There were a couple of things I DID like about this book. One thing was the heart breaking choice Tobias made after Tris was gone. The scene where he went back to his old house, cut his hair, and took out the memory serum. So sad. :-( Choosing between living with the unbelievable pain of loss and all the good and bad memories that go along with it, or forgetting it all, which means to have no memory of Tris....like she had never existed. Wow. So heartbreaking. And to have Christina be the one to help him walk away from this. I thought that was really cool. Very well written. The other part I liked was at the end with Peter. Peter was such an evil person, but for him to see this and want to change the direction of his life, I thought that was cool. I guess you could see it either way. You could see his action as being a coward, or being brave. I prefer brave. The funniest part of this was the way Tobias said that after Peter took the serum, he was so clueless about everything, and couldn't even remember his name after being told over and over again. That was a very UNPeter thing. Kind of poetic justice.So there you go. I definitely will still go see the movie, but it will be a bit sad knowing how it will all end.

No Detailed Spoilers - I know that there's a mix between those that agree and don't agree with the ending of this series but for me, I thought is was one of the best ways to say goodbye to the story and characters that I grew to love throughout the three books.Like the first two, I devoured this book over a weekend.  Before I started it and as I was reading through it I knew that there was a big surprise coming and I kept wondering what it would be.  Truthfully, the other endings that I thought up wouldn't have felt as right at how Ms. Roth put it all together.This book does a great job of explaining the world Tris and Tobias grew up in, Tris' family tree and the world outside the fence.  You get angry and interested in this larger world and the new characters that you meet.  There are several tough choices that Tris, Tobias and the others have to make and you see them growing up and really weighing the consequences. As you understand the larger picture I think you realize that there isn't really a chance at a happy ending the way other YA books go because their world will still be severely broken after they've done everything they can to help it - but they've made it better and that's how they leave their mark.

After looking at several reviews and comments I simply must add my own comments about this novel. It's dynamic, fascinating and moving. I truly enjoyed the story including the development of the romance between Four (Tobias) and Tris. The tale develops according to the personalities of the characters. True, I was sometimes disappointed in the portrayal of Four's fears and insecurities because I found them so hard to believe after reading the first two novels in the series. However, Tris emerges as a strong, mature character who bolsters him in every way because she loves him. Told from both viewpoints, the two narratives are linked in such a way that I felt the story flowed well. In short, as my reading progressed I found it hard to put the book aside.Leaving the city, to travel outside and discover the truth takes courage to face the unknown. When the group, led by Tris and Tobias, find another controlled society where the city is viewed as an experiment and the people within it as scientific subjects, they are not certain where to turn. And, because of the decision by the scientists to reset the city - start over - the group cannot bear to see the memories of their friends and families erased. Yet how can a group of newcomers change the outcome? Knowing that the scientists were responsible for so much of the chaos and death in the city they are determined to try to save the city. As the book comes to it climax I found myself running with these young idealistic young people so full of hope for the future.Yes, I thought this was an excellent well written novel. I'm glad I read it and believe that the author did credit to her story and the characters in the outcome. Rather than give away the ending, I simply suggest that it be read with an open mind and enjoy it for its many merits.
summary: Follow Tris and Four (Tobias) Outside the City

reviewText: Spoiler Alert:  I really loved the first two books and couldn't wait to finish the trilogy.  This third book was very disappointing! Okay, if you have not read the first two book in this series, START there, with Divergent and read no further in this review! If you are looking to as to how the book is before you buy it ... YES! READ IT!! I will let you know right up front that this book was an emotional zip-line that you MUST ride! To sum it up in the only way I can is this .... Veronica Roth has balls of cold hard steel! My hat is off to her! Bravo!*** SPOILER ALERT - YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED ***Dear Ms. Roth,I would like to personally say THANK YOU for keeping it real and having the cojones to do what you felt was needed to keep the story true to itself. I have no doubt that you knew good and well people were going to react in a not so favorable way, and yet you still remained true to the story and I can not express how "upsettingly awesome" it was to read! I cried, I rejoiced, and I found myself believing in hope. Life does not always have a happy ending, and I believe Tris and Four remained true to their characters all the way to the last word of the novel! So thank you, so very much, for giving me a story whose ending was a great reminder that integrity, courage, and being true to one's self, sometimes for the greater good, is the most honorable testimony to one's life there is. It was a beautiful, bittersweet ending to an amazing series. Thank you!A fellow artist, and now unyielding fan,Rhea Cryingwolf

Spoiler Alert! First, I loved Divergent. I liked Insurgent. And I hated Allegiant.  There are so many reasons, Many of which are echoed in other reviews here.  In short, the dual narration could have worked, but instead of hearing Tris and Tobias - we get Tris, the obnoxious version and Tobias, through a Tris lens.  If Roth was going to us this technique, her editor should have made sure the two narrators had two distinct voices. Next, the plot was pathetic, disappointing and felt like it was written by a different author to end a different story. I love sci-fi. I love dystopian novels. So I'm willing to buy into a certain amount of suspended reality. But this one goes off the deep end. For most of the book you just get boring exposition about the stupid reason why the factions existed in the first place. And it is stupid, scientifically not plausible, and a waste of time. Do not waste your time on this book. I'm so sad they are making a movie of Divergent because that means they'll probably eventually make a movie of this pathetic mess.

A lot of people are giving this book low stars. I gave this 4 stars because . . . well, Veronica Roth must have iron writers armor and a keyboard of steel. She wrote with power and wrote the story exactly how it should of ended. I know a lot of people complain about the ending, but sometimes, well-written and real life ending are extremely hard for some readers.*Book Details*Allegiant by Veronic Roth was published by Katherine Tegen Books in October 2013. It had 545 pages.The novel’s premiseTris and Tobias leave Chicago, everything they have ever known, and see the surrounding world only to find out the people outside their windy city are not quite as oblivious of Chicago as they were led to believe.*Point of View*Quality: Needs ImprovementSo in this third book, Veronica switches points of view between Tris and Tobias. This was not executed well. The only difference between the points of view was that under each chapter heading, the point of view character was listed: Tris or Tobias.This POV switching didn’t work well for me. After two books of exclusively Tris’s point of view, Veronica needed to write in some obvious tag at the start of each Tobias chapter. Multiple times I was pages into the chapter before I realized the point of view was Tobias’s.Also, I didn’t get the feel that Tobias had his own personality. In writing his chapters, Veronica really needed to give him his own voice. It seemed like we were getting Tobias’s point of view from Tris’s voice. To make matter’s worse, Tobias’s voice wasn’t exactly a man’s voice.*Editing*Quality: StandardI highlighted a single comma overuse issue.However the content editor should have helped with the point of view issues.*Imagination and Uniqueness*The imagination seemed quite limited. Veronica let us out of Chicago but she didn’t seem to be able to show us the world very well. We got to see a single government facility and a single fringe neighborhood.There were a lot of ways the outside world could have gone. Being stuck in a government facility the whole book, except for Tris’s single trip to the fringe, which while good, was not enough on its own.*Characters*This is the third book, so by now we are all familiar with Beatrice Prior (Tris) and Tobias Eaton (Four), and their budding romance. Though the relationship wasn’t as awesome as it could have been after last been when it seemed so stressed. There relationship was once again stressed.The addition of a few characters from outside helped this book along. However, Tris and Tobias remained the focus.There were a lot of side characters and that made it hard to focus on any particular side plot and this story really needed some better side plots.*eBook Quality*Quality: HighVery high quality eBook and extremely easy to read.
summary: Veronica Roth must have iron writers armor

reviewText: Veronica Roth’s Divergent series comes to a close with the third and final novel, Allegiant, a book which comes in with a bang and leaves with a whimper. Not in the sense that the ending is disappointing, but, well, it’s more than a little sad, with a bittersweet feeling that you don’t find in too many YA books of that genre.The story was told from alternating viewpoints, both Tris and Tobias getting first-person time in the spotlight. The voices were similar but still distinct enough to tell them apart without much trouble, and I loved reading Tobias’s narrative because his thoughts flowed in a way similar to my own, expansive and thoughtful compared to Tris’s energetic emotionally-charged viewpoint.Nature versus nurture was possible the strong theme running through this book, with the issue of genetic damage enhancing one characteristic at the expense of another, and that being what led to the experiment in forming the Factions. It was an interesting idea to play with, especially in that there was no final determination as to which played a larger part in a character’s personality. Genetic predisposition combined with upbringing as well as the general essence of a person all combined, and those who tried to insist that one side or the other won out were pretty quickly shot down. I liked that, since there’s a tendency to try for hard-and-fast explanations in most futuristic fiction, and those rigid explanations rarely stand up to scrutiny.Ultimately this was a powerful end to a powerful series, and I was glad to see it through even when my interest in dystopian and post-apocalyptic fiction started to wane. If more books could be like this, I would be much more satisfied with YA genre books.
summary: A powerful ending to a powerful series.

I found this finish to the series pretty good, but not really great.  I was glad there was an actual explanation as to what happened to cause this situation in the first place. However, I was somewhat disappointed in a few aspects of the story.  Most people will be upset at the ending.  Not getting the ‘happy ending’ you want tends to do that to most, however I for one think it would not have worked any other way.  I was somewhat disheartened to find out they were in an experiment and there was the rest of the world outside the town.  Based on many things mentioned in the first two books, I had this as a theory of what they were and I find being able to predict this plot twist a bit of a letdown.  I mean, that has been done so many times, I was really hoping I was wrong. That being said, the actual story of how the group gets out of the town (that most of us already knew was Chicago) is very exciting and has a good pace.  The conflict of the folks from the town against what they are being told is well done.  As the outside reader, you know there is an angle to everything they are being told but see the struggle of Tris & Four trying to figure it out.My major disappointment with this one is the more in the way it was written.  I have read several books from dual points of view.  In every one of them, you can usually tell which person POV you are reading from.  Sorry to say, there were many (and I mean many) times I had to remind myself or figure out from other parts of the page whose POV it was. The tone, word choices, etc. are usually different between characters in some way, especially when you have one male and one female.  Different ways of thinking, acting, etc. are one of the ways used to tell the reader about the character.  It seems like this was not held to the higher writing standards of the original book.  Yes, I know this is for YA readers, however I still expect better of the writer than this.
summary: Good finish to the series but could have been better.

Amnity had all the green houses and I felt there were answers there that were never explored. The whole issue about genetic modification seems to be just skimmed over. The only thing that I felt gave closure in the book was Tris. The book was predictable in the sense that Tris would sacrifice herself for what she thought was right.

This book takes what was laid out in Insurgance and adds an element of the story that is too big to be covered in one book. The story itself wasn't very interesting because of cookie-cutter characters and multiple moral (boring) themes. The plot was interesting and thought provoking but there was much that wasn't covered. A story development in the Fringe would've been most welcome but alas. Roth uses death, loss and love as her emotional plot elements and she succeeds in constantly over using them. If you have money and time, it might be worth a read but if not, you're not missing out on much.

reviewText: There are so many ways to be brave in this world. Sometimes bravery involves laying down your life for something bigger than yourself, or for someone else. I really enjoyed the first two books in the series, but the ending to Allegiant left me unsatisfied and disappointed. I understand that it is a realistic scenario, but if I want to be depressed, I'll just read the news. My favorite character was killed off, and my second favorite character was left alone. Neither had a remotely happy ending.After finishing Allegiant, it occurred to me that I should have seen it coming. The writer changed the point of view from Tris in the first two books to Tobias in the third. She did that because had she left it in Tris's POV, the story would have had to end at her death. I should have wondered why the author shifted, but I didn't.I spent two weeks reading 1500 pages to end up down in the dumps and hopeless.I suppose I belong in Candor.

Wow, wow, wow.... It's hard to describe how I feel about this book right now. It is truly a different ending to a series than most endings to series are, so there's a definite check on orginality. This book definitely made me go through almost every emotion nameable, like i'm completely serious. It is a very moving book.I have to be honest with all of you, I did really love this ending to this trilogy. I mean, almost every book series ends with a somewhat happy ending with the two lovers happily ever after so this book was very different. I like that. It was definitely a risk the author took with this book but I feel like she made the right one.Though I am still and will be for a long while now grief stricken, I am very happy I read this trilogy. I do now realize why almost everyone was buzzing with energy about this trilogy and I am eagerly awaiting the movie premier of Divergent in March.

This is the spoiler free review.I loved Divergent and Insurgent I've read both of them a few times.  I know that it isn't the strongest world building and some of the stuff is so far from real, but I like the spirit of the story so much I really let that go.  I enjoyed the idea factions and simulations and breaking out of your norms to be something more.Allegiant wasn't the book I hoped it would be.  Part of that is my fault of course for being so excited about it the other part is the direction the author took in the story.  It is a departure from some of the things I really loved in the first two books.  There is definitely not as much action in this one and some of the things that happened I thought were mistakes characters had already made in Insurgent and I thought they had already learned those lessons in a hard enough way they would not repeat them.That said the overall story is enjoyable I got to have some FourTris cuddle time and relationship development that I really liked.--  I fell in love with him.  But I don't just stay with him by default as if there's no one else available to me.  I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other.  I choose him over and over again, and he chooses me.Seeing the world from both Tris's and Tobias's POV went well for me.  I knew Tobias was a flawed character so I wasn't surprised to see some of his struggles while others seemed a little off the mark.  There is a resolution of sorts with Caleb.  We get to see what is outside of the fence, it isn't at all what I thought it was.  Christina became a character I loved even more along with Cara.  There are new bad guys and new problems to deal with.  But the overall storyline just missed the mark with me a little.  It seemed a little like filler to get to the Big Event.I will say that the writing right before and after the Big Event is some of the best I've read from Roth and while I didn't like the direction the story took I respect that as the author that is where she chose to go and she at least wrote those parts beautifully.  The last 15% of the book is absolutely beautiful even if I didn't like where the story went.  But congrats to VR for doing something different with her story.My entire problem I think is that VR didn't make me believe in her ending.  I forgave some plot holes but the resolution between Evelyn and Tobias almost seemed like a cop out.  I did however like the arrangements between the Allegiant and Factionless at the ending.I will probably never read this one again even though Divergent is still one of my favorite books.  There is a definite ending and epilogue so we are not left hanging like in a few other dystopia trilogies I've read.Here is my silly math on how I came to my rating.  4 Stars for the commitment of the author to the ending she wanted, 1 Star for how I felt after finishing the book, 2.5 Stars for the overall outside the fence story line, and 5 stars for beautiful writing of the last 15% of the book.  (4+1+2.5+5)/4 = 3.125 so I'll just round down to 3 Stars total.If you would like to see my full review with spoilers please go to [...]

(** spoiler alert ** )did this book break my heart? yes.was it a near perfect ending?...i think so.i think overall we've been spoiled by an overabundance of HEAs. in the world roth built, HEAs seem rare and hard won. sacrifice and growth, giving the world a chance to heal and grow (people mending people) become the HEA, not necessarily the relationship between the 2 main characters.all that said, it's been quite some time that a book made me cry the way this one did. tris made the ultimate sacrifice, and while i hated that it had to happen, it made sense. her abnegation background...the legacy of her mother...her realization of worthiness due to four. it was who she was.i see people saying that they felt roth didn't stay true to her characters, but i disagree. for one, circumstances change people. finding out your entire existence has been the result of an experiment, and that almost everything you thought you knew was lies? there's no way you'd stay the same.but love...love changes a person, too. and tris and four had been through so much together; it wouldn't have been realistic for things to stay smooth sailing indefinitely (esp seeing what strong-willed characters they both are). i love that they made it through the storm, though. love that they "got it", that they didn't let pride damage what they had.and, if nothing else, tris' realization of the way she and four loved one another...it's going down as one of my favorite passages in history. it was so right on, so emotionally articulate:"If we stay together, I'll have to forgive you over and over again, and if you're still in this, you'll have to forgive me over and over again too," I say. "So forgiveness isn't the point. What I really should have been trying to figure out is whether we were still good for each other or not."All the way home I thought about what Amar said, about every relationship having its problems. I thought about my parents, who argued more often than any other Abnegation parents I knew, who nonetheless went through each day together until they died. Then I thought of how strong I have become, how secure I feel with the person I now am, and how all along the way he has told me that I am brave, I am respected, I am loved and worth loving. "And?" he says, his voice and his eyes and his hands a little unsteady. "And," I say, "I think you're still the only person sharp enough to sharpen someone like me."I am," he says roughly. And I kiss him. His arms slip around me and hold me tight, lifting me onto the tips of my toes. I bury my face in his shoulder and close my eyes, just breathing in the clean smell of him, the smell of wind. I used to think that when people fell in love, they just landed where they landed, and they had no choice in the matter afterward. And maybe that's true of beginnings, but it's not true of this, now. I fell in love with him. But I don't just stay with him by default as if there's no one else available to me.I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other. I choose him over and over again, and he chooses me."i loved this series. the sparse writing, world building...all of it. i'll miss it.and for now, i'm still kind of grieving.

Okay. Veronica Roth, you slayed me. That endinggggg :'(Let me start of by saying this book is very well written and it is a GOOD BOOK. However, I can't give it more than 3 stars, and this is why:First of all, I felt like this book took the series in a direction that it didn't need to go. I just feel like Divergent was filled with such amazingness of a new world and then Insurgent kind of veered away from it, but I was thinking maybe we would get more discovery of the factionless and that there would be more going on. What actually happened in this book, however, (no spoilers) was completely different. I just didn't like the way it went.Kind of along the same lines, I felt that when the story did take this turn and we find out about "the experiment", it's like there's all this information shoved at us and none of it fits into what we've already read and fallen in love with. I just wanted to throw my Kindle a couple of times because I was frustrated. It wasn't the way I wanted it to go.The ending, in my opinion, was unnecessary. I don't mean that because of what actually happens (spoiler free), but of WHY and HOW it happens. It doesn't add up, it doesn't make sense, it didn't make me feel like the ending was justified to end that particular way. I've read books with similar endings where I understood it, but this one just made me angry and sad.The characters introduced in this book seemed kind of flat to me and didn't really serve much of a purpose other than to move the plot along, and in fact they kind of mirrored other characters. And the switching POVs was confusing several times for me, even after reading the name at the top, because Tris and Tobias apparently sound exactly the same in their thoughts. Not a fan.And my final point for three stars is not going to make sense to anyone who's not a romance fan, but that couch scene... WHAT ACTUALLY HAPPENED!? Like seriously, Roth, you couldn't give us some guaranteed assurance? No little snippet of a scene? Even Meyers gave us some headboard breaking sex, for pete's sake lol. But I digress.I will say, I did think the book was well written and I'm glad I read it and finished the series. If you've already read the first two, go ahead and finish - just be prepared for this series to crash and burn a little.

What a disappointing ending.  This part of my review is sort of spoiler-ish relating to the outside of the fence.Isn't it bad enough that the city itself was in disarray?  Chaos and rebels along with a tyrant running the city.  Things were bad.  Then they ventured outside the fence where, guess what?  It was more orderly but still there were rebels, people wanted to rise up and fight the government.  Wasn't it already bad enough in the city?Now on the SUPER SPOILER section of my review.  Yea be warned...  Don't read it if you don't want to know!!First and foremost, what an utter disappointment to kill Tris!  This character has struggled to overcome many obstacles and has grown (realizing she wanted to live). she finally came to a good place with Tobias and them BAM!  You killed her?  I'm all for a writer being bold but this made me feel like I just wasted my time reading the whole story from the beginning.  It felt cheap.Plus Tobias's mother just doing a 180 and saying OK, I'll end this revolt because my son gave me an ultimatum.  She was an extremist that wholeheartedly believed she was doing the right thing!  She even cut her son out of meetings and plans because she couldn't trust him or didn't think he was on board one hundred percent.And lets not overlook the fact that the memory wipe they did at the bureau would only effect that city.  You're not starting from the top down.  Only that city would be better for the "GD's" until the government came in and got them back on track.  That story may have had time to work out if it wasn't rushed and smashed into the last book.  It took two books overthrow the faction system in the city.I think there could have been a much better scenario for the "beyond the fence" world.  And the knife twist at the end?  Peter (who is a terrible and evil person) wanted to have his memories taken and then started showing the same symptoms as before.  No way!  Peter was narcissistic and selfish but he got to live????  I don't really believe he would want redemption by wiping his memories at that point.I am severely disappointed with the last book, I hope if the movies are successful that the third one gets a serious re-write!

reviewText: I normally don't add reviews for books. but after seeing the average, even poor reviews, I needed to comment.  The final book in this series ebbs and flows around the story of injustice and war. Veronica Roth has the ability to have you see both sides of war and it's injustices, show  you how each side can defend it's beliefs, and make you understand that in the end,  everyone loses.  I cried for at least an hour AFTER I finished the book, and to be truthful, I am crying while I'm writing this review.I believe that the reason why this book has so many average reviews is that those people felt as upset and empty as I did after finishing the book...but that is what LIFE is about - love, loss, and the daily decision to be the person you want to be - and sometimes you have to fight for what you believe in.Veronica Roth - thank you for telling this story.

If the first movie does well, I can't imagine them making a trilogy movie with this storyline.  The movie editors will severely change it.I will attempt to provide no spoilers in this review in case you decide to go ahead and read/purchase this third book, but in my opinion you would be better off enjoying the first two books and avoid this one.StyleThis one is written from the 2 main characters perspective.  While this is a different style from the first two, it does not work for this series, which has been told from a teenage girl perspective. So who lives/dies/succeeds is all part of the story.  The real issue with the ending is that it ends.  Done, drop...  Another paragraph or 2 would have helped.Content:I was disappoint in Ms. Roth extra content in the story.  She introduces a Homosexual couple.  Just a paragraph or two, just to say she has one in her story.  Why?  Those lines have nothing to do except she wanted to put this in a YA bookAs to foul language, is significant in this YA book compared to the other 2.  I assume she just wanted to add this as well.My suggestion:  Abstain from this book.  Let Ms. Roth know that her 2 first stories were enjoyable, but writing this kind a novel is poor judgment.

For an author to make me feel that strongly about something is a gift.  I don't mind the sad ending.  What happened is gritty and real.  Life is hard and we make choices on how we deal with it.  Kudos to the author for not conforming to some sappy love ending with both people suddenly whole and life is rosy perfect.  I like the reality presented in the ending even though it was horribly sad.The reason for four stars:  We lose Four's voice here.  In the first two books he is a magnetic personality; strong, protective, intelligent.  When we switch to Tobias we find the deep scarring and he comes across almost pathetic in his indecision at times.  That was inconsistent with the Four/Tobias from the first two novels.  I agree with other reviewers that his voice/Tris's voice sound so similar in this book that switching from one to the other gets confusing.  Four/Tobias's voice would have been better if the Four of the first two books could have carried through.  I understand he is hurt and struggling...but this book made him seem weak.  I kept getting impatient with his character and want the boy back who fights for himself and those he cares for.Best advice...read the first two books and then read Allegiant.  You will see a well written story from beginning to end.  Loved it.

reviewText: *Spoilers contained*I got on board the Divergent train (get it?) a bit late, but I was excited because this meant I didn't have to wait long for the last installment of the trilogy, which I pre-ordered. Though not always a fan of Tris, in the first two books, I though Veronica Roth (VR) did a good job of creating a believable dystopian society and that she raised excellent questions regarding the nature of man and what kind of solutions might exist. I recommended the series to all my fellow readers. As I got into the third book, I wondered exactly how VR could possibly wrap everything up in just one last book. The expansion that occurred could have paved the way for a much longer exploration, but I was happy to think that at least Tris and Four would get their closure (and myself by extension)- and boy did they! Now, I'm not saying there must be unrealistic happily-ever-afters in dystopian settings, and I didn't expect this given the number of characters that were killed off in the first two installments. However, I DO expect in a YOUNG ADULT trilogy that if a couple's relationship is a main thrust of the story, they will at least get some kind of "together forever" as in the Hunger Games finale.I was so blindsided by Tris' end that I skimmed over the final 10% of the book still thinking she would have to come back somehow! Again, not my cup of tea, but if an author wants to do a stand-alone book with a tragic end for the lovers, I'm okay with that; but, to drag out the story for three books and THEN kill the protagonist (after conveniently inserting a second POV to facilitate this narrative) is completely ridiculous! I agree with the reviewer who stated the author broke the cardinal rule of romance (though I would insert YA trilogy as a more accurate category) as well as the trust of the reader. The fact that VR managed to get a movie deal BEFORE completing a trilogy is quite the accomplishment, but I for one, now have zero desire to relive the experiences of a girl who will soon be dead. What's the point? I have a feeling most audiences will agree and I will be surprised if the other books end up on the big screen. VR has lost me as reader. I will never again trust her to provide my fictional escape where I expect an outcome that is different from real life! Additionally, I found it ludicrous that the competent, well-respected Four is basically emasculated and becomes incapable of making a sound decision for a good portion of the book. What?!?!  And he is the one who lives?? Oh yes, along with a great majority of other secondary and/or non-admirable characters about whom I don't give a damn. The trilogy has gone from being my recommendation of choice to a never-to-be-revisited waste of time that I will be sure to decry at every opportunity.

MAJOR SPOILERS BELOW********************I'm going to attempt to be coherent here, but no guarantees.  I read this book straight through last night, staying up until well past midnight reading/crying.  I am so, so proud of how Veronica Roth decided to end it.  I think that killing off the main character is the bravest thing an author can do.  It takes guts to kill of a character who has been born and grown in your mind through such an eventful series, and tears aside (and there were MANY TEARS SHED), I'm kind of glad she did it.  This story needed to have an emotionally BIG ending, and it didn't disappoint.Other thoughts: you really couldn't have predicted most of the events of this book.  The beginning did seem to drag a lot in its lengthy information dump, and it was often confusing which side was what and why they did what they did.  The point was that everyone was morally complex and ambiguous, and I get that, but introducing a new big bad and making it so confusing got overwhelming easily.  I think that says more about me as a person than the book itself, as I think we humans are not very well conditioned to accept complexity.I'm so happy with the way Four's story was resolved.  I knew someone was going to die, and I hoped it wasn't him, and I'm really selfishly happy that, for once, the character with the tragic backstory doesn't have a tragic ending.  It's empowering to read a book where an abuse survivor is a main character and he comes out alright.  That means the world to me.  I am also extremely satisfied with the way Tris and Four's relationship exists in the story.  Unlike a lot of book couples, there was no overblown love triangle, and while there were certainly heightened emotions, there were a lot of meaningful discussions.  When a problem came up, either Tris or Four would pull their partner aside and mention that they should talk and proceeded to do so.  Talk about setting a great example for a healthy relationship, especially where one character has tendencies toward unhealthy relationships.  Again, extremely satisfying to see in a work of popular fiction.I honestly think this was the perfect ending to the series, but as it is with subjective opinions towards books, YMMV.  We may have lost a dear character, but as Veronica Roth has stated, this wasn't something she relished doing.  This was something that had to be done for the greater story, and that is something to be respected.This has been a good year for powerful, meaningful young adult novels.Thanks, Veronica Roth.

I feel like most of the "terrible" reviews are from people who didn't like the ending. I get that, but it was a realistic choice, and actually I applaud Veronica Roth because I am sure she knew there would be backlash. I actually liked the ending.Here's the thing, if you have read the first two book in the series, you SHOULD read the last one, and if you are thinking about starting the trilogy, you absolutely should because Divergent in particular is one of the best YA novels out there.The problem for me in this last book is that you are introduced to a world outside the city and it's never really clear what's going on with it. This is where a trilogy like Hunger Games really shines because Collins does a wonderful job introducing you to the world outside of district 12 along with Katniss.  I *think* this was Roth's intention but it didn't work at all for me (maybe because it's essentially crammed into one book that already has a lot else going on).  I still am fairly confused about what happened to the US re: genetic modifications and how the country is set up (is there a centralized government? Is it mostly genetically damaged people in all the cities? I'm just confused - could be because I was reading it at 2 AM).For a story that seemed so carefully planned out in the first two book, Allegiant seemed a little ad hoc at times. Tris's mom was able to just be dropped into Dauntless at age 15 and no one questioned where she came from? There was an effort to remove the divergent population but Tris's mom never thinks to remove her own daughter? Evelyn and Marcus just kind of come to an agreement? The diver gents are so important to the scientists and they just let the slaughter occur when they could have intervened with serum the whole time?  I would have preferred Roth to expand to a 4th book if she couldn't do the story justice in 3.
