reviewText: I literally JUST finished Allegiant and had to head out to see what others were saying about it. I was completely shocked to see all the negative reviews. Most of them I have to believe are provoked by the way it all ends, and I have to completely disagree with them. Tris' final decision makes perfect sense to me, given who she was written to be at her very core.SPOILERS AHEADFrom the way Insurgent ended, I knew we were in for a wild ride once Allegiant was in our hands, but I certainly didn't see the true nature of the dystopian world coming the way it did. Genetic manipulation and the chaos it caused leading the US Government to make some radical choices, allowing the pursuit of science and perfection to turn them into god. When that failed, their answer was to start all over by resetting the entire city's memories. Someone has to stop them. And of course Tris, our ever selfless heroine, does just that.Tobias, Christina, Marcus, Uriah, and the rest of the Allegiant cast journey though the discovery of the true reality of who they are and why the Factions and their city of Chicago are so important to those outside the fence. But it's the bitter reality of finding out his, and others, genetic makeup isn't perfect enough for the government that brings division and confusion to Tobias, even among his friends. Thankfully, this group is strong enough to believe in themselves, in who they are as people, without allowing those who think otherwise to divide them completely. At least not for long.Tris and Tobias continue to struggle through their relationship and they both make painful decisions but they are finally able to come to the understanding that life does that to couples. Just like in reality, they realize that holding a grudge against someone you love isn't the right answer. Life is painful, and the only way to survive the pain is to agree to give forgiveness before it's even required. And there is a lot to forgive in Allegiant.Tobias' poor choice leads to the eventual death of a friend, and Tris' wise decision leads to the ultimate sacrifice. Something all us readers should have seen coming. Painful and heart wrenching as it was to read, every character held true to who they were written to be. Having the book written between Tobias and Tris' point of views truly only made sense in the end, but that's where the real power in this book comes through. Dealing with the loss of war, rebellion, and the death of those who believe in the cause enough to give their lives for it takes the last chapters of this whole trilogy to a new level. Tobias' character is pushed to the limit, and we get front row seats as he shows us the real strength it takes to move past the loss of someone you love, and the courage it takes to allow those who've hurt you the most the opportunity to make things right.I do agree with those who are comparing this final book in the Divergent Series to Mockingjay of the Hunger Games Trilogy, in that, despite the tragic ending and saying good-bye to several beloved and vital characters, Allegiant, though horribly painful to finish, left me feeling much more satisfied and convinced that those who were left will indeed succeed. It was a brilliant end to the story of Beatrice Prior, and a fresh beginning for everyone who survived.It will be a long time before I can emotionally handle re-reading this series, but it will forever be one of my favorite book series to date.Thank you, Ms. Roth. You've not only written an amazing trilogy, but you've given us a lot to ponder. And THAT is the mark of a brilliant dystopian series.
summary: Powerful and Thought Provoking to the End

Well it came and it went and I still don't even know how I feel about this book.The Positives: We finally learned the whole reason behind the factions and who was outside Chicago and it was a completely thorough explanation that was satisfying, while also being a commentary on today's society. The book was extremely fast-paced with no lagging and overly drawn out internal monologues that have lately been overtaking the third books in YA series. There were no crazy last minute introductions of new characters that utterly destroyed the flow (sure there were new characters, but no one that really mattered or that we were suppose to get emotionally invested in)The Negatives: Was it just me or was the writing really easy, like juvenile fiction easy? There was nothing complex about it, just straightforward writing. Also, while I appreciated the dual points of view, I often found myself forgetting who I was reading from because Tris and Tobias had the same voice! There was no differentiation between the two, which is unacceptable. Take a note from Marie Lu if you want a perfect way to write a book from dual p.o.v.The ending: I'm mixed about this end. On one hand I understand why Roth did it, not romanticizing war, but also being brave herself as a writer to do something that would make over half of her fans cry foul and turn on her faster then Marcus Eaton would on..well..anyone. However, the fan girl in me says she only did it for shock value to get people talking about it and keeping the sales up. BUT, the first movie is already set for March with a fantastic cast so keeping the series relevant is not needed. Why not give the fans what they want?? I really don't think it would have taken anything away from the overall story or emotional journey she took us on with these characters. She already created the friction between Tris and Tobias with Tobias joining Nita and her crazy plan so the ending just seemed like more crap to get through.Obviously read this if you have invested time in the other two, but with the addition of this third book, the series as a whole just went downhill for me much like Matched and Delirium. If Legend and Shatter Me do the same, I'm going have some serious problems with YA lit.

A group of people including Tobias and Tris leave to go outside of the fence to find out what is outside and that is where the fun begins. They find out some huge things about their lives and it is hard for them to handle it.Tris and Tobias go through a lot of issues in their relationship as well, due some of the things that they find out. The thing that I didn't really care for was that every time Tobias and Tris gets together it's a make out session for them. There doesn't seem to be a time where they aren't kissing and I don't know, it just didn't belong in it to me. I know that they are together and that's what couples do but I'm not sure, it could have been without about a half of the times and it would have been better.Caleb gets rescued by Tobias on account of Tris not wanting him to die and the turmoil that Tris and Caleb go through is kind of heartbreaking. In fact, some of it had me in tears because you don't really know what Caleb was thinking while he was doing all of the stuff he did before and you can tell that he regrets it. reviewText: I just finished this book and I literally threw it across the room when completed. The whole book I was groaning at the lack of ANYTHING in this book!SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS******I CAN'T BELIEVE SHE KILLED THE MAIN CHARACTER! BAD AUTHOR!! BAD! SHAME ON YOU!!Seriously? Would have preferred an unfinished series, than the bitter taste this book left in my mouth.

I'm going to begin my review by saying that I loved Allegiant, not for its perfection, but for it's ability to make me think.  I dislike reviews that contain spoilers, so this one will not.  What I will say is that those of you loved Divergent and Insurgent should not expect Allegiant to be a carbon copy but rather more of a revelation.  If the reader dislikes science or the study of human behavior, or was waiting for nothing more than the culmination of a romance, you'll certainly find fault here.Chapters are divided between Tris' perspective and Tobias'.  I do agree with a previous reviewer that at times it became confusing, but that aside I think it was vital for Ms. Roth to write the book in this manner.  Allegiant is about many things -- strength, weakness, failings, character development, science vs human nature, and the survival or destruction of a society.  Nowhere can this be better understood than being inside the minds of Tris and Tobias, watching their growth, their failures, and their resurgence.  And that could only happen by giving them their own chapters, especially as they saw the unfolding world with sometimes different perspectives.  Separating characters by chapters must be a hard thing to do, but I think this author did a more than passable job. It was only my struggle to keep the chapters straight between Tris and Tobias that kept me from giving Allegiant a rating of 5 stars.I'm told there are rabid Divergent fans out there now who are completely tearing Allegiant apart shades of Kathy Bates character in Misery because they disagree with one particular turn of the story or are unhappy with the ending.  Anyone who truly understands the process of writing knows that characters belong to the author.  They spring from the author, from his or her imagination, from the heart.  Authors are filled with emotion for and commitment to their characters.  They feel every heartache, every wound, every mistake.  The characters in this trilogy were rich and memorable.  Dystopian novels are not meant to end on a particularly happy note.  In fact, the word "dystopia" means "a community or society, usually fictional, that is in some important way undesirable or frightening."  (Wikipedia)  If readers begin a book like this wearing rose colored glasses, they're bound to be unhappy.  There may be other genres more their liking.I found everything about the ending to be right and meaningful.  It ended as it should have, the characters occupying the spaces where they needed to be, where they were destined to be.  Ms. Roth brought the story full circle, answered a myriad of questions, and while it was a very heavy read because of the subject matter, for me it was extremely satisfying because it kept me on my toes.  I love this trilogy, and I was never disappointed, from the first page of Divergent to the last page of Allegiant.  A huge thank you to Veronica Roth for a wonderful experience.  It was quite a ride!
summary: Allegiant Is Worthy Of Much Better Reviews

reviewText: Loved the book.  It was hard to put down.  There are so many characters in the trilogy that I had difficulty remembering back to the first book and how everyone originally fit in to the story.  So I went back and read them all over again. I admit I went into "Allegiant" with a negative bias against it. "Divergent" and "Insurgent" were good--but they aren't my favorite books ever. Probably not even in the Top 25. That being said, I did want to finish the series and see how things would all work out, because many aspects of the first two books were very intriguing, especially the (obvious) revelation at the end of the second book.We start "Allegiant" with no sense of where we are. How long has it been since the end of Book 2? Pssh. Who knows? It's never stated. All we know is summer is ending. That no sense of time continues throughout the entire book. At one point we are told "it has been a few weeks" since an attack that occurs over halfway through the book, but it feels like four days, maximum. Later we are told there will be an attack in "48 hours time," but I counted three days. Then we blast ahead 2.5 years and things are all out of whack.Next, the entire book beats us over the head with this "be brave" message. Over. And over. And over. And over. About sacrificing yourself for the greater good and blah blah blah. And it wasn't implicitly suggested at all, like a good book would've accomplished--no, we are TOLD, multiple times, about bravery. It wasn't a theme, it was literally written word-for-word every few pages. Imagine someone slapping you over the head yelling, "BRAVERY IS SELF-SACRIFICE!!!" That's what this felt like, and that's what was literally said at some parts.Next comes the contrived scenes. You know, when things go EXACTLY ACCORDING TO PLAN? Yeah, that didn't just happen once, or twice...it happened throughout the entire book. And these weren't intricate, complicated plans. These were slashing tires and the guys driving the trucks don't even care. Like, seriously. I nearly put the book down when the driver basically said, "Bummer. Oh well!" Yeah.For the last part of my review, I'm going to focus on the dual-perspective between Tris and Tobias. IT DIDN'T WORK. Take everything you know about Tobias and throw it out the window. His personality COMPLETELY changes. He and Tris were VERY annoying. He literally describes EVERY. LITTLE. DETAIL. I'm not saying that people don't do that. I'm not saying he shouldn't. But those moments when he would take two whole paragraphs to describe the expression on someone's face? Yeah, completely unnecessary and boring. Tris was Tris. Together they were self-righteous, full of themselves, thinking they're the best things to ever happen in the world. And based on interviews, I feel like Veronica Roth feels that way about these books, too. She's not a humble author by any means, and that clearly leaked into this book.To wrap things up, "Allegiant" made me angry. It did. There was NO climax. Seriously, it DID NOT EXIST. This was the DIVIDE BY ZERO ERROR of books. I got to page 500 thinking, "If the bullets don't start flying in the next paragraph, then this book was a complete waste of time." And guess what? The bullets never flew.If you expected an action-packed thriller like "Divergent" and "Insurgent," you will be disappointed. Nothing big happens. No great power struggle. A let down of a finale. An insult to a decent series.
summary: Arrogant, Flawed, and an Insult to the Trilogy

reviewText: When it came to the first two books in the series, I couldn't put them down, but almost from the start of this book, I questioned whether I'd be able to get myself to finish it. Roth breaks with her previous narration through Tris' eyes and goes back and forth between Tris and Four's view point. She also seems to back down from the action and suspense he the previous books had. As the story moves along and the explanation for their city and the world outside it unravel, it seems neither shocking nor all that interesting. I began to wonder if maybe the secrets to the city were better off left unexplained. The plot becomes very predictable and the deaths of familiar characters seem to be an attempt to add some unexpectedness to the book, but instead come off as needless and don't really move the plot along. Even the once captivating and explosive relationship between Tris and Four become stale and boring. Though I made it through to the end, I felt no satisfaction or sense of closure from it and wish that I, and Roth, had stopped with book two.

Roth defines life outside the gates of Chicago with "Allegiant." Wanting the factions back, Tris's friends form the "Allegiant" to go up against the factionless and Evelyn. A handful of loyal supporters are picked to venture past the gates and find out what's outside, but are the answers what the allegiant hope they will be?Tris, Tobias, and their friends go past the gates and discover a community of geneticists living in the old remains of O'Hare Airport. There they come to understand the purity war and the important of having pure genes. It's one shock after another as Tris and Tobias realize the extent of lies and manipulation regarding the inner city where they grew up. Can they save the community from a memory erase or will the lies in the name of genetics continue?Roth's writing is easy to read, however the book's narrative is told switching between Tris and Tobias. Unfortunately, Tobias' character voice sounds an awful lot like Tris, leaving the reader uncertain at times as to whose point of view the story is being told from. I often found myself double-checking the chapter heading to see which character was narrating.The plot moves well and there's plenty of twists and turns. The characters are achingly human in this haunting dystopian society. Tobias possesses inner strength, but is tormented by the violence he's encountered. Tris is strong-willed, yet vulnerable when it comes to Four.Allegiant offers explanations that helps Tris to understand her world. The best part of the novel is the ending - in the aftermath of war, we all still have to pick up the pieces and live. Allegiant is a satisfactory ending to the series and will resonate with readers long after they've put the book down.
This book wrapped up the story well. It makes you think and feel. Moral of the story is that life isn't always easy, but we get through it together.
This book was so awesome. It was very sad at parts and extra sad in the end. The middle was a bot slow but still, it was a very good book.

Series is similar to hunger games and a fast read. The first book was lengthy and wordy but great! the second book was ok, but this last book was a major disappointment. Horrible ending to the series.  I agree with other reviewers--read the first two then make up your own ending. Because the ending Roth wrote will leave you feeling angry and frustrated with the time you spent falling in love with the characters in books 1&2.Spoilers!!!!!!After reading the first two books in a matter of days I couldn't wait to finally discover what was outside the fence. I was immediately  irritated by the way the third book was written. It was difficult to keep track of which characters point if view you were reading. At first I thought it was just me since I was quickly losing interest in the story line and characters. However, it's seems I am not alone. For two characters that had such spunk and determination they both ended up sounding like angsty, emotional teens! Tobias was a stong and courageous DAUNTLESS leader for crying out loud! In this book he sounds like a little girl! Very disappointing!Also very let down on how the author chose to wrap up the series. Tris dying served no point whatsoever. She magically is able to mentally over power the death serum that no one else is able to overcome only to be shot! Give me a break! Then to have her mom show up in ghost form and say its okary to let go and everyone will keep surviving. Please...how lame. The same girl that defied odds time and time again only to be shot dead is just pointless. The same ending could have occurred if tris lived. It's not like the characters outrage over her murder spurred them to make change. The Chicago expirment could have made the deal with the government and everyone could have continued on.Also frustrating was the whole genetic mutation story line. Was talking about the fringe really necessary? It just seemed like the author started a million other story lines to disguise the fact that her ending made no sense whatsoever. The characters could have actually thought out a more logical way to use the serum and the government could have used the serum to stop everything from happening in the first place! Instead of supplying Jeanine with the simulation serum why not just erase everyone's memory of the knowledge they wanted kept secret. And! If the divergent didnt need to help save the outside world why was that movie even made?! If the first prior knew they didn't need to save the outside world, because she came from outside the experiment, why did she make the clip in the first place?! The whole story was just frustrating and a major let down.Ending a series can't be easy, but it just seems like the author did not put any thought into this. THere were so many loop holes and the characters did not stay true to themselves.

I wanted to love this. I really really did. I had to take a break between the first and second books because my jaw was sore from being wide with shock. I knew as soon as I started this one it was going to be hard to get through.. I HATED the style it was written in.. What with going back and forth between Tris and Tobias. I don't mind when stories are told that way, but when you have become accustomed to a certain style throughout the first two it's kind of annoying. And THEN... HUGE SPOILER, AVERT YOUR EYES IF YOU HAVE NOT ALREADY READ THIS... The author freaking kills off Tris?!? WHAT?? I just can't even.. Nope. Such a disappointment to become so attached to a series to have the last one just stomp on your soul. Sigh.

What is there to say? This book would be best used to prop of a crooked table or a couch that's missing a leg -- but not for reading. It's awful and I'm not talking about the ending that everyone hated (all though, that's bad enough as well). Roth wrote the first book really well, the second started to slip in writing level, and this one is terrible. I don't think an editor even looked at it. The worst offence is that Tris and Four's POV sound the exact same. That's poor writing. It doesn't get worst than this.
Such an amazing book series, one of my favorites, and I'm sad it's over and this book broke my heart in all the right ways.
summary: A good read, heart breaking, but good.

reviewText: Allegiant by Veronica Roth is probably the last book in the Divergent series (on her website, Roth says that in her mind, this was always supposed to be a trilogy). The first thing I have to say about this book is that it was written in a different perspective than its predecessors. Divergent and Insurgent were written solely from Beatrice’s perspective making them easy to follow.However, Allegiant was written by alternating between Beatrice and Four’s perspectives. While reading, I found this very hard to follow at first as I was used to reading only from one perspective. But to be honest, once I got used to it, I enjoyed seeing the events from another perspective, allowing us to get to know another character as well as we came to know Beatrice.With books, I believe that the ending really can make or break its success. The ending of this novel is what affected me the most. It brought me to tears, and couldn't have been written any better! It wrapped up the trilogy beautifully and gave readers something to think about.Overall, I believe that Allegiant is my favourite book in the trilogy! This is because I loved learning more about the factions and how they came to be as well as learning about life on “the other side of the fence”.This trilogy as a whole is a must read.

OK that feeling of crushing disappointment, anyone recognise it? ANYONE tell me I'm not the only one PLEASE.What a disappointing end. *sigh* *double sigh* I feel like I emotionally invested myself so much and the book was so disappointing.I feel so distressed and quite confused. It honestly felt like a different author had written this book, only this author was hell bent on including so many plot holes and tearing apart the faction world that had been created. As soon as we moved away from the world of factions and the story is moved outside the city, the book quite frankly fell apart. I am very sorry but I think it is impossible for me to review this book without being a tad spoilery. If you haven't read the book and don't want spoilers, look away now and please excuse me whilst I have a little rant.In terms of characters, Tobias was the most frustrating and difficult to sympathise with. It's like he has had a complete character change out of nowhere. He is no longer able to process situations logically, gone is the intelligent instructor who is able to calculate his decisions and movements logically. Instead we are placed with a Tobias who doesn't take in the facts and make rational decisions. Seriously, this character change is ridiculously frustrating and honestly it doesn't make sense to me. It doesn't contribute anything to the plot but instead created unnecessary complications. On the bright side, Tris kicked butt in this book and she was still a really good heroine.Was I the only one getting slightly confused as I was reading? A lot of the time it was getting really complicated for no reason. I could've seen the book written in a way that had an interesting plot line but wasn't written in a complicated way. Sometimes it is possible for a book to be interesting and amazing without it being confusing and having so many gimmicks in order to interest us. One confusion was the fact that the book was split between Tris and Tobias' point of view, yet they were written in EXACTLY THE SAME WAY. I'd find myself re-reading chapters because I got confused in whose point of view I was reading. Another thing that really confused me was the fact that the characters in this book only suddenly thought about what was going on beyond the boundaries of the city of Chicago. So I am supposed to believe that this whole time they have been living in this faction world they haven't wondered what lay beyond the boundaries? Not even once?
summary: Disappointing end to one of my favourite trilogies.

reviewText: Do no continue with this series. Imagine your own ending. Anything you think of will be 1000000000x's better than Allegiant. I promise you. Save yourself a torturous read and then heartbreak.The heartbreak for a series you had such high hopes for and then this amateur author ruins it. Absolutely ruins it. Her style of writing  for this was so confusing, the whole dual perspective- great idea! We, as readers can finally see into the mind of Four/Tobias.The strong and tough Dauntless hottie.How about the little girl who whines the entire novel?We get to meet that Tobias.WHERE DID THAT GUY COME FROM?And half the time while you were suffering through the terrible writing you would have to flip back to the beginning of the chapter just to figure out who was talking.. because there was very little difference between Tris and Tobias. You couldn't tell who you were reading. I am ripping Ms. Roth apart because she failed as an author. She failed terribly.Her writing was confusing, the plot was non existent and her explanation of everything was just absolutely confusing. We are smart humans and her explanation was not up to par. If you should read this you will find the holes I am talking about and realize that Veronica Roth just ruined a series ending.I am excited for the movie. But if Veronica Roth has any say in it... i suspect it to be just as terrible as Allegiant.Please, do not bother purchasing this last book. Imagine your own ending. Because it will be better than what Veronica Roth vomited out.

Tris and Tobias (Four) find out what is beyond the wall when the Allegiant faction go to find out if Edith Prior's message is correct.  The Allegiant split into 2 groups, one to stay and fight the new factionless army and the other to find out what is beyond that wall and if they can help stop the violence in the city. What they find seems great until the truth is revealed.Despite what a lot of people have said about the end. I must say it was ok. I loved the book. Yes it was sad however, I don't think a book always has to have a happy ending and I also think that Veronica Roth has done a great job with the book. Look at the passion it has created from it's readers. Whether it be outrage or enjoyment, she has achieved what I think a lot of authors strive to achieve and that is making the readers 'feel' the book and it's characters. Let's face it, I get upset with movies and books when they don't end how I want them to. Doesn't mean I didn't enjoy it, just means it has made me passionate about it and stirred up my emotions towards it.

Most of the negative reviews are here for a reason. This book will leave you feeling empty, hopeless, discouraged and with a feeling of despair. I would give anything if there were a way to just erase it from my mind, permanently. This book leads the reader to a place that is devoid of all hope, to some senseless end with absolutely no closure to it.There is only one single thing that is "good" about this book: When you go camping, it makes for decent toilet paper, and kindling for your campfire.This final installment was an EPIC failure in terms of writing. The poor publishing company probably had a difficult time finding the courage to send it to print, since they could not understand the author's concept of "courage" which just faded into oblivion. This last book is at best depressing, makes no sense, has no continuity to the previous books, has more holes in the plot than swiss cheese, it's confusing, it's pointless, it's illogical, incorrect on many simple levels, it's senseless, and the only things you think to yourself while reading it are "huh?, what?, why? I don't get it?, and holy moly, did she ACTUALLY just kill off her own main character in a way that is completely out of character with the character?" (Tris decides to commit suicide after what seemed like just a few days after her big fat revelation that "SHE WANTS TO LIVE LIFE!" ). I had to really force myself to get the the last page of this book. So, I had to just push myself through the last several chapters waiting for some kind of closure that had any significance. But it never happened.And how on earth did Four ever become such a pansy in this third book??????I felt really really traumatized by the whole ordeal of reading this. I seriously felt horrible, depressed and in shock for days. Everyone I have spoken to who read this book stated to me that they felt the exact same way. But, if that's your thing, then by all means, read this piece of dung.I think Veronica Roth is not very bright. It's as if she dug herself a 50 foot hole in the ground, jumped into it, and asked her readers and movie watchers to bury her. She has ruined her own career. I will never see any further "Divergent" movies, or read any other books from this author. Shame on you Veronica Roth, for writing Divergent in the first place only to seduce the audience into reading this pathetic excuse for a "book". I would not call this literature, I would just call it toilet paper.
summary: I wish I could un-read this book...

reviewText: I was lost in this story. Book one was amazing. Then book two, now ending with a good closure, however I cried slot for the ending.I'm a sucker for happy ending.  This was not how I wanted it to end, but nether the this, turned out good like real life.I'm left feeling sad.These books gets you lost in the excitement and thrill.I highly recommend

I was extremely disappointed by the author's choice of ending.  The investment the reader and the author had in the main character of Tris is enormous.  How could she write her out so unceremoniously?  She came back after every incident throughout 3 books. I kept expecting it again right up to the last page!!! That was unforgiveable in my opinion.

I finished the book about a week ago so I am not jumping into this review without thought.This book missed the mark for me. I didn't hate it, but I also didn't love it like I loved the other two. The new characters weren't built on; they were just added for the purpose of the conclusion. None of the new characters play a huge part and none of them make me like this book more. We lose the old scenery of the Divergent/Insurgent stories and are brought into the world of (psychotic) normalcy. The community we knew is gone and now the characters are in a government building full of U.S. government people. It was just... boring. I missed all the characters that died in Insurgent and I missed the factions! Veronica Roth did not make up for those losses with anything worthy of them in this last installment.*Spoilers - but won't give too much away:The only thing I can honestly say I liked about the book was Tris and Tobias's connection growing. I loved Tris's realization about their relationship.I feel like Veronica Roth planned to take her series one direction and then when it came down to writing the last book she changed it. I feel this way because what Edith Prior says at the end of Insurgent is not true; which is strange. Why would Edith Prior or the Bureau leave a message at all, why not just go in a release everyone once there are more divergents in the population. This and many other things are odd about this last book.To me a good book is one that I want to read again and again. This books ending left me depressed and I honestly don't know if I'll ever read the series again. Before this final book came out I probably read the first two (Divergent and Insurgent) two times waiting for the last one to hit the market. Now I don't think I could read any of the books without knowing the depressing future of the characters. I get killing off characters (HP reference: I mean when Fred died I was devastated but it added to my attachment to the books, you don't see JK Rowling killing off the entire Wesley family! That would be outrageous!! Same with Hunger Games... even that brutal series didn't kill off everyone) but there is a limit to how much an audience can take.
Not the ending I would have chosen but a good series overall. Very thought provoking and mature. Lots of life lessons.

I read the reviews before I bought all three books. I was hesitant after reading the reviews but I have to say I completely disagree with all the negative comments. I loved this book and found the ending to be appropriate with the rest of the series. Not sure why so many people feel this book fell short, it didn't at all. I won't go into too much detail to give spoilers but I highly recommend this book as well as the trilogy.
I wish it would have never ended, I loved the series. One of my favorite reading experience of all time.

To start with, I was reading Tolstoy's War and Peace as well as The Great Gatsby concurrently with Allegiant. So Allegiant probably didn't have a great chance, although that isn't the case with all Y.A. literature. Roth has a good story idea but its execution was dissatisfying. Of course, I recommend it to anyone who read the first two books in the series; you've got to have this third novel for completion.I read the first two books (Divergent and Insurgent) and enjoyed them more than this one. I found the ultra-simple language downright annoying, almost condescending, but every so often Roth would have some insight into characters that was much more perceptive and nuanced.The ending was OK -- I can see that many fans will have huge issues with it and rate the book based on the plot's outcome -- but I read this book very quickly, more to get through it and get back to my real reading than anything else. As for the ending, it might be the best part about the book -- there are some themes that show depth only hinted at in the rest of the book.I feel bad about disliking this book so much, because I liked the first two and want to be supportive of this author. But it's hard for a book like this not to be an annoying gnat in the shadow of Tolstoy and Fitzgerald. I did take into account the genre and expected audience, which is why I gave it three stars; it's a quick read, but sort of like watching General Hospital right after The Cain Mutiny.
summary: Read it if you read the other two

reviewText: I was surprised by the ending, but pleased that it was more realistic than the happily ever after.  All three books were a good read.

SPOILERS – LOTS AND LOTS OF SPOILERS‘Allegiant‘ was so incredibly bad, and the ending was the least of it.A lot of the things I had problems with have already been mentioned in other reviews, but I have to put my own spin on things.First, what the heck was going on with Four and Tris? Did they have a ‘Freaky Friday’ moment and switch personalities, because seriously, Four was a whiny little girl. There were several times where I just wanted to yell at him to change back to the character I knew in ‘Divergent’ and ‘Insurgent‘. If this was supposed to be character development, well, it didn’t work. And Tris went to being one of the most selfish, self-serving characters I’ve read in some time. I know I was supposed to believe she was selfless, but I didn’t. Sorry. But not really.And the deaths?  I know its war time, but I seriously think the author was in a bad mood when she wrote those scenes because she killed almost everyone off, except the villains I noticed. Seriously, bad people do die in war too. They don’t get to take memory serums and live out their lives as if nothing ever happened. That part was just insanely bad.Okay, so another thing was the duo voices. And this is part of the reason why I don’t think it was edited very much and if it was, it wasn’t done very well. Tris and Four’s voices were identical. In fact, if it hadn’t been for the character saying ‘Tris’ or ‘Tobias’ I would have had to check to see whose chapter it was. And, as together as they were in the first two books, they were apart in this one.In ‘Allegiant‘,  Tris and Tobias’s relationship seemed almost forced. There wasn’t the same connection. I know they kissed a lot, but they never seemed to talk to each other the same. There were scenes where there were serious issues between them and instead of talking it out, they spoke for five seconds and then made out.Then there was the info-dumping and the introduction of genetics. That introduced a whole new lot of problems for me. I was so disappointed that all the fantastic adventure and fun I had with the other two books came down to ‘damaged’ genetics. That’s what it all boiled down to? That some people didn’t have perfect genes and didn’t think or act in the same ways as those who did, therefore they had to be confined in some kind of massive mental hospital, which just happened to be the city of Chicago? Isolated, watched and experimented on in the hopes they become ‘better.’ Yeah.I know a lot of people have mentioned the ending over and over again. And I have to agree with them. I didn’t mind Tris dying, but it was the senseless, unrealistic way it was done. I know that I was supposed to get into the reasoning behind her decision to die, but all I felt was that Tris had a self-serving Martyr complex about her.The sad reality is I didn’t get emotionally invested in Tris’s death at all. It didn’t mean a single thing to me, because the way it was done was butchered. It was so unrealistic that I could have cried. She survived the death serum and then got shot? The same character who had survived several attacks on the compound? I would have believed in her death more, if she were killed in enemy crossfire.As for the mission they had getting into the building. I didn’t buy that either. You’re dealing with a world that can decide what memories you keep or lose, but they didn’t have or couldn’t invent a device that cracks codes or a powerful portable vacuum unit that could suck in and contain all the death serum? And Tris was running about in a war-torn country and she wasn’t carrying a gun? When she had been just chapters before? Too many variables for this death to be even remotely realistic.If you’re going to kill a main character off at least give it a realistic edge.Now don’t misunderstand me. I can appreciate sad endings when they’re done well. ‘The Faults in Our Stars’ by John Green was done well. It was realistic and I could see it happening.  It quickly became one of my favorite books.  ‘Sever’ by Lauren DeStefano was also another book where my favorite character had a sad ending, but that was bittersweet because instead of his ending coming to him surrounded by four walls, he had a chance to live. It made his ending special.All Tris’s death taught me is that a person can go through hell and back and that’s it’s just a waste of time, because the bad person is still going to win anyway. She should have just died with that first initial jump in ‘Divergent’ for all her death meant to me in this book.Another thing that got to me about this book is that parents, ones that love and care about you, would not wish death upon you. The idea that a child would choose to die just because they think it would end up honoring the parent needs psychiatric help. Because that’s about as far from the truth as a person can get. Tris’s parents would have wanted her to live, especially when she had someone to live for.So all I get out of this is that Tris didn’t love Four, because if she had she wouldn’t have done what she had. She had her own agenda – one that instead of being selfless was actually one of the most selfish things I’d ever read. She didn’t give a damn about the people she left behind as long as she got to be the martyr. Everything’s for the greater good after all. It wasn’t like there wasn’t someone else willing to do it, regardless of their reasons, was there? No?  Oh, wait, I believe there was someone else who would have done it.Ha-ha I’m raging and I know it, but seriously there was no point to this character’s death apart from the author writing it that way. Senseless. Pointless. Meaningless. Weak.Anyway, I couldn’t help, but write a little ditty. Inspired by ‘Billy, don’t be a Hero‘ by Paper Lace. It’s a chorus and the ending of that song – only I’ve called it ‘Tris, don’t be a Hero.’  Somehow I thought it was fitting.Tris, don’t be a heroDon’t be a fool with your lifeTris don’t be a heroCome back and make Four the happiest guy (sorry that line a bit of a squash compared to the song)And as Tris started to goFour said, “Keep your pretty head low.”Tris don’t be a heroCome back to me…I heard there was supposed to be a reasonThat explained why Tris died that dayThe author wrote it as if Tris was a heroWe should be proud she died that wayI heard some readers threw the series away…
summary: So many things wrong with this book - SPOILERS

reviewText: This was a disappointing conclusion. The plot seemed jumbled, certain details didn't make sense, and Tris's death was weak. I don't have a problem with her dying, but her death needed to be for a good reason. I feel like it was thrown in there for no other reason than shock factor.

I probably need to say that this review will probably be a jumbled mess. Bear with me please. I don't normally feel the need to state this, but with all of the controversy surrounding this book, I want to make sure you know this review is spoiler free.I’m sure you all have seen tons of press about Allegiant. This was probably the most anticipated book of the year for most people. It definitely was for me. So I’m sure you saw the Allegiant countdown widgets on everyone’s blogs. I’m sure you saw dozens of Waiting on Wednesday posts about this. There was a mishap with some supplier somewhere and some people got copies super early, which means spoilers were leaked. And then release date finally came. Now normally, I go to my local book store and pick up books that I’m highly anticipating so that I can have them on release day, but the last one I bought was almost half price on Amazon compared to my local book store on release day. (Yeah, yeah, Amazon’s the devil. Well not to me. I heart Amazon.) And so this time I preordered Allegiant through Amazon instead of picking it up on release day. This meant that tons of people got their hands on Allegiant a couple of days before me. Enough time for spoilers to begin amassing, comments to begin piling up, and opinions began to be formed.And well, I say all of that to say that I was extremely nervous going in to Allegiant. I’m not normally one of those people who dreads reading the last book in a series just in case it doesn’t go the way I want it to. I’m more of the type that dives in head first because I can’t wait to experience it whether good or bad. But all of the hype and comments had me stressed to the max about this book. Let me be clear, I didn’t read any spoilers, but I did read some where others had read spoilers and based off the spoilers decided not to even pick up the book. All of this buzz and conflict had me a bundle of nerves. (Didn’t help that I was already having some anxiety over some real life things as well.)Ultimately I picked up and finished Allegiant. The beginning was going just fine. I wondered to myself “what are all of these people complaining about?” And then I hit the middle and I started getting frustrated with these characters *clears throat and cuts eyes* (**FOUR!!!!!). I really wanted to pop them him over the head. And I don’t know if it was the negative hype, my personal frustrations with characters making some really dumb decisions especially when those characters are supposed to be smart, or if it was my general anxiety, but during this part of the book, I really just wanted to throw the thing across the room. The ending wasn't the part that frustrated me the most. It was the middle. But nevertheless, I moved passed the frustrating middle business and things got better for me. And then the ending happened. I probably would have been frustrated with it had I not been warned that many people hated it, and therefore I lowered my expectations. But the ending really just wasn’t that big of a deal for me as far as getting angry or upset. It made me sad. I teared up, but I found the ending to be solid and acceptable.Four and Tris start off Allegiant in a rocky kind of place. She lied to him about several things in Insurgent, and so he’s got some trust issues based off that. But they have a talk about how they both need to do a better job being honest with each other, and so things get better. They find themselves on more stable ground.My favorite relationship oriented quotes:“We’re not people who touch each other carelessly; every point of contact between us feels important, a rush of energy and relief.” - Four“I Feel the urge, familiar now, to wrench myself from my body and speak directly into her mind. It is the same urge, I realize, that makes me want to kiss her every time I see her, because even a sliver of distance between us is infuriating.” - FourI was as I mentioned above extremely frustrated with Four at one point. He made a decision that was contradictory to a conversation that he and Tris had. Then he semi-rectifies it and talks about it with her. But he doesn’t listen to her. Turns out she was right. I know that’s a sticky place to be—situated between your own judgment and the judgment of someone else that you highly respect and trust. Truthfully I felt like the Four from Allegiant, and even Insurgent really, wasn’t the same person from Divergent. He felt like a completely different person. His mannerism. His speech. His attitude. His decisions. They all felt like they were coming from two different people. Maybe that was supposed to be the difference between him being Four and him being Tobias (I hate that name by the way). But I would think that Tobias would be a more complete person and Four would be just one side of himself—just the Dauntless side. But that wasn’t the case at all. Maybe the Tobias part is the part that carries the baggage from his past which weighs him down and causes him to question and doubt. Whatever the cause, and not just because of the name, but Four is a much more likable and understandable character than Tobias for me.One of my favorite aspects of Allegiant, and something that I don’t point out in books that I read enough, was the quotable moments that seem more like life lessons. Here are a couple of examples:“I need to deny them the power to control me. I need to know that I am stronger than they are.” – Four, discussing his fears.“And as I stare out at the land, I think that this, if nothing else, is compelling evidence for my parents’ God, that our world is so massive that it is completely out of our control, that we cannot possibly be as large as we feel.” – Tris, which makes me think of Romans 1:20 (NKJV) – “For since the creation of the world His invisible attributes are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even His eternal power and Godhead, so that they are without excuse.”“I feel like what I have become is halfway between my mother and my father, violent and impulsive and desperately afraid. I feel like I have lost control of what I have become.” - Four“So how can I hold Tobias’s desperation against him, like I’m better than him, like I’ve never let my own brokenness blind me?” – Tris, forgiveness—something this world could use a little more of.“I used to think that when people fell in love, they just landed where they landed, and they had no choice in the matter afterward. And maybe that’s true of beginnings, but it’s not true of this, now. I fell in love with him. But I don’t just stay with him by default as if there’s no one else available to me. I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other. I choose him over and over again, and he chooses me.” – Tris, love isn’t just about how someone makes me feel, it’s more, it’s deeper, it’s harder than just that. Yet it is utterly simply at the same time.Other memorable quotes:“I sigh. I may like to run, but I hate climbing stairs.” –Tris, a throwback to the Abnegation days of climbing to the choosing ceremony from the very beginning of Divergent.“There’s no need to giggle...” – Caleb (you need the context to find this funny)“Be brave.” - FourUltimately I think that the Divergent series reminds me a lot of The Hunger Games series not just in concept, but in how I felt about both series as a whole. I LOVED the games. And I LOVED the Dauntless initiation process. But I hated the political part of both of these series. I disliked the whole war idea and taking down the corrupt government. While I do really love the idea of how much one person can make a difference, this side of the series—the war and politics—wasn’t what I fell in love with. I wanted more initiation. I wanted more Dauntless. While I love Tris and Four, I think I would have been happier with the series if we’d followed other characters through their initiation process rather than follow Tris and Four through the rise and fall of multiple corrupt governments. Whereas with The Hunger Games series, I loved both The Hunger Games and Catching Fire because both of these had a the games in them, I didn’t really like Mockingjay as much because it focused on the politics. Unfortunately for the Divergent series, Divergent itself was the only book in the series that focused on the initiation process. And therefore, both Insurgent and Allegiant felt lacking to me. I don’t typically read reviews before I write my own, but I broke my own rule in this case and I can’t think of a better way to describe this than she did. Jen from YA Romantics said in her review of Allegiant on Goodreads that Divergent felt more Dauntless and Allegiant felt more Abnegation. That’s the perfect way of describing these two books.The ending of Allegiant was very Abnegation—true Abnegation. I strongly wish I could discuss this is greater detail with you guys, but I can’t spoil it for anyone who hasn’t read it. I’m surprised I haven’t spoiled anything in this review as it is.Anyway, I think Allegiant gets 4 Stars. It’s still a well written book. It still sparked emotion within me—even if mostly anxiety. Have you read Allegiant? If so, what did you think? (Please keep comments spoiler free!)**I refuse to call him "Tobias" except when referring to the differences in his personality.
summary: 4 Stars - Controversial Ending to the Series

reviewText: I won't give away any of the story lines, although if you have read other reviews, you know enough not to waste your money on buying this book! Again, I have to confess that I am much older than the target audience. Because I don't have any children, I also don't know WHAT kids like.  But I read the first two books of the trilogy; I liked the first one and was disappointed with the second one. This third one was terrible. Insurgent started to get stranger and more improbable as each page was turned; the actions of the protagonists were more and more stupid and inexplicable. The inexplicableness and stupidity of the characters' actions rapidly progressed exponentially in this third, and hopefully last, novel of the trilogy. I don't think that even 12 year olds would be able to swallow the incredible stupidity of what the main characters did in this book. Imagine a 16 year old going to the White House, and the head of the NSA recruits this 16 year old stranger into the higher echelons of the most secret programs. Come on!! The worst things for me were: 1) There really was no true character development of the main characters. You never get to really know them, why they acted as they did. You would get a one sentence glimpse into their past, and then it was dropped. 2) There were huge numbers of dangling threads that were never tied up or explained-instead, some intriguing thing would occur, and then it was totally ignored and never explained. 3) The main characters decided to do the most stupid things in answer to some problem-it was always a split second decision, with no analysis. 4) The romance between the two main characters was as boring as could be!! That is a BAD thing!! This author is newly married, so you would think she would have some idea of passion and love! If her marriage is as boring as the romance in this book, there is little hope for it. Now, I know that this is written for a young audience, so no one wants to read pornography. However, these 2 characters have NO chemistry at all. Snooze....Overall, my recommendation is for anyone thinking of paying real money for this book-instead, go to the reviews and read Penny's review. Her review is much more exciting than this book was. Penny also gives a synopsis of the novel, so you can know what happens. Then save your money, save your peace of mind, save some anger and frustration while still knowing what happens, and then find a good book to read.
summary: You will be VERY disappointed to have spent money on this book!

reviewText: This was probably the best Divergent book! I loved the different points of view and the big reveal of what was lying outside of Chicago. And the ending, SPOILER ALERT!! when Tris sacrifices herself for Caleb... wow. It was SO sweet and showed the true meanings of bravery and selflessness. It taught great lessons, and it was sad and hopeful all at once.

Oh man. Ohhh man. I read Allegiant the week after it came out; but I've been stalling on this review up until now.The reason why is simple: because I've invested so much love in the Divergent series, and, like a parent whose kid brings home a less than satisfactory report card, I'm not angry with Veronica Roth after finishing it. Just disappointed.I guess it's worth noting that a common trend in dystopian YA trilogies is a significant dip in quality from the first book to the second; and again from the second to the third. Even the massive juggernaut that is the Hunger Games trilogy suffers from this problem: if Mockingjay had been the first book in the trilogy, I guarantee you that it would not have become a global phenomenon. And maybe it was stupid of me, but I really, really hoped that Allegiant would be different.I mean, Veronica Roth really seemed to care about her world and her characters. There was such a sureness and a sense of purpose in her writing, like she truly knew what was going on and wasn't just making it all up as she went along. I was so excited for her to pull back the curtain on the warring factions and show us all the corrupted glory behind it - and yet when the time came, she didn't deliver. Not even a little bit. In fact, I can think of literally nothing about this novel that didn't disappoint me in some way.Tris and Tobias' alternating perspectives sounded great in theory, but in execution, it quickly became clear that not only was this not helping the story, it was actually damaging it. Roth's weaknesses were on display as I found myself flipping back to check who was talking every time there was a chapter break - that's how indistinguishable the main character's voices became. As for the rest of the characters; well, the less said about them, the better - either they fade into the background, meet some undeserved fate, or become completely 2-dimensional.The plot, too, is underwhelming; serving up some heavy-handed allegorical lessons without the gutsy, meaty fun that accompanied the original clash between the five factions. Everything I as a reader believed to be important to the world of the series was systematically stripped away and devalued; and not in an awe-inspiring way. Instead, it just left me feeling confused, sad, and very much alone - rather like the characters who manage to squeak past Roth's merciless death count.The only thing that truly stands out about Allegiant is its ending, and all that served to do was put the entire series in a new, depressing light. Some people might say that what she does is a bold move, but in reality it's just like the rest of the book: unfocused, heavy-handed, and ultimately empty.The sad thing is, the Divergent series used to be my absolute favorite. Now...well, I'm not even sure if I'll see the movie. Sorry, V-Roth, but this effort was subpar at best.

reviewText: The conclusion to Veronica Roth's Divergent series isn't as wonderful and satisfying as the first two books in her series, but it does have it's good points.

First off, while I haven't reviewed them on this site, I've read each of the other books in this series several times over. I adored both of the novels and each of the Four-centric shorts we've had. Allegiant, however, left me feeling a little flat. I'm not somebody that needs a happy ending to enjoy a book. Some of my very favorite novels end with a tragedy, and I honestly feel that, if done well, it usually makes a story better than a pat, happy ending. In this case, though, I think it was to the book's detriment. There were both good and bad parts, and I purposely let this review stew for 24 hours so I could make sure my opinion didn't change as I thought it over. Unfortunately, like most of the reviewers so far, I thought there was more bad than good, but I couldn't bring myself to give it only 1 star when I loved the rest of the series so much.***Spoilers***First, the good.- It started off very well. I thoroughly enjoyed the beginning sections of the book.- I liked the Tris/Caleb arc (at least, until the ending). There was one scene in particular that touched me.- I enjoyed learning more about Tris's parents. Natalie is probably my favorite character at this point.- There was a lovely moment between Tris and her mother.- I liked that the relationship between Tris and Four was realistic. They argued, they forgave each other, neither of them was perfectly right or perfectly wrong, etc. I don't think there's enough of that in YA literature, and it was really good to see Four telling Tris off for the way she was acting. She deserved it, and it was nice that the author didn't try to pretend that the way she was treating him was okay.- It was good to see Peter, one of my favorite characters in the series, attempt to somewhat take responsibility for his actions and do something to change, even if it didn't work.- I appreciated the setting of the epilogue. It was satisfying to see Four finally facing his fears and jumping off the Hancock Building, and if they had to dump Tris's ashes anywhere, that was probably the best place to do it. He really did face his four fears in much more profound ways than by simply revisiting his fear landscape over and over again, but it's hard to love that growth he showed when he still ended up shattered and alone.- There were some interesting ideas about love, forgiveness and sacrifice presented, and I love when a book makes you think a little as well as entertains you.Unfortunately, that was pretty much all of the good. Now for the bad.- The pacing was off, and the flow of the narrative was choppy. I was surprised, because it was a little jarring, compared to the other books.- Characterizations were all over the place. So many of the actions they took in this one didn't feel true to their established characters at all.- As has been mentioned by a ton of other reviewers, Four and Tris have the exact same inner monologue voice. They're indistinguishable from one another.- The new characters introduced in this book were pretty unlikable, even the ones we were supposed to care about. And Caleb was even more despicable in this book than he was in the last one, which is really saying something.- The book was far, far too reliant on the different serums. There should have been much more to the story than just that. Beyond that, a great deal was made of Tris's immunity to them. She even inoculated herself against the death serum, something that nobody in the world had been able to do up until that point. And yet, it was never explained how that was even possible. Why was she was able to do that when nobody else could? What made her special or unique? That answer is never given.- There were several threads that were started and then immediately dropped, going absolutely nowhere. The editor of this series and I have a mutual friend, so I happen to know that she (the editor) was going through a career transition during the final editing process of this book, but I'm really surprised that the book was released in this state, with all of these problems everyone is pointing out. I'd be interested to talk with her and find out why she gave so many of these ideas the green light when they're executed so badly.- There was far too much of the wrong kind of exposition and very little action. Because of this, there wasn't any tension in the story. It felt like 2/3 of the book was filled with one long-winded explanation after another, and yet, somehow, we still didn't get the full backstory.- We didn't get the full backstory! The explanation for the Chicago/Faction experiments that the characters (and readers) were given was proven to be full of holes, lies and half-truths, and yet, it was the only one they ever got. In all of that exposition given, Ms. Roth never bothered to explain the real story, or even why the lies were told in the first place. It was explained away with a character musing that "these kinds of things always have more than one reason behind them." That's not an answer. If the author couldn't even come up with a plausible explanation for how things got to the point that it did, how are we even supposed to take her world seriously?- The two earlier books made a great deal out of Divergence and how unique and special it was. In this book, we learn that Divergence really just means that you're completely normal. That was a total, complete letdown.- Peter's ending actually supported David and the government's point of view. He took the memory serum, wiped himself clean, and in the epilogue, it says that most of his old behaviors returned. If it wasn't his experiences or the way he was raised, if it was just who he was always meant to be, then they were right: his genetics caused his bad behavior. That one sentence right at the end negated the entire premise of the book.- The main characters, our "heroes," did a horrible, horrible thing in order to win, and they brushed it aside like it was nothing. Most of the book was spent moralizing against using the memory serum to wipe people's memories without their consent, essentially erasing them from existence. When they found out that the Bureau was going to use the memory serum on the innocent citizens of Chicago, what was their solution? To use the memory serum on not only the bad guys working at the Bureau, but all of the innocent people working there as well. Four was the only one to object at all, and when he pointed out the hypocrisy of their plan, that doing it made them no better than the people they were trying to stop, his concerns were brushed aside with, "We don't have time to come up with something else, and hey, better them than us!" That was their rationalization. Better them than us. Think about it for a minute. Let's say that one country's government decided to blow another country off the map. The second country found out a day in advance, and decided that instead of trying to fend off the attack or negotiate or something, they would launch an immediate pre-emptive strike, and destroy the first country and all of its innocent citizens instead. Or, to use a real life example, look at the Germans during WWII. Many of them knew about the Nazi concentration camps and what was going on there, and that was their exact reaction: "It's horrible, but it's better than it happens to them than to us." Looking back on it now, they're seen as cowardly or callous monsters. How is that okay? That moral relativism really bothered me. Like, a lot. I can't ever look at the characters the same way again, because it really damaged my view of them. Something that terrible is not okay just because it's the only idea you can come up with. Four was right: in the end, they were no better than the bad guys. How are you supposed to root for characters like that? The author either should have come up with another plan, or shouldn't have spent the entire book talking about how horrible it was to do something like that, right up until having her main characters do it. The fact that we like those characters doesn't make their behavior acceptable. In fact, it makes it worse.- Tobias ends up alone and broken, a shell of the person he once was. Yes, he faced his fears once and for all, but as I said, it's hard to care when he's left struggling just to exist.- The death. As I said, I'm fine with deaths in literature, if they serve a point. This one didn't. Yes, it did bring up some interesting points about love and sacrifice, but those exact same arguments could have been presented by another character's death. Uriah, if Roth was going to kill him anyway, or Caleb or Christina. Instead, Tris sacrifices herself again. Yeah, it's true to her character and it makes sense that she'd do it, but if the author was going to inoculate the character against the death serum, then why shoot her afterward? That was just pointless. She already made her sacrifice when she took Caleb's place, so there was no reason to kill her afterward - especially when it didn't change anything at all. There were still GD rebels waiting to attack. Outside of Chicago, the world was still exactly the same. Tris'd entire death, the sacrifice she made, it was all meaningless. I was left feeling flat and disappointed, just like so many other readers. I honestly feel cheated by it, which surprises me. The hope was completely gone. If Tris's death served a purpose, or if Four died with her or something, I could maybe find a way to be okay with it. But this? No. It was just wrong. It didn't add to the story, it detracted from it.So, all in all, this was a disappointing end to a great series. There were far too many things that needed to be changed for the story to go out on a high note. It was like the massive letdown of reading Mockingjay or Breaking Dawn all over again. It could have been amazing. The author is certainly capable of it. What a shame.
summary: I have mixed thoughts on this one

reviewText: I was a little hesitant coming into this book because I didn't understand why the reviews were so low, for a Veronica Roth book! So I came into it a little sad, thinking that this last one was going to end on a cliffhanger like Requiem or Mockingjay. So I waited and waited, and I just finished the book and you know what? It was amazing.First of all, I love how unpredictable these books are. It's like we learn something important in the first book, and we believe that it's true because Tris and her people do. Then in the second book, we learn that what we thought was true was actually...only half of a truth. So throughout this whole series, I came to realize that people lie a lot and a lot information gets twisted around-they only give us partial truths. Maybe I am not as clever as everyone else who "saw it all coming from the beginning" but there was so much information to absorbed, and it was amazing and crazy and I loved every moment of it!THE FEELS ARE STRONG in this last book-there is so much tension and hatred within the characters, but there were also moments of strong love and forgiveness that I couldn't help but get pulled under by. Veronica Roth is spectacular, and she makes me feel such strong, vivid emotions for these characters as if I knew them in real life. I never once thought "oh these are just made up people, they don't exist" because reading this series from the beginning, there is no way not to get attached to these characters. I cried so much in this book, more than any other book I have read...in my life. I love these characters, and they will always stay with me.The dual narrative was great, and I understood what Veronica Roth meant when she said that Tris' point of view was too narrow for this last book. I like seeing a whole different side of Tobias, he's strong despite his insecurities and I love him now even more than I did in the first two books. It kind of annoyed me when people saw him as whinny in this last book because looking at his background, it was obvious from day 1 that he was never as strong as he made himself to be, and it isn't until he admits his insecurities that he really does become strong.I just wanted to say to those people who gave this book a 1 star review: Have you ever read a one star book? Those are ones that are so bad that you can't even finish them. I get why people are upset, I mean, come on, that ending was like being stabbed in the heart repeatedly, it still hurts even after I closed the book. But it doesn't take away from how amazing this series is as a whole, and it was a complete ending with no unanswered questions. I wish it would have ended differently, I really do because I am still feeling the aftermath of all these feels but damn, this last book was amazing. Don't let other people's opinions cloud your own because I thought Allegiant was a fantastic book, and ended a phenomenal series on a very strong and memorable point.
summary: Do people even know what a 1 star book is like?

reviewText: I really liked the first two books. This book however was incredibly difficult to get through because I was bored out of my mind. It was too slow, too preachy, and scattered. After reading the first two books in the Divergent trilogy, I was kind of on the fence. I didn't dislike the books, in fact I liked them enough to keep reading. I saw the big reveal at the end of the second booking coming from a mile away, but sometimes guessable plots are something we deal with in YA novels, and so I didn't think too much of it. I was not excited for this book, but when I was bored the other night I decided to purchase it. I was SHOCKED at how many bad reviews it had and thought it must be a fluke, so I purchased the book.... (Spoilers past here!)Allegiant starts off with a good feel and set-up. The old way has fallen. Tris and Four are still on the rocks. There is a looming outside world waiting for us. What will we find? Will our heroic couple make it or fall apart?  If we ignore the switch between Tris and Tobias (Which, as other reviewers said, is hard to read because you can barely tell their tones apart, and often I would skip reading WHO was narrating the chapter and find myself confused until they spoke about the other person), this is the best part of the book, in my opinion. It all goes downhill when they actually visit the outside world. The big reveal of the outside world falls short. As a reader, I was amped up and ready for SOMETHING. Instead, much like the characters, we are left with chapters and chapters of limbo. In dialogue, we even get something along the lines of "We haven't really been sure of what to do with you guys and we think you haven't been sure either." That's how the book feels! Limbo. The genetic stuff seems dull, because there is little set up of it. We don't really get to feel the affects of the divide in this outside world, we're just given a glimpse and told it sucks, so we should be behind ending it. As I trudged through the pages, waiting for something exciting to happen, I realize that the reason for the POV shift is because Tris is going to die, but the story is going to continue after her death. And she does and it does. And it's all so BORING.All in all, I feel like this had a lot of potential, but it felt rushed and sloppy. There was action, but not enough world building for us to care about it. I was more excited about the glimpses of what was happening back in Chicago then I was about what was happening around the main characters. If you're like me and you like to finish what you started... Pick it up and read it. Just don't get your hopes up too high.

I read a lot of YA books, and after you read a bunch of them they all start to sound the same.  They follow the same plot and you can sort of see everything that is going to happen.  Whenever a book deviates from that and surprises me I'm usually really happy.  I think that really is impressive on the writers part to break out of the mold and tell a really new story or have a really different perspective.  So, part of me really wants to commend Veronica Roth for breaking out of the mold and for not giving me exactly what I wanted and expected.  But, in truth, there is a reason I keep reading this genre.  I like the happy endings, and I like the break from reality.  I like to see people persevere through difficulties.  At the beginning of the book I felt like Four and Tris' relationship was awkward.  It wasn't the way I remembered it, and I didn't like it.  I did like getting inside Four's head and seeing the difference in how the two of them saw the world.  But, their relationship was sort of weird. reviewText: This last book in the series was disappointing. The sad ending was a downer, but mainly it just wasn't a good story.

First off: Spoilers. There will be lots in here. Well actually, only one, which is really what it all comes down to, and which, I suspect, is going to make this series both notorious and wildly successful for the foreseeable future. And btw, I gave this 2 rather than 1 star because it kept me reading till the disastrous ending, which must mean something. But anyway, about *that* ending:First of all, I don't call the ending disastrous because it's tragic. There are novels with devastating endings built on tragic love stories that I've nevertheless loved - "At Swim, Two Boys" and "As Meat Loves Salt" come immediately to mind. Or in the YA realm: "The Book Thief" or "The Sweet Far Thing" or "The Amber Spyglass." Yet while I loved all of those books, I hated "Allegiant", to the point - two stars not withstanding - where I wish I'd never read it.As a writer, that's something I don't say lightly; in fact I don't think I've ever said it at all, about any book. And the thing is, I don't hate it because Tris died. I get the Christ analogy. I get that sacrificing herself to save everyone she loves is the obvious culmination of being both Abnegation and Dauntless. Thematically it makes perfect sense, and executed differently, it might have made a poignant ending, rather than one that made me wish I could scrape it out of my head. What it killed it for me is that the story wasn't strong enough support the death of the main character, and in so many ways that there really isn't any room for equivocation.To begin with, the plot was riddled with holes. For instance (and ignoring the most ridiculous ones) what good is it going to do to 'reset' this one facility to forget their prejudices and save the memories of another small group of people, when there's no evidence that the rest of the world isn't working on the same prejudiced principles, doing the same thing? None of the kids plotting the insurrection have been any further than the GP facility. What do they really know? And then, who exactly is left in Chicago for the reader to care about, once the main characters have left? If Tobias had been left behind, and was in danger of being reset or killed or whatever, then I could have begun to understand Tris's choice. But condemning him to grief and misery because It's The Right Thing To Do and My Brother's Doing It For the Wrong Reasons? It doesn't wash.Speaking of characters: none of the supporting cast is particularly well fleshed out, and as a result I didn't really care about any of them. The relationship between Tris and Tobias was the reason I kept reading. So take that away, and yes, it feels like a betrayal. In fact I'm guessing this is the root of most of the vitriol over this ending - not that Tris died, per se, but that the reader isn't left with anything redeeming to look to, any bright spot amidst the loss. All we get is a Tobias more broken than he was already, and a society that's miraculously healed within two years of its extremely virulent problems. And that's a pretty paltry offering when you've invested nearly 2000 pages in a love story.I also resented the gap between the gain and the enormity of Tris's sacrifice (never mind that she was doing to one group of people exactly what they'd planned to do to another.) Maybe the future of humanity did depend on 'resetting' the scientists, but if so, the evidence eluded me. It read as if Tris died for the dubious honor of re-educating a building full of bigots, and for the love of her wishy-washy brother who tried to kill her. Why? What about her love for Tobias, and his for her? What about his brokenness, and how much he needed her to be whole? And then, there's a whole world beyond the research complex that she knew nothing about, except by hearsay, and that, therefore, could easily have undone what she died for the next day. It all left me mentally screaming: 'Whyyyyyy?'But the deal-breaker for me comes not in the writer-analysis, but in the mommy-analysis. I have an 11-year-old daughter who is a very precocious reader. And while I generally don't censor what she reads - 'The Book Thief' and 'The Mortal Instruments' and 'Ender's Game' are some recents - I would never give her this book, for the simple reason that the main and most identifiable female character, who is otherwise actually a pretty decent role model for young girls, dies to save someone who really doesn't deserve it. Liberal commie-mommy that I am, I can't bear to propagate the attitude that women's primary value is in giving to others at the expense of themselves. Yes, selflessness is admirable, and necessary if we aren't all going to sink back into the Cosmic Soup. But angsty, dramatic, half-baked heroics? Spare me.
