reviewText: I really enjoyed the first two books in this series. They were interesting and fast paced. This last book is a disappointment.First of all I feel like it was written at a 12 year old level. I understand it is young adult but the writing was so simplified and the vocabulary was so poor that it was difficult to read. The characters were very hollow with none of the depth that the first two books had. A large chunk of the book involves Tris and Four sneaking off to be alone and make out, then they promise not to lie to each other anymore. This happens over and over again.The end of the second book is exciting. Many questions are asked. What is outside the city? How did Chicago become the way it is? Who is Beatrix Prior? The answers given seem to have been thrown together quickly without actually thinking about them. Tris and the gang are welcomed into the Bureau with no questions asked and Tris is even made a jr. council member. After that they just kind of forget about Chicago till the end of the book. Four becomes a terrorist and is caught only to be let free. The guards in the Bureau are horrible as they let Tris and anyone else talk to the prisoners whenever they want with no supervision.Then we have the serums. They have a serum for everything apparently and also an inoculation against them. My that is convenient. Don't forget Tris is immune to them also. Very convenient as well.So at the end of the book we find out that the Bureau is going to reset everyone in Chicago's memory to keep the experiment going. Tris decides this is wrong and that they must stop them. The only way to stop them she decides is to reset their memories. Because that makes perfect sense. Caleb for some reason is chosen to sacrifice his life and risk the dreaded death serum to release the memory reset serum. Then of course Tris doesn't let him do that and she goes off to release the memory serum.So Tris is exposed to the death serum and beats it surviving something no one else can do. How special of her. Mean while Four is off visiting back home for some reason. I really don't understand why Four and the others went back to Chicago is they were planning to stop the memory reset serum to be released in Chicago anyways.So Tris survives the death serum to find David guarding the memory reset serum in his wheelchair with a gun. Good thing for David he had the inoculation for the death serum. Tris releases the memory rest serum on the Bureau and David shoots her.Honestly if you didn't think Tris was going to die at the end of the books you weren't paying attention. The girl had a death wish from the start.The rest of the book is Four being sad about Tris being dead.

This was an incredible journey with these unique people. It was quite a story, and even though sad at parts, very well written. It should be read and thought about because it pertains to all of us in this day of age. It will keep you in the edge of your seat the entire time.

I absolutely adored the first two books in this series. I loved reading the storyline and also appreciated Tris' journey/growth as a character.I was super pumped for this book...I pre-ordered it through amazon and started reading the first day. Instantly, I was turned off. Not only does it keep switching from Tris to Tobias but the tone of each character was EXACTLY the same so I had to keep trying to remember which character this chapter belonged to.Now that they finally escaped the fence, I was really hoping for some meat in the plot but it turned out to be incredibly boring...the government shutting people away to weed out the genetically damaged people and produce genetically pure ones. Blah blah blah. I am so terribly confused by this whole story after that fact came out. Why would they shut them up with no control? Scientifically standing, this makes no sense...you need to have direction and involvement in this sort of program but it seems like it is just a bunch of government people watching the people in the fence all day. Really? If you are talking about genetically pure vs genetically damaged in the sense that the pure people did not have alterations done (blue eyes, blonde hair, etc), this would never work the way it is portrayed in the book. Everyone keeps breeding with everyone and eventually genes will sort themselves out again...but this could be happening inside or outside the fence.Also, the government compound is in...what, O'hare airport? Uh huh...right. And then you have the genetically damaged people living in the outskirts of chicago, again with no oversight. So, again, the damaged genes gets pushed all together, breeding with each other, never truly solving the problem. I am so confused! I felt like there was NO POINT to this entire story now. Nothing got accomplished...especially since this is going on all over the country!Now back to Tris and Tobias; they flat-lined as a couple. Throughout 75% of the book, they were awkward and weird with each other. They either couldn't stop arguing or they would kiss for a moment and say something cheesy before running away from each other. If you are going to throw in a love plot in a book, you need to commit to it so that it works in line with the whole series. This third book left me feeling like Tris and Tobias barely knew one another.Finally, Tris dying. One of the most pointless and unremarkable deaths I have read in a long time (this third book is on par with Twilight writing). She, of course, steps in to release the memory serum and she beats the death serum but ultimately is killed by the government's leader (in a wheelchair). And then, nothing happens. Vision going black, oh, I see my mom, time to die. There was no time taken to expand or revolt against what happens to Tris. Her brother was right there...plus all of her friends had been sneaking around for days getting things set up and no one is around to help or kill David or something.Another thing, all this security and no one notices all these kids whispering in broom closets with maps and whatever else...I wanted to beat my head against the wall.And Tobias's mother...after YEARS and YEARS of trying to become who she eventually became, she just gives it up in a less than 2 minute conversation. Willy nilly, no big deal. Easy peasy man. Let me just put down my gun cause my son wants me to and I will give it all up. Definitely not the same woman in book 2.This book seemed really rushed...not only rushed but a panicked rushed. 'I gotta write this third book to finish the series which has taken off...movies being made...' The author fell so far short of finishing this series well that I am surprised the book even has three stars.As I was reading, I would find myself looking for anything else to do beside read it...first time that has ever happened. I will finish anything but this was almost painful to keep reading. I was so disappointed. I hope they have some fan fiction come out for this series so I can read one of those endings instead to satisfy me.Boo, two thumbs down.Summary; book felt like it was written in a panicked, rushed state of mind. It was a disappointing and painful way to end the series. I really hope they take a second look when they decide to do this book in the movies.

This was just okay as the last entry in the Divergent series. The formula got a little predictable by this point. Adding the viewpoint of Tobias was okay but it ultimately did not breathe new life into the formula. LOved the ending, however.

The pacing of the novel is really weird. Sometimes it seems like its going really slow, and that you’re learning a lot about what is going on, but nothing is really happening. Then all of a sudden, things seriously sped up and ended. So the pacing of the novel was incredibly awkward. I thought maybe the book could have been longer, or that the slower parts could be shorter and the action part longer. It seemed sort of weirdly balanced. Once the action started, it was so easy to finish the book, but the build up took a very long time.The Good:That all being said though, I really loved this book. I don’t want to spoil anything because the book just came out a few days ago, and I don’t want to ruin it for anyone. I want to tell everyone what I think without ruining it for those who have not been able to read it yet, or who are catching up on the other books.I loved the direction that Veronica Roth took it in. The end of Insurgent leaves hanging with the idea of an outside world, that needs the Divergent. Which is so different than the city that Tris lives in, where the Divergent are hunted down. But when we finally see the outside world, its so different than what I had ever expected. What we learn and find out is incredible. Confusing, but incredible and it really explains so many plot holes that exist in the previous two books.I really liked the back and forth between Tris and Four. I feel like, its kind of become a habit for authors to do this dual point of view thing, especially for final books. It would normally kind of make me mad because of the repetitiveness but I really liked it. The only thing we’ve gotten of Four in the previous books is Tris’s own vision of him. Getting into his head, seeing his motives, his love for Tris, his fears, his hopes, all of that, really helps to carry the story. They clash all the time, and they both have such different fears and different backgrounds and it motivates their actions in different ways, and its also the way they come together.Some people had an issue with the end, and what happens there, and I’m going to try and say my thing without spoiling anything. I was immensely heartbroken by what happened at the end. It was incredibly unexpected and it ripped me to pieces. I spent a lot of time crying, which clouded up my glasses quite nicely. I think it makes the most sense, and that the way in which the events unfold seem so likely to me. In fact, before they unfolded, I was surprised at the direction that Veronica was taking the characters in. When things changed, and ended the way they did, it just made sense to me. The decisions that were made by the different characters just seemed to fit for each of them, and the ending was a full circle for the story. I think that Veronica took leaps and risks that some authors don’t do but I think it played out nicely for her.I’ve also not cried this hard with a book since I read the epilogue of Clockwork Princess.I don’t want to spoil much, because there is too much in this book to spoil for anyone but I loved it. I didn’t think it was perfect, because the pacing is just so weird, but I thought it was a beautiful, unexpected ending. People die, lives change, and I cried like crazy. Somehow my favorite character (I hope I never told you who that is…) survives but other characters that I love die. I think that there’s so much to learn and to still contemplate about their world and what could and will happen to everything and everyone. Its a beautiful book and I think Veronica leaves us with the same sort of bittersweet ending that JK Rowling leaves us with in Deathly Hallows.If you want a spoiler discussion, you can read it on my blog whatanerdgirlsays.com
reviewerName: What A Nerd Girl Says "Book Blogger"

reviewText: After completely loving the first and second books in this series, I felt like Allegiant fell flat in so many areas. From the beginning, I was struggling to feel the connection. I thought Tris really came together within this book though. The strength and confidence within herself consistently grew through this series, and it continued to do so. With all the build up, I expected something huge to go down, but it never really did. And the ending? I don't even want to talk about it.

Veronica Roth has lately achieved the almost success and popularity as Suzanne Collins.  If you’re unfamiliar with her work – you may be soon!  Divergent the movie is set to release in March.  I came across Divergent almost by accident after reading the Hunger Games trilogy and really enjoyed it but somehow lost track as each new book was being released so when I saw that Allegiant was out I put in on hold at the library and proceeded to wait about three months for it to come in.  This is the third book in the Divergent trilogy.Tris is once again imprisoned in the Erudite building awaiting her fate and contemplating the video released by Tobias (Four) at the end of the last book.  Tobias’s mother Evelyn the Factionless leader has taken over the city.  She forces everyone in the city to live as if they are factionless, gone are the clothing and traits that identify each faction; every person in the city must wear more than one color they must intermingle in their living quarters.  There is a contingent of rebels that wants to maintain factions however.  The factionless and faction rebels have several small skirmishes culminating in a large one at the over the bowls used at the Choosing Ceremony.  When the fight ends in death Tris accepts an invitation to a meeting of the rebel group.  In the meantime Tobias tell her that her brother Caleb has been sentenced to be executed in two weeks.  While unable to get beyond her brother’s betrayal that lead to her own near execution when she decides to leave the city with a group of rebels taking Caleb along is her one condition.Tris and a group of her friends escape the city losing Tori, to be found by someone Tobias thought was dead his former initiate instructor Amar.  They are taken to headquarters of the Bureau of Genetic Welfare at the former O’Hare airport, confirming for the reader that Tris’s city was indeed Chicago, just in case you weren’t sure because sometimes books like this take place in fictional places that just have similarities to our world.  At the Bureau they are told that the cities were an experiment.  Their goal is to get Divergent people, people with pure genes.This story moves fairly fast considering how long it is, and while I enjoyed it there were almost too many twists and turns for me.  The end shocked me, I never saw it coming.  Maybe I should have; I’m sure other readers did but not me.  It is a realistic ending though not entirely happy, such is life.  I’d honestly be curious to see an update of this world a few years later, or a companion book from another city/experiment similar to Scott Westerfield’s Extras after her Uglies trilogy, another great futuristic yet in the real world set of books.  There you go, three sets of books to read if you like this genre, and three more sets of books that get kids and adults alike to learn to love reading just for fun: the Hunger Games trilogy, the Divergent trilogy, and the Uglies set.

So I'll stick with being a weirdo of the 3rd order but I must ponder these thoughts as is required my lot in life.

reviewText: I absolutely loved this series! I'm usually a romance junkie. Don't be afraid to venture out for this series. It's worth it. You won't regret this read.

There may be mild, implied spoilers.  I am not sure if I would have given this book five stars had it not been for all the horrible one star reviews that this book does NOT deserve.Ok, the negatives first.This book has a different pace, tone, voice ( I don't know what exactly to call it ) than the other two books; not so much that it seems out of place but it is enough that when reading them together without a time gap that it is noticeable.  There is quite a lot of character death in this series which can be incredibly depressing.  Tris continually comes across as way more "right" than a sixteen year old girl should be.Now on to the positives.Typical books aimed at this demographic are horribly unrealistic and usually follow the exact same plot line over and over again.  They are written in such a way that the main character is supposed to be completely average in every single way yet somehow manages to steal the hearts of everyone with two of the most handsome men to ever grace this planet fight over her.  The girl is generally incapable of making the "wrong" choice.  Take Twilight for example:  The girl falls in love with her stalker who would like to eat her, lets another boy that she doesn't love take care of her while she is pretty much suicidal over the loss of the man who wants to eat her, then chooses an immortal life in which she doesn't have to give up her family, friends, the ability to have a child, or even have to suffer the desire to eat everyone who still possesses a heart beat.  Seriously, there are absolutely no consequences for her actions and that is how this genre tends to work.  I really do not think it is a good idea to keep filling teenage girls heads with that.  In this book Tris has to actually work at her relationship with Tobias.  They have issues and they fight but they also have to approach things in a mature way and work things out.  It isn't some fake soul mate crap that sets girls up for failure.  It is completely believable.  There are constant consequences for their actions.  News flash people, in real life there are good and bad things that happen based off of your actions and nonactions.  I love that both are addressed in this series.  I love that this series doesn't make it out like every person has to lead a poor sap on in order to determine if the girl actually loves the first guy or not.  I love that Tris went through a phase where she was putting herself in unnecessary danger and then she actually matures enough to realize that sometimes trudging into a situation head first is the wrong call.  We watch a girl actually grow up and not just get her way.  I really love that.

When I visited Amazon to purchase this last book in the Divergent series, I was surprised to see that the number of 1 star ratings was nearly equal to the number of 5 star ratings. I didn't read reviews because I didn't want the spoilers, but I did see that many people were disappointed regarding the ending. But I bought it anyways because I had been hooked on the series and I wanted to know what was coming next.*****SPOILER ALERT******Now I'm no fan of sad endings. When I read the end of  "My Sister's Keeper," I literally threw the book across the room- I was that mad. That ending seemed to be pointless- and Hollywood must have recognized that since they changed it for the movie.(Now I have a Kindle and cannot throw books across the room- one shortcoming of digitized reading material!)Anyways....I had loved the first two installments of the series, reading each in a matter of hours. When I wasn't reading, I was thinking about the story line and wondering what was coming next.Allegiant uses a dual narrative and I sometimes had to back up to the beginning of a chapter to see whose voice I was reading. Not because the narratives were that similar, but because they were discussing people or scenarios that they were both familiar with.One review said the narrative of Tobias made him sound like a "15 year old girl." I disagree. Tobias had always represented strength to Tris and to the readers. It was interesting to see that he was much more vulnerable then he had previously portrayed himself to be.Tris comes into her own in Allegiant. I suspected that she was much more cunning and insightful than in previous situations and it seems the character begins to trust herself and became much more confident. All three of her possible faction choices come in to play regarding her decisions which I thought was a nice touch.The genetic component seemed to me to be an substitute for race. That's what I took away from it. I mean seriously, how different is "genetically pure" from "racially pure?"  They're basically one and the same. Especially when you find out that those who are "genetically damaged" are treated much differently than those who are "genetically pure." The GD receive harsher penalties for crimes and little or no government assistance.The ending did not surprise me. I felt that Tris had been leading us to a point where she would ultimately sacrifice herself for the greater good. That was her journey.Some readers thought hers to be a pointless sacrifice. I disagree. From her childhood in Abnegation, she had been taught about sacrifice. That lesson remained with her as she rejected that faction and essentially tried to develop herself into a person who valued self over anything else.At the end it seems she embraces her truth, that she believed in self-sacrifice. When she was about to die in "Insurgent," her inner monologue screams that she doesn't want to die. At the end of Allegiant though, she recognizes that her death is necessary and she welcomes it.In summation, I loved this series. The death of the lead character was extremely sad but was also fitting. Tris had led the reader on this journey to the very end. Her death did have meaning and it changed everything- the epilogue proves that.Tris displayed a character trait, deep empathy, that I wish a lot of real people had. Tris felt for those who struggled and did what she could, and had to do, to make her world a better place.Not every story has a "happily ever after" ending, especially in reality. I think this is why most readers crave that from literature. We want black and white, every plot and sub-plot tied up with a neat little bow. We want that because it rarely happens in real life. I myself also love it when stories end that way.But this series could not deliver that package. If it had, it would not have been so poignant. If it had, some one out there would be bound to complain anyways.I have recommended this series to all of my friends. I would, and probably will, read all three books again.

reviewText: Contains SpoilersI just finished this, and even knowing and being prepared for the ending I am angry.  I read Ms. Roth's statement about why before reading the book and went into it wanting to know what led to this finale... Was it at least a good story leading up to the devastating ending.  The answer to that is yes, it was a good story and the motivation behind Tris' sacrifice was clear.  She really did come full circle and the author does a good job showing her growth and maturity.  However, the ending just didn't serve any purpose.  Yes, we get she couldn't let Caleb die, yes she followed in her parents footsteps, but what was the point?  Especially after she survived the death serum, found out David did indeed love her mother, and then only to be shot?!?!  I mean come on, how lame can you get?? So many other things could have happened and she picked the worst and lamest way to go.  If she didn't want to go for shock value then she shouldn't have included all the tear jerkers either... Looking into Tobias' eyes, planning a future together, finally having a reason to want to live through the good, bad, and ugly.  Knowing the ending definitely made me more aware of these lines and it was just an attempt to go straight to the heartstrings.. These attempt would not be needed if she were just going for a powerful ending, and as a result ended up coming across as trite.There was so much potential for a wonderful novel and I wanted to love it... Would have loved it if she had gone virtually any other way then she did.  And this is not simply because I'm upset the heroine died, but it was trite, superficial, and either the author wanted shock value or else just wanted a reason to never have to write about this story again.  As President Snow said in the Hunger Games as long as there is hope that is all someone needs to have a spark.  Well, all hope was dashed completely and buried in the ground. Do not know if I have ever been more dissappointed in a book before.

I found the fluctuating point of view writing mechanic confusing and tedious.That said, the pace picked up when our heroes make it to the Bureau.  I actually enjoyed the sociology related to this flawed society, a society that chose a simplistic rationale as a reason for impossibly difficult societal ills.  Some things  I liked, some I didn't.  That is how my view of the book came up as, "It's okay," or 3 stars.Based on the reviews i have read, a lot of folks are really unhappy with the ending.  I hate spoilers so I won't provide any here.  However, those of you who are angry, remember that Tris was raised Abnegation.  Her earliest teachings were from that venue.  She idolized her parents for their selflessness even as she chose Dauntless as her faction.  Tobias too carries those early teachings in his psyche and those teachings were a force in each of their choices.I can't second guess the author, but I think Ms. Roth was demonstrating that upbringing and teachings, rather than genetic structure, are critical in any discussion of choices and behavior.  Science has llong questioned whether background or genetics is the primary motivating factor. We, as humans are shaped by both genetics and society.  I didn't feel the anger.  Tris did what her parents would have done, and was at peace with that decision.

reviewText: I love a good story, but after the first, Divergent, the next two in the series paled in comparison.  Allegiant was "okay."

Although this, the third and final book of the trilogy, did indeed tie up the majority of the "loose ends", it was distracting for me to have the chapters bounce back and forth between the two main characters.  That always makes it difficult to remember who the "I" is when I'm in the grips of the story itself.  Other than that ... and I understand why she did it .... it was another great book, and twisted really well before closing.

I didn't hate this book, as many other reviewers did.  It was by far the weakest of the series (including the short stories), but there were parts I liked.  It also had some of the same "I can't stop reading" feel that the others had.  However, it left me with a tremendous feeling of loss, and I didn't personally gain enough from it to make up for that, so I'd suggest thinking twice before reading it.In particular, if you love Tobias, and especially if you love the relationship between him and Tris, please let yourself be happy with the first two books, the short stories, and fan-fiction.  Let your imagination fill in the rest to give them the ending you feel they deserve.  You won't get enough new romance out of this book to make up for what it will do to you.Also, if you only kind of liked the first two books, save your money and skip this one.  It's not as good.The rest of you might want to read it, despite its flaws.  It does wrap up the story, and the ending is powerful -- not pleasant, but powerful.  To help you decide, here's a summary of what works and what doesn't...What works:1. You learn more about Tris' mother.  It's not as interesting as it should be, but it's there.2. You find out what happened to some characters who were mentioned earlier but not shown.3. You get the story on the world around Chicago, why they're there, and how they came to be.4. There are some good scenes.  I didn't find any of them exciting enough to bookmark the first time through, but I did go back and re-read four scenes after finishing the book, and I've found myself thinking about some of the others.5. It explores concepts you don't often see in YA books -- remorse, change, death, healing, and everyday forms of courage.  In particular, though the end is crushingly sad, you realize that some of the characters improved each others' lives permanently and changed the world around them for the better, and that this effect doesn't go away when they die.  Basically, their lives and relationships were worthwhile, even if much too short.What doesn't work:1. The book lacks emotion.  "Divergent" and "Insurgent" have a lot of feeling, both stated and implied.  There are many scenes in those books that I re-read repeatedly, just savoring the feel of them.  This book has very, very little of that, and what it does have isn't as good.  The only feeling that's deep is grief, which is overwhelming at the end, but honestly, most of that grief is because you love the characters from how they were in the earlier books, not for what you saw in this book.2. The narration never finds its groove and doesn't sound like it did in earlier stories.  Tris's sentence structure is suddenly short, with no "poetry" to the words, and Tobias/Four doesn't sound at all like he did in the short stories.  Also, they sound so much like each other that I kept forgetting whose POV I was reading.3. Most of the other characters disappear or die without any further development.  They have very few lines, and some of them (including some important ones) literally die without ever speaking a new word.4. The whole faction concept, with all of its interesting elements, basically just goes away.5. The characters are under-developed.  Personally, I thought there were subtle clues in the earlier books about some of them, and I expected to see Roth pick up on those clues the way JK Rowling always did, but absolutely none of them came back that way.  As an example, Tori got through Jeanine's defenses, implying she was Divergent, yet we saw her kill an Abnegation leader during the simulation, implying she wasn't.  I thought we'd learn more about her, but she doesn't speak a single word in this book.  I expected some big reveals about Caleb and Peter, but that didn't happen either.  Uriah, one of the more interesting side characters, says almost nothing.  The same goes with Evelyn, and the relationship between her and Natalie Prior, and Marcus, and really all of them -- those clues are all left as loose strings.6. The plot is simplistic and full of holes.  The earlier two books had a lot of action and unexpected twists and turns.  This one doesn't.* Warning: The rest of this review contains major spoilers. *To me, the biggest disappointment with Tris wasn't her death.  That was actually the most in-character part of the book.  What frustrated me was how she got there.  She finds out that people are going to wipe memories, and she immediately plans to wipe their memories instead, without even trying to think of any other solutions?  She doesn't offer to go into the city and fix things another way to avoid the need for the reset (you know, like her mother did)?  She doesn't try using her influence on David to get him to see another perspective?  She doesn't kidnap him and take him into the city?  She doesn't use the memory wipe serum directly on him?  No, she jumps straight to the idea of setting off the serum en masse.  And then, after she decides that, she can only think of one way to get it?  She doesn't try to figure out the passcode, even though Tobias is great with computers and even though David was obsessed with her mother and maybe used her name as a passcode?  She doesn't consider attacking the group that's taking the serum to the plane - you know, releasing the serum by shooting the container it's in?  Instead, she just states that it's a suicide mission and lets her brother agree to die for it.  It's so glaringly out of character that I assumed Roth was going to have a bunch of other things happen to change this course of action, but she didn't.Also, I have to ask... after everything Tobias has been through in his life, how could that be the ending that Roth felt he deserved?  Tris was the only bright spot in his very dark life, and he lost her.  She accepted her fate and was glad to go to her mother, so I don't feel as bad for her, but it just feels blatantly unfair to Tobias.  What was the point of doing that to him?  To me, it ruined the idea of this as a romance book.
summary: If you love Tris and Tobias, think twice before reading this book

reviewText: Let me start off by saying, I loved Divergent. It was unique, intense, introduced great characters, and had phenomenal world building. Insurgent was really good, but I felt like it was missing the spark that was Divergent. I don't know what was missing. I speculated that it was Tris and Four - their relationship was this amazing building block in Divergent and had become not necessarily an obstacle but they weren't always beside one another. Insurgent pushed the envelope in terms of their relationship, in many ways putting them at odds and making you miss what they had. It's probably why I'd give Insurgent 4 stars and Divergent 5 stars.So, with high hopes I purchased a copy of Allegiant. There's something about trilogies and lately I feel like they're hit or misses. The author has created this grand story, with characters you've invested in emotionally. Unlike a single book on its own, you read it for a few days or a week, put it down and are done. Series have a way of capturing you long term. You read the first book. You fall for the characters, the story, the plot and pacing. You become a part of the adventure. Each book is like unlocking a secret into a world you want to know more about. You're given only pieces of the story in the series and it's the final book that you expect answers, and in many cases hope for a happy ending.The first part of this review for Allegiant will be spoiler free. I will have a warning for when I explain the details of my rating.I commend Roth for taking a chance with using both Tris and Four's voice for alternating chapters. It was something the readers looked forward to. I feared it and will explain why beneath where spoilers are below.I felt the pacing in Allegiant was off. I read it, I turned the page, I put the book down. I read Divergent in three days. It took me ten days to read Allegiant. At least one, if not two of those nights I deliberately chose not to read the book. I needed a break from it. There wasn't enough action and when it was integrated into the plot, it didn't flow like Divergent had. Maybe I remember Divergent different then it was. Maybe I've put the book high on a pedestal and Allegiant could never compare. Personally, I don't think that's the case. I just felt bored by the story. I also felt some of the explanations (Divergent and what it means) ruined the series for me. The pieces of the puzzle (Divergent & Insurgent) when put together and given a full explanation consisted of disappointment (Allegiant).SPOILERS BELOWSo here's the thing. I've read other trilogies lately, Dystopian and felt the endings fell flat. For example, Lauren Oliver's Requiem (Delirium 3). I loved the first two books in her series. The third book felt like a cop out. She has a love triangle with two guys and doesn't give us an actual ending. It's the final book. We want everything spelled out for us, happy ending and all, including what happens to everyone. No such luck. I loved Mockingjay's ending for The Hunger Games. I know there are others out there that hated it but of all the dystopian endings lately, that has been the best I've read. The  I suppose it's how it's done, unraveling the story and still keeping certain elements alive.Here's my issue with Allegiant. It wasn't just a sad ending. It felt like part of it was unnecessary. Tris risks her life, knowing she is doing it to save her brother that betrayed her. I read the reasoning, I understand it. I can even accept that she went in to do the mission. Okay. She struggled but survived. What I thought sucked, yes this is how I felt, was that after everything she got shot. I'd have rather her died from the poison. I felt like being shot was so blah. Like - this is how she died? She's this big, bad ass chick that we've fallen in love with and she's dead from a friggin' bullet. Maybe I expect too much. If she's going to die, it should be bigger, bolder.Okay next, Tris and Four's point of view. I loved the idea that we'd finally feel and experience things from Four's perspective. I was a little nervous though. If only for the fact that let's face it - in first person point of view - the person telling the story can't die. If they're telling the story, they make it to the end, they're safe. (Unless you're reading a diary style novel). Now the author brings in Four's POV. The initial fan reaction was YAY! I felt that too, until I realized it means, Tris is very much at risk for dying. Could Tobias/Four be killed off? Sure, but then it would have remained in Tris' point of view. So, from the beginning I knew the basic fact for the ending. Plus, with the fan reaction of OMG horrible ending, it was quick to realize that it was probably fact. All that aside, my actual opinion on the point of view switch is that the intent was good, the execution fell flat to me. The chapters didn't feel different upon reading them. I also didn't feel like Four was the character we met in Divergent. The toughness to him had melted away, and not in an enjoyable way. I half-wonder if the books issues are a result of the movie being constructed. Authors have a character in their head. Then when the movie is being produced, seeing a new version of a character (and with a director that may have a different vision than what you had), it's possible your own perception shifts while writing the novel. It may be something you don't even notice doing, or perhaps I just felt like Tobias was out of character in his dialogue and thoughts.Why do I feel this way? For example we learn what Divergent actually means. Tobias gets super emotional over it. Don't get me wrong, the initial shock would probably bother most people. Dauntless are taught to be tough. Tobias has been strong in the first two novels. To see him come so easily undone by people that you don't know, truths you're told that you wonder if they're actually real, it was a mess to me. Which leads to..Too much of the book focused on Genetically Pure and Genetically Damaged. The whole meaning of Divergent, the cool aspect of what these people were disappeared. The spark that had been created in the first book, fizzled out. For example, online we choose factions based on the books. It's fun, it's a way to connect with readers, and it's also a way to show what we think of ourselves. Veronica Roth did amazing in creating these factions. The factions themselves, the initial idea was smart. Readers connected with it. I felt the unfolding of it in Allegiant wasn't done well. Maybe it was the explanation itself that I didn't like. It all being an experiment, Divergent's are Genetically Pure and everyone else is Genetically Damaged. Too much of the book focused on this and it was something that I understood, but didn't connect with. When reading it on my Kindle - I noticed that at 80% the story kicked up a notch. I felt like we finally had the action that I'd been missing. Veronica Roth writes action well. I missed it in Allegiant.Would I recommend Allegiant? If you've read, Divergent, then you're likely going to want to finish the series and know what happens to the characters. Will I read another book by Veronica Roth? Honestly, I don't know. I don't like investing in characters and not liking the final book. It doesn't need to be a best seller, but I do need to feel like my time wasn't wasted and that the author cares about the characters too. That aside, I'm not a fan of unhappy endings, unless I'm reading a Contemporary novel (stand-alone, not a series). I think if you're investing in the time it takes to read a series, then readers are going to expect an ending they want for the characters they love. Otherwise, you're taking a chance at antagonizing the audience. Just my 2 cents.
summary: The pieces of the puzzle (Divergent & Insurgent) when put together consisted of disappointment (Allegiant)

reviewText: This book was amazing and so is its author! The end through me for a loop... not gonna tell you what it is though!!!

I read Divergent this summer and then finished Insurgent last week. Thought both were good, possibly great, depending on this vital, third book.Oh boy.I'm not going to go into spoilers, but I will say that the only reason I'm giving this book two stars instead of one is because I'll give the author some props for having the guts to do the ending she wanted to do.The only problem is that the ending didn't really fit with the characters she had portrayed the rest of the series. Tris and Four had been set up to be unique characters, but then when Roth uses both as first-person POV in this book instead of just Tris, it weakens the characters instead of strengthening them. In a way, she painted herself into a corner by going first-person in Divergent instead of third person, but it didn't work in this book.There were plot holes. It seems as though ANY authority figure is automatically corrupt, but most can change their ways with a simple speech. Every guard is pathetic and can't watch the person they are supposed to guard. Tris becomes an infallible source of information (far different than in Insurgent) and Four becomes weak and fragile.By the time I was halfway through, I was trudging through, just plodding along to finish and the ending just confirmed the rating for me.

Yes, I'm fully going to spoil it.This story took me on such a wild and hazed out experience that I couldn't perceive what Ms. Roth's point of writing it was.  Honestly, I feel that she just cranked it out since her first one is being turned into a movie.  Reminds me of Michael Chrichton's sequel to Jurassic Park (oh, 'hey, it became a movie so I'd better spit out a quick sequel, even if it totally sucks!').And killing off Tris and then dragging the reader through Four's grief was totally not okay.  Really, if I'd known that unnecessary death would be the major emphasis for this book's ending (and really the whole series) I would never have bothered with it in the first place.  I have to add that a lot of my disgust stems from the TOTAL lack of closure or even the need for Tris' death in the first place.  (I'll add Will, Uriah, Tory, Natalie Prior to that as well.)And, really, killing off the young girl who's blossoming into our strong heroine - is that what Ms. Roth wants young girls to be left with???  That young ladies who aspire to greater things, who struggle to grow into better humans, who become brave and self-sacrificing - should let themselves be done away with?  That's really disconcerting.Also:  Why bother bringing up how good a leader Four could be and then he does nothing of the sort?  At the end, we find him as an assistant - assistant?!?! - to Johanna who's now in some governmental position.  Whaaaaaat....All I'm left with is a total sense of disillusionment and I am disgusted with the ending.  Save your reading time for something better; say The 5th Wave, Stung or Chanur's Saga.  Don't waste your time on this one.Edited 01/09/14A few things that have been nagging me since I posted this review:One:  Uriah's demise is completely glossed over.  For the whole second book (Insurgent) we are dragged on and on and on and on over Will's death.  But come this third book and, oh, you know, it's only Uriah; he is killed off and forgotten in about six pages.  Wow.  It completely fails the character that Ms. Roth built to become Uriah.  Oh, let's vilify Tris and give her depression over Will, but have Tobias say 'oh, sorry' and dismiss his actions that lead to Uriah's death.  How hypocritical on the author's part!Second:  What in the world are Divergent/Dauntless doing using flashlights while on a clandestine mission to exit the city at night???  Um, we're talking about Four, Tory, Uriah and Tris, who've all moved around in the dark previous to this without lights.  What gives?  Oh, wait - it's an easy way to kill off characters!  Of course!  I totally thought that we were getting a real story - my bad.  Hey, want to get rid of Tory?  Have her use a flashlight in the dark when she's approaching the fence, knowing that the Factionless all have weapons and that Evelyn doesn't want anyone to leave.  Bang, bang!  Okay, that character is taken care of!  That was really, really, REALLY hard to buy into.  I think it was actually easier for me to buy into Tris' death than Tory's.Third:  Since the Bureau can 'see all' in the city and clearly has easy access to all the data in the city, I found it very implausible that they could be indicted for having come up with the 'simulation serum' and then passing it onto Jeannine Matthews.  They could just as easily copied the formula from her equations and duplicated it themselves.  So how does a vial of it in a filing cabinet in some back room storage PROVE that they gave it to Jeannine???Again, save yourself; read the 5th Wave instead.  Sooooo much better.

The 3rd book in the Divergent Series is equally as good as the first two.  This one seemed to have more twist and turns than the first two. It kept you guessing right to the end. This was a wonderful series.

The saccharine romance which never took off.  Felt as if Tris and what's-his-face were brother and sister (albeit inappropriately CLOSE siblings) Don't waste your time with this series.  The movie is bound to be better than the book.

reviewText: The people who have complained about the final book in this series were expecting a storybook ending, I think, rather than a realistic one. I thought this book wrapped up the series very well!

Miss Roth has clued us in, seeing as she sent Tris to her death before, but I, personally, never believed that she would go to "that area" of writing. But let me just say, it was not a happy ending, with Tobias dying as well in the end, and they meet up in Heaven and live happily ever after the end. Oh no, he's alive, heartbroken, most likely to never love again. Yay! Not.Divergent was amazing and fresh. A new idea, a new discovery for the ages, something I expected to end up being a classic.I was severely disappointed in Insurgent. Tris was very bland, afraid, and nave. But yet, I truly liked the book because it answered somethings key to the story's plot.Allegiant was the worst mistake ever. Tris AND Tobias's POV? Ok, Tris is dead. But let's just say I thought optimistically and had a spark of hope that Tris would be fine as fresh pie. And, and let's not forget that the way the book is devised just plainly, well... sucks. It is monotone, bleak, and if not for the captions that say Tris or Tobias then I would be like: ooh! Tris's POV! Wait... no... It's Tobias...Let's not forget how it all ends:"Be brave."Even if Tris did die and Tobias survived, the ending could have been more assertive and powerful, filled with meaning and inspiration.

[...]I've come to the conclusion that there's something about dystopian trilogies that inevitably lead to the same conclusion: The existing government is overthrown by the rebel-led insurrection, but something always is amiss. Maybe it's just me, but the finales for a lot of dystopian trilogies tend to fall flat (Ally Condie's "Matched" series comes to mind here), and leave you feeling a little disappointed at how an exciting beginning can end almost lifelessly. "Allegiant", the third and final book to Veronica Roth's riveting "Divergent" trilogy, left me feeling that way, bringing what could've been an unputdownable series to close.The world as Tris knows it has disappeared. The factions have been abolished, fractured by betrayal and violence and replaced instead by a new, problematic society led by Tobias' mother, Evelyn. So when she is offered a chance to explore the world beyond the fence, a world in which she and Tobias can find a simple new life together, Tris is more than ready to go. But when she discovers that her new reality is even more disturbing than the one she's left behind, with secrets that force her to examine her loyalties and discoveries that change the hearts of those she loves. Once again, Tris must fight to comprehend the complexities of human nature--and of herself--while facing impossible choices of courage, allegiance, sacrifice, and love.I know my introductory paragraph up there hardly left any room for optimism, but trust me when I say that "Allegiant" isn't a crappy book. In fact, Tris and Tobias' character developments were interesting to read about as the book progressed, especially since it is the final book in the trilogy, which means that they will soon reach the crux of their character journeys before the last page. Tris, to me, is an awesome heroine. Not only is she a brave, butt-kicking and stubborn protagonist, but she is also compassionate and thoughtful, which, I guess, is the whole point of her role as a Divergent: Tris is an amalgamation of all these different characteristics which make each and every one of us human, from erudition, dauntlessness, abnegation, candor and amity (see what I did there). Watching her as she deals with conflicting problems and new, life-changing discoveries, as well as with her relationships with her family, friends, and Tobias, reveals the huge amount of change she's gone through since the beginning of the series. Tris is, without a doubt, a great heroine you can't help but become invested in and root for from the start, and I'd even go so far as to say one that you can look up to as a sort of role model.The same, unfortunately, can't really be said about Tobias. If Tris is the epitome of a teenaged heroine, then Tobias is more of a gritty, 'real' character, with possibly more faults than admirable traits. I understand that growing up, Tobias had to deal with a butt ton of issues that left a lot of emotional, mental and physical scars, but there were times when I just felt like he was kind of annoying. This might be because of the comparison between his perspective and Tris', since the chapters alternated between their two points of view. There was definitely a sort of emotional journey that he goes through, what with his mother and abusive father and Tris and so on, but I still felt like he ended up as a character I lost interest in. On the other hand, he and Tris were generally pretty sweet as a couple, with a strong and believable dynamic between them that allowed them to mature both individually and as a pair. I just wish Tobias himself was a little more likable and strong as a character, especially since he was pretty great in the first two books!The real disappointment I felt toward "Allegiant" was about its plot. It seemed as if the real action was over in the second book, and "Allegiant" just dragged it on for the sake of having a third book in the trilogy. Like I said before, the storyline is pretty generic for a dystopian finale, where there are post-insurrection problems that make the characters realize that everything is not as they seem. The pace was pretty plodding throughout the entire novel, and there wasn't much of a climax either. In a way, it's kind of like the storyline meanders this way and that, and never skyrocketed in tension or excitement. This may be due to the fact that Ms. Roth was trying to tie up all of the loose ends from previous books, in terms of Tobias' family and Tris' struggles with Caleb and being Divergent, but it ultimately fell flat.All in all, "Allegiant" is a pretty disappointing finale to what had been an exciting and refreshing dystopian trilogy. It's unfortunate to see such great world-building, strong characters and riveting storylines decline to a dull end, as much as I (really, really, really!) don't want to say it.Rating: 2/5

reviewText: Veronica Roth completes her Divergent Trilogy with a shocking, well plotted, consistent, rather long installment that has Tris and Tobias venturing out of the only world they have known and being awakened to what is really going on.  Ms. Roth, as has been true for the previous two installments in this (rightfully so) best-selling Young Adult series, pulls no punches and gives the reader no reason to expect the future to be much different from the world inhabited at present.  There is much good around each of us, an equaling amount of cause for alarm and each person must make choices that will lead them onto paths that will define the next choice offered them.After the “purging” that ended the Insurgent section of the series, the Factions are disbanded, leadership is returning to the tyrannical practices “of the previous administration,” and everyone, it seems, are living with rules that are shadowy and constantly in flux.  Tris, having been branded a traitor because of her actions in the insurrection, must face questioning, after been given Truth Serum, to determine her fate. As a result of her being “divergent,” she is able to withstand the effects of the serum and is given a sentence that gives her to opportunity to escape and fulfill Edith Prior’s directive of “helping us outside the fence.”  Tobias, son of the new leader of the City, surrenders his position to join the Allegiant, a group who want to overthrow the present regime and return to life as it was and also to escape to the world beyond the boundaries of the only reality he has ever known.Similar to Plato’s cave analogy, what this group (of six, including our heroes) discovers when they arrive at their destination is a shock, discovering that what they “knew” to be true was but a illusion meant to keep them entertained until they discovered they were only looking at shadows.  This is but the first incident of being confronted with truth that was not True.  With each new revelation, each person must assess the information, choose what to believe and take action.  There are changes that must be made and difficult selections to face by all.  Late in the book Tobias gives definition to the trilogy, “Sometimes, all it takes to save people from a terrible fate is one person willing to do something about it” (p.438).The story is a bit draggy for the first third to half of its length (better editing would have improved the book tremendously) but once it starts rolling, the reader is often left breathless in an effort to keep pace with its cadence. There is harsh language that is surprising for younger readers, and occasional “romantic” moments that are warm, but never cross into “hot.” Told from the alternate, first person perspectives of Tris and Tobias, the book proffers the reader viewpoints that are often at odds but whose tension is the foundational element of the series.  In order to understand the majority of this book, the reader must have read the previous two volumes in the trilogy.Ms. Roth is brave in her ending the trilogy as she did.  It would have been just as easy to have all the heroes walking in a world that is clean, orderly and without conflict. To have done so would have been to lessen the impact of the trilogy.  It has been honest, offering a realistic assessment of the world, demanding in its assessment that not all good choices end with the reward expected or merited but that does not make the choice any less needed or correct.  Difficult conflict will occur and be resolved; life will offer new conflicts just as difficult tomorrow.  Living requires that we: work hard, laugh, make connections, watch those connections be suddenly severed, go make new relationships just as vital, rise each morning with the knowledge that“Life damages us, everyone. We can’t escape that damage.But now, I am also learning this: We can be mended. We mend each other” (p. 526).

reviewText: When went into this book, I knew about all the bad reviews, but I didn't know why. Something terrible must have happened to have angered so many fans. I had just reread Divergent and Insurgent before reading Allegiant, so the details of the previous books were still fresh in my mind. As I was rereading, I noticed so many hints as to what could possibly happen in the final book. In an interview, Veronica Roth stated she had the ending planned out since Divergent. It was not a last minute decision. She had this planned out, and there were plenty of indications in the last two books. Yes, the ending was truly heartbreaking. I wish it had a happier conclusion. Emotions were rolling through me. It still pains me to think about it. I would not say Allegiant was my favorite of the three. Divergent is my favorite, but the ending did not stop me from enjoying Allegiant. There were things that I liked and things I didn't like. For one thing, I wish there was more distinction between Tris and Tobias's perspectives. I would pick up where I left off reading and think I'm reading Tris's pov when it's actually Four's. There were heart wrenching scenes, and beautiful ones. In fact, Roth left us a little hopeful message at the very end. We cannot just dismiss her skills as a writer for an ending we did not want. Veronica wrote a beautiful story. Tragic, yet beautiful.
summary: I understand why the bad reviews, but I still enjoyed it.

reviewText: I am a bibliophile and truly appreciate not just a good story, but a beautiful one. A story that is not only well written, creatively original, and full of deep personalities, not just characters, but that also teaches lessons. That is where a story is granted its power, in its ability to teach powerful life truths.This series, and this book in particular, encompass all of that. I am not just rating a book here, I am rating a story, and this one is right up there with Les Miserables, A Tale of Two Cities, The Lord of the Rings, Dracula, and the Hunchback of Notre Dame. It is an amazing piece of literature, and deserves to be read.

This book was not was I was expecting for the conclusion of this series. Up until this point the series had been primarily focused on Tris, her life her choices. In this book it did both her point of view and Tobias point of view.Tris was a unique character within the series. She had her good points and her bad. She mostly was caught in still defining herself as the faction in which she had been raised, however from getting to know her I believe her test should have placed her in four factions. I know it states her results were of three factions but she really falls under Candor to in my opinion because she tells it how it is and mostly thinks of herself when speaking. When she is thinking thoughts she’s more Abnegation. Her curiosity falls under Erudite and her thrill seeking is Dauntless.Back to this book wasn’t what I was expecting. The ending took me by surprise even though it had been spoiled by a few friends, it wasn’t how I had seen the book playing out. In fact it was very far from it.I am not sure I agree with how everything played out and what became of the characters. But I am sure that it is a well written series and I’d gladly read it again and again.I look forward to reading the rest of the mini stories to this series as well as future writings by Ms. Roth.
